1 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Africa's Gradual Rise to Olympic Prominence


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996


LENGTH: 1855 words


 

Dakar, Senegal - Africa's participation in the Olympics started with South Africa in the 1908 London games, in Britain. Egypt joined that country as Africa's second representative in the 1928 event.

From 1908 to 1924 South Africa, represented only by its European population, performed well. It gained a medal in the 100-metre London competition in 1908. 

Four years later in Stokholm, South Africa won the marathon and Ruud Lewis, of the same country, claimed victory in the individual cycling competition.

South African faired even better in 1920 in Antwerp, Belgium. It won gold medals in the men's 4,400-metre, 4x100-metre relay, rowing and boxing.

With much less success in the 1924 Paris Games, the South Africans only won a medal in boxing. At the 1928 Amsterdam Games, the South Africans fared as well as the Egyptians.

In the 110-metre hurdles South Africa's Sydney Atkinson was magnificent as was the Egyptian weightlifter, Sayedd Nosseir, who earned his country's first Olympic medal.

While the two countries remained Africa's only representatives until sub-Saharan countries began to gain independence, mostly in the early 1960s, South Africa performed better than Egypt.

The vast majority of African countries began participating in the Olympics from this period. The best years for Africa were 1968 in Mexico, 1988 in Seoul, Korea, and 1992 in Barcelona, Spain, where Kenyan runners creamed medals.

Africans were expected to do well before Barcelona were it not for the near-absolute boycott of the 1980 Montreal Games and partial participation in the games at Moscow in 1980, Los Angeles in 1984 and Seoul in 1988.

Of the 149 medals (47 gold, 48 silver and 54 bronze) won by African countries more than the half were gained in athletics, mostly in track.

Ethiopia's marathon runner, Abebe Bikila, put the stamp on his country's first Olympic appearance of the 60's in Rome, Italy.

Bikila gained sub-Sahara Africa's first Olympic medal, winning the marathon, in Constantine, Italy. It was here, 30 years earlier, that Italy's first dictator, Benito Mussolini, decided to invade Ethiopia.

Bikila's success was the harbinger of other outstanding African Olympians.

Four years later, he repeated his achievement in Tokyo, Japan, where South Africa was banned from the Olympic movement because of its racially discriminatory policy of apartheid.

African athletes reached their pinnacle at the 1968 Mexico games. Kenya's Kipchoge Keino won the 1,500-metre gold. Nine of 16 African medals, three of them gold, were won by Kenyans.

Tunisia solidified Africa's lead when Mohamed Gammoudi won the 5,000-metre gold. This came after he won a Certificate of Merit in the mid-long distance event four years earlier.

In the 1972 Munich Olympics, African athletes equalled their 16-medals haul of Mexico. The stars, this time, were the Ugandan 400-metre hurdler, John Akii Bua, and Keino, who took the gold in the 3,000-metre steeple chase.

However, Africa progress stopped with the boycott of the 1976 Montreal Games. Only Cote D'Ivoire and Senegal participated. They refused to abide by the call for the boycott made by African countries, in protest against the participation of New Zealand which had relations with apartheid South Africa.

Four years later in Moscow some 20 African countries, among them Kenya, the driving force of African athletics, followed a U.S.-led boycott in protest against the Soviet Union's war in Afghanistan.

Ethiopia, then a close ally of the Soviet Union, took part in the games. Mirus Yfter won gold medals in the 5,000-metre and 10,000-metre races. These games were the first in which Africa won a medal in a collective event: Zimbabwean women's field hockey team.

In a tit-for-tat, the Soviets refused to take park in the 1984 Los Angeles Games supported, also, by few African countries.

However, those African states which participated won 13 medals, three of them gold. Kenya won just one gold medal, courtesy of Julius Korir in the 3,000-metre steeple chase. That was Kenya's poorest performance since 1968.

Morocco won two gold medals with Said Aouita in the men's 5,000-metre in 13 minutes, 21 seconds and Nawal El Moutawakil on the women's 400-metre hurdles in 54.61 seconds, the first individual victory of an African woman.

In the country's first Olympic winning, Gabriel Tiacoh of Cote D'Ivoire got the 400-metre men's gold while Zambia and Algeria won medals in boxing.

Ethiopia was the only African nation to boycott the 1988 Seoul Games. The Kenyans bounced back from their slump with four gold medals won by Paul Ereng in the 800-metres, Peter Rono in the 1,500-metres, John Ngugi in the 5,000-metres and Julius Kariuki in the 3,000-metre steeple chase. The late Rober Wangila won gold in boxing.

Africa's other gold was won by Moulay Brahim Boutayeb, 21, of Morocco. Virtually unknown before the competition, he upset Kenya, the 10,000-metre favourites.

Like Cote D'Ivoire four years earlier, Senegal gained its first Olympic medal when hurdler El Hadji Amadou Dia Ba won the silver, ahead of America's Edwin Moses, in the 400-metre hurdles. Africa won 14 medals in Seoul.

In 1992, in Barcelona, where virtually all of Africa was represented, women athletes stole the show. Hassiba Boulmerka became Algeria's first Olympic gold medalist. She won the 1,500-metre event. Ethiopia's Derartu Tulu was winner of 10,000-metre in an epic duel with Elena Meyer, the most talented representative and symbol of the post-apartheid South Africa. That country was reintegrated into the Olympic fold after 28 years of isolation.

Kenyan athletes performed less well than usual. They carried away two gold medals won by William Tanui in the 800-metre event and by Matthew Birir in the 3,000-metre steeple chase. Kenya lost the 10,000-metre to Morocco's Khalid Skah and accused the Moroccans of unfairly helping each other.

In its maiden Olympic appearance, Namibia's Frankie Fredericks won silver medals in the 100-metre and 200-metre races.

In soccer, Ghana became the first African team to finish among the top three, winning the bronze.

In all, Barcelona marked Africa's best Olympic performance. The continent hauled 25 medals: five gold, 13 silver, seven bronze.

Now, all eyes are on Atlanta.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Nigerian Stock Market All-Share Index Down


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996 by Paul Okolo, PANA Correspondent


Lagos, Nigeria - Trading slowed at the Nigerian stock market last week, amid cautious moves by investors. Although the all-share index rose by 14.4 points in the week ending on June 21, compared to 28.72 points gained in the previous week, brokers attributed the cautious trend to uncertain signals from the oil marketing sector. Recent trading results showed declining earnings and rising inventories, the analysts said. The volume and value of shares also dipped in comparison to the previous week's performance. Traded shares totalled 11.4 million, down from 11.7 million in the week before, while value fell to 100.9 million naira from 124.6 million naira (1 U.S. dollar = 81 naira). The number of deals, however, rose to 1,187 from 929 in the week in review. Most shares traded on the Lagos floor were in the banking sector, where some 1.9 million shares worth 9.7 million naira changed hands in 170 deals. The automobile sector, with 6.3 million shares valued at 80.2 million naira in 19 deals, were traded in the week in review. Price movements were moderated by the cautious pricing of oil marketing equities following a recent disappointing first quarter result by Mobil. The sector, usually the toast of the Nigerian market, witnessed few gains in the week. Nigerian Bottling Company, gained the most, adding 77 kobo to close at 22.00 naira (1 naira = 100 kobo). TEXACO and Lever Brothers followed with 51 kobo and 45 kobo respectively. TEXACO finished at 20.66 naira while Lever Brothers ended at 22.25 naira. West African Portland Cement and ATT were adjusted for the payment of dividend and bonus shares in the week just ended. They shed 8.20 naira and 5.89 naira respectively to close at 23.30 naira and 8.11 naira. Wema Bank lost 50 kobo to 5.50 naira because of brokers' reaction to a recent robbery in one of its branches involving 36 million naira. But United Bank for Africa and Nigerian Breweries slid due to their excess shares flooding the market. The bank fell by 20 kobo to 5.65 naira, while the troubled brewer ended at 15.20 naira.


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Ashanti Gold Fields Regains Lost Grounds


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Accra, Ghana - The Ashanti Goldfields Campany of Ghana bounced back on the stock exchange Monday, regaining the 2,000 cedis it lost last Friday, to close at 31,000 cedis.

The AGC's gain helped to propel the Ghana Stock Exchange All-Share index up by 4.98 points to 362.95 points, from Friday's close of 357.97 points. 

Analysts said the company's loss on Friday, which came only a few days after it presented its quarterly report, was due to a slip in the world market price of gold.

Total shares traded at Monday's session slumped in volume terms to 135,750. Offers stood at 890,480 while bids were 288,100. All equities maintained their last prices except AGC, Social Security Bank (SSB) and Unilever.

Total market capitalisation appreciated slightly from last week's 3,022.80 billion cedis.

On the broader market, AGC gained 2,000 cedis to close at 31,000 cedis, while SSB gained five cedis at 865 cedis. Unilever lost one cedi at 829 cedis.

All equities except CFAO, Fan Milk Limited, Ghana Commercial Bank, Guinness Ghana Limited, and UTC-Estates, had negative pressures on their prices as supply exceded demand.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Kwacha Continues To Depreciate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Dakar, Senegal - The Zambian kwacha has continued to depreciate, selling Tuesday at 1,325 for one U.S. dollar, from some 1,259 previously. Officials attribute the decline to decreased foreign currency inflows and uncertainty triggered by the current political crisis in the country. 

Financial analysts said Tuesday in Lusaka that limited proceeds from copper, the country's major foreigner exchange earner, had also contributed to the scarcity of foreign currencies on the local market.

However the CFA franc, used in 13 French-speaking African countries, remained fairly stable this week, opening Tuesday at the nominal rate of 519.3 to the dollar.

In Dakar, the currency exchanged at 504 (buying) and 534 (selling) to one greenback. On the same day last week, the currency exchanged at the rate of 505 (buying) and 521 (selling).


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Donors Pledge $420 Million (USD) For African Bank


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Abidjan, Cote D'Ivoire - Donor countries have pledged some 420 million additional funds for the replenishment of the African Development Fund, the soft loan affiliate of the African Development Bank.

The bank said Tuesday, at its Abidjan headquarters in Cote D'Ivoire, that the amount was promised by 16 of the 24 non-African shareholders of the bank when they met Friday in Osaka, Japan. 

In May, shareholders of the bank approved 2.6 billion dollars for the long-delayed replenishment of the fund, the major source of investment funds for 39 of its 53 African members.

The new pledges brings to some three billion dollars, the amount available for onlending to these countries through 1998.

The countries reaffirmed their continued commitment to mobilise concessionary loans to needy African countries through the bank, which recently undertook wide-ranging reforms to make it more attractive in the international investment finance markets.

They also expressed strong support for the bank's President, Omar Kabbaj of Morocco. He assumed office in September 1995.

The bank said Brazil, Canada, China, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Korea, Norway, Portugal, Saudi Arabia, Sweden, Switzerland, Spain, United Kingdom and host, Japan, were represented at the meeting.

Meanwhile, two international credit rating agencies, Fitch and Moody, have confirmed their "A" ratings for the African Bank.By its New York Headquaters, Fitch scored a "AAA" for the ADB's senior debt and "AA Plus" for its subordinated debt.

Moody gave an "Aaa" for the senior and an "Aa1" for subordinated debt in ratings announced in May. The bank was set up by African governments in 1963, to look for funds for the continent's economic and social development. Its aggregate resources currently stand at over 33 billion dollars.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996

6 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Former Nigerian Military Ruler Avoids Politics


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lagos, Nigeria - Former Nigerian military ruler Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, who stepped down in August 1993, has ruled himself out of his country's politics.

Babangida cancelled Nigeria's June 1993 presidential election, plunging his country into political turmoil, which lingers on. 

"I have no interest to go into politics or be lured into it," he said in a rare interview with journalists at his home in Minna, northern Nigeria Monday.

Babangida, whose eight-year rule ended in an aborted Third Republic after he annulled the presidential poll, dismissed as baseless press reports that he wanted to float a political party.

"I have already had my time," he said, adding that he had chosen to be "a good citizen of the country."

"I will continue to pray and encourage the current efforts of the present government towards successful transition to civilian rule," he said.

Babangida has remained out of the limelight since he stepped aside Aug. 26, 1993.

A lame duck interim civilian administration he installed after annulling the presidential election suddenly resigned Nov. 17, 1993. It was replaced by the current military regime of Gen. Sani Abacha.

Abacha, a key figure in the Babangida regime, is implementing a 36-month transition to democracy program expected to end in October 1998.

The Abacha regime has come under intense international pressure over Nigeria's troubled march to democracy and a poor human rights record.

Politician Moshood Abiola, who claimed victory in the presidential election cancelled by Babangida, is in detention awaiting trial for treasonable felony after he defiantly declared himself president in June 1994.

Brushing aside local and international appeals for his release, Abacha has insisted that Abiola's trial will go ahead.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria More Nigerian Political Detainees Freed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lagos, Nigeria - The Nigerian military administration has released four more detained opposition members, raising the number to six in the last three days, pro-democracy groups said in Lagos Tuesday.

Fred Eno, personal assistant to detained politician Moshood Abiola, was among those freed Monday, according to his family. 

He was detained in August 1994 shortly after the beginning of Abiola's treason trial, for proclaiming himself president.

Also released were two leaders of the banned National Association of Nigerian Students, Hilary Ojukwu and Charles Titiloye.

Civil rights activist Mathew Popoola has also regained his freedom.

Freed earlier were Abdul Oroh of the Civil Liberties Organisation and Tunji Abayomi, lawyer to former Nigerian military ruler, Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo.

Obasanjo is serving term along with 39 others implicated in a 1995 coup plot.

The release of two other detainees, Chima Ubani and Nosa Igiebor, editor of the weekly "Tell" magazine has not been confirmed.

Meanwhile, presidential adviser Awalu Yadudu has dismissed the suggestion that the release had anything to do with ongoing London talks between Nigeria and the Commonwealth. The organisation suspended Nigeria last November over alleged human rights abuses.

Yadudu said the latest Nigerian move was in response to the "reconciliatary" approach by the United Nations, which recently sent a fact-finding mission to Nigeria.

The U.N. mission's report recommended political and judicial reforms in Nigeria, but refrained from calling for more sanctions against the country.

It said the Abacha regime's 36-month transition to democracy program, criticised by opposition, seemed genuine.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Benin New Court Set Up In Benin


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996 by Ali Idrissou Toure, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Cotonou, Benin - Benin has created a "high court of justice" to "judge the president of the republic and members of the government in case of high treason and contempt of the parliament," national television reported Monday. It said the move was in keeping with the December 1990 constitution. The court will comprise six members of the the constitutional court, six members of parliament and the president of the supreme court. The decision on whether or not to bring the president to court will be decided by a two-thirds majority in parliament. Once indicted, the president, or any other officer before the court, will be suspended from office. They will, if convicted, be fired. The court will not be fulltime and will meet only to hear cases.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambia Says It Won't Be On SADC Agenda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Harare, Zimbabwe - Zambian said Friday it will not allow the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Security Summit scheduled for Friday in Botswana to specifically discuss rising political tension in Zambia.

Foreign Minister Christon Tembo also told the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency, ZIANA, in Harare, that Zambian President Frederick Chiluba would not attend the summit called by SADC chairman, Ketumile Masire, after a series of recent bomb blasts blamed on supporters of former President Kenneth Kaunda rocked Lusaka.

Kaunda and his supporters are protesting new constitutional amendments effectively barring the former president from contesting in presidential elections scheduled for October. 

"You don't put other countries on the agenda," he said, responding to questions after delivering a letter from Chiluba and discussing with President Robert Mugabe for over an hour.

"It will be a SADC meeting but not specifically on Zambia," he said.

The 12-member SADC recommended in January the setting up of a body to monitor the security situation in Southern Africa and the Botswana summit on Friday will implement the plan with the situation in Zambia, seen as potentially explosive, being the first case.

However, the Zambian government, facing mounting criticism at home and abroad, is reluctant to have the SADC Organ on Politics, Defence and Security interfere with its internal problems. Therefore, Zambia has mounted a diplomatic offensive to head off this possibility.

Tembo, who was accompanied by former foreign minister Vernon Mwaanga, also ruled out the possibility of the on-coming Yaounde summit of the Organisation of African Unity discussing Zambia's political problems.

Because of prior engagements, Tembo said, Chiluba would not attend the SADC security summit.

"But he will be well-represented," Mwaanga, founder-member of the ruling Movementy for Multiparty Democracy, said.

The MMD ousted Kaunda in the first pluralist elections in decades held in 1992.

Mwaanga was forced to resign as foreign minister after he was implicated in a drug scandal.

The Zambian delegation is also expected to visit Botswana Tuesday where the SADC Secretariat officially announced the summit to be held at the Botswana National Productivity Centre.

"The SADC leaders will also review developments in the region and internationally, with particular emphasis on matters relating to politics, defence and security in Southern Africa," the secretariat said.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


Swaziland Swazi Schools Reopen But Teachers Stay Out Of Classrooms


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996 by Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Mbabane, Swaziland - Schoolchildren in Swaziland flocked back to classes Tuesday as schools re-opened after a 10-day closure, but some teachers sent them home saying they were waiting union notification that their strike was over.

The teachers, along with the country's civil servants whose association executive decided to strike as from Friday, are demanding an 18 percent salary increase. The government has offered 9.9 percent, in line with the infation rate, plus about 4 percent in allowances. The Industrial Court ordered Monday the Swaziland National Association of Teachers and the civil servants to restrain, immediately, from their strike. The court said the action violated their collective agreements with government. 

Following the court's instruction, Education Minister Solomon Dlamini announced Monday the reopening of schools.

Although a survey Tuesday showed most schools in the capital Mbabane and surrounding districts reported back to normal, children arriving at several schools in the capital and in the city of Manzini were reported to have been sent home by their teachers. They say they will not teach until officially informed by their asociation executive.

The association's deputy secretary general, Musa Dlamini, told PANA that the teachers' class boycott would not be lifted by the association's executive until a mandate was received from the teachers at a mass meeting. This, he said, would be called only after Friday, when the association has been ordered to appear before the Industrial Court to show cause why the court order should not be made final.

Thousands of boarding students are travelling long distances back to their schools and may be stranded if they find the doors still closed.

"We can only keep our fingers crossed and hope the government is aware of this possibility," Dlamini said.

He was referring to demonstrations last week by members of the unofficial Swaziland Association of Students and Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions. These bodies were demanding that schools be reopened despite the strike.

Dlamini said the teachers had nothing to do with either of those organizations, which appear to be exploiting the teachers' strike for their own ends.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


Sudan and Egypt Presidents Meeting Positive In Mending Relations


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Khartoum, Sudan - Sudan's foreign affairs minister, Ali Osman Mohamed Tahq, said Tuesday that the meeting between the presidents of his country and Egypt, during the recent Arab Summit in Cairo, was a decisive turn for the better in the relations between the two states.

Reporting to the National Assembly, he said both leaders had reaffirmed their desire "to bypass the era of tension and conflict (and move) to an era of cooperation and concord that realizes the interests of the two sides." 

Egypt and Sudan have been at loggerheads for years over a number of issues. The most grave of these has been Egypt's accusation that Sudan harbours Muslim militants trying to depose Mubarak's government.

Tension escalated in June 1995 when Mubarak accused Khartoum of being behind the attempt to kill him when he arrived in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, to attend a summit of the Organization of African Unity.

Omar Hassan El Bashir, the Sudanese leader, attended the Arab summit last week convened in Egypt. His lengthy meeting with Mubarak ended in an agreement for the extradition of criminals, news reports said.

Tahq said he expected the meetings between security and political officials of the two countries to be held in the near future. This would be a follow up to the security agreement and an opportunity to improve bilateral relations.

"It is hoped that the coming days will witness bilateral meetings at the level of security and political and other executive organs in the two countries to discuss and tackle matters in keeping with the spirit of rapproachement and cooperativeness that dominated the meeting of the two presidents," he said.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Southern Africa South African Residence For Southern Africans


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996 by Lionel Williams, PANA Corresopondent


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Johannesburg, South Africa - South Africa is paving the way for thousands of other Southern Africans to obtain permanent residence in the country.

The South African Department of Home Affairs said Monday that up to one million nationals of other Southern African Development Community states could qualify for permanent residence in the country. This follows a recent cabinet decision.

The department estimates there could be up to four million illegal immigrants in South Africa.

Home Affairs Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi has invited illegal immigrants from Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe -- SADC members states -- to make official applications for residence. In order to qualify for permanent residence, the applicants will have to meet four criteria. They must prove continous residence in South Africa since July 1st 1991, be engaged in productive formal or informal economic activity, have dependant children born or residing lawfully in South Africa, and have no crimical records.

The home affairs spokesman said that applications for permanent residence would be accepted at any South African home affairs office between July 1 and Sept. 30 this year.

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Troops To Ensure Peaceful Elections in Kwazulu-Natal


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 25, 1996 by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Johannesburg, South Africa - A large number of police and defense force troops have been deployed throughout South Africa's troubled Kwazulu-Natal province in readiness for Wednesday's local government elections.

The combined force of more than 25,000 -- with another 5,000 on standby -- will make an all-out effort to ensure that the recent drop in political violence continues, as close to four-million people cast their votes at some 3,300 polling booths throughout the province. 

Provincial police spokesman Bala Naidoo is confident. "All indications are that we are heading for a peaceful election," he said. "Things are looking good, and we hope they stay that way."

He added that every single polling booth would be manned by policemen, and that no weapons of any description would be allowed into polling areas.

Tuesday was quiet after campaigning had officially ended at midnight Monday. According to South African law, no political party is allowed to campaign on the day before an election.

The two main players, the Inkatha Freedom Party and the African National Congress, closed their campaigns Monday in a spirit of peace and goodwill.

IFP leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi said: "This is a time for torelance and reconcialation. It is a time for us to hope that at long last we are leaving this vale of misery."

He added: "The future is now in your hands."

ANC leader Nelson Mandela said: "I will do anything the provincial leaders want me to in order to bring about peace."

He warned: "We are being laughed at by others... we are very backward and barbaric, killing one another instead of sitting down to talk about our problems."

Violence from the two sides has over the last few years left hundreds dead.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


14 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Uganda Uganda Holds Parliamentary Elections


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 26, 1996 by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Kampala, Uganda - Ugandans are to vote Thursday in legislative elections to choose members of parliament for 214 constituencies throughout the country.

A day before the polls, the interim electoral commission organising the elections declared 18 candidates unopposed. 

Among the 18 were prime minister Kintu Musoke and six ministers whose opponents either withdrew or were technically disqualified from the race.

President Yoweri Museveni, the incumbent, on May 9 won the presidential elections with 75.5 of the vote.

Meanwhile, on Tuesday, the country's disabled persons elected their five representatives to the next parliament at polls held Tuesday at Seeta near Kampala.

Among the representatives was a blind female teacher, Baba Diri Margaret and a deaf, Alex Ndeezi, a social science student from Makerere University. They were chosen by an electoral college of disabled people.

Four of those elected will represent the four regions of Uganda and one will represent disabled women.

The disableds' electoral college was composed of 156 voters from the 39 districts of Uganda. There were four delegates from each district. The college comprised 36 blind people, 37 deaf and 78 physically handicapped people.

It was the first time, since independence in 1962, that Uganda organised elections for the disabled.

Uganda last held parliamentary elections in 1980. The results of the Commonwealth-observed polls were widely disputed by the contesting parties, including Museveni's Uganda People's Movement (UPM).

Museveni went to the bush to wage a five-year guerilla war, which eventually led to the overthrow of the military government


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Problems in South Africa's Kwazulu-Natal Elections


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 26, 1996 by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Johannesburg, South Africa - The first democratic local government elections in South Africa's Kwazulu-Natal province encountered a variety of problems from the moment they took off Wednesday.

Polling stations in the cities were opened on time but reports from various rural areas said there were delays there. 

The election helpline was also besieged by callers complaining that their names were not on the voters' roll.

There were also reports of intimidation and some violence. A polling station at Umlazi, near Durban, was forced to close following allegations of intimidation.

Scuffles between supporters of the two main parties -- the Inkatha Freedom Party and the African National Congress -- were reported at some stations.

Up to four million voters were expected to have cast their ballots at 3,300 polling booths throughout the province by the close of voting Wednesday night.

A combined defence and police task force of almost 25,000 was deployed throughout the province to ensure free and peaceful polling.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

16 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


United States and Africa U.S. Appoints New Ambassador to Zambia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 27, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka, Zambia - The United States president, Bill Clinton, has nominated Arlene Render, a career diplomat, as new ambassador to Zambia.

She will take over from Roland Kuchel.

A statement from the U.S. embassy in Lusaka said Wednesday that Render currently directs the Office of Central African Affairs at the U.S. Department of State. She had previously served as ambassador to Gambia and as deputy chief of mission in Ghana and Congo. She has also worked in Cote d'Ivoire, Jamaica, Italy and Iran. Testifying in favour of her nomination before the Senate Africa Sub-Committee in Washington on June 20, Render said that if confirmed she planned to work hard to "encourage" Zambia in its current democratization process and advance United States interests in the country. Her appointment still has to be confirmed by the U.S. senate. Render told the committee that recent actions by the Zambian government threatened to seriously damage the electoral process and weaken the country's new democracy. She was referring to the current problems created by the adoption by President Frederick Chiluba's government of a new constitution that bars citizens with parents born outside Zambia from contesting this year's presidential elections. 

The United States early this month demanded an immediate withdrawal of the disputed citizenship clause in the constitution and threatened to withhold bilateral aid if this was not done.

Senator Nancy Kassebaum, who chaired the June 20 senate sub-committee hearing, used the occasion to question the Zambian government's commitment to democracy.

She was quoted as saying that it was "a real sorrow" and "a disappointment" to see the recent anti-democractic development in Zambia which, she said, had the potential for great wealth.

The United States had earlier held Zambia as "a model of democracy in Africa."

Other donors have threatened to withold aid if the Zambian government does not reverse the constitutional changes barring first generation Zambians from contesting presidential election.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

June, 1996


Africa-at-Large African Leaders In Accra For Investment Forum


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 27, 1996


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Accra, Ghana - Three African heads of state arrived in Accra on Wednesday to participate in the international conference on private investment in Africa, which opened on Monday.

They are Presidents Sam Nujoma of Namibia, Alpha Oumar Konare of Mali and Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. 

Also in the country for the conference is the First Deputy President of South Africa, Thabo Mbeki. All the heads of state were met on arrival by a welcoming party led by President Jerry Rawlings.

The heads of state and Mbeki were presented with bouquets by 10 year-old Victoria Ntow and eight year-old Candada Assuman, after which libation was poured by a traditional chief, Nii Noi Agebeti II of Osu Wulomo, in typical Ghanaian and African tradition.

The three-day forum was convened by the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa, based in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. It provides a platform for African governments to highlight current economic policies and investment opportunities in their respective countries.

According to the program, the heads of state will launch a forum on African capital markets and participate in a round-table summit.

The leaders will also share their vision for Africa and reiterate the need for the revival of private investment on the continent.

A panel of leading international and prominent African business people will engage the heads of state in a dialogue on policies and opportunities for new ventures on the African continent, officials said.

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Commonwealth Ministers Suspend Sanctions On Nigeria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 27, 1996 by Nasir Mahmoud, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LONDON - After meeting for two days with a Nigerian government delegation, the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group has decided to suspend its recommendation for sanctions on Nigeria, the News Agency of Nigeria reported Tuesday.

The chairman of the group, Zimbabwean Foreign Minister Stanley Mudenge, said in a press conference Tuesday that the meeting with the Nigerians was fruitful, the agency reported. 

Therefore, Mudenge said, the group has decided to "hold in reserve" the measures it had agreed to take against Nigeria.

In April this year the group recommended that Commonwealth member nations should, in addition to other measures like visa restriction, cut-off airlinks with Nigeria and freeze the personal assets of members of the Nigerian military government.

Mudenge, who read the communique on behalf of the participants, said that both parties "agreed that the constructive dialogue which had taken place needed to be continued."

He said that the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group had raised issues of concern to the Commonwealth with the 17-man Nigerian delegation and, in turn, had had received a briefing on developments in Nigeria since November, when the country was suspended from the association.

Mudenge said that the the ministerial group was impressed with the issues raised by the delegation and that the group would think about them before the next meeting, on date yet to be fixed.

Nigeria's foreign affairs minister, Tom Ikimi, said that the dialogue had "broken the impasse" between Nigeria and the Commonwealth.

However, he said, Canada had disagreed with the suspension of punishment for Nigeria, instead insisting on implementing the measures recommended by the group in April.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambian Court Condemns Police Harassment


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 27, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 694 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Hearing began Thursday in Lusaka of an appeal against the continued detention of eight Zambian opposition party members for treason, with High Court Judge Peter Chitengi condemning the police for harassing their sympathisers outside the courtroom.

As the trial against senior members of former President Kenneth Kaunda's United national Independence Party (UNIP) got underway, defence lawyer Patrick Mvunga claimed the police had beaten up people and that some had to be taken to hospital for treatment.

Mvunga said it was wrong for the police to beat up UNIP cadres while the treason trial was taking place, as if the court building was a barracks or military camp. 

Over 500 policemen were deployed at the court.

"This may be an embarrassment to the defence lawyers that these acts are taking place within the courts buildings. It is important that senior policemen who appreciate law and order are invested in maintaining order," Mvunga said.

So, Chitengi ordered a senior police officer to report to him about the incident outside the court.

"I hope you will see that there is order because I will not proceed with the confusion outside the courts," he said.

Witnesses said that besides beating some UNIP members the police also beat a photographer for the government-owned Times of Zambia newspaper. The police were reported to have arrested some UNIP cadres.

Earlier one of the detainees, Senior Chief Inyambo Yeta, told the court that police had searched his Lusaka home on June 3 with a warrant indicating that they were looking for seditious materials, guns and explosives.

He said nothing was found at his home and office. Yeta said he was later asked to accompany the officers to the police station where he was detained after a female police officer told him that they had been ordered to arrest him on a charge of conspiracy to commit a felony.

Cross-examined by Mvunga, Yeta was asked whether it was possible he planted a bomb at State House on May 16. Yeta said it was impossible since that day he was attending meetings by opposition party presidents, who were preparing for a conference with ambassadors and high commissioners accredited to Zambia.

"My lord, the charge does not mention other people apart from my other seven colleagues of planting bombs. And to my knoweledge since I have been in detention from June 3, there were bomb explosions on June 5 at Limson House in Lusaka, June 6 at the airport and June 10 in Mufulira," he said.

The other accused, UNIP Central Commitee member Rabbison Chongo, denied planting the bomb at State House. He said he left the same day in the company of Kaunda for a conference in Canada.

"Even the day when the bomb was said to be planted at Intercontinental Hotel, I was in Canada and it is physically impossible for me to have planted the bomb as I can only be in one place at a time," Chongo said.

He told the judge that he feared the current detention could be a repeat of what happened in 1993 when he was arrested and detained for two months without trail in connection with what was known as "Zero Option." Purportedly, this was a plot by UNIP to topple Chiluba government.

The court is hearing an appeal by the eight treason accused against continued detention.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria University Of Lagos To Reopen Amid Teachers' Strike


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 27, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lagos, Nigeria - The University of Lagos has announced that classes will resume July 1, in spite of a strike by the country's university teachers which entered its 78th day Thursday.

The university, which concluded its sessional examinations and went on vacation in May after the strike called on April 9 by the Academic Staff Union of Universities (ASUU), said in a statement Thursday that lectures should resume July 1. 

ASUU launched the strike to press for better pay for its members and adequate funding of Nigerian universities, based on the review of a 1992 agreement with the government.

But negotiations between the Union and the military government collapsed.

The government accused the ASUU executives of causing academic disharmony.

It then banned the Union, froze university teachers' pay nationwide and gave lecturers of the country's estimated 40 universities an ultimatum to return to work or risk being fired.

The government also directed that further negotiations were to continue with individual universities.

The ultimatum given to the universities to resume lectures expired July 18, but most of the schools are still shut.

Meanwhile, ASUU's law suit challenging the government ban came up for hearing at a Lagos court Wednesday.

In the suit filed on behalf of its national president, Asisi Asobie, the Union asked the court to declare the government action illegal.

But ASUU's lawyer, Olasupo Ojo, told the high court that government was not represented Wednesday.

The case was then adjourned till July 5, to enable the respondents -- the education and justice ministers -- to be properly served with the notice.

Observers are concerned that the delay in resolving the crisis could harm higher education in Nigeria, which suffered months of academic disruptions in 1992/93 over prolonged teachers' strikes.

LANGUAGE: English

21 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Africa Hopes To Improve Medal Harvest in Atlanta


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 27, 1996 by Cheikh Mamadou


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Dakar, Senegal - Athletics is a discipline in which Africa has always occupied a respectable position during previous Olympic Games.

African athletes are again expected to perform well during the 1996 Atlanta Summer Olympics, even if in Barcelona, where the last games were held in 1992, they won only five medals, one less than in Seoul, in 1988.

However, things have changed since Barcelona, if one goes by the good performance from the continent's athletes.

Seven world records are currently held by African runners. These are Algeria's Nourredine Morceli (1,500m, 1,000m, 2,000m and 3,000m), Haile Gebreselassie of Ethiopia (5,000m and 10,000m) and Kenya's Moses Kiptanui (3,000m Steeple chase). 

These performances raise the hope for a higher medal harvest in Atlanta, Georgia, where Namibia's Frank Fredericks is also expected to be among the continent's star performers.

In Barcelona, Fredericks won silvers in the 100m and 200m sprints. The time of 9.96 secs in the 100m Fredericks registered during an international meet in France last month was clear testimony that he is in great form.

In the sprints, the continent will also count on Nigeria's Davidson Ezinwa, Africa's record-holder in the 100m (9. 94 secs), and his twin brother Osmond, who are even better than Fredericks in that race.

Besides the twins, Olapade Adeniken and the newcomer Deji Aliu are also tough sprinters who can be relied upon in the United States. With this crop of sprinters, Nigeria is a likely candidate for a medal in the 4 X 100 relay.

It might be difficult for African runners to beat the Americans in the 400m sprint. However, surprises could come from Nigeria's Sunday Bada and Samson Kitur of Kenya, currently the continent's best in that discipline.

Africans are expected to have an easier task in the medium and long distance races, ranging from the 800m and 1000m to the 3,000m steeple chase. In these, Kenyan, Ethiopian, Algerian and Moroccan athletes are expected to put up a stiff fight.

Although Kenya failed to win honours in the 800m for the first time in history during the 1995 world championships at Goteborg, Sweden, it is expected to field new athletes to repair the damage.

Burundi's Arthemon Hatungimana, last years's world number two in the race, is another hope for a medal.

In the 1,500m race, Africa's hopes for a gold are even higher. It can count on the strength of Nourredine Morceli, the young Moroccan Hichem El Guerrouj and his compatriot Rachid Labsir, the Burundian Venuste Niyongambo and the Kenyans.

Morceli, the three-time world champion, should be particularly motivated to win his first Olympic title. Sick during Barcelona 1992, he came 7th in the final.

In the 5,000m and 10,000m, the continent's hopes will be pinned on the Ethiopian Haile Gebreselassie, the holder of two world records. He is expected to add an Olympic title to his credit.

The Ethiopian will try to perform better than the Moroccan Khalid Skah, Olympic champion in the 10,000m in Barcelona and Salah Hissou and the Kenyans Ismael Kirui (two times 5,000m world champion.) There will also be Paul Tergat and William Sigei, both two times world cross country champions.

Meanwhile, Africa also stands high medal chances in the 400m hurdles and 3000m steeplechase, which has been monopolised by Kenyans since the 1968 Olympic games in Mexico. In Barcelona, four years ago, Kenya placed three athletes on the podium in that discipline.

The East Africans are expected to maintain their lead in this discipline by fielding Moses Kiptanui, the three time world champion.

In the 400m hurdle, Zambia's Samuel Matete, Africa's record-holder (47 seconds 10) and world champion in 1991, will face an array of tough American hurdlers.

Another field where Africa has some hope is the pole vault with South Africa's Okkert Brits. He is the third person to cross the six meter barrier. The two others are Ukraine's Segei Burka and Russia's Rodion Gatauline.

There is also hope for improvement among Africa's women athletes, who won two gold medals in Barcelona. Maria Mutola of Mozambique is expected to do well in the 800m. She should have won a medal at the world championship last year but was disqualified for crossing into another runner's lane.

The Algerian Hassiba Boulmerka, the African athlete with the highest number of medals at the world championship (two medals), is expected to put up a stiff fight to defend the gold medal she won in Barcelona in the 1,500m. Her major challengers are expected to be the Chinese.

Africa will also count on the Ethiopian woman athlete, Derartu Tulu, the 10,000m champion in Barcelona, although she faces a stiff challenge from the Portuguese Ribeiro, who beat her during last year's world championship. Other medal prospects lie within the crop of middle distance runners Kenya is expected to field.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Southern Africa SADC To Hold Summit As Tension Mounts


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 27, 1996 by Elliot Mahende, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Harare, Zimbabwe - Southern African leaders are expected to launch on Friday a body to monitor defence and security matters, amid a political crisis in Zambia and a border dispute between Botswana and Namibia.

The organ is to be launched during an emergency summit of the 12-nation Southern African Community (SADC), to be held in Gaborone, Botswana, where the leaders will to ratify an agreement setting up the sub-regional body.

The meeting will take place as Zambia teeters on the brink of civil conflict after the government enacted laws barring certain categories of Zambians, including former President Kenneth Kaunda, from standing for president. 

The new body will replace the "Frontline States" grouping, currently chaired by Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe, which handled such issues during the struggle against apartheid in Namibia and South Africa.

According to a draft agreement prepared by SADC foreign ministers in January this year in Windhoek, Namibia, the proposed body will operate at both ministerial and summit level with the chairmanship rotating annually on a troika basis.

Countries in the SADC are Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

A statement from the SADC secretariat in Gaborone said the new body would provide a framework for co-ordination of security, defence and political matters in the region.

"The SADC leaders will also review developments in the region and internationally, with particular emphasis on matters relating to politics, defence and security," read the statement.

Several bombs, allegedly planted by Kaunda's supporters, and violent demonstrations have hit Zambia since President Frederick Chiluba signed into law the constitutional amendment which bars first generation Zambians from standing in the forthcoming presidential elections.

According to the amendment, Kaunda is disqualified because he has already served more than two terms as president and his parents came from neighboring Malawi.

The security organ, to have a wide mandate including military intervention where necessary, is being set up in a region which despite being on the brink of peace for the first time in decades, has several simmering points which may erupt into violence.

Its immediate problems also include instability in Swaziland, where the powerful monarch, King Mswati II, is resisting demands for democratic changes.

As a sign of the worsening relations between Botswana and Namibia, Windhoek's foreign minister, Theo-Ben Gurirab recently described Botswana's military build-up near the disputed island of Kasikili/Sidudu on the Chobe river as "provocative."

The tension between the two countries has worsened with reports that Botswana planned to upgrade its combat capability with the acquisition of modern fighter jets and main battle tanks.

Mugabe, who along with Nelson Mandela of South Africa and Botswana's Ketumile Masire, helped defuse the crisis in Lesotho, will join other SADC leaders in Gaborone on his way from an investment summit in Ghana.

However, Chiluba whose country's crisis precipitated the emergency summit, will not attend.

Zambian Foreign Minister Lt.Gen. Christon Tembo, on a diplomatic offensive to play down the crisis and stress his country's sovereignty, said Chiluba had prior engagements.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa South Africa's Kwazulu-Natal Votes Peacefully


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 27, 1996 by Lionel WilliamS, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Johannesburg, South Africa - The first democratic local government elections in South Africa's troubled Kwazulu-Natal province ended in peace late Wednesday night. No major incidents of violence were reported throughout the day. 

At a news conference in Durban Wednesday night, provincial police and defence force chiefs, Chris Serfontein and Chris le Roux, praised the 25,000-member combined force which had prevented widespread intimidation and helped ensure peaceful elections.

"We are very thankful to say it has been a relatively quiet day and incident-free election," said Gen. Serfontein. He added that a few minor incidents had been reported, but none of a serious nature. A number of voters had been escorted out of some volatile areas and there had been minor skirmishes between rival groups at some polling stations. The two main contenders in the electrion are the African National Congress and the Inkhata Freedom Party.

Nevertheless, voting was orderly in most areas, despite widespread registration and logistical problems. Security force patrols remained on duty in most parts of the province after the polls closed at 22:00 local time.

The general opinion Thursday was that reconciliation between the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party had been the main force behind the peaceful election climate. Hundreds of thousands of voters streamed to the more than 3,000 polling stations throughout the province to cast their ballots. A voter turnout of more than 50 percent was anticipated. Preliminary results have started coming in, but the final picture of the Kwazulu-Natal local government elections is not likely before Friday or even Saturday.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Africa Unhappy With Investors


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 27, 1996 by Sharon Mlambo, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Accra, Ghana - A group of African leaders meeting in Ghana have expressed disappointment at the low direct foreign investment in the continent despite the adoption of investor-friendly policies by most countries.

At a summit in Accra Wednesday night, the leaders said they were seeking partnerships and not aid from the developed countries.

The summit, attended by presidents Jerry Rawlings (Ghana), Apha Konare (Mali), Sam Nujoma (Namibia), and Robert Mugabe (Zimbabwe) as well as South African first vice president Thabo Mbeki, was part of an international conference on reviving private investment in Africa. 

The summit also brought to the fore Africa's shortcomings in attracting investment.

Some leaders, including Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe, were sceptical about how much African economies should be opened up without sacrificing national sovereignty.

"We are not asking for welfare," said host President Jerry Rawlings, "because we have appropriate skills to do a lot of things for ourselves."

Rawlings said privatising crucial sectors such as telecommunications could be retrogressive as most government bills would be inflated.

"It is not everyone who goes into telecommunications for economic reasons," agreed Mugabe. "Some want to have their ears everywhere."

Mugabe warned that some investors expected to control economies and politics of countries in which they invested.

"We have to look at whether the role of investment is for the development of economies or to extend political control," he said.

Mugabe and Rawlings emphasised that investment should be based on partnership.

President Alpha Konare of Mali said Africa should build her economic capacity through "friendship and partnership".

Investor representatives said economic policies in Africa should be fine-tuned to match the conducive environment which had been created by recent advances toward more open economies.

They said governments should review tariffs to bolster international trade.

Bureaucracy and rigid foreign currency regulations should be scrapped, said the representatives from Britain, Malaysia and the United States.

South Africa's first vice-president, Thabo Mbeki, said the governments of developed countries should show confidence in the continent's economies first, if their business people are to be convinced there is a future in investing in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance SA Asks If Lowered Interest Rates Will Stem Capital Outflow


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 28, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Johannesburg - A volatile interest rate climate is not conducive to long-term investment planning, either by individuals or big business. And while the surprise rate cut by Amalgamated Banks of South Africa (Absa) this week -- closely followed by the other leading banks -- is welcome, it is not entirely convincing.

Absa made the move because conditions in the money market had stabilised; the liquidity problem had dissipated -- for the moment. 

"Where is the proof, in the form of concrete data, that the capital outflows have come to a standstill? Or that the easing in the money market shortage is more permanent, thereby lending credibility to a rate cut?" asks an analyst.

The banks were very quick to raise their rates six weeks ago and in retrospect they could be accused of having acted too hastily. "On a 16-year trend, their margins were not that out of line," says a banking analyst. "They did themselves no favours by acting when they did, alienating many of their customers as a result."

But hindsight is an exact science, says Steven Nathan, banking analyst at Ivor Jones. "They certainly did face a severe liquidity crunch and their earnings were under pressure. Nobody wants higher rates; they lead to bad debts and hit costs. People forget that banks also have to look after their shareholders."

The Reserve Bank helped matters further by halving the rate it charges for "second-tier" loans to the banks, thus providing a buffer should the liquidity situation deteriorate again. Its move came as an even greater surprise than Absa's, but with credit demand easing, the pressure for punitive rates to regulate the money supply and ultimately dampen the inflation rate is receding.

"The Reserve Bank has made sure that external conditions are easier, but that is not the same as saying capital flows have turned positive," says First National Bank's chief economist, Cees Bruggemans. "While portfolio investors were active in May and June, the net result was negative."

Since the first hike in interest rates, evidence of a slowdown in the economy has been growing. The latest Reserve Bank quarterly bulletin points to a decline in domestic demand for the first time since mid-1993. Total real gross domestic expenditure fell by 1,5% in the January to March period, as inventories were run down and private consumption slowed.

Thus, the conflict between domestic demands and external realities is hotting up. One school of thought is that the reaction to the falling rand was overdone, but it is not clear that sentiment really has turned around sufficiently to withstand further upheavals in the financial markets.

The government has certainly been working hard at promoting its new growth strategy, trumpeting privatisation and offering reassurances on exchange controls. But are the financial managers convinced?

"For the sake of consumers and potential investors, we must make sure this interest rate cut sticks," says the analyst. "We can't afford a reversal in the few weeks' or months' time; the blow to confidence will be immense."

Initial market reaction to the bank's move was promising -- the R150 bond rate fell 15 points to around 15,04%, with talk of 15% in the near future, as foreign buyers piled in. The money market call rate, however, was stubbornly steady at 16 to 16,25%, signalling tight cash conditions.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa New Telecom Minister Caught In SA Telkom Controversy


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 28, 1996 by Stefaans Brummer


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Johannesburg - Jay Naidoo is embroiled in his first major controversy as post, telecommunications and broadcasting minister after he made "secret" eleventh-hour changes to the Telecommunications Bill accepted by Cabinet last week. Stakeholders accuse him of reneging on consensus painstakingly built over more than a year by his predecessor, Pallo Jordan.

The version of the Bill accepted by Cabinet differs significantly from the Telecommunications White Paper -- the pinnacle of Jordan's two-year incumbency -- which was approved by Cabinet in March.

The Mail & Guardian has learnt that Willie Currie, the adviser Naidoo inherited from Jordan and who drove the wide-ranging Green Paper and White Paper policy consultations, resigned in protest this week. Key pillars of Jordan's policy, now overturned, included a phased end to Telkom's monopoly status and guarantees of an independent telecommunications watchdog. 

Said a senior official involved in telecommunications policy formulation: "There had been an extensive consultative process, but at the last minute the minister makes changes ... The minister should have gone back to the sector and said, 'I'm not happy' -- instead of saying, when he first came in, that the minister has changed, not the policy."

A telecommunications industry member who was involved in the White Paper formulation said industry stakeholders -- with the exception of Telkom, which now appears to have an indefinite reprieve as monopoly operator -- were "furious".

And he warned that because Naidoo's rewrite brought the proposed industry-wide South African Telecommunications Regulatory Authority (Satra) under the control of his own ministry, which also governs Telkom, there would be a "serious conflict of interest". This could scare off international investors.

The National Telecommunications Forum (NTF), the industry stakeholders' body formed in 1993 with representatives from the government, business, labour and civil society, and the main vehicle for Jordan's consultative process, was to meet Naidoo on Thursday to "ask for an explanation".

Ironically, the NTF had been the brainchild of Andile Ncaba, then a member of the ANC Department of Information Systems and now postmaster general. Ncaba, who backs Naidoo's changes, earlier said about the NTF: "One of our objectives ... was to create an investor-confident environment where policies could be addressed in the open, unlike during the apartheid years."

To add to Naidoo's troubles the five-person Eminent Persons' Group -- appointed by Jordan last December to resolve differences between stakeholders in the drafting of the White Paper -- last Friday said in a memo to Naidoo it would not certify the new Bill as consistent with the White Paper, another of its duties.

But group member Dupree Vilakazi said yesterday the memo had been withdrawn on Tuesday after the final version of the Bill -- which previously it could not obtain -- was handed to it. "By Tuesday we were in full support of what happened in Cabinet."

A central motive for Naidoo's rewrite relates to government's stated intention to privatise -- a road Telkom appears to have travelled further than any other state utility, with players like Deutsche Telekom, France Telecom and the United States AT&T seriously eyeing the minority stake, worth as much as R10-billion, government wants to sell.

Naidoo seems to want to squeeze maximum value out of such a deal: The longer Telkom's guaranteed monopoly is perpetuated, the greater is the value of the stake bought by the equity partner. Naidoo this week acknowledged the change could be seen as a "sweetener" to attract buyers.

But an industry source criticised this as "narrow minded", saying that international experience has shown increased competition can only increase the strength of the former monopoly operator. Mexico's Telmex, which was privatised in 1990 when it was twice the size of Telkom, has since grown to six times Telkom's size.

Jordan's White Paper proposed that Telkom's monopoly be maintained for five years while it meets Reconstruction and Development Programme objectives to supply lines to under-serviced communities, followed by two years of phased market liberalisation.

But Naidoo's Bill omits the time-frame altogether, leaving liberalisation at the sole discretion of his ministry. Vilakazi said: "You need a minister with teeth, not a minister who is toothless."

The rationale behind the loss of Satra's independence is less clear, but the official involved in policy formulation claimed it represented "some state of drift, of asserting more and more state power".

Naidoo's clipping of the comparable Independent Broadcasting Authority's wings after he took office -- he appropriated its policy-making powers for his ministry -- seems to have informed his approach to Satra.

Government appears to have been stung by criticism over the IBA's slow pace of work, and Naidoo may have felt a repeat of that experience could be avoided by placing the telecommunications regulatory function under his ministry. But this fails to address concerns about a conflict of interest where the same ministry controls Telkom and the body that has to regulate Telkom alongside other industry players.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Kenya 'Secret' Arms Factory Sparks Fears In Kenya


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 28, 1996 by Greg Barrow


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Nairobi - The citizens of Eldoret, a small town at the top of the Rift Valley, cannot believe their luck. Eldoret, once known only for its mushroom farming and world- class middle-distance athletes, has become Kenya's main beneficiary of government development money and industrial growth schemes.

The sleepy town of just over 100 000 residents already prides itself on having one of the best hospitals in Kenya, a university, a military barracks and a branch of the central bank. 

By December, Eldoret will also be home to Kenya's third international airport -- and an armaments factory capable of producing 20-million bullets a year.

Why has Eldoret received so much government aid? Some Kenyans say the answer is simple. The town is situated deep in the heart of Kalenjin country, the tribal homeland of Kenyan president Daniel arap Moi.

Debating societies in Moi University, on the outskirts of Eldoret, have shied away from discussing the government's generosity to their hometown. But in the Nairobi parliament the issue has become a hot topic.

Opposition parties which balked at the international airport are fuming about the armaments factory. It is estimated to cost somewhere between O6-million and O170-million, but the government has shrouded it in a veil of secrecy and refuses to discuss the financing arrangements.

Under normal circumstances, a cross-party defence committee should have examined the project, but it too has been kept in the dark.

Moi says there is nothing sinister about the bullet factory, and claims it is a government project funded from the military budget. The subject has, however, raised concern in Belgium, home to the armaments manufacturer Fabrique Nationale Herstal, which is helping to build the Eldoret factory and supplying much of the machinery.

Some Belgian MPs have questioned whether it is wise for a Belgian company to support the factory in a country with a questionable human rights record. They also point to potential arms markets in neighbouring countries such as Burundi, Somalia and Sudan -- all embroiled in conflicts.

Belgian foreign minister Erik Derycke said: "It is not in accordance with current African policy, which is aimed at preventative diplomacy and conflict prevention."

The main opposition Ford-Kenya party has sent a protest letter to the Belgian government, and is considering lobbying European Union member states over Belgian involvement.

Opposition parties in Kenya are also concerned about the role the factory will play in domestic politics. Although there is little threat of Moi's governing party losing elections due before the end of 1997, some politicians suggest that Eldoret, with its bullet factory, military barracks and airport, would provide a defensive enclave for the government in case of trouble.

"Given the history of the last elections in 1992, when there were land clashes and tribal flare-ups in the Rift Valley, we're very worried that there is a preparation for something," said Otieno Kopeyo of the Ford-Kenya party. "Weapons manufactured at this new factory could be used against civilians, and that is the most pressing concern."


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


28 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zimbabwe Neighbours Must Sell To Protect Mugabe's Security


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 28, 1996 by Iden Wetherell


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Harare - Property owners in Harare's upmarket Borrowdale suburb whose homes overlook an estate used by President Robert Mugabe as a weekend retreat have been told to sell their properties to the government for "security reasons". But they say they are only being offered half the market value.

The 12-hectare estate, including an imposing homestead, is owned by the ruling Zanu-PF party's shadowy investment company M&S Syndicate which bought it in 1987 as a weekend retreat and retirement home for the president and his late wife, Sally. The previous owner who made his fortune from commodity broking in Zimbabwe lives in Cape Town. 

The five neighbouring property owners said they were first approached last year by the senior government valuator, Sunil Fernando, who said he was acting for the Ministry of Defence.

Informed they didn't want to sell, Fernando cited security considerations: "You are not listening. The Ministry of Defence wishes to acquire your property," he told them, suggesting they obtain independent valuations of their properties.

"When we submitted the independent valuation he went ballistic," said one of the owners, Rick Passaportis. "He claimed the valuation was worthless and out of all proportion to the value of the property."

Passaportis said a reputable local estate agent had valued his property at Z$6-million (about R3- million). His 10ha property contains a four-bedroom main house, three-bedroom cottage, dam, stables, tennis court and swimming pool. The government has offered Passaportis Z$3-million.

The total value of the properties the government seeks to acquire is Z$20-million. This is twice the figure the government allocated to its rural resettlement programme in the current fiscal year. Mugabe made land redistribution the centrepiece of his re-election campaign in April. But critics have said the programme has seen prime land distributed to Mugabe's cronies rather than to peasants crowded in former rural reserves.

"I understand that governments everywhere have the right to acquire land. But in view of the fact that in our case this is not for resettlement, government should pay the market price," Passaportis said, pointing out that he had invested enormous capital and energy building up his property.

His lawyers argue the controversial Land Acquisition Act, authorising the government to acquire land, does not cover cases such as this, where no health, public safety or defence interest is involved.

So far, two of the owners have accepted the government's offer to purchase their properties. But the government has yet to come up with the money, leaving the owners in a predicament.

"The houses are blighted," says Peter Hartnack, one of those who have agreed to sell. "Nobody will buy them knowing the government has expressed an interest. And we can't make the government pay because a successful suit in the courts could not be enforced."

Mugabe is known to be obsessive about his security, sealing off the approach roads to his main Harare residence and travelling only in heavily armed motorcades.

He owns other properties in Zvimba, north of Harare, and in Nyanga, in the Eastern Highlands. In both locations people have been displaced, mostly peasant farmers.

Asked why the government had not made good its offer to buy those properties offered to it, Fernando told the Mail & Guardian: "I don't know. You should talk to the relevant authorities."

No response could be obtained, however, from the Ministry of Defence.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
