44 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambia Fights Illicit Drug Trade


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 28, 1996 by Moses Mbulo


LENGTH: 1920 words


 

Nairobi - The number of illicit drug cases involving Zambians and their accomplices locally and abroad have reached an alarming level, and those involved in the "get rich quick" trade range from high ranking government leaders to ordinary school children, says the country's Drug Enforcement Commission (DEC).

The true picture of more Zambians taking to the drug trade is backed by DEC statistics which indicate that in February and March 1996 alone, the commission arrested more than 200 traffickers and seized drugs worth Kwacha 2 billion (US dollars 2 million) from the illicit trade.

Drug Enforcement Commission spokesman Mukutulu Sinyani concedes that the influx of hard drugs like ephedrine was prevalent in the country and mentions others like mandrax, opium and cannabis as being readily available on the local market.

Following the upswing in the trade which involves locally grown cannabis and the proliferation of foreign drugs on the Zambian market, DEC says it has devised a national combat strategy to eradicate drugs in the country.

The commission's efforts to fight the drug scourge was further strengthened by Zambia's hosting of the Interpol African Regional Conference in Lusaka in June 1995. Opening the conference, President Fredrick Chiluba commended the timing as it coincided with a period when the region was searching for solutions to the high crime rate sponsored by drug barons. 

The conference brought together more than 30 countries including observers from seven countries from Europe, the United States and Asia.

During its deliberations, the Interpol meeting observed that the drug dealers were taking advantage of Zambia's liberalised economy to pose as investors who associate themselves with politicians to influence decisions in their favour.

The drug scourge has not spared families of top leaders in the government who have come to discover that they could enrich themselves overnight by dealing in what is referred to here as the "emerald of Zambia."

Maliko Mwaanga, 19, son of former Foreign Affairs Minister Vernon Mwaanga who himself stepped down to pave way for investigations in alleged drug dealings, together with two retired soldiers were arrested by army officers at Lusaka showgrounds in the capital as they were about to conclude a transaction involving cocaine with a street value of Kwacha 69 million ($69,000).

The DEC spokesman Mukutulu Sinyani said Maliko -- then a grade 12 pupil at Choma Secondary School, and his accomplices, retired soldiers Emmanuel Chola 33 and Kayumba 36, were trafficking 153 grammes of very high grade cocaine.

On goes the list ...a Lusaka resident caught red-handed with 212 tablets of mandrax was jailed for two years with hard labour while the accomplice, a minor, was ordered to be caned six times by a Lusaka magistrate court.

Principal Resident Magistrate Meebelo Kalima told Moses Mutalama, 20, and a grade 10 schoolboy that drug dealing was prevalent and so it was up to the courts to mete out deterrent sentences.

And Interpol President Bjorn Erickson who is the Swedish Commissioner of Police, chairing the African Regional Conference said, drug barons were exploiting the liberalization of the economy by entrenching themselves in businesses and influencing decisions. He charged that Africa's drug business had reached a staggering $400 billion, and a further $100 billion was used to establish banks which were used in money laundering operations.

Mr. Erickson regretted that most governments were cutting budgetary allocations to police at a time when more resources were needed to support measures aimed at fighting drug trafficking and crime, which endanger the moral fabric of society and national development.

At last year's forum, DEC spokesman Mr Sinyani alluded that opium reaching Zambia was from the "Golden Triangle" in Asia while cocaine came mainly from Brazil. He explained that following the identification of drug sources, DEC had opened an active network with Brazil and expressed hope the measures would achieve results.

The climax to the extent to which Zambians have gone to trade in drugs is illustrated by a February 1996 incident in which DEC seized the biggest haul of cocaine, when it apprehended a woman at the Lusaka International Airport with more than four kilogrammes of the drug worth nearly kwacha 2 billion ($2 million).

The suspect, Evelyn Mombasa Mwanakaoma, 40, a housewife, was arrested upon disembarking from a plane coming from Luanda.

The seizure was made when Mrs Mwanakaoma was found with drugs concealed in her brand new suitcase which had two false compartments where the consignment was expertly concealed. Her air ticket indicated she left Rio-de Janeiro in Brazil for Lusaka via Luanda. Her circuitous route when travelling from Brazil earlier in January 1996 was Lusaka, Johannesburg, Luanda and Rio-de Janeiro.

There are more startling incidents. One that was extensively covered by a local daily here was that of a former Zambia Airways employee Florence Kapata, 26, and her Ivorian boyfriend Mammadou Konate, 32, who in June appeared in a Lusaka Magistrate Court charged with murdering Mrs Barbara Sakwanda, a primary school teacher.

The couple was alleged to have made Mrs Sakwanda swallow 29 pellets of drugs with a street value of K 102 million, ($102,000) which became stuck in her throat and eventually led to her death.

Fighting to preserve Zambia's credibility which is at stake, the DEC has reiterated that it would make frantic efforts to ensure the country was not turned into a safe haven for traffickers.

But as the DEC researches on new strategies to combat drug peddling, dealers are also busy devising sophisticated methods of evading the dragnet.

The intensification of the war on drug dealers is to some extent paying dividends, according to the DEC. There is one incident of four tonnes of Zambian grown cannabis worth more than K 1 billion ($1 million) that was seized in Canada. "If Canada which is away from Zambia can have four tonnes of cannabis from Zambia, what do you expect Zambia to have?" poses Sinyani.

Realising the immense monetary gains derived from cannabis, a good number of Zambian peasant farmers have abandoned growing legalized cash crops such as the staple food maize, in preference to cultivating large tracts of cannabis fields from which they reap abnormal profits.

According to the DEC, the series of arrests countrywide is enough proof of more Zambians getting enticed to the money spinning cannabis farming. Sinyani singled out Southern Province where cannabis that is grown extensively today, was originally used for traditional purposes.

The number of farmers arrested by DEC for growing cannabis has risen tremendously. Recently, two Chibombo peasant farmers in Central Province fell victim to DEC operations for cultivating 866 kilogrammes of cannabis worth street value of K 216.5 million ($216,500). The deal was foiled when the growers severely beat up and killed one of the pigs they found grazing in the cannabis plantation. In a similar operation in the North Western Province town of Solwezi, the DEC arrested five people found with cannabis.

The DEC statistics show that in 1994 alone, 870 tonnes of cannabis were seized throughout Zambia.

In the light of the intensity of drug activities in the region, African heads of drug services who converged in Lusaka to map out new strategies of combating drug trafficking, recommended that bank laws in their countries be revised to facilitate investigations of money laundering to curb the rising menace in the region.

Among the recommendations passed by the Interpol delegates included one which stipulated that the cultivation of cannabis should be banned because it was the most abused drug in the region.

Zambia's DEC spokesman Mukutulu Sinyani said delegates had resolved that countries should adopt mechanisms and enact legislations which would enable officers to monitor and investigate money laundering.

The delegates also agreed that countries in the region should sign extradition treaties so that suspected criminals would be tried in countries in which they committed crimes regardless of their nationality.

"Those countries in the region which had not yet ratified the 1961, 1971 and 1988 United Nations Conventions on Drug Trafficking and Psychotropic Substances should ratify them as soon as possible to facilitate implementation of the resolutions," the Lusaka forum emphasized.

>From the gloomy picture painted of the involvement of its citizens in the flourishing lucrative drug trade within and across its borders, the government of Zambia, must unleash and put in place workable measures to fight the vice.

Worse still, the authorities may find it difficult to fight the scourge from within, following the implication of cabinet ministers and other high ranking leaders in the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government.

Last year, President Fredrick Chiluba's government came under fire Deputy Speaker Mr Sikota Wina and his wife Princess Nakatindi Wina, and former Foreign Affairs Minister Vernon Mwaanga to pave way for investigations. They have since been acquitted of charges.

Ordinary peasant farmers, school children and the novice to the drug business know very well the risks involved but find it an easy way to eke a living in a country riddled with high poverty rates, malnutrition and low levels of employment opportunities.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambian Journalists Refuse To Reveal Information Source


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 28, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Lusaka - Four Zambian journalists have refused to name their sources leading to a story alleging that Legal Affairs Minister, Remmy Mushota, attempted to cash on April 4 this year a Zambian Kwacha ZK 210 ($210,000) government cheque.

The independent Post managing editor, Bright Mwape and the paper's senior journalist, Chilombo Mwondela, including Chronicle newspaper journalists, Nkonkomalimba Kafunda and Anthony Mukwita, were summoned on June 19 to appear before a legal tribunal appointed to verify the journalists' allegations.

The four could face imprisonment if their story is found to be false and continue not to reveal their sources.

According to information availed here by the Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), the four journalists were summoned to appear before the tribunal on June 19 under a parliamentary and ministerial Code of Conduct Act which contains a clause requiring journalists to disclose their sources. 

The Act was passed early last year amid protests from journalists saying that it was professionally unacceptable.

Meanwhile, investigations into the case are still continuing and if the tribunal's initial findings prove that press allegations against Mushota were false, a second tribunal will be established to compel the four journalists to reveal their sources or risk imprisonment, says MISA.

According to Mwape, the government called for the tribunal when a member of the public, retired Brigadier General Nicholas Zulu, wrote to ask for an inquiry into the matter after reading the allegations in the press.

Zulu is a United Independence Party (UNIP) member, now under custody awaiting treason trial, for alleged involvement in a spate of bomb blasts in May.

Mwape said the Zambian Constitution has a provision stating that a member(s) of the public can ask the government to investigate media allegations.

The tribunal is chaired by a High Court Judge and two other judges while witnesses have been subpoenaed from the Ministry of Legal Affairs accounts department, the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Zambia. The Anti-Corruption Commission is also expected to give its evidence.

The subpoenaed civil servants stand to be punished if they refuse to testify before the tribunal and if they are found to have leaked information to the press.

The June 20 edition of The Post quoted Mwape objecting before the tribunal that he and his colleagues should disclose sources saying: "I want to tell the tribunal that my profession thrives on mutual trust and confidence between journalists and their sources and I won't sacrifice that trust and breach it for Dr. Mushota's sake."

Mwape reportedly told the tribunal that he believed justice would still be done since "evidence given to the tribunal so far had confirmed the accuracy of The Post story and my sources would not add any value to Mushota's case."

Mushota reportedly had himself persistently demanded that in "the interest of justice, Mwape should disclose his sources" because "the duty of this tribunal is to establish facts and truth."

The Post quotes Mushota as arguing that justice will not be done if Mwape does not reveal his sources. Mwape is, however, reported to have added that he was aware of the government's high-handed action against public employees leaking information to the media even if such information was accurate.

Meanwhile, Lucy Sichone, a civic activist and freelance columnist for The Post, told MISA on June 24 that Mushota has initiated criminal defamation charges against her, a human rights lawyer Rodger Chongwe, The Post editor-in-chief Fred M'Membe, The Post's special projects editor, Masautso Phiri, Mwape, Mwondela, Nkonkomalimba Kafunda and Anthony Mukwita for writing and commenting on the allegations that he attempted to cash the ZK 210 million government cheque.

Sichone, however, said that the Mushota case is test ground for the "government's commitment to transparency and accountability and we are waiting to see how they will deal with their minister if found guilty."

At its 1994 Annual General Congress in Swaziland, MISA called for the scrapping of the clause in the Parliamentary and Ministerial Code of Conduct Act requiring journalists writing about political leaders "to appear before a tribunal to justify stories and to disclose their sources."

The clause was at the time in its draft form and was passed early last year. According to MISA, the clause "undermines press freedom and, gives exclusive privilege to a few individuals in society, and breaches ethical demands of the profession of journalism."


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Nigeria Frees Detainees As Commonwealth Gets Tough


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 28, 1996


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Lagos - Nigeria has released several political detainees as representatives of its military junta entered a final day of talks in London on June 25 over threatened Commonwealth sanctions for the country's human rights record.

The release of Nosa Igiebor, editor-in-chief of the weekly Tell magazine, after six months of detention, brought to four the number of detainees known to have been freed on June 23 and 24, although the latest cases had not yet been officially confirmed.

Press reports said on June 25 that at least three other detainees, including two student activists, had also been set free. 

The release coincide with a meeting June 24 and 25 between Nigerian military leaders and Commonwealth ministers in a bid to avert punitive sanctions for Nigeria's human rights record.

The regime of General Sani Abacha provoked international outrage last November after it hanged writer Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other minority rights activists from the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP) of southern Nigeria. Shortly after, Nigeria was suspended from the Commonwealth over the executions.

But the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group (CMAG), charged with reporting on human rights abuse in Nigeria, has allowed Lagos to send a 17-member delegation headed by Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi to the London talks.

At an earlier meeting in London in April, the CMAG recommended sanctions against the West African nation but agreed to allow it to argue its case before implementation.

Nosa, who was arrested here on December 23 and released on June 24 from Minna prison in the north, according to journalists who saw him on June 25, was one of four detainees interviewed in April by a United Nations team that visited the country to investigate its human rights situation.

The press reported on June 25 that Fred Eno, personal secretary to detained opposition leader Moshood Abiola, was also released on June 24 after spending nearly two years in prison.

There was no official confirmation of his release, but Abiola's Concord newspaper group told journalists that he was released from Enugu prison on the morning of June 24.

Abiola, whose wife Kudiratu Abiola was shot dead by assailants on June 4, is still in jail facing a charge of treason for declaring himself president as the presumed winner of elections in June 1993, which the military annulled.

The military authorities on June 23 also released human rights activists Tunji Abayomi, the attorney of detained former head of state Olusegun Obasanjo and chairman of the Nigerian branch of Human Rights Africa, and Abdul Groh, head of the Organisation for the Defence of Civil Liberties. Both had been held since July last year.

Meanwhile, Nigeria on June 25 won a three-month reprieve from Commonwealth sanctions that had been threatened following last November's execution of the nine human rights activists but its suspension from the Commonwealth club remained in force.

The high-level panel of Commonwealth ministers announced after a two-day meeting in London with Nigerian officials that an impasse had been broken, and a range of trade and economic sanctions would be held in abeyance until another meeting in September.

A grim-faced Nigerian Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi, who led a 17- member delegation that met with the CMAG, declined to give specifics of the meeting, and only said that the "impasse" that had existed since Nigeria was suspended from the Commonwealth following the hangings "had now been broken."


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Rwanda Parliament Row BLocks Rwanda's First Genocide Trial


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 28, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Kigali - An attempt to bring to trial suspects for Rwanda's 1994 ethnic genocide has been postponed for several more weeks due to a dispute between the Rwandan National Assembly and the government, deputy speaker of the Rwandan parliament Laurent Nkongori announced on June 22.

Rwanda's first trial of the genocide suspects was due to open in the month of June, but has stalled several times in a dispute between the National Assembly and the Rwandan government over the law to be used in cases of genocide and crimes against humanity.

The key sticking points are the period the law should cover, sentencing and compensation.

A parliamentary debate on the issue was suspended on June 19 after three days of discussion and was scheduled to be brought back for debate after two weeks, "a move that would delay the opening of the trial, but not for long," Nkongori said. 

The law will first have to go to the constitutional court after adoption by parliament.

The National Assembly is dominated by Tutsi members of the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF), who are in power after defeating in July 1994 the majority Hutu-dominated army of the late Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana who was killed in a suspected planecrash in April 6, 1994 along with Burundi Hutu President Cyprien Ntaryamira.

Their death triggered an ethnic bloodbath which left between half a million and one million people dead, most of them minority Tutsi's and moderate Hutus, whose deaths were blamed on the defeated Hutu army and extremist Hutu militias.

The slaughter only ended when the RPF seized power, and currently more than 73,000 Hutus are awaiting trial in Rwanda's overcrowded jails.

The Tutsi-led government wants to set up its own warcrimes court in parallel to what it regards as an inefficient United Nations Tribunal -- set up in November 1994.

The UN tribunal, sitting in Arusha, Tanzania, opened preliminary hearings on its first three suspects last month, but the trial is not due to begin until late September.

Nkongori, who heads the commission set up to examine the new law, believes the jurisdiction of the new court should not be restricted to the suggested October 1990 to December 1994 period, but also take account of murders after that date.

"The objective is to eradicate impunity. If there has been a genocide, it is because for a long time in Rwanda, there was this idea of impunity. There must be a wish to resolve the problem. It must not be allowed to pressurize the work ofthe trial," Nkongori explained.

The deadlock in parliament persists despite the growing number of murders of witnesses to the genocide, which has prompted the UN human rights office in Kigali to voice its concern over the killings that have taken place mainly in the west of the country bordering Zaire.

Between January and May, at least 48 people have been killed and three reported missing.

The most recent attack came overnight on June 18 when 18 escapees from the 1994 massacres -- and therefore potential witnesses -- were killed in the western district of Kibuye by Hutu extremists crossing from Zaire. A Rwandan army soldier was also killed.

The killings come amid growing insecurity throughout the west of the country and frequent cross-border raids by Hutus based in Zaire, according to the Rwandan authorities.

The extremists are among some 1.7 million Hutu refugees in Zaire, Tanzania and Burundi who fled massacres and refused to return to Rwanda fearing reprisals by the new Tutsi-dominated government.

On June 24, the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, sitting in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha, issued arrest warrants for six more Rwandans accused of genocide and crimes against humanity, and violating the Geneva Convention.

The six were not identified, at the prosecutor's request, following reports that key witnesses living in Rwanda were being eliminated by armed groups, bringing the number of suspects charged so far in relation to the ethnic massacres in Rwanda in 1994 to nine.

One of the UN tribunal judges, Lennart Aspagren, also granted a prosecution request that four key witnesses detained in Cameroon since March be held for a further 30 days, pending their extradition to face charges by the UN court.

The four, considered to have masterminded the 1994 ethnic slaughter, are Theoneste Bagosora, Ferdinand Nahimana, Andre Ntagorura and Anatole Nsengiyumva.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Burundi Neighbours Officer Burundi Military Help To End Violence


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 28, 1996


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Arusha, Tanzania - A regional summit of Burundi's neighbours has agreed to provide the war-torn tiny central African nation with military assistance to prevent simmering ethnic violence from exploding into another bloodbath like in neighbouring Rwanda, which has a similar ethnic mix.

The decision was reached on June 25 at a summit in this northern Tanzanian town attended by leaders from six countries in the region -- Burundi, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda and Tanzania and Uganda -- as well as the Organization of African Unity (OAU).

It was the first time ever during the summit that the Burundian government sought outside help to restore peace in the country, where clashes between Hutu guerrillas and the Tutsi-dominated army have left hundreds dead in recent months.

A "technical committee" to be chaired by Tanzania was set up to determine the type and level of assistance needed. 

Host Benjamin Mkapa, the Tanzanian President, said the four-hour summit had been "very productive," adding that he hoped the committee could submit a preliminary report before the next OAU summit, set to begin July 8 in Yaounde, Cameroon.

Burundian Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo took pains to make it clear that Burundi was not seeking a military operation, but "only help to ensure everyone's safety is assured. We have not changed our mind."

While the type of aid is yet to be determined, "we are not ruling out any means," he added, although the government has always said it is hostile to foreign intervention.

Burundi erupted into ethnic violence in October 1993 when Melchior Ndadaye, the country's first elected president from the Hutu majority, was assassinated in an attempted military coup, which has left thousands of people dead since.

Burundi's death toll in 1995 alone was put at about 30 a day, but the recent fighting has raised fears of all-out civil war similar to that in Rwanda, which has the same ethnic mix of some 90 per cent Hutus and some 14 per cent Tutsis.

In Rwanda, between 500,000 and one million people were in 1994 massacred, most of them minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus, allegedly by the defeated Hutu army and extremist Hutu militias.

In their summit communique, the Heads of State and/or Governments present in Arusha affirmed that the negotiations should involve all groups and parties."

The communique made a "renewed and urgent" appeal to all sides in the conflict to put an immediate halt to the violence.

Burundian President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, a Hutu and a member of the Front for Democracy in Burundi (FRODEBU), said: "There is a strong wish for the violence to stop."

However, the main opposition Unity for National Progress (UPRONA) and the Tutsi-dominated army were categorically opposed to the participation of rebel leader Leonard Nyangoma in future peace talks.

UPRONA and the army accuse the Hutu rebels of committing genocide, an accusation the rebels make against the army.

The June 25 closed-door summit was the first time the Hutu president and the Tutsi prime minister, a member of UPRONA, had agreed to attend such a meeting together.

Also present were Presidents Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda.

The absence of Zairean leader Mobutu Sese Seko, who sent Foreign Minister Jean-Marie Nititwa Tumansi instead, was the summit's main disappointment, as Zaire is currently home to more than one million Hutu refugees from neighbouring Burundi and Rwanda, and their governments complain that Zaire is serving as an operational base for extremist Hutus who carry out raids in Burundi and western Rwanda.

Ahead of the Arusha summit, which former Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere helped to organize, earlier talks initiated by Nyerere had apparently stalled, dashing Burundi's hopes of finding a speedy resolution to the conflict.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Rwanda and Burundi Churches Join To Assist East African Refugees


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 28, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Nairobi - With their continent housing some 8 million refugees and 15 million internally displaced persons -- one of the highest number of refugees in the world, churches in Africa are gradually extending their pastoral care to refugees.

The Methodist Church in Kenya jointly with the New York, USA-based General Board of Global Ministries (GBGM) and the United Methodist Committee on Relief (UMCR), have instituted a joint refugee programme to cater for Rwandese and Burundian refugees based in Zaire.

The programme, which mainly provides pastoral, relief and medical services to the needy Rwandese and Burundian refugees in the refugee camps in Uvira, Bukavu and Goma (Zaire), was initiated late 1994 following a visit to Rwanda by Methodist church ministers from the United States and Kenya, at the height of the influx of Rwandese refugees into Zaire. 

According to Bishop Charles Makonde, who is coordinating the church's (Kenya) programme for preparedness, disaster and relief activities, the team recruits doctors, nurses, pastors and social workers to serve the refugees in Zaire for a three-week period.

"The recruitment takes place both here in Kenya and the USA and goes beyond doctrinal lines," Bishop Makonde told APS in an interview.

Bishop Makonde says about 24 Kenyans and 200 Americans have so far participated in the programme since it was begun nearly two years ago.

The Methodist clergy said the programme will in future move some of its operations to Rwanda and Burundi "to serve the returnees." But this, he stressed, would depend on among other factors, the availability of funds.

Bishop Makonde said much of the financial support was coming from the GBGM and UMCR although the Methodist church in Kenya was also making its own contributions. He did not however disclose the amount of money put aside for the programme.

In a recent interview with APS an official with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), here said there is a voluntary repatriation of an estimated 500 Rwandese and Burundian refugees from Zaire every week.

Other statistics released by the UNHCR to mark this year's Organisation of African Unity (OAU) African Refugee Day on June 20, indicates that Zaire is rated as one of the countries with the highest concentration of refugees in Africa.

The available figures say Zaire currently hosts an estimated 1.5 million Rwandese refugees; 180,000 Burundian; 200,000 Angolans; 111,000 Sudanese and 18,000 Ugandans.

Asked about some of the major challenges, they were facing in the implementation of the programme, Bishop Makonde said..."There are times we were not able to dispatch the recruited people to the camps, because Zairean authorities barred foreigners from entering the refugee camps.

Bishop Makonde is also the chairman of the Eastern Africa regional committee of the Refugee and Emergency Services of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC).


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Channel Africa To Stay But ...


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 28, 1996


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Windhoek - South Africa's cabinet has passed a decision to continue supporting Channel Africa, the external radio service of the South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC) but on a "more rationalized form."

On June 19, the Cabinet decided to grant Channel Africa a stay of execution pending an investigation into the future of the radio station by a cabinet-appointed committee, says a statement from the Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) here.

The cabinet's decision followed a world-wide campaign against the closure of the station, which is estimated to have around 15 million listeners throughout sub-Saharan Africa. The task force has been given until October to report back to the Cabinet. 

However, in a press release issued on June 19, Minister of Posts Telecommunications and Broadcasting, Jay Naidoo, said: "The precise format and financing of the external service of the SABC shall be finalised by the committee (task force) chaired by the Deputy President, Thabo Mbeki".

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs responsible for financing Channel Africa had not set aside funds for the station for the 1996/97 year and had indicated in March this year that it would scrap the station's funding and close down the service.

Staff at Channel Africa formed a committee to try to block the station's closure by lobbying Cabinet and mobilising support from listeners throughout Africa. As a result, hundreds of letters from different organisations and individuals throughout the world poured in urging the Cabinet to withdraw its decision to close Channel Africa.

According to a June 9 press release, the sub-committee to be chaired by Deputy-President Thabo Mbeki, comprises the Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Posts and Telecommunications and Broadcasting, Arts, Culture, Science and Technology, and Finance.

"A report will be submitted to Cabinet by October (1996) taking into consideration reports from the task group on government communications and further feasibility studies done by the SABC," said t

Speaking to MISA on June 24, Acting Executive Editor for the radio, Flame Nieuwenhuizen, said he would not precisely say what "rationalized form" implied.

"One thing might happen; Cabinet could decide to cut down the budget by October while discussions on the future of Channel Africa continue." He, however, said that he would not be able to say what would happen in the event that the budget is reduced.

But a Channel Africa employee who asked for anonymity told MISA that "the matter remains sensitive." He said there was still fear among journalists and other employees that "come October, Cabinet could decide to close down Channel Africa."

Said the employee: "This celebration that the government will continue to support Channel Africa is rather too early. Campaigning for continuation of Channel Africa from outside should continue or we could be surprised by the end decision."

Channel Africa broadcasts in seven languages to much of the African continent and Nieuwenhuizen claims that about 15 million people listen to this channel.

It is housed in the SABC's Johannesburg headquarters, and employs just over 100 staff plus 30 to 40 correspondents throughout Africa. For many years, the station was a propaganda tool of the apartheid regime, but Channel Africa has since changed along with the country's political development.

The service was first established in 1966 as Radio Republic of South Africa but repositioned itself as Channel Africa in 1992. It embarked on a transformation process resulting in a new mission statement which pledged to make the station "a comprehensive and authentically African communications forum which serves Africa from Africa, totally objective and credible and reliable, dedicated to the promotion of positive development in Africa, committed to the enhancement of dialogue, understanding and co-operation between all African people as their 'Channel of Goodwill'...'


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Tutu Says Farewell To His Anglican Province


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 28, 1996


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

Cape Town - South Africa said goodbye and thank you to the Archbishop Desmond Tutu of Cape Town and Metropolitan of the Church of the Province of Southern Africa, in a glittering service attended by clerics, kings and African leaders on June 23.

Heading the list of dignitaries attending the thanksgiving service at Saint George's Cathedral here were President Nelson Mandela, deputy president Thabo Mbeki and Fredrick de Klerk, Lesotho King Letsie III, Zulu King Goodwill Zwelethini, President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique and Sir Ketumile Masire, president of Botswana.

Mandela, in an address to the densely packed cathedral congregation, said that Tutu "has been a blessing and inspiration to countless people, here and abroad," and praised him as "a fearless fighter against the evil and inhuman system of apartheid."

Tutu, who will be 65 in October, hands over to a new archbishop of Cape Town, Njongonkulu Winston Ndugane, on June 30, but will continue as chairman of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is charged with uncovering the gross human rights violations of the apartheid era, and under certain conditions forgiving their perpetrators. 

This task is likely to last another 18 months after which the archbishop-emeritus will take up a university fellowship in Atlanta, Georgia.

Leading a battalion of bishops from the Anglican communion and from other churches around the world, the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, insisted: "No one would possibly say we have heard the last of Desmond Tutu."

In the course of a sermon from the cathedral pulpit, Carey described Tutu, who was awarded the Nobel Peace prize in 1984, as a "fearless

and outspoken critic of all that is unjust."

While Mandela was in jail, he said, "Desmond's voice was one of the few heard in my country and abroad."

Carey also spoke about the retiring archbishop's noted sense of humour. "His laughter ringing out has given courage to a downtrodden people," he said.

The Canterbury Archbishop gave a special award, which he said he had long been planning to institute, to Tutu as its first recipient. It is, Carey said, the Archbishop of Canterbury's award for outstanding service to the Anglican Communion.

Similarly, the World Council of Churches (WCC) paid tribute to retiring Archbishop Desmond Tutu, whom General Secretary Dr. Konrad Raiser described as a gift to the ecumenical movement and WCC in particular.

The message from the WCC General Secretary was presented by Rev. Dr. Alan Falconer, Director of Faith and Order.

On behalf of the WCC, its Central Committee, commissions and staff, Dr. Raiser paid tribute to "the incredible faith and hope which emanates from this man (Tutu) who has spurred on the veterans, stirred the complacent and inspired the young. He challenged and goaded and, so often, laughed and laughed until we cried."

Recalling Archbishop Tutu's compelling vitality, humour and challenge as he addressed the 1994 WCC Central Committee in Johannesburg, Raiser noted that after years of exclusion, "the WCC had finally returned with joy and thanksgiving to South African soil."

The WCC General Secretary also thanked Tutu's family whose constant support helped to keep the Bishop strong and well for his onerous tasks. "With gratitude we acknowledge the central role of (his wife) Leah, whose loving care and understanding sustained the Archbishop and enabled him to carry on," added Dr. Raiser.

The All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) also thanked Bishop Tutu for his commitment to the continental church body which he has served as President since 1987.

Mrs. Mary Jalan'go AACC Vice-President representing the Eastern Africa region, read the message on behalf of General Secretary Rev. Jose Chipenda.

In his capacity as President of the umbrella church body, Tutu has "piloted the ecumenical ship very safely" and "demonstrated excellent church diplomacy," said the AACC.

The AACC also highlighted Tutu's concern for peace and reconciliation in Africa, saying he has been a "roving ambassador on behalf of the churches. He has visited many countries to promote dialogue and reduce civil strife."

President Mandela also presented an award to Tutu: the Order of Meritorious Service (Gold), one of the country's most distinguished civilian honours.

The award is made for exceptionally meritorious service in the public interest, and the citation called Tutu "a champion of justice, truth and righteousness, and a fearless opponent of injustice."

Mandela in his address referred to Tutu's readiness to take unpopular positions without fear, and said that he speaks his mind on matters of public morality.

"As a result, he annoyed many of the leaders of the apartheid system. Nor has he spared those that followed -- he has from time to time annoyed many of us who belong to the new order," said the South African Head of State.

To laughter, the president added: "But such independence of mind -- however wrong and unstrategic it may be at times -- is vital to a thriving democracy."

Tutu, in a tearful speech, thanked all those who had supported him throughout his ministry. He thanked his dean, and his vicar- general, his predecessor Archbishop Philip Russel, and his wife and family.

He told President Mandela: "You are a precious gift to this land. You are a precious gift to the world."

United States President Bill Clinton stated in a message that Tutu epitomised the process of triumphant, democratic transformation. He was a leader in both struggle and reconciliation, Clinton said.

In a video message, American comedian Bill Cosby asked: "How do you retire from God?"

The thanksgiving service was an eclectic mixture of African and Anglican ritual.

Tutu, resplendent in a shining brocade robe, gave his final blessing in Xhosa, before leading his distinguished guests to sign a book of farewell.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Zambia faces major economic collapse


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 25, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has analysed the consequences of donor withdrawal from Zambia and forecast a major economic collapse if the trend is not reversed.

But government has insisted on taking a resolute stand condemning donors for tying political strings to economic programmes.

According to a June 13 report released by the UNDP last week, the flow of external aid to Zambia is dependent on adherence to "positive social, economic, and political reforms including the dictates of multi-party democracy and good governance". 

The report also revealed that the UNDP programmes in Zambia might be adversely affected by donor withdrawals, especially those which are co-financed.

However, finance minister Ronald Penza last Saturday insisted that the government has fulfilled its economic and financial benchmarks.

"We are now waiting for the donors to fulfill their obligations. If they do not pay I shall fail to service debts and the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Programme will have been seen to have failed," he said. "I am now waiting for my cheque."

But the report circulated to all major embassies, including the British, United States, German, and Norwegian embassies, said the recent constitutional and political developments in the country have raised the possibility of withdrawal of donor assistance, mainly the balance of payments support.

"This would put SAP and the overall economic recovery programme in disarray,"read the report. "The country's export earnings are insufficient to meet the country's critical import needs."

But economists and other market players are already pointing to the escalating exchange rate over the past few weeks as evidence of economic collapse.

"One US dollar now costs K1,350 compared to K1,000 three months ago. With the Kwacha falling and interest rates rising, the economy is going back into recession. There will be further job losses and misery," said Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) Economic Chairman, Rolf Shenton last Friday. " Zambia simply cannot afford this to happen."

Shenton added that "the people of this country have swallowed the bitter pill over the last five years to enable the MMD to manage a Structural Adjustment Programme".

Meebelo Mutukwa, an economist, said the country was in a deep crisis economically which needed immediate attention.

"We have to realise that politics must fall second to the economy and we must not jeopardise our bright economic future," Mutukwa said.

The UNDP report concluded that there are a number of donor-funded programmes in the social sector which would be affected by aid cuts, for example, health and education reforms. The agency hopes the withdrawal of aid should be selective to ease the plight of the poor.

Almost all key western donors among them Norway, Britain, the United States of America, Denmark and Germany are witholding aid in protest against Zambias violation of the issues raised by the UNDP report.


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Angola and Zambia UNITA rebels join National Army


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 24, 1996 by Mukalya Nampito


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - United Nations special envoy on Angola peace talks, Alioune Blondin Beye, said last week that about 51,000 UNITA rebels had been registered for the National Army.

Beye was speaking in reply to a question asking him to confirm reports that UNITA rebels were getting arms through Zaire.

He said he could not confirm this but that out of the 62,500 rebels, as of Wednesday 51,000 had been integrated and that they had brought some arms with them. He added that Zaire was a sovereign nation. 

"In the last few weeks, there has been some peace. Dr Jonas Savimbi (UNITA rebel leader) assured us that there would be peace. At least now there are no 1,000 people dying in Angola every day," Beye said in an interview on Friday. "The commitment made by UNITA is being implemented."

President Chiluba in welcoming Beye said Zambia had heard the difficulties that he was going through.

"Our role here is to try and listen from you the message of peace and to let us know what we can do to further strengthen the peace in Angola," President Chiluba said. "We are very hopeful that peace is coming in Angola."

Beye said the 600 Zambian soldiers sent to Angola had been deployed at the Angola/Namibia border and had done an excellent job.

He said the commandant had decided to send Zambian troops to that particular border because Zambia has good relations with Namibia.

UN secretary general, Boutros Boutros Ghali, in a May 22, 1996 letter to the Zambian UN representative, Peter Lesa Kasanda, expressed his gratitude for Zambia's participation in the peace-keeping mission.

"The dedicated and exemplary manner in which soldiers from your country performed this difficult and delicate operation, often under adverse conditions, met with the highest standards of international service and reflect great credit on your country and its armed forces," the letter read.

Beye also touched on the subject of Savimbi's vice-presidential appointment in the new Angolan government. He said this particular question has been an object of public discussion but there are still some details to be finalised before it is implemented and this may be at the extraordinary congress to be held by UNITA in August.

June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambian FOotball Association Turns Down Sponsor Deal


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 25, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - The Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) has turned down the US$40,000 deal with Zambia Breweries saying the amount involved is too small, it has been learnt.

Zambia's international consultant John Fashanu is said to have made the observation that the amount the Mosi company had offered was too small and advised FAZ to put off the deal in which Zambia Breweries had offered to sponsor the national team.

"Fashanu observed that the US$40,000 Zambia Breweries were offering us was too small and asked them to increase the money or forget about sponsoring the national team," said an official who attended the meeting held between FAZ officials and Zambia Breweries. 

Sources indicated that Fashanu insisted on putting off the deal considering that Zambia as Africa's highest rated team could not be getting anything less than what South Africa national team was getting.

"South Africa is sponsored by Anglo-American Company, the same firm that owns Zambia Breweries and South African Breweries. So Fashanu wondered how the money for Zambia could be that small when South Africa gets about US$400,000 a year," said a source who disclosed that Fashanu, who also represents the Tanzanian Football Association is trying to nullify a similar deal signed by Anglo-American's Tan- zania's Breweries.

"Anglo-American must be realistic that FAZ spends about US$40,000 on one trip and how can they offer that amount for a year? I think Fashanu must also go and modify the Tanzanian deal," suggested a soccer official.

But Mpashi who confirmed that the meeting was held last Tuesday, suggested only Zambia Breweries could issue a press statement.

"We had a meeting with Zambia Breweries officials but if you want information, get in touch with Breweries officials as they are the ones to talk on that," said Mpashi in an interview on Friday.

But when asked for a comment Augustine Seyuba, said he will need some time to make any comments.

"Get in touch with me say after a week's time, that is when I will be in a position to make any comments," Seyuba said.

Among the officials who attended the meeting included FAZ general secretary, Hermann Mpashi, his assistant Julio Chiluba, John Fashanu and one of his local assistants, Zambia Breweries' Augustine Seyuba who was in the company of another representative.

June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: Association Throws Out Friendly


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 26, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - The Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) has refused to allow the senior national soccer team to travel for an international friendly match against a South Korean under-23 team.

Informed sources indicated that FAZ decided to turn down the South Korean invitation extended to the soccer team because of short notice for the trip as well as the insufficient money on offer. 

"The South Koreans through their agents in England, KAM Sports International, asked us to send our senior national team for a two-match friendly trip to Korea but we are unable to send the team because we got the notice rather late," said the source.

But FAZ general secretary Hermann Mpashi, could not be reached for a comment on the trip as he was out of Lusaka on a private visit.

The South Koreans wanted to use the matches, in which the Zambians would have spent ten days in Korea as part of their preparations for the Olympics slated for Atlanta in America.

The source said the team had the trip put off because the US$20,000 the South Koreans offered for each match was not enough.

"We could not allow to be paid a mere US$20,000 per game because our team is the highest ranked in Africa," disclosed the source.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Rights Group Opposes Use Of Live Bullets


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 24, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - The Inter-Africa Network for Human Rights (Afronet) has condemned the use of live bullets for riot control saying such extreme force was unnecessary.

Afronet executive director Ngande Mwanajiti said in an interview on Friday, in reaction to the violent dispersal of UNIP cadres at the Lusaka Magistrate's Court the previous day, that police knew various techniques of crowd control which they could have safely used.

"I see no reason for using live bullets because there are acceptable ways to disperse crowds and the police know how to peacefully deal with violent crowds," he said. 

Mwanajiti said police should not use force at the slightest provocation and called for strict guidelines from the police command on when officers should fire at unarmed civilians.

"The gravity of the matter requires that the police high command should only give instructions to fire to officers who can defend such action," he said. "The use of arbitrary force can only worsen an otherwise tense situation."

Mwanajiti said police brutality made a mockery of the government's wish to establish a permanent human rights commission.

"The call for a human rights commission is inconsistent with what is happening in the country," he said.

And Zambia Civic Education Association chairperson Lucy Sichone, who braved bullets to rescue a girl who was being bludgeoned by paramilitary police during the confusion at the courts said in an interview on Friday that "at the moment there is simply no morality or compassion. Zambia is in the worst category of violators."

UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda at a press briefing yesterday condemned the violent suppression of the riot by the police, saying their brutality was "terrifying" and reminiscent of the Apartheid South African police action against unarmed black demonstrators.

"We demand the immediate abolition of the MMD police cadres, they should go home, away from the people," he said

The riot erupted after principal resident magistrate Francis Nsokolo rejected an application by lawyers representing the eight UNIP members facing treason charges that the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) should appear to explain the state of the docket police claim has been sent to his chambers.

The application came after defense lawyers were told by the DPP he has not received any docket on the matter but police kept on telling them it was with him. The defense feels the state is not ready with the case and just wants to use the unbailable treason charges to detain UNIP members without declaring a state of emergency which empowers the President to do so.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Olympics Nigeria Ends Pre-Olympic Trials


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 23, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lagos, Nigeria - The 1996 Nigeria track and field events to choose the country's athletes for the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, the United States, ended on June 22 in Lagos.

Some 20,000 spectators watched the finals at the National Stadium in Sururele, a Lagos neighbourhood, with the 100 metre race for men and women as major highlights. 

African track queen Mary Onyali-Omagbemi beat all comers in the women's 100-metre race, finishing in 10.67 seconds. She also won gold in the women's 200-metre race.

Davidson Ezinwa, another United States-based sprinter, won the men's 100-metre dash with a time of 9.86 seconds.

But the times are subject to confirmation because officials said they were manually recorded.

Two of Nigeria's four athletes, Chioma Ajunwa and Clement Chukwu, made impressive comeback after serving their four-year ban by the International Athletics Federation.

Chioma came second behind Onyali-Omagemi in the 100-metre women's race and picked up the gold in the long jump. Chukwu, on the other hand, placed third in the 400 metres behind policeman Sunday Bada and Jude Monye who placed first and second in the explosive race.

Two other returnees Charity Okpara and Innocent Asonze were not as lucky.

June, 1996


United States and Africa Groups Set Vigil on Zaire


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 26, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Washington, DC - The following is the text of a press release by a coalition of groups interested in Zaire.

The All North America Conference on Zaire, the Committee of the Democratic Forces of Zaire, and the Zaire Educational Council announce a MARCH and MATANGA, an all-night vigil, organized to hasten the end of one of the most ruthless dictatorships left on earth. The march will (1) commemorate countless martyrs who died in the struggle against dictatorship; (2) call for increased resources, monitoring and enforcement personnel for free and fair elections in July 1997; (3) protest against the support accorded by the Republican Right, the Clinton Administration and the Republic of France for the illegal government of Mobutu and Kengo wa Dondo; (4) and will remind the American people, whose money was used to build dictatorship in Zaire, that Mobutu is still to be brought to justice for perpetrating genocide in Rwanda, Burundi, Angola, and Zaire.

Leaders of the movement to end dictatorship in Zaire will arrive in the Washington Metropolitan Area during the week of June 24th 1996 to attend this historic event. Activities will take place in Lafayette Park (in front of the White House), Washington, D.C. on June 30th, 1996 and July 1st, 1996 at 12:00 Noon.

Other Sponsors include Zaire Network, Alumni of the American School of Kinshasa, The International Association for Zaire, The Zaire Community of Iowa, The Zaire Community of Minnesota, Zairian Community Charlotte (North Carolina), La Mutualite Zairoise de Philadelphie, Concerned American Citizens, Immigrants, and Exiles of Zairian Origin, Forum Zairois, The Zairian Community of Lexington, Kentucky.

For further information please contact Dr. Alafuele Kalala, (301) 460-1533, Dr. Mwana N. Mawampanga, (606) 269-2714 or Tshimanga John Metzel (202) 783-2777.
