59 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Rail Authority Works Out Survival Plan


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 26, 1996 by Rose Nyanga


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Mufulira - Rather than cow in a cocoon of fear and despair that the competition brought about by the opening of the southern trade route would wipe them out, the Tanzania Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA) and its partners on the Dar-es-Salaam corridor have decided to meet the challenge head on and plan on how to win the battle.

TAZARA which for years enjoyed the monopoly of being the only rail outlet for Zambia to sea now has to cope with stiff competition from the southern route, which under the Unilateral Declaration of Independence (UDI) became practically impossible for Zambia to use due to political reasons.

With the liberation of countries in Southern Africa and the opening of free trade in the region, however, the inevitable had to happen. Flow of traffic on the corridor was affected. 

Traffic on the TAZARA has since reduced drastically and operations are just over 50 percent capacity level according to TAZARA deputy managing director Mr Ernest Mulokozi.

Mr Mulokozi told a visiting team of Zambian pressmen in Dar-es-Salaam recently Zamcargo haulage on the TAZARA had fallen from about one million tonnes of cargo per annum in 1992-93 to about 600,000 tonnes today.

He said that the task for his company now was to try and improve the situation through attraction of more customers by offering competitive freight conditions and dealing with customers on an individual basis while leaving room for negotiation. So far customer response has been encouraging, he said.

The prime objective of all the actors on the Dar-es-Salaam corridor now is to operate more efficiently as a single train while capitalising on the fact that the route still offers the shortest altenative to sea for a number of countries in central Africa.

As far as Zambia is concerned, the port of Dar-es-Salaam is nearest in terms of distance compared to other South African ports.

The distance between Dar-es-Salaam and Lusaka by rail for instance is 2150 kilometres while Dar and the Copperbelt is 1650 km on the other hand, the distance between Lusaka and Cape Town is 3100 kilometres, Lusaka to Maputo is 2007 kilometres and Lusaka to Lobito is 2700 kilometres.

Director-General of the Tanzania Harbours Authority (THA) Mr Samson Luhingo echoed Mr Mulokozi's sentiments saying the entire corridor will have to exploit the shorter distance advantage that the routeenjoys over the other routes of the south to survive the competition.

As a major factor on the corridor, the rail is committed to providing the best services for customer satification.

TAZARA works out survival plan two Mufulira Mr Luzingo said that competition that was now being posed by the southern routes was in fact healthy and good for business.

''We are not going to dig a grave and bury ourselves just because the south has opened up to business and is posing a big challenge for us. We are taking on the challenge,'' he said.

Since the onset of free trade especially with the south, the quality of service provided on the Dar-es-Salaam corridor has tremendously improved, triggered of course by the rising talent of competition.

Transit time for cargo from Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) to the port of Dar and unto the ship for instance has been reduced from an average of three weeks to under two weeks.

Zamcargo Tanzania regional manager, Mr Andrew Musonda, said that the future for the corridor was bright.

He said for the first time in years, Zambian copper was able to move from source to the port in just under two weeks.

''Operations on the Dar corridor are on the road to improvement because all players, that is Zambia Railways, TAZARA and the Tanzania Harbours Authority are working as a single chain for the benefit on the customers,'' Mr Musonda said.

The players in the corridor meet quarterly to map out strategies of continued survival in view of the now existing competitive market. The last meeting was on May 1 in Malawi.

Mr Musonda said that there was in fact room for further improvement of transit time on the TAZARA and as soon as this was achieved, the entire corridor would offer more advantages than any other route for Zambia.

As the saying goes, the taste of the pudding is in eating it. The factors on the dar corridor are challenging importers and exporters in these parts of the Africa to try their service. They may never regret it.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

Issue Date: July 1, 1996


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Minister Says Aid Cuts Unfair


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 26, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - Finance and Economic Development Minister, Ronald Penza, today maintained that Zambia has not breached any conditions of good governance for the developed donor countries to cut development aid.

Speaking on Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation radio programme "Tell the Nation" programme this morning, Mr Penza said Zambia has not interfered with any fundamental human right enshrined in the constitution. 

He said the problem was with international co-operating partners who have a different perception of the newly assented constitution.

Mr Penza, therefore, called on Zambians to work hard to make the economy in the country vibrant rather than keep talking of the constitution which has already been assented to. He said Zambians had the responsibility of developing the economy and of creating an enabling environment in the country.

Mr Penza said Zambia was not poor in the real sense except that she has a huge debt left behind by former Republican President, Dr Kenneth Kaunda.

Meanwhile Mr Penza has urged police not to detain people if they had no evidence, saying this only embarrased the government.

He said in order not to breach the confidence of people in their government detained people should be taken before courts of law as early as possible.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Ghana The Ultimate Showdown


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) June 26, 1996 by Theo Nicol


LENGTH: 1707 words


 

Accra - Ghanaian leader, Jerry Rawlings and Kow Arkaah, the vice-president, are set to clash in what could be an acrimonious presidential election.

Months back Jerry Rawlings, the Ghanaian president, hit the headlines on turning his vice, Kow Nkensen Arkaah, into a punching bag during a heated argument in the cabinent chambers. Many observers were shocked by the barbaric act and wondered why Rawlings would not choose the more honourable option of sacking Arkaah if relations between them had completely broken down.

The fact, however, is that Rawlings' hands are tied by the 1992 constitution which midwifed the return of democracy in Ghana after years of military misrule. According to the constitution, the president and his vice must work together under all circumstances and must leave office together, except one dies or the other resigns. What that means is that the president cannot sack the vice-president. If the vice-president chooses not to resign his appointment, he could only be removed by impeachment or a referendum. 

But the "marriage" between Rawlings and Arkaah is an unholy one. The two men come from different political parties. Rawlings is of the National Democratic Coalition while Arkaah joined the cabinet on the platform of the National Convention Party, with which the NDC struck an alliance after the last elections. Worse, both the president and his vice are temperamental and see things from different perspectives. In the circumstances, conflcits and disagreements over how the country should be governed, how policies should be implemented and how issues are to be handled, have become a part of life in the presidency.

That Rawlings and Arkaah do not think alike could be partly attributed to the generation gap that exists between them. While Rawlings is a young, active man in his early 50s, Arkaah is 68. Besides, both men come from contrasting backgrounds: Rawlings is a career soldier who rose to the rank of flight lieutenant in the Ghanaian Air Force before he became head of state in 1979; Arkaah is a technocrat.

The ultimate showdown between the two strange bedfellows is expected to take place this December when they square off in the presidential elections. For Arkaah, the road to a shot at the presidency was cleared June 9 when his new party, the People's Convention Party, voted him its presidential candidate for the elections, slated for December 10. He polled 952 votes, representing 62.7 percent of the total votes cast to beat six others at the PCP's first National Delegates Conference held at the Great Hall of the University of Ghana, Legon, Accra. Arkaah's victory did not, however, go down well with everyone. His opponents refused to accept defeat. They accused Arkaah of buying votes and of using the power of incumbency to influence the election results. Some argued taht he should have resigned as vice-president before the elections.

But it was an elated and unruffled Arkaah that mounted the rostrum minutes after the results were announced to address the press. "I am very happy today," he told the newsmen. "The election was life and death for me. My victory is very important. Now I can resign (his appointment as vice-president) and damn that boy called Rawlings."

The next day the pro-Rawlings Ghana Palaver newspaper took on Arkaah, dismissing him as "a rolling stone that gathers no moss." According to the newspaper, Arkaah has hardly served for more than three years with any firm organisation in his working life. "The only exception," say the paper, "seems to be the vice-presidency, and even here, it is believed that the vice-president had hoped for a miraculous elevation to the presidency by the third year in office. This probably accounts for his frustration at not making it this time around which found vent in undermining the government of which he is vice-president, even after his party had abrogated the alliance with the NDC which gave him the vice-presidency on a platter of gold."

Arkaarh's currculum vitae casts him in the mould of an adventurous soul, as it shows that he worked for short spells in Ghana, Sierra Leone and The Gambia before he went into politics. He was educated at Harvard University, U.S.A. and was once a consultant to the United Nations. Among the firms Arkaah has worked with are PZ in Sierra Leone, for less than three years, before it collapsed in the 1970's; a trading company in The Gambia, where he was asked to leave after a short spell; and Ghana Airways, for a year. Arkaah later worked for two years with International Trading Operations, Ghana from 1986-88; three months as a consultant in Ethiopia; one year as a consultant with Johnson Products and nine months with the Economic Commission for Africa. He then returned to Ghana to work for a year with Ghana Airways, and for about three years with GNTC.

Whatever may be his faults, Arkaah's new party, the PCP, believes that he is the best material they have to contest the presidency against Rawlings. As Ghanaians prepare to go to the polls to elect a new president and parliament to usher in the fourth republic in line with the 1992 constitution, the air is heavy with political bitterness. Candidates who have just emerged from the party primaries, and even the parties themselves, are using the polarised press to haul brickbats at their opponents. There are three major parties in the race for Osu Castle, another name for the presidential mansion. They are Arkaah's PCP, Rawlings' NDC and J.A. Kufuor's New Patriotic Party.

As the elections draw near, the PCP and NPP are whipping up traditional sentiments in a desperate bid to upstage the ruling party. Both claim to be offshoots of Kwame Nkrumah's political dynasty and therefore expect elderly Ghanaians to vote for them as they would have done for Nkrumah, if he were still alive and contesting the election.

This sentiment could perhaps have had some meaning if the presidential candidates had the same charisma or organisational ability as Nkrumah, the Osafyefo. The PCP, for one, was only able to hold its primaries after a long delay and not less than seven candidates contested. Arkaah's victory in the elections that climaxed a very bitter and rancorous campaigns has been rejected by all the defeated candidates, leaving the party more divided than before. The NPP had earlier elected John Agyekum Kufuor as its presidential candidate under similar acrimonious circumstances.

As they did in 1992, the PCP and NPP have agreed to form an alliance against Rawlings. As early as October 1995, the two parties had signified their interest in merging to get Rawlings out of office. But internal bickerings may mar this brillant political strategy. For instance, the defeated presidential aspirants in PCP are yet to accept Arkaah as their presidential candidate and are not ready to support him. Instead, they are calling on him to resign his appointment as vice-president, a call he is not ready to heed. A more serious problem facing the alliance is the question of who to choose as a common presidential candidate. Although both Kufuor and Arkaah have in seperate interviews pledged to respect the wishes of the party members, who are expected to choose a presidential candidate for the alliance, observers believe that a rather gregarious Arkaah may not easily accept defeat if the primaries turn against him. Kufuor, too, is likely to cry foul if he loses to Arkaah. This is likely to weaken the alliance and strengthen Rawlings' chances of returning to Osu Castle for a second four-year term as Ghana's elected president.

Apart from the apparent disunity in the parties, Rawlings' power of incumbency is a major factor that could work in his favour. While the other politicans are still struggling for support at the party level, Rawlings and his very active wife keep moving from village to village at the grassroot level, commissioning one completed project or the other, or establishing new ones, using such opportunities to campaign for re-election.

While the other parties are still trying to get their acts together, Rawlings' NDC has already started campaigning nationwide through newspaper and television advertisments, using powerful slogans to convince voters that Rawlings is still the answer to Ghana's problems.

A more important factor in Rawlings favour is his attitude towards the aggressive and insultive opposition presion. With all the provocation, Rawlings has tolerated the opposition press and is likely to do so till at least the end of the elections, so as not to be branded as a dictator.

In the final analysis, a Rawlings victory in December may not necessarily lie in his strength as a much loved candidate, but in the weakness of his opponents who seem to have aged and style very much against him.

Issue Date: July 1, 1996


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


62 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Air Safety Questioned


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) July 26, 1996 by Amos Esele


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Lagos - The death, in a plane crash, of Mohammed Wase, military administrator of Kano State and 11 others once more brings into focus the poor state of aviation facilities in the country.

The Nigerian government and aviation officials are becoming wiser by the day with each fatal aircrash involving prominent personalities. Since the death of Ibrahim Abacha, son of the head of state, and 13 others in January 17 presidential plane crash in Kano, official reaction had stopped blaming every air disaster in the country on "an act of God."

The early morning fatal plane crash that killed Mohammed Abdullahi Wase, a colonel and administrator of Kano Sate and 11 others, June 19, was from all indications, not an act of God. 

The chartered 19 seater Gulf Stream II, with registration number VRD-BLJ reportedly took off from Kano airport at 7.01 a.m. for Jos, Plateau State, that fateful Thursday. Wase and his entourage had left early enough ostensibly to condole his father on the death of another of his sons, Bashir, before attending the commissioning of some projects in his home town of Wase by Ishaya Bamaiyi, Chief of Army Staff. Accompanying Wase on the trip were Mohammed Vice Adamu, special duties commissioner; Dambo Gambo, managing director of state housing corporation; Sulaiman Dambata, a director general of the government house; Eli Atabor, a captain and aide-de-camp to Wase; as well as Jauru Awak, a corporal and Wase's orderly. Others were Sule Batsari and Mohammed Mohammed, friends of the administrator, John Howell, the pilot and Allen Taylor, the co-pilot.

Thirty minutes later, the journey was about to end on a successful note when the first sign of tragedy suddenly appeared in the skies. The weather was foggy and the British-born pilot had problems landing in the poorly equipped Jos airport. The Instruments Landing System at the airport packed up way back in February 1991, leaving pilots familiar with the environment to navigate their way by instinct.

Suddenly aware that the ILS, which guides safe landing through data information to pilots, was out of order, Howell was said to have radioed the control tower to announce his intention to brave the odds. This was after he had missed the runway in his first attempt to land. Warned to be careful as visibility was low at 250 feet, a far cry from the normal 800 feet, Howell sought alternative information from the pilot of a Kabo aircraft waiting to take off. The comrade's information was not different from that of the control tower. Howell then tried to find a route to approach the runway for safe landing. That was the fatal decision. In his attempt to land, the plane hit the transmission towers of the Nigerian telecommunications PLc in Kassa village 42 kilometers from Jos, exploded in mid-air before crash landing in flames. All occupants were mangled beyond recognition.

A pistol, a magazine and a cellular phone set were found in the wreckage. Mohammed Mana, Plateau State administrator who supervised operations at the airport, directed that the found items be kept with security agents. All the Nigerian victims were buried a few hours later according to Muslim rites, at Zaria Road Cemetery, while the bodies of the pilots were deposited at the Jos morgue.

Sani Abacha, head of state and Oladipo Diya, chief of general staff, led a large number of mourners from the presidency and the cabinet.

There was no immediate official statement on the accident. Samuila Nakama, director general of Federal Aviation Authority who immediately travelled to Jos airport in company of his managing director, Sani Baba, however, said that the crash could have been caused by engine or weather problems.

Though 31-years old, the aircraft, run for the past 15 years by NANCO, a member of the Dantanta business empire of Kano, reportedly had a history of good health. This made it the choice aircraft of several dignitaries such as emirs, businessmen and state officials like Wase, who regularly used it.

Born in 1948 at Wase, some kilometers from his death place, Wase in 1993 briefly served as sole administrator of National Electoral Commission following the sack of its chairman, Humphrey Nwosu, after the annulment of the June 12 presidential election.

with Fatai Salami and Yemi Akanbi.

Issue Date: July 1, 1996


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


63 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Former President May Be Abiola Suspect?


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) June 26, 1996 by Godwin Agbroko


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4440 words


 

Lagos - The administration's suspicions turn to former President Ibrahim Babangida on the June 4 Murder of Kudirat Abiola. Is this a case of calling a dog a bad name?

If it were a religious schism, then some of the rising pressure in the cauldron could be let off by break-away factions. This time, the object in the pressure cooker is far from spiritual, it is one apparently with no safety valve, welling up as it were from the grossest of banal passions - power.

The chief characters in the live soap opera about to unfold before drama-loving Nigerians are the military quartet of Sani Abacha, head of state, Ibrahim Babangida, Muhammadu Buhari, and Tunde Idiagbon. Apart from the very brief interregnum of Ernest Shonekan's interim government, all three have ruled Nigeria except for Idiagbon, who served as Buhari's side-kick. Ironically, it is Abacha and Babangida - mentor and protege - that are pitted against each other, with the pair of Buhari and Idiagbon playing a supporting role on Abacha's side. 

On June 4, the opera reached a dramatic flashpoint with the murder of Kudirat, wife of the detained politician, Moshood Abiola. A source who was with Abacha on that day when the news was broken to him said the head of state was crestfallen. According to the source, Abacha's immediate response was: "My God." After a prolonged silence, he muttered, "Why have they done this to me?" A few days after Kudirat was shot to death on the streets of Lagos, a politician visited one of the topmost officials of the administration at Aso Rock. In the course of their discusiions, what looked like an answer to Abacha's question started to emerge. The official told his guest that the the government was damn sure that the intention of the killers of Kudirat was to embarrass the administration and to strengthen its already odious reputation at home and abroad. As if answering Abacha's question on hearing of the assassination, the official said the administration was of the suspicion that the mastermind was Babangida whom he accused of being capable of incalculable mischief.

In the thinking of the official, part of that mischief may have to do with eliminating Kudirat to prevent her struggle for the restoration of the presidential mandate of Abiola which Babangida annulled in 1993 and consequently forced him to vacate the presidency prematurely.

It was that suspicion that shaped government's reaction. The day after the assassination, the head of state expressed government's determination to track down the killers. That was followed immediately by a condolence message in which Abacha poured fulsome eulogies on the slain Kudirat as a caring mother with the virtues of a motivator and counsellor and one whose death at this time of Nigeria's political development was a loss to the nation. That same day, the government despatched a 10-man delegation to condole the Abiola family. To give effect to its words, the administration immediately constituted an investigating team to be headed by Archibong Nkana, the deputy inspector-general of police in charge of the Federal Investigations and Intelligence Bureau. Apart from a genuine desire to apprehend the killers, the official told his visiting friend that the government's uncharacteristically swift response was aimed at ensuring that the agent provocateur did not realise his intention and to assure the international community that it was blameless.

For now, the administration seems to be handling its suspicion with utmost care. Even so, Theweek learnt that Babangida was summoned to Abuja immediately after the news of Kudirat's assassination. A source close to Aso Rock says that on June 5, the day after the murder, Babangida had an audience with the head of state. What transpired at the meeting is still a secret but the source conjectured that Abacha may have summoned the former head of state either to size him up or to broach the subject of his suspicion.

If Abacha pursues the present line of suspicion, it could only lead to a climax of a long simmering clash that started the very day Babangida stepped out of office on August 26, 1993. Three years after, the mystery of how Abacha survived Babangida in government continues to persist. There are varied conjectures. One version has it that Babangida's precipitate departure was forced on him by rumours of an impending coup. He was said to have felt that even if he were out of office, the coup could still occur and rebound on him. To stave off that eventuality, he left Abacha behind to contain any possible insurrection. Another says that in the twilight days of his regime, Babangida had lost out to Abacha in the game of loyalist in the military hierarchy. And when Abacha insisted on staying behind, Babangida had no choice but to leave him alone. And yet another which seemed to have the most plausibility was that when Babangida saw his going as inevitable, he installed Abacha whom he regarded as his closest collaborator in government in the interim administration. In Babangida's reasoning, according to this version, Abacha who was then directly in line of succession to Shonekan was to serve as the surrogate that would enable him cling to power or stage a come-back.

If Babangida's intention was to hold onto power by whatever means, his designs soon exploded in his face. The day after he left office, he caused Duro Onabule - still styling himself the chief press secretary - to announce replacements for the service chiefs whom Babangida had forced into retirement with himself. Abacha, as secretary of defense, reacted swiftly by quashing the appointments, except for one or two that were agreeable to him. Next Abacha moved to dismantle Babangida's clique of loyalists within the military by retirements and redeployments. On November 17, Abacha received a purported letter of resignation from Shonekan and installed himself as head of state.

Abacha's first actions as head of state were a clear signal that the Babangida era had truly come to an end. In his maiden broadcast the day he took over power, Abacha axed the parliament and all other democratic structures that were the monument to Babangida's eight-year transition programme. In addition, he promised to restructure the armed forces and to reform government establishments and parastatals, an euphemism for purging all the institutions of vestiges of Babangida's influence. That month, the new head of state sent 17 Babangida "boys" out of the armed forces into retirement.

In all this, the most telling blow was struck, not at the level of officaldom, but at the domestic front. On May 17, 1994, Maryam Babangida's object of obsession, the Better Life Programme, BLP, for which she won international awards, was brought down. In a memo on that day, Abubakar Abudullahi, writing on behalf of the principal secretary to the head of state direct that all posters, signboards and inscriptions bearing the BLP logo should be changed to reflect the new project - the Family Support Programme, FSP, the creation of Maryam Abacha, wife to the new head of state. The memo said the programme was changed because of "the general public outcry against the BLP for its elitist, theorectical and flambuoyant nature and outlook, and the need to redefine the scope and objectives of the programme to conform with the practical realities and the mood of the nation." No indictment of licentiousness of the Babangida era could have been more scathingly phrased. Even so, the more painful barb was to come in the renaming of the Maryam Babangida Centre and the change of the ownership structure to exclude the former First Lady completely from the centre.

Though it is difficult to put a finger exactly on the cause of the rift between Abacha and Babangida, it seems certain that it has to do with an erstwhile protege trying to assert to his former mentor that a new sun had arisen and that the ancient regime was dead for good. Having dealt with virtually all the high and mighty that could pose an opposition to him, the only man left that Abacha seems to be mortally afraid of is Babangida, an adept at creating pockets of civilian and military loyalists, a master tactician and strategist at coup-making, and above all, a man believed to be full of intrigues and guile.

The presence of Babangida is said to have been making Abacha acutely uncomfortable despite the numerous retirements and redeployments of civilian and military personnel in the past. Only now is he said to be feeling a little more secure with the conclusion of the recent mass retirements from the armed forces. Early on, Abacha had given a clear signal that he bore the former head of state a deep animus when he reportedly said that he was marginalised under the Babangida regime. Babangida was said to have been taken aback by that statement, coming from a supposedly bosom friend whom he used to refer to fondly as his co-collaborator in government. In fact, Babangida as president was said to have relied most on Abacha's advice in taking crucial decisions. So confounded was the former head of state that he was said to have confessed to his close associates that he didn't really know Abacha.

Since then, more shocks have come the way of Babangida, the latest apparently being the suspicion of his complicity in Kudirat's murder. Only recently, the Kaduna State government took on Sunny Okogwu, the elder brother to Babangida's wife, Maryam. Ostensibly waging a war on tax evaders, the tax auditors have written to Okogwu to provide details of his business activities in Nigeria and abroad, including certified financial accounts of his companies. Furthermore, he was told to appoint a "competent tax consultant who will liase between you and the tax authorities at the federal, state and local government levels, including appeals against assessment."

If Okogwu were to go by the words of Habib then his fate is a foregone conclusion. If the proposal of the state government is carried out, then Babangida's brother-in-law could be hauled before the miscellaneous offenses tribunal, tried and jailed as a common tax felon. For as Yakubu, executive chairman of the state's internal revenue board has declared, Okogwu has been filing false declarations of tax returns to the board in the past six years. What seems intriguing in the Okogwu case is the interest of the board not only in knowing about his business in Kaduna State alone, but throughout Nigeria and abroad. And what is more, the directive to him to appoint a competent tax consultant to liase between him and the federal government. Those who claim to be in the know see the action of the state government as that of a proxy to the federal authorities who may wish to get at Babangida eventually since he is believed to be in business partnership with his in-law. Okogwu had walked a similar path before. During the Buhari regime which Babangida overthrew, the government had shut down Okogwu's company in Kaduna because according to Buhari, "there was an investigation by security agencies that a civilian outfit is growing out of a military establishment." If any was needed, Buhari's statement was proof that Babangida, at the time the chief of army staff, was hand-in-gloves with his brother in-law in business matters.

Still, whatever designs Abacha have on him, Babangida might ultimately perish by his own hubris. He triggered off his current travails more than a decage ago when he light-heartedly sacked Buhari's government on August 17, 1985. Though he was the regime's chief of army staff and highly visible member of the Supreme Military Council, Babangida turned round to castigate Buhari and Idiagbon in overflowing measures. In his coup-day manifesto, Babangida thundered that "The principles of discussions, consultations and cooperation which should have guided the decision-making process of the SMC and the Federal Executive Council were disregarded soon after the government settled in 1984." Turning specifically on Buhari, he said it was regrettable that the former head of state "was too rigid and uncompromising in his attitude to issues of national significance (and) efforts to make him understand that a diverse polity like Nigeria required recognition and appreciation of differences in both cultural and individual perspectives only served to aggravate these attitudes."

To Idiagbon, the vitriol was no less corrosive. His upbraiding of Idiagbon sounded like the appraisal of a junior officer. "As chief of staff, Supreme Headquarters, he failed to exhibit the appropriate disposition demanded by his position." And castigating his pig-headedness, Babangida said Idiagbon "arrogated to himself absolute knowledge of problems and solutions and acted in accordance with what was convenient to him, using the machinery of government as his tool."

All of that was understandable as the rationalisation of a man who forcibly took over power. What was not so clear was the severity of the punishment he inflicted on Buhari and Idiagbon thereafter. Immediatley he came to power, Babangida clamped Buhari into what he described as protective custody. He was to remain there for upward of three years until he was released in December 1988. Indeed, it was the death of his mother, Hajiya Julaiba Musa, who Buhari was not around to bury that finally moved the government into releasing him. In the meantime, Buhari's marriage to Safinatu had collasped, leading to a divorce.

Idiagbon was on pilgrimage to Mecca when Babangida struck. Apparently encouraged by government's announcement that all political fugitives were free to return home, Idiagbon turned up in Nigeria in September 1985 and was promptly placed under house arrest in Bauchi. He was to regain his freedom on December 16, 1988, shortly after Buhari's release. Even so, the freedom of both men was partial as they were restricted to their local government areas and barred from speaking to the press. These restrictions were only lifted almost after a year in August 1989. This kind of treatment could only have sprung either from a pathological fear of the straight-arrowed duo or from vendetta.

Whatever the sources, of the punitive measure, it strained the relationship between the erstwhile friends beyond repair. And Buhari who appeared to have suffered more personal losses took measured steps to demonstrated the depth of his angers even while Babangida was still in power. The first public demonstration of Buhari's anger came on February 21, 1991 when Babangida paid an official visit to Daura, Buhari's hometown. He ensured that he was away to Kaduna days before Babangida called. As a former head of state and a Daura prince, Buhari was conspicuous by his absence at the civic reception for the then head of state.

In less than four months afterwards, he had other occasions even on a grander scale to vent his spite. At the opening ceremony of the 27th summit of the Organisation of African Unity at Abuja in June 1991, Babangida proudly put on display Nigeria's surviving heads of state. The roll call: Yakubu Gowon, Olusegun Obasanjo and Shehu Shagari. Absent was Buhari. He confirmed that he received an invitation and would at a conducive time inform the people why he chose to abstain. Soon after, he took a blistering swipe at the Babangida transition programme on a BBC interview in his farm house in Daura. Saying that the elections would not be free and fair, he predicted that "people may elect candidate A while candidate X will emerge the winner."

It was not until 1993 in the dying days of the Babangida regime that Buhari came out full blast against his erstwhile tormentor. In an interview with The News in June that year, he described the government as totally lacking in credibility. His indictment: "In terms of the Second Republic, we reached the same stage again. This present government has no credibility inside or outside the country." Attacking the administration for graft and corruption, he described Babangida's government as a "hostage leadership" whose interests were at variance with those of Nigerians.

Even with Babangida out of office, Buhari's icy attitude did not thaw. When both men met for the first time since the August 1985 coup, the bostitlity was so thick as to be almost visible. The day was June 24, 1994 and the occasion was the simultaneous marriage ceremonies of seven daughters of Sani Zango Daura, a prominent Daura indigene. Buhari and Babangida arrived the Emir of Daura's palace, venue of the wedding, at different times and sat, one immediately to the left of the Emir and the other immediately to the right. The two former heads of state did not utter a word to each other. At the end of the ceremony, Buhari made to go away immediately but was halted by the Emir who introducted Babangida as his visitor. Buhari managed to limp a handshake and scurried to his home. Later, Babangida in the company of Shehu Yar'Adua and other dignitaries had to drive to Buhari's house in an attempt to heal the breach.

The reconciliation evidently didn't work. Less than four months after the Daura event, Buhair took his second public step to strike back at Babangida. The first of such moves occurred on November 5, 1994 during the launching of the Family Support Programme meant to erase the Better Life Programme of Babangida's spouse. Buhari's presence there was seen not only as an endorsement of the FSP but a vote of confidence on the BLP it was replacing. In that same month, the former head of state accepted to serve as the chairman of the administration's Petroleum Trust Fund, PTF. Buhari's chummy relationship with the administration is said to derive from his belief that "Abacha could be encouraged to do the right thing." And doing the right thing in Buhari's mind is by "bringing Babangida to book" through probing him.

Idiagbon, unlike Buhari, did not utter a word publicly all the while that Babangida was in power. His first public utterance came on January 29 last year. At a lecture he chaired in Katsina to honour Buhari for the conferment of an honorary doctorate on him, Idiagbon, apparently referring to the locust years of Babangida lamented that "General Buhari showed the torch but we refused to follow the light." He proceeded to narrate the pressures that were piled on Buhari to elevate himself to the rank of a four-star general and the numerous entreaties of various communities to bestow traditional titles on him, all to no avail. "The policy of our administration," Idiagbon said, "was that we should not honour ourselves."

Even in his moment of glory, Buhari could not help taking a swipe at his old foe. Dismissing accusations of having abused the trust reposed on him as Nigeria's leader, he declared: "If the weakest point of a leader is abusing trust, I have less weakness than some of my colleagues that incarcerated me and labelled me as dishonest." Disclosing that he had declared his assets three times, he volunteered to do so again along with past Nigerian leaders. His challenge: "I invite my other colleagues, former heads of state to declare their own assets, including mine and the difference we have between what we have declared and what is worked out to be our legitimate earnings, let them take it over and prosecute us." The object of his baiting was obvious.

Abacha is apparently exploiting this animosity. It was what got Buhari to his side of the plot in the impending confrontation with Babangida. Using the logic that the enemy is my friend, Abacha has sought to draw Idiagbon into the foray. Theweek learnt that about two months ago, the adminstration approached Idiagbon with the offer of chairmanship of the failed contracts tribunal to be set up soon. Using tactics identified to those it adopted in getting Buhari to come on board, the government sent a delegation of eminent persons for whom Idiagbon has tremendous respect to Ilorin to try to persuade him to regard the offer as a service to the nation. In their attempts, members of the delegation tried to strike a responsive cord by appealing to him to aid in clearing the scandalous mess of abandoned contracts now depriving the masses of needed infrastructure and services. At a stage they even restorted to subtle flattery; that the new government measures were actually lifted from Buhari-Idiagbon era when probity and accountability in government business was a public policy.

So far, Idiagbon remains unpersuaded. It is said that Buhari had advised against the offer because Idiagbon is yet to be convinced that the political atmosphere was conducive for him to venture into public life. That was precisely the answer with which he politely warded off the delegation. As a source put it, "Idiagbon definitely understands the forces at play in this government, and having suffered incarceration once, does not wish to suffer it again."

The administration is said to have been surprised that Idiagbon did not eagerly accept the job from where he would be in a eminent position to deal with Babangida and the acolytes who received patrongage from him. It is believed that any serious probe of failed contracts would thorougly discredit the Babangida era, if not taint his person indelibly. Perhaps, it was the belief that Idiagbon would finally come around to the government side that made Abacha to announce the proposed setting up of the panel with fanfare last month. There is no doubt that Idiagbon's participation in such would have enhanced its credibility to no ends. During his brief sojourn on the national landscape, he came to represent for Nigerians, the quintessence of honesty, integrity and all that is noble. His long hibernation from the public has only added to his mystic. It is all these qualities that the Abacha government has tried to exploit.

Whether the administration would push its suspicions of Babangida to the logical conclusion or employ other weapons in the simmering face-off is as yet uncertain. What seems clear, however, is that the killing of Kudirat has affected the government in a fundamental sense. Unlike in the past when discussions of Abiola's freedom is rebuffed by the government with inflexible determination, it now seems sobered enough to give serious consideration to the issue. An authoritative source has told Theweek that the head of state himself has directed Oyebade-Lipede, the Alake of Egba-Land, from where the detained politician hailed, to hold a meeting urgently with the Abiola family to discuss the modalitites for the release of the head of the household. It is not clear whether the police would have to release such arrested members of the family as are necessary for the discussion with the Abiola family. It is said that Abacha wants to meet with the Alake alone and nobody else. According to the source, the presidency has asked that everything should be done to ensure that Lipede who is said to be slightly indisposed gets to Aso Rock for the meeting.

For the investigating police team last week, it was routine as usual as it continued to invite scores of persons who were known to have been close to the deceased in one way or the other while she was alive. If that is the signpost of the future, then the only good that may turnout, if it can called one, is that Kudirat used her blood as a ransom for Abiola's freedom.

With Yusuph Olaniyonu, Emmanuel Ado in Kaduna, Jaiyeola Ajasa, TAye Ige, and Ukpong Kalu Mba

Issue Date: July 1, 1996


LOAD-DATE: July 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


64 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Consortium Snubs Editorial Charter


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Jacquie Golding-Duffy


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Johannesburg - The National Empowerment Consortium, which isheading the bid for a stake in Times Media Limited's owner,Johnnic, has trashed the idea of an editorial charter as long asit remains a pre-condition of sale.

Cyril Ramaphosa, who is soon to be executive deputy chairman ofNew Africa Investments Limited (Nail), snubbed TML management byrejecting its idea for an editorial charter which was presented tohim for his seal of approval.

The editors have publicly declared the charter as a means of"preserving age-old traditions and editorial integrity" and withthis they tried to seduce Ramaphosa. 

Although he acknowledged that editorial independence wasimportant, Ramaphosa indicated a polite thanks, but no thanks.Sources close to Ramaphosa say both the owners and editors of TMLpresented the idea of an editorial charter as part of thetransaction, but that Ramaphosa would not budge on the issue.

It is understood that Ramaphosa is perplexed by the fact thatthe charter is a matter of urgency for TML with prospective newowners, but it was not -- and still remains -- a non-issue withthe editors during the course of their current dealings withJohnnic.

According to a source, it emerged during the course ofdiscussion between Ramaphosa and the editors that an immediateendorsement by Ramaphosa for the charter would smooth ongoingnegotiations on the unbundling of Johnnic considerably, especiallysince a hard bargain is being driven by Johnnic.

Ramaphosa remains unconvinced by this and will continue towithhold his consent on the charter, insiders say.

Although Ramaphosa expresses support for editorialindependence, the urgency for a charter suggested an uneasiness onthe part of TML at the prospect of black owners. TML managingdirector Roy Paulson says the charter was drawn up and handed toAnglo American, but he has no knowledge of whether it was handedover to Ramaphosa. In fact, the idea has been conveyed toRamaphosa on several occasions during the ongoing talks.

To some media observers, the "chickens have come home to roostfor TML". An insider, privy to negotiations between TML and NewNation two years ago, says TML management belittled the idea of aneditorial charter when New Nation requested one.

According to the source, Paulson attempted to ensure that TMLwould have had editorial control over and above a New Nationeditorial charter, under instruction from executives at Omni Mediaand Johnnic.

"It's ironic that when they were negotiating they agreed to aneditorial charter as long as they still maintained editorialcontrol. For the publicity's sake, they even offered us 51% of thedeal but they wanted to hold the reins. Now the time for TML hascome, they are shaking in their boots and are pushing for acharter in desperation."

Paulson rejected these claims, saying that although he didapproach New Nation, TML's intentions were honourable. "It'stotally untrue that we offered New Nation a stake in the company.TML went in to buy the company and it would have been wholly ownedby us," Paulson says.

"We respected their editorial independence and even had noproblems with them supporting the African National Congress aslong as it did not impinge on the commercial viability of thepublication," he said.

New Nation editor Gabu Tugwana confirmed there was a "problem"which resulted in a breakdown in talks but refused to divulgedetails.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Whose Life is it anyway?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Johannesburg - Independent Newspapers' magazine Sunday Life maybe sued by Time Warner, proprietor of the Life trademark.

Bob Scherer of the Trademark Council, a division of Time Warnerin the United States, says talks are under way with IndependentNewspapers' management, and although talk of a lawsuit may be "abit premature", the issue is "far from resolved".

Law firm Adams & Adams, representing Time Warner, may have aconflict of interest since the firm also represents IndependentNewspapers. Because of this conflict, Adams & Adams may have toabandon representing Time Warner. 

A source at the firm says Time Warner has not yet institutedproceedings, and Independent Newspapers must meet certainconditions in a bid to settle out of court. "It's difficult toprove trademark infringement and the matter may have to benegotiated further," an insider said.

Another adds that the issue at stake is whether or not theoriginal trademark was copied and the defendant has to prove thatit was not; alternatively, the plaintiff has to prove that it was.

Talks between the two parties have been ongoing for the pastyear. Sunday Life editor Les Aupiais says, as far as she knows, itwas agreed Sunday Life will abide by certain conditions. These arethat the magazine will not be sold as a stand-alone with a coverprice, the name will not be printed in white on a red backgroundas in the original Life magazine and that it will always have theprefix "Sunday" before "Life".

"The magazine will always be a supplement to the main bodynewspaper," says Aupiais, adding that the typeface of the magazinewas also specially designed for the magazine and is nothing likethat of the original Life trademark. "The typeface of Sunday is=46irmin Didot and Life is in Doric. It was not copied from theoriginal Life magazine," she says.

Managing director of Cape Newspapers Rory Wilson told the Mail& Guardian that Time Warner approached the stable some months agowhere they stated their case. "We then took counsel's opinion onthe matter and we are not infringing any trademark. We are holdingby that," Wilson says.

Cape Newspapers' sales and marketing manager Greg Brophyconfirms that legal counsel was sought. He says Sunday Life aretwo generic words which do not infringe on the trademark of Lifemagazine. "We have pumped lots of money into the marketing ofSunday Life and before that was done we ensured that we were onsolid ground in terms of ethics and legal aspects."

Executive director of the Association of Marketeers DerekDickens says trademarks and brands are what the free market is allabout and well-known trademarks, for this reason, have to beprotected.

According to Dickens, the Trademarks Act in South Africa is "alot more lax" than in other countries. However, it is adequate toprotect local and international brands.

The issue of Sunday Life and Time Warner boils down to whetherSunday Life was registered under the old Trademarks Act, whichallowed for South Africans to register trademarks as long as theywere not well- known locally, he says.

In the early Nineties, with the formation of the EuropeanEconomic Council, there was an international effort to harmoniseall trademark laws across the globe.

In an effort to keep in line with international trends, SouthAfrica brought its own old-fashioned trademarks act into line withworld standards. Now, with the old act repealed, the new Actinsists that a trademark can only be registered once a worldwidesearch of brands is conducted by the applicant.

"America has put pressure on South Africans who harbourtrademarks under the old Act. We have to get in line and respectinternational trademarks and make sure they are protected in thiscountry as we risk losing favoured nation status," Dickens says.

A case in point is the international McDonalds versusMacdonalds, says Dickens.

Section 34.2 of the new Trademarks Act states that the rightsof a trademark will be infringed if there is an unauthorisedidentical or similar mark in the form of shape, colour or name,that so nearly resembles another trademark that it is likely to beperceived as such or cause confusion.

Dicken argues that Time Warner in all probability has a strongcase unless Independent Newspapers registered its Sunday Life logounder the old Act. He says the stable's counsel will then have toprove that the two brands cannot be confused. but with the new actin place, the newspaper house will have to get in line.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

June, 1996


Business and Finance In South Africa, 'Now is the time to buy'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Johannesburg - Investors should not be put off shares justbecause the Johannesburg Stock Exchange has taken a beating thanksto the rand's tumble. Rather, now is a good time to buy, saysSchalk Theron, senior portfolio manager of Sanlam Unit Trusts. 

"The average annual after-tax return on shares over 20 yearsfar exceeds that of other investments, so investors should take along-term view and consider the softening of the JSE as a buyingopportunity.

"It would be silly for a regular monthly investor todiscontinue buying, because one can get more units for the sameamount."

Shares are by their very nature volatile. But investors shouldnot judge unit trust performance over periods of less than threeyears, says Theron. "Chasing returns over shorter periods becomestoo risky for prudent portfolio management," he says.

For example, gold funds would have yielded a 30% return in thelast quarter - but over a five-year term, that would havetranslated into 10%, as against the 25% return an industrial trustwould have yielded at a much lower level of risk.

And the fundamentals continue to look good. "I do not think theshare market is overvalued. I am bullish about prospects forgrowth," says Theron.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Labor Commission Stresses Jobs, Not Capital


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 800 words


 

The Labour Market Commission has sharply criticised SouthAfrica's obsession with huge capital-intensive projects ratherthan more labour-intensive projects.

South African manufacturing was dominated "to an unusualdegree" by highly capital-intensive sectors such as commoditychemicals, electricity generation and non-ferrous metals. Evenservices and agriculture were capital intensive. 

At the same time, there was significant under- investment insectors such as clothing, footwear, furniture and tourism, withvery little participation by small- to medium-sized firms.

South Africa's high capital intensity was, in part, due to theemergence of large and powerful public and private sectorconglomerates that "have become deeply locked into our economicstructure and will resist policy interventions that attempt totransform it". These had developed because of sanctions and theneed to ensure self-sufficiency, while gaining access to securesources of foreign exchange.

The new government had an entirely different set of prioritiesand concerns, not least job creation for the large pool ofunskilled and semi-skilled labour and the better use of capitaland skilled labour.

This did not imply that government should not support largeprojects now being planned, but "every effort" should be made toensure that as many upstream and downstream jobs as possible werecreated at the same time.

"The current focus on development corridors clearly representsan attempt to generate sustainable employment clustered aroundinfrastructural development and is welcomed," the commission said.

The move to create more jobs should be accompanied by specificpolicy measures aimed at dealing with the "notoriously weakcompetition policy", state purchasing that favoured large firms,export incentives biased against small firms and inadequatetraining for small business.

The commission warned, however, that "the labour market cannot,and should not, be expected to bear the full brunt of theadjustment alone".

As long as industries continued to benefit from subsidisedelectricity and finance, labour would continue to be a relativelycostly input, which could lead to demands for wage cuts in returnfor employing more people.

The commission said these factors appeared to be recognised ingovernment's present approach to industrial policy, but itexpressed concern that it was not focused enough on the efficientand effective use of scarce capital resources.

It urged that the Industrial Development Corporation be forcedto refocus its activities. It recognised that this "may be akin toturning a supertanker", but said it should focus more on jobcreation.

"A disproportionate share of its resources is devoted to verylarge highly capital-intensive projects, generally in partnershipwith a predictable array of well-resourced corporations," thecommission said.

Key to any attempt to move towards labour-intensive policieswould be concerted efforts to improve productivity and link thatto wages.

"In fact, as the South African economy becomes more open tointernational competition, firms will only be able to survive iftheir costs and productivity are comparable to those of theirmajor international competitors," the commission said.

The commission said there was no clear evidence that SouthAfrican wages were out of sync with the rest of the world, butthere was no room for complacency. Productivity had to be improvedthrough the introduction of training programmes, multi-shiftsystems and the development of new products.

Big business could at the same time encourage the developmentof small and medium enterprises by sub- contracting out work.Unions have been somewhat uneasy with the idea, fearing that sub-contractors might be exploited at the expense of workers, but thecommission warned against unions trying to ban sub-contracting andbusiness against promoting the proliferation of sweatshops.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance South African Markets Unimpressed With Economic Strategy


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Peter Hilsenrath


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Johannesburg - Government has delivered its long-awaitedeconomic strategy. Developed by an impressive team of economists,it adheres to established economic principles and promotes fiscaldiscipline. Yet markets remain unimpressed. Why?

The main reason is slow growth and inadequate employmentcreation. Economic growth in the integrated scenario projectionremains below 4% through 1998. In the very uncertain "out-years"of 1999 and 2000, the model shows more impressive growth of 4,9and 6,1% respectively. Employment growth only averages 2,9%through 2000. This does not adequately address South Africa'sprincipal problem: unemployment. 

The growth that is envisaged is driven primarily by privatesector investment and exports. Government investment actuallydrags economic growth down in 1996 and 1997 because its growth islower than the gross domestic product (GDP) growth. In the "out-years", government investment rises inexplicably from 7,5% in 1999to 16,7% in 2000 to provide an average growth rate for the 1996 to2000 period of 7,1%. Perhaps Reconstruction and DevelopmentProgramme (RDP) investment will surge in 2000, but RDP spending isno engine of growth for the next few years.

Export sector growth depends to a great extent on preservingthe shift in relative prices brought about by rand depreciation.This requires a vigilant stance against inflation. Both tightmonetary policy and incomes policy can be used here. One hopesthere will be greater reliance on the latter, permitting lowerreal interest rates.

The real bank rate is seen to fall by four percentage pointsbetween 1996 and 1999. But sour management-labour relations couldundermine incomes policy and lead to excessive monetary restraint.This would strangle the domestic sector in favour of exporters.Another concern is the response of exporters to wider profitmargins. Will they expand output or reap higher profits? Muchdepends on expectations of relative competitiveness. Moreefficient production is needed. Lower tariffs should help.

The model shows real wages rising in spite of chronicunemployment. Yet there is talk of more flexible labour markets.Clearly, there is need for elaboration on how more flexible labourmarkets will come about.

Finally, there is much reliance on private sector investment todrive growth, with private investment growing by about 9% annuallyuntil 1999 and then jumping to even higher rates thereafter. Butthere is no consensus that private investment will grow at theselevels. Financial markets have not responded with enthusiasm tothe government's vision -- evidence that for all the rhetoricabout fiscal discipline, what investors really want is growth,earnings and high rates of return. Since the government appearsintent on waiting several more years before investing in SouthAfrica, many domestic and foreign investors may decide to do thesame.

Dr Peter Hilsenrath, an economist with the University of Iowa,has worked with Syfrets since August 1995

Business and Finance Record Diamond Sales For De Beers


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Johannesburg - De Beers' Central Selling Organisation (CSO)posted record rough diamond sales in the first six months of theyear, increasing 8,2% in dollar terms over the same period lastyear. De Beers said the CSO sold US$2,748-billion worth ofdiamonds this year against $2,540-billion in the first half of1995.

In rand terms, sales increased by 20% to R10,945- billion fromR9,117-billion last year. De Beers said the half-year sales hadseen continuing firm demand for larger better quality roughdiamonds above half a carat, while retail jewellery sales remainedpositive, rising 5 to 6% in value last year and continuing to growthis year.

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Labor Group Questions Job Numbers


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Lynda Loxton


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Johannesburg - A controversial study suggests South Africa'sunemployment rate is not the highest in the world and averages 20%against the 32% quoted by most experts.

The International Labour Organisation (ILO) study recognisesthat unemployment is a problem, but is not the Sword of Damoclesthat has sent various government departments and unions scurryingaround for solutions. 

The ILO report rejects notions that South Africa suffers from"structural unemployment" as hazy and elastic and slams thefigures produced by the most widely quoted October HouseholdSurvey as "distorted and an exaggeration".

It is hesitant about giving its own estimate on unemployment,but claims "one would not be far wrong in 'guesstimating' anunemployment rate of about 20%. Such a level is serious, but wellshort of the figure of 32% cited by politicians, economists andthe media.

Blacks, youths and women should be granted special assistance"both in the labour market and through tackling barriers to theirlabour force entry and their access to employment," it says.

The report also warns about the likely short and medium termeffects on unemployment of rapid trade liberalisation and marketreform.

71 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa 'C-words' Replace The 'F-word'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Johannesburg - Few politicians mention the "f-word" anymore --it has been replaced by the "c-words" which are more and morecharacterising the ANC's approach to governing South Africa.

The "f-word" -- federalism -- was deliberately dropped duringconstitutional debate earlier this year, so that parties couldmove away from time-worn arguments and develop a new system ofgovernment based on the golden principles of co-operation,consultation and compromise.

"Co-operative government" is a term that can be sourced indebates about federalism and describes a system where provincialgovernments co-operate with one another for the common good,rather than compete against each other for individual gain. In theNew South African sense it is embodied in the new Council ofProvinces (COP), which will replace the Senate, and in theIntergovernmental Forum which is a forum for provincial andnational executives, as well as in Minmec forums, which aremeetings of national and provincial line-function ministers andMECs. 

The ANC is thrilled with this model, partly because it was away of side-stepping a head-on argument over federalism andcentralism -- but also because it is a pleasant and positivenotion which decreases the chances of messy conflict and stand-offs between the central and provincial governments. Further, itcomplements the African principle of ubuntu, which describes afeeling of the worth of the community, a shared brotherhood of menand women and a sense of working for the common good. It is hopedthat the model will be implemented before the end of the year.

The National Party supports the model of "co-operativegovernment" and the principle of provincial co-operationenthusiastically, and does not believe that the accumulation ofANC interests in the COP will drown out the opposition voice of anNP-led Western Cape or an Inkatha-led Kwazulu-Natal. Both the ANCand the NP believe that the co- operative model is a healthy stepaway from Westminster type opposition politics.

Inkatha, however, is wary of the new set-up because it equatesANC co-operation with co-option. IFP hardliner Walter Felgatewastes no words: "Co-operative government is a shot-gun marriagebetween the provinces and central government". That is, "co-operation" will allow for easier, painless majority rule, he says.

ANC sources indicate that the model of co-operation was bornpartly with Inkatha-led Kwazulu-Natal in mind, in order to containthat province's waywardness and to build it into a system whichallows provincial integrity on the one hand, but curtails maverickprovincial impulses born from a desire to pursue competitivefederalism.

Presidential adviser Professor Fink Haysom warns againstcompetitive federalism, saying it could lead to an enormous wasteof resources.

"In the competitive system, each province competes againstevery other province and too much political energy goes intosecuring the little good."

Haysom believes that competitive government could well lead tograve instability within the country and economic weaknessnationally.

Certainly Haysom and the ANC have a valid point, and thepursuit of co-operation among all interest groups, large andsmall, is a welcome contrast to the previous era, where the needsof a tiny sector of the population were foisted on everybody elsewithout attempts to reach consensus. The result was thedestructive skewing of resources for which South Africans will payfor decades.

However, the ANC use of the word "co-operation" has anOrwellian resonance to it, especially if it is to become an end initself, or is coupled to internal political agendas.

The debate around a new education system is an interestingexample. It reveals that there is an articulated desire for co-operation on a highly sensitive issue, but that the ANC-ledgovernment is determined to push through its agenda, in spite ofconsultation, while using the co-operative forums to bind criticalvoices into the agreement.

"Co-operation" could become, at crunch-time, a thinly veiledmajoritarianism which masquerades as the common good, but in factrepresents ANC interests.

Fights about what is the common good are expected to escalatewhen the government implements national norms and standards inareas such as health, education and welfare. In terms of theconstitution, the central government can overrule provincialobjections when implementing national norms and standards, andeffectively can make the co-operative COP a lesser partner in itsdecisions.

Political scientist Professor Willie Breytenbach says that thejury is still out as to whether or not the ANC is going to use"co-operation" to bulldoze through its political will.

However, it is interesting that Freedom Front leader GeneralConstand Viljoen -- once the ANC's sweetheart -- is concernedabout the extent to which the ANC is prepared to listen todifferences of opinion and then ignore them, especially in thefield of education.

On the basis of that experience, and the experience ofnegotiating for volkstaat agreements for over two years, he givesthis advice to members of the public who have to negotiate withthe ANC on matters of difference: "Certainly, talk, consult withthe ANC, but be very careful because you must never underestimatethe enemy, you must never underestimate the ANC, or theintellectual part of the ANC which is the SACP.

"You must have a clear idea of what you want to do, in linewith international law, and you must stick to your point,otherwise you are on thin ice ..."

Viljoen said that minority parties could be sucked into awhirlpool of "co-operation" in which their interests could bedrowned.

ANC intellectual and SACP member MP Pravin Gordhan hits back atthat point of view: "The smaller parties' fear of co-operation isa search for leverage to defend, protect, enhance minority partyconcerns.

"It's not conflict we want, it's co-operation; it's notdebilitating disagreement we want, it's optimal consensus; it'snot unilateralism we want , it's multilateralism. We don't wantindividuals to be empowered to stand in the way of the collective,we want a collective in which the individual can find a means ofexpression."

Africa News


June, 1996


Zimbabwe Mystery Surrounds Media Clampdown


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Richard Saunders


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Johannesburg - There is a mystery over the government takeoverof the Zimbabwe Mass Media Trust (ZMMT), the nominally independentbody which is the majority shareholder in Zimpapers, the country'sonly national newspaper chain.

Last month the Mail & Guardian reported on the government'smove following a brief statement by director of informationBornwell Chakaodza, carried as a front-page news item inZimpapers' flagship weekly, the Sunday Mail. Chakaodza announcedthat the trust's founding deed of 1981 had been amended in Aprilfollowing a cabinet decision. 

After that no further explanations were given for thegovernment's abrupt reversal of a key plank in its post-independence media policy -- a change with profound implicationsfor the state's role in the determination of editorial andmanagement policy of the dominant national press.

Pointedly, journalists and editors working for Zimpapers andZiana, the government news agency, did not pursue the subject,after having spent years proclaiming the sanctity of the ZMMT'sindependence.

If they had gone after the story they probably would not havegot far.

Since Chakaodza's policy bombshell, ZMMT officials have beenquiet, deflecting requests for copies of the amendments.Chakaodza's information ministry has also been evasive.

Searches for the director's initial press statement, still theonly source of official comment on the matter, have come up empty-handed.

And still no copies of the deed changes. A check at the DeedsRegistry office in Harare last week perhaps explains why.

According to registry officials no changes to the original 1981ZMMT Deed have in fact been registered. Which means that theoriginal 1981 trust deed is still legally in effect.

If the deed amendments have not been registered, one wonderswhere they are, why it has taken so long to put them intooperation -- and why the Director of Information announced thatthe changes had been made on April 29?

Moreover, if there has been an error of fact by eithergovernment or the media which carried Chakaodza's announcement,why was it not later corrected by the ZMMT, government or by theZMMT's own media?

Six weeks after the announcement of government's clampdown onthe national press structures these questions remain unanswered.

The lack of clarity has led to further speculation. Last year,Honour Mkushi, the liberal-minded lawyer selected by trustees in1995 as ZMMT chairman against the wishes of the informationministry, spoke of the ZMMT's new struggles to carve out anindependent path just as government was twisting the ZMMT's arm toaccept the state's control over the body.

"The trust doesn't want to operate on the basis of being tiedat the end of a string that can be pulled by the Ministry ofInformation and government," Mkushi said. "If I was asked to windup the trust on political grounds, I-- and several othertrustees, I think -- would prefer to fight for survival on thegrounds of protecting the principle of the trust."


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia Selassie's Death Recounted


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Alice Martin


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Addis Ababa - Dramatic new details about the mysterious deathof Emperor Haile Selassie in 1975 emerged last week during a warcrimes trial in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa.

The trial, which is considering evidence of alleged atrocitiescommitted during the country's communist period from 1974 to 1991,was told that Selassie, who ruled Ethiopia for more than 50 years,was driven away from his palace on September 12, 1974, in aVolkswagen Beetle -- never to be seen in public again.

The first public account of the emperor's death came from twoattendants who stayed with him in custody. They were brought in tosee his body on the morning of August 26, 1975. 

"There was a smell of ether in the air," one witness said. "Andhis majesty was not lying in his usual position. He only had onepillow. The shawl that he wrapped himself in when he went to sleepwas lying in another part of the room. His face was ghastly andthere was a bandage around his neck."

The witness described how he had been with the emperor until9pm the previous evening, when soldiers came to take him away.

"His majesty came from his bed and when he saw what washappening tears came to his eyes and he cried out: 'Is it nottrue, Ethiopia, that I have strived for you?' He fell on his kneesand prayed. Later I realised that these were his last words tome."

A third witness described how Colonel Haile Mariam Mengistu,who had assumed leadership of Ethiopia's military council, theDergue, ordered a number of graves to be dug in the grounds of theGrand Palace -- where the military's headquarters were.

The emperor, he said, was buried under Mengistu's officewindow.

"I was worried he would kill me," the gravedigger told thecourt, "but he lit a cigarette for me and told me to fence thearea. I did it in 15 minutes while he watched from the window.Then he ordered me to construct a building on the site. I did itin two weeks."

Forty-six members of the Dergue are in the dock, with someformer leaders -- including Mengistu, who fled to Zimbabwe --being tried in their absence.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

74 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zimbabwe Press Awards Steeped In Farce


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Jan Rath


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Johannesburg - Zimbabwe's national award ceremony forjournalists, an annual beanfeast which for the past six years haspresented solid trophies and real prize money for independent,unfrightened journalists, is probably no more, following thisyear's occasion.

The National Journalists and Media Awards (NJAMA) is aninstitution where the praise singers of Zimbabwe's press are, forone day of the year, ignored, and reporters who write what is infront of their noses are rewarded for doing it.

In a nation where the daily newspapers, radio and televisionare owned by President Robert Mugabe's government and receivetheir instructions from the seldom-swept offices of the ministryof information in central Harare, NJAMA has been an inspiration.

Last year, a pair of journalists received due recognition asnews reporters of the year for catching most of the ruling Zanu-PFparty politburo parcelling out former white-owned farms to eachother. This year the first prize was for a series of reportsexposing ruling party officials trying to purloin the tender forthe country's first cellular telephone network. 

The second prize was for breaching the bounds of thepresidential bedroom and identifying Mugabe's new wife, whom hemarried clandestinely.

But this year's ceremony was blighted by folly from which itmay prove impossible for the organiser, the Willie MusarurwaMemorial Trust, to recover. One after the other, sponsors on whosesupport the ceremony is dependent, have announced theirwithdrawal.

It was a critical misjudgment to hold the affair in the hall ofthe Zanu-PF headquarters, a vast and dingy auditorium the size ofa rugby field whose parquet flooring obviously has not tastedpolish in the decade of its existence.

The bar at the Zanu-PF headquarters was run by someone'srelative who runs a bottle store 30km outside town. It was arevealing indication of the headquarter's usual clientele. It costZim $5 deposit for a glass for each drink, and it was a nightmaretrying to get the money back.

On the day of the ceremony, Kindness Paradza, the president ofthe Zimbabwean Union of Journalists (ZUJ), was urging members ofhis union to boycott the awards because, he said, the electronicmedia, which consists entirely of the state-owned ZimbabweBroadcasting Corporation (ZBC), were not represented in theawards.

ZBC had let the organisers know in March that it waswithdrawing its participation because of the way its journalistshad been "lampooned" at the awards last year, but also because oneof the judges was Jeremy Brickhill, a private television producerwho is suing the ZBC for a large amount of money for non- paymentof fees. ZBC journalists affirm they were instructed by theirmanagement not to have anything to do with NJAMA.

ZUJ had already expressed concern that the venue, chosenbecause the organisers got it "dirt cheap", might prejudice theimpartiality of potential participants, 90% of whom comprised theZBC, Zimpapers, the national newspaper chain and the ZimbabweInter-Africa News Agency (ZIANA), the domestic news agency, all ofwhom fall under the financial and editorial direction of Zanu-PF.

ZUJ was a member of the organising committee which had beenmeeting twice a month since November last year, although itsrepresentative made only sporadic appearances. The first thecommittee heard of ZUJ's withdrawal was in the columns of thedaily newspapers on the day of the awards.

But ZUJ's boycott pretty well worked. The collection of tablesin the southern section of the hall was already dwarfed by theimmensity of the auditorium, and the effect was enhanced by theoccupation of only about half of the seating.

Recipients of awards had been advised, however, that failure toattend the ceremony would deprive them of their award and of theprize money (R1000 for first place, R500 for second and R250 forthird). The only person not to turn up for his award failed to doso because he was injured in a car crash. It could not beestablished whether he forfeited his prize money.

Guest speaker for the occasion was Deon du Plessis, managingdirector of Gauteng Newspapers, whose huge bodyguard drewappreciative murmurs as he ferried many large brandies and coke tohis employer.

Du Plessis's speech, stating that South African newspapers have"a good news obligation" under the new government, went down likea stone with those in the audience who had anything to do with thelate Willie Masururwa, the patron of the trust and former editorof the Sunday Mail, Zimbabwe's biggest selling newspaper. Msururwahad repeatedly warned his staff of the dangers of "sunshinejournalism".

The massacres of civilians in the western provinces ofMatabeleland by Mugabe's 5th Brigade, corruption, Zanu-PF'speculiar support for the PAC instead of the ANC, and its"leadership code" of austerity that everyone ignored were issuesthat Musarurwa could not close his eyes to.

Musarurwa was sacked on Mugabe's orders in 1985. Maybe, in histime, he would have survived had he listened to the likes of DuPlessis.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
