Africa News


June, 1996


Angola Corruption Rife In Angola's Ruling Party


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Johannesburg - The ailing Angolan president is turning his backon his own party, reports the latest edition of AfricaConfidential.

President Jose Eduardo dos Santos's recent sacking of PrimeMinister Marcolino Moco and his cabinet was a belated attempt torally his troops before they have to start doing business withJonas Savimbi's political cadres in Luanda.

The merging of government and rebel armies is meant to befinished within three months.

But Angolans are sceptical; Dos Santos is widely seen asheading a weak, divided and discredited party. 

Fernando Franca Van-Dunem, whom Dos Santos has chosen torevitalise the government, does not stand out as a beacon ofreforming zeal.

And Dos Santos himself seems seriously weak. Diplomats inLuanda have been trying to discover just what is wrong with him.Since he was treated at a private clinic in France in April, hehas rarely been seen in public and has received few visitors atthe Futungo de Belas palace. There are rumours circulating that hehas prostate cancer.

There is uncertainty everywhere, especially around the peaceprocess. The Uniao Nacional para a Independencia Total de Angola(Unita) has tentatively begun to move its troops into quarters,but its commitment to peace remains highly ambiguous.

Most importantly, the ruling Movimento Popular de Libertacao deAngola (MPLA)) is on the brink of collapse. In 1992 Dos Santoscampaigned on his own merits, aided by a slick Brazilian-runadvertising campaign, and since then put a distance betweenhimself and the party.

Dos Santos relies heavily for advice on a small group offriends and family. The United States has invested a great deal inits relationship with the president. An important channel has beenformer assistant secretary of state Herman Cohen, whose consultingcompany has worked closely with the Dos Santos government.

Dos Santos has recently failed to give a consistent politicallead at home or abroad; to many he appears more interested in hisprivate affairs than in running the state.

Diplomats fear that Dos Santos may reject the advice of theposter at Luanda airport proclaiming "Angola no coracao (Angola inthe heart)" and might leave for Brazil and a wealthy retirement.Ill-health and his growing fear of plots have made the presidencytougher than ever. But senior MPLA officials work hard to keep himgoing. They fear bloodletting in the party if he quits.

The MPLA is regularly attacked from inside. Lucio Lara, theformer secretary general, recently called the party "old andtired". It has not held a congress since 1991 and the centralcommittee decided in February to postpone the next congress to1997. The apparatchiks do not want to draw attention to thedivision, corruption and weakness of the party.

For a year after Bicesse Accords, in May 1991, the MPLA failedto meet the challenge of Unita, which lost the multi-partyelections of September 1992 mainly because of Jonas Savimbi'sthreatening campaign, rather than the MPLA's merits. The MPLA wasstimulated to pull itself together by Unita's rejection ofelectoral defeat and its return to armed struggle.

Even before the Lusaka Protocol in 1994, the government army,=46orcas Armadas Angolanas (FAA), clearly had the military advantageover Unita forces. But this is not the same thing as the MPLAhaving the military advantage. FAA officers such as General Joaode Matos have shown open contempt for the party. De Matos himselfnever joined the MPLA.

The MPLA of old started dissolving in the run-up to the 1992elections. when many members started moving their families out ofAngola and got as much money out as they could. That process hasnever been reversed and the party has not been renewed. Now MPLAofficials seem intent on pursuing their private interests andleaving the growing urban poor in the hands of United Nationsagencies and foreign non- governmental organisations.

State power is supposed to be concentrated and co- ordinated inthe Council of Ministers. In practice ministers look after theirown ministries and governors after their provinces. Strategicdecisions are made mainly by the president's Futungo palace.

Futungo overrules cabinet frequently. For example, in September1995 it stopped the issue of new banknotes by Finance MinisterAugustino Tomas. There is almost no talk of post-warreconstruction. Futungo's longest perspective is the two-monthlyrenewal of the mandate of the UN Angola Verification Mission.

The rulers' main energies go into their own business affairs.Minister of Agriculture Isaac dos Anjos recently got a bank loanto set up a fruit factory in which he is the shareholder-owner. Hetold the press that he had to look after his own interests first.There are more than 70 foreign security firms in Luanda,protecting senior people's interests. Meanwhile teachers are paidabout $3 per month; a bottle of beer costs $1. The foreign-exchange value of the Kwanza fell by 3,608% in 1995.

The government announced in May that it is planning measures toease the crisis. After the reshuffle, it is rumoured there will bepay increases for state employees. Without sound public finances,that can only spur inflation.

Crime is pervasive. The authorities have banned severaldemonstrations, broadcasting warnings on the radio and stationingrapid-intervention police (the infamous "Ninjas") to deter would-be demonstrators.

The government cannot really trust the active army and theregular police, some of whose senior officers sympathise with thediscontented civilians.

The government tries to hold the loyalty of senior servingofficers by allocating profitable enterprises to them. The MPLAhopes this will increase its influence, because they need partypatronage if they are to make profits. But some officers have setup on their own accounts. In Lunda Norte, at Calonda, a diamondconcession is run by Tricorn, which is linked to Chief of StaffJoao de Matos and other officials.

Unita, too, is becoming a business alliance. Of Angola's totaloutput of diamonds, estimated by Western intelligence reports tobe worth up to $690- million, Unita mined and smuggled out $430-million in 1995. The alluvial diamonds of Lunda Norte are almostworked out. In 1996 Unita brought in equipment and skilled stafffrom South Africa to work the Cuango riverbed.

Savimbi and his Unita associates may even be worried by DosSantos's reported illness. They do not respect the president, butregard him as a stabilising influence. The government's seniorofficers and the MPLA's cadres envy Unita's hold on diamond-richareas. Business could bring the rivals together -- or in theunrest that would follow Dos Santos's departure, set them at eachothers' throats again.

June, 1996


South Africa Abortion Vote Pressures Parliament


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Johannesburg - When new legislation liberalising South Africa'sabortion laws reaches Parliament, much will depend on whetherAfrican National Congress MPs vote en bloc or according to theirconsciences. While the debate has yet to rage in the ANC caucus,MPs are already under pressure.

ANC policy has been unequivocally in favour of women's right tosafe, legal abortions -- and usual practice is for caucus to guidevoting on related legislation. But Christian and Muslim MPs andothers who oppose abortion on moral grounds face a dilemma --spelt out in a document circulating among MPs which urges the ANCto oppose an open vote. 

It carries the name of deputy president Thabo Mbeki's adviser,Reverend Frank Chikane, and is a position paper issued by theResearch Institute on Christianity in South Africa at theUniversity of Cape Town's Department of Religious Studies.

Co-authored by Professor John de Gruchy and Reverend BarneyPityana, the paper, entitled The Dilemma of Some Christian MPs andthe proposed abortion policy, does not argue for or againstabortion, but for the right of MPs to dissent on party policy onreligious or moral grounds, while remaining loyal party members.

They argue that because MPs cannot cross the floor to anotherparty without losing their seats, coupled to the fact they are notelected by constituencies, an open vote is necessary on religiousor moral principle.

"Many members of the ANC honestly believe the pro- abortionpolicy which has been proposed is an expression of the commitmentto gender rights and equality (and) also regard it as the best wayto deal with a highly complex moral and medical issue," theywrite. "But there are also those who disagree on the basis of adifferent interpretation of human rights.

"The question of abortion is a particularly difficult one formaintaining party discipline because it is on the boundary betweenwhat the ANC might expect from its members who support its standon gender issues and yet who, on religious or moral grounds,cannot support legalised abortion or the proposed legislation.

"There can be no doubt that the rights of women cannot bedenied or voted against by ANC representatives; there can also beno doubt that Roman Catholics as well as believers of some othertraditions cannot vote for abortion without denying their faithand its moral demands. They want to support gender equality andrights, but not in this way. So in all conscience, they are dutybound to dissent. It is precisely on such boundary issues that anopen vote becomes necessary."

Allowing a free vote would be "a clear sign that the ANCrecognises the higher loyalty which people of all faithsacknowledge". "Instead of alienating sections of the populationwhich are generally supportive of ANC policy, they will strengthentheir commitment to the party," the paper says.

MPs facing this dilemma find it compounded by the fact theirvotes become part of the public record.

Said a Muslim ANC MP: "We have already been denounced byreligious leaders for not speaking out against abortion duringconstitutional negotiations. We are members of the ANC and thecountry is governed by a Constitution guaranteeing women'sequality, but ultimately we are bound by the Qu'ran."

In response, the Reproductive Rights Alliance has urged the ANCto reaffirm its position on abortion. "The fact that abortion is amoral issue should not mean the ANC need feel obliged to abandonparty discipline .

As things stand, the African Christian Democratic Party isopposed to liberalising abortion laws. So is the National Party,which will use the whip to ensure its members toe the party linein voting against the new bill -- unless sufficient NP womensupporters who feel differently can make their voices heard.

The Democratic Party will allow its MPs to vote according totheir consciences. After a debate in the Inkatha Freedom Partyparliamentary caucus last year, IFP leader Mangosuthu Butheleziallowed MPs to do the same.

"There are different views within the IFP and they areirreconcilable," said an MP. "The one is that abortion is a crime,the other that it's a crime that women can't have them. But itseems the majority of caucus is opposed."

The big question is which way the ANC will jump.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Costs Of Stalling Abortion Law


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

Johannesburg - Draft legislation liberalising the country'sabortion law was due before a cabinet committee on May 29. Buthealth minister Nkosazana Zuma withdrew it at the last minute,fuelling suspicions that political considerations -- not the leastpending KwaZulu-Natal local government elections -- has seen itpushed to the backburner.

The Mail & Guardian established this week that the draftTermination of Pregnancy Bill was submitted by the department ofhealth drafters on May 22 and scheduled to go before the CabinetCommittee on Social Affairs and Administration on May 29. Thematter was left in abeyance at the request of the minister. 

Department of health legal section head Sello Ramasala saidthis week he was not aware of any problems with the bill -- rulingout the possibility of it being withdrawn for technical reasons.

Speculation is now focused on whether the political sensitivityof the legislation -- which provides for abortion on request -- isnot the issue. There was also concern this week that the delaywould prevent the bill from being introduced to parliament beforeit rises at the end of the year.

Zuma said she did not want to discuss Cabinet issues with thepress. "On principle, members of Cabinet do not go to the press onCabinet issues until approval has been reached, because it is acollective," said director general Dr Olive Shisana.

"If I recall we in the department had not worked out thefinancial implications and had to do that on the Cabinet memo tobe sure the minister was properly advised in terms of theimplications of the policy.

"The department did not withdraw the Cabinet memo. But theroutine is that if there are financial implications it's requiredto consult the Department of State Expenditure. That could not bedone because while the provinces said they had the money, we hadto have it in writing -- we couldn't rely on verbalconsultations," said Shisana. "We felt it was important to takethat step."

There was "no way" she could give dates when the Bill wouldcome before Cabinet. The ball is rolling.

Indications are that the African National Congress is waryabout floating the issue ahead of the KwaZulu-Natal elections forfear it will become a political football. The Inkatha FreedomParty is also divided on the issue.

"It would appear to me the matter is deliberately being put onthe backburner until after the KwaZulu- Natal elections," said IFPMP Suzanne Vos.

There is also speculation that Zuma -- who strongly backsabortion reform -- may be less than keen on engaging in a heftypolitical battle so soon after the Sarafina 2 debacle.

But for health care providers the issue is critical. Hospitalsare battling to cope with the demand for legal terminations interms of the existing law and they have to plan to provide theinfrastructure and training necessary to cope with demand once thelaw is changed.

The judicial process has also been affected: in somemagisterial districts, cases involving medical practitionerscharged with providing illegal abortions have been stayed pendingchanges in the law.

Dr Marj Dyer, president of the Abortion Reform Action Group,said she was receiving up to four calls a day from women "acrossthe spectrum of population groups, income level and religiousaffiliation" seeking terminations.

Hospitals are not coping with the demand for legal terminationsunder the current law. The new bill, if passed, would provide forwomen to be treated at primary and secondary health-carefacilities -- taking the strain off the major hospitals and givingwomen more equal access to help.

In the Western Cape, a provincial task group has been set up todeal with problems being encountered in implementing the existinglaw. "There's this sense of limbo because we don't know what'shappening with the legislation. There is a need for government totake a lead and say these are the services we will need toprovide," said a task group source.

Groote Schuur Hospital (GSH), one of three hospitals allowed tocarry out legal terminations, handles the majority of cases andcannot meet the demand.

Head of GSH's obstetrics and gynaecological departmentProfessor JB Dommisse has said in an internal Medical Associationof South Africa newsletter that the high demand was a result ofmany women thinking abortion on demand was available.

Limited resources and other demands on the department forcedGSH to put in place two years ago a quota system limiting thenumber of women who can be given legal terminations.

But this quota system is giving rise to its own problems.Gynaecological and out-patients' department staff find themselvessubjected to harassment from referring doctors and patients whentold the quota is full.

Women, told they can't be seen in a given week, try again andagain, creating a bottleneck which sees women presenting at moreadvanced stages of pregnancy.

A GSH representative said: "The bottleneck phenomenon is alogical consequence of any quota system where demand exceeds theability of resources to cope." Women who could not be seen werereferred back to their doctors.

They can go to a private hospital -- which would exclude, ongrounds of cost, the majority of women, or another state hospitallicensed to do terminations. However, the increase in demand atGSH is understood to reflect the difficulty women have in gettingterminations at the only other hospitals licensed to do them,Tygerberg and Somerset Hospitals.

In addition, implementing the abortion law is costing thecountry millions of rands a year and effectively sentencing womenwho resort to backstreet abortionists to illness, sterility ordeath.

In a recent study, the Medical Research Council estimated that44 686 women a year, ranging in age from 14 to 49, presented tohospitals with incomplete abortions. The vast majority (84%) wereAfrican women, followed by coloured (11%), Asian (4%) and white(1%).

During 1994, 2 180 legal abortions were performed - -- 61,3% onwhite women from the urban middle class.

The study found that 425 women each year could die in hospitalfrom septic abortions, that each year countrywide 6 961 women were"moderately sick" and 5 886 "very ill" after abortions usuallycarried out on the backstreets. The total costs of treatingincomplete abortion cases in one year was R18,6- million. Thisamount could fund more than 88 000 safe abortions using existingtechnology.

"The health costs and consequences of unsafe abortion to SouthAfrican women are a serious public health issue," said MichelleO'Sullivan of the Reproductive Rights Alliance, a network oforganisations formed to lobby for and promote comprehensivereproductive health care services.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Poll Will Entrench Parties' Strongholds


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Ann Eveleth


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

Johannesburg - The Inkatha Freedom Party is likely to win mostrural areas, and the African National Congress is poised to winthe powerful Durban metropolis and Pietermaritzburg in KwaZulu-Natal's long-awaited local government elections next Wednesday.

The result will merely entrench the two parties' strongholds,keeping the province politically divided into mainly rural andurban constituencies.

Both parties, however, are hoping for more. The ANC is pushingfor victory in at least one of the province's seven over-archingregional councils, and several of the main towns and citiesdotting the countryside, while the IFP wants to capture at leastone of the six sub-structures comprising the Durban metro. 

The ANC is pushing hardest for the urbanised Midlands RegionalCouncil, which stretches from Kranskop in the north to EastGriqualand in the south, Pietermaritzburg in the east and Impendlein the west.

The ANC won roughly 49% of the region's votes in 1994. The IFPcame second with 35%. Comprising 20 municipalities, the regionforms part of the powerful Durban-Pietermaritzburg corridor --Ethecentre of commercial activity in the province.

Also comprising important rural constituencies, the battle forcontrol of this region has been the fiercest, marked notably byseveral violent confrontations, particularly in rural Donnybrook.

The IFP's push to make Ulundi the provincial capital, the ANC'suncontested victory in strife- torn Richmond, and a concentrationof ANC strongholds in many of the region's townships, have madethe IFP's fight for the region far more difficult than in the sixremaining regional councils, where it held a clear victory in1994.

The province's complicated rural local government formula --Eatransitional arrangement making chiefs automatic rural local"councillors" and reserving them 20% of seats on the second-tierregional councils --Ehowever, makes victory an uphill battle forthe ANC.

Although the party has launched a legal challenge to theformula, the reservation of seats for mainly IFP-aligned chiefs --Etogether with the 10% reserved for mainly conservative whitefarmers or "levy payers" --Emean only 70% of regional councilseats will be elected from rural party lists and municipalcouncils.

The ANC would have to win at least 70% of elected seats to gaina simple 50% majority on a regional council. It could easily winthe majority of votes and still lose control of the region.

In the province's 61 towns and cities, the application of theKempton Park horse-trading deal known as the "50-50" arrangement--Ewhere small white constituencies in the town centres will electthe same number of councillors as populous black townships on thetowns' outskirts --Ewill be decisive in towns where the ANC winsthe most votes but falls short of an absolute council majority.

Perhaps the most complicated voting formula -- Eespecially forfirst-time municipal voters -- Eis that for the Durban metro. Themetro's 1,1-million voters will cast three ballots each todetermine the winner: one for a councillor in one of 164 wards,one from a party list for one of six sub-councils, and one from aseparate party list for the metropolitan council.

The ANC was the biggest party in the metro area in 1994 withapproximately 41% of the votes, followed by the National Party(31%) and the IFP (21%).

A massive area comprising nearly one-third of the province'svoters, and controlling a R3,6-billion budget, the Durban metrowill be the prize of this election.

The IFP is pushing hard to prevent this, relying partly on the50-50 deal which divides the wards equally between former white,Indian and coloured areas on the one hand, and traditionallyAfrican areas (townships) on the other.

Known as "A-wards" and "B-wards" respectively, these are notstrict racial classifications but are rather based on former GroupAreas Act divisions. The IFP hopes to benefit from the inclusionof mushrooming informal settlements into some A-wards andparticipation in joint development forums with these settlements'"minority" neighbours.

The IFP gained significant support from Durban's white votersin 1994 and has made a push for Indian supporters in thiselection. The party hopes its recent work will boost the 5% Indianvote it received in 1994 and deliver a victory in the largelyIndian northern substructure or "suburb" (comprising Tongaat andVerulam), where it is contesting 16 of the 18 wards --Ealbeit withmany of its Indian candidates declining to put the party logo nextto their name.

An IFP victory in this substructure would deliver apsychological blow to the ANC --Erepresenting not only an IFPadvance into its metro stronghold, but also marginalising theANC's hard-won Hambanathi stronghold within the sub-structure.

Hambanathi was the site of intense violence in the early 1980s,at the start of the province's civil war. Nevertheless, the ANC isexpected to emerge with the highest number of metropolitan votes,the only question being one of percentages.

If the party falls short of an absolute majority of seats, itmay find its power usurped by a hostile coalition. Most of the 53000 new Metro voters registered during the one-month delay theparty demanded in April are believed to be ANC supporters and theparty has worked non-stop to mobilise its constituencies since thedelay.

The metro's black townships are largely ANC-aligned, althoughthey contain significant IFP strongholds. The minority A-wardswhich hold the balance of power are mainly Indian-dominated andthe ANC gained about 25% of the community's vote in 1994 --Esecondto the National Party's 60% majority.

While the ANC's Indian support-base derives mainly from middle-class Natal Indian Congress supporters, its local governmentcandidates have campaigned vigorously in the working classneighbourhoods of Chatsworth and Pheonix, where its civicstructures -- such as the Pheonix Working Committee -- havefought long battles over local issues.

Competition for the metro's significant Indian and marginalcoloured votes is the most intense -- Ewith canvassers from theNP, ANC, IFP, Minority Front, Democratic Party and a host ofindependent groups practically stumbling over one another as theybeat a path to the next house.

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa 'Peace' Is The New Campaign Buzzword


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Ann Eveleth


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Johannesburg - Peace has become the buzzword on KwaZulu-Natal'scampaign trails as more than 14 political parties and a host ofindependent candidates and ratepayers' bodies mark the finalcountdown to Wednesday's polls.

Senior political leaders, national ministers and severalprovincial premiers have descended on the province in recent weekshoping to bolster their parties' showing among the province's 3,5-million registered voters.

Major provincial parties ranked peace at the top of theirelection biddings, amid signs that the recent African NationalCongress-Inkatha Freedom Party peace effort has taken the steamout of the third- ranked National Party's strategy to portrayitself as the peaceful alternative to two warring African parties. 

Blue posters bearing NP leader FW de Klerk's "NP for Peace"message lost their impact when ANC President Nelson Mandela,Deputy President Thabo Mbeki and IFP leader Mangosuthu Buthelezideclared the 13-year civil war "over" at weekend rallies aroundthe province.

While national politicians competed broadly for the kudos ofthe recent peace pact and pumped national issues at traditionalrallies and public meetings, the diverse political styles of theparties emerged from the campaigns waged by their provincial andlocal counterparts.

In the penultimate campaign weekend, the IFP airdroppedhundreds of thousands of party pamphlets over "no-go" areas.

The ANC concentrated its energies on a revival of its once-powerful mobilisation tool: the street meeting. Addressing dozensof small neighbourhood gatherings in "minority" areas, partycandidates reminded voters of their recent civic campaignsuccesses.

The NP had a quiet weekend, with its campaign set for take-offonly this week, but grabbed local headlines by plastering treesalong the main highway into Indian-dominated Chatsworth with starkred posters promising to "Hang the killers, hang the rapists".

The campaigns of two of the smaller parties -- the DemocraticParty and Pan Africanist Congress -- juxtaposed their distantphilosophies in classic style: while PAC candidates armed withmegaphones drove postered bakkies around the crowded WarickTriangle African market area, a dozen DP supporters waged atelephone campaign from a small office in central Durban.

Minority Front leader Amichand Rajbansi augmented his publicmeeting campaign with a strategic poster drive: three faces of the"Bengal Tiger" mark the centre of one overpass on the N3 intoDurban between alternate rows of ANC and IFP posters symbolisingthe MF leader's "neutral" self-portrait.

If posters were the sole determinant of election results, theANC and MF would have a clear lead in the powerful Durbanmetropolitan area. The poll is, however, about far more thanposters.

Haunted by claims of 1994 electoral fraud, suffering under adivided and lethargic provincial government, and seriouslyflirting with a full-scale ceasefire, KwaZulu-Natal's second post-apartheid poll is set to define the balance of power moreprecisely than ever before.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


80 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa On The Campaign Trail With TheIFP


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 1934 words


 

Johannesburg - There are a number of things about Philip Powellthat confirm the media's representation of him as a warlordsenator. He is fond of wearing olive-green military trousers and abaseball cap with the logo of Inkatha's paramilitary protectionunits above the peak.

His turbo-charged bakkie echoes a scene from Somalia as itspeeds through a burnt-out part of a township in the NatalMidlands with men in the back carrying shotguns and automaticrifles. He calls David Ntombela, a dreaded Inkatha strongman, hisspiritual father. And in his book case at home in Howick, there isa book entitled How to Make War.

So it comes as a relief when this amiable and articulate manopens a trunk in the van -- which African National Congress peoplewill swear to you is frequently packed with M-26 hand grenades --to reveal camping equipment and boxes of canned food. 

These, he says, are more useful than guns when you are on anelection trail, trying to build the grassroots structures of apolitical party.

Powell describes himself as an Inkatha Freedom Party populist,forced in the turbulent wars of the 1980s and early 1990s to dirtyhis hands in paramilitary work, but now dedicated to what he callsthe democratisation of the party.

There is some evidence, at least in Powell's case, to back theclaim.

He has attended 36 election rallies, some in the most remoteareas of the province, in the past four weeks. And he hasdelivered the same speech at most of them.

It is based on the cliche of a cake that will be divided up innext week's local government elections. But it draws skilfully onthe culture and the material conditions of the rural people whoinhabit his power base in the Midlands of KwaZulu- Natal.

White people have grown fat on the cake, he tells a rally tolaunch a new branch at Mahobeni village in the Vulindleladistrict, and they don't want to give it up. Coloureds and Indiansgot a few small slices in the apartheid era. ANC people in thetownships got some of the crumbs --and they don't really want toshare them. The poor rural communities, whose mothers still cutwood in the forest and whose sisters collect water from the riverin buckets, still have nothing.

"Where are the schools and the clinics and the roads that theANC has promised? Where is the electricity and the taps? ... Youmust elect people who will fight for the cake. You must electpeople who, when the fat white man doesn't want to give it up,will not lie down and say 'Ja Baas'," he tells the applaudingcrowd.

"Most of all you must not elect someone who will eat the cake.You do not want to see the person you vote for next year drivingaround in a big car with a wife who washes her dishes under a tapwhile you are still walking to river to fetch water."

The speech is littered with irony -- and licence. It ignoresthe fact that Ntombela, chairman of this Inkatha district andprovincial parliamentarian, drove to this very meeting in a whiteMercedes, and that Mrs Ntombela washes dishes under hot runningwater while most wives in her village carry buckets on theirheads.

And Powell forgets to mention that it is the IFP government inthe province that is responsible for building schools and roads.

But his imagery strikes a chord in the poorest of theprovince's poor. His ability to tune into his constituency'sculture is demonstrated by the ripple of laughter that runsthrough the men's ranks when he ends by shouting: "And most ofall, comrades, you must remember that this election is all about... the keke!"

His last word is a play on Zulu slang for what can be seen asthe sweetest part of a woman's body.

After the rally, Powell is in a more serious mood. He insiststhat to understand Inkatha and its "old militarism" it isnecessary to understand both the culture and the wretched materialconditions of its class base in the 1980s -- the rural peasantryand the urban impoverished urban strata who live in the province'simpoverished villages and shantytowns.

Shacklords and warlords emerged in these areas as a reaction tothe attacks carried out in the 1980s by ANC youth on older peopleand chiefs in defiance of Zulu culture's veneration of authority-- and militaristic forms of punishment.

The chiefs and their supporters mobilised in the best way theyknew: by calling their indunas and forming amabutho to disciplinethe boys who had initiated what "to the chiefs was almost a pogromagainst them".

In the 1960s and 1970s, says Powell, Inkatha was a movement ledby the "amakholwa", a mission-trained Zulu elite made up ofgenteel men like Ben Ngubane, Frank Mdlalose, Oscar Dhlomo andSibusiso Bhengu.

In the 1980s, because it was the only organisation sympatheticto plight of the traditional chiefs, Inkatha's power base shifted.Warlords like Ntombela emerged as a "spontaneous" bulwark againstan ANC- inspired rejection of the values that Zulu elders stoodfor. The militaristic mood and tactics of the movement's new rank-and-file spread from below, rather than from the movement'sleadership, he maintains.

Powell is adamant that the IFP is now moving into what he callsits third "institutional phase", forgoing armed methods in favourof building an efficient electoral machinery and democratic partystructures. The party, pushed by its chief strategist Ziba Jiyane,is exhausted by war. It now wants to concentrate on mobilising itsnatural constituency, the urban and rural poor, by exploiting theANC's failure to deliver on the Reconstruction and DevelopmentProgramme. And this is best achieved, he points out, by civilmethods of organisation.

"I don't like to use military metaphors," says Powell (althoughthey still come naturally to him). "But we see these localgovernment elections as a live firing exercise for the big one in1999." If this is true -- and the analysis is presented withsophistication and apparent sincerity -- then it can only meangood for those parts of the province reduced to near-ruin bywarlordism and violence.

But there are aspects of the senator's past that make thissound rather strange. In the 1980s, Powell worked in the D Sectionof police intelligence, where he did a masters thesis on thetactics of the mass democratic movement in the Eastern Cape. Hewon't admit this, but it is likely his work fed into theclandestine project used by the police against the ANC in theregion at that time.

Then there is his "father-son" relationship with Ntombela, aman whose hands are deeply steeped in the blood of the province'sconflict. "Ntombela came to see me when I was in hospital afterbeing wounded in a shoot-out in 1992," says Powell. "I heard himtell my father, who was still alive at the time, in Zulu, that hewould have to share being my father. Since then he has been mydeepest source of inspiration."

Yet Father Tim Smith, a Roman Catholic priest who was houndedout of Ntombela's Elandskop stronghold, says Ntombela murdered hisown brother after an argument, in front of witnesses, on ChristmasDay 1984.

Ntombela's impis, probably assisted by trainees from Inkatha'snotorious Caprivi unit, led an attack by thousands of Inkathawarriors on ANC-held sections of the Edendale valley in March1990. They killed about 50 people and caused some 14 000 to flee.The warlord's apparent immunity from prosecution at the time ledhim once to say of a witness, in front of a magistrate, "What doesthat man want here? I can shoot him even here in court."

Eugene de Kock, the police colonel who has promised to giveevidence in a number of "third force" trials, says he personallydelivered truckloads of automatic rifles, ammunition and handgrenades to Powell when the Inkatha activist was in charge oftraining the IFP's self protection units (SPUs) at a camp near theUmfolozi Game Reserve in 1994.

Powell says he cannot comment on De Kock's charges because hewill possibly be involved in a criminal trial over the matter. Buthe insists the SPUs were set up to defend against attacks from theANC's self-defence units, that no weapons were issued during thetraining he supervised, and that police authorities were fullyinformed about the activities in his training camp.

The latest peace agreement between warlords on both sides, hesays, "comes from the people who are directly involved in theviolence and that's why it's more important than anything else inensuring that the peace holds". The fighters are tired offighting, he says.

There are signs that Powell is personally tired of the warlordsenator role -- or of being perceived in that way. His wife, thedaughter of parents who were classified coloured in the apartheidperiod, is pregnant with their first child. And the senator isclearly concerned, if only for their sake, that he should "stayout of the clutches of the like of (Police Minister) SydneyMufamadi."

"I suppose I'm enough of a student of Leninism," he says inresponse to questions about his martial image, "to know thatdifferent stages of struggle call for a different politicalstrategies. We have now realised it to would be futile for us tochallenge the ANC in any other way than institutionally. We havecommitted ourselves to an institutional struggle and willpersevere however hard it is for us."

Maybe one day, while he was on the road to one of theprovince's many war zones, Philip Powell did undergo a genuineconversion. If that means there is a genuine effort to implementhis articulate notion of a new "phase of institutional politics",it may just be the senator will have to keep baked beans insteadof bullets in the back of his bakkie for good.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

June, 1996


South Africa A Twinkle Of Humour In A Most Serious Trial


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Stefaans Brummer


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Johannesburg - It started in February last year as SouthAfrica's first "third force" trial, austere in emotion andstaggering in consequence. But this week, with 16 months of legalbattle drawing to a close, Pretoria Supreme Court Judge Willem vander Merwe allowed the courtroom an occasional moment of lightrelief.

Gone were the charged opening scenes when an incredulous SouthAfrica followed the participants' every utterance; when Eugene deKock's former Vlakplaas subordinates packed the public gallery ina show of support; when De Kock himself may still have hopedagainst hope that there was a way out. 

Now many of De Kock's own men have testified against theirformer commander. De Kock himelf has admitted, in another trialwhere he testified for the prosecution, that it was "accurate" todescribe him as "South Africa's most effective assassin" and thathe expected a lengthy sentence.

De Kock seemed relaxed on Wednesday as the trial resumed forfinal argument, sometimes taking notes, sometimes watchingimpassively, a pen in his mouth, as prosecutor Anton Ackermanargued. After the day's proceedings he chatted warmly with wild-bearded Dougie Holtzhausen, one of the men who had turned againsthim. Holtzhausen was the only member of the Vlakplaas gang to havefollowed the entire day's proceedings.

But Judge Van der Merwe stole the show, often engaging inlengthy dialogue with Ackerman, expounding philosophically on thedifference between "your truth, my truth and the truth" -- andasking a member of the attorney general's office to "stamp on" hiscellphone when its ringing interrupted proceedings.

When Ackerman referred to Holtzhausen's testimony, the judgecautioned: "You must be careful that he (Holtzhausen) does notthrow stones at you from the back."

But it was on the subject of state witness Chappes Klopper --whom the defence had tried to discredit with stories ofprostitutes, drugs, gold chains and more -- that Judge Van derMerwe had the most to say. "If you look at what the (other) statewitnesses said, it looks like he missed Sunday school reasonablyoften."

But a judge remains a judge, and that means extraneous factorsshouldn't cloud judgment. Said Judge Van der Merwe of Klopper: "Heis not the type of character that I would want to stroll with on aSunday afternoon in a park, but that doesn't mean I should rejecthis evidence."

June, 1996


South Africa Commander's Trial Winds Up After 16 Months


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Stefaans BrUmmer


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Johannesburg - The marathon murder trial of Eugene de Kockentered its final stages this week with a blistering prosecutionattack on the former Vlakplaas commander's lawyers for drawing outproceedings with "irrelevant" cross-examination.

Prosecutor Anton Ackerman, deputy Transvaal attorney general,made the charge in a lengthy submission as the 16-month-old trialresumed in the Pretoria Supreme Court on Wednesday for finalargument. De Kock's defence team has already cost taxpayers morethan R4-million, about half in fees for chief defence counsel FlipHattingh. 

Late last month Hattingh accused Ackerman of "seriousmisconduct" for meeting De Kock, who is charged on 121 counts ofmurder, fraud and unlawful weapons possession, in January at thePretoria Central Prison.

Hattingh, who said he should have been consulted about themeeting, threatened to ask for a mistrial and reported Ackerman tothe Pretoria Bar Council.

While Ackerman at no stage said Hattingh acted outside hisrights in his style of cross-examination, he argued Hattingh hadoften dwelt, sometimes for weeks, on "collateral" aspects whencross-examining state witnesses.

Ackerman said Hattingh attempted "from the outset" to discreditstate witnesses, often on extraneous factors such as Vlakplaasinformant Ben van Zyl's "extra-marital affair", or allegations ofChappies Klopper's relations with prostitutes. He said the statedid not regard Klopper -- witness "Q" who first told the GoldstoneCommission about Vlakplaas crimes -- as a key witness. "Hundredsof pages" of cross-examination had been spent on Klopper's ownbackground and on the 1985 departmental hearing of state witnessand former Vlakplaas commander Dirk Coetzee.

Ackerman said it was common for witnesses to differ on minorapects, but that Hattingh had spent much time teasing out theexpected. "This is exactly what happened in this case ... while itwas never stated what the accused will maintain."

He said the defence had taken a new tack in September last year-- where previously it appeared to have believed De Kock could becleared of the charges, Hattingh then tried in cross-examinationto show that De Kock had merely followed orders from "thegenerals". (Significantly, this was when De Kock's confidantWillie Nortje started his testimony against his former commander,and when police commissioner George Fivaz first said police wereconsidering withdrawing state funding of the defence.)

Ackerman also accused Hattingh of "a conscious attempt" todiscredit Transvaal attorney general Jan D'Oliveira'sinvestigation team by saying, for example, that "the defence wasbugged where it met with the accused". But after objections fromHattingh, Judge Willem van der Merwe told Ackerman he could notpursue the argument without specific reference to what Hattinghhad said in court.

Ackerman also outlined what he called the former securitypolice "modus operandi". He said "people who wanted to makerevelations over police irregularities were to be killed", andthat this was confirmed by, for example, the cassette player bombsent to Coetzee. The bomb killed lawyer Bheki Mlangeni -- hisdeath is one of the murders of which De Kock is accused.

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Winnie's Audit Splits ANC Women's League


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Johannesburg - Former senior members of the ANC Women's League(ANCWL) have raised questions about the impartiality of theauditor who compiled the report on the league's finances, as therow over financial mismanagement in the league escalated inParliament this week.

However, such is the fear and loathing between various sectorsof the league that suspicions are not stated openly, and the auditreport has remained sizzling in the fat of secrecy all week.

It was revealed at the weekend that the auditors, commissionedby the ANC, had discovered "serious discrepancies" in the spendingof about R7,8-million by the ANCWL during a period when ANCstalwarts Adelaide Tambo and Makhosazana Njobe were treasurers,and Baleka Kgotsisile, now deputy speaker of Parliament, was itssecretary general.

The audit, by Hardman and Associates, was commissioned by ANCsecretary general Cyril Ramaphosa after fights about power andfinances within the league last year, which have not yet beenresolved. 

While Ramaphosa appointed the auditors, Winnie Madizikela-Mandela is said to have suggested which firm be employed.

Jeff Manning, senior partner of Hardman and Associates, saidweekend media reports "had got it all wrong".

He said 99% of the almost 7,8-million could be accounted forand the report did not apportion blame to anyone in the ANCWL.Manning added that Tambo was "not a financial whizz-kid" and mostof the problems were due to a lack of proper controls and systemsand to the inexperience of junior officials, not tomisappropriation.

"Nobody could be accused of fraud on the basis of the report,"he said. "I've recommended that Mrs Tambo and Mrs Madizikela-Mandela sit down together and go through all the transactions anddecide which ones should be accepted and which ones not."

The ANC has said it would call such a meeting that wouldinclude Ramaphosa and ANC treasurer general Reverend ArnoldStofile to help to sort out the problems.

Manning said he had also discovered that last year's fall-outin the ANCWL, which led to the walk-out by nine executive membersincluding Tambo and Kgotsisile and the resurrection of Madizikela-Mandela as unchallenged president, had been over nothing at all.

The recommendations of the auditor -- which appear to be of apolitical nature -- have not gone down well with those who walkedout last year, and who fear he wrote the audit from a particularperspective.

"The ANC has spent R91 000 on an assault on our integrity,"growled one.

The unnamed former executive members say the auditor had notquestioned key role-players such as Tambo and Njobe about allegedirregularities and say they are suspicious that the audit tookmore than six months to complete at a cost of R91 000.

But to add to the saga, the so-called Winnie camp -- currentleague executive members -- say they are equally distressed thereport was leaked.

They refuse to comment until the league's national executivemeets to discuss the report. These members believe this debacle is"slowing their progress" in the empowerment of women. Asked if theleague should perhaps disband, executive member Maureen Malumisereplied: "Absolutely not, we are very strong on the ground. Theleague is bringing women together over women's issues."

Members point out the league sets up workshops on subjects suchas reproductive rights, land rights, equality and empowerment, isdriving a programme of action inherited from the Beijing Women'sConference and has led a campaign about abused women.

Yet women MPs from outside the league are asking under theirbreath whether the league, with its power-play and its set agenda,is serving any real purpose in politics.

Male ANC MPs who entertain the same question say they arefrightened to raise the issue lest they get branded as sexist, sothe questions remain buried.

The official line is defensive. ANC MP Carl Niehaus answeredquestions about the ANCWL's role by saying: "It's not what they'vedone, it's what they have the potential to achieve."

And league members, past and present, are wary of what they seeas male plots, speculating the audit report was leaked by male MPsto disempower women within the organisation, and to undermine theleague after its outspoken criticism of the Sarafina II affair andits support for beleaguered Deputy Enviroment Minister BantuHolomisa.

Some see criticism of the league as a strategy to unseatMadizikela-Mandela from her last throne.

Niehaus said the ANC is waiting for additional information onthe finances before proceeding with the meeting. This contradictsManning, who says he has closed his books on the league for good.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance South Africa's Telkom Struggles In The Net


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Justin Pearce


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Johannesburg - Telkom's plans to set itself up as an Internetservice provider (ISP) have prompted the Internet ServiceProviders' Association (ISPA) to take the parastatal to theCompetitions Board. The ISPA believes Telkom is using its uniquelyprivileged position to squeeze existing ISPs out of the market.

With Telkom's monopoly on telephone lines and othercommunications infrastructure, ISPs are forced to become clientsof the South African Internet Exchange (SAIX), a division ofTelkom. In the case of the larger service providers, this costs inthe region of R1-million a month. 

Now the ISPs believe Telkom is undermining them by marketingitself direct to the public and to corporate clients.

"ISPs are legally obliged to buy all communications servicesfrom Telkom," says David Frankel, joint chair of ISPA. "Thisincludes artificially expensive international circuits tocommunicate with the United States. If ISP were allowed to bypassTelkom using international carriers directly out of South Africa,our prices to end users could be reduced dramatically. Telkom isabusing its monopoly and profitability in this area to undercutexisting ISPs."

As service providers have to work through Telkom whenconnecting a new client to the Internet -- a process which cantake up to eight weeks for Telkom to install a digital line --there are concerns that SAIX will be at an unfair advantage whenit comes to linking up new customers, since Telkom will be able togive first priority to SAIX clients.

ISPA fears that Telkom's entry into the service provisionmarket could bring an end to the healthy competition in theindustry which has so far seen a boom in Internet serviceprovision in South Africa. Frankel has received hundreds ofletters from existing or prospective clients who acknowledge thatsubscribing to SAIX will be far more competitive than remainingwith the existing ISPs.

In an interview with Intelligence magazine, Telkom's strategyand business development executive Blackie Lahoud claimed Telkomwas not guilty of unfair competition, but "we're doing what Telcosaround the world are doing -- adding value to our services".

Frankel points out this is an invalid comparison, given theabsence of competition or regulation to keep a check on Telkom.

Telkom's Internet product manager Rikus Mattyser said in aninterview with Sapa this week that SAIX is not a service provider,and that the existing ISPs are its only clients.

Yet publicity material put out by Telkom clearly expresses anintention to become a service provider dealing direct with thepublic. "Will Telkom provide Internet services? YES!" proclaimsone brochure. It goes on to detail the advantages of Internetaccess to the business user, and declares "Telkom's SAIX servicemakes it easier than ever to access the Internet."

Approached for further comment, Telkom representative ZandileMxaku said the matter was now before the Competitions Board, andthe corporation could not respond to media enquiries at thisstage.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


85 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa The Vanishing Left


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Johannesburg - Next month, the South African Communist Partycelebrates 75 years of struggle for the socialist transformationof South Africa, as the oldest communist party on the continent.But this week, comrades were asking what had happened to thesocialist agenda.

Unease in party ranks over the direction the economy is takingwas ratcheted up by the SACP Central Committee's support for theobjective of the macro- economic framework announced by governmentlast week -- a package that also had business applauding.

"Comrades are uncomfortable," said a source. "With thedocuments inhaled by business as it was, there must be somethingwrong for the SACP to have reacted as it did." 

In its statement, the Central Committee said it "fully backed"the objectives of the package, noting it was designed as a vehicleto achieve Reconstruction and Development Programme goals, thatthe role of the public sector would be expanded and the labourmarket would be regulated, rather than left to market forces.

But the policy has been criticised by left-wing economists forgiving business most of the benefits and relying on the privatesector to turn them into growth, job creation and wealthredistribution. It has been compared with the normative economicmodel unveiled by the National Party in the last days of its rule-- which focused on export-led growth, fiscal conservatism andtight economic policy.

In some quarters of the SACP, the framework's commitment toincreased social spending and other aspects are seen as mere sopsto the working class.

African National Congress MP and party official Phillip Dexterdismissed suggestions the party was backing a right turn bygovernment, saying the new economic paradigm was forged duringnegotiations in 1994.

"We're not saying there are not weaknesses in the framework --but it's unfair to say government has adopted a Thatcheritevision," said Dexter.

The reliance on foreign and domestic private sector investment-- without any suggestion of how this would be levered -- was ofpersonal concern to him, Dexter said. "But that's not to say thedocument failed miserably."

The party's only rider in its response to the framework was tosay it intended "taking forward discussion, elaboration anddebate" on the strategy and that "questions of detail andimplementation require ongoing scrutiny".

Party sources said this week the SACP and its alliance partner,Cosatu, had been consulted "very late" over the package. Therewere suggestions political pressure had been applied and that theparty had buckled to it -- as it needed the ANC more as analliance partner than the ANC needed it. Why else, asked one,would the party be "running cover" for the government.

SACP deputy secretary general Jeremy Cronin said consultationwas late, "but thorough". The government's argument that the areahad been bedevilled by speculation and so had to be kept underwraps had been appreciated, he said. "We are not just runningcover for the ANC and government. We have been calling for thepast two years for a clear macro-economic framework and forgovernment to take the lead. This has been done."

The "crunch issue" was that the framework opted for a verytight budget restructuring to reduce the deficit by 1% in oneyear, Cronin said. "We're not sure this is the right route.

"There are good arguments for reducing the deficit -- itcreates breathing space and the country won't be pushed into adebt trap -- but it's founded on the hope that business will cometo the ball. Our concern and scepticism centre on this."

A clear framework meant that within a year or two there couldbe an assessment of what should have happened but hadn't. Cronindenied any political pressure had been applied on the party totemper its response. "There were honest discussions within thealliance about the framework and the reasons for it. Wisdominformed us that a certain degree of support is important. Therewere no pressures on us, and they would not work."

However, there had been a call "for a level-headed appreciationfor what government is trying to do".

He conceded the left's failure to come up with an alternativemodel -- Cosatu's social equity document does not address macro-economic policy -- reflected weaknesses, such as a lack oftechnical capacity.

Unease in party ranks was more a problem for the ANC-ledgovernment. "The critical thing is to open the debate and discusshard choices and prevent the tendency of bureaucrats to do thingsquietly in the dark."

A meeting of the Central Committee in two weeks' time could seesparks. "Labour and the broad left within the party are going tobe very critical," said a source.

"But a key question is whether we as a working class movementhave been able to create pressure for these issues to be engagedfrom a working class point of view. We must all takeresponsibility for that."


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Oppenheimers Meet Mandela


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Johannesburg - The Oppenheimer heirs -- Anglo American deputychairman Nicky Oppenheimer and Mary Slack -- met President NelsonMandela at his Houghton home last week to discuss the possibletakeover by the National Empowerment Consortium of AngloAmerican's press interests.

Presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana said the meeting hadbroached a range of issues, but he refused to confirm or denywhether the matter of the press interests had been raised.

The Mail & Guardian understands that Oppenhemier and Slackvoiced concern about the possible control of the publicationsowned by Times Media Limited (TML), which publishes Business Day,Sunday Times and Financial Mail. TML is part of the Johnnic group,the collection of Anglo American assets earmarked for sale in amajor black empowerment deal. 

The possible exercise of editorial control by the NationalEmpowerment Consortium, the group of companies bidding forJohnnic, prompted senior TML officials to draw up an editorialcharter, effectively enshrining the publications' editorialindependence and preserving the publications' Anglo traditions.

It is understood that the consortium, which includes New AfricaInvestments Limited (Nail), has scoffed at the idea of such acharter. Ironically, TML first encountered the idea of aneditorial charter when it was eyeing New Nation, the weeklynewspaper now owned by Nail. TML frowned at New Nation'ssuggestion of a charter, saying editorial control would have torest with it. Nail also owns the Sowetan and is bidding for one ofthe SABC radio stations up for sale.

The M&G understands the meeting between Mandela and theOppenheimers was intended to focus on the continued independenceof the press if and when it comes under black control.

Ironically, and it has not been lost on the ANC, it was Slack'sformer husband, Gordon Waddell, in his executive position atAnglo, who was primarily responsible for closing a former TMLpublication, and its flagship the Rand Daily Mail. Senior ANCmembers are riled that Anglo is suddenly worried about pressindependence on the eve of possible black ownership of itspublications.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance South Africa's Anglo Companies' Deal Flounders


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Johannesburg - One of South Africa's most trumpeted blackempowerment deals to date is floundering badly.

Sources close to the negotiating team thrashing out theNational Empowerment Consortium's bid for a collection of stakesin Anglo American companies say that, after a heavy round of talkson Youth Day, the deal seems to be in peril.

The consortium bidding for the Anglo companies includes NewAfrica Investments Limited (Nail), and its negotiating team isheaded by outgoing African National Congress secretary generalCyril Ramaphosa. 

The stakes in the companies in its sights were hived off byAnglo into a holding company called Johnnic -- in preparation,Anglo said, for a sale which promoted black economic empowerment.

But Anglo is angling for a price far beyond the reach of theblack businessmen it seeks to empower. "Anglo American is pushingthe price to a point where it could mean this is not the rightdeal for the National Empowerment Consortium," an analyst close tothe negotiators said this week.

Some players in the negotiations say it appears Anglo Americanis backtracking on the deal. Although it set up Johnnic with theexpress intention of selling it on to promote black economicempowerment, it has shied away from the idea of selling the parcelof assets off at any discount.

Nail chairman Nthato Motlana expressed concern about the pricelast year, but since then it had appeared Anglo was willing tonegotiate downwards. "At first they were in a hurry to push thedeal through. Now it looks as if they are having second thoughts,"a source said.

A financial analyst at the Johannesburg Stock Exchange said itappeared Anglo had originally trumpeted the Johnnic deal in a bidto "get the heat off them on black economic empowerment".

Now it appeared Anglo was willing to ditch the deal if it didnot get the market price for Johnnic. It would then split upJohnnic, and the various players in the National EmpowermentConsortium could pick up the pieces separately.

Many commentators believe this might not be such a bad thing.=46or although the Johnnic deal has been touted as a pivotal steptowards black economic empowerment by both Nail and AngloAmerican, many analysts and union advisers are unimpressed withthe mixed bag of assets on offer.

The assets include substantial stakes in Anglo American'slisted press companies, Times Media and Omni Media, as well assmaller stakes in South African Breweries, Toyota and Premier.

The main criticism is that, apart from the press companies,Nail will not have anything approaching control of the others inthe portfolio, which is a tiny mirror image of Anglo American -- asprawling conglomerate which has invested in many unrelatedcompanies in all sectors of the economy because exchange controlsbarred it from investing abroad.

"The main motivation for the deal is to get some senior blackfaces in South African business quickly. But there is not going tobe much empowerment from it (the deal)," said the JSE analyst.

He suggested that if Anglo American were unable to sell offJohnnic as a whole, halted the talks with the consortium and splitup Johnnic, it would allow Nail to snap up Johnnic's press assets.

This would make strategic sense, given that Nail owns theSowetan and New Nation.

Other members of the consortium are also known to have theireye

on particular parts of the Johnnic portfolio. Wiseman Nkuhlu'sWorldwide Africa Investments, which is

also in the consortium, is apparently keen on buying thePremier stake.

It is therefore understandable that a source close to the Nailnegotiating team said: "It is not the end of the world if we don'tget Johnnic. We have lots more up our sleeve."

Anglo American refused to comment on the Johnnic talks thisweek.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

88 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Olympics South Africa: Last Two Pieces In Olympic Puzzle


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Julian Drew


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Johannesburg - The final two pieces to the Olympic jigsawpuzzle which has been forming since February fell in to place onTuesday when pole vaulter Riaan Botha and modern pentathlete ClaudCloete were named to the team which leaves for Atlanta a week onSunday.

There was surprise in some quarters that the National OlympicCommittee of South Africa (Nocsa) failed to select a secondathletics candidate. Nocsa left open two more places for thissport when the original athletics squad of 23 was announced at theend of April. The truth is, however, that none of the other fournominations on Athletics South Africa's (ASA) list met thestringent selection criteria laid down by the national Olympicbody. 

Athletics simply found out what several other sports had learntearlier in the year: meeting the required qualification standardsis not necessarily good enough to book a passage to Atlanta.

Botha, who was inexplicably left out of the first athleticscontingent, having already cleared the qualifying standard fourtimes during the South African season, gave the selectors nooption but to include him on the team when he cleared a personalbest 5.85m in Lyon last Friday.

Cloete failed to qualify at two Olympic qualificationcompetitions in Seoul and Rome earlier in the year but his badluck in drawing a belligerent horse for the equestrian round wherehe failed to score any points almost certainly cost him a worldclass score in Seoul. That convinced Nocsa that Cloete was worth awild card nomination.

Wild cards are awarded to athletes from developing countrieswho have not qualified in a sport through the normal channels. TheIOC duly obliged at the weekend and Cloete has become the onlyAfrican representative in the modern pentathlon in Atlanta.

Ironically Botha's name was not at the top of ASA's list ofnominations despite the fact that his 5.85m clearance last weekplaces him eighth in the world at the moment and makes him agenuine medal prospect at the Games. Top spot belonged to racewalker Chris Britz who was controversially nominated to theoriginal squad on a "B" standard qualifier, the only athlete to beconsidered on such a standard despite the omission of many "A"standard qualifiers.

Britz was subsequently rejected by Nocsa but a lifeline wasthrown to him and other athletes who were surprisingly omittedlike Botha, javelin thrower Philip Spies, high jumper HestrieStorbeck and hurdler Ferrins Pieterse.

Nocsa said they would leave two places open until June 18, bywhich time candidates should have registered an "A" qualifier anddemonstrated their fitness, among other conditions. Britz went toGermany and recorded an "A" qualifying time, shattering his ownnational 20km record by more than two minutes to record 1:22:16.

Impressive as this time may be in one of South Africanathletics' Cinderella disciplines it is unlikely that it placeshim in the current world top 50. The world ranking lists of June11 are only 30 deep but those of May 27 which are 50 deep show himin a lowly 48th position. While not wanting to detract fromBritz's performance, it is important to put it in perspectiveafter such ludicrous claims have been made on his behalf by ASA.

Stating that such a performance would have won the 1993 worldchampionships, placed him second at the Barcelona Games and sixthat last year's world championships is a bit like comparing adownhill marathon course with a tailwind like Boston to the toughand humid Honolulu Marathon. Britz's time was recorded at theEuropean Race Walking Grand Prix in Eisenhuttenstadt, Germany,which, along with Fana in Norway for track walking, is renowned asone of the fastest road circuits around.

Quite how this performance ranks above Botha's completelydefies logic as does the absence of Spies' name from the list. Hethrew twice over the qualifying distance this year despitethrowing at a stage of his training when he would not normally bethrowing. His best of 81.34m ranks him 17th in the world on lastweek's world rankings.

Spies, however, had already resigned himself to the fact thathe wouldn't be on the list after challenging ASA over their aboutturn on his positive doping result last year. While suchconspiracy theories can often be taken with a pinch of salt it hasnot gone unnoticed that Britz is a loyal apparatchik of theTransvaal Amateur Athletic Congress and boasts the likes of ASApresident Leonard Chuene and ASA secretary general Banele Sindani,the two most powerful figures in the sport, as his closecolleagues.

It is admirable to promote a discipline like race walking butwhen Olympic places are at stake simple criteria like merit musttake precedence. In athletics such attributes are relativelysimple to measure and compare provided, of course, that you have abasic understanding of the sport.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Olympics South Africa: The Lapses Leading Up To Atlanta


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Mark Lamport-Stokes


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Johannesburg - If Preparation is one of the major keys tosuccess -- whether in sport or in battle -- then the South Africanmen's hockey team are on a hiding to nothing for the upcomingOlympic Games in Atlanta.

Not only have the squad been forced to condense their build-upto the Games because of the late "green light" giving them the go-ahead to compete, but their recent competitive track record ishardly the stuff of inspiration.

Their last 10 internationals have not produced a single win andtheir lost/drawn ratio stands at 9/1. And they have hardly beenhelped along the way with injuries to key players Wayne Graham(captain and centre half), Alistair Fredericks (centre forward andleading goal-scorer) and Brian Myburgh (rated as one of the topgoal-keepers in world hockey). 

In mitigation, though, the opposition during this 10-matchcycle has hardly been weak. Down Under in Cairns and Brisbane forthe recent four-nation tournament, South Africa faced the strengthand class of Australia (who are generally considered gold medalfavourites for Atlanta), India (currently ranked five in theworld) and a New Zealand side more or less on a par with the SouthAfricans.

South Africa's report card there read: played seven, lost six,drawn one -- with the draw a 2-2 scoreline against New Zealand andone of the losses being a 2-2 result after fulltime against thesame side in a positional play-off, only for South Africa to godown on penalty flicks 5-4.

Back at home, the South Africans took on a fit Spanish side,who were missing only two of their first-choice players, in athree-match series in Pietermaritzburg. Both teams used theinternationals as part of their final preparation for Atlanta but,once again from a South African point of view, the resultstatistics were not exactly worth framing and hanging up in a Hallof Hockey Fame.

Despite playing some very good hockey in parts, the SouthAfricans appeared fatigued at times and made too many unforcederrors. They lost the three matches 4-1, 2-1 and 6-2. Nationalhockey coach Gavin Featherstone believes one of the major lessonslearnt from this series is that South Africa desperately needs anupgraded domestic league. "We don't have a club system in thiscountry to give our guys constant pressure week in, week out,"=46eatherstone says, "and hopefully one of the lessons of 1996 willbe that this country urgently needs a national league."

"We need to pool all our top players to play against each otherregularly -- and not just once a year at the inter-provincialtournament. Our players aren't used to playing regular competitivehockey at the level they do in Europe, or at the level they do inAustralasia or in Asia. Only when our top players get this type ofcompetitive level will they develop the discipline to avoid what Iterm the 'lull periods' in team sport. Then they won't go throughthese lapses and lulls where they get punished at internationallevel."

While obviously disappointed at the 3-0 whitewash at the handsof the Spanish, Featherstone takes the pragmatic viewpoint: "Afterlosing the third Test to them, we had played 10 internationals in17 days and I think it was a case of a bridge too far. We didn'tplay the Spanish on an equal playing field; we went round theworld, played seven matches and then said, within two days, thatwe could take them on in three Test matches. It proved a littlebit too much for our lads at this stage.

"But anyone who saw the quality of our play in the first halfof that third Test can see the standard we play at. Occasionallyit does happen that the bottom falls out -- but I think we musttake heart at our result in the second test ... where we lost 2-1... and at the first half of that third Test. We showed that wecan play at this level."

"I think the main thing the boys are learning is that you canhave a lot of the game and yet still lose by three goals becauseyou have to concentrate extra hard on teams who counter-attackwell. There's no doubt in my mind that that is the area I've gotto work on very hard with the players mentally between now andAtlanta." What also has not helped the South African cause was the latego-ahead given for their Olympic Games participation -- and thishas directly led to the condensed period of preparation by thehockey squad since February.

"Remember we were allowed to go to Atlanta in mid- February,although we qualified in September at the All-Africa Games,"=46eatherstone says. "So we had a five-month period where we didvery little and weren't allowed to really. What we've had to do iscondense our physical training. So far, we've done endurancetraining and only now can we get on to our speed and sharpness."

Featherstone feels the difference in fitness levels betweenSouth Africa and Spain during their recent series was marked:"There's no doubt that the Spanish showed that they are matchsharp now for the Olympics, whereas we've still got a month to goon that training. And, in fact, our training will actuallycontinue in Atlanta because we had such a late start in goingthere."

Late start or not, there is very little else that the SouthAfricans could have done in recent months to improve on theirOlympic Games preparation. As Featherstone points out, a briefbreak is vital to rest bruised and overworked bodies after theintensity of playing 10 hockey internationals in under threeweeks. And an extra bonus from this short lay-off period would bethe full return to match fitness of playmakers Wayne Graham andAlistair Fredericks.

Despite all this, it may be that South Africa will still be ona hiding to nothing come Atlanta. But the South African hockeyteam are probably owed one or two favours by Dame Fortune -- andthey could certainly do with that modicum of luck which has notsmiled upon them over the last month.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


Arts Is White South African Rock Resurging?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian(Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Johannesburg - According to Tusk's Benjy Mudie, there's a"renaissance" happening, something of a "new wave". He may beright -- either that, or local record execs are just catching upwith their counterparts overseas. At last, the garage band iscommercial again.

Given an injection of new life by neo-punk, grunge and alterna-rockers like REM, Nirvana, Pearl Jam and Green Day, the genre ofwhite-boy-plays-loud-guitar is flowering globally. Oasis and theirlike have topped the British charts, where once only synth-swathed ditties ruled. The constraints of the mainstream money-makers, obsessed with the lowest common denominator and terrifiedof anything not produced to death, seem to have loosened. 

And South Africa is surfing that wave too. It may be somethingto do with our national sense of new freedoms, or perhaps it'sjust preparation for the quota system, but it does feel as thoughan awful lot of "local product" has been released in the last fewmonths.

Highlights include albums by The Pressure Cookies (okay, mostof them are female) and The K=EArels. New work from well-knownfigures such as Tony Cox and Valiant Swart (his first CD, DieMystic Boer) is on the shelves. Bright Blue are back with a three-track EP, Open Your Eyes, and The Usual -- who share Bright Blue'sguitarist-singer Tom Fox -- have a six-track mini-album, Six Songsfrom the Inside, out too.

Moreover, two new compilation CDs give a reasonably rosypicture of exactly where South African rock'n'roll stands atpresent.

Street Level: Bare Essentials is the product of Cape Town'sStreet Level Studio, started by Richard Black and James Stewart.They have recorded The Usual as well as a handful of other CapeTown bands, giving them each a track or two on Bare Essentials toshow what they can do. The featured bands include Psycho- Deli,Black Diamond, The Groove Kings and Woodshed.

The fact that the CD has been released by record giant BMG --who also put their imprimatur on The Usuals' package -- gives hopethat the era of bands languishing in semi-obscurity without big-label support is over. The new lot, with luck, will have careerslonger than those of many of their Eighties' predecessors, forwhom the release of a record was very often swansong instead ofstarting- point.

The other compilation CD, the Tusk/5FM My Generation, is not --as the title, stolen from The Who circa 1965, might imply -- arepository of retro-rock. The only song on it that seems reallyout of place in 1996 is Duc the Fox's Love or Money. Otherwise,this is pretty much up-to-the-minute, a cross-section of SouthAfrica's newest, freshest talent.

Several of its 17 tracks, notably, came via the Shifty/Tic TicBang nexus, and it is a well-shaped collection that ranges fromthe guitar-lashed constructions of Squeal, Springbok Nude Girls,Sugardrive and Lithium, to the effervescently jivey pop of UrbanCreep and the New-Age yodelling of QCumba Zoo.

Several of the bands featured on My Generation are touring thecountry on the Bandslam bill, which hopes to do for us whatLollapalooza did for the USA. Perhaps it will be a further step inthe direction of white South African musicians, at last, making aliving from original music. At the very least, the concerts shouldhelp sell some CDs.

In the meantime, beyond all this big-hype activity, the newreleases keep coming. The aforementioned Valiant Swart CD isenjoyably barbed blues-rock; KwaZulu-Natalian Syd Kitchenimpresses with his jazzified City Child; and Joe Silva takes anunusual tack with Journeys into Coincidence, a selection of laid-back numbers, a bit like Ry Cooder in lazy- soundtrack mode, whichcan only help one feel meditative.

And then there's Jonathan Handley. The King Rat, pretending tobe The Glee Club, continues his South African Gothic saga withpart two, Transvaal Gothic (the first was Free State Gothic). Thewhole is a massive cycle of 33 songs, revolving around thepicaresque story of a sometime windmill salesman. Maybe onedoesn't need all 33 songs to get the picture, but none are merethrowaways, and many are as good as anything of that ilk ever madein this country.

And Handley is still, scandalously, on cassette only.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
