Africa News


June, 1996


Sudan Arabs Violate Peace Accord In Northern Sudan


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

London - In a report dated 22 April, the "Gazette" has receivedaccounts of surprise attacks by a joint force of the Misiriya Arab"murahaleen" and the Popular Defence Forces (PDF) of the Khartoumregime upon the Dinka communities in the Abyei and NorthernGogrial areas. These areas had been peaceful since 1991 owing toa peace accord signed by the Misiriya Arabs with the Ngok and TwicDinka. It now transpires that the National Islamic Front(NIF)regime offered the Misiriya Arabs all manner of inducements tobreak that peace accord and finally, in February, it succeeded inthat objective.

The joint force launched its attack on 29 February along theRiver Kiir. The operation lasted until 3 March, by which timeseveral Dinka villages had been ransacked and burnt down. Theyare: Malwal, Rumbek, Nguet, Micar, Atong, Majok Alieu and Lang.Cattle was looted and crops were destroyed. 

This past year had seen a bountiful harvest and the Dinka wereconfident that they would not need any additional relief aid. Itis believed that the Dinka's move towards self sufficiencyprovoked Khartoum into attacking at this time.

On 10 March, a further military force launched a second attackon other villages in the area, destroying Malual Alieu, Dier,Gongmabil, Rumnyien, Kokwei, Mabil Anyiuel and Kol Kuot. Thisforce was reinforced by units of the regular army stationed atAbyei. On 29 March, the attackers returned to the area in evengreater numbers. The attack was co-ordinated with the Nuer tribalmilitia from Bentiu. That militia had instructions to prevent anyDinka cattle from using the common grazing land, so that no Dinkacattle or property escaped the looters.

The Sudan People's Liberation Army's (SPLA) civiliancommissioner for Abyei, James Ajing Path, has produced a detailedreport of the attacks. In the attack of 29 March, more than fortycivilians were killed, thirty of them named in the report; morethan one hundred women and children were captured and sold intoslavery, including twenty-nine identified by the name in thereport.

Slave Market. A slave trading and exchange camp was set upoutside Abyei. Women were offered for their sexual services and asdomestic slaves to Arabs who had not been involved in the attacks.The Dinka themselves were allowed to buy back their relatives atthe rate of five cows per person or the equivalent in cash.

Following the third attack, large numbers of Dinka movedfurther South into Bahr El Ghazal and have sought refuge aroundthe relief centre at Mayen Abun in the Twic Dinka area of NorthernGogrial. They are now at the mercy of the providers of relief aid.The areas is part of Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) but because itis in territory disputed by the SPLA and the NIF regime, therelief flights are infrequent and often cancelled at a whim by theregime.

Not all the Dinka made homeless by the attacks have managed toreach Mayen Abun. Reports suggest that many thousands are hidingout along the River Kiir, afraid that the marauders will return tocapture them or finish them off. Those that have arrived arealready suffering from food shortages.

Mr James Ajing Path has appealed to the international reliefcommunity to quickly come to the aid of this newly displacedpopulation. The displaced people are quite capable of organisingthemselves to plant crops in the area during the rainy season, ifthey are given the seeds and tools with which to do it. Theplanting season in this area is quite flexible and crops could besworn as late as June and July. Obviously, the people will needrelief supplies to last until the crops can be harvested. Thesepeople are keen to become self sufficient once more, having losteverything in the three raids. As many as 100,000 people have beendisplaced by the attacks.

Workable Airstrips. There are a number of workable airstrips inthe area that could be used for bringing in emergency reliefsupplies. Apart from Mayen Abun itself, there is the airstrip atAkak to the West, and airstrips at Turalei and Maper to the East.OLS has used all four airstrips in the past. There are a furthertwo airstrips to the North of Mayen Abun at Ajak Kwac and Agok.These last two airstrips are closest to the area of devastationand lie in a very fertile agricultural area which could be usedfor planting crops.

Demand for Self Defence. There are many loud voices now withinthe Dinka communities, particularly in Northern Bahr El Ghazal butalso elsewhere, who are calling for the SPLA to help the tribe setup and arm home guards to defend themselves against the Arabs andother tribal militias that seem to attack them with impunity. TheSPLA has rightly resisted these calls. However, in the absence ofany other alternative for the security of this tribe- so targetedfor genocide by the NIF regime- the case for the tribe to armitself to resist the regime's machinations is quite strong. Thatis, unless the SPLA finds itself with the resources and facilitiesto station a protective force in the border areas of Northern BahrEl Ghazal.

When in 1987-88 the government in Khartoum unleashed Arab andother tribal militias against the Dinka communities in the borderareas, there was also a call to the SPLA to train and arm homeguards. The reasons for resisting these calls for arms to thetribes were valid at that time and they remain so today. Perhapsthe SPLA should consider placing its guerrilla units in theseborder areas to give the tribes there the confidence they need fortheir security and protection.

Where Is the SPLA? Whilst all the devastation and destructiontook place, the forces of the SPLA were nowhere to be seen. Thisraises the obvious question as to why this was the case. Perhapsthe SPLA believed that the peace accord between the Arabs and theDinka was the best guarantor of security in the area. Even if thatwas not the case, the SPLA would need a huge military force toprotect the area from the hit and run raids of the militia forces.

The NIF regime's plan is a simple one. If it can keep thetribes in the border areas fighting one another, then it canredirect its own war resources away from this area to other battlefronts in the South, the Nuba Mountains and now Eastern Sudan. Itis not clear what SPLA forces may have been in the area becausethere was also the problem further South inside Bahr El Ghazal ofthe militia force of the renegade commander Kerubino Kuanyin Bolat Gogrial.

The SPLA has in the past been reluctant to engage in wholesaleattacks on tribal militias, as it is a force fighting for nationalliberation from the NIF regime. However, the SPLA cannot ignorethe security of the local population in these areas forever,because it ultimately needs their support. These communities arebeing attacked because they are perceived by the NIF to besupporters of the SPLA. They would not be under such severepressure if they accepted Khartoum's overlordship. It must behoped that the SPLA will recognise that these communities do needproper protection before the regime succeeds in convincing thepeople that the SPLA has abandoned them. The SPLA will not be ableto maintain the loyalty of these groups unless it does somethingto alleviate their suffering.

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Call For Robben Island Prison To Be A Museum


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Pretoria - Obviously nauseated by his memories of SouthAfrica's Robben Island, a visiting Namibian Minister has requestedthe South African government to turn its notorious jail house intoa museum.

Mr. Andimba Toivo Ya Toivo, Namibia's Minister for Mines, whohad accompanied President Sam Nujoma to the prison on May 15, andwho spent 16 years on the prison for opposing Pretoria's rule,said such a move would help future generations learn about thehistorical importance of the island.

Young people, he emphasised, should be able to see and knowwhere their leaders came from. 

Robben Island is situated 12 kilometres offshore Cape Town.Current South African President, Nelson Mandela, among others,spent 18 of his 27 years in jail on the island. The future of theprison, which is now said to hold 133 common law prisoners, is asubject of heated debate in South Africa.

Toivo Ya Toivo, who is also a senior member Namibia's rulingSouth- West African People's Organization (SWAPO) further said hisreturn to the island brought back mixed feelings.

The Namibian minister recalled one incident whereby he wasassaulted by prison guards until he collapsed. "If you reported acase of assault, they would turn against you and say you arespreading malicious rumours," he recalled.

But despite bad memories of the prison, Mr. Toivo Ya Toivoconceded that the place had its good moments. Said he: "It bringsback memories and mixed feelings, some good and some bad."

According to some press reports, the South African governmentappointed a cabinet committee late last year to look into ways ofturning the island into a profitable possession when it ceases torun as a prison at the end of this y

An official document quoting the country's Arts, Culture,Science and Technology Minister Ben Ngubane says; "Robben Islandhas been declared a national monument. This will involve theentire island, together with a stretch of one sea mile surroundingit."

The same document describes Robben Island as a former leper andlunatic colony, and the prison where Nelson Mandela was locked upfor 18 years.

LANGUAGE: English

June, 1996


Central African Republic Central African Opposition Shuns New Government


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Bangui - A government of national unity was formed on June 18in the Central African Republic, a month after the nation wasparalysed by a mutiny but without the main opposition parties,which refused to join.

The 21-member government, formed overnight on June 17 to June18 by Jean Paul Ngoupande, will have none of the main parties inthe seven-party Democratic Council of Opposition Parties (CODEPO)in its ranks, which maintained that the division of ministries inthe new government was not representative, and announced that theywould hold a press conference later on June 18.

Ngoupande said in a radio address that he regretted the absenceof the opposition within his government but added that his "doorremained open" to change and that he would continue cooperatingwith the CODEPO. 

Four of the ministers belong to the Central African DemocraticRally (RDC), which was also in opposition but was not a member ofCODEPO, while the remainder are from the ruling party and civiliansociety.

Ngoupande was called to form a government of national unityafter a bloody 10-day mutiny by hundreds of soldiers late lastmonth when more than 40 people were killed and widespread damagewas caused.

President Ange-Felix Patasse's ruling Movement for theLiberation of the Central African People (MLPC) wanted to holdmost posts, but CODEPO said the government should fully reflectall political forces.

The presidential majority has 10 seats, six for the MLPC andfour for its allies, while the RDC has four, civilianrepresentatives another four and independents have two.

The 21st member of the government is Ngoupande himself, up tonow ambassador to Paris, who is counted as a representative ofcivilian society.

Ngoupande and the government will have their work cut outtrying to restore economic progress blighted by the mutiny and theexodus of up to 2,000 foreign nationals.

One of the first tasks will be to give state employees twomonths back pay to offset wage arrears, which sometimes reach backmore than a year.

But French Cooperation Minister Jacques Godfrain has saidFrance will help the Central African Republic pay the salaries ofits bureaucrats, arguing that if it did not help, reforms would beimpossible.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Vatican And Egypt's Sunni Muslims Set Up Joint Committee


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 720 words


 

CAIRO - The Roman Catholic Church and Egypt's highest Muslimauthority have decided to set up a joint committee to stimulatedialogue between the two religions with a view to promotingtolerance and fighting religious extremism, it was learnt here onJune 15.

An announcement by Al Azhar spokesman Omar Bastawissi said theVatican and Al Azhar, Egypt's highest Sunni Muslim authority,would set up the joint committee soon to stimulate dialoguebetween the two religions.

"The creation of this committee is aimed at bringing Islam andChristianity closer together as well as coordinating efforts by AlAzhar and the Vatican to promote tolerance and to fight againstany kind of (religious) extremism," said Bastawissi, who heads theoffice of Al Azhar Sheikh, Mohammad Sayed Tantawi. 

"The committee will also be tasked with protecting the sublimeprecepts of Islam and Christianity and the dignity of God'smessengers," he added.

Bastawissi said "a meeting between the two parties will be heldin the near future to organise the setting up of this committee,which will be made up of Al Azhar and Vatican officials as well asthe president of the International Union for Dialogue between theThree Monotheist Religions, Ali al-Saman."

He added that the creation of the committee was approved at ameeting in Cairo at the beginning of the month between Tantawi andCardinal Francis Arinze, president of the Vatican's committeeaimed at forging dialogue between different religions.

The development is the more significant because it comes at atime when conservative religious scholars who once held sway atAl-Azhar, the citadel of Sunni Muslim orthodoxy, were now battlingto keep their influence under the new, more moderate head sheikh,Tantawi.

Since Tantawi took the helm of the 1,000-year-old institutionin March, conservatives have opened fire on his rulings, led bythe Azhar Scholars' Front (ASF) grouping around 1,000 theologians.

The ASF has even cast doubt on Tantawi's religious credentials,targeting in particular his refusal to declare militants who carryout anti-Israel suicide bombings as being "martyrs."

The Front insisted Tantawi's statements on the bombers were"his personal opinion which cannot be considered a fatwa," orofficial religious decree.

Tantawi, who was the mufti of Egypt before becoming sheikh ofAl- Azhar, often differed with his more hardline predecessor Gadal-Haq Ali Gad al-Haq over issues such as bank interest andcircumcision of girls.

But even while battling Tantawi, conservatives are also beinghemmed in by government moves to crack down on radical clericsbacking Muslim militants in their anti-state campaign which hasclaimed more than 1,000 lives since 1992.

They especially protest a draft law from the Religious AffairsMinistry allowing only ministry-appointed imams to preach and anew rule requiring ministry permission to build new privatemosques, and have warned that the law could cause "unrest whichwould go beyond any unrest in the past," referring to themilitants' armed campaign.

The Religious Affairs Ministry runs 34,000 mosques and plans totake over another 20,000 private ones.

"The conservative movement sees itself threatened by Tantawi'sattempts to use the mobilization against Islamic radicals to bringthe moderate trend into dominance," and the Sheikh's latest moveon relations with the Vatican could unleash another round ofcriticisms from the conservatives.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


95 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Information Ministers Plan OAU Radio Station


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Pretoria - A meeting of African Information Ministers here onJune 18 ordered a study into the feasibility of establishing anOrganization of African Unity (OAU) radio station, a statementissued by the group said.

The study will consider the cost, content, languages, and rangeof transmission of such a station, according to the statement bythe Bureau of the Conference of African Information Ministers.

The meeting of the bureau, a sub-structure of the conferencethat is chaired by South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, wasattended by ministers from Cameroon, Ethiopia, South Africa, Togo,Tunisia and Zambia, countries which currently run the Pan AfricanNews Agency (PANA), a multi-national project of the OAU. 

At the June 18 meeting, the ministers also approved a new legalstatus for PANA and appealed to OAU member states to pay theirarrear contributions to the agency's budget.

The proposal for an OAU radio station comes amid a debate inSouth Africa over the future of Channel Africa, the Johannesburg-based shortwave external radio service that is one of the largestbroadcasters to the continent.

South Africa's Foreign Ministry, which has funded ChannelAfrica since it was established in 1966 as a propaganda stationfor the apartheid government, wants to close down the servicebecause it can no longer afford to run it.

South Africa's Foreign Ministry, which has funded ChannelAfrica since it was established in 1966 as a propaganda stationfor the apartheid government, wants to close down the servicebecause it can no longer afford to run it.

A campaign launched by Channel Africa's staff to save theservice has received wide support from some internationalorganisations and some of its 15 million listeners in Africa andelsewhere.

Its supporters say that Channel Africa has transformed itselfto become the voice of democratic South Africa and a credible andunbiased source of news and information in a continent where suchfree speech is limited.

The cabinet was scheduled to decide Channel Africa's fate at ameeting in Cape Town late on June 19.

Flame Nieuwenhuizen, the channel's acting executive editor,said in a statement on June 18 that there are many "creativesolutions" to keep the station on the air, including extending itscoverage outside of Africa.

"The service should not be scaled down but if anything,expanded to Europe and North America, the Indian sub-continent,and in Arabic to North Africa and the Middle East where SouthAfrica is cementing new friendships," he said.

Nieuwenhuizen said Channel Africa played a valuable role insupplementing South Africa's diplomatic missions in Africa andother parts of the world.

"Not only does it reach Africa's elite, but also people inremote areas -- indeed people who are the main participants inAfrica's democratisation process," he said.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


96 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large UNICEF Marks African Child Day


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Nairobi - Kenyans on June 18 joined other nations marking "TheDay of the African Child" which also coincided with the UnitedNations Children's Fund (UNICEF) 50th anniversary.

Speaking to a gathering at the City Stadium here, the UNICEFKenya country representative Mr. Chrispin Wilson noted that evenat such a time of optimism during the celebration of life andwell-being of the children present, there was need to think aboutthose children categorized as being "in extremely difficultcircumstances."

"There are many instances when children in our country areunable to rejoice, to benefit from their educationalopportunities, to play in a carefree way and to live outuntroubled lives within a secure family context," Wilson toldguests marking the Africanc Child Day, an occasion that waspreceded by a week of related activities. 

Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) orphaned childrenwho are stigmatized and denied a nurturing family environment, thedisabled and abandoned as well as those from poverty situationshaving to work from an early age and live in inadequate,overcrowded and unsanitary housing, are some of the childrenliving in difficult circumstances.

UNICEF programmes, he added, were focusing on vulnerable groupssuch as the urban poor and nomadic groups and also trying toreduce geographic and gender disparities in Kenya. Girls educationis now acknowledged as one of the most powerful instruments ofprogress, the Kenya country representative observed.

The day's theme, Children First, emphasized the fact that theessential needs of children should be given priority in both badand good times. Some 12,000 children turned up for thecelebration, the largest number since its inception in 1991.

The day's events were marked by presentations of songs, dances,plays and poems from school children, children's homes such asthose for street and displaced children, and approved schools aswell as from adult drama groups on AIDS awareness.

Children's presentations which greatly moved the audiencehighlighted the plight of street children and the young ones' needfor parental love even amidst plenty.

During the week's activities street children received freescreening and educational awareness on sexually transmitteddiseases, drug abuse, hygiene and nutrition, courtesy of Kenya'sMaendeleo Ya Wanawake Organization (MYWO) the national women'sumbrella body advocating for the progress of women all over thecountry.

The MYWO chairlady Mrs Zipporah Kittony revealed that over 90per cent of African children live in abject poverty with more than60 per cent of births taking place in unhygienic conditionsleading to high infant mortality.

The Day of The African Child, set up by the Organization ofAfrican Unity (OAU) with support from UNICEF,commemorates the 1976massacre of South Africa's Sowetan children who were protesting aruling by the then apartheid government that they be taught inAfrikaans, regarded by the blacks as the language of oppression.

According to UNICEF, the day while marking the past, alsofocuses on the future as it gives governments, organizations, thegeneral public and children an opportunity to assess Africa'sachievements as well as its children's continuing needs.

The 50 year-old UN Children's Fund, working mainly to nurturelong- term development, has had to rechannel an increased amountof its resources for emergency care of children suffering theconsequences of war, a situation that sadly bears great similaritywith that of the 1946 post-World War II, which occasioned itsestablishment.

UNICEF estimates that during the last decade, 2 millionchildren have been killed, 4 to 5 million orphaned or separatedfrom their parents and 10 million psychologically traumatized as aresult of wars.

Africa News


June, 1996


Uganda Ugandan Churches Lobby For Peace, Sanity In The North


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Kampala - Christian leaders in Uganda have made an impassionedplea to Uganda rebel leader Joseph Kony of the Lord's ResistanceArmy (LRA), to end the spate of senseless killings that his rebelforce has been committing in the north against his own Acholipeople.

The Christian leaders' statement came ahead of a communiquedated June 13 from the Uganda People's Defence Force (UPDF),stating that 15 people travelling in a pick up in Gulu District ofnorthern Uganda were killed when their vehicle detonated alandmine.

The landmine believed to be an anti-tank device was so powerfulit threw the vehicle at least 20 metres into the bush.

The Christian leaders' statement was signed by the chairman ofthe Uganda Joint Christian Council (UJCC), Emmanuel CardinalWamala. It read: "We address you Joseph Kony as a person whoclaims to be a Christian believer. One of the commandments in theBible and a basic tenet of Christianity is : 'Thou shall notkill'." 

The statement was also addressed to the leader of the pro-IdiAmin West Nile Bank Front (WNFB) who are waging war against thegovernment of President Yoweri Museveni in West Nile in north-eastern Uganda.

The statement asked the government to do "everything possible"to bring the suffering of the people of the north to an end.

Meanwhile, President Yoweri Museveni has expressed shock at thekilling of two Acholi elders allegedly by the LRA. The elders,Samson Okot-Ogoni and Olanya-Lagony were killed while on a missionto meet the rebels after initial contacts with them.

President Museveni has said repeatedly that he would not talkto Joseph Kony, citing the numerous atrocities the LRA are knownto have committed in the course of waging war against thegovernment in the north.

In another development, the Uganda Episcopal Conference hasmandated three Bishops - Bishop Dr. Paul Kalanda of Fort Portal,Bishop Adrian Ddungu of Masaka and Bishop Erasmus Wandera ofSoroti to visit Gulu and report on the possibility and modalitiesof dialogue with Joseph Kony.

The Catholic Church in Uganda has also started prayers for therestoration of peace and sanity in the north. A mass held atRubaga Cathedral on June 16 prayed for Joseph Kony's change ofheart.

The turn-out for the main mass was described as low. Ugandanleaders and politicians were conspicuously absent. Local dailyNew Vision reported that neither Cardinal Wamala nor the AuxiliaryBishop Mathias Ssekamanya were present. -0-(hdLiberiaBishop Warns Liberian Catholics As Institutions Close(byAll Africa Press ServiceJune 24, 1996 (1

Monrovia - Liberia's Catholic Archbishop Michael K. Francis haswarned that any church member found to have links with any of thecountry's warring factions will be excommunicated.

In a strongly worded pastoral letter read out at Monrovia'sSacred Heart Cathedral on June 16, Archbishop Francis alsoannounced that all Catholic-run institutions, including healthcentres and schools will be closed until a constitutionallyelected government takes over in Liberia.

The archbishop was reacting to the continuing insecurity in thecountry, heightened by recent factional fighting which resulted inheavy loss of lives, widespread looting and destruction ofproperty in Monrovia. However, the pastoral letter signed byArchbishop Francis said Catholic churches throughout the countrywill continue to operate.

The Catholic Church has been at the forefront of reliefoperations in Liberia during the six-year-old civil war, and theSt. Joseph's Catholic Hospital in Monrovia is regarded as one ofmost efficient in delivering health services. The University ofLiberia's Medical College is attached to the hospital.

For years in pre-war Liberia, Catholic schools dominated toppositions in the state exams administered by the West AfricanExaminations Council (WAEC).

Asked in a British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) interviewwhether he has abandoned the Liberian people, Archbishop Francisreplied: "Of course not, but I am disappointed with the violencethat has

taken place." He warned that the church could not afford tocontinue to rebuild while the warring factions continue todestroy.

The Catholic radio station in Monrovia was among manyfacilities extensively damaged in an orgy of looting during nearlytwo months of bloody factional fighting in the capital.

The church's decision to close down vital institutions has beendescribed by analysts as a severe blow to humanitarian efforts inLiberia.

Meanwhile, after 24 days in high seas, a Russian trawlercarrying more than 400 Liberian and other West African refugeestrying to flee the conflict, has returned safely to Monrovia afterit was turned away by neighbouring countries.

Ivory Coast, Ghana, Togo and Benin, are all said to haverefused to grant permission for the ship to dock at their ports,arguing that they did not want to encourage a further influx ofrefugees from Liberia. The vessel, Zolotitsa (Little golden one)left Monrovia on May 26 with its cargo of about 450 refugees andwas reported missing at one stage.

Before its arrival back in Monrovia, aid workers using a lightplane mounted an unsuccessful search for the ship for more than aweek. Aid workers who visited the ship after its arrival at theFreeport of Monrovia are quoted saying conditions on board weresqualid, but that the passengers were in good shape. There were nodeaths reported among the passengers.

Meanwhile, the World Health Organisation (WHO) has warned of analarming health situation developing in Liberia's north-westernLofa county.

In a statement released here on June 18 following an assessmentmission to the county, the WHO described health conditions thereas "alarming, and there was an urgent need for humanitarianassistance."

The WHO said some of the health facilities in Lofa "are in poorcondition while others have been completely destroyed."

The Curran Memorial Hospital in Zorzor, formerly run by theLiberian Lutheran Church, "is completely burnt down, while theTellewoyen Hospital in Voinjama was in dire need of renovation torestore it to its former status."

The WHO, however, said four health facilities in upper Lofacounty were still catering to some 348,000 people, 44 per cent ofwhom are Sierra Leonean refugees.

The statement quoted physicians at the four health facilitiessaying that malaria, acute respiratory infection and diarrhoeaaccount for 60 per cent of out-patient cases.

A week earlier, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) delivered 380tonnes of badly needed relief food to Lofa "to ease the acute foodshortage facing thousands of war-weary citizens" in that county.

Few non-governmental aid agencies are active outside Monrovia,having reduced their operations when factional fighting broke outin the capital early April.

On June 11 more than a dozen NGOs announced they would limittheir work in Liberia to emergencies only until conditionsimproved.

They said persistent looting of their vehicles and equipment byarmed factions was prolonging the civil conflict that has ragedsince 1989, making their presence in the West African country moreharmful than beneficial to Liberian civilians.

In another development, at least 470 bodies have been recoveredand buried in the main cemetery in Monrovia by a health teamsearching for victims of Liberia's latest factional fighting.

Chief government pathologist Isaac Moses, supervising thesearch, said on June 18 the bodies were found in several parts ofthe city, including areas around the Greystone displaced personscentre in the diplomatic enclave of Mamba Point.

He said the search for and reburial of the bodies started twoweeks ago, with bodies recovered including 150 exhumed on beachesin Mamba Point on June 17 and reburied by the health team.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambian Church And State On Collision Course


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

Lusaka - The Church and government of Zambia have disagreed onthe May 28 signing of the Mwanakatwe Constitution Amendment Bill,barring former President Kenneth Kaunda and his United NationalIndependence Party (UNIP) deputy senior chief Inyambo Yeta fromcontesting presidential and parliamentary elections scheduled forOctober this year.

The Catholic bishops have further rejected the inclusion of thedeclaration of Zambia as a "Christian Nation" in the preamble ofthe new Constitution of Zambia.

They feel this could be the beginning of a state religion inthe country, Acting Secretary General at the Catholic Secretariatin Lusaka Fr. Joe Komakoma has said. 

"President Fredrick Chiluba's government has not respected therecommendations made by the Mwanakatwe Constitution ReviewCommission that Zambia shall not adopt a state religion. Thismeans the government has no respect for the wishes of the peoplebecause something that has been rejected by the MwanakatweConstitution Review Commission is now being forced on us," saidFr. Komakoma.

Fr. Komakoma, who is the Executive Secretary of the CatholicCommission for Justice and Peace (CCJP), said the position of theCatholic bishops as contained in their pastoral letter, had notchanged in view of the declaration of Zambia as a Christiannation.

In their pastoral letter, The Future is Ours of 1992, and anOpen Letter to President Chiluba and Members of Parliament, datedApril 26,1996, the Catholic Bishops maintained that a nation'sChristian character could not be identified by such declarationsbut by its deeds of justice and concern for the poor.

Fr. Komakoma said the arrogance of the MMD government was againreflected in the lack of theological conference or debate on theissue to discuss the implications of the inclusion of thedeclaration in the constitution.

But the government said that the declaration of Zambia as aChristian nation did not mean punishing people who belonged toother religions.

President Chiluba pointed out that on the contrary, people withdifferent religions are free to practise what they believe inwithout interference from anybody. He noted that Christianity wasnot an exercise in vanity but embraced spiritual ideals intendedfor the good of the believers.

At a recent United Church of Zambia (UCZ) fund-raising dinnerdance held in the northern town of Ndola, where President Chilubawas guest of honour, Rev. Valerie Ogden in the company of Rev.Mwape Chilekwa, welcoming President Chiluba, complained about thehigh import duty that the Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA) subjectedthe church to when receiving donations from overseas.

Rev. Ogden said the ZRA sometimes charges twice the originalvalue of the donated items. This kind of attitude does not reflecta Christian nation as the government does not value the donationsthe church receives from sister organisations overseas.

"It is unfortunate that the government has not listened to thebishops, but as long as they (authorities) do not abide by gooddeeds, the inclusion of Zambia as a Christian nation in theConstitution would not change the character of this nation," addedFr. Komakoma.

In another development, Bishop Stephen Mumba of Lusaka AnglicanDiocese pointed out that people are Christians without Zambiabeing pronounced Christian.

He requested the MMD government to let Christians worship Godas they have always done in the past saying, Zambia as a secularstate was better than it is now.

"It does not mean that when Zambia is a Christian nation thegovernment is perfect. We have known of countries where the Biblehas been used to oppress others," cautioned Bishop Mumba.

The Church has told the MMD Government that barring formerPresident Kaunda from running for elections defeats the wholepurpose of declaring Zambia a Christian nation because in such anation every citizen has the right to contest presidential andparliamentary seats.

It is believed here that since President Chiluba was elected asthe MMD leader, even the voter registration exercise has had aninauspicious beginning.

The Church, non-governmental organisations (NGOs) andopposition parties are geared to dialogue with government toreverse the assented constitution to allow former PresidentKenneth Kaunda to contest.

Lately, Zambia has experienced a series of bombings andexplosions launched by the hitherto shadowy group calling itselfBlack Mamba which the MMD government has linked with UNIP.

A police bomb disposal expert, Ordon Banda, was killed on June7, 1996 and his colleague Paul Ngoma seriously wounded when a bombplaced under a lavatory seat at Lusaka International Airport wentoff.

And on June 19, UNIP's deputy, chief Inyambo Yeta, KennethKaunda's press aide Muhabi Lungu and six others appeared before aLusaka court to answer charges linking them to terrorism.

The eight are accused of being behind the Black Mamba, a groupunder whose name bombs have been planted in various parts of thecountry as a protest sign against laws barring the former Zambianpresident from running for presidency, come elections in October.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


-0United States and Africa Sports - Olympics Nigeria Ends Pre-Olympic Trials Panafrican News Agency June 23, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent LAGOS, Nigeria - The 1996 Nigeria track and field events to choose the country's athletes for the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, the United States, ended Saturday in Lagos. Some 20,000 spectators watched the finals at the National Stadium in Sururele, a Lagos neighbourhood, with the 100 metre race for men and women as major highlights. African track queen Mary Onyali-Omagbemi beat all comers in the women's 100-metre race, finishing in 10.67 seconds. She also won gold in the women's 200-metre race. Davidson Ezinwa, nother United States-based sprinter, won the men's 100-metre dash with a time of 9.86 seconds. But the times are subject to confirmation because officials said they were manually recorded. Two of Nigeria's four athletes, Chioma Ajunwa and Clement Chukwu, made impressive comeback after serving their four-year ban by the International Athletics Federation. Chioma came second behind Onyali-Omagemi in the 100-metre women's race and picked up the gold in the long jump. Chukwu, on the other hand, placed third in the 400 metres behind policeman Sunday Bada and Jude Monye who placed first and second in the explosive race. Two other returnees Charity Okpara and Innocent Asonze were not as lucky. (DOCUMENT) US Groups Plan March and Vigil Against Dictatorship in Zaire


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Washington, DC - The following press release was announced by acoalition of groups interested in Zaire.

The All North America Conference on Zaire, the Committee of theDemocratic Forces of Zaire, and the Zaire Educational Councilannounce a MARCH and MATANGA, an all-night vigil, organized tohasten the end of one of the most ruthless dictatorships left onearth. The march will (1) commemorate countless martyrs who diedin the struggle against dictatorship; (2) call for increasedresources, monitoring and enforcement personnel for free and fairelections in July 1997; (3) protest against the support accordedby the Republican Right, the Clinton Administration and theRepublic of France for the illegal government of Mobutu and Kengowa Dondo; (4) and will remind the American people, whose money wasused to build dictatorship in Zaire, that Mobutu is still to bebrought to justice for perpetrating genocide in Rwanda, Burundi,Angola, and Zaire.

Leaders of the movement to end dictatorship in Zaire willarrive in the Washington Metropolitan Area during the week of June24th 1996 to attend this historic event. Activities will takeplace in Lafayette Park (in front of the White House), Washington,D.C. on June 30th, 1996 and July 1st, 1996 beginning at 12:00Noon.

Other Sponsors include Zaire Network, Alumni of the AmericanSchool of Kinshasa, The International Association for Zaire, TheZaire Community of Iowa, The Zaire Community of Minnesota, ZairianCommunity Charlotte (North Carolina), La Mutualite Zairoise dePhiladelphie, Concerned American Citizens, Immigrants, and Exilesof Zairian Origin, Forum Zairois, The Zairian Community ofLexington, Kentucky.

For further information please contact Dr. Alafuele Kalala,(301) 460-1533; Dr. Mwana N. Mawampanga Tshimanga, (606) 269-2714;or John Metzel (202) 783-2777.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Bishops Lament Africa's Avoidable Disasters


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Nairobi - Following the collapse of a supermarket that killed16 people in downtown Nairobi on May 14 this year, CatholicBishops of Kenya issued a statement blaming the incident on suchvices as corruption and neglect. Similar sentiments were expressedby the Catholic Bishops of Mwanza, the Rt. Rev. Anthony Mayala inthe aftermath of the ferry tragedy on Lake Victoria that cost thelives of more than 600 people mid-May.

More than 70 Ethiopians being smuggled illegally into SaudiArabia were burnt to death when a ship they were sailing in wasengulfed in flames, off Massawa, Eritrea in early June. It isbelieved that petrol was stored on board on makeshift containers.An explosion ensued when one of the passengers or crew lit acigarette. 

In Africa, it is common to find petrol and other flammablematerials regularly ferried in passenger compartments of vehiclesand boats. One is almost certain the Massawa tragedy is not thelast one of a similar nature.

In mid-May, an extension to the verandah roof of SunbeamSupermarket situated on a busy Nairobi street collapsed. Hugeboulders falling on a crowd sheltering from a torrential downpourkilled 16 people and left 50 others seriously injured.

The Catholic Bishops of Kenya lamented that such tragedies werecaused by rampant corruption and negligence on the part ofplanners, construction companies and surveyors. The chairman ofthe Kenya Episcopal Conference Archbishop Zacheus Okoth, who sentcondolences to the bereaved families urged the government toprosecute negligent builders and launch intensive scrutiny of allupcoming structures.

An enquiry is under way, but surprisingly, it is not acommission of enquiry.

Aware that corruption had thoroughly destroyed the credibilityof their trade, the 14,000 strong Kenya Union of Architects andBuilders issued a belated statement, What Might Have Happened andWhat Should Be Done.

The professionals agreed that henceforth inspection ofbuildings should be mandatory. This practice was common in thepast, particularly in the colonial period when building standardswere rigorously enforced. Indeed when a cinema hall collapsed inNairobi in 1954 killing one person, the colonial administratorsinstituted a commission of enquiry.

Barely one week after the mid-May Nairobi supermarket tragedy,a bigger disaster occurred on Lake Victoria, Africa's largestfresh water body. A condemned steamer capsized at dawn on May 21claiming more than 600 lives. The accident occurred only eightkilometres from the ship's destination port of Mwanza, Tanzania.The accident apparently happened in calm water and was initiallyblamed on overloading.

It has since emerged that the steamship was unseaworthy, a factthat was clearly known to its owners, the Tanzanian RailwayCorporation (TRC).

A fact many find difficult to comprehend is an advertisementappearing in the government owned Uhuru daily dated April 30,announcing the vessel's operation had been withdrawn due toserious mechanical problems. The ship was supposed to have gonestraight into a dry dock for mandatory repairs.

A marine electrical engineer named Kamuli Magolanga survivedthe tragedy by the sheer grace of God and because he was aware ofthe inherent dangers. He donned a life jacket right from theoutset when the M.V. Bukoba sailed out of Bukoba on the westernshores of Lake Victoria on the night of May 20.

"I put on my life jacket because I knew something was terriblywrong with the vessel's balance mechanism. I believe the TRC knewbetter," declared Magolanga.

The ill fated M.V. Bukoba carried some 250 people above thestated capacity of 450 passengers. Other survivors say the ferrywas carrying as many as 1,000 people. The true figure may never beknown since President Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania abruptlyterminated body salvage operations due to the advanced stage ofdecomposition of unrecovered bodies that were still entombed inthe vessel, 100 feet under water.

But overloading may still not have been the only factor in theill- fated accident since the ship had a high capacity for cargowhich was only fractionally utilised.

The M.V. Bukoba was not insured. Another disturbing revelationwas that the supplier of the vessel, a Belgian company, knew thedesign was inherently faulty. A Belgian government officialaccepted partial responsibility for the tragedy.

It is not clear however if Belgium will help boost acompensation fund for victims' families. Tanzanian embassiesabroad are collecting money for voluntary compensation to affectedfamilies.

Bishop Anthony Mayala of the Catholic Diocese of Mwanza thankedthe government, the Red Cross, Caritas and numerous well wishersfor all help offered in the recovery of bodies and subsequentinterment. The government also fed the thousands who thronged theharbour at Mwanza awaiting word about their loved ones.

On June 4, a flotilla of boats comprising members of variousreligious - Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, and Hindus, - sailed outfrom Mwanza to the spot where the tragedy occurred. "We took thewhole lake as a graveyard and blessed it. It was a deeply touchingservice for the departed souls."

Bishop Mayala lamented that such tragedies "happen when peoplefail to take care; when people do not fulfil their duty..."

He lost six missionaries in the Mwanza tragedy. Three CanossianSisters, one Daughter of St Mary and two Ugandan Brothers of theBanakaroli Brothers of Kisubi, near Kampala, perished. Among manyothers also lost in this tragedy were choir members of theEvangelical Lutheran Church in Tanzania (ELCT) Bugando parish.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

101 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Food Crisis Threatens Sub-Saharan Africa


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996 by Joseph K'Amolo


LENGTH: 1707 words


 

Nairobi - A recent report by the United Nations Food andAgriculture Organization (FAO) gives a very grim scenario of thefood situation in sub-Saharan Africa.

FAO which closely monitors the global food situation, says inits May 29 report that about 220 million people in sub-SaharanAfrica are currently facing food emergencies of varying intensity.

The 48 countries in the region require cereal importation ofabout 12.7 million tonnes for the period 1995/96, some 5 per centmore than the actual amount received in the previous year.

Mr. Abdur Rashid, head of FAO's Global Information and EarlyWarning System, which published the report warns that "Africa'sprecarious food security could lead to a genuine human tragedy."Already 210 million people in Africa suffer from hunger andundernutrition, 40 per cent of the continent's population. 

Sub-Saharan Africa has fared poorly against other world foodproducers since the 1970s and there are no signs of imminentimprovement in the food supply even in the near future.

This factor is brought about by Africa's over reliance onhighly variable and erratic rainfall. Worse still is the problemof recurrent severe droughts which precipitate large scale sub-regional food emergencies, such as those of 1972/71, 1983/84,1992/93 and 1994/95.

Land degradation due to soil erosion also contributes to lowfood production in the region. In 1991/92, some three milliontonnes of grain worth US$700 million - food for 25 million peoplewere lost to drought and desert encroachment.

Rising population pressure has also resulted in the decline infarm size as land is converted into other uses. The effect is seenin the annual population growth rate at an average 3 per cent,compared to a low 1.9 per cent increase in food production.

In East Africa alone, there are some 9 million people currentlyfacing food shortages including some 7 million from the Horn ofAfrica.

The prospects in Southern and Western Africa are not promising.A fairly good number of people from these regions need food aid.

In Southern Africa for instance, where favourable harvests areexpected following the generally good rainfall although with aslow start in Malawi, Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe, somecountries may still record low harvests, says the FAO report.

The FAO country profile shows that Angola's yield may beaffected by input shortages in some regions as a result oftransport difficulties.

Mozambique has experienced a double tragedy -- an acute dryspell in January followed by flooding in February. Both extremeshave adversely affected maize production in the country's southernprovinces.

Zambia too can only expect a dismal harvest following aninvasion of the large grain borer, a new pest in the country thathas jeopardized expectations of bumper crop. In Madagascar, lastJanuary cyclones will affect rice production.

The FAO report reveals an overall satisfactory food supply inWest Africa with the exception of Liberia and Sierra Leone.Traditionally food deficit countries like Burkina Faso, Chad, Maliand Niger will also experience localized food difficulties. Theextents vary from country to country with seriously threatenednations like Burkina Faso and Niger, having launched an appeal forinternational food aid.

Burkina Faso with a population of 9.5 million people isadversely affected in the northern parts of the country, requiringabout 24,000 tonnes of food for some 700,000 affected persons in17 provinces.

However, the FAO report notes that sub-Saharan Africa'sprecarious food security outlook, takes place as global cerealsupplies tighten and food aid availabilities shrink, resulting insharp increases in cereal prices on the world market. The highcost of cereal imports, coupled with balance of payments in fooddeficit countries further undermines the region's food security.

Eritrea which for example requires 191,000 tonnes of food aidto fill the gap created by a poor harvest has so far received only58,000 tonnes of food pledges, less than one third of the totalrequirements, yet, only 8 per cent of this assistance has beendelivered so far. The FAO report calls for prompt delivery tourgently avert an impending food emergency in the country.

While in some countries the food deficit is the result ofunfavourable ecological conditions, for others, it is purely dueto political instability.

Countries like Liberia, Rwanda, Burundi, Sudan and to someextent, Somalia have experienced political clashes that forcepeople to flee their farms and seek refuge elsewhere, thusescalating food demand in such areas.

Over the years, such trends have led to a rapid rise incommercial food imports and food aid which have registered annualgrowth rates of 4 per cent and 7 per cent respectively.

But in spite of these food inflows, food intake per person iscurrently estimated at around 87 per cent of the requirement,implying growing chronic undernutrition, observes FAO.

The situation generally seems to be getting worse, given thepoor balance of payment position and crushing debt burden of mostsub- Saharan African countries, exacerbated by a rise in grainprices on the world market and dwindling global food aidavailabilities.

Against this background, the international community isrequired amongst other things to focus attention on how the lowincome food deficit countries of sub-Saharan Africa would gettheir food aid to meet minimum requirements for 1996.

Increasing Africa's food output also calls for a significantexpansion of irrigation activities in farming. The absurd truth isthat of sub-Saharan Africa's irrigation potential estimated ataround 33 million hectares, only 16 per cent are currently underuse, leaving 27.7 million hectares unutilized.

Moreover, 68 per cent of the irrigated land in the region wasconcentrated in three countries namely

Sudan (30 per cent), Madagascar (17 per cent) and South Africa(20 per cent).

However, the FAO report acknowledges that the full irrigationpotential may be constrained by economic and technical factors butadds that tapping even only 10 per cent of the potential couldlead to full substitution of cereal imports.

The report further observes that applying supplementaryirrigation to rain fed crops would minimize the water stresscaused by short, dry spells during the growing season and, thussubstantially raise rain fed production as well.

Besides its basic function of meeting crop water requirements,irrigation increases the impact of other yield-enhancingtechnologies, particularly of fertilizer applications.

With the foregoing, UN agencies targeting food securityglobally need to focus on concerns like soil degradation, controlof desertification, access to water, supporting sustainable livingconditions in marginal environmental zones and introduction ofeffective low cost technology.

The survival of 200 million people in the Sahel and Horn ofAfrica now depends on efforts to reverse the trend of landdegradation and desertification.

It is perhaps against this realization that the Convention toCombat Desertification convened a meeting on June 17 this year, tofocus on the need to maximize efforts by the internationalcommunity to contain progressive desertification especially inAfrica, but also in Asia, Latin America, Southern Europe and partsof Northern America.

And from November 13 to 17 1996, world leaders will assemble inRome, Italy at a meeting called by FAO, to make public commitmentto eliminate hunger.

This assembly will provide a historic opportunity forgovernments, international organizations and all sectors of civilsociety to join forces in a concerted campaign to ensure foodsecurity - access at all times to the food required for a healthy,active life of a human being.

This summit is coming at a time when the global populationwhich today stands at some 5.7 billion, is projected to top 8billion by 2020. The population increase will be experiencedmostly in the developing world, where constraints to increasedfood production are daunting.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


102 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Uganda Clergy Want To Mediate For Peace In Northern Uganda


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996 by Peter Mungherera


LENGTH: 1907 words


 

Nairobi - "The public is hereby informed that from now on fuelused by the Uganda People's Defence Forces (UPDF) at all fuelstations in the country will be coloured green," reads anannouncement being broadcast over state radio every several hours.

The announcement by Uganda's Defence Ministry follows a seriesof other media statements, one of which recently called for freshrecruitment of local militias in the strife torn northern regionof this East African country, to back up government troops aheadof a plan to militarily occupy the north and evacuate hundreds ofthousands civilians to "safe camps".

Ironically, running side by side of the media announcements,are declarations on rebels fighting to unseat President YoweriMuseveni's government from the improvised northern region.

As recently as June 13, church leaders made yet another appealto President Yoweri Museveni and the rebel leaders to end thefighting in the north.

In a statement signed by the Roman Catholic Archbishop CardinalEmmanuel Wamala who chairs the Uganda Joint Christian Council(UJCC), the churches expressed their willingness to promotedialogue and reconciliation between Museveni's government, theLord's Resistance Army (LRA) of Joseph Kony, and the West NileBank Front (WNBF) led by Juma Oris. 

Earlier this year, Cardinal Wamala had urged Museveni to seek apolitical solution to the fighting in the north, a proposal thePresident rejected, vowing that "he would crush and finish therebels."

"The rebels are in disarray and will be crushed shortly --there are only a tail of the insurgency," is a common phrase bytop Uganda government officials including President Museveni whenreferring to the northern conflict.

The government owned New Vision daily is carrying reports of 20to 50 rebels being killed by the UPDF and hundreds of others beingcaptured in various attacks.

But a senior Defence Minister official who spoke on conditionof anonymity confirms some reports in privately owned Kampalanewspapers which indicate that between 10 and 20 governmentsoldiers are being ambushed by rebels or killed in dissidentlandmine attacks during various skirmishes.

President Museveni has often publicly admitted that the expansebushy terrain in the north is giving his 10,000 strong armydifficulty in transversing. The army is dominated by soldiers fromthe heavily populated and vegetated south.

Several top Uganda government officials, including close aidesto President Museveni like his half brother and military advisormajor general Salim Saleh, blamed political and economic factorsfor the war in the north.

Since 1986 when the ruling National Resistance Movement (NRM)government came to power, there has been magical growth of themajority south and south-western parts of the country, to theextent of putting this East African country on the list of whatforeign donors categorize as fastest growing economies in Africa,with a growth rate of 8 per cent.

This growth which donors say is a result of an impressiveliberalization and investment programme, has however not beenshared by the north.

"When one travels from the south of Uganda to the north, it islike travelling from earth to another planet. From civilization tobackwardness, spotted with worm infested feet and emaciatedchildren --- one is not surprised that there is a rebellion in thearea at all," said a senior United Nations World Food Programme(WFP) official who did not want to be named.

The north is home to 2.5 million of Uganda's 18 millionpopulation. "The two parts of Uganda should have been differentcountries," he added.

Cecilia Ogwal, a well known fiery official of former presidentDr. Milton Obote's Uganda People's Congress (UPC) which has ruledUganda for most of the period since independence from Britishcolonial rule in 1962 and during which, the army, then dominatedby ethnic northern soldiers killed thousands of southerners, says:"The people in the north look at the UPDF as a foreign force outto avenge their tribal connection with Obote.

"President Museveni and his NRM, which analysts interpret asthe first uprising by the southerners against decades of northernrule, should know that the mistakes of Obote and (former Ugandandictator) Idi Amin (a northerner) should not be meted out to thelocal people," Ogwal observed.

The UPC Official was apparently referring to atrocitiesallegedly committed by UPDF soldiers against the civilianpopulation in the north, some of which have been publicly admittedby the Ugandan government.

The most vivid one was in the north-eastern Soroti District inMukura village, where several years ago, hundreds of civilianswere suffocated in a disused train wagon by government troops.

Says a senior army officer; "One cannot blame these Kadogos," -young orphans from the south whose parents were killed bygovernment troops during the Obote regime in the early 1980's andwere forced to join Museveni's guerrilla war to defend themselvesand are now part of the army.

"If your mother and father are slaughtered infront of you andyou meet one of those who did it what should you do? ... The UPDFis not a force of angels," the official added.

The rebel conflict in northern Uganda has since 1987 beencentred around the towns of Kitgum and Gulu, 50 kilometres fromthe border with Sudan. The uprising which began after the NRMcaptured power in Kampala ousting Obote's mainly ethnic northernsoldiers from the Ugandan capital to the north of the country, haswidened to embrace the West Nile District which encompasses largeareas bordering Sudan. Uganda has accused Sudan of arming therebels, a charge which Khartoum denied.

Local state media including independent newspapers in thecapital Kampala which have been previously mentioning the rebelLord's Resistance Army (LRA) commanded by Joseph Kony, are nowfrequently also referring to another group of insurgents, thedissidents West Nile Bank Front (WNBF) led by Idi Amin's formerforeign minister colonel Juma Oris.

The Amin rebels whom the government alleges infiltrated thenorth- western region from southern Sudan in groups of 1000 arereported to have blown up several bridges leading to the area.

The conflict in northern Uganda intensified after the May 9general election in which President Museveni, who has ruled thecountry for the past ten years, trounced his two opponents with74.3 per cent of the votes, clinching another five-year term.

Before the election, the LRA and WNBF had called for aceasefire and advised Ugandans to vote for Museveni's major rivalDr. Paul Ssemogerere, who warned that there would be an out-breakof full scale war in the north if the elections were rigged.

And indeed no sooner had Ssemogerere rejected the electionresults in which he polled a mere 23.7 per cent of the ballotsthan the northern conflict intensified.

The state owned New Vision daily reported late May thatparliamentary elections in two counties in the north-west havebeen postponed as a result of insecurity.

During the election whose procedure and outcome were okayed bylocal and international poll monitors, Ssemogerere swept theentire north with between 80 and 90 per cent of the votes cast.

"The election was a clear result of rejection by thenortherners of President Museveni's government. Now they haverealised that they can never return to power or even get a fairamount of the economic cake by the ballot, they have resorted toforce," a northern parliamentarian said.

Analysts say that UPC had hoped to bring northern Uganda backinto the country's political arena through its alliance withSsemogerere, a member of the majority southern Buganda tribe, byexploiting the ethnic group's disappointment at the NRM's refusalto grant Kabakaship or ancient mornachy its century longinfluential political status and autonomy.

But Museveni's campaign reminder of the 1980-1985 Obote regime,during which the four million strong Baganda suffered killings andlooting of property by government troops and the formerpresident's 1966 abolition of their monarchy, outweighed all theseconsiderations.

Basking in his landslide victory and his imminent success inthe June parliamentary polls, Museveni has made it clear he willnot negotiate with key northern rebel leader Joseph Kony.

Shortly after he was sworn into office on May 12, Musevenireminded Ugandans of his earlier stance on the LRA leader, sayinghis job was "to kill Kony."

In a statement broadcast over Radio Uganda and TelevisionMuseveni on June 3 said he will give priority to "areas thatsupported my political programmes in political appointments. It isnot discrimination because it does not affect the development ofthe country which I will make uniform."

The June 3 appeal from the leader of Uganda's majority CatholicChurch, asking Museveni to negotiate with Kony and accommodate thehostile north in his government plans, seems to have had littleeffect in placating the president's stand. Ssemogerere is astaunch Catholic.

Observers fear that Western donors who are concentrating on thedevelopment of the rich and wetter majority southern part ofUganda will sit on the fence and watch the drier and minoritynorth burn to ashes.

As one American businessman privately put it when confrontedwith the northern Ugandan conflict: "What matters is Kampala andEntebbe (Uganda's international airport 26 kilometres south of thecapital)."

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large African Churches Asked To Do More For Uprooted People


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Nairobi - The All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) hascalled on churches to intensify their pastoral services among theuprooted people on the continent.

In a message sent out to all the AACC member churches, to markthe June 16 to 23 Week of Prayer and Confession in Africa for theUprooted People, General Secretary Rev. Jose Chipenda acknowledgedefforts by churches in Africa to provide assistance to theuprooted through the AACC and the Geneva-based World Council ofChurches (WCC) but cautioned that they can still do more.

The churches on the continent for example, have not adequatelyspoken against injustices perpetrated in African countries,resulting in forced movements of people, laments the AACC. 

The Pan-African religious body, which represents 142 memberchurches and a number of affiliated national christian councils in39 countries, also cited other factors which prompted the markingof the week of prayer and confession for the continent's churches.

These include the ineffectiveness of the churches' role inpreventing uprootedness by tackling the underlying causes;reaffirmation of the urgent need for the churches to adopt a firmstand for justice and peace in the name of the gospel; the needfor solidarity with the uprooted people; and creation of publicawareness and sensitivity to the problems of Africa in general anduprooted people in particular.

The week of prayer and confession in Africa was instituted in1995, after a series of meetings organised by the refugee andemergency service departments of the AACC and WCC.

A document from the AACC says A Week of Prayer and Confessionin Africa , was designed to give churches, in particular thoseworking within the refugee and emergency services areas, a periodto meditate, reflect and even confess the "sins", they might havecommitted in their services among the uprooted people.

The document also thanks the WCC for its proposal that 1997 bea year of solidarity with uprooted people, describing the idea ascommendable. "Our week of prayer is a prelude, which will help toprepare people to be more responsive to the needs of the uprootedby first taking responsibility for them (uprooted) uponthemselves."

In an earlier message informing all AACC-member churches of thedecision to mark the week of prayer and confession in Africa, theAACC General Secretary noted that although churches on the African

continent in collaboration with the AACC and WCC have beenaddressing themselves to the uprooted people and particularly therefugees, their number (uprooted people) has steadily increased.

"Inspite of these efforts, the number of the uprooted peoplehas been increasing steadily," observed Rev. Chipenda. Africa hasan estimated 8 million refugees,representing about one third ofthe world's refugee population; well over 15 million internallydisplaced persons and several more millions of migrants.

He pointed out that the AACC has decentralized the operationsof its refugees and emergency services to ensure effectiveparticipation of the churches in the work for and with theuprooted people.

At the same time, the WCC has developed a policy statement onthe uprooted people which was approved by its central committeelast September.

The AACC week of prayer and confession was designed to coincidewith the African Refugee Day of the Organisation for African Unity(OAU), which is celebrated annually on June 20.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Ethiopia Declares Independence from Banking System


BYLINE: Addis Tribune June 24, 1996 By Our Economics Correspondent


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Addis Ababa - There was some cheerful economic news during the lastweekend of May 1996 from the Vice Minister of the Ministry of EconomicDevelopment and Cooperation, Ato Mekonnen Manyazewal. He said thegovernment would not borrow money from the domestic banking systemduring the current fiscal year of 1995/96 which runs from the end ofJune through July ("Addis Zemen," Ginbot 17, 1988 E.C.).

It is understood that the government's remarkable prospectivefinancial independence from the domestic banking system includes notjust the current budget but the capital budget as well. If it turns outto be true, it is a fiscal first worthy of a full page in the annals ofEthiopian financial history. 

But is it really true that the government will not resort to thedomestic banking system during 1995/96? Has it not already takenrecourse to it? There is hardly any doubt that the government has,during the course of 1995/96, already borrowed from the banking system,which includes the National Bank of Ethiopia, the Commercial Bank ofEthiopia (CBE) and other state-owned and private banks, through variousborrowing mechanisms, mainly direct advances and treasury bills. It iswell known that the CBE is a major player on the domestic monthly 91-daytreasury bills auction market.

So, what the V. Minister perhaps meant to say was that the governmentwould not incur any additional domestic debt during the current fiscalyear. This could possibly happen if the government repaid, includinginterest, all its borrowings during 1995/96 from the domestic bankingsystem before the fiscal year runs out. Since the fiscal year still has,at the time of writing, some one month and nine days to go it would bepresumptuous to try to predict the outcome in this respect with onehundred percent certainty.

The V. Minister's announcement of the government's financialindependence from the domestic banking system at least for the currentfiscal year is premised on the assumption that domestic governmentrevenue for 1995/96 would amount to a record-breaking total of 7.1billion birr, registering a phenomenal increase of 1.4 billion birr (ornearly 25 percent) over 5.7 billion birr domestic revenue realized in1994/95 ("Addis Zemen", Ginbot 17, 1988 E.C.).

Obviously, the 7.1 billion birr figure is an estimate not onlybecause an actual figure cannot be obtained when there is still over amonth before the fiscal year is out, but because there is usually a lagof at least three months before even preliminary actual fiscal figurescan be made available. As a matter fact, even figures for 1992/93 arestill at the "preliminary actual" of stage!

Hence, the 7.1 billion birr domestic revenue figure cited by the V.Minister is only a projection, not an actual outcome. Several questionscould be raised concerning this very important fiscal estimate,including the following:

- What are the major sources of the remarkable increases in domesticrevenue?

- Does it include foreign grants in kind, in cash and in what areknown as counterpart funds? (Such foreign grants are estimated to haveamounted to over 1 billion birr in 1994/95).

- In the light of the immediately foregoing query, would it be rightto attribute all the 7.1 billion to domestic revenue?

- How is it possible for there to be such a large increase indomestic revenue when there have been substantial reductions in taxrates, including those on business profits, personal income and imports.Has tax collection improved that much? Has the economy been expandingall that rapidly? There is plenty of room for doubt here!

- Why cite a projected figure rather than an actual figure in thefirst place? It would have been more appropriate to give whatever actualor preliminary actual figure (say for 8 or 9 months of E. FY 1995/96) isavailable and compare it with the corresponding figure for 1994/95 thanto indulge in speculation when making definitive policy statements suchas: "the government will not borrow money from the domestic bankingsystem in E. FY 1995/96".

- How does such a policy statement reconcile with the followingstatement made recently by the Prime Minister: "On the whole, 13 -14billion birr is needed to cover rural roads and highway constructionover the five-year period (or about 2.7 billion annually)? Thegovernment's total capital expenditure in 1994/95 was estimated at alittle over 3 billion birr. If 2.7 billion birr is required annually forthe road construction programme alone, how can the government helptaking recourse to the domestic banking system in the future?

To sum up, first contrary to what the V. Minister stated, thegovernment has borrowed from the domestic banking system during E. FY1995/96, and there are indications that it has incurred additional debton its treasury bills account during the year, although its debtposition with the banking system on aggregate appears to have declinedappreciably. At any rate, reducing the government's outstanding internaldebt does not necessarily mean that there has been no governmentborrowing from the banking system during E. FY 1995/96.

Secondly, since there is still some way to go before the end of the1995/96 fiscal year, it is conceivable that further credit accommodationmay be sought by the government from the banking system, although thismay not substantially affect the overall net favorable internal debtposition of the government.

Thirdly, the 7.1 billion birr figure cited is a projection not anactual outcome. It would have been better to quote the available actualor preliminary actual figure and compare it with its correspondingfigure for 1994/95.

Fourthly, the major sources of the very substantial increase. Issue cover date: June 14


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

June, 1996


Ethiopia How is Free Press Doing in Ethiopia?


BYLINE: Addis Tribune June 24, 1996 By Our Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Addis Ababa - According to the latest Ethiopian Free PressJournalists Association's (EFJA) report, more than 150 journalists havebeen put in jail for short or long periods of time during the past fiveyears. Over thirty two editors and publishers have also been, it said,fined a total of 45,000 birr. 

EFJA named journalists Getahun Bekele, Andargue Mesfin and SissayAgena as 'convicted prisoners' currently serving from 12 to 36 monthterms at the Central State Prison. Two others, Kumsa Burayu and TsegayeMeskalu are listed as 'missing independent journalists'. EFJA listed tenother names as 'unconvicted independent journalists'. A further nineteenwere cited as 'released independent journalist prisoners', having beenheld in prison from a week up to a year.

The quarterly journal published by the US-based Committee to ProtectJournalists (CPJ) also had something to say on freedom of press in thecountry. In its Spring 1996 issue, CPJ reported that at the end of 1995,'For the third consecutive year, Ethiopia held more journalists in jail- 31 at years end - than any other country in Africa. Most were detainedwithout charges.' CPJ also noted that 'upcoming elections in severalcountries, including Ivory Coast (Cote d'Ivoire). Ethiopia and Chad,proved reason enough for governments to impose greater restrictions - ifnot all-out crack downs - on the media'. Fifty-three journalists werealso said to have been 'killed in the line of duty' over the past tenyears in thirteen African countries - three of them in Ethiopia, fifteenin Rwanda and nine in Somalia

Ethiopia Circumstances of Emperor's Death Come to Light


BYLINE: Addis Tribune June 24, 1996 By Our Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Addis Ababa - Witnesses for the Special Prosecutor's Office (SPO)gave their testimonies on Tuesday regarding the death of the lateEmperor Haile Selassie in August 1975.

It was revealed that the Emperor had been in good health after asuccessful operation was carried out in June by a team of doctors led byProfessor Asrat Woldeyes. According to the testimonies, the Emperor diedafter he was made to take a certain tablet.

Of those testifying, one was the same individual who recently led theauthorities to the spot where Haile Selassie was buried. This burialplace as well as the circumstances of his death had been a mystery forover a decade.

Witnesses said on the stand that two other attempts had been made onthe Emperor's life before the final and fatal one.....................................................

June, 1996


Ethiopia Reduced Regional Crops Offset Ethiopian Food Production Reporter


BYLINE: Addis Tribune June 24, 1996 By Our Staff


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa The report stated that there was a continuing food emergency in partsof the Horn of Africa, despite some good harvests. Reduced crops inEritrea, Somalia and Sudan more than offset the significant gain inproduction in Ethiopia, said the report. 

The second in a series of reports for 1996, prepared by the FAOGlobal Information and Early Warning System, was issued in May. Itfocuses on the food supply situation and crop prospects in sub-SaharanAfrica.

There are an estimated 9 million people facing severe food shortagesin eastern Africa including some 7 million in the Horn of Africa.Ethiopia recorded average to above average rainfall in February andearly March. The report added that the good 1995 cereal harvest relievedthe food supply situation, however food aid assistance is needed forlarge numbers of people in traditionally food deficit parts of Tigray,Wollo, Walaita and Haraghe zones.

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, FAO,will hold a World Food Summit in November this year. The summit isexpected to gather heads of state and government from close to 200countries.
