Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia Ethiopia's Revised Draft Investment Proclamation


BYLINE: Addis Tribune June 24, 1996 By Our Economics Correspondent


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

Addis Ababa - Let us first highlight the major revisions made. Theseinclude the following:

* The minimum capital required for foreign investment in Ethiopia hasbeen reduced from 500,000 US dollars to 300,000 US dollars in the caseof joint ventures;

* This minimum capital required has been further reduced to 100,000US dollars in the case of retained profits and dividends invested in newinvestment and to 40,000 US dollars if such funds are invested in theexpansion of existing enterprises. Further, for foreign investment inengineering and technical consultancy the minimum capital requirementhas been reduced from the previous 500,000 US dollars to 100,000 USdollars;

* The requirement for foreign investors to deposit 125.000 US dollarsin a blocked account with the National Bank of Ethiopia prior toinvestment licensing has been abolished;

* Restrictions on foreign investment in building construction anddevelopment, in leasing of construction equipment and in hotels belowthe four-star and five-star grades have been lifted;

* Foreign investors are allowed to open foreign currency accountswith local banks for operations related to their investment activities;

* Foreign investors are permitted to repatriate their investedcapital free of tax upon sale, liquidation or transfer to residents;

* Foreign investors are allowed to remit abroad in foreign currencyprofits, dividends, loan repayments and interest and payments arisingfrom technology transfer;

* Except according to the law and in the interests of the public atlarge, foreign investments shall not be nationalized or confiscated; inthis connection, internationally accepted arbitration procedures havebeen clearly laid down;

* Investment incentives will be given to the following additionalsectors; education, health, catering (hotels) and tourism;

* Special priority sectors are to be accorded 3 - 5 years' taxholiday and loss carry-over privileges depending on the regions wherethe investment is made;

* Priority sectors will be granted one year's tax holiday and losscarry-over incentives;

* Domestic entrepreneurs who invest below 250,000 birr as well asthose who invest above this amount will now be granted investmentincentives (the existing investment code restricts such incentives toonly those who invest about 250,000 birr). 

* Sectors reserved for government only -- Defense industries;Electricity generation above 25 megawatts; Air transport using aircraftwith carrying capacity above 20 passengers; Rail transport; Post andtelecommunications (except express post service).

* Sectors reserved for domestic investors only -- Banking andInsurance; Electricity generation up to 25 megawatt capacity; Airtransport using aircraft with carrying capacity up to 20 passengers.

* Sectors reserved for joint venture only, if capital invested isabove 20 million US dollars (domestic participation is to be no lessthan 27 percent) -- Engineering and metallurgy industries;Pharmaceuticals factories; Basic chemical and petro-chemical industries;Fertilizer factories.

* Investors can borrow money from abroad subject to registration bythe National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE);

* Subject to the approval of the NBE, foreign investors can openforeign currency accounts with local banks for operation involving theirinvestment activities;

* Remittances on account of external debt servicing are allowed forforeign investors;

* Land will be made available to licensed investors in 60 days;

And now for our comments.

The reduction in the minimum capital required for investment may behelpful, but it is not going to be decisive in attracting foreigninvestors. In this connection, it does not make much sense to say thatthe amount of foreign retained profits and dividends to be invested inexisting enterprises cannot be less than 40,000 US dollars.

Suppose just 35,000 US dollars is required for a minor expansion orimprovement in existing facilities. Is this going to be prohibited? Theabolition of the requirement for 125,000 US dollar prior deposit forforeign investors is also a positive step.

So is the opening up of more sectors for foreign investors such ashotel development below the four-star and five-star grade levels;however, it is doubtful whether there is an urgent need for foreigninvestment in real estate development such as the construction of high-rise buildings for rent.

This can quite easily be done by domestic investors provided foreigncontractors are available where domestic construction capacity islimited. In other words, foreign investment in the construction industryis highly welcome but not in the construction of high-rise buildings andvillas for rent.

On the other hand, foreign investment in varying degrees would havebeen helpful in banking and insurance and small-scale air transport andelectricity supply services where foreign technical know-how would bevaluable. For example, in the banking and insurance sector a foreignequity participation of, say, up to 15 - 20 percent, together with theaccompanying foreign management participation, would have been helpfulin acquiring modern banking and insurance techniques.

In a similar vein, why is foreign investment not allowed in thefollowing sectors?

* Rail transport

* Telecommunications

* Electricity generation with capacity above 25 megawatts.

Similarly, why is foreign investment restricted to only joint ventureabove 20 million US dollars capital in the following sectors?

* Engineering and metallurgy

* Pharmaceuticals production

* Basic chemical and petro-chemical industries, and

* Fertilizer industries.

These are all production activities where not only foreign technicalexpertise but also capital is badly needed.

The draft proclamation does not say much about the eligibilitycriteria for investment incentives and the types of incentives to begranted, although the former are said to be based on the country'sinvestment objectives and the latter are mentioned as generally coveringtax holidays and loss carry-over privileges.

The lifting of the 250,000 birr minimum capital required foreligibility for investment incentives in the case of domestic investorsis welcome, but the proposed investment authority would need to be well-prepared to handle much more investment licensing and otheradministrative processing than is being done at present.

On the question of borrowing from abroad, it is not clear whetherboth foreign and domestic investors are allowed to do this subject toregistration by the NBE. If this is the case, then remittances forforeign debt servicing should be allowed for domestic investors as well.

Perhaps the most dramatic revision in the new draft investmentproclamation is that land for investment will be made available in 60days. The revision is highly welcome and long overdue, but theinevitable question would be: is the revision practical in the light ofthe gross inefficiency of the government bureaucracy and the additionalcomplications the government land lease policy has created? Besides, twomonths is not a short time. Even then, in the present Ethiopiancircumstances the amendment is too good to be practicable!

Finally, the draft proclamation has not addressed two importinvestment issues, namely investment in financial instruments such astreasury bills, bonds, stocks and other securities; and the question ofresidence and nationality. In connection with the latter, what is goingto be the fate of Eritreans who are now widely engaged in activitiesreserved for Ethiopian nationals only? It may be a politically sensitivequestion, but it cannot be evaded indefinitely! On the other hand, thebroader investment issues would include the following doubts andapprehensions:

- It is doubtful whether an investor will get land in 60 days asstipulated in the draft investment proclamation even though this may beconsidered a pretty long time by many people. The further questions toask at this point would be: In how many days would an investor get waterelectricity and telephone connections? How long would it take him toobtain a bank loan, to clear his imported goods through customs, etc.?

- What is the difference between Ethiopians and foreigners withrespect to land tenure? Apparently there is no difference. They are bothleaseholders! The national interest should be protected where it mattersmost!

Issue cover date: June 14


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Oppenheimers Talk Press Ownership With Mandela


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Johannesburg - The Oppenheimer heirs -- Anglo American deputychairman Nicky Oppenheimer and Mary Slack -- met President NelsonMandela at his Houghton home last week to discuss the possibletakeover by the National Empowerment Consortium of AngloAmerican's press interests.

Presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana said the meeting hadbroached a range of issues, but he refused to confirm or denywhether the matter of the press interests had been raised.

The Mail & Guardian understands that Oppenhemier and Slackvoiced concern about the possible control of the publicationsowned by Times Media Limited (TML), which publishes Business Day,Sunday Times and Financial Mail. TML is part of the Johnnic group,the collection of Anglo American assets earmarked for sale in amajor black empowerment deal. 

The possible exercise of editorial control by the NationalEmpowerment Consortium, the group of companies bidding forJohnnic, prompted senior TML officials to draw up an editorialcharter, effectively enshrining the publications' editorialindependence and preserving the publications' Anglo traditions.

It is understood that the consortium, which includes New AfricaInvestments Limited (Nail), has scoffed at the idea of such acharter. Ironically, TML first encountered the idea of aneditorial charter when it was eyeing New Nation, the weeklynewspaper now owned by Nail. TML frowned at New Nation'ssuggestion of a charter, saying editorial control would have torest with it. Nail also owns the Sowetan and is bidding for one ofthe SABC radio stations up for sale.

The M&G understands the meeting between Mandela and theOppenheimers was intended to focus on the continued independenceof the press if and when it comes under black control.

Ironically, and it has not been lost on the ANC, it was Slack'sformer husband, Gordon Waddell, in his executive position atAnglo, who was primarily responsible for closing a former TMLpublication, and its flagship the Rand Daily Mail. Senior ANCmembers are riled that Anglo is suddenly worried about pressindependence on the eve of possible black ownership of itspublications.

LANGUAGE: English

110 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance South Africa's Anglo Companies' Deal Flounders


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Johannesburg - One of South Africa's most trumpeted blackempowerment deals to date is floundering badly.

Sources close to the negotiating team thrashing out theNational Empowerment Consortium's bid for a collection of stakesin Anglo American companies say that, after a heavy round of talkson Youth Day, the deal seems to be in peril.

The consortium bidding for the Anglo companies includes NewAfrica Investments Limited (Nail), and its negotiating team isheaded by outgoing African National Congress secretary generalCyril Ramaphosa. 

The stakes in the companies in its sights were hived off byAnglo into a holding company called Johnnic -- in preparation,Anglo said, for a sale which promoted black economic empowerment.

But Anglo is angling for a price far beyond the reach of theblack businessmen it seeks to empower. "Anglo American is pushingthe price to a point where it could mean this is not the rightdeal for the National Empowerment Consortium," an analyst close tothe negotiators said this week.

Some players in the negotiations say it appears Anglo Americanis backtracking on the deal. Although it set up Johnnic with theexpress intention of selling it on to promote black economicempowerment, it has shied away from the idea of selling the parcelof assets off at any discount.

Nail chairman Nthato Motlana expressed concern about the pricelast year, but since then it had appeared Anglo was willing tonegotiate downwards. "At first they were in a hurry to push thedeal through. Now it looks as if they are having second thoughts,"a source said.

A financial analyst at the Johannesburg Stock Exchange said itappeared Anglo had originally trumpeted the Johnnic deal in a bidto "get the heat off them on black economic empowerment".

Now it appeared Anglo was willing to ditch the deal if it didnot get the market price for Johnnic. It would then split upJohnnic, and the various players in the National EmpowermentConsortium could pick up the pieces separately.

Many commentators believe this might not be such a bad thing.For although the Johnnic deal has been touted as a pivotal steptowards black economic empowerment by both Nail and AngloAmerican, many analysts and union advisers are unimpressed withthe mixed bag of assets on offer.

The assets include substantial stakes in Anglo American'slisted press companies, Times Media and Omni Media, as well assmaller stakes in South African Breweries, Toyota and Premier.

The main criticism is that, apart from the press companies,Nail will not have anything approaching control of the others inthe portfolio, which is a tiny mirror image of Anglo American -- asprawling conglomerate which has invested in many unrelatedcompanies in all sectors of the economy because exchange controlsbarred it from investing abroad.

"The main motivation for the deal is to get some senior blackfaces in South African business quickly. But there is not going tobe much empowerment from it (the deal)," said the JSE analyst.

He suggested that if Anglo American were unable to sell offJohnnic as a whole, halted the talks with the consortium and splitup Johnnic, it would allow Nail to snap up Johnnic's press assets.

This would make strategic sense, given that Nail owns theSowetan and New Nation.

Other members of the consortium are also known to have theireye

on particular parts of the Johnnic portfolio. Wiseman Nkuhlu'sWorldwide Africa Investments, which is

also in the consortium, is apparently keen on buying thePremier stake.

It is therefore understandable that a source close to the Nailnegotiating team said: "It is not the end of the world if we don'tget Johnnic. We have lots more up our sleeve."

Anglo American refused to comment on the Johnnic talks thisweek.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


111 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Olympics South Africa: Last Two Pieces In Olympic Puzzle


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Julian Drew


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Johannesburg - The final two pieces to the Olympic jigsawpuzzle which has been forming since February fell in to place onTuesday when pole vaulter Riaan Botha and modern pentathlete ClaudCloete were named to the team which leaves for Atlanta a week onSunday.

There was surprise in some quarters that the National OlympicCommittee of South Africa (Nocsa) failed to select a secondathletics candidate. Nocsa left open two more places for thissport when the original athletics squad of 23 was announced at theend of April. The truth is, however, that none of the other fournominations on Athletics South Africa's (ASA) list met thestringent selection criteria laid down by the national Olympicbody. 

Athletics simply found out what several other sports had learntearlier in the year: meeting the required qualification standardsis not necessarily good enough to book a passage to Atlanta.

Botha, who was inexplicably left out of the first athleticscontingent, having already cleared the qualifying standard fourtimes during the South African season, gave the selectors nooption but to include him on the team when he cleared a personalbest 5.85m in Lyon last Friday.

Cloete failed to qualify at two Olympic qualificationcompetitions in Seoul and Rome earlier in the year but his badluck in drawing a belligerent horse for the equestrian round wherehe failed to score any points almost certainly cost him a worldclass score in Seoul. That convinced Nocsa that Cloete was worth awild card nomination.

Wild cards are awarded to athletes from developing countrieswho have not qualified in a sport through the normal channels. TheIOC duly obliged at the weekend and Cloete has become the onlyAfrican representative in the modern pentathlon in Atlanta.

Ironically Botha's name was not at the top of ASA's list ofnominations despite the fact that his 5.85m clearance last weekplaces him eighth in the world at the moment and makes him agenuine medal prospect at the Games. Top spot belonged to racewalker Chris Britz who was controversially nominated to theoriginal squad on a "B" standard qualifier, the only athlete to beconsidered on such a standard despite the omission of many "A"standard qualifiers.

Britz was subsequently rejected by Nocsa but a lifeline wasthrown to him and other athletes who were surprisingly omittedlike Botha, javelin thrower Philip Spies, high jumper HestrieStorbeck and hurdler Ferrins Pieterse.

Nocsa said they would leave two places open until June 18, bywhich time candidates should have registered an "A" qualifier anddemonstrated their fitness, among other conditions. Britz went toGermany and recorded an "A" qualifying time, shattering his ownnational 20km record by more than two minutes to record 1:22:16.

Impressive as this time may be in one of South Africanathletics' Cinderella disciplines it is unlikely that it placeshim in the current world top 50. The world ranking lists of June11 are only 30 deep but those of May 27 which are 50 deep show himin a lowly 48th position. While not wanting to detract fromBritz's performance, it is important to put it in perspectiveafter such ludicrous claims have been made on his behalf by ASA.

Stating that such a performance would have won the 1993 worldchampionships, placed him second at the Barcelona Games and sixthat last year's world championships is a bit like comparing adownhill marathon course with a tailwind like Boston to the toughand humid Honolulu Marathon. Britz's time was recorded at theEuropean Race Walking Grand Prix in Eisenhuttenstadt, Germany,which, along with Fana in Norway for track walking, is renowned asone of the fastest road circuits around.

Quite how this performance ranks above Botha's completelydefies logic as does the absence of Spies' name from the list. Hethrew twice over the qualifying distance this year despitethrowing at a stage of his training when he would not normally bethrowing. His best of 81.34m ranks him 17th in the world on lastweek's world rankings.

Spies, however, had already resigned himself to the fact thathe wouldn't be on the list after challenging ASA over their aboutturn on his positive doping result last year. While suchconspiracy theories can often be taken with a pinch of salt it hasnot gone unnoticed that Britz is a loyal apparatchik of theTransvaal Amateur Athletic Congress and boasts the likes of ASApresident Leonard Chuene and ASA secretary general Banele Sindani,the two most powerful figures in the sport, as his closecolleagues.

It is admirable to promote a discipline like race walking butwhen Olympic places are at stake simple criteria like merit musttake precedence. In athletics such attributes are relativelysimple to measure and compare provided, of course, that you have abasic understanding of the sport.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Olympics South Africa: The Lapses Leading Up To Atlanta


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Mark Lamport-Stokes


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Johannesburg - If Preparation is one of the major keys tosuccess -- whether in sport or in battle -- then the South Africanmen's hockey team are on a hiding to nothing for the upcomingOlympic Games in Atlanta.

Not only have the squad been forced to condense their build-upto the Games because of the late "green light" giving them the go-ahead to compete, but their recent competitive track record ishardly the stuff of inspiration.

Their last 10 internationals have not produced a single win andtheir lost/drawn ratio stands at 9/1. And they have hardly beenhelped along the way with injuries to key players Wayne Graham(captain and centre half), Alistair Fredericks (centre forward andleading goal-scorer) and Brian Myburgh (rated as one of the topgoal-keepers in world hockey). 

In mitigation, though, the opposition during this 10-matchcycle has hardly been weak. Down Under in Cairns and Brisbane forthe recent four-nation tournament, South Africa faced the strengthand class of Australia (who are generally considered gold medalfavourites for Atlanta), India (currently ranked five in theworld) and a New Zealand side more or less on a par with the SouthAfricans.

South Africa's report card there read: played seven, lost six,drawn one -- with the draw a 2-2 scoreline against New Zealand andone of the losses being a 2-2 result after fulltime against thesame side in a positional play-off, only for South Africa to godown on penalty flicks 5-4.

Back at home, the South Africans took on a fit Spanish side,who were missing only two of their first-choice players, in athree-match series in Pietermaritzburg. Both teams used theinternationals as part of their final preparation for Atlanta but,once again from a South African point of view, the resultstatistics were not exactly worth framing and hanging up in a Hallof Hockey Fame.

Despite playing some very good hockey in parts, the SouthAfricans appeared fatigued at times and made too many unforcederrors. They lost the three matches 4-1, 2-1 and 6-2. Nationalhockey coach Gavin Featherstone believes one of the major lessonslearnt from this series is that South Africa desperately needs anupgraded domestic league. "We don't have a club system in thiscountry to give our guys constant pressure week in, week out,"Featherstone says, "and hopefully one of the lessons of 1996 willbe that this country urgently needs a national league."

"We need to pool all our top players to play against each otherregularly -- and not just once a year at the inter-provincialtournament. Our players aren't used to playing regular competitivehockey at the level they do in Europe, or at the level they do inAustralasia or in Asia. Only when our top players get this type ofcompetitive level will they develop the discipline to avoid what Iterm the 'lull periods' in team sport. Then they won't go throughthese lapses and lulls where they get punished at internationallevel."

While obviously disappointed at the 3-0 whitewash at the handsof the Spanish, Featherstone takes the pragmatic viewpoint: "Afterlosing the third Test to them, we had played 10 internationals in17 days and I think it was a case of a bridge too far. We didn'tplay the Spanish on an equal playing field; we went round theworld, played seven matches and then said, within two days, thatwe could take them on in three Test matches. It proved a littlebit too much for our lads at this stage.

"But anyone who saw the quality of our play in the first halfof that third Test can see the standard we play at. Occasionallyit does happen that the bottom falls out -- but I think we musttake heart at our result in the second test ... where we lost 2-1... and at the first half of that third Test. We showed that wecan play at this level."

"I think the main thing the boys are learning is that you canhave a lot of the game and yet still lose by three goals becauseyou have to concentrate extra hard on teams who counter-attackwell. There's no doubt in my mind that that is the area I've gotto work on very hard with the players mentally between now andAtlanta."

What also has not helped the South African cause was the latego-ahead given for their Olympic Games participation -- and thishas directly led to the condensed period of preparation by thehockey squad since February.

"Remember we were allowed to go to Atlanta in mid- February,although we qualified in September at the All-Africa Games,"Featherstone says. "So we had a five-month period where we didvery little and weren't allowed to really. What we've had to do iscondense our physical training. So far, we've done endurancetraining and only now can we get on to our speed and sharpness."

Featherstone feels the difference in fitness levels betweenSouth Africa and Spain during their recent series was marked:"There's no doubt that the Spanish showed that they are matchsharp now for the Olympics, whereas we've still got a month to goon that training. And, in fact, our training will actuallycontinue in Atlanta because we had such a late start in goingthere."

Late start or not, there is very little else that the SouthAfricans could have done in recent months to improve on theirOlympic Games preparation. As Featherstone points out, a briefbreak is vital to rest bruised and overworked bodies after theintensity of playing 10 hockey internationals in under threeweeks. And an extra bonus from this short lay-off period would bethe full return to match fitness of playmakers Wayne Graham andAlistair Fredericks.

Despite all this, it may be that South Africa will still be ona hiding to nothing come Atlanta. But the South African hockeyteam are probably owed one or two favours by Dame Fortune -- andthey could certainly do with that modicum of luck which has notsmiled upon them over the last month.

Africa News


June, 1996


Arts Is White South African Rock Resurging?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian(Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Johannesburg - According to Tusk's Benjy Mudie, there's a"renaissance" happening, something of a "new wave". He may beright -- either that, or local record execs are just catching upwith their counterparts overseas. At last, the garage band iscommercial again.

Given an injection of new life by neo-punk, grunge and alterna-rockers like REM, Nirvana, Pearl Jam and Green Day, the genre ofwhite-boy-plays-loud-guitar is flowering globally. Oasis and theirlike have topped the British charts, where once only synth-swathed ditties ruled. The constraints of the mainstream money-makers, obsessed with the lowest common denominator and terrifiedof anything not produced to death, seem to have loosened. 

And South Africa is surfing that wave too. It may be somethingto do with our national sense of new freedoms, or perhaps it'sjust preparation for the quota system, but it does feel as thoughan awful lot of "local product" has been released in the last fewmonths.

Highlights include albums by The Pressure Cookies (okay, mostof them are female) and The Kerels. New work from well-knownfigures such as Tony Cox and Valiant Swart (his first CD, DieMystic Boer) is on the shelves. Bright Blue are back with a three-track EP, Open Your Eyes, and The Usual -- who share Bright Blue'sguitarist-singer Tom Fox -- have a six-track mini-album, Six Songsfrom the Inside, out too.

Moreover, two new compilation CDs give a reasonably rosypicture of exactly where South African rock'n'roll stands atpresent.

Street Level: Bare Essentials is the product of Cape Town'sStreet Level Studio, started by Richard Black and James Stewart.They have recorded The Usual as well as a handful of other CapeTown bands, giving them each a track or two on Bare Essentials toshow what they can do. The featured bands include Psycho- Deli,Black Diamond, The Groove Kings and Woodshed.

The fact that the CD has been released by record giant BMG --who also put their imprimatur on The Usuals' package -- gives hopethat the era of bands languishing in semi-obscurity without big-label support is over. The new lot, with luck, will have careerslonger than those of many of their Eighties' predecessors, forwhom the release of a record was very often swansong instead ofstarting- point.

The other compilation CD, the Tusk/5FM My Generation, is not --as the title, stolen from The Who circa 1965, might imply -- arepository of retro-rock. The only song on it that seems reallyout of place in 1996 is Duc the Fox's Love or Money. Otherwise,this is pretty much up-to-the-minute, a cross-section of SouthAfrica's newest, freshest talent.

Several of its 17 tracks, notably, came via the Shifty/Tic TicBang nexus, and it is a well-shaped collection that ranges fromthe guitar-lashed constructions of Squeal, Springbok Nude Girls,Sugardrive and Lithium, to the effervescently jivey pop of UrbanCreep and the New-Age yodelling of QCumba Zoo.

Several of the bands featured on My Generation are touring thecountry on the Bandslam bill, which hopes to do for us whatLollapalooza did for the USA. Perhaps it will be a further step inthe direction of white South African musicians, at last, making aliving from original music. At the very least, the concerts shouldhelp sell some CDs.

In the meantime, beyond all this big-hype activity, the newreleases keep coming. The aforementioned Valiant Swart CD isenjoyably barbed blues-rock; KwaZulu-Natalian Syd Kitchenimpresses with his jazzified City Child; and Joe Silva takes anunusual tack with Journeys into Coincidence, a selection of laid-back numbers, a bit like Ry Cooder in lazy- soundtrack mode, whichcan only help one feel meditative.

And then there's Jonathan Handley. The King Rat, pretending tobe The Glee Club, continues his South African Gothic saga withpart two, Transvaal Gothic (the first was Free State Gothic). Thewhole is a massive cycle of 33 songs, revolving around thepicaresque story of a sometime windmill salesman. Maybe onedoesn't need all 33 songs to get the picture, but none are merethrowaways, and many are as good as anything of that ilk ever madein this country.

And Handley is still, scandalously, on cassette only.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sudan Arabs Violate Peace Accord In Northern Sudan


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

London - In a report dated 22 April, the "Gazette" has received accounts of surprise attacks by a joint force of the Misiriya Arab "murahaleen" and the Popular Defence Forces (PDF) of the Khartoum regime upon the Dinka communities in the Abyei and Northern Gogrial areas. These areas had been peaceful since 1991 owing to a peace accord signed by the Misiriya Arabs with the Ngok and Twic Dinka. It now transpires that the National Islamic Front(NIF) regime offered the Misiriya Arabs all manner of inducements to break that peace accord and finally, in February, it succeeded in that objective.

The joint force launched its attack on 29 February along the River Kiir. The operation lasted until 3 March, by which time several Dinka villages had been ransacked and burnt down. They are: Malwal, Rumbek, Nguet, Micar, Atong, Majok Alieu and Lang. Cattle was looted and crops were destroyed.

This past year had seen a bountiful harvest and the Dinka were confident that they would not need any additional relief aid. It is believed that the Dinka's move towards self sufficiency provoked Khartoum into attacking at this time. 

On 10 March, a further military force launched a second attack on other villages in the area, destroying Malual Alieu, Dier, Gongmabil, Rumnyien, Kokwei, Mabil Anyiuel and Kol Kuot. This force was reinforced by units of the regular army stationed at Abyei. On 29 March, the attackers returned to the area in even greater numbers. The attack was co-ordinated with the Nuer tribal militia from Bentiu. That militia had instructions to prevent any Dinka cattle from using the common grazing land, so that no Dinka cattle or property escaped the looters.

The Sudan People's Liberation Army's (SPLA) civilian commissioner for Abyei, James Ajing Path, has produced a detailed report of the attacks. In the attack of 29 March, more than forty civilians were killed, thirty of them named in the report; more than one hundred women and children were captured and sold into slavery, including twenty-nine identified by the name in the report.

Slave Market. A slave trading and exchange camp was set up outside Abyei. Women were offered for their sexual services and as domestic slaves to Arabs who had not been involved in the attacks. The Dinka themselves were allowed to buy back their relatives at the rate of five cows per person or the equivalent in cash.

Following the third attack, large numbers of Dinka moved further South into Bahr El Ghazal and have sought refuge around the relief centre at Mayen Abun in the Twic Dinka area of Northern Gogrial. They are now at the mercy of the providers of relief aid. The areas is part of Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) but because it is in territory disputed by the SPLA and the NIF regime, the relief flights are infrequent and often cancelled at a whim by the regime.

Not all the Dinka made homeless by the attacks have managed to reach Mayen Abun. Reports suggest that many thousands are hiding out along the River Kiir, afraid that the marauders will return to capture them or finish them off. Those that have arrived are already suffering from food shortages.

Mr James Ajing Path has appealed to the international relief community to quickly come to the aid of this newly displaced population. The displaced people are quite capable of organising themselves to plant crops in the area during the rainy season, if they are given the seeds and tools with which to do it. The planting season in this area is quite flexible and crops could be sworn as late as June and July. Obviously, the people will need relief supplies to last until the crops can be harvested. These people are keen to become self sufficient once more, having lost everything in the three raids. As many as 100,000 people have been displaced by the attacks.

Workable Airstrips. There are a number of workable airstrips in the area that could be used for bringing in emergency relief supplies. Apart from Mayen Abun itself, there is the airstrip at Akak to the West, and airstrips at Turalei and Maper to the East. OLS has used all four airstrips in the past. There are a further two airstrips to the North of Mayen Abun at Ajak Kwac and Agok. These last two airstrips are closest to the area of devastation and lie in a very fertile agricultural area which could be used for planting crops.

Demand for Self Defence. There are many loud voices now within the Dinka communities, particularly in Northern Bahr El Ghazal but also elsewhere, who are calling for the SPLA to help the tribe set up and arm home guards to defend themselves against the Arabs and other tribal militias that seem to attack them with impunity. The SPLA has rightly resisted these calls. However, in the absence of any other alternative for the security of this tribe- so targeted for genocide by the NIF regime- the case for the tribe to arm itself to resist the regime's machinations is quite strong. That is, unless the SPLA finds itself with the resources and facilities to station a protective force in the border areas of Northern Bahr El Ghazal.

When in 1987-88 the government in Khartoum unleashed Arab and other tribal militias against the Dinka communities in the border areas, there was also a call to the SPLA to train and arm home guards. The reasons for resisting these calls for arms to the tribes were valid at that time and they remain so today. Perhaps the SPLA should consider placing its guerrilla units in these border areas to give the tribes there the confidence they need for their security and protection.

Where Is the SPLA? Whilst all the devastation and destruction took place, the forces of the SPLA were nowhere to be seen. This raises the obvious question as to why this was the case. Perhaps the SPLA believed that the peace accord between the Arabs and the Dinka was the best guarantor of security in the area. Even if that was not the case, the SPLA would need a huge military force to protect the area from the hit and run raids of the militia forces.

The NIF regime's plan is a simple one. If it can keep the tribes in the border areas fighting one another, then it can redirect its own war resources away from this area to other battle fronts in the South, the Nuba Mountains and now Eastern Sudan. It is not clear what SPLA forces may have been in the area because there was also the problem further South inside Bahr El Ghazal of the militia force of the renegade commander Kerubino Kuanyin Bol at Gogrial.

The SPLA has in the past been reluctant to engage in wholesale attacks on tribal militias, as it is a force fighting for national liberation from the NIF regime. However, the SPLA cannot ignore the security of the local population in these areas forever, because it ultimately needs their support. These communities are being attacked because they are perceived by the NIF to be supporters of the SPLA. They would not be under such severe pressure if they accepted Khartoum's overlordship. It must be hoped that the SPLA will recognise that these communities do need proper protection before the regime succeeds in convincing the people that the SPLA has abandoned them. The SPLA will not be able to maintain the loyalty of these groups unless it does something to alleviate their suffering.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Consortium Snubs Editorial Charter


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Jacquie Golding-Duffy


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Johannesburg - The National Empowerment Consortium, which is heading the bid for a stake in Times Media Limited's owner, Johnnic, has trashed the idea of an editorial charter as long as it remains a pre-condition of sale.

Cyril Ramaphosa, who is soon to be executive deputy chairman of New Africa Investments Limited (Nail), snubbed TML management by rejecting its idea for an editorial charter which was presented to him for his seal of approval.

The editors have publicly declared the charter as a means of "preserving age-old traditions and editorial integrity" and with this they tried to seduce Ramaphosa. 

Although he acknowledged that editorial independence was important, Ramaphosa indicated a polite thanks, but no thanks. Sources close to Ramaphosa say both the owners and editors of TML presented the idea of an editorial charter as part of the transaction, but that Ramaphosa would not budge on the issue.

It is understood that Ramaphosa is perplexed by the fact that the charter is a matter of urgency for TML with prospective new owners, but it was not -- and still remains -- a non-issue with the editors during the course of their current dealings with Johnnic.

According to a source, it emerged during the course of discussion between Ramaphosa and the editors that an immediate endorsement by Ramaphosa for the charter would smooth ongoing negotiations on the unbundling of Johnnic considerably, especially since a hard bargain is being driven by Johnnic.

Ramaphosa remains unconvinced by this and will continue to withhold his consent on the charter, insiders say.

Although Ramaphosa expresses support for editorial independence, the urgency for a charter suggested an uneasiness on the part of TML at the prospect of black owners. TML managing director Roy Paulson says the charter was drawn up and handed to Anglo American, but he has no knowledge of whether it was handed over to Ramaphosa. In fact, the idea has been conveyed to Ramaphosa on several occasions during the ongoing talks.

To some media observers, the "chickens have come home to roost for TML". An insider, privy to negotiations between TML and New Nation two years ago, says TML management belittled the idea of an editorial charter when New Nation requested one.

According to the source, Paulson attempted to ensure that TML would have had editorial control over and above a New Nation editorial charter, under instruction from executives at Omni Media and Johnnic.

"It's ironic that when they were negotiating they agreed to an editorial charter as long as they still maintained editorial control. For the publicity's sake, they even offered us 51% of the deal but they wanted to hold the reins. Now the time for TML has come, they are shaking in their boots and are pushing for a charter in desperation."

Paulson rejected these claims, saying that although he did approach New Nation, TML's intentions were honourable. "It's totally untrue that we offered New Nation a stake in the company. TML went in to buy the company and it would have been wholly owned by us," Paulson says.

"We respected their editorial independence and even had no problems with them supporting the African National Congress as long as it did not impinge on the commercial viability of the publication," he said.

New Nation editor Gabu Tugwana confirmed there was a "problem" which resulted in a breakdown in talks but refused to divulge details.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


116 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Whose Life is it anyway?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Johannesburg - Independent Newspapers' magazine Sunday Life may be sued by Time Warner, proprietor of the Life trademark.

Bob Scherer of the Trademark Council, a division of Time Warner in the United States, says talks are under way with Independent Newspapers' management, and although talk of a lawsuit may be "a bit premature", the issue is "far from resolved".

Law firm Adams & Adams, representing Time Warner, may have a conflict of interest since the firm also represents Independent Newspapers. Because of this conflict, Adams & Adams may have to abandon representing Time Warner. 

A source at the firm says Time Warner has not yet instituted proceedings, and Independent Newspapers must meet certain conditions in a bid to settle out of court. "It's difficult to prove trademark infringement and the matter may have to be negotiated further," an insider said.

Another adds that the issue at stake is whether or not the original trademark was copied and the defendant has to prove that it was not; alternatively, the plaintiff has to prove that it was.

Talks between the two parties have been ongoing for the past year. Sunday Life editor Les Aupiais says, as far as she knows, it was agreed Sunday Life will abide by certain conditions. These are that the magazine will not be sold as a stand-alone with a cover price, the name will not be printed in white on a red background as in the original Life magazine and that it will always have the prefix "Sunday" before "Life".

"The magazine will always be a supplement to the main body newspaper," says Aupiais, adding that the typeface of the magazine was also specially designed for the magazine and is nothing like that of the original Life trademark. "The typeface of Sunday is Firmin Didot and Life is in Doric. It was not copied from the original Life magazine," she says.

Managing director of Cape Newspapers Rory Wilson told the Mail & Guardian that Time Warner approached the stable some months ago where they stated their case. "We then took counsel's opinion on the matter and we are not infringing any trademark. We are holding by that," Wilson says.

Cape Newspapers' sales and marketing manager Greg Brophy confirms that legal counsel was sought. He says Sunday Life are two generic words which do not infringe on the trademark of Life magazine. "We have pumped lots of money into the marketing of Sunday Life and before that was done we ensured that we were on solid ground in terms of ethics and legal aspects."

Executive director of the Association of Marketeers Derek Dickens says trademarks and brands are what the free market is all about and well-known trademarks, for this reason, have to be protected.

According to Dickens, the Trademarks Act in South Africa is "a lot more lax" than in other countries. However, it is adequate to protect local and international brands.

The issue of Sunday Life and Time Warner boils down to whether Sunday Life was registered under the old Trademarks Act, which allowed for South Africans to register trademarks as long as they were not well- known locally, he says.

In the early Nineties, with the formation of the European Economic Council, there was an international effort to harmonise all trademark laws across the globe.

In an effort to keep in line with international trends, South Africa brought its own old-fashioned trademarks act into line with world standards. Now, with the old act repealed, the new Act insists that a trademark can only be registered once a worldwide search of brands is conducted by the applicant.

"America has put pressure on South Africans who harbour trademarks under the old Act. We have to get in line and respect international trademarks and make sure they are protected in this country as we risk losing favoured nation status," Dickens says.

A case in point is the international McDonalds versus Macdonalds, says Dickens.

Section 34.2 of the new Trademarks Act states that the rights of a trademark will be infringed if there is an unauthorised identical or similar mark in the form of shape, colour or name, that so nearly resembles another trademark that it is likely to be perceived as such or cause confusion.

Dicken argues that Time Warner in all probability has a strong case unless Independent Newspapers registered its Sunday Life logo under the old Act. He says the stable's counsel will then have to prove that the two brands cannot be confused. but with the new act in place, the newspaper house will have to get in line.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance In South Africa, 'Now is the time to buy'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Johannesburg - Investors should not be put off shares just because the Johannesburg Stock Exchange has taken a beating thanks to the rand's tumble. Rather, now is a good time to buy, says Schalk Theron, senior portfolio manager of Sanlam Unit Trusts. 

"The average annual after-tax return on shares over 20 years far exceeds that of other investments, so investors should take a long-term view and consider the softening of the JSE as a buying opportunity.

"It would be silly for a regular monthly investor to discontinue buying, because one can get more units for the same amount."

Shares are by their very nature volatile. But investors should not judge unit trust performance over periods of less than three years, says Theron. "Chasing returns over shorter periods becomes too risky for prudent portfolio management," he says.

For example, gold funds would have yielded a 30% return in the last quarter - but over a five-year term, that would have translated into 10%, as against the 25% return an industrial trust would have yielded at a much lower level of risk.

And the fundamentals continue to look good. "I do not think the share market is overvalued. I am bullish about prospects for growth," says Theron.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

118 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Labor Commission Stresses Jobs, Not Capital


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 814 words


 

The Labour Market Commission has sharply criticised South Africa's obsession with huge capital-intensive projects rather than more labour-intensive projects.

South African manufacturing was dominated "to an unusual degree" by highly capital-intensive sectors such as commodity chemicals, electricity generation and non-ferrous metals. Even services and agriculture were capital intensive. 

At the same time, there was significant under- investment in sectors such as clothing, footwear, furniture and tourism, with very little participation by small- to medium-sized firms.

South Africa's high capital intensity was, in part, due to the emergence of large and powerful public and private sector conglomerates that "have become deeply locked into our economic structure and will resist policy interventions that attempt to transform it". These had developed because of sanctions and the need to ensure self-sufficiency, while gaining access to secure sources of foreign exchange.

The new government had an entirely different set of priorities and concerns, not least job creation for the large pool of unskilled and semi-skilled labour and the better use of capital and skilled labour.

This did not imply that government should not support large projects now being planned, but "every effort" should be made to ensure that as many upstream and downstream jobs as possible were created at the same time.

"The current focus on development corridors clearly represents an attempt to generate sustainable employment clustered around infrastructural development and is welcomed," the commission said.

The move to create more jobs should be accompanied by specific policy measures aimed at dealing with the "notoriously weak competition policy", state purchasing that favoured large firms, export incentives biased against small firms and inadequate training for small business.

The commission warned, however, that "the labour market cannot, and should not, be expected to bear the full brunt of the adjustment alone".

As long as industries continued to benefit from subsidised electricity and finance, labour would continue to be a relatively costly input, which could lead to demands for wage cuts in return for employing more people.

The commission said these factors appeared to be recognised in government's present approach to industrial policy, but it expressed concern that it was not focused enough on the efficient and effective use of scarce capital resources.

It urged that the Industrial Development Corporation be forced to refocus its activities. It recognised that this "may be akin to turning a supertanker", but said it should focus more on job creation.

"A disproportionate share of its resources is devoted to very large highly capital-intensive projects, generally in partnership with a predictable array of well-resourced corporations," the commission said.

Key to any attempt to move towards labour-intensive policies would be concerted efforts to improve productivity and link that to wages.

"In fact, as the South African economy becomes more open to international competition, firms will only be able to survive if their costs and productivity are comparable to those of their major international competitors," the commission said.

The commission said there was no clear evidence that South African wages were out of sync with the rest of the world, but there was no room for complacency. Productivity had to be improved through the introduction of training programmes, multi-shift systems and the development of new products.

Big business could at the same time encourage the development of small and medium enterprises by sub- contracting out work. Unions have been somewhat uneasy with the idea, fearing that sub- contractors might be exploited at the expense of workers, but the commission warned against unions trying to ban sub-contracting and business against promoting the proliferation of sweatshops.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


119 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance South African Markets Unimpressed With Economic Strategy


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Peter Hilsenrath


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Johannesburg - Government has delivered its long-awaited economic strategy. Developed by an impressive team of economists, it adheres to established economic principles and promotes fiscal discipline. Yet markets remain unimpressed. Why?

The main reason is slow growth and inadequate employment creation. Economic growth in the integrated scenario projection remains below 4% through 1998. In the very uncertain "out-years" of 1999 and 2000, the model shows more impressive growth of 4,9 and 6,1% respectively. Employment growth only averages 2,9% through 2000. This does not adequately address South Africa's principal problem: unemployment. 

The growth that is envisaged is driven primarily by private sector investment and exports. Government investment actually drags economic growth down in 1996 and 1997 because its growth is lower than the gross domestic product (GDP) growth. In the "out- years", government investment rises inexplicably from 7,5% in 1999 to 16,7% in 2000 to provide an average growth rate for the 1996 to 2000 period of 7,1%. Perhaps Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) investment will surge in 2000, but RDP spending is no engine of growth for the next few years.

Export sector growth depends to a great extent on preserving the shift in relative prices brought about by rand depreciation. This requires a vigilant stance against inflation. Both tight monetary policy and incomes policy can be used here. One hopes there will be greater reliance on the latter, permitting lower real interest rates.

The real bank rate is seen to fall by four percentage points between 1996 and 1999. But sour management-labour relations could undermine incomes policy and lead to excessive monetary restraint. This would strangle the domestic sector in favour of exporters. Another concern is the response of exporters to wider profit margins. Will they expand output or reap higher profits? Much depends on expectations of relative competitiveness. More efficient production is needed. Lower tariffs should help.

The model shows real wages rising in spite of chronic unemployment. Yet there is talk of more flexible labour markets. Clearly, there is need for elaboration on how more flexible labour markets will come about.

Finally, there is much reliance on private sector investment to drive growth, with private investment growing by about 9% annually until 1999 and then jumping to even higher rates thereafter. But there is no consensus that private investment will grow at these levels. Financial markets have not responded with enthusiasm to the government's vision -- evidence that for all the rhetoric about fiscal discipline, what investors really want is growth, earnings and high rates of return. Since the government appears intent on waiting several more years before investing in South Africa, many domestic and foreign investors may decide to do the same.

Dr Peter Hilsenrath, an economist with the University of Iowa, has worked with Syfrets since August 1995

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

June, 1996


Business and Finance Record Diamond Sales For De Beers


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Johannesburg - De Beers' Central Selling Organisation (CSO) posted record rough diamond sales in the first six months of the year, increasing 8,2% in dollar terms over the same period last year. De Beers said the CSO sold US$2,748-billion worth of diamonds this year against $2,540-billion in the first half of 1995.

In rand terms, sales increased by 20% to R10,945- billion from R9,117-billion last year. De Beers said the half-year sales had seen continuing firm demand for larger better quality rough diamonds above half a carat, while retail jewellery sales remained positive, rising 5 to 6% in value last year and continuing to grow this year.

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Labor Group Questions Job Numbers


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Lynda Loxton


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Johannesburg - A controversial study suggests South Africa's unemployment rate is not the highest in the world and averages 20% against the 32% quoted by most experts.

The International Labour Organisation (ILO) study recognises that unemployment is a problem, but is not the Sword of Damocles that has sent various government departments and unions scurrying around for solutions. 

The ILO report rejects notions that South Africa suffers from "structural unemployment" as hazy and elastic and slams the figures produced by the most widely quoted October Household Survey as "distorted and an exaggeration".

It is hesitant about giving its own estimate on unemployment, but claims "one would not be far wrong in 'guesstimating' an unemployment rate of about 20%. Such a level is serious, but well short of the figure of 32% cited by politicians, economists and the media.

Blacks, youths and women should be granted special assistance "both in the labour market and through tackling barriers to their labour force entry and their access to employment," it says.

The report also warns about the likely short and medium term effects on unemployment of rapid trade liberalisation and market reform.
