122 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa 'C-words' Replace The 'F-word'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Johannesburg - Few politicians mention the "f-word" anymore -- it has been replaced by the "c-words" which are more and more characterising the ANC's approach to governing South Africa.

The "f-word" -- federalism -- was deliberately dropped during constitutional debate earlier this year, so that parties could move away from time-worn arguments and develop a new system of government based on the golden principles of co-operation, consultation and compromise.

"Co-operative government" is a term that can be sourced in debates about federalism and describes a system where provincial governments co-operate with one another for the common good, rather than compete against each other for individual gain. In the New South African sense it is embodied in the new Council of Provinces (COP), which will replace the Senate, and in the Intergovernmental Forum which is a forum for provincial and national executives, as well as in Minmec forums, which are meetings of national and provincial line-function ministers and MECs. 

The ANC is thrilled with this model, partly because it was a way of side-stepping a head-on argument over federalism and centralism -- but also because it is a pleasant and positive notion which decreases the chances of messy conflict and stand- offs between the central and provincial governments. Further, it complements the African principle of ubuntu, which describes a feeling of the worth of the community, a shared brotherhood of men and women and a sense of working for the common good. It is hoped that the model will be implemented before the end of the year.

The National Party supports the model of "co-operative government" and the principle of provincial co-operation enthusiastically, and does not believe that the accumulation of ANC interests in the COP will drown out the opposition voice of an NP-led Western Cape or an Inkatha-led Kwazulu-Natal. Both the ANC and the NP believe that the co- operative model is a healthy step away from Westminster type opposition politics.

Inkatha, however, is wary of the new set-up because it equates ANC co-operation with co-option. IFP hardliner Walter Felgate wastes no words: "Co-operative government is a shot-gun marriage between the provinces and central government". That is, "co- operation" will allow for easier, painless majority rule, he says.

ANC sources indicate that the model of co-operation was born partly with Inkatha-led Kwazulu-Natal in mind, in order to contain that province's waywardness and to build it into a system which allows provincial integrity on the one hand, but curtails maverick provincial impulses born from a desire to pursue competitive federalism.

Presidential adviser Professor Fink Haysom warns against competitive federalism, saying it could lead to an enormous waste of resources.

"In the competitive system, each province competes against every other province and too much political energy goes into securing the little good."

Haysom believes that competitive government could well lead to grave instability within the country and economic weakness nationally.

Certainly Haysom and the ANC have a valid point, and the pursuit of co-operation among all interest groups, large and small, is a welcome contrast to the previous era, where the needs of a tiny sector of the population were foisted on everybody else without attempts to reach consensus. The result was the destructive skewing of resources for which South Africans will pay for decades.

However, the ANC use of the word "co-operation" has an Orwellian resonance to it, especially if it is to become an end in itself, or is coupled to internal political agendas.

The debate around a new education system is an interesting example. It reveals that there is an articulated desire for co- operation on a highly sensitive issue, but that the ANC-led government is determined to push through its agenda, in spite of consultation, while using the co-operative forums to bind critical voices into the agreement.

"Co-operation" could become, at crunch-time, a thinly veiled majoritarianism which masquerades as the common good, but in fact represents ANC interests.

Fights about what is the common good are expected to escalate when the government implements national norms and standards in areas such as health, education and welfare. In terms of the constitution, the central government can overrule provincial objections when implementing national norms and standards, and effectively can make the co-operative COP a lesser partner in its decisions.

Political scientist Professor Willie Breytenbach says that the jury is still out as to whether or not the ANC is going to use "co-operation" to bulldoze through its political will.

However, it is interesting that Freedom Front leader General Constand Viljoen -- once the ANC's sweetheart -- is concerned about the extent to which the ANC is prepared to listen to differences of opinion and then ignore them, especially in the field of education.

On the basis of that experience, and the experience of negotiating for volkstaat agreements for over two years, he gives this advice to members of the public who have to negotiate with the ANC on matters of difference: "Certainly, talk, consult with the ANC, but be very careful because you must never underestimate the enemy, you must never underestimate the ANC, or the intellectual part of the ANC which is the SACP.

"You must have a clear idea of what you want to do, in line with international law, and you must stick to your point, otherwise you are on thin ice ..."

Viljoen said that minority parties could be sucked into a whirlpool of "co-operation" in which their interests could be drowned.

ANC intellectual and SACP member MP Pravin Gordhan hits back at that point of view: "The smaller parties' fear of co-operation is a search for leverage to defend, protect, enhance minority party concerns.

"It's not conflict we want, it's co-operation; it's not debilitating disagreement we want, it's optimal consensus; it's not unilateralism we want , it's multilateralism. We don't want individuals to be empowered to stand in the way of the collective, we want a collective in which the individual can find a means of expression."


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


123 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zimbabwe Mystery Surrounds Media Clampdown


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Richard Saunders


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Johannesburg - There is a mystery over the government takeover of the Zimbabwe Mass Media Trust (ZMMT), the nominally independent body which is the majority shareholder in Zimpapers, the country's only national newspaper chain.

Last month the Mail & Guardian reported on the government's move following a brief statement by director of information Bornwell Chakaodza, carried as a front-page news item in Zimpapers' flagship weekly, the Sunday Mail. Chakaodza announced that the trust's founding deed of 1981 had been amended in April following a cabinet decision. 

After that no further explanations were given for the government's abrupt reversal of a key plank in its post- independence media policy -- a change with profound implications for the state's role in the determination of editorial and management policy of the dominant national press.

Pointedly, journalists and editors working for Zimpapers and Ziana, the government news agency, did not pursue the subject, after having spent years proclaiming the sanctity of the ZMMT's independence.

If they had gone after the story they probably would not have got far.

Since Chakaodza's policy bombshell, ZMMT officials have been quiet, deflecting requests for copies of the amendments. Chakaodza's information ministry has also been evasive.

Searches for the director's initial press statement, still the only source of official comment on the matter, have come up empty- handed.

And still no copies of the deed changes. A check at the Deeds Registry office in Harare last week perhaps explains why.

According to registry officials no changes to the original 1981 ZMMT Deed have in fact been registered. Which means that the original 1981 trust deed is still legally in effect.

If the deed amendments have not been registered, one wonders where they are, why it has taken so long to put them into operation -- and why the Director of Information announced that the changes had been made on April 29?

Moreover, if there has been an error of fact by either government or the media which carried Chakaodza's announcement, why was it not later corrected by the ZMMT, government or by the ZMMT's own media?

Six weeks after the announcement of government's clampdown on the national press structures these questions remain unanswered.

The lack of clarity has led to further speculation. Last year, Honour Mkushi, the liberal-minded lawyer selected by trustees in 1995 as ZMMT chairman against the wishes of the information ministry, spoke of the ZMMT's new struggles to carve out an independent path just as government was twisting the ZMMT's arm to accept the state's control over the body.

"The trust doesn't want to operate on the basis of being tied at the end of a string that can be pulled by the Ministry of Information and government," Mkushi said. "If I was asked to wind up the trust on political grounds, I -- and several other trustees, I think -- would prefer to fight for survival on the grounds of protecting the principle of the trust."


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia Selassie's Death Recounted


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Alice Martin


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Addis Ababa - Dramatic new details about the mysterious death of Emperor Haile Selassie in 1975 emerged last week during a war crimes trial in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa.

The trial, which is considering evidence of alleged atrocities committed during the country's communist period from 1974 to 1991, was told that Selassie, who ruled Ethiopia for more than 50 years, was driven away from his palace on September 12, 1974, in a Volkswagen Beetle -- never to be seen in public again.

The first public account of the emperor's death came from two attendants who stayed with him in custody. They were brought in to see his body on the morning of August 26, 1975. 

"There was a smell of ether in the air," one witness said. "And his majesty was not lying in his usual position. He only had one pillow. The shawl that he wrapped himself in when he went to sleep was lying in another part of the room. His face was ghastly and there was a bandage around his neck."

The witness described how he had been with the emperor until 9pm the previous evening, when soldiers came to take him away.

"His majesty came from his bed and when he saw what was happening tears came to his eyes and he cried out: 'Is it not true, Ethiopia, that I have strived for you?' He fell on his knees and prayed. Later I realised that these were his last words to me."

A third witness described how Colonel Haile Mariam Mengistu, who had assumed leadership of Ethiopia's military council, the Dergue, ordered a number of graves to be dug in the grounds of the Grand Palace -- where the military's headquarters were.

The emperor, he said, was buried under Mengistu's office window.

"I was worried he would kill me," the gravedigger told the court, "but he lit a cigarette for me and told me to fence the area. I did it in 15 minutes while he watched from the window. Then he ordered me to construct a building on the site. I did it in two weeks."

Forty-six members of the Dergue are in the dock, with some former leaders -- including Mengistu, who fled to Zimbabwe -- being tried in their absence.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


125 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zimbabwe Press Awards Steeped In Farce


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Jan Rath


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Johannesburg - Zimbabwe's national award ceremony for journalists, an annual beanfeast which for the past six years has presented solid trophies and real prize money for independent, unfrightened journalists, is probably no more, following this year's occasion.

The National Journalists and Media Awards (NJAMA) is an institution where the praise singers of Zimbabwe's press are, for one day of the year, ignored, and reporters who write what is in front of their noses are rewarded for doing it.

In a nation where the daily newspapers, radio and television are owned by President Robert Mugabe's government and receive their instructions from the seldom-swept offices of the ministry of information in central Harare, NJAMA has been an inspiration.

Last year, a pair of journalists received due recognition as news reporters of the year for catching most of the ruling Zanu-PF party politburo parcelling out former white-owned farms to each other. This year the first prize was for a series of reports exposing ruling party officials trying to purloin the tender for the country's first cellular telephone network. 

The second prize was for breaching the bounds of the presidential bedroom and identifying Mugabe's new wife, whom he married clandestinely.

But this year's ceremony was blighted by folly from which it may prove impossible for the organiser, the Willie Musarurwa Memorial Trust, to recover. One after the other, sponsors on whose support the ceremony is dependent, have announced their withdrawal.

It was a critical misjudgment to hold the affair in the hall of the Zanu-PF headquarters, a vast and dingy auditorium the size of a rugby field whose parquet flooring obviously has not tasted polish in the decade of its existence.

The bar at the Zanu-PF headquarters was run by someone's relative who runs a bottle store 30km outside town. It was a revealing indication of the headquarter's usual clientele. It cost Zim $5 deposit for a glass for each drink, and it was a nightmare trying to get the money back.

On the day of the ceremony, Kindness Paradza, the president of the Zimbabwean Union of Journalists (ZUJ), was urging members of his union to boycott the awards because, he said, the electronic media, which consists entirely of the state-owned Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC), were not represented in the awards.

ZBC had let the organisers know in March that it was withdrawing its participation because of the way its journalists had been "lampooned" at the awards last year, but also because one of the judges was Jeremy Brickhill, a private television producer who is suing the ZBC for a large amount of money for non- payment of fees. ZBC journalists affirm they were instructed by their management not to have anything to do with NJAMA.

ZUJ had already expressed concern that the venue, chosen because the organisers got it "dirt cheap", might prejudice the impartiality of potential participants, 90% of whom comprised the ZBC, Zimpapers, the national newspaper chain and the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency (ZIANA), the domestic news agency, all of whom fall under the financial and editorial direction of Zanu-PF.

ZUJ was a member of the organising committee which had been meeting twice a month since November last year, although its representative made only sporadic appearances. The first the committee heard of ZUJ's withdrawal was in the columns of the daily newspapers on the day of the awards.

But ZUJ's boycott pretty well worked. The collection of tables in the southern section of the hall was already dwarfed by the immensity of the auditorium, and the effect was enhanced by the occupation of only about half of the seating.

Recipients of awards had been advised, however, that failure to attend the ceremony would deprive them of their award and of the prize money (R1000 for first place, R500 for second and R250 for third). The only person not to turn up for his award failed to do so because he was injured in a car crash. It could not be established whether he forfeited his prize money.

Guest speaker for the occasion was Deon du Plessis, managing director of Gauteng Newspapers, whose huge bodyguard drew appreciative murmurs as he ferried many large brandies and coke to his employer.

Du Plessis's speech, stating that South African newspapers have "a good news obligation" under the new government, went down like a stone with those in the audience who had anything to do with the late Willie Masururwa, the patron of the trust and former editor of the Sunday Mail, Zimbabwe's biggest selling newspaper. Msururwa had repeatedly warned his staff of the dangers of "sunshine journalism".

The massacres of civilians in the western provinces of Matabeleland by Mugabe's 5th Brigade, corruption, Zanu-PF's peculiar support for the PAC instead of the ANC, and its "leadership code" of austerity that everyone ignored were issues that Musarurwa could not close his eyes to.

Musarurwa was sacked on Mugabe's orders in 1985. Maybe, in his time, he would have survived had he listened to the likes of Du Plessis.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


126 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Angola Corruption Rife In Angola's Ruling Party


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Johannesburg - The ailing Angolan president is turning his back on his own party, reports the latest edition of Africa Confidential.

President Jose Eduardo dos Santos's recent sacking of Prime Minister Marcolino Moco and his cabinet was a belated attempt to rally his troops before they have to start doing business with Jonas Savimbi's political cadres in Luanda.

The merging of government and rebel armies is meant to be finished within three months.

But Angolans are sceptical; Dos Santos is widely seen as heading a weak, divided and discredited party. 

Fernando Franca Van-Dunem, whom Dos Santos has chosen to revitalise the government, does not stand out as a beacon of reforming zeal.

And Dos Santos himself seems seriously weak. Diplomats in Luanda have been trying to discover just what is wrong with him. Since he was treated at a private clinic in France in April, he has rarely been seen in public and has received few visitors at the Futungo de Belas palace. There are rumours circulating that he has prostate cancer.

There is uncertainty everywhere, especially around the peace process. The Uniao Nacional para a Independencia Total de Angola (Unita) has tentatively begun to move its troops into quarters, but its commitment to peace remains highly ambiguous.

Most importantly, the ruling Movimento Popular de Libertacao de Angola (MPLA)) is on the brink of collapse. In 1992 Dos Santos campaigned on his own merits, aided by a slick Brazilian-run advertising campaign, and since then put a distance between himself and the party.

Dos Santos relies heavily for advice on a small group of friends and family. The United States has invested a great deal in its relationship with the president. An important channel has been former assistant secretary of state Herman Cohen, whose consulting company has worked closely with the Dos Santos government.

Dos Santos has recently failed to give a consistent political lead at home or abroad; to many he appears more interested in his private affairs than in running the state.

Diplomats fear that Dos Santos may reject the advice of the poster at Luanda airport proclaiming "Angola no coracao (Angola in the heart)" and might leave for Brazil and a wealthy retirement. Ill-health and his growing fear of plots have made the presidency tougher than ever. But senior MPLA officials work hard to keep him going. They fear bloodletting in the party if he quits.

The MPLA is regularly attacked from inside. Lucio Lara, the former secretary general, recently called the party "old and tired". It has not held a congress since 1991 and the central committee decided in February to postpone the next congress to 1997. The apparatchiks do not want to draw attention to the division, corruption and weakness of the party.

For a year after Bicesse Accords, in May 1991, the MPLA failed to meet the challenge of Unita, which lost the multi-party elections of September 1992 mainly because of Jonas Savimbi's threatening campaign, rather than the MPLA's merits. The MPLA was stimulated to pull itself together by Unita's rejection of electoral defeat and its return to armed struggle.

Even before the Lusaka Protocol in 1994, the government army, Forcas Armadas Angolanas (FAA), clearly had the military advantage over Unita forces. But this is not the same thing as the MPLA having the military advantage. FAA officers such as General Joao de Matos have shown open contempt for the party. De Matos himself never joined the MPLA.

The MPLA of old started dissolving in the run-up to the 1992 elections. when many members started moving their families out of Angola and got as much money out as they could. That process has never been reversed and the party has not been renewed. Now MPLA officials seem intent on pursuing their private interests and leaving the growing urban poor in the hands of United Nations agencies and foreign non- governmental organisations.

State power is supposed to be concentrated and co- ordinated in the Council of Ministers. In practice ministers look after their own ministries and governors after their provinces. Strategic decisions are made mainly by the president's Futungo palace.

Futungo overrules cabinet frequently. For example, in September 1995 it stopped the issue of new banknotes by Finance Minister Augustino Tomas. There is almost no talk of post-war reconstruction. Futungo's longest perspective is the two-monthly renewal of the mandate of the UN Angola Verification Mission.

The rulers' main energies go into their own business affairs. Minister of Agriculture Isaac dos Anjos recently got a bank loan to set up a fruit factory in which he is the shareholder-owner. He told the press that he had to look after his own interests first. There are more than 70 foreign security firms in Luanda, protecting senior people's interests. Meanwhile teachers are paid about $3 per month; a bottle of beer costs $1. The foreign- exchange value of the Kwanza fell by 3,608% in 1995.

The government announced in May that it is planning measures to ease the crisis. After the reshuffle, it is rumoured there will be pay increases for state employees. Without sound public finances, that can only spur inflation.

Crime is pervasive. The authorities have banned several demonstrations, broadcasting warnings on the radio and stationing rapid-intervention police (the infamous "Ninjas") to deter would- be demonstrators.

The government cannot really trust the active army and the regular police, some of whose senior officers sympathise with the discontented civilians.

The government tries to hold the loyalty of senior serving officers by allocating profitable enterprises to them. The MPLA hopes this will increase its influence, because they need party patronage if they are to make profits. But some officers have set up on their own accounts. In Lunda Norte, at Calonda, a diamond concession is run by Tricorn, which is linked to Chief of Staff Joao de Matos and other officials.

Unita, too, is becoming a business alliance. Of Angola's total output of diamonds, estimated by Western intelligence reports to be worth up to $690- million, Unita mined and smuggled out $430- million in 1995. The alluvial diamonds of Lunda Norte are almost worked out. In 1996 Unita brought in equipment and skilled staff from South Africa to work the Cuango riverbed.

Savimbi and his Unita associates may even be worried by Dos Santos's reported illness. They do not respect the president, but regard him as a stabilising influence. The government's senior officers and the MPLA's cadres envy Unita's hold on diamond-rich areas. Business could bring the rivals together -- or in the unrest that would follow Dos Santos's departure, set them at each others' throats again.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


127 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Abortion Vote Pressures Parliament


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Johannesburg - When new legislation liberalising South Africa's abortion laws reaches Parliament, much will depend on whether African National Congress MPs vote en bloc or according to their consciences. While the debate has yet to rage in the ANC caucus, MPs are already under pressure.

ANC policy has been unequivocally in favour of women's right to safe, legal abortions -- and usual practice is for caucus to guide voting on related legislation. But Christian and Muslim MPs and others who oppose abortion on moral grounds face a dilemma -- spelt out in a document circulating among MPs which urges the ANC to oppose an open vote. 

It carries the name of deputy president Thabo Mbeki's adviser, Reverend Frank Chikane, and is a position paper issued by the Research Institute on Christianity in South Africa at the University of Cape Town's Department of Religious Studies.

Co-authored by Professor John de Gruchy and Reverend Barney Pityana, the paper, entitled The Dilemma of Some Christian MPs and the proposed abortion policy, does not argue for or against abortion, but for the right of MPs to dissent on party policy on religious or moral grounds, while remaining loyal party members.

They argue that because MPs cannot cross the floor to another party without losing their seats, coupled to the fact they are not elected by constituencies, an open vote is necessary on religious or moral principle.

"Many members of the ANC honestly believe the pro- abortion policy which has been proposed is an expression of the commitment to gender rights and equality (and) also regard it as the best way to deal with a highly complex moral and medical issue," they write. "But there are also those who disagree on the basis of a different interpretation of human rights.

"The question of abortion is a particularly difficult one for maintaining party discipline because it is on the boundary between what the ANC might expect from its members who support its stand on gender issues and yet who, on religious or moral grounds, cannot support legalised abortion or the proposed legislation.

"There can be no doubt that the rights of women cannot be denied or voted against by ANC representatives; there can also be no doubt that Roman Catholics as well as believers of some other traditions cannot vote for abortion without denying their faith and its moral demands. They want to support gender equality and rights, but not in this way. So in all conscience, they are duty bound to dissent. It is precisely on such boundary issues that an open vote becomes necessary."

Allowing a free vote would be "a clear sign that the ANC recognises the higher loyalty which people of all faiths acknowledge". "Instead of alienating sections of the population which are generally supportive of ANC policy, they will strengthen their commitment to the party," the paper says.

MPs facing this dilemma find it compounded by the fact their votes become part of the public record.

Said a Muslim ANC MP: "We have already been denounced by religious leaders for not speaking out against abortion during constitutional negotiations. We are members of the ANC and the country is governed by a Constitution guaranteeing women's equality, but ultimately we are bound by the Qu'ran."

In response, the Reproductive Rights Alliance has urged the ANC to reaffirm its position on abortion. "The fact that abortion is a moral issue should not mean the ANC need feel obliged to abandon party discipline.

As things stand, the African Christian Democratic Party is opposed to liberalising abortion laws. So is the National Party, which will use the whip to ensure its members toe the party line in voting against the new bill -- unless sufficient NP women supporters who feel differently can make their voices heard.

The Democratic Party will allow its MPs to vote according to their consciences. After a debate in the Inkatha Freedom Party parliamentary caucus last year, IFP leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi allowed MPs to do the same.

"There are different views within the IFP and they are irreconcilable," said an MP. "The one is that abortion is a crime, the other that it's a crime that women can't have them. But it seems the majority of caucus is opposed."

The big question is which way the ANC will jump.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


128 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Costs Of Stalling Abortion Law


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

Johannesburg - Draft legislation liberalising the country's abortion law was due before a cabinet committee on May 29. But health minister Nkosazana Zuma withdrew it at the last minute, fuelling suspicions that political considerations -- not the least pending KwaZulu-Natal local government elections -- has seen it pushed to the backburner.

The Mail & Guardian established this week that the draft Termination of Pregnancy Bill was submitted by the department of health drafters on May 22 and scheduled to go before the Cabinet Committee on Social Affairs and Administration on May 29. The matter was left in abeyance at the request of the minister. 

Department of health legal section head Sello Ramasala said this week he was not aware of any problems with the bill -- ruling out the possibility of it being withdrawn for technical reasons.

Speculation is now focused on whether the political sensitivity of the legislation -- which provides for abortion on request -- is not the issue. There was also concern this week that the delay would prevent the bill from being introduced to parliament before it rises at the end of the year.

Zuma said she did not want to discuss Cabinet issues with the press. "On principle, members of Cabinet do not go to the press on Cabinet issues until approval has been reached, because it is a collective," said director general Dr Olive Shisana.

"If I recall we in the department had not worked out the financial implications and had to do that on the Cabinet memo to be sure the minister was properly advised in terms of the implications of the policy.

"The department did not withdraw the Cabinet memo. But the routine is that if there are financial implications it's required to consult the Department of State Expenditure. That could not be done because while the provinces said they had the money, we had to have it in writing -- we couldn't rely on verbal consultations," said Shisana. "We felt it was important to take that step."

There was "no way" she could give dates when the Bill would come before Cabinet. The ball is rolling.

Indications are that the African National Congress is wary about floating the issue ahead of the KwaZulu-Natal elections for fear it will become a political football. The Inkatha Freedom Party is also divided on the issue.

"It would appear to me the matter is deliberately being put on the backburner until after the KwaZulu- Natal elections," said IFP MP Suzanne Vos.

There is also speculation that Zuma -- who strongly backs abortion reform -- may be less than keen on engaging in a hefty political battle so soon after the Sarafina 2 debacle.

But for health care providers the issue is critical. Hospitals are battling to cope with the demand for legal terminations in terms of the existing law and they have to plan to provide the infrastructure and training necessary to cope with demand once the law is changed.

The judicial process has also been affected: in some magisterial districts, cases involving medical practitioners charged with providing illegal abortions have been stayed pending changes in the law.

Dr Marj Dyer, president of the Abortion Reform Action Group, said she was receiving up to four calls a day from women "across the spectrum of population groups, income level and religious affiliation" seeking terminations.

Hospitals are not coping with the demand for legal terminations under the current law. The new bill, if passed, would provide for women to be treated at primary and secondary health-care facilities -- taking the strain off the major hospitals and giving women more equal access to help.

In the Western Cape, a provincial task group has been set up to deal with problems being encountered in implementing the existing law. "There's this sense of limbo because we don't know what's happening with the legislation. There is a need for government to take a lead and say these are the services we will need to provide," said a task group source.

Groote Schuur Hospital (GSH), one of three hospitals allowed to carry out legal terminations, handles the majority of cases and cannot meet the demand.

Head of GSH's obstetrics and gynaecological department Professor JB Dommisse has said in an internal Medical Association of South Africa newsletter that the high demand was a result of many women thinking abortion on demand was available.

Limited resources and other demands on the department forced GSH to put in place two years ago a quota system limiting the number of women who can be given legal terminations.

But this quota system is giving rise to its own problems. Gynaecological and out-patients' department staff find themselves subjected to harassment from referring doctors and patients when told the quota is full. Women, told they can't be seen in a given week, try again and again, creating a bottleneck which sees women presenting at more advanced stages of pregnancy.

A GSH representative said: "The bottleneck phenomenon is a logical consequence of any quota system where demand exceeds the ability of resources to cope." Women who could not be seen were referred back to their doctors.

They can go to a private hospital -- which would exclude, on grounds of cost, the majority of women, or another state hospital licensed to do terminations. However, the increase in demand at GSH is understood to reflect the difficulty women have in getting terminations at the only other hospitals licensed to do them, Tygerberg and Somerset Hospitals.

In addition, implementing the abortion law is costing the country millions of rands a year and effectively sentencing women who resort to backstreet abortionists to illness, sterility or death.

In a recent study, the Medical Research Council estimated that 44 686 women a year, ranging in age from 14 to 49, presented to hospitals with incomplete abortions. The vast majority (84%) were African women, followed by coloured (11%), Asian (4%) and white (1%).

During 1994, 2 180 legal abortions were performed - -- 61,3% on white women from the urban middle class.

The study found that 425 women each year could die in hospital from septic abortions, that each year countrywide 6 961 women were "moderately sick" and 5 886 "very ill" after abortions usually carried out on the backstreets. The total costs of treating incomplete abortion cases in one year was R18,6- million. This amount could fund more than 88 000 safe abortions using existing technology.

"The health costs and consequences of unsafe abortion to South African women are a serious public health issue," said Michelle O'Sullivan of the Reproductive Rights Alliance, a network of organisations formed to lobby for and promote comprehensive reproductive health care services.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

129 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Poll Will Entrench Parties' Strongholds


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Ann Eveleth


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

Johannesburg - The Inkatha Freedom Party is likely to win most rural areas, and the African National Congress is poised to win the powerful Durban metropolis and Pietermaritzburg in KwaZulu- Natal's long-awaited local government elections next Wednesday.

The result will merely entrench the two parties' strongholds, keeping the province politically divided into mainly rural and urban constituencies.

Both parties, however, are hoping for more. The ANC is pushing for victory in at least one of the province's seven over-arching regional councils, and several of the main towns and cities dotting the countryside, while the IFP wants to capture at least one of the six sub-structures comprising the Durban metro. 

The ANC is pushing hardest for the urbanised Midlands Regional Council, which stretches from Kranskop in the north to East Griqualand in the south, Pietermaritzburg in the east and Impendle in the west.

The ANC won roughly 49% of the region's votes in 1994. The IFP came second with 35%. Comprising 20 municipalities, the region forms part of the powerful Durban-Pietermaritzburg corridor --Ethe centre of commercial activity in the province.

Also comprising important rural constituencies, the battle for control of this region has been the fiercest, marked notably by several violent confrontations, particularly in rural Donnybrook.

The IFP's push to make Ulundi the provincial capital, the ANC's uncontested victory in strife- torn Richmond, and a concentration of ANC strongholds in many of the region's townships, have made the IFP's fight for the region far more difficult than in the six remaining regional councils, where it held a clear victory in 1994.

The province's complicated rural local government formula --Ea transitional arrangement making chiefs automatic rural local "councillors" and reserving them 20% of seats on the second-tier regional councils --Ehowever, makes victory an uphill battle for the ANC.

Although the party has launched a legal challenge to the formula, the reservation of seats for mainly IFP-aligned chiefs -- Etogether with the 10% reserved for mainly conservative white farmers or "levy payers" --Emean only 70% of regional council seats will be elected from rural party lists and municipal councils.

The ANC would have to win at least 70% of elected seats to gain a simple 50% majority on a regional council. It could easily win the majority of votes and still lose control of the region.

In the province's 61 towns and cities, the application of the Kempton Park horse-trading deal known as the "50-50" arrangement --Ewhere small white constituencies in the town centres will elect the same number of councillors as populous black townships on the towns' outskirts --Ewill be decisive in towns where the ANC wins the most votes but falls short of an absolute council majority.

Perhaps the most complicated voting formula -- Eespecially for first-time municipal voters -- Eis that for the Durban metro. The metro's 1,1-million voters will cast three ballots each to determine the winner: one for a councillor in one of 164 wards, one from a party list for one of six sub-councils, and one from a separate party list for the metropolitan council.

The ANC was the biggest party in the metro area in 1994 with approximately 41% of the votes, followed by the National Party (31%) and the IFP (21%).

A massive area comprising nearly one-third of the province's voters, and controlling a R3,6-billion budget, the Durban metro will be the prize of this election.

The IFP is pushing hard to prevent this, relying partly on the 50-50 deal which divides the wards equally between former white, Indian and coloured areas on the one hand, and traditionally African areas (townships) on the other.

Known as "A-wards" and "B-wards" respectively, these are not strict racial classifications but are rather based on former Group Areas Act divisions. The IFP hopes to benefit from the inclusion of mushrooming informal settlements into some A-wards and participation in joint development forums with these settlements' "minority" neighbours.

The IFP gained significant support from Durban's white voters in 1994 and has made a push for Indian supporters in this election. The party hopes its recent work will boost the 5% Indian vote it received in 1994 and deliver a victory in the largely Indian northern substructure or "suburb" (comprising Tongaat and Verulam), where it is contesting 16 of the 18 wards --Ealbeit with many of its Indian candidates declining to put the party logo next to their name.

An IFP victory in this substructure would deliver a psychological blow to the ANC --Erepresenting not only an IFP advance into its metro stronghold, but also marginalising the ANC's hard-won Hambanathi stronghold within the sub-structure.

Hambanathi was the site of intense violence in the early 1980s, at the start of the province's civil war. Nevertheless, the ANC is expected to emerge with the highest number of metropolitan votes, the only question being one of percentages.

If the party falls short of an absolute majority of seats, it may find its power usurped by a hostile coalition. Most of the 53 000 new Metro voters registered during the one-month delay the party demanded in April are believed to be ANC supporters and the party has worked non-stop to mobilise its constituencies since the delay.

The metro's black townships are largely ANC-aligned, although they contain significant IFP strongholds. The minority A-wards which hold the balance of power are mainly Indian-dominated and the ANC gained about 25% of the community's vote in 1994 --Esecond to the National Party's 60% majority.

While the ANC's Indian support-base derives mainly from middle- class Natal Indian Congress supporters, its local government candidates have campaigned vigorously in the working class neighbourhoods of Chatsworth and Pheonix, where its civic structures -- such as the Pheonix Working Committee -- have fought long battles over local issues.

Competition for the metro's significant Indian and marginal coloured votes is the most intense -- Ewith canvassers from the NP, ANC, IFP, Minority Front, Democratic Party and a host of independent groups practically stumbling over one another as they beat a path to the next house.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Commander's Trial Winds Up After 16 Months


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Stefaans BrUmmer


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Johannesburg - The marathon murder trial of Eugene de Kock entered its final stages this week with a blistering prosecution attack on the former Vlakplaas commander's lawyers for drawing out proceedings with "irrelevant" cross-examination.

Prosecutor Anton Ackerman, deputy Transvaal attorney general, made the charge in a lengthy submission as the 16-month-old trial resumed in the Pretoria Supreme Court on Wednesday for final argument. De Kock's defence team has already cost taxpayers more than R4-million, about half in fees for chief defence counsel Flip Hattingh. 

Late last month Hattingh accused Ackerman of "serious misconduct" for meeting De Kock, who is charged on 121 counts of murder, fraud and unlawful weapons possession, in January at the Pretoria Central Prison.

Hattingh, who said he should have been consulted about the meeting, threatened to ask for a mistrial and reported Ackerman to the Pretoria Bar Council.

While Ackerman at no stage said Hattingh acted outside his rights in his style of cross-examination, he argued Hattingh had often dwelt, sometimes for weeks, on "collateral" aspects when cross-examining state witnesses.

Ackerman said Hattingh attempted "from the outset" to discredit state witnesses, often on extraneous factors such as Vlakplaas informant Ben van Zyl's "extra-marital affair", or allegations of Chappies Klopper's relations with prostitutes. He said the state did not regard Klopper -- witness "Q" who first told the Goldstone Commission about Vlakplaas crimes -- as a key witness. "Hundreds of pages" of cross-examination had been spent on Klopper's own background and on the 1985 departmental hearing of state witness and former Vlakplaas commander Dirk Coetzee.

Ackerman said it was common for witnesses to differ on minor apects, but that Hattingh had spent much time teasing out the expected. "This is exactly what happened in this case ... while it was never stated what the accused will maintain."

He said the defence had taken a new tack in September last year -- where previously it appeared to have believed De Kock could be cleared of the charges, Hattingh then tried in cross-examination to show that De Kock had merely followed orders from "the generals". (Significantly, this was when De Kock's confidant Willie Nortje started his testimony against his former commander, and when police commissioner George Fivaz first said police were considering withdrawing state funding of the defence.)

Ackerman also accused Hattingh of "a conscious attempt" to discredit Transvaal attorney general Jan D'Oliveira's investigation team by saying, for example, that "the defence was bugged where it met with the accused". But after objections from Hattingh, Judge Willem van der Merwe told Ackerman he could not pursue the argument without specific reference to what Hattingh had said in court.

Ackerman also outlined what he called the former security police "modus operandi". He said "people who wanted to make revelations over police irregularities were to be killed", and that this was confirmed by, for example, the cassette player bomb sent to Coetzee. The bomb killed lawyer Bheki Mlangeni -- his death is one of the murders of which De Kock is accused.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Winnie's Audit Splits ANC Women's League


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Johannesburg - Former senior members of the ANC Women's League (ANCWL) have raised questions about the impartiality of the auditor who compiled the report on the league's finances, as the row over financial mismanagement in the league escalated in Parliament this week.

However, such is the fear and loathing between various sectors of the league that suspicions are not stated openly, and the audit report has remained sizzling in the fat of secrecy all week.

It was revealed at the weekend that the auditors, commissioned by the ANC, had discovered "serious discrepancies" in the spending of about R7,8-million by the ANCWL during a period when ANC stalwarts Adelaide Tambo and Makhosazana Njobe were treasurers, and Baleka Kgotsisile, now deputy speaker of Parliament, was its secretary general.

The audit, by Hardman and Associates, was commissioned by ANC secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa after fights about power and finances within the league last year, which have not yet been resolved. 

While Ramaphosa appointed the auditors, Winnie Madizikela- Mandela is said to have suggested which firm be employed.

Jeff Manning, senior partner of Hardman and Associates, said weekend media reports "had got it all wrong".

He said 99% of the almost 7,8-million could be accounted for and the report did not apportion blame to anyone in the ANCWL. Manning added that Tambo was "not a financial whizz-kid" and most of the problems were due to a lack of proper controls and systems and to the inexperience of junior officials, not to misappropriation.

"Nobody could be accused of fraud on the basis of the report," he said. "I've recommended that Mrs Tambo and Mrs Madizikela- Mandela sit down together and go through all the transactions and decide which ones should be accepted and which ones not."

The ANC has said it would call such a meeting that would include Ramaphosa and ANC treasurer general Reverend Arnold Stofile to help to sort out the problems.

Manning said he had also discovered that last year's fall-out in the ANCWL, which led to the walk-out by nine executive members including Tambo and Kgotsisile and the resurrection of Madizikela- Mandela as unchallenged president, had been over nothing at all.

The recommendations of the auditor -- which appear to be of a political nature -- have not gone down well with those who walked out last year, and who fear he wrote the audit from a particular perspective.

"The ANC has spent R91 000 on an assault on our integrity," growled one.

The unnamed former executive members say the auditor had not questioned key role-players such as Tambo and Njobe about alleged irregularities and say they are suspicious that the audit took more than six months to complete at a cost of R91 000.

But to add to the saga, the so-called Winnie camp -- current league executive members -- say they are equally distressed the report was leaked.

They refuse to comment until the league's national executive meets to discuss the report. These members believe this debacle is "slowing their progress" in the empowerment of women. Asked if the league should perhaps disband, executive member Maureen Malumise replied: "Absolutely not, we are very strong on the ground. The league is bringing women together over women's issues."

Members point out the league sets up workshops on subjects such as reproductive rights, land rights, equality and empowerment, is driving a programme of action inherited from the Beijing Women's Conference and has led a campaign about abused women.

Yet women MPs from outside the league are asking under their breath whether the league, with its power-play and its set agenda, is serving any real purpose in politics.

Male ANC MPs who entertain the same question say they are frightened to raise the issue lest they get branded as sexist, so the questions remain buried.

The official line is defensive. ANC MP Carl Niehaus answered questions about the ANCWL's role by saying: "It's not what they've done, it's what they have the potential to achieve."

And league members, past and present, are wary of what they see as male plots, speculating the audit report was leaked by male MPs to disempower women within the organisation, and to undermine the league after its outspoken criticism of the Sarafina II affair and its support for beleaguered Deputy Enviroment Minister Bantu Holomisa.

Some see criticism of the league as a strategy to unseat Madizikela-Mandela from her last throne.

Niehaus said the ANC is waiting for additional information on the finances before proceeding with the meeting. This contradicts Manning, who says he has closed his books on the league for good.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance South Africa's Telkom Struggles In The Net


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Justin Pearce


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Johannesburg - Telkom's plans to set itself up as an Internet service provider (ISP) have prompted the Internet Service Providers' Association (ISPA) to take the parastatal to the Competitions Board. The ISPA believes Telkom is using its uniquely privileged position to squeeze existing ISPs out of the market.

With Telkom's monopoly on telephone lines and other communications infrastructure, ISPs are forced to become clients of the South African Internet Exchange (SAIX), a division of Telkom. In the case of the larger service providers, this costs in the region of R1-million a month. 

Now the ISPs believe Telkom is undermining them by marketing itself direct to the public and to corporate clients.

"ISPs are legally obliged to buy all communications services from Telkom," says David Frankel, joint chair of ISPA. "This includes artificially expensive international circuits to communicate with the United States. If ISP were allowed to bypass Telkom using international carriers directly out of South Africa, our prices to end users could be reduced dramatically. Telkom is abusing its monopoly and profitability in this area to undercut existing ISPs."

As service providers have to work through Telkom when connecting a new client to the Internet -- a process which can take up to eight weeks for Telkom to install a digital line -- there are concerns that SAIX will be at an unfair advantage when it comes to linking up new customers, since Telkom will be able to give first priority to SAIX clients.

ISPA fears that Telkom's entry into the service provision market could bring an end to the healthy competition in the industry which has so far seen a boom in Internet service provision in South Africa. Frankel has received hundreds of letters from existing or prospective clients who acknowledge that subscribing to SAIX will be far more competitive than remaining with the existing ISPs.

In an interview with Intelligence magazine, Telkom's strategy and business development executive Blackie Lahoud claimed Telkom was not guilty of unfair competition, but "we're doing what Telcos around the world are doing -- adding value to our services".

Frankel points out this is an invalid comparison, given the absence of competition or regulation to keep a check on Telkom.

Telkom's Internet product manager Rikus Mattyser said in an interview with Sapa this week that SAIX is not a service provider, and that the existing ISPs are its only clients.

Yet publicity material put out by Telkom clearly expresses an intention to become a service provider dealing direct with the public. "Will Telkom provide Internet services? YES!" proclaims one brochure. It goes on to detail the advantages of Internet access to the business user, and declares "Telkom's SAIX service makes it easier than ever to access the Internet."

Approached for further comment, Telkom representative Zandile Mxaku said the matter was now before the Competitions Board, and the corporation could not respond to media enquiries at this stage.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


133 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa The Vanishing Left


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Johannesburg - Next month, the South African Communist Party celebrates 75 years of struggle for the socialist transformation of South Africa, as the oldest communist party on the continent. But this week, comrades were asking what had happened to the socialist agenda.

Unease in party ranks over the direction the economy is taking was ratcheted up by the SACP Central Committee's support for the objective of the macro- economic framework announced by government last week -- a package that also had business applauding.

"Comrades are uncomfortable," said a source. "With the documents inhaled by business as it was, there must be something wrong for the SACP to have reacted as it did." 

In its statement, the Central Committee said it "fully backed" the objectives of the package, noting it was designed as a vehicle to achieve Reconstruction and Development Programme goals, that the role of the public sector would be expanded and the labour market would be regulated, rather than left to market forces.

But the policy has been criticised by left-wing economists for giving business most of the benefits and relying on the private sector to turn them into growth, job creation and wealth redistribution. It has been compared with the normative economic model unveiled by the National Party in the last days of its rule -- which focused on export-led growth, fiscal conservatism and tight economic policy.

In some quarters of the SACP, the framework's commitment to increased social spending and other aspects are seen as mere sops to the working class.

African National Congress MP and party official Phillip Dexter dismissed suggestions the party was backing a right turn by government, saying the new economic paradigm was forged during negotiations in 1994.

"We're not saying there are not weaknesses in the framework -- but it's unfair to say government has adopted a Thatcherite vision," said Dexter.

The reliance on foreign and domestic private sector investment -- without any suggestion of how this would be levered -- was of personal concern to him, Dexter said. "But that's not to say the document failed miserably."

The party's only rider in its response to the framework was to say it intended "taking forward discussion, elaboration and debate" on the strategy and that "questions of detail and implementation require ongoing scrutiny".

Party sources said this week the SACP and its alliance partner, Cosatu, had been consulted "very late" over the package. There were suggestions political pressure had been applied and that the party had buckled to it -- as it needed the ANC more as an alliance partner than the ANC needed it. Why else, asked one, would the party be "running cover" for the government.

SACP deputy secretary general Jeremy Cronin said consultation was late, "but thorough". The government's argument that the area had been bedevilled by speculation and so had to be kept under wraps had been appreciated, he said. "We are not just running cover for the ANC and government. We have been calling for the past two years for a clear macro-economic framework and for government to take the lead. This has been done."

The "crunch issue" was that the framework opted for a very tight budget restructuring to reduce the deficit by 1% in one year, Cronin said. "We're not sure this is the right route.

"There are good arguments for reducing the deficit -- it creates breathing space and the country won't be pushed into a debt trap -- but it's founded on the hope that business will come to the ball. Our concern and scepticism centre on this."

A clear framework meant that within a year or two there could be an assessment of what should have happened but hadn't. Cronin denied any political pressure had been applied on the party to temper its response. "There were honest discussions within the alliance about the framework and the reasons for it. Wisdom informed us that a certain degree of support is important. There were no pressures on us, and they would not work."

However, there had been a call "for a level-headed appreciation for what government is trying to do".

He conceded the left's failure to come up with an alternative model -- Cosatu's social equity document does not address macro- economic policy -- reflected weaknesses, such as a lack of technical capacity.

Unease in party ranks was more a problem for the ANC-led government. "The critical thing is to open the debate and discuss hard choices and prevent the tendency of bureaucrats to do things quietly in the dark."

A meeting of the Central Committee in two weeks' time could see sparks. "Labour and the broad left within the party are going to be very critical," said a source.

"But a key question is whether we as a working class movement have been able to create pressure for these issues to be engaged from a working class point of view. We must all take responsibility for that."


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa 'Peace' Is The New Campaign Buzzword


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Ann Eveleth


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Johannesburg - Peace has become the buzzword on KwaZulu-Natal's campaign trails as more than 14 political parties and a host of independent candidates and ratepayers' bodies mark the final countdown to Wednesday's polls.

Senior political leaders, national ministers and several provincial premiers have descended on the province in recent weeks hoping to bolster their parties' showing among the province's 3,5- million registered voters.

Major provincial parties ranked peace at the top of their election biddings, amid signs that the recent African National Congress-Inkatha Freedom Party peace effort has taken the steam out of the third- ranked National Party's strategy to portray itself as the peaceful alternative to two warring African parties. 

Blue posters bearing NP leader FW de Klerk's "NP for Peace" message lost their impact when ANC President Nelson Mandela, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki and IFP leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi declared the 13-year civil war "over" at weekend rallies around the province.

While national politicians competed broadly for the kudos of the recent peace pact and pumped national issues at traditional rallies and public meetings, the diverse political styles of the parties emerged from the campaigns waged by their provincial and local counterparts.

In the penultimate campaign weekend, the IFP airdropped hundreds of thousands of party pamphlets over "no-go" areas.

The ANC concentrated its energies on a revival of its once- powerful mobilisation tool: the street meeting. Addressing dozens of small neighbourhood gatherings in "minority" areas, party candidates reminded voters of their recent civic campaign successes.

The NP had a quiet weekend, with its campaign set for take-off only this week, but grabbed local headlines by plastering trees along the main highway into Indian-dominated Chatsworth with stark red posters promising to "Hang the killers, hang the rapists".

The campaigns of two of the smaller parties -- the Democratic Party and Pan Africanist Congress -- juxtaposed their distant philosophies in classic style: while PAC candidates armed with megaphones drove postered bakkies around the crowded Warick Triangle African market area, a dozen DP supporters waged a telephone campaign from a small office in central Durban.

Minority Front leader Amichand Rajbansi augmented his public meeting campaign with a strategic poster drive: three faces of the "Bengal Tiger" mark the centre of one overpass on the N3 into Durban between alternate rows of ANC and IFP posters symbolising the MF leader's "neutral" self-portrait.

If posters were the sole determinant of election results, the ANC and MF would have a clear lead in the powerful Durban metropolitan area. The poll is, however, about far more than posters.

Haunted by claims of 1994 electoral fraud, suffering under a divided and lethargic provincial government, and seriously flirting with a full-scale ceasefire, KwaZulu-Natal's second post- apartheid poll is set to define the balance of power more precisely than ever before.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

135 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa On The Campaign Trail With The IFP


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 1960 words


 

Johannesburg - There are a number of things about Philip Powell that confirm the media's representation of him as a warlord senator. He is fond of wearing olive-green military trousers and a baseball cap with the logo of Inkatha's paramilitary protection units above the peak.

His turbo-charged bakkie echoes a scene from Somalia as it speeds through a burnt-out part of a township in the Natal Midlands with men in the back carrying shotguns and automatic rifles. He calls David Ntombela, a dreaded Inkatha strongman, his spiritual father. And in his book case at home in Howick, there is a book entitled How to Make War.

So it comes as a relief when this amiable and articulate man opens a trunk in the van -- which African National Congress people will swear to you is frequently packed with M-26 hand grenades -- to reveal camping equipment and boxes of canned food. 

These, he says, are more useful than guns when you are on an election trail, trying to build the grassroots structures of a political party.

Powell describes himself as an Inkatha Freedom Party populist, forced in the turbulent wars of the 1980s and early 1990s to dirty his hands in paramilitary work, but now dedicated to what he calls the democratisation of the party.

There is some evidence, at least in Powell's case, to back the claim.

He has attended 36 election rallies, some in the most remote areas of the province, in the past four weeks. And he has delivered the same speech at most of them.

It is based on the cliche of a cake that will be divided up in next week's local government elections. But it draws skilfully on the culture and the material conditions of the rural people who inhabit his power base in the Midlands of KwaZulu- Natal.

White people have grown fat on the cake, he tells a rally to launch a new branch at Mahobeni village in the Vulindlela district, and they don't want to give it up. Coloureds and Indians got a few small slices in the apartheid era. ANC people in the townships got some of the crumbs --and they don't really want to share them. The poor rural communities, whose mothers still cut wood in the forest and whose sisters collect water from the river in buckets, still have nothing.

"Where are the schools and the clinics and the roads that the ANC has promised? Where is the electricity and the taps? ... You must elect people who will fight for the cake. You must elect people who, when the fat white man doesn't want to give it up, will not lie down and say 'Ja Baas'," he tells the applauding crowd.

"Most of all you must not elect someone who will eat the cake. You do not want to see the person you vote for next year driving around in a big car with a wife who washes her dishes under a tap while you are still walking to river to fetch water."

The speech is littered with irony -- and licence. It ignores the fact that Ntombela, chairman of this Inkatha district and provincial parliamentarian, drove to this very meeting in a white Mercedes, and that Mrs Ntombela washes dishes under hot running water while most wives in her village carry buckets on their heads.

And Powell forgets to mention that it is the IFP government in the province that is responsible for building schools and roads.

But his imagery strikes a chord in the poorest of the province's poor. His ability to tune into his constituency's culture is demonstrated by the ripple of laughter that runs through the men's ranks when he ends by shouting: "And most of all, comrades, you must remember that this election is all about ... the keke!"

His last word is a play on Zulu slang for what can be seen as the sweetest part of a woman's body.

After the rally, Powell is in a more serious mood. He insists that to understand Inkatha and its "old militarism" it is necessary to understand both the culture and the wretched material conditions of its class base in the 1980s -- the rural peasantry and the urban impoverished urban strata who live in the province's impoverished villages and shantytowns.

Shacklords and warlords emerged in these areas as a reaction to the attacks carried out in the 1980s by ANC youth on older people and chiefs in defiance of Zulu culture's veneration of authority -- and militaristic forms of punishment.

The chiefs and their supporters mobilised in the best way they knew: by calling their indunas and forming amabutho to discipline the boys who had initiated what "to the chiefs was almost a pogrom against them".

In the 1960s and 1970s, says Powell, Inkatha was a movement led by the "amakholwa", a mission-trained Zulu elite made up of genteel men like Ben Ngubane, Frank Mdlalose, Oscar Dhlomo and Sibusiso Bhengu.

In the 1980s, because it was the only organisation sympathetic to plight of the traditional chiefs, Inkatha's power base shifted. Warlords like Ntombela emerged as a "spontaneous" bulwark against an ANC- inspired rejection of the values that Zulu elders stood for. The militaristic mood and tactics of the movement's new rank- and-file spread from below, rather than from the movement's leadership, he maintains.

Powell is adamant that the IFP is now moving into what he calls its third "institutional phase", forgoing armed methods in favour of building an efficient electoral machinery and democratic party structures. The party, pushed by its chief strategist Ziba Jiyane, is exhausted by war. It now wants to concentrate on mobilising its natural constituency, the urban and rural poor, by exploiting the ANC's failure to deliver on the Reconstruction and Development Programme. And this is best achieved, he points out, by civil methods of organisation.

"I don't like to use military metaphors," says Powell (although they still come naturally to him). "But we see these local government elections as a live firing exercise for the big one in 1999." If this is true -- and the analysis is presented with sophistication and apparent sincerity -- then it can only mean good for those parts of the province reduced to near-ruin by warlordism and violence.

But there are aspects of the senator's past that make this sound rather strange. In the 1980s, Powell worked in the D Section of police intelligence, where he did a masters thesis on the tactics of the mass democratic movement in the Eastern Cape. He won't admit this, but it is likely his work fed into the clandestine project used by the police against the ANC in the region at that time.

Then there is his "father-son" relationship with Ntombela, a man whose hands are deeply steeped in the blood of the province's conflict. "Ntombela came to see me when I was in hospital after being wounded in a shoot-out in 1992," says Powell. "I heard him tell my father, who was still alive at the time, in Zulu, that he would have to share being my father. Since then he has been my deepest source of inspiration."

Yet Father Tim Smith, a Roman Catholic priest who was hounded out of Ntombela's Elandskop stronghold, says Ntombela murdered his own brother after an argument, in front of witnesses, on Christmas Day 1984.

Ntombela's impis, probably assisted by trainees from Inkatha's notorious Caprivi unit, led an attack by thousands of Inkatha warriors on ANC-held sections of the Edendale valley in March 1990. They killed about 50 people and caused some 14 000 to flee. The warlord's apparent immunity from prosecution at the time led him once to say of a witness, in front of a magistrate, "What does that man want here? I can shoot him even here in court."

Eugene de Kock, the police colonel who has promised to give evidence in a number of "third force" trials, says he personally delivered truckloads of automatic rifles, ammunition and hand grenades to Powell when the Inkatha activist was in charge of training the IFP's self protection units (SPUs) at a camp near the Umfolozi Game Reserve in 1994.

Powell says he cannot comment on De Kock's charges because he will possibly be involved in a criminal trial over the matter. But he insists the SPUs were set up to defend against attacks from the ANC's self-defence units, that no weapons were issued during the training he supervised, and that police authorities were fully informed about the activities in his training camp.

The latest peace agreement between warlords on both sides, he says, "comes from the people who are directly involved in the violence and that's why it's more important than anything else in ensuring that the peace holds". The fighters are tired of fighting, he says.

There are signs that Powell is personally tired of the warlord senator role -- or of being perceived in that way. His wife, the daughter of parents who were classified coloured in the apartheid period, is pregnant with their first child. And the senator is clearly concerned, if only for their sake, that he should "stay out of the clutches of the like of (Police Minister) Sydney Mufamadi."

"I suppose I'm enough of a student of Leninism," he says in response to questions about his martial image, "to know that different stages of struggle call for a different political strategies. We have now realised it to would be futile for us to challenge the ANC in any other way than institutionally. We have committed ourselves to an institutional struggle and will persevere however hard it is for us."

Maybe one day, while he was on the road to one of the province's many war zones, Philip Powell did undergo a genuine conversion. If that means there is a genuine effort to implement his articulate notion of a new "phase of institutional politics", it may just be the senator will have to keep baked beans instead of bullets in the back of his bakkie for good.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa A Twinkle Of Humour In A Most Serious Trial


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 21, 1996 by Stefaans Brummer


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Johannesburg - It started in February last year as South Africa's first "third force" trial, austere in emotion and staggering in consequence. But this week, with 16 months of legal battle drawing to a close, Pretoria Supreme Court Judge Willem van der Merwe allowed the courtroom an occasional moment of light relief.

Gone were the charged opening scenes when an incredulous South Africa followed the participants' every utterance; when Eugene de Kock's former Vlakplaas subordinates packed the public gallery in a show of support; when De Kock himself may still have hoped against hope that there was a way out. 

Now many of De Kock's own men have testified against their former commander. De Kock himelf has admitted, in another trial where he testified for the prosecution, that it was "accurate" to describe him as "South Africa's most effective assassin" and that he expected a lengthy sentence.

De Kock seemed relaxed on Wednesday as the trial resumed for final argument, sometimes taking notes, sometimes watching impassively, a pen in his mouth, as prosecutor Anton Ackerman argued. After the day's proceedings he chatted warmly with wild- bearded Dougie Holtzhausen, one of the men who had turned against him. Holtzhausen was the only member of the Vlakplaas gang to have followed the entire day's proceedings.

But Judge Van der Merwe stole the show, often engaging in lengthy dialogue with Ackerman, expounding philosophically on the difference between "your truth, my truth and the truth" -- and asking a member of the attorney general's office to "stamp on" his cellphone when its ringing interrupted proceedings.

When Ackerman referred to Holtzhausen's testimony, the judge cautioned: "You must be careful that he (Holtzhausen) does not throw stones at you from the back."

But it was on the subject of state witness Chappes Klopper -- whom the defence had tried to discredit with stories of prostitutes, drugs, gold chains and more -- that Judge Van der Merwe had the most to say. "If you look at what the (other) state witnesses said, it looks like he missed Sunday school reasonably often."

But a judge remains a judge, and that means extraneous factors shouldn't cloud judgment. Said Judge Van der Merwe of Klopper: "He is not the type of character that I would want to stroll with on a Sunday afternoon in a park, but that doesn't mean I should reject his evidence."


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

June, 1996


(DOCUMENT) US Groups Plan March and Vigil Against Dictatorship in Zaire


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 24, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Washington, DC - The following announcement was released by a coalition of groups interested in Zaire.

The All North America Conference on Zaire, the Committee of the Democratic Forces of Zaire, and the Zaire Educational Council announce a MARCH and MATANGA, an all-night vigil, organized to hasten the end of one of the most ruthless dictatorships left on earth. The march will (1) commemorate countless martyrs who died in the struggle against dictatorship; (2) call for increased resources, monitoring and enforcement personnel for free and fair elections in July 1997; (3) protest against the support accorded by the Republican Right, the Clinton Administration and the Republic of France for the illegal government of Mobutu and Kengo wa Dondo; (4) and will remind the American people, whose money was used to build dictatorship in Zaire, that Mobutu is still to be brought to justice for perpetrating genocide in Rwanda, Burundi, Angola, and Zaire.

Leaders of the movement to end dictatorship in Zaire will arrive in the Washington Metropolitan Area during the week of June 24th 1996 to attend this historic event. Activities will take place in Lafayette Park (in front of the White House), Washington, D.C. on June 30th, 1996 and July 1st, 1996 beginning at 12:00 Noon.

Other Sponsors include Zaire Network, Alumni of the American School of Kinshasa, The International Association for Zaire, The Zaire Community of Iowa, The Zaire Community of Minnesota, Zairian Community Charlotte (North Carolina), La Mutualite Zairoise de Philadelphie, Concerned American Citizens, Immigrants, and Exiles of Zairian Origin, Forum Zairois, The Zairian Community of Lexington, Kentucky.

For further information please contact Dr. Alafuele Kalala, (301) 460-1533; Dr. Mwana N. Mawampanga, (606) 269-2714; or Tshimanga John Metzel (202) 783-2777.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Olympics Nigeria Ends Pre-Olympic Trials


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 23, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria -


The 1996 Nigeria track and field events to choose the country's athletes for the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, the United States, ended Saturday in Lagos. Some 20,000 spectators watched the finals at the National Stadium in Sururele, a Lagos neighbourhood, with the 100 metre race for men and women as major highlights. African track queen Mary Onyali-Omagbemi beat all comers in the women's 100-metre race, finishing in 10.67 seconds. She also won gold in the women's 200-metre race. Davidson Ezinwa, nother United States-based sprinter, won the men's 100-metre dash with a time of 9.86 seconds. But the times are subject to confirmation because officials said they were manually recorded. Two of Nigeria's four athletes, Chioma Ajunwa and Clement Chukwu, made impressive comeback after serving their four-year ban by the International Athletics Federation. Chioma came second behind Onyali-Omagemi in the 100-metre women's race and picked up the gold in the long jump. Chukwu, on the other hand, placed third in the 400 metres behind policeman Sunday Bada and Jude Monye who placed first and second in the explosive race. Two other returnees Charity Okpara and Innocent Asonze were not as lucky. -0United States and Africa


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
