Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 21, 1996 by Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Dakar, Senegal - The plight of Africa's deprived children, commemorated June 16 as the Day of the African Child, was of interest to the Ethiopian Herald daily newspaper, published in Addis Ababa.

It said that observing children's rights, such as theirs to education, was "an important component" of the convention on the Rights of the African child.

It noted that many events of national or international days of significance were observed in Africa.

"There has never been lack of vowing for commitments by governments to meet the objectives of alleviating this or that festering social and political problem," it said. 

But it continued, "Not much of the resolutions or commitments aspiring for lofty ideals are taken heed of after (they are) marked. That is, statements of the resolutions often appear overambitious and sometimes even impractical."

So, it said, "genuine and purposeful activities, no matter how small the magnitude may be, are more helpful than repetitions of verbal commitments and declarations for achieving overambitious objectives."

Dakar's Sud Quotidien, a Senegalese daily, commented on the effort by Tanzania's first president, Julius Nyerere, to call a meeting aimed at bringing political stability to Burundi.

The meeting took place with many members of the main politcal parties but without Hutu militants.

It noted that Burundi Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo, who did not take part in the conference but who met later with Nyerere, never reprimanded his army for any troubles in the country.

So it wondered rhetorically, "How can citizens have confidence in their army if it fails to be representative of all sectors of the country?"

Then, the paper turned to the bid by the United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to seek a second term this year.

It noted that the Egyptian diplomat was being reproached by the United States for "having failed in Somalia and for lacking firmness on certain issues." It said, also, that the United States was encouraging female candidates "even though these people have not yet declared their candidacy.

"Boutros-Ghali must be aware that the battle is lost, despite the yet undeclared support of some western countries."

It wondered whether France would support him to the extent of alienating the United States.

"Nothing is less certain," it said. "And yet, France should be at the forefront of the countries supporting Boutros-Ghali among which many African and Francophones do."

If support is not forthcoming, it said, this would "very likely expose the injustice in the method" of chosing leaders of international institutions.

"One of the principles of democracy consists in respecting the viewpoint of the majority. Within the U.N. the continued existence of the veto, which no longer corresponds to no political necessity, limits and even stiffles the expression of the majority's right," it said.

"The election will be so controversial that, as with that for the NATO secretary-general where the White House had its own preferences, a third candidate is likely to win the seat," it said.

"Whether or not Boutros-Ghali is re-elected...the real issue is that, this election is going to be so controversial that the revision of the texts governing the institution will be inevitable, despite the American veto," it said.

Most Mauritanian newspapers published stories on the arrival of Israeli's first diplomat to Mauritania, who landed in Nouakchott June 10.

One of that city's daily newspapers, Le Calame, said that the dipolmat's arrival was evidence that extensive Spanish mediation between Noakchott and Tel Aviv was finally taking effect.

"These relations are perhaps deeply ingrained in a broader strategy that brings together several partners (in their effort) to avoid future sources of conflict and, mainly, to circumvent the (militant) Islamic threat." it said.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Zimbabwe Mugabe Says His Party's Organs Are In Shambles


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Harare, Zimbabwe - President Robert Mugabe Friday said that the organs of his ruling Zimbabwe African National Union Patriotic Front (ZANU PF) were in shambles.

As a result, he told a meeting of the ZANU PF central committee here, the party's ordinary members were not participating in its decision making. 

Mugabe, whose party won all but three of the 150 seats in last year's parliamentary elections, regretted that the organisational restructuring has not been completed.

However, the party's process of selecting candidates for constituencies left behind a lot of acrimony and accusations that some unfit candidates had been imposed on the people.

The Zimbabwean leader, who has been in power since 1980, also overwhelmingly won the presidential elections held earlier on, after his opposition challengers withdrew, claiming that the electoral law was not transparent.

He warned that the party should wake up to the truth, lest one day it would be overwhelmed by the truth, saying 1996 could not be allowed to pass without implementation of the restructuring exercise.

"The people massively support us, but our party organs for them are in shambles. Can we this day pledge ourselves to accomplish the party re-organisational task in 1996,?" asked Mugabe.

In light of the good agricultural season, Mugabe said the party also had a duty to protect communal farmers from unscrupulous businessmen out to exploit them by offering them cash for their produce at far less than officially declared prices.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambia's Ruling Party Sets Conditions for Interparty Talks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 21, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka, Zambia - Zambia's ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) of President Frederick Chiluba has said that it will meet opposition political parties for reconciliatory talks only if they publicly renounce violence and stop campaigning for international sanctions against the government.

The conditions were announced Thursday by MMD national chairman Sikota Wina in the capital, Lusaka, in the wake of renewed calls by the opposition parties for resumption of the aborted interparty talks.

The ruling party in May snubbed scheduled interparty consultations intended to ease rising tension over the government's disputed constitutional amendments and preparations for this year's presidential and parliamentary elections. 

Chiluba has since assented to the controversial constitution which bars former president Kenneth Kaunda from contesting the presidency. It says only Zambian-born citizens with both parents also born in Zambia qualify for the presidency. Kaunda had Malawian parents.

Opposition parties have condemned the new law as discriminatory and undemocratic. They have accused the ruling party of enacting the law out fear for Kaunda as an individual.

They are also protesting what they call "haphazard" arrangements for the elections which they claim the MMD wants to rig.

The MMD government in 1995 engaged a private Israeli firm, Nikuv Computers, to update the national voters register, ahead of the elections. The opposition have charged that Nikuv is an arm of Mossad, the Israeli intelligence organization, and that it has been contracted to rig the polls in favour of the ruling party.

Wina said Thursday that all parties needed to agree to an electoral code of conduct by pledging to cooperate with the country's electoral commission.

The opposition have launched an international campaign for sanctions against Zambia. They also want the Chiluba government ostricized by the international community until it agrees to a universally accepted electoral process for the forthcoming polls.

The United States-based National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, which had been assisting in the country's democratisation process, announced this week that it was withdrawing its support.

It said in a statement that it was not satisfied that there would be free and fair elections following the limitation of choice of leadership by the voters. It was referring to the ban on "non-indigenous Zambians" from contesting the presidency.

Chiluba has vowed he will not go back on the constitution which he says reflects the "will of the Zambian people."

His government is under pressure from, among others, donors, civil society organisations, and the churches to nullify the new constitution.

A clandestine terrorist group calling itself 'Black Mamba" has since launched an anti-constitution bombing campaign in which one policeman has so far been killed.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


142 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Man Claims He Bought Chiluba's "Fake" Birth Certificate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 21, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Lusaka, Zambia - Bondo Lusato, a man engaged by the opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) to investigate President Frederick Chiluba's birth origin, claimed in Friday that he bought a "fake" birthday certificate in Zaire to show that the president was born there.

Lusato told a press conference in Lusaka that he, with his friend John Simusoko, had conspired with medical officials at Chibambo Mission in Zaire to produce a new birth certificate to show that Chiluba was born in Zaire.

Lusato said that after failing to come up with evidence to prove that Chiluba was born in Zaire, they decided to buy a fake certificate which was later given to UNIP. 

One's birth place has become critical for Zambians aspiring to become president. This is as a result of a recent constitutional amendment which bars citizens with foreign-born parents from constesting the highest office in the land.

Zambia is due to hold presidential elections in 1996 in which former President Kenneth Kaunda was pitted to run against the incumbent, President Chiluba. Kaunda, who had Malawian parents, has been disqualified by the new law.

Lusato claimed that UNIP, led by Kaunda, paid the two men 3,000 U.S. dollars in December 1995 to go to Zaire and fake information on the birth of President Chiluba.

Lusato, who produced the fake certificate to reporters, charged that the privately-owned Zambian newspaper, the Post, had provided two video cameras to him and one of its reporters when he travelled to Zaire.

When asked by reporters if he knew the seriousness of the offence he had committed, Lusato said he was aware and had already told the police about the case.

"I know that what I did was wrong and I am asking for forgiveness from all Zambians and in particular the president and his relatives. My mind that time was corrupted," he said, adding he no longer wanted to be investigator for the Post or UNIP.

Lusato, who announced that he has now rejoined the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) of President Chiluba, said that he had not yet approached the president to seek his forgiveness and that he will do so through the press.

Local reporters led by Richard Sakala, the special press assistant to President Chiluba, were in 1995 taken to Zaire to verify reports carried by the Post, that Chiluba was born there. The newspaper is currently facing charges after State House sued over the article written in 1995 alleging that Chiluba was born in Zaire.

The Post carried an article Monday which claimed that Lusato, one of their witnesses in the on-going court trial, had been bought by State House for 200 million kwacha (about 200,000 U.S. dollars) to work out a "credible denuciation" of everything published by the newspaper.

According to local reports Friday the opposition Zambia Democratic Congress said it has instructed its lawyers to petition the courts about Chiluba and Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda's citizen status in the light of the new constitutional amendments enacted.

The congress charged Thursday that it had sufficient information and evidence from its investigators in the United States, Belgium, Zaire and Zambia to the effect that Chiluba's parents were born and came from Zaire and had later migrated to Luapula and settled in Musangu village, northern Zambia.

The congress also claims that Miyanda's father came from Angola via Mozambique to eastern Zambia where he married a local woman there.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


143 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Botswana and Zimbabwe Zimbabwe Says Botswana Arms Procurement No Threat


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 21, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Harare, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe Defence Minister Moven Mahachi said Friday his country was not threatened by the huge arms procurement made recently by neighbouring Botswana.

"We don't feel threatened. We have an excellent relationship with Botswana," he said.

Botswana recent bought German-designed Leopard tanks and North American fighter bombers worth one billion zimdollars (100 million U.S. dollars). The purchase has baffled western diplomats and political analysts, with some suggesting the buy could trigger an arms race in the region.

However, Mahachi told the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency, or ZIANA, that Zimbabwe was satisfied Botswana was buying the arms for self-defence.

"Botswana is a very friendly country. We don't want to interfere if our neighbors buy large arms. We have no legitimate right to ask them," he said.

Botswana is reportedly expanding its army from 7,000 to 10 000 troops and officials were quoted in press reports as saying the build-up was part of a long term plan to beef up its deterrence capability.

With the end of apartheid in South Africa it is unclear who Botwsana's potential enemy might be. However, one radio report has said recently that Botswana wanted to improve its capability to take part in peace-keeping operations.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Swaziland Swazi Civil Servants To Join Teachers Strike


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 21, 1996 by Tom Holloway, PANA Corrrespondent


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Mbabane, Swaziland - Swaziland's civil servants resolved Thursday to join a strike by the country's teachers which began June 14 to force the government to an 18 percent salary increase for civil servants and teachers.

The civil servants had given the government one week from June 14 to reconsider what it said was its final offer of a 9.9 percent salary increase plus housing allowance increases amounting to a total increase of 13.7 percent.

Swaziland's acting prime minister, Sishayi Nxumalo, said Tuesday that the government was unable to budge from the maximum increases offered to teachers and civil servants which total 91 million rand (about 21 million U.S. dollars). 

He said if government were to give the 18 percent demanded it would cost another 52 million rand (12 million dollars) which, he added, the government just has not got.

Successive finance ministers have warned of the dangers facing the government due to the growth rate of the civil service and shrinking financial resources to pay the increasing salary bills and pensions.

In a statement Thursday reacting to the refusal of the teachers and civil servants leaders, Finance Minister Derek Von Wissell warned "if the government is forced to pay the 18 percent demand when the state of the country's economy is so sensitive there was a real possibility of the International Monetary Fund imposing structural adjustment measures on Swaziland."

He said if this were to happen it would result in thousands of Swazis being retrenched and important development projects having to be abandoned.

However, the strike resolution taken at Thursday's Civil Servants Association meeting in Manzini is being challenged by the government and by civil servants who attended the meeting as unconstitutional and illegal.

That it "could be considered unconstitutional" was admitted to PANA Thursday by the association's secretary-general, Fortunate Zwane.

She said the association had some 27,000 registered members but Thursday's meeting was attended by an estimated 2,000 people.

Zwane said she did not know if all were association members as the meeting was open to the public and no cards had to be shown.

"I agree there was no quorum," she said.


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


145 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Nigerian Police Interrogate Abiola Family


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 14, 1996 by Paul Ejime , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 851 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - At least four other family members of detained Nigerian politician Moshood Abiola have been interrogated in connection with the June 4 murder of his wife, Kudirat, family sources said in Lagos Friday.

Those arrested Thursday were Abiola's younger brother Mubashiru and three members of his extended family, the sources said. 

Abiola's eldest son, Kola, arrested Tuesday, is still with the police.

The Nigerian police are not giving out much information on the arrests, to avoid jeopardising investigations.

There were indications that the international police could be involved to help unravel the murder.

Kudirat, 44, was shot dead by unidentified gunmen, while driving in Lagos.

She was an outspoken supporter of her husband, Abiola, the presumed winner of the June 1993 presidential election, annulled by the military regime that ruled Nigeria then.

Abiola is awaiting trial for treasonable felony after he declared himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

Before her death, Kudirat and Kola were involved in a family feud over Abiola's legal representation.

Kola wanted his father's original defence lawyer changed because of what he called lack of progress in the case, but Kuridat resisted the move.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


146 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Opposition Pirate Radio Now Heard in Nigeria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 14, 1996 by Paul Ejime , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian authorities have not yet officially reacted to the setting up of a pirate radion station that has been broadcasting opposition propaganda intermittently on Nigerian airwaves since Wednesday.

Wednesday was the third anniversary of the 12 June 1993 presidential election annulled by the country's last military regime. 

It is unclear if the station, calling itself Radio Democratic International Nigeria, is operating from within or outside the country. Its short wave signals are, however, being received in several Nigerian cities. These include Lagos and Abuja, the nation's capital.

Playing Nigeria's discarded national anthem and tunes by Afro-beat musician, Fela Anikulapo-Kuti, the station kicked off with an anti-government broadcast by Anthony Enahoro, self-exiled leader of the National Democratic Coalition.

On Thursday it aired an interview with another self-exiled Nigerian 1986 nobel literature laureate, Wole Soyinka, critical of the military regime.

Soyinka, who fled Nigeria in November 1994, described detained politician Moshood Abiola, the undeclared winner of the annulled 1993 presidential election, as the "embodiment of people's will."

The pirate station said it would soon announce its full programming for broadcasts in Nigeria's three major languages -- Hausa, Igbo and Yoruba.

A spokesman of the Nigerian Broadcasting Commission said the commission would issue a statement on the "illegal" station.

Similar transmission by another pirate station calling itself Radio Freedom Frequency, hit the Nigerian airwaves several times last year.

The broadcasting commission dismissed it as illegal. Its operators have not been found.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

June, 1996


Rwanda Rwanda Genocide Suspect Arrested in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 200 words


 

KIGALI, Rwanda (PANA) - Rwandan announced Thursday the arrest of Karamira Frodonald, a key suspect in the country's 1994 genocide.

It said Ethiopian authorities arrested Frodonald in Addis Ababa after he tried to evade extradition to Rwanda. He was being ferried from India where he had been arrested and extradited.

Kigali said it was trying to obtain Frodonald's extradition from Ethiopia to Rwanda.

Frodonald, a prominent Kigali businessman turned politician, is accused of having led a branch of the Republican Democratic Movement. The Hutu ethnic grouping is said to have played a major role in the genocide in which some 500,000 people died.

He fled to India after the regime of the late president Juvenal Habyarimana was toppled by the predominantly Tutsi Rwanda Patriotic Front in July 1994.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambia Launches Election Newspaper


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia has launched a newspaper ahead of this year's elections to level the political playing field and help to educate voters.

The newspaper, a weekly, is funded by a consortium of donors. 

Launching the newspaper Friday, Zambian Information and Broadcasting Services Deputy Minister Valentine Kayope warned that sensational media coverage would destroy the foundation of the country's democracy.

The warning comes in anticipation of possible violence in the upcoming elections. He said it was imperative that campaigns should be peaceful.

This, he said, could only be achieved if the media remained professional.

The election newspaper, named The Monitor, is published by Zambia's Committee for a Clean Campaign.

It will cover all political events including campaigns during the run-up to the 1996 presidential and general elections scheduled for October. It will also act as a guide to political education for the electorate.

Kayope termed the newspaper's establishment timely and crucial to the transition period of the elections.

The committee's chairman, Ngande Mwanjiti, said the body had embarked on a difficult task of levelling the political playing field before the elections.

149 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Niger Niger Mends Fences With IMF


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 14, 1996 by Idimama Kotoudi , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 507 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - The 43 billion F CFA loan (about 860 million dollars) credit line which Niger recently obtained from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) marks the end of a long dispute between the West African country and the Bretton Woods institutions.

For six years, under pressure from trade unions and other political problems, the authorities in Niamey and the IMF were unable to reach any agreement on structural adjustment.

The two parties had in 1990 agreed on a framework program on economic policy. It, however, remained unimplemented because of the country's long national conference, which led to the introduction of multipartism. 

At the July 29 to November 3, 1991 conference in Niamey, the 1,200 delegates voted against implementation of the Structural Adjustment Program (SAP).

Things changed with the election of Mahamane Ousmane, a staunch advocate of SAP, as president in 1993.

His cabinet, headed by Prime Minister Mahamadou Issoufou, managed to conclude an agreement with the Bretton Woods institutions. The government was forced to shelve this agreement due to pressure from trade unions which went on an indefinite strike in 1994.

However, the two sides continued to maintain close contacts. In December 1995, Niamey wrote a new letter of intent to the financial institutions in Washington D.C..

At about the same time, changes in parliamentary seats downgraded the coalition of President Mahamane Ousmane to a minority, forcing him to name Hama Amadou, of the former ruling party, as prime minister.

Amadou's government concluded a three-year agreement with the IMF. But the program hardly got off the ground when the military seized power Jan. 27.

The militarymen promised to conclude negotiations with the IMF and the World Bank. To achieve this, they retained the experienced Almoustapha Soumaila as finance and planning minister.

The arrival of the Fund's deputy director-general, Alassane Drame Outtra, in Niamey on Thursday, was a clear indication that relations between the two sides had improved.

A day earlier, the IMF board signed the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility agreement, opening new credit lines for Niger.

The three-year agreement ends the financial embargo which Niger had to contend with for six years.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

June, 1996


Niger Niger Launches Election Campaign


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - Niger's military ruler, General Ibrahima Bare Mainassara, on Thursday night officially launched the country's presidential election campaign.

The move was a rebuttal of appeals from the Independent National Election Commission that the elections be postponed to July 27. 

The commission had asked for more time to sort out organisational problems, especially the compilation of the electoral roll.

In a nationwide radio and television broadcast Thursday night, Gen. Mainassara pledged to "keep the army out of the political game". He also called for a sense of national interest by urging "fellow citizens from all parties to bear in mind that they all belong to the same country".

Gen. Mainassara, leader of the military junta that seized power in January, is standing as an independent candidate against four others supported by their parties.

They are Tandja Mamadou of the National Movement for Development Society; Mahamane Ousmane, former head of state overthrown by Gen. Mainassara and a candidate of the Social and Democratic Convention; Mahamadou Issoufou of the Niger Party for Democracy and Socialism; and Mahamadou Issoufou, former prime minister in Mahamane Ousmane's government.

151 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Sub-Sahara Africa Lags Behind in Education


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 17, 1996 by Felix Njoku , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 560 words


 

AMMAN, Jordan (PANA) - Mired by a host of problems, most of sub-Sahara Africa is not making substantial progress in basic education and literacy, according to a report being discussed at the Consultative Forum on Education For All (EFA) which entered its second day Monday.

"Basic education is not progressing at the pace that will enable most countries to attain more than modest EFA targets by the end of the decade," the document says.

Haiti is the only country, outside Africa, in the same category of less performing countries in education and literacy. They are so categorised at a time when most countries of the world are making major breakthroughs in educating their peoples. 

The report cites such problems as drought, famine, internal conflicts, political instability debt and unfavourable terms of trade, among some of factors which have compromised EFA goals in Africa.

African countries were among 155 states which endorsed the goals at the 1990 World Education Summit in Jomtien, Thailand.

In that year some 37.3 million sub-Sahara African children were not in school. At the end of 1995, the number had risen to 39.3 million. Girls make up two-thirds of this number, according to the report issued by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. The agency is hosting the Amman forum along with the World Bank and other U.N. agencies including UNICEF, UNFPA and UNDP.

During the past five years, total primary school enrolment expanded by only 17 percent to 72.3 million pupils.

However, the results cites considerable progress in literacy, which rose from 40.2 percent in 1980 to 56.8 percent in 1995. Two-thirds of the region's male adults are literate, compared to less than half of adult females.

Since Jomtiem, more than half of the countries in sub-Sahara Africa, including some of the least developed, have been able to reverse the steep decline in basic education and literacy of the 1980s.

The report cites the case of Mozambique, which recently emerged from 16 years of war and has been able to increase primary school enrollment by 155,000 in the last five years. The country hopes to put some 1.6 million children in school by the end of the decade.

Benin, Burkina Faso, Guinea, Malawi, Namibia, Tanzania and Senegal are also among the countries which have made significant strides in the achievement of the world's education goals.

The report estimates that some 2.5 billion U.S. dollars would be required to provide universal primary education in the continent each year.

Sub-Sahara Africa alone pays more than 20 billion dollars annually in servicing and repayment of its 300 billion external debt.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


152 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Nigeria Issues Guidelines For Party Politics


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 17, 1996 by Paul Ejime , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 560 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The National Electoral Commission of Nigeria (NECON), unveiled Monday guidelines for the registration of political parties under the military government's transition to democracy program.

The commission's chairman, Sumner Dagogo-Jack, said political associations seeking registration must have at least 40,000 card-carrying members in each of Nigeria's 30 states and at least 15,000 members in Abuja, the nation's capital.

Nigeria has an estimated population of 100 million people. NECON said some 24 million Nigerians voted in the last local council elections in March. 

Dagogo-Jack told a news conference in Abuja Monday that his commission would not place any limitation on the number of persons that could belong to a political party.

However, he said "it is a strict condition for registration that membersip of a political association should, among others, exclude persons below the age of 18 years."

Other persons excluded from joining party politics are members of the armed forces, the police, security agents, para-military organs, members of the pubic service and traditional rulers.

To qualify for registration it is mandatory for a political association to have a manifesto containing the aims and objectives, as well as its principles.

The NECON chairman said associations seeking registration as political parties must submit the relevant application with "a short profile on who, when and where the idea of the association was conceived, its motive and its intellectual or philosophical background."

Registration forms are to be available from Wednesday.

Nigeria's chequered political history has involved some 25 years of military rule in its 36 years of independence.

The Second Republic of 1979-1983 was run on six registered political parties under the American-type executive presidential system cut short by the 1994 New Year's eve coup.

The aborted Third Republic, midwived by the last military regime of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, crashed ever before it took off under two political parties.

Politician Moshood Abiola, who claimed victory in the June 1993 presidential election annulled by Babangida, is in detention awaiting trial for treason after be proclaimed himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

But following the March council poll, new political associations have emerged. A re-alignment of forces by Nigerian politicians is also underway.

It is unclear how many of the associations will qualify under NECON's registration procedures.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Children Hold Parliamentary Session In Addis Ababa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 17, 1996 by Ghion Hagos , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 520 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Children in Addis Ababa Monday adopted a declaration calling on the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) to ensure the rights of all the continent's children to education.

The declaration was adopted at the end of a two-hour "Children's Parliament," convened as part of the activities marking this year's day of the African child, which was observed Sunday.

The document is to be forwarded to next month's OAU summit, to be held in Yaounde, Cameroon from July 8 to 10. 

The declaration urges OAU member states to ensure the survival and development of the African child, as stipulated in the U.N. convention on the rights of the child and the African charter on the rights and welfare of children.

The children's parliamentary session was organized to commemorate the "Day of the African Child", which was proclaimed by the OAU in memory of the 65 Soweto schoolchildren masacred June 16, 1976 by the South African apartheid regime's police.

The actual day fell Sunday, but the OAU requested that its observance be shifted to Monday, with events befitting this year's comemorative theme -- "Education for Peace and Development: Rights and Welfare of the Child."

Ethiopia's "Children's Parliament" was presided over by Dawit Yohannes, speaker of the federal assembly. He was assisted by two child co-speakers: Miss Kabaye Liku of Nazareth school in Addis Ababa, and Abenet Taye, a student from Dire Dawa in Eastern Ethiopia.

After an opening statement by the Ethiopian speaker, the children parliamentarians and the real ones debated the theme of the Day of the African Child.

The debate also covered the rights of children to education, and the children asked elder parliamentarians about war and peace, and what should be done to promote education and development in Africa.

Earlier, a "Children's Dialogue" session was held at Africa Hall at which officials from the Ethiopian government, the OAU and UNICEF responded to children's question on the day's theme.

Children from many other African countries, whose parents work for the OAU and other international organizations in the Ethiopian capital, also took part in the dialogue.

In a message issued Friday to mark the day, the OAU urged African governments to ensure that all children, and girls in particular, have access to high quality education.

June, 1996


Sudan Sudanese Demonstrates In Support Of Libya Children


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 17, 1996 by Yahya El Hassan , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 280 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - An estimated 10,000 Sudanese children marched through the streets of Khartoum Sunday in support of Libyan children affected by the United Nations air travel embargo imposed on Libya in the aftermath of the Lockerbie affair.

The children proceeded to the Libya "Brotherhood" office (Embassy) in Khartoum where they were addressed by the ambassador who said the sanctions against Libya were the doing of the "powers of arrogance and Zionism." 

Sanctions were imposed on Libya following accusations that it supported terrorists responsible for the crash of a Pan Am airliner over Lockerbie, Scotland. The airliner exploded in midair, killing all on board. The demonstrators handed memorandums condemning the sanctions against Libya and addressed to the United Nations, the Organisation of African unity, the Non-Alignment Movement, the Organisation of Islamic Conference and the Arab League to the general secretary of the Sudanese Council for International Friendship, Ahmed Abdulrahaman. Abdulrahman said it was unfortunate three of the Arab countries -- Sudan, Libya and Iraq -- were subject to the United Nations sanctions. He said Sudan will continue to stand by Libyan people until the U.N. sanctions are lifted. The memorandum pledged the Sudanese children's solidarity with those of Libya in the face of the sanctions, which has had a "tremendous effect on the bodies and souls of the Libyan children."

Africa News


June, 1996


Mozambique Mozambique Clears Over 50,000 Landmines


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 17, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - At least 50,203 landmines and other explosive devices have been cleared in Mozambique since the country's peace accord.

According to statistics from the National Demining Commission (CND), cited in Monday's issue of the daily paper, Noticias, 6,017 kilometres (3,730.54 miles) of road have been cleared. But the program is now facing financial problems, said the CND's executive director, Osorio Mateus.

The operation is being undertaken by the Mozambican government, in coordination with the United Nations and several Western NGOs, notably Norwegian Peoples Aid, and the British Halo Trust.

Mateus in the report complained that the Mozambican government has not yet released the necessary budget for the CND's full scale operations.

"We need to buy equipment for our work and we still don't have the money," he said. "This makes it difficult to establish CND regional delegations, or to set up a data bank to allow us to gather all the information needed."

Mateus added that the government has only released five billion meticais (about 445,000 US dollars) for the CND. The amount is not, however, enough for the work the directorate must do, Mateus said.

The CND is negotiating with the German government for the establishment of a data bank on mines in the country and a preliminary agreement has been reached, he said.

Mateus said that the United Nations is also looking for consultants to provide expertise to the CND.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Nine Crushed At Soccer Stadium in Lusaka


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 17, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 267 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Nine Zambian soccer fans were crushed to death Sunday and 52 others injured when they were trapped between a closed gate and a stampede of other spectators trying to leave Lusaka's Independence Stadium after a match.

Witnesses said the large crowd in one part of the 35,000-seater stadium surged toward the nearest exit gate but found it closed. Some of the victims fell down and were trampled.

This occurred at the end of an international World Cup preliminary qualifier match between Zambia and the visiting Sudanese national soccer team. Zambia won the game 3-0 to qualify for the next round.

Zambia Police Inspector-General Francis Ndhlovu denied the accident was caused by the "tight security" enforced at the match attended by President Frederick Chiluba.

Some witnessess suggested the police had deliberately left the gate closed after the match to allow the presidential motorcade quick exit through the stadium grounds. The motorcade left through a different gate.

It is the first such incident involving deaths of spectators at a soccer stadium in Zambia. Police blamed the incident on congestion at the stadium, which was filled to capacity.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Study Shows Pornography Influences Students' Sex


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 18, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 494 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A medical professor has disclosed that about 79 percent of the male and 46 percent of female students in Zambia are sexually active.

Prof. Alan Haworth told delegates Tuesday at the on-going sixth national aids conference in Lusaka that a study he conducted early this year found that 36 percent of "born-again-Christian" students and 34 percent of those who were not born-agains said they regularly had sex.

Presenting a paper on "Youth and HIV infection: What challenges face HIV/AIDS programmes", Haworth said the study, conducted in 17 learning institutions which included secondary schools and training institutions, found that pornographic films had influenced students sexual behaviour. 

The youths actively got involved in sex after watching pornographic films.

Haworth said that 80 percent of students who watched pornographic movies said they were sexually aroused after watching the films, while another 80 percent of the male and 73 percent the female students admitted that they watched pornography.

He said 80 percent of the male and 31 percent of the female "born-again Christians" said they were also sexually aroused by such films.

He said that pornographic films were bad in any society as they influenced the moral behaviour of children who later wanted to try what they watched.

Haworth blamed churches in the country which he said were in the forefront agitating against condoms.

While the church advocated for morality, Christians themselves were involved in sex which could spread HIV infection, he said.

He said about 50 different denominations in Zambia are very strong on their views of not allowing the use of condoms, which was dangerous to the nation.

According to the study, 25 percent of the students said they were engaged in oral sex, most of them after watching pornographic films.

Haworth said that over 50 percent of the male and 33 percent of the female respondents said they masturbated, while 34 percent born-again Christian students also admitted doing the same.

He said, however, contrary to what people say masturbation does not cause any physical or psychological harm to people.

June, 1996


Sports--Soccer Tempers Rise In Khartoum After Soccer Defeat in Lusaka


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 18, 1996 by Yahya el Hassan , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudanese newspapers have angrily reacted to the 3-0 the defeat of their country's national football team in the return World Cup qualifier match in Lusaka last Sunday.

The defeat has been hard to digest because the Sudanese team had defeated the high-performing Zambian side in Khartoum 2-0 a fortnight ago.

Sports critic Ahmed Mohammed El Hassan, writing in the government daily El Sudan El Hadeeth, on Tuesday rejected the allegation of biased refereeing "because after all the kicks, did not cancel a goal our players had netted". 

"If we accept it that the referee had hepled the Zambians with two fake scores, we should then ask the legitimate question: What did our talkative forwards to to change the result? How many goals did they score?," the critic asked.

Meanwhile all the Khartoum dailies also focused on the row over the ball used during the match.

The Government daily, El Engaz El Watani, said the secretary of the Sudanese Football Federation, Shams Eddin, had complained to the world soccer governing body, FIFA, that the ball was too small and did not carry the FIFA stamp as required.

The paper said the Confederation of African Football observer and the referee had objected to the ball the day before the match but the Zambian side failed to change it when the two teams went on the pitch.

A cartoonist ridiculed this claim by posing the question: How was the ball unsuitable? Was it drunk?".

The Khartoum papers wrote about the death of nine soccer fans and injury of 50 others in a stampede at the Lusaka stadium entrance at the end of the match.

"The Lusaka stadium tragedy is ranked second to the aircrash that claimed the lives of all members of the Zambian national team three years ago", wrote El Engaz El Watani.

159 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zimbabwe Foreign Investors Shed Zimbabwe Shares


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 18, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Nervous foreign investors are scrambling to off-load shares on the Zimbabwe stock market amid uncertainty about the future economic direction of the Southern African state.

Trading in the week to June 17 was mainly characterised by profit taking, with Delta Corporation, the largest quoted company, experiencing the heaviest loss.

Figures showed that in the fortnight to last Friday, Delta was the most actively traded share, with trade worth Zimdollars 39.4 million (3.9 million U.S. million dollars), representing 36.2 percent of total market trading of Zd 108.8 million (11 million U.S. million dollars). 

According to market analysts, foreign investors bought just five percent of the Delta shares and sold at least 52 percent.

"Share prices have come under attack during the past two to three weeks, which has caused both (industrial and mining) indices to fall from their recent record highs," the company Dataworld said.

The key industrial index was on June 17 quoted at 5,478.22, a fall of 2.8 percent from the record high of 5,637.2 set on May 27, while the mining index also fell from a high of 1,565.22 on May 2 to 1,431.3 last Friday.

According to Dataworld, mining shares were coming under pressure from the weak gold price, as well as the collapse of the copper price on June 14, following the shock announcement by the Japanese trading house, Sumitomo, that it faced a loss of 1.8 billion dollars due to unauthorised trading in copper by one of its dealers.

"The stock market can be expected to continue to drift downwards over the next few weeks as buyers continue to pull back while selling pressure increases in selected counters.

"The number of available bargains should increase as some sellers are bound to overreact in the absence of firm buyers," Dataworld said, but warned investors to be selective.

Meanwhile, the industrial index was on Tuesday quoted at 5 469.7, down 8.53 points from Monday, while the mining index also lost just over 30 points to end trading at 1,401.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Abacha Launches Human Rights Panel


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 18, 1996 by Paul Ejime , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, has inaugurated a 16-member National Human Rights Commission and renewed his administration's commitment to the protection of personal liberty and the rule of law.

Administering the oath to the commision's members in Abuja Monday, he said the recent amendment to two controversial decrees on detention of persons and removal of the armed forces personnel from the Civil Disobedience Tribunal, were clear demonstrations of this commitment.

Nigeria has been under international pressure over its troubled march to democracy and record in human rights. The pressure was intensified with the November 1995 executions for murder of nine Nigerian human rights minority leaders, among them author Ken Saro-Wiwa. 

Inaugurating the commission, Abacha promised that his administration would bequeath "a virile democratic polity, an orderly society and a responsible citizenry to present and future generations of Nigerians."

But he added that the rule of law and fundamental human rights hardly thrived in anarchy or disorder.

"I also seize the opportunity of this occasion to remind our people," he said, "that no absolute rights exist here or in any other human society (as) our rights are of necessity limited by those of other individuals and the larger needs of our society."

Part of the commission's briefs is to assist victims of human rights violations and seek appropriate redress and remedies on their behlaf.

It will also to undertake studies on all matters pertaining to human rights and assist the government in the formulation of appropriate policies on human rights issues for public enlightenment.

The commission will publish periodic reports on the state of human rights protection in Nigeria and organise local and international seminars, workshops and conferences on the subject.

It is expected to liaise with local and international organisations with the aim of advancing the promotion and protection of human rights in Nigeria.

The body is chaired by retired Supreme Court Judge Paul Nwokedi. Its members include journalists, lawyers, representatives of non-governmental organisations and government officials.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


161 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia U.S. Group Suspends Aid To Zambia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 18, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 560 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The United States-based National Democratic Institute for International Affairs said Tuesday it will suspend its election-support programs in Zambia effective June 30.

The agency's president, Kenneth Wollack, said in a statement from Washington D.C. that the measure is being taken because of the unstable political environment in Zambia. This situation, he said, could threaten parliamentary and presidential elections for 1996. 

He said that the organisation was unable to undertake programs to ensure open and fair elections when there was no dialogue among Zambia's major political players.

"Therefore, once our funding from the U.S. Agency for International Development expires June 30, NDI plans to suspend its election-support programs and withdraw its Lusaka-based staff," he said.

Wollack said that the institute was deeply concerned that the political environment leading to the elections threatened to undermine Zambia's status as a model of democratic change.

Since 1991, the institute has been helping Zambia consolidate its democratic institutions.

"Five years ago the citizens of Zambia made a historic turn in their call for multiparty democracy...actions that have curtailed electoral competition and participation, political discourse and freedom of expression raised serious questions for meaningful elections," he said.

The ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy of President Frederick Chiluba recently adopted constitutional amendments to bar former President Kenneth Kaunda from running for office.

Kaunda had Malawian parents. The amendments require that only Zambian-born citizens with both parents also born in the country, or were of Zambian descent, qualify to run for republican president.

The new law also bans traditional chiefs from participation in politics, unless they resign their traditional thrones. It also recognises Zambia as a Christian nation.

Chiluba had, earlier in 1996, taken the constitutional debate to his government-dominated parliament in defiance of widespread public demand that the constitution be adopted by a constituent assembly and referendum for wider consensus on the country's supreme law.

Western donor countries, including the United States and Britain, have told Chiluba to reverse the constitution or risk losing bilateral aid.

Zambian opposition parties have appealed to the donors and neighbouring Southern African states to impose sanctions on and ostracise Chiluba's government. They say this would force him to revoke the constitution which, they claim, is discriminatory and undemocratic.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambian Court Asked to Order Prosecutor to Appear


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 19, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1574 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Defence lawyers for eight detained United National Independence Party (UNIP) members facing treason charges Wednesday appealed to a Lusaka magistrate to order Zambia's Director of Public Prosecution (DPP) to appear before the court to explain why he had not processed their docket.

The eight, who include UNIP vice-president, senior chief Inyambo Yeta, are facing four counts of treason. This is in connection with the Black Mamba terrorist group that has launched a bombing campaign in the southern African country.

Principal resident magistrate Francis Nsokolo reserved ruling to Thursday. 

Nsokolo said he needed time to study submissions by both the defence and prosecution.

The accused are being represented by 16 lawyers.

One of the defence lawyers, Edward Shamwana, asked the court to order that the DPP appears in person to explain why he had not consented to his clients' docket so that trial could proceed.

Under Zambian law, the DPP needs to be satisfied about the merit of some of the more serious cases, including treason, before sanctioning prosecution.

Defence lawyer Sebesitain Zulu said he had himself approached the DPP on June 4 and asked him to get the docket from the police so that he could decide on the case before the accused appeared in court.

"It is quite clear that the police have not yet handed the docket to the DPP because they are still investigating," he said.

UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda later told a huge gathering of party supporters outside the courts that the current government of president Frederick Chiluba will put Zambia on fire.

"We are dealing with little political savages and frightened little men who will put this country on fire," Kaunda said.

He charged that the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) were afraid to confront UNIP on a clean political platform and that is why they have enacted an "apartheid" constitution.

The new constitution bars Kaunda, who had Malawian parents, from contesting the presidency later this year. Kaunda was Zambian president for 27 years before losing power to the MMD in 1991.

Kaunda said UNIP was not behind the Black Mamba and his members in detention were being prosecuted because they were UNIP supporters.
HEADLINE
Nigeria
Mediation for Nigerian University Teachers' Strike
(by
Panafrican News Agency
June 19, 1996
by Paul Ejime , PANA Staff Correspondent
(tx

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Committee of Vice-Chancellors of Nigerian universities were meeting Wednesday to try and resolve the deadlock between government and teachers striking for better service conditions and funding of higher education in the country.

This followed the expiry Wednesday of a government ultimatum for the teachers to resume work or face mass dismissal.

The Academic Staff Union of Universities (ASUU) in Nigeria went on strike April 9, accusing government of reneging on a pledge to review a 1992 accord with the union on better pay and funding of the country's 40 universities.

Following a breakdown of negotiations, the military government on May 16 banned ASUU. It accused the union of formenting trouble and disrupting academic work on the campuses.

The government also froze the striking teachers' pay and threatened to evict them from official housing.

It also said negotiations were to continue with individual universities.

Later, the National Universties Commission directed vice-chancellors to report progress in their individual universities on the directive to reopen them by Wednesday (June 19).

Some vice-chancellors opened registers for signing by teachers willing to end the strike. The teachers were to be paid their frozen salaries after signing. Those who chose to continue with the strike were told to count themselves fired.

There were also indications that government could formally shut the universities, should the strike persist.

But according to reports from several universities, the government directives have provoked mixed reactions with a number of teachers having reportedly signed the registers to protect their jobs.

However, ASUU national president Assisi Assobie in a statement Wednesday claimed that closing the institutions or sacking the teachers was not the solution. He said negotiation remains the answer.

A check at the University of Lagos and Lagos State University Wednesday showed that most teachers were not at work.

Some teachers seen on campus declined to comment, saying only their union could issue statements.

Observers fear that the latest crisis, similar to the protracted strike in 1993, could further jeopardise higher education in Nigeria, Africa's most populous country with an estimated 100 million people.
HEADLINE
Swaziland
Stalemate in Swazi Teachers' Strike
(by
Panafrican News Agency
June 18, 1996
by Tom Holloway , PANA Correspondent
(tx

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - A nationwide strike by teachers in Swaziland entered its third day Tuesday after negotiations between the government and leaders of the National Association of Teachers and the National Association of Civil Servants again failed to reach agreement over a salary dispute.

Acting Prime Minister Sishayi Nxumalo said Tuesday that government was unable to offer more than 9.8 percent salary increase and housing allowances totalling 91 million rand (almost 20 million U.S. dollars).

Nxumalo said if the government were to give the 18 percent demanded it would cost an additional 52 million rand (12 million U.S. dollars) for teachers and civil servants.

This, he said, would force the government to retrench large numbers of civil servants to avoid the expenditure on the civil service exceeding the maximum required by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) of 40 percent of the total budget. Expenditure above this would result in the IMF imposing harsh structural adjustment measures on Swaziland.

Nxumalo said the alternative would be for the government to abandon some important national development projects in order to use the funds to pay the teachers and civil servants their demands. Government, he added, would not do this.

Meanwhile, thousands of members of the Swaziland National Association of Students are expected to gather today for mass meetings in each of the country's four regions. They are expected to discuss the disruption of education caused by the strike.

Members of the Civil Servants Association are due to hold a mass meeting in Manzini Wednesday to decide whether to join the teachers' strike, if no agreement is reached with the government.

June, 1996


Nigeria Military To Assist In Tracking Pirate Radio


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 19, 1996 by Paul Ejime , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 214 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - In its first reaction, Nigeria's defence headquarters said Tuesday it would help in tracking an opposition pirate radio station, which has been transmitting anti-government programs since June 12.

The date was the third anniversary of Nigeria's 1993 presidential election annulled by the last military regime. 

Speaking to journalists Tuesday in Lagos, Defence Spokesman Fred Chijuka said the broadcast, by Radio Democratic Nigeria, was sabotage and a treasonable offence.

"I hope they (the operators) know it is a treasonable offence," Brig. Gen. Chijuka said.

The relevant military units, he said, were investigating. The radio has not disclosed its headquarters. It has transmitted broadcasts by self-exiled National Democratic Coalition leader Anthony Enahoro and an interview with Nigeria's nobel literature laureate, Wole Soyinka.

Africa News


June, 1996


Mozambique Mozambique Has Only 500 Doctors


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 19, 1996


LENGTH: 214 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambique has only 500 medical doctors for its population of about 17 million, or an average of one doctor for 34,000 inhabitants, an official in the ministry of health has said.

Lucas Jeremias, of the national directorate of health, said this in an interview shortly before a meeting between Mozambican Health Minister Aurelio Zilhao, and the visiting Cuban Foreign Minister Roberto Robaina. 

Jeremias said that "of the 500 doctors, 200 are Mozambicans and the rest are foreigners".

He said there are 53 Cuban doctors working in the southern province of Maputo, the central provinces of Sofala, Manica and Zambezia, and Nampula and Cabo Delagado in the north.

The Cuban doctors are contracted under an agreement signed in Havana in 1995.

Cooperation with Cuba also covers medical training, both in Mozambique, at Maputo's Eduardo Mondlane university, and in Cuba.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large O.A.U. Appeals To Members On Refugees


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 19, 1996 by Ghion Hagos , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 547 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Organization of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim called on governments Wednesday to address, seriously, the root causes of refugees and to create satisfactory conditions for their voluntary repatriation.

In a message marking Africa Refugee Day to be observed Thursday, he said that the plight of refugees could be overcome "only through greater respect of human rights, national reconciliation, social and economic progress and the establishment of lasting democratic institutions.". 

Africa, he said, needed the contributions of each citizen to enter the 21st century as a prosperous continent and therefore could not afford refugees.

Despite efforts by Ethiopia, Eritrea, Mozambique and Sierra Leone at voluntary repatriation, he said, the magnitude of the problem of refugees and displaced persons remained.

He said this had "seriously disturbed the OAU and has become a source of its major concern."

There are seven million refugees and at least 20 million internally displaced Africans. These, Salim said, were victims of conflicts in countries such as Burundi, Liberia and Somalia.

Hosting these people has brought about destruction which the asylum countries suffer, Salim said, "as refugees forage for firewood or grazing cattle, causing severe loss of vegetation cover and the depletion of the carrying capacity of the land."

The long-term effect of this and the impact on the conservation of natural resources was, he said, enormous.

The problem, he added, was also emerging increasingly as a source of tension between states. Therefore, he said, solving this problem had become urgent.

"This is even more critical given the enormous pressure that it exerts on the resources and security of the countries concerned," it said.

However, some countries had granted asylum to refugees and Salim said this demonstrated their "enormous generosity."

The enormity of the refugee problem, he said, had caused the O.A.U. and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to chose the environment as the theme of the commemoration of this year's refugee day.

The regions most affected by the problem of refugees in 1996, he said, were central and west Africa, where there was a crisis of "monumental proportions."

In these regions, most refugees are to be found in Cote D'Ivoire, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone, Tanzania and Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Central African Republic UN Issues Humanitarian Appeal for CAR


BYLINE: United Nations June 20, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

United Nations (Department of Humanitarian Affairs, June 19) -- The United Nations today requested the international community to provide $1.3 million for emergency assistance to the Central African Republic in response to humanitarian needs arising from armed conflict last month. The request is contained in an inter-agency situation report on that country issued today. 

The conflict among elements of the Central African Republic army seriously damaged the already fragile infrastructure, creating considerable humanitarian assistance needs in that country. While immediate food needs will be met by the World Food Programme (WFP) through existing stocks, the proposed assistance programme, which is to cover a three-month period ending mid-September aimed at meeting on a priority basis the health and nutritional rehabilitation requirements of vulnerable groups in Bangui, the capital. It will also address gaps in the areas of education, agriculture and animal health which, if left unattended, could seriously affect key socio-economic sectors and create an additional destabilizing factor.

The United Nations agencies in Central African Republic -- the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), WFP and World Health Organization (WHO) -- have, in collaboration with other international and national relief organizations -- Midecins sans frontihres, Belgium, and Central African Red Cross -- carried out assessments of the immediate crisis-related humanitarian requirements. The details of these requirements are spelled out in the "Expanded Situation Report" on that country sent to Member States and concerned relief organizations today.

LANGUAGE: English
