Africa News


June, 1996


United States and Africa U.S. Condemns Massacre Of 70 In Burundi


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 20, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Washington - Statement by U.S. State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns on June 19 condemning killing in Burundi of civilians near Kibimba, three International Committee of the Red Cross workers near Cibitoke, a nun in Gitega:

The United States vehemently condemns the massacre of over 70 civilians near Kibimba, the recent killings of three ICRC workers near Cibitoke, and the June 16 murder of a nun in Gitega. The Kibimba massacre was reportedly carried out by elements of the Burundi military; most of the victims were women or small children. The ICRC workers were killed by unknown assailants while traveling in a clearly marked Red Cross vehicle; they were attempting to provide humanitarian assistance to the civilian population. Insurgents reportedly attacked a car carrying three Burundian church workers near Gitega, killing one nun. 

We call upon the government and military of Burundi to undertake complete and transparent investigations of all these incidents, and to do all that is necessary to bring those responsible for these atrocities to justice, including, if appropriate, members of the Burundi military.

These cowardly murders of innocent civilians, aid workers, and church workers are appalling, and once again underscore the necessity for all sides to abandon violence, join together in frank negotiations, and commit themselves to peace and reconciliation. Violence begets violence in Burundi, and the only way to reverse this self-destructive course is for all Burundians to renounce violence as a means of resolving their differences and find a path toward peace.

The U.S. repeats its call to all parties to reject extremism and work together for a better future for all Burundians. The Mwanza III peace talks, organized by former Tanzanian President Nyerere, provide a unique opportunity for parties across the political spectrum to seize the moment and find a way to bridge the differences that separate them.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Malawi Chintheche Paper Project On Hold


BYLINE: Malawi News Online June 19, 1996


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Blantyre - The resuscitation of a project, shelved in the eighties, for the establishment of a paper and pulp project at Chintheche in Nkhata-Bay, north Malawi - a joint venture between Birla Engineering Services of India and Malawi's Viphya Corporation Limited (VIPCOR) - rests upon the investors' ability to raise US$250 million (MK3.75 billion) for the project, and the outcome of an environmental impact assessment (EIA).Prospective donors for both the EIA study and the paper project are the World Bank and the African Development Bank.

The pace and direction of the project's implementation, however, depends on how soon the final EIA study will be done and on its recommendations. The EIA will itself depend on the outcome of a detailed project report to be prepared by the technical partner and VIPCOR. In 1991/92, an environmental study was done, but only focused on three areas, Chikangawa, Elephant Rock and Bondera Village, as possible sites for the paper and pulp plant. However, Mrs Eta Mmangisa from the Ministry of Research and Environmental Affairs said the study did not include the lake shore site, Chintheche, now wanted by Birla Engineering Services for the paper and pulp plant. 

Chintheche has always been a favourite site for the project. The place was originally proposed in the 1970s, but the project is now known to have fizzled out due to the economic recession at that time - contrary to the widely held belief that the project was shot down by donors who were not satisfied with mechanisms put in place for the disposal of effluent from the mills. Fears have been expressed that Malawi would reap millions of Kwachas from the project but lose billions if it starts without detailed and careful planning.

Apart from the paper and pulp plant, there are a number of other projects due to be implemented under the agreement, such as the manufacture of organic fertilisers, charcoal briquettes and the rearing of dairy cattle and meat goats, the General Manager of VIPCOR, Luke Jumbe has said.

VIPCOR Project Manager, Cedric Makunganya, in an interview said the project will need an initial capital of US$250 million, with construction work due to start in three years' time. "The project will obviously need a lot of government support to kick off," said Makunganya, adding government will have to act as a guarantor for the local partner, in order to raise the required capital. The exact equity holding in the joint venture is yet to be worked out, though Makunganya hinted the technical partner could get up to 51% of the shares if it so wished, with the local partner taking up the rest.

It is estimated that the plant, which will have a capacity to process 100,000 metric tonnes of pulp per annum, will offer direct employment to 1,200 people. With expansion, some 6,000 others will be indirectly employed in planned chemical companies, following the establishment of the paper and pulp plant.

" For Chintheche, there is need for the new study as the last one was done 18 years ago and is now stale," said Mmangisa. "6The population of Chintheche, for example, is not the same as it was in the 70s, while the new site also poses the question of how the pulp will be transported. "The Ministry of Natural Resources is aware of this and is to advise the developer accordingly."

Makunganya, however, remains very positive. ''The technical partners are quite capable. They run the biggest paper mills in Nigeria, Kenya and other countries. They will try to adhere to international standards,'' he said parrying fears that effluent from the mills would harm aquatic life in the nearby lake.

Malawi News Online is a fortnightly news update produced by Malawian journalists in cooperation with South Africa Contact, i'Afrika Magazine and Inform-bbs in Denmark. E-mail: AfricaNN@inform-bbs.dk.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


169 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Malawi Malawi News Round Up


BYLINE: Malawi News Online June 19, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Blantyre - The hearing of the marathon Mwanza murder trial appeal case has once again been postponed. The trial, involving former head of state Kamuzu Banda, his right hand man John Tembo, confidante Cecilia Kadzamira, former police chief McWilliam Lunguzi, and three other policemen, will now take place in October. The appeal case was supposed to be heard in May.

High Court Registrar,Edward Twea, explaining the delay, cited the huge amount of information to be sifted through by lawyers and judges, contained in 400-page volumes. This, he said, would be done in July and August. "We are behind schedule, by now (June) we expected that everything should have been over," said Twea. 

MAIZE PRICES GO DOWN

Malawi's grain-milling and retailing company, GRAMIL has reduced prices for all maize products effective 10 June. A 20 kg bag of maize flour will now be sold at K98 ($6.5) from a previous price of K119 from ($8).

" I should congratulate Grain and Milling for reducing the prices" President Bakili Muluzi said on June 9 in Lilongwe. This is what we want" he said and asked other companies to emulate the milling company's example by also reducing their commodities.

Muluzi said the government will not hesitate to revoke licences of companies which overcharge without justification. In the rural areas, 50 kgs of maize now sells for K60 ($5).

AFORD'S MONTH OF NOTICE GIVES PROBLEMS TO UDF

Addressing a rally in his home district of Machinga, President Bakili Muluzi indicated that it would be difficult for the UDF to work with AFORD, its coalition partner, as they serve a month long notice.''I wish to tell them to leave immediately, " he said, as though telling the country that AFORD's pull-out was "good riddance".

Muluzi said he had not enjoyed the working relationship with AFORD since the party started making threats to pull out, saying that it was at that time he lost confidence in the party. He said the party's pull-out would not in any way shake the government's proceedings. However, the UDF is now left with only 85 seats in the 177- seat chamber, far short of the two-thirds majority it needs to pass decisions.

NO DEBT FORGIVENESS

Malawi does not qualify for debt relief, the World Bank representative in Malawi, Mr Arif Zulfiqar said in a recent interview. Malawi wants the international creditors to scrap the country's Mk31.5 billion ($2.1 billion )debt. However, Zulfiqar said Malawi's debt is not serious enough to merit debt forgiveness.

Malawi is among the many African countries that appealed to multi-lateral donor nations at a recent summit in Washington for a 90% debt reduction. The Paris Club of Creditor Nations identified seven African countries: Burundi, Guinea Bissau, Mozambique, Sao Tome and Principe, Sudan, Zaire and Zambia as eligible for debt relief.

HOSPITAL EMERGENCY LOOMS DUE TO LACK OF MEDICAL SUPPLIES

Government has by-passed formal tendering procedures for the procurement of drugs and other medical supplies, as a last minute emergency stop-gap measure to prevent a looming crisis in the health care system.

A high powered four-man delegation left June 8 for Europe to arrange the air-freighting into Malawi of an emergency order of Mk8 million ($ 533,000) worth of medical supplies for the country's major hospitals of Lilongwe, Queen Elizabeth Central and Zomba General Hospital, where the situation is described as desperate.

A senior government official - who asked to remain anonymous - leading the group said in an interview that the measures have been taken to avert a crisis after the government learnt that the stock of medical supplies it had ordered from Europe, and which were expected in the country early or mid May, would not be arriving until end July. " As you know tendering is slow, but without authority the ministry cannot procure anything," the official said.He was accompanied to Europe by officials from the health, treasury and central tender board.

He complained that the public has so far been misled on the issue of drugs in the country. He said the health ministry had now been given authority to procure what is available locally and abroad outside normal tendering procedures, as an emergency.

GOVERNMENT TO BUY ESTATE LAND

Lands and Valuation Minister, Peter Fachi, announced June 11 the government is to buy 600 hectares of land from Mandala Properties, in Mulanje southern Malawi, and redistribute it to the landless in the district.

Fachi said the government would buy the land at MK18 million ($1.2 million ). Mandala Estates have a workforce of nearly two thousand. The workforce will be absorbed by the Malawi Tea Company.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


170 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Malawi Becomes First To End Leprosy


BYLINE: Malawi News Online June 19, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Blantyre - Malawi has become the first country in the world to wipe out leprosy and has achieved the feat five years ahead of schedule.

British Leprosy Relief Association(LEPRA), Director Terry Vasey, in announcing the news said Malawi could be happy and proud for beating all other countries in the world. In 1991 the World Health Organisation set the year 2000 for the elimination of leprosy as a public health problem. But Malawi, said Vasey, hit the target five years early.

In Malawi in 1966 there were close to 2000 registered patients. By last year, there were only 764 cases.

Currently LEPRA is supporting a research centre in Chilumba where the organisation is trying to establish if there is a link between leprosy and the human immuno deficiency syndrome. So far, said Vasey, no connection had been found between the two.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


171 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Extinction Threatens Hippos And Elephants In Malawi


BYLINE: Malawi News Online June 19, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Blantyre - On 13 April this year, shortly after he finished duty, a 38 year-old night guard at the Malawi College of Forestry, Romeo Sadaraki, was killed by a stray elephant bull which he had pelted with stones.

An eye witness, Weluzani Mofati, later said Sadaraki had reacted to the shouts of the people who had tried to scare the elephant bull away. He walked up to within 20 metres of the elephant and started pelting it with stones. The enraged bull trumpeted three times, before charging. Sadaraki took to his heels, tripped and fell. The elephant struck Sadaraki with its tusks, trampling on him killing and him on the spot. 

Sadaraki's violent death by an elephant is an isolated case in Malawi, a country which witnesses man's indiscriminate slaughter of game without the slightest regard for their value - economic or ecological.

In Malawi, like in many other countries in Africa, man is the biggest enemy of wildlife, having already rendered some game and fish species extinct and threatening the existence of many others. Rhinos, for example, are extinct in Malawi, except for the two juvenile ones that the government imported from South Africa in 1993. Many other types of wildlife in Malawi face the same fate as that of the rhinos if the present rate at which they are being massacred is left unchecked.

Parks and Wildlife Officer in south Malawi, Leonard Sefu, said in an interview that the most sought-after game in the country is the elephant. These animals are a target for game poachers because of their valuable tusk. The elephant population in all the country's national parks and game reserves is diminishing at an alarming rate.

Kasungu National Park in central Malawi was once home to 2,000 elephants. Today there are only 200 to 300 left - the rest have been killed off and their tusks smuggled out of the country, says Sefu. In the Majete Game Reserve, south Malawi, there was a population of 300 elephants a few years ago. But all of them have been wiped out. He said there are still a few elephants left in Vwaza game reserve in Mzimba, in northern Malawi but they are also under threat of being wiped out.

"The general picture is one of gloom for all types of wildlife in the country," he says.

According to Sefu, poachers sneak into the game reserves and kill the elephants with AK47 attack rifles. Elephant tusks are then smuggled out of Malawi to Zambia and Mozambique. From there the ivory finds its way to Europe and Asia. As in many other countries, Malawi's elephants are protected and poachers, once caught, are prosecuted and sentenced. So far prison sentences have been anything from three years upwards but judging by the increasing rate at which poaching is taking place, it is clear the punishments are not severe enough to stop the offences.

Between January and February this year, Sefu says, over 40 hippos have been killed along the Shire River, near the outlet from Lake Malawi. The Shire is Lake Malawi's outlet and the country's biggest and longest river. It drains into the Zambezi.

With Malawi's population growing at a rate of 3.2 % yearly there has been an increased demand for land suitable for cultivation. As a result, people along the Shire River, just like in many other parts of the country, have opened up gardens in places previously not cultivated. Some of these places are long-time natural grazing lands for hippos and they naturally come and graze on the crops.

Sefu says villagers in the area are not happy and so they poison the hippos to protect their crops. The people of the villages believe they have been cheated by their local politicians. These politicians promised to pressure government to relocate the hippos to the nearby Liwonde National Park, once they were elected to parliament.

But wildlife officials contend that removing hippos from the area was an untenable thing since hippos, like other animals, have natural habitats where they must be protected. They say that people should report crop destruction to the authorities, not just kill the animals, and especially not by poisoning as this might be dangerous to other animals and fish, as well as people.

According to a 1990 count, there were 6,000 hippos in Malawi but Sefu however believes that with increased human activities the hippo population has been reduced considerably.

Hippos are one of Malawi's most popular tourist attractions. They are part of Malawi's "big five" - lion, elephant, buffalo, hippo and leopard - that people want to see. The big five used to include the rhino, not the hippo. But those days are gone in Malawi as in many other parts of Africa.
Malawi News Online is a fortnightly news update produced by Malawian journalists in cooperation with South Africa Contact, i'Afrika Magazine and Inform-bbs in Denmark. E-mail: AfricaNN@inform-bbs.dk.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


172 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Sudan Opposition Reforms Move On Pace


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London) June 17, 1996


LENGTH: 2000 words


 

London - The Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) has often received a poor press over the issues of internal democracy and lack of respect for human rights. Such criticisms were used as an excuse for the schism at Nasir in 1991. Since then, the SPLA has embarked on a programme of reforms which has gone a considerable way towards increasing internal democracy and improving the guerrilla army's record on human rights. The SPLA has initiated this programme whilst continuing the military struggle against the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime in Khartoum. Though detractors might still point out the need for further improvements, it cannot be denied that the SPLA's progress in these areas has been both remarkable and impressive.

The democratisation process began with the SPLA's first national convention in April 1994. Following on from that successful exercise in democracy, a senior officers' conference was convened in August and September 1995. Over one thousand SPLA officers attended and debated the issues fiercely. Naturally, military matters were also discussed and astute readers will no doubt make the connection between this conference and the SPLA's successful military offensive that began in October 1995. 

The importance of the conference lay in convincing the military leadership of the movement of the need to pursue the creation of a working civil society in the liberated areas. Without the support of the military leaders such an exercise would be futile. It is admirable that the SPLA is currently attempting to instate civil authority over the military with the active acceptance and co-operation of the military leadership.

The Civil Society Conference: This reporter has just returned from a ten-day stay in Southern Sudan where he attended and participated in an SPLA conference on civil society and civil authority. The conference was held in the Imatong Mountains in Eastern Equatoria in the liberated lands that the SPLA has renamed the New Kush. The actual valley where the conference was held is known to the local tribe as Eman.

Tribal chiefs from the Dedinka, Taposa and Latuka tribes from the surrounding areas were invited to participate in the conference. Many international guests and observers also took part. The local chiefs expressed their concern and grievances with the SPLA and, in particular, complained of guerrilla fighters who married local women but who then failed to abide by local customs and traditions. Fighters have been accused of leaving their women and children behind when they move on to other areas and postings. A comparison was made with the Northern soldiers who have also abused the local populations. Complaints were also made about the arbitrary arrest, maltreatment, torture and even rape of the local tribes people by the SPLA soldiers.

Misapprehension: The exchanges at the conference were very frank and honest. This led one foreign delegate, who represented a British-based humanitarian organisation, to conclude that the SPLA was on the verge of another split. She flew from Eman-New Kush to Maridi in Western Equatoria and said as much to the local SPLA commanders there. However, such is the new born confidence of the guerrilla army that the young lady's concerns were recognised as naive and were dismissed accordingly. Four or five years ago such rumours and comments might have caused serious problems between the humanitarian agency and the SPLA.

Frankness and Openness: The conference also heard some positive stories of the SPLA's role as liberator in Southern Sudan. SPLA fighters have often risked their lives to save civilians. They have protected whole communities from the NIF regime's forces and they have evacuated civilians from the war fronts when necessary.

The SPLA was given a chance to put its side of the story the day before the conference split up into committees and discussion groups. Commander Uyai Deng Ajak summed up the attitude of the SPLA soldier when he said:

"We are not perfect. We are human beings and we make mistakes. We have made mistakes in the past and will most definitely make mistakes in the future. To say that we deliberately target our own people for mistreatment runs contrary to the objectives for which we took up arms and is objectionable. We have in the past corrected the mistakes made by individual SPLA soldiers and we will continue to correct these mistakes in the future."

Commander Uyai said that the real question needing an answer from the people of Southern Sudan is whether they want the armed struggle and the liberation to continue. If the Southern people want it to continue, then, he said, they must give their full support to the SPLA's systematic reforms designed to educate the SPLA soldiers on issues of human rights. Commander Uyai received a lengthy applause at the end of his speech.

The conference was then addressed by Commander Majak Agot who is in command of officers' training. He stated that the SPLA had already incorporated human rights charters and issues into the officers' training programme. He asked that the civil population be patient and understanding because the new reforms would take time to have an effect.

Perhaps the most representative view came in the form of a poem read by one of the SPLA women commanders, Commander Grace Datiro Okerruk, entitled, "I Don't Complain".

Issues at Stake: The conference discussed many issues including the relationship between a civil society and authority in a democracy; the development of democratic institutions in the civil society; the role of the civil authority in the socio-economic development of society; the democratic empowerment of civil society and civil authority, on the one hand, and the military during a liberation struggle.

The conference split up into seven committees, each considering specific aspects of the civil society issues. These committees made many valuable recommendations which are expected to be implemented in the future.

One of the many positive aspects of the conference was the presence of so many international guests. They included representative of human rights organizations, humanitarian and relief organizations, the United Nations and other international aid agencies. All were impressed that the SPLA could convene such a conference in the midst of a liberation struggle.

Some harsh remarks about the SPLA's past record were inevitably made. However, significant progress was observed by the representative of Amnesty International who encouraged the SPLA to continue on this path towards full human rights observance. The representative commended the fact that the SPLA appears no longer to be keeping political prisoners.

The aid agencies themselves were not free from criticism. The question of agreeing to common norms of human rights observance was raised time and time again. There was concern about double standards when measuring human rights abuses. Many human rights organizations persist in quoting data from the past just to make a point. For instance, that the SPLA too abuses human rights. The agencies were criticised for having made little endeavour to recognise the SPLA's achievements on the human rights front over the past two years. These organizations were accused of continuing to use data from pre-1991, often without furnishing an accurate date, and claiming that this is indicative of SPLA practice in 1996. These organisations have taken to the extreme the notion that they must be even handed and often repeat the tired old cliche that "both the NIF regime and the SPLA engage in human rights abuses". Such comments ignore the reforms within the SPLA.

Most of the international agencies at the conference had met with the SPLA last November, when many of the sensitive issues and irritants in their relationship were discussed. This meant that at Eman-New Kush the atmosphere was far more relaxed and amicable in May.

Among the international personalities who attended the SPLA civil society conference and who addressed the meeting was the president of the Swiss-based Christian Solidarity International (CSI), Reverend Hans Stukelberger. He told the conference that the secret to gaining and maintaining public support for any political movement lay in its ability to respect the freedom and views of the individual members of society. He described the levels of democracy in Switzerland and offered them as a successful example of decentralised power within the state. He welcomed the chance to visit Southern Sudan because he was now better able to appreciate the potential of its people.

CSI has been a steadfast campaigner against the human rights abuses of the NIF regime and the atrocities committed against the people of the South, the Nuba Mountains, the Ingessina Hills an the Beja region. It is also involved in humanitarian support to the people of these areas.

SPLA Leader's Closing Remarks: The conference was opened and closed by the leader of the SPLA, Colonel John Garang. The theme he adopted on each occasion was similar: that liberation and development are not mutually exclusive and must progress simultaneously. The SPLA must begin developing the liberated areas while the struggle for liberating the rest of Sudan continues.

Colonel Garang described an elaborate vision of the alliances that will need to be forged with elements within the old Sudan if the development within the new Sudan (the liberated areas) is to be consolidated. He differentiates between the old Sudan as represented by the extremist Islamic policies of the NIF, currently in power, and the ld Sudan of the traditional political forces, who have now come to accept that the predominance of one religion and culture is untenable and unworkable. He sees the old Sudan of the political parties in alliance with the SPLA against the old Sudan of the NIF. Colonel Garang's vision incorporates two basic premises: firstly, that there is a common political agenda based on the Asmara Declaration of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA); and secondly, that the SPLA's military strength and policies will need to be maintained to ensure that each party lives up to their part of the deal. He believes that the representatives of the North and the South must accept each other's word at face value if the relationship is to succeed. He believes it is possible to build a new Sudan of democracy and equality.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


173 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Sudan and Uganda Sudanese Watching Ugandan Presidential Elections


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London) June 17, 1996


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

London - Sudanese of all political persuasions were united last month in agreeing, each for their own reasons, that the presidential elections in Uganda held considerable importance for the people of Sudan. After all, Uganda is host to the largest number of Sudanese refugees and also in recent years the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime has provided support and assistance to the Ugandan rebel group the so-called Lords Resistance Army (LRA). The Ugandan government of President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni has been at the forefront of the peace initiative organised by the peace committee of the Intergovernmental Authority on Drought and Development (IGADD).

The outcome of the elections was a resounding victory for President Museveni as the Ugandan people voted to continue the stability he has brought to their country over the past ten years. The "Gazette" welcomes this result as President Museveni has been a good friend to the Southern Sudanese people, which in the eyes of the powers that be in Khartoum made him a potent foe of that repressive regime. 

Member of IGADD: As a member of the IGADD peace committee, Uganda has tried to mediate an end to the Sudanese civil conflict. Those efforts have been frustrated by the actions of the NIF regime which has refused to continue working with IGADD. That is because the peace committee has defined and identified the root causes of the conflict in its Declaration of Principles (DOP) and Khartoum did not like what it said. The DOP has been accepted by the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) and the opposition National Democratic Alliance (NDA), which have incorporated it into their national agenda. The NIF regime objects most strongly to the clauses on Self-determination and the creation of a secular state. In response to IGADD's efforts, the NIF regime has attempted to destabilise the IGADD states of Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda through terrorist activities.

So far, the authorities in Kampala have established that Khartoum has sponsored the LRA, a bizarre Christian Fundamentalist group from North-eastern Uganda, provided it with training and military equipment and infiltrated it across the border from Southern Sudan. The regime has used the LRA to destabilise the border areas, and has countered any accusations from Kampala by claiming that President Museveni is actively providing military support for the SPLA.

During the presidential elections in May, the LRA supported President Museveni's principal opponent, Dr. Paul Ssemogerere, a former foreign minister in Mr. Museveni's administration. Mr. Ssemogerere campaigned during the elections for Uganda to reconcile with the NIF regime, a policy which he had pursued even whilst foreign minister.

During the initial meetings of the IGADD peace committee on Sudan in Nairobi in 1992, Mr. Ssemogerere worried his colleagues from the other countries by adopting a similar position to that of the NIF regime. The Southern Sudanese delegation was greatly alarmed at this. Perhaps IGADD would never have endorsed the DOP if Mr. Ssemogerere had not been called away on urgent business and replaced by his deputy minister. He never returned to the IGADD talks, whilst the support for the DOP was consolidated and the principles adopted as the basis of the peace initiative.

Strong Stand on Issues: President Museveni has taken a strong stand on the causes of the conflict in Sudan. He is unusual amongst African leaders in that he sees nothing to be gained from failing to address the causes of internal political dissent wherever it occurs across the continent. He has urged all African leaders to speak out for fairness and justice in those parts of the continent, like Sudan, where political grievances are ignored and human rights blatantly violated by the regime in power.

In his inaugural address at the swearing in ceremony in Kampala on 10 May, attended by several African heads of state, President Museveni warned the NIF military leader, Lieutenant General Omer Hassan El Beshir, to watch his step with Uganda. There will be no adopting of a policy of appeasement towards Sudan and if Khartoum does not desist from its policies of subversion and support for terrorists, Uganda will take the necessary action required to end Khartoum's provocations, Mr. Museveni warned.

During the election campaign, Mr. Museveni spoke of the horrendous situation imposed by the regime upon the people of Sudan. Addressing a political rally at the beginning of May, he complained that African leaders were not doing enough to help the people of Southern Sudan. He said that Mr. Ssemogerere, his opponent, was wrong to suggest a reconciliation with Khartoum when no effort had been made to redress the causes of the conflict in the first place. The Ugandan leader promised that he would put an end to the insecurity in Northern Uganda caused by Khartoum's support for the LRA and he would also ensure that Africa addresses the causes of conflict in Sudan.

Refugee Problem: One of the direct effects of the conflict in Sudan has been the influx of refugees from Southern Sudan into Northern Uganda. Over the past five years the number of refugees has increased dramatically because of the regime's policy of aerial bombardment of civilian settlements. President Museveni has ensured that the huge refugee population has been cared for and looked after despite the burdens this has placed upon his country's resources. On the other hand, the Khartoum regime has demanded that Uganda close its border with Southern Sudan in order to stop the refugees from crossing over. It has been Kampala's refusal to carry out such a policy which has resulted in Khartoum's terrorist activities in the border areas.

The refugee situation and its role as a political football between Kampala and Khartoum is nothing new. Many Southern Sudanese can remember past atrocities which arose from collusion between Uganda and Sudan. It is these memories which made the refugees so concerned at the talk of reconciliation engendered by Mr. Ssemogerere in his election campaign. Whether the presidential candidate was playing politics to win votes, or whether he really intended to carry out this policy is immaterial now. However, it did cause concern to many refugees.

Recent Examples: In the 1960's, Father Saturnino Lohore was a political leader of some repute in the South. He had been a member of the 1958 parliament that was removed by the Abboud regime following the coup d'etat. The Catholic priest was an ardent advocate of a federalised Sudan. In 1966, Father Saturnino Lohore was assassinated by security agents of the government which replaced the Abboud regime at his native village of Loronyo near Torit in Eastern Equatoria. When the "Vigilant" newspaper exposed the story and insisted upon a public inquiry into the death, Khartoum used its influence with the Obote government in Uganda to concoct a story whereby Father Saturnino had been killed by a Ugandan border guard whilst trying to cross the border illegally. Many Southern Sudanese will remember countless other examples.

Divided Opinion: Whilst all Sudanese were interested in the outcome of Uganda's elections, their motives for being so differed considerably. The Khartoum regime and its supporters would have dearly liked to see President Museveni defeated because the election of one of his opponents would have given the regime a weak political leader to deal with. Following Mr. Museveni's resounding victory, Khartoum now realises that it will have to deal with an experienced politician who is well aware of all of the regime's tricks and schemes.

Most Southern Sudanese have been relieved to see President Museveni re-elected. The refugees inside Uganda need not worry about the repercussions of this victory. However, supporters of Riek Machar, with their most recent moves towards an all out incorporation into the system of the NIF regime, will have viewed the victory in Kampala with some considerable concern.

It must now be hoped that with the elections out of his way in Uganda, President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni will use his new mandate to press ahead with the IGADD peace initiative, together with his other three colleagues, Presidents Daniel arap Moi of Kenya and Isaias Afeworki of Eritrea and Prime Minister Meles Xenawi of Ethiopia. The result of the Uganda elections is good news for the long suffering people of Southern Sudan.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Nine Soccer Fans Die In Stampede


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 17, 1996 By Lewis Mwanangombe


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Lusaka - Nine soccer fans died in a stampede at Lusaka's Independence Stadium Sunday and 76 others were injured seriously at the end of an explosive Zambia versus Sudan World Cup qualifying match.

But by this morning University Teaching Hospital Public Relations Manager, Don Mwape, was reporting that all but 12 of the injured had been discharged.

Mr Mwape reported that apart from the nine who were brought in dead last evening there had been no other fatalities.

Of the still admitted nine are men and three are women, while 64 have been discharged. 

A survivor, Mr Kelvin Munkanta, who is still nursing his wounds in ward GO1 of the University Teaching Hospital said the stampede was triggered by a group of hooligans who shouted a warning, as jubilant fans were trooping out of the stadium, that a bomb had been planted at the entrance of 'D' Gate.

As the fans in front pulled back in fear of the bomb that really was not there they met tremendous resistance from those who were still headed for the exit.

In the ensuing 'pulling and pushing' some fans begun to collapse and as they did so they were quickly trampled by the surging mass of people. Some of the victims survived with injuries but the unlucky nine met their deaths.

Police Inspector-General Francis Ndhlovu disclosed that six of the dead were men while three were women, who included a woman police constable.

"It is difficult to stop such a stampede and there was little which my officers could do," he said at the UTH last evening shortly after the tragedy occured.

Red Cross volunteers at the stadium had also treated some fans who had minor injuries while some reporters actually counted six such casualties being taken on stretchers.

The deaths at the stadium are the worst in the sporting history of the country and they shocked and dampened the nations celebrations once the magnitude of the tragedy spread to every corner of Zambia.

Youth, Sport and Child Development Minister, Samuel Miyanda, described the deaths as the most tragic thing to happen especially since the national team had so gloriously won the match.

President Chiluba was among the more than 35,000 strong crowd which turned up for the match but his motorcade left the stadium shortly after the end of the match.

Earlier the President had granted Zambia national team skipper Kalusha Bwalya a diplomatic passport which will enable him enjoy VIP treatment foreign airports. Mr Chiluba said he hoped the passport will enable skipper Kalusha taken on the responsibility of representing Zambia during his many travels.

Earlier before the tragedy Zambia had succeeded in coming out of the rut by white-washing stubborn Sudan 3-0 by the end of the 90 minutes.

Zambia had started the return leg under-dogs having gone down 2-0 to Sudan in Khartoum two weeks ago.

The Zambians lived up to the expectations of their hundreds of thousands of fans spread across the country when they made their surge for the goal in the opening minute of the first half which ended with Sudan conceding a corner which was carefully taken by skipper Kalusha.

There was no goal from this manouver but hardly ten minutes later when another of the many waves which had shackled the entire Sudanese team in their own half broke on the goal mouth Dennis Lota made no mistake in converting a throw from defender Mordon Malitoli into a sure goal.

On 40 minutes Zambia wom corner number seven and "ambassador" Kalusha floated the ball in from the right. A poor clearance fell to Mutale whose angled shot was turned in via a cheeky back-heeler from Mwewa near the post to make it 2-0.

As the two teams went off for half time Sudanese coach Ahmed Abdalla was so upset he gave his goal keeper abdelmanes a tongue-lashing and a rough push towards the dressing rooms. Adelmanes could only cry openly.

On resumption of play Zambia continued to pressurise the Sudanese and these efforts were rewarded when Lota headed home a clincher to seal the fate of the Sudanese and open what should have been one of most delightful of evenings but for the tragedy which occured at Gate 'D'.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Sudan Team Not Threaten By Skipper


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 14, 1996 By Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The Sudanese national team is not threatened by the presence of skipper Kalusha Bwalya in the Zambian side, trainer Abdulla Ahmed announced on arrival at Lusaka International Airport yesterday.

Ahmed, who is carrying 21 players including two professionals, said while he respected Zambia's skipper Kalusha Bwalya, his team will not fear him. 

"We have come to play the Zambia national team which has eleven players and not an individual. We respect Kalusha but I don't think he can be the subject of the match," said Ahmed.

"Football is a very tough game but we will try our best," said the native Sudanese trainer, whose side was met by staff from the Saudi Arabian and Sudanese embassies resident in Zambia.

The two professionals in the Sudanese line-up are Omer Ecacamin who plays his club football in oil-rich Oman and Akif Ata, who plays in Qatar.

And national soccer team coach, Roald Poulsen has assured that he has assembled a solid backline to check the Sudanese strikers despite the absence of towering Elijah Litana.

"We know Litana is a world class defender and we will miss him but as it is there is nothing to worry about his absence.We are confident that even with his absence, we can still win," said Poulsen at a Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) press conference yesterday.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Sudanese Protest Article About Team


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 14, 1996 By Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - Angry Sudanese resident in Zambia yesterday inundated The Post newspapers with calls and personal visits protesting against Bright Mwape's Behind The Scenes column which they said belittled their national soccer team.

The calls which begun about 09:00 hours in the morning ran throughout the day and included one from the Sudanese ambassador to Zambia.

"You cannot refer to our national team like a bunch of school kids without any idea of football, please leave us alone," said one early caller before slamming the phone down. 

Another Sudanese who only identified himself as Muhammed followed: "Why is Zambia so full of itself especially on soccer. We know you are a great footballing nation but your words on Sudan are unfair to our up coming players."

The Sudanese protested that they do not want their players to go on the pitch intimidated and emotionally distressed by insults and unfair commentary.

"As a Sudanese living in Zambia I have the greatest admiration for the talent and skill of the Zambian Football team. However, what Bright Mwape wrote in The Post issue of June 13 about the Sudanese national team lacks objectivity and the minimum courtesy for a visiting team," wrote one Waleed Taha in his letter to the editor.

Mwape wrote in his article yesterday titled, Stop Sudan and redeem Africa, that Sudan is not ready to represent Africa in the World Cup and they must not be allowed to mess up Africa's chances at the expense of quality teams.

He argued that the Sudanese victory was accidental and propelled by factors outside skill and good football.

"I appreciate the frustration of playing amateurs running about in all directions and cheered in their confusion by a religiously partisan croud," Mwape wrote.

But the Sudanese ambassador to Zambia argued that the words were too harsh and uncourteous to the visiting Sudanese national team.

"Your article on Sudan in today's edition has been too insulting. I feel very bad about it. I am not angry but how can you write these things about the Sudan national team. It is not a good way to welcome a visiting team," said the ambassador who promised to make his complaint more formal.

Mwape maintained: "I could have been of any other nationality but would not have said Sudan in its form is a team for Africa's soccer leadership."

June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zimbabwe Scraps Through World Cup Qualifier


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 17, 1996


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Harare - Zimbabwe scrapped through to the round robin stage of the Africa zone World Cup qualifier after a mediocre performance against Madagascar Sunday in Harare.

Zimbabwe, which won 4-3 on goal aggregate after being held to a 2-2 draw on Sunday, was largely disappointing against a technically superior Madagascar. 

Dynamos' Claudius Zviripayi and United States based Vitalis Takawira scored for Zimbabwe. Madagascar's dangermen Rado and Toi scored for their side.

On several occasions, the islanders overran the Zimbabwean defence which was forced to backpedal.

Disappointing in the Zimbabwean team were goalkeeper, Ernest Chirambadare, who appeared nervous everytime the Madagascar team was on the run, and the strike force which was inept in front of goal.

Attendance was estimated at 30,000.

June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia To Play Critical World Cup Qualifier Against Sudan


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 15, 1996


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia plays against Sudan on Sunday in a "do or die" World Cup 1998 qualifying match following a 2-0 loss in an away game in Khartoum two weeks ago.

Zambia has to win by three goals in tomorrow's match to remain in the tournament. Sudan is already leading by two goals.

Zambia will be playing without its international defender, Elijah Litana, who is undergoing a knee injury treatment in Saudi Arabia.

The Sudanese are, however, said to be jittery of the presence of the international striker, Kalusha Bwalya, who joined the squad on Tuesday but did not play in the Khartoum match.

Zambia's national team coach Roald Poulsen has kept his line-up for tomorrow a secret. But he is expected to keep most of the players who featured in the Khartoum match, though a strong defence line will be needed to keep the Sudanese attackers at bay.

Zambia is expected to take advantage of the home ground.

The country's national television, ZNBC, will broadcast the match live from Lusaka's Independence. The Football Association of Zambia is demading 8,000 dollars for broadcasting rights.

June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Security Heightened For World Cup Qualifier


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 16, 1996


LENGTH: 200 words


 
Lusaka - Zambian police manned strategic positions at Independence Stadium and turned away soccer fans carring parcels, baskets and carrier bags, in a mesaure to head off possible bomb attacks during the Zambia and Sudan World Cup qualifying match.

Police Public Relations Officer Francis Musonda warned Saturday that soccer fans would not be allowed into the stadium if they carry these objects. 

The movements of fans were restricted to designated areas within the facility. They were not allowed to loiter or pass between vehicles parked within the premises of the stadium.

Police examined food and drinks before fans were allowed to take them inside onto the terraces. Food vendors were kept outside the stadium's main gates.

A razor wire rings the stadium to keep determined fans from creeping under the terraces.

Africa News


June, 1996


d Sports - Soccer Nine Crushed To Death At Soccer Stadium in Lusaka


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 17, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - Nine Zambian soccer fans were crushed to death Sunday and 52 others injured when they were trapped between a closed gate and a stampede of other spectators trying to leave Lusaka's Independence Stadium after a match.

Witnesses said the large crowd in one part of the 35,000-seater stadium surged toward the nearest exit gate but found it closed. Some of the victims fell down and were trampled.

This occurred at the end of an international World Cup preliminary qualifier match between Zambia and the visiting Sudanese national soccer team. The hosts won 3-0 to qualify for the next round on a 3-2 goal aggregate.

Zambia Police Inspector-General Francis Ndhlovu denied the accident was caused by the "tight security" enforced at the match attended by President Frederick Chiluba.

Some witnessess suggested the police had deliberately left the gate closed after the match to allow the presidential motorcade quick exit through the stadium grounds. The motorcade left through a different gate.

It is the first such incident involving deaths of spectators at a soccer stadium in Zambia. Police blamed the incident on congestion at the stadium, which was filled to capacity.

Hundreds of anxious friends and relatives thronged Lusaka's University Teaching Hospital morgue on Sunday looking for missing relatives.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Aid Cuts Handled Diplomatically


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 15, 1996


LENGTH: 667 words


 
Lusaka - Zambia is to handle threats of aid restrictions from some of her co-operating partners diplomatically, President Frederick Chiluba told his supporters at State House today.

Mr Chiluba told hundreds of supporters who marched kilometres to show their support and anger at the violent acts of the shadowy terror organisation calling itself, 'Black Mamba' that there was reason for government to quarrel openly with donor governments.

But that there was sense in reasoning with them over the open pronouncements made by their envoys as regards the freezing of development aid just because the Zambian parliament had enacted a so called 'citizenship clause'. 

Mr Chiluba lamented that the extent of poverty on the continent of Africa had repeatedly compromised sovereignity of democratically elected governments and he appealed to Zambians to work hard in order to earn their own wealth.

He observed that if Zambia had its own resources it would have gone ahead and done many things which suited its own style of government but because of the poverty levels the tune was now being called by rich donor countries who attach grim conditionalities to their developmental aid support.

The President observed that though Europe had discriminatory clauses on their statutes, this was not allowed to happen in an African country without intereference from outsiders.

Mr Chiluba expressed unequivocal support for the Constitutional Amendment bill which he signed into law slightly over a fortnight ago saying it will bring genuine independence to the people of Zambia.

He accused his predecessor, Dr Kenneth Kaunda, of having imposed a brutal dictatorship on the country and its people by ignoring recommendations of the Chona Commission of 1972 which would have resulted in him being voted out of office.

Even the 1991 Mvunga Constitutional Review Commission had come up with recommendations which would have strengthened democracy and enhanced human rights but these were conveniently swept aside.

Mr Chiluba told the cheering hundreds of supporters that democratisation was a logn process and there was need for them to observe the rule of law and co-operte fully with the police as they crack down on the 'Black Mamba' organisation.

Commenting on the arrest of Senior Chief Inyambo of Sesheke district, Mr Chiluba said Chiefs should abide by the Constitution and not get involved in politics.

Those of them wishing to be politicians should step down from their thrones and be counted as full fledged politicians who should be treated as such.

The President noted that it was easy for chiefs to be misguided by political philosophers.

Mr Chiluba maintained that Chief Inyambo was arrested for his involvement in politics and suspected indulgence in the activities of the shadowy organisation 'Black Mamba' and not out of his traditional affiliations.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Election Agency To Leave End Of June


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 17, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - The National Democratic Institute is to pull out of Zambia at the of June once funding from the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) expires.

NDI President Kenneth Wollack said in a statement issued in Lusaka on Monday that the move will affects his organisation's election support programmes and it will the withdrawal of all Lusaka based members of staff. 

''Given NDI's long standing presence in Zambia and our commitment to the democratization process, this decision was a difficult one for us to make,'' Mr Wollack says.

Inspite of the pull back NDI will, however, continue to monitor the situation and if dialogue between civic and political leaders will yield desired results then the institute will resume its programme of activities in zambia, he added.

NDI talks of 'political environment leading up to this year's elections' without going into specifics but hinting that some of these actions may have curtailed electoral competition and participation, political discourse and freedom of expression.

Zambia adopted a law, end of May, which require future presidential candidates to be Zambians whose parents too were Zambians.

Some candidates, like former President Kenneth Kaunda, are precluded from contesting elections by this law since his parents came from Malawi and he himself only renounced his Malawian citizenship in 1969 - five years after taking over as President of Zambia.

Source: ZAMTODAY

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Donors Aid Review In Zambia Won't Derail Agriculture Programme


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 14, 1996 By Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The Ministry of Agriculture has allayed fears that the Agricultural Sector Investment Programme (ASIP) might be derailed following the donors' review of their aid commitments to Zambia.

Agriculture minister Suresh Desai disclosed in an interview yesterday that none of the donor countries had indicated intentions, after their general threats to review multilateral and bilateral relations with Zambia, of cutting aid in the ASIP programme which has so far consumed K1 billion in the continuing efforts to revitalise agriculture. 

"I should say none of the donors has made any indication of halting their aid flow in the ASIP programme," Desai disclosed. "It is for this reason that I feel everything is still on course."

Last month, at a meeting held to review progress on the agricultural reforms, the ministry announced that it had met its contribution of K7 billion towards the first quarter of the programme.

Speaking at the same function which was held on May 16, agriculture permanent secretary, Austin Sichinga, disclosed that the programme would be kicked off by the restructuring of the agriculture ministry which would only retain quality staff.

Government further expressed concern at reservations by some donors to commit themselves to help finance the ASIP.

And the United Nations, through its resident representative, Gary Davies, was quoted in the latest Zambia Farmer magazine as having assured that Zambia would be one of the likely beneficiaries under its US$25 billion special initiative on Africa aimed at improving food availability and water supply.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Science Conservation Group Starts Zambian Wetlands Programme


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 18, 1996


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - The International Union for the Conservation of Nature has started a wetlands programme in western Zambia which aims at giving further protection to the flood-plain, dambo lands, marginal woodlands and fisheries.

Start of the wetlands programme was witnessed by IUCN Southern Africa Regional Director, Yemi Katerere, who explained that the idea is to increase protection the natural habitat of game, birdlife, fish and even domestic animals like cattle.

Mr Katerere disclosed that the programme will consume more than K600 million annually and much of the funding for the scheme will come from the Royal Netherlands government through the Royal Netherlands Embassy in Lusaka. 

Speaking at the launch ceremony Environment Minister, William Harrington, noted that it was only fitting that the wetlands programme was being started in Western Province because the area has for long been a natural habitat for an abundant flock of birdlife, herds of wild game and schools of fresh water fish.

Mr Harrington observed that because of the rich grass on the flood plain the area has also been an important kraal for traditional cattle.

The Minister disclosed that Western Province at the moment accounts for 20 percent of the entire Zambian cattle herd and 25 percent of all traditional cattle sales.

"It is vital to support this particular wetland as it has a major impact on the national economy," Mr Harrington said.

His sentiments were echoed by Ngambela of the Lozi people, Mr Maxwell Mututwa, who told the visitors that natural resource management was not a new phenomenon to people in that part of Zambia.

He disclosed that for centuries there had been un unwritten laws which controlled the hunting of wild game, the culling of bird-life from breeding grounds known as 'sitaka' and drawing of fish from breeding grounds known as 'masa'.

The Ngambela, who is Prime Minister to the traditional ruler the Litunga, noted, however, that though natural resource conservation was a part of the Lozi it was always refreshing to receive teachings on how such matters can be handled in modern times.

He, therefore, thanked IUCN, the Royal Netherlands and the Zambian governments for having chosen the area for the launch of the wetlands programme which may shift to other areas after Western Province.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Copper Lures Chinese To Zambia


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 18, 1996


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - Officials from a Chinese firm arrived in Lusaka to explore posibilities of opening investment in the Zambian copper industry making it the first country in Africa to attract possible mining investment from Beijing.

Management officials from the China National Non-Ferrous Metals Corporation are led by assistant company president, Yang Guneuang, arrived in Lusaka on Monday and proceeded to hold official talks with Mines Permanent Secretary, Joseph Phiri.

Mr Yang said China imports 500,000 tonnes of copper conecntrates a year and his company has been in the business for many, many years now. 

The company is presently capable of exploring, mining, smelting, refining and processing copper into consumer goods and that was why it was interested in Zambia since the country is a 'granary' of the raw material.

While in Zambia the Chinese team from CNNM Corporation will visit Baluba Mine in Luanshya, Mufulira Mine and surface installations like the concentrator and smelter in other parts of the Copperbelt.

Briefing the Chinese team Dr Phiri assured the visitors that they were not wrong in picking Zambia for their source of raw resources because the copper ore in Zambia assayed at a much higher level than elsewhere in the world.

He pointed out that in the main it averaged 3.8 or 4 percent copper content and this was by far much higher.

In addition Zambia has a very highly skilled labour force as over the past 30 years more people have been trained in such fields as engineering, geology, metallurgy and actual mining.

He noted that the interest which the Chinese had shown in Zambia was evidence that the outside world was receiving positively the new investment incentive highlighted in the new Mines and Minerals Act.

He told Mr Yang that Zambian mines had the infrastructure but still required private sector investment for them to operate efficiently.

Following in the footsteps of Mr Yang's delegation will be coming the a government Chinese delegation headed by Vice-Minister of commerce, Trade and Industry Liu Shazai who is expected to sign several aid agreements with the Zambian government.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


186 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Soccer Fan: 'Bomb Alarmist Crushed To Death'


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 18, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 
Lusaka - The man who sounded a false alarm at the Independence Stadium in Lusaka igniting a stampede in which nine people were killed was also claimed by the same frenzy as he was crushed underfoot to death.

Survivors of the tragedy interviewed yesterday said the alarmist shouted that theres was a bomb so that he could create room for himself to manouvre quickly out of the stadium.

At the University Teaching Hospital (UTH) one of the survivors, Mr Kelvin Munkanta, said from his hospital bed that the spectator shouted in vernacular that a bomb was about to explode at Gate 'D' as people were trooping out of the stadium.

"I was right next to the man who shouted that there was a bomb and immediately people heard this they retreated," he said. 

"I saw the alarmist fall down and several others fell on him. I fell too but was lucky my brother pulled me up. Suddenly several people were lying dead," Mr Munkanta recalled.

Police public relations officer Francis Musonda said he had not received a full report on the incident but police had launched investigations.

Mr Munkanta said police manning Gate 'D' closed it in panic after the false alarm causing more congestion as fans were surging forward while others were pushing forward.

Football Association of Zambia Chairman, Michael Chiti, regretted the tragedy.

Mr Chiti, Youth Sport and Child Development Ministry Permanent Secretary Arthur Yoyo and officials from Federation of International Football Associations (FIFA) on Monday returned to Independence Stadium to inspect the area where the tragedy occured and afterwards Mr Yoyo reported that all was well at the stadium.

There were no collapsed walls or broken gates. Neither were there any rolls of barbed which could have prevented jubilant fans from exiting the stadium properly.

Mr Yoyo promised to inform the nation fully about findings of the investigation into the tragedy which is now underway.

Youth, Sport and child Development Minister Samuel Miyanda described the event as a sad occurence since the national team had won the encounter with Sudan.

Among the Zambian soccer heroes the tragedy cast a long dark shadow over what should have been their biggest celebration party.

The talk in their Hotel Inter-Continental rooms and over breakfast was about the tragedy that claimed lives of eight soccer fans at the end of Sunday's 3-0 victory over Sudan at Independence stadium.

"That kind of thing shouldn't happen at a football match. Eight lives is too many and although no one seems sure what caused it, it just should not happen at a football match," said midfielder Joel Bwalya - young brother of star team Captain Kalusha Bwalya.

"We had a terrific atmosphere in the stadium for the match. I would say the best we have ever experienced and it's a great shame that some of those who helped cheer the team to victory are now not around to celebrate with us," said the Beligium-based Joel.

Kenneth Malitoli, a Zambian forward, said the tragedy came too soon after the 1993 Gabon plane crash which claimed the lives of 18 Zambia internationals and 12 others en route to a World Cup qualification match in Senegal.

"It's going to scare the fans away from the game. We didn't need this tragedy so soon after Gabon. We were all geared up for celebrations after a great game and a great result but you cannot go out and celebrate with this thing weighing on your mind," Malitoli said.

Defender Allan Kamwanga who sat out the match on the bench said the deaths and the injured spoiled the victory party.

Harrison chongo described the incident as bad for Zambian football.

"Zambians are crazy about soccer and to get something like that happening after winning is very sad and bad for the game," he said.

In his comments after the inspection tour of the stadium Permanent Secretary Yoyo disclosed that government had already drawn up plans for construction of a much bigger stadium in Lusaka as well as the renovation of Independence stadium so it can reach high international standards.

Mr Yoyo said these plans, will also include the rebuilding of Dag Hammerskjoeld stadium in Ndola which was razed by the Kaunda regime almost ten years ago but never replaced.

Mr Yoyo says government is determined to see that these plans are brought to fruition within the next two years in a bid to advance the game of soccer a step further.

Source: ZAMTODAY-Times of Zambia


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Football Association Didn't Over-Sell Tickets


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 18, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Facing mounting pressure over the death of ten soccer fans, the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) has refuted reports that the match was over-sold saying that only about thirty thousand tickets were sold.

"We did not over-sell tickets. When we realised that more people were buying tickets than expected we ordered the stoppage of the sales. I personally instructed Ahmed Pandor to see to it that no more tickets were sold," said FAZ chairman Michael Chiti of his committee member, Pandor who also admitted that ticket sales were stopped earlier than planned. 

But some fans who were at Gate D charged that the accident was as a result of the decision to maintain the separation of Gate D from the other gates.

"What FAZ officials could have done was simply to open the joining entrances from Gate D to Gates C and E. It was not necessary to maintain the status quo of those paying K2,500 to be packed at Gate D when the space could not accommodate them all, they should have opened Gate C and gate E entrances," said a fan.

Chiti, who had gone on a fact-finding tour of the accident area at the Independence Stadium yesterday, further claimed that when it was observed that the Stadium was full, entrance was stopped even to those people with tickets.

"When we saw that at around 10:00 hours the Stadium was full, we closed some gates and in fact, we also had to let some FAZ officials with VIP tickets stand on the running track of the stadium. And with about twenty minutes before the end of the match, we opened gates to let people move out," said Chiti who regretted the deaths of the fans.

"On behalf FAZ, I wish to express my sadness over the death of the soccer fans. When playing a game like the one we had against Sudan, we had a lot of support from fans and it is actually the fans that inspired the team," said Chiti.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large OAU Finds Zambia Guilty Over Senes


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 17, 1996 by Mabeni Sikalyabwanda


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) found Zambia with a case to answer after allegedly violating Article 12 of the African Charter that does not permit any member country to deport, expel or chase aliens en masse.

Passing judgment on a case advanced by a Senegalese Non-Governmental Organis- ation(NGO) that presented the case of over 500 Senegalese expelled from Zambia last year, the OAU Commission for Human Rights represented by Tanzania, Nigeria, Tunisia and Egypt has ordered Zambia to compensate all the Senegalese forced out of the country in United States dollars.

The amount has not yet been revealed but University of Zambia Law School lecturer Michelo Hansungule told a human rights workshop held for all judges from the Supreme, High Court and Industrial relations Courts at Mosi-o-Tunya Hotel on Thursday last week that Zambia was found to be in a habit of violating the African Charter to which she was a signatory. 

"The African Commission on Human Rights made a ruling , especially over the property the Senegalese who were deported and this would cost Zambia dearly, human rights should be respected if this country has to enjoy international commendation, failure to which the international community would make us suffer,"Hansungule said.

Hansungule said Zambia failed to defend the accusations of violating the Charter and instead admitted to the charges levelled and expressed willingness to pay compensation.

"We are just waiting to be told how much we shall pay as a nation,"Hansungule said.

Last year the government expelled more than 500 Senegalese, 8 Zaireans, 2 Ivorians and 2 Ghanaians - a move which can now not be defended by the government.

But the Judges meeting took a swipe at the ruling saying the African Commission to which the country was not represented was biased and full of incompetent human rights lawyers. The Judges accused the Commission of being unfair to Zambia.

Hansungule, however, reminded the audience that Article 12 of the Charter applied to every African state and cited a case against Uganda which she lost when some Nigerian nationals were expelled.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


189 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Parties Warn No Consensus, No Elections


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 18, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - No elections will be held this year if the Constitutional impasse and electoral process are not resolved, opposition Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) warned yesterday.

ZDC deputy general secretary, Azwell Banda, said in an interview yesterday that his party will not accept what he called "feudal and quack" elections and advised the ruling MMD to revert to the 1991 Constitution for this year's polls.

"Unless the Constitutional issue is resolved and all the parties sit down and review the electoral process, it will be impossible to hold elections this year," Banda warned. "There will be agitation. We have committees in all the 150 polling districts. We are going to set them in motion as soon as the MMD government announces the dates for the elections. Whether this translates into war is neither here nor there." 

Banda poured scorn on President Chiluba's "habit of arresting political opponents" and warned that it won't work.

"He can fill up all the jails but injustice is injustice and it will be fought. It won't work," Banda carped.

Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) chairman, Rodger Chongwe, also maintained in a seperate interview yesterday that the opposition will not allow the elections to take place if the two issues are not resolved.

"During the rally on June 8, we said that we are not going to allow the elections to take place if there is no re-registration of voters. The Nikuv register is deficient and the courts have said so," Chongwe said. " In fact, as of today nobody is a registered voter in Zambia because Nikuv has not issued anyone with a voter's card."

Chongwe added that the question of the independence of the electoral commission and equitable use of government facilities and the government owned electronic media should also be resolved before the commencement of the elections.

Both Chongwe and Banda implored the donor community to step up pressure on Zambia and not release aid so that the MMD can do the needful and quickly revert to the 1991 Constitution.

"That is the only civilised way of preventing catastrophe in this country," Banda said.

Chongwe added: "Chiluba knows that he is no longer popular and his days are numbered. The incident at the Independence Stadium when ten soccer fans died in a stampede after security officers closed most of the gates until after his departure is a sign that he is more freightened now than ever before."

On Wednesday last week Foundation for Democratic Process (FODEP) president Bishop John Mambo advised against going to the polls with the current electoral register and implored on the MMD to return to the negotiating table.

"The only way forward is through the interparty meeting. Let's bury our differences," Mambo advised. " We cannot afford to habour hatred."

But President Chiluba has maintained that governmet will use the recently adopted controversial Consitutional (Amendment) Bill during the forthcoming elections.

Business and Finance Zambia Delays Continental Air Routes


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 18, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - Plans by the transport and communications ministry to finally issue the intercontinental air routes this month have been derailed again.

The ministry is instead concentrating on the delayed air service tests being carried out on Aero Zambia's newly acquired aircraft. 

This was disclosed in an interview with the ministry's permanent secretary, Ronald Mukuma, who explained that the committee responsible for allocating the air service routes had failed to sit due to on-going tests.

"As earlier reported we were supposed to sit by the end of last month but we have had other commitments that have led to the stalling of progress in that area," Mukuma disclosed in an interview yesterday, adding: " We had problems during the inspection of the Aero Zambia B737 aircraft."

Mukuma, however, disclosed that the committee with representation from both the Department of Civil Aviation and the transport ministry, would be sitting to allocate the still 'vacant' intercontinental routes.

Local airlines are most interested in the Lusaka-London route where defunct Zambia Airways slot at Heathrow has remained unserviced since the airline's collapse almost two years ago.

Business and Finance Reduced Border Formalities To Aid Southern Transportation


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 18, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambian government is signing an agreement with South Africa and some neighbouring countries to ensure that bureaucracy at border posts is removed.

Communications and transport deputy minister, Gilbert Mululu disclosed this in an interview in Lusaka on Saturday during the introduction of a new luxury coach by a South African company, Translux. 

Executive manager for Translux, Chris Brand, said in an earlier interview that the duration of the trip from Johannesburg to Lusaka, which takes one day, would be reduced further if the lengthy border formalities were removed.

"We could cut down on the time by more than three hours if the formalities were simplified," Brand said.

But Mululu said the government was concerned with such delays and an agreement will be signed soon to remove these delays.

Mululu said the understanding to be signed will benefit both cargo and passenger transporters to encourage more investment in the liberalised transportation sector.

And operations director for Budget Conference -- the Zambian agents for Translux, Enock Kabwe, said the service would soon be extended to the Copperbelt.

But Brand said the company will not be able to use the latest low suspension buses due to the poor state of the roads.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Opposition: Electoral Act Tailored To President


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 18, 1996 by A Staff Writer


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition parties last week, charged that the move by the ruling MMD government to change the presidential qualifications in the Electoral Act was an attempt to "accommodate" President Frederick Chiluba's troubled candidacy.

The Liberal Progressive Party (LPF), Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) and UNIP all called the changes a means by which to enable President Chiluba to qualify as a presidential candidate in the forthcoming presidential and general elections in October this year.

The amendment contained in section 9 (1) (d) and which make it easy for President Chiluba to stand as President requires the candidate to produce certificates which cannot be questioned in courts of law. 

"A candidate for election as President shall deliver - a certificate of birth or where the candidate does not possess a birth certificate, a certificate from the area of his birth issued by (ii) the Chief, whose certificate shall be endorsed by a maternal and paternal relative, as to the truth of the facts stated in the certificate; or

(i) District Secretary;

(iii) a representative of a church certifying the place of birth of the candidate and that of his parents and such certificate shall be conclusive as to the facts therein stated and shall not be questioned by any court, authority or the returning Officer."

But LPF president Rodger Chongwe wondered why the courts would not have the power to question such an important qualification.

"Village life is such that a chief would not know all the babies born in his village in a day. This will create more lies than we have had before. Chiluba is trying to cover up his tracks," Chongwe charged last Friday.

And UNIP publicity secretary Bweendo Mulengela said at his press conference on Tuesday that the MMD had realised the problems President Chiluba would face because of his parentage that is still in question as he has failed to prove it and had decided to amend the Electoral Act to qualify himself.

"They want President so-called relatives to testify to his having been born in Zambia so he can qualify to stand as President," Mulengela said.

ZDC deputy general secretary, Azwell Banda, said his party was aware that between now and the elections, the Electoral Act would be amended to enable President Chiluba, who would had serious problems with his place of birth and parentage, to stand.

"He has already disqualified himself by birth and descent because he is clearly not a Zambian," Banda charged. " The Act cannot be higher than the Constitution."

Elections Office spokesman and assistant director, Joel Sikazwe, confirmed the impending amendment to the Electoral Act which has become necessary after the Constitution was amended but denied having any knowledge of what the new Act would state.

The Electoral Act of 1991 which is now being amended, says nothing about parentage and only requires a person to show he is a Zambian, 35 years and above and has mustered 200 signatures from his supporters.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
