Africa News


June, 1996


Science Zambian President Praises NGOs' AIDS Fight


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 18, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba has commended NGOs for the role they are playing in the fight against the spread of AIDS.

In a speech read on his behalf by health minister Katele Kalumba at the officialJopening of the sixth NGO AIDS conference at Lusaka's Mulungushi International Conference Centre yesterday, President Chiluba said NGOs are grass-roots based and are therefore an effective channel of communication between the target groups, donor agencies and the government.

President Chiluba assured the participants that the government was committed to fighting the AIDS pandemic. 

"We are going to make AIDS a top priority for external resource allocation so that Africa benefits from the maximum international cooperation and solidarity in overcoming the epidemic and its impact,"JPresident Chiluba said, adding that Zambia was a signatory to the Dakar declaration for global efforts in the AIDs fight.

Southern African Network of AIDS Services Organisation (SANASO), chairperson Dr Clarence Mini of South Africa, called on the government to re-affirm its commitment to ensure that all people get to know the causes of AIDS. He also implored the government to implement suitable policies in HIV/AIDS prevention and ensure equal access to prevention facilities.

"Fullest political commitment to mobilise society is crucial," Dr Mini said, advising: "No taboos should be allowed to interfere with human life."

Last Tuesday, youth, sport and child development minister Samuel Miyanda disclosed that 500 Zambians are infected with the HIV/AIDs virus every day.

Addressing participants at a peer educators facilitators workshop, Miyanda said "the retrospective epidemiological analysis by the World Health Organisation (WHO) of HIV transmission in East and Central Africa illustrates the growing vulnerability of the youth, particularly young women, to HIV infection".

The conference which has attracted participants from the Southern African region is funded by the Norwegian Agency for Development (NORAD), Swedish International Development Agency (SIDA) and the AIDS/ STD leprosy control programme in Zambia.

LANGUAGE: English

194 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Ten People Die In President's Stadium Security


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 17, 1996 by Reuben Tonga and Samson Mujuda


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Lusaka - Police security measures to close the gates of Independence Stadium until after the departure of the Presidential motorcade led to the death of ten people and fifty-two injured in a stampede that ensued thereafter.

Gates which are normally left wide open for most part of second half were yesterday kept locked to allow for the safe passage of the President.

And one of the injured, John Chibwe of Chelstone, said in an interview last night after being discharged from the University Teaching Hospital (UTH) that security men had put barbed wire across the gates, and closed Gate D.

"Police blocked the outlet and when they opened the gates we fell down. I don't know why the police blocked the way for us," Chibwe carped. "If it were not for the security men the stampede wouldn't have happened." 

But by 20:00 hours last night, Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) officials were not aware of the accident.

"We are not aware of that incident but if it is true, it is a very sad development, but I think the chairman could make an official statement later as he is not here," said FAZ treasurer Musa Kasonka in a telephone interview last night.

An eye witness, Gilbert Mbewe, blamed the security men and accused them of being overzealous.

"The police caused that stampede," Mbewe said in an interview at the UTH after he had been discharged last night. "Innocent lives have been lost because of being overzealous."

But Inspector General of Police Francis Ndhlovu, claimed that it was not true that his men were trying to shield the President.

"Its not true that police were trying to protect the President, the true version is that as the fans were moving out of the stadium, one of them shouted that there was a bomb within the area they were seated, and hence they rushed out of the stadium and in the process, lives were claimed," Ndhlovu said in an interview last night. " But I can confirm that by the time I reached UTH, eight fans were reported dead and fifty-two others injured."

But the person who Ndhlovu claims to have shouted "bomb" has neither been identified nor arrested by police.

But a reporter from the one of the state owned newspapers, who near the scene, accused Ndhlovu of telling lies.

"It is a lie that there was a person who shouted that there was a bomb. The gate was blocked while the people were pushing wanting to get out," she said. "And when it was opened those who were in front fell down and were trampled on. And it took the police and the Red Cross about thirty minutes to come and pick up the victims."

When President Chiluba was entering the stadium paramilitary police men armed took positions while State House security men balanced on the doors of the cars that were in the Presidential motorcade.

Through out the game the paramilitary men kept on brandishing their guns with the barrels directed towards spectators.

"This is too much. If the President feels uncomfortable with his safety, he should avoid coming to such places," a soccer fan carped. "This is inconveniencing us."

After the game had finished President Chiluba's motorcade sped off at a break-neck speed out of the stadium.

A revisist to the UTH by The Post found that the police post had been sealed off by armed paramilitary police with the bodies paraded for identification.

And Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) yesterday described the accident as most sad for the Zambian people after the 3-0 victory over Sudan.

"We wish to state that the death of the soccer fans is regrettable and were are sending our condolences to the families of the dead fans and the Football association of Zambia," ZDC secretary general Derrick Chitala said in a telephone message to The Post last night, adding: " But all this is as result of negligence on the part of both the UNIP and MMD governments who have failed to increase the seating capacity at the stadium, they know that soccer is our number sport but they still fail to invest into it."


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


195 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large New Executive for Global Coalition


BYLINE: Global Coalition For Africa June 18, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Washington, DC - The Co-Chairpersons of the Global Coalition for Africa (GCA) are pleased to announce the appointment of the new Executive Secretary, Ambassador Ahmedou Ould-Abdallah, effective June 15, 1996. Ambassador Ould-Abdallah has succeeded the late Dr. Boubakar Diaby-Quattara, who was the first GCA Executive Secretary from its inception in 1990 until his death in April, 1996.

A citizen of Mauritania, Ambassador Ould-Abdallah will be continuing a distinguished career in public service during which he has occupied senior posts in both his own country and in the United Nations. He served as the Special Representative of the UN Secretary General in Burundi from November, 1993, to October, 1995. Prior to his service in Burundi, he was at the UN Headquarters in New York as the Special Coordinator for Africa and the Least Developed Countries, a position to which he returned following completion of his assignment as Special Representative. In this capacity, he represented the UN which was co-organizer, along with the Government of Japan and the GCA, of the Tokyo International Conference on African Development (TICAD) in October 1993. 

Ambassador Ould-Abdallah has held several important posts in his native Mauritania, including Director-General of National Industries (1968-71), Minister of Commerce and Transportation (1971), Ambassador to the United States of America (1973-76), the European Union, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands (1976-79), and Minister of Foreign Affairs (1979-80). He was also a member of the Board of Directors and CEO of Societe Nationale Industrielle et Miniere, Mauritania's largest corporation involved in iron ore mining, in 1980.

Ambassador Ould-Abdallah is also a co-founder and board member of Transparency International, an international non-governmental organization devoted to fighting corruption, and the author of numerous articles on preventive diplomacy and development issues.

Born in 1940 in Hassi-Abdallah, Mauritania, Ambassador Ould-Abdallah received his higher education at the Universities of Grenoble and Paris, Sorbonne, and the Paris Institute of Etudes Politiques in France. He has been honored by the Governments of Mauritania, Senegal, and Belgium.

The Global Coalition for Africa (GCA) is a North-South forum dedicated to forging of policy consensus on development priorities among African governments, their northern partners, and non-governmental groups working in Africa. The Coalition is based on the premise that Africa can grow only from within, but that to do so it needs outside support. It seeks to improve the working partnership between Africa and the North which has been evolving for many years.

At a time when sweeping changes are occurring around the world, the GCA seeks to keep Africa on the world agenda and to mobilize international support.

The small GCA secretariat is based in Washington, DC at 1750 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW, Suite 1204.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


196 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 14, 1996 by Olu Sarr PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1957 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Although African editorials this week focused on seemingly local issues, they were of wider appeal than might at first meet the eye.

The Times of Swaziland, for example, commented on the much criticised effort to introduce a trade control bill in parliament. The proposed bill bars foreigners from running restaurants, cafes and general stores in the country.

"Jobs offered by anybody should now be welcomed, whether they are from blacks, whites, browns, yellows or little green men," it said. 

The job-seeker on the streets doesn't "give a damn who he works for," it said, "as long as be gets paid and can see some sort of future ahead and gets experience."

As many foreigners as possible needed to come in and start businesses, it said, so Swazis could learn from them. In addition, it said there was already "enough legislation" to protect the work force against unscrupulous employers.

The new Industrial Relations Act, the Prepared Trade Central Bill and the constant racialism raised in the senate, it added, were "what will deter most decent investors" from bringing to Swaziland their ideas, money and experience.

"Wake up Swaziland, while our leaders are fighting each other over who holds the power, our economy is slowly bleeding to death," it concluded.

The semi-official New Nigeria, published in the northern city of Kaduna, focused on the 26th meeting of the Council of Ministers of the Nigeria-Niger Joint Commission for Cooperation. The paper hailed it as an example of what inter-African relations should be.

The meeting ended with a commitment to strengthen cooperation on transborder security and enhance the socio-economic status of the peoples of the two countries.

It reaffirmed the commitment of the neighboring countries to the objectives of subregional organisations like the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and the Organization of African Unity.

The joint communique, issued at the end of the one-day event, also reiterated the determination of Nigeria and Niger to enhance bilateral relations in the areas of agriculture, livestock, water resources, control of water hyacinth and pests, health, international road links and rail transportation. Others are the redemarcation of Nigeria-Niger boundary, telecommunications, and postal services, as well as the supply of electricity to Niger.

"The significance of the annual ministerial session can be viewed against the background of increasing socio-economic interdependence and unity among regional and subregional blocs worldwide," it said.

"The fact that it has continued to be held regularly since 1970 testifies to the existence of excellent bilateral relations between Nigeria and Niger," it said.

It welcomed "any initiative" to enhance bilateral relations between Nigeria and its four French-speaking neighbors.

"It is a matter of concern, therefore, that while relations on our northern border remains pleasant, the same cannot be said of other borders, notably in the east where armed robbery and recurrent incidents of incursions by Chadian gendarmes, as well as the crisis with Cameroon over the Bakassi peninsula constitute major security threats," it added.

"There is a crying need to build on the gains of such initiatives as the Nigeria-Niger relations with our other neighbors towards fulfilling the cardinal principles of ECOWAS.

"Nigeria's leading role on the continent emphazises the need for her to maintain excellent relations with her neighbors, and the Nigeria-Niger Commission is a worthwhile factor in this direction." Notwithstanding such example of excellent inter-African relations, the privately-owned Dakar newspaper, Sud Quotidien, criticised Nigeria's internal political shortcomings. Its comment came against the background of the lack of support for the general strike called by Nigerian opposition.

It said that three-years after the annulled presidential elections, no country had punished Nigeria beyond the sanctions imposed by the Commonwealth. It asked whether this was not because Nigeria was seen as a large and important country, compared with other military-run states in Africa.

"So, it is preferable to attack the small states like Niger, which was forced to bring forward its date for elections, than the giant of Africa were there are still political assassinations," it said.

Turning to the weakness of Africa's opposition in challenging ruling parties, Sud used the Central Africa Republic as an example.

It cited an unidentified opposition member who joined the besieged ruling party of President Ange-Felix Patasse's Movement for the Liberation of the People of Central Africa, despite protests from his former colleagues. The individual, it said, told his former comrades that being in opposition did not pay, particularly when it was sterile.

"This statement is the best illustration of Africa's political reality these last years. In fact, the fight for ideals has given way to to opportunism," it said. "The phenomenon, already perceptible under one-party systems, seems to be developing and flourishing under (political) pluralism."

It also cited an unidentified head of state from central Africa who, it said, stated that it was the belly which was talking when the politician defected, meaning hunger.

"When it is the case, reason gives way to this urgent need which has to be satisfied immediately. The solution would be to share out the loot, to invite anyone to the feast. Ideological considerations and beliefs can wait if they are not suited to the task at hand," it said.

For its part the Bangui newspaper, Vouma (meaning fly) commented on the decision to call in French troops to put down an army mutiny in the Central African Republic.

"While Central Africans were outraged by the soldiers' mutiny, they were disappointed by the president's appeal for a foreign army, and the French army at that, to intervene in a purely national affair to subdue his own troops, his elite army," it said.

"One wonders whether demanding the resignation of a leader, even an elected one, and purchasing a new khaki outfit decorated with medals, a new pair of boots, are sufficient elements to provoke a fraticidal war?" it said.

"At any rate, there are (now) embers under the ashes. And the one continually stoking the fire is not the Central African citizen but our brother and friend (France?)," it said.

Business and Finance Ethiopian Air Set For Five Fokker-50's


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethiopian Airlines is to receive its ordered five Fokkerr 50 airplanes in a not distant future, the Royal Netherlands Embassy here announced Thursday.

The headquarters of the Ethiopian Airlines, however, declined to confirm the statement. 

In a statement it sent to the Ethiopian News Agency, the Dutch Embassy said the first Fokker-50 airplane for the Ethiopian Airlines is expected to arrive in Addis Ababa in the second half of next July.

The embassy said the delivery of the five Fokker-50 airplanes to the Ethiopian Airlines was materialised due to the intervention of the Netherlands Government.

The Ethiopian Airlines, which celebrated its golden jubilee last April has ordered five Fokker-50 airplanes in November 1995 for their high standard of passenger comfort, their sturdy and durable construction suitable to the topography of Ethiopia.

Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia Witness Says Emperor Killed on Third Try


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Addis Ababa - The eighth and ninth witnesses testifying for the Special Prosecutor's Office (SPO) in the case involving top Derg officials clamed here yesterday that Emperor Haile-Selasie appeared lively and in good mood the night before he was found dead.

Both former personal valets of the Emperor, the Witnesses told the First Criminal Bench of the Central High Court that following a successful surgery in late June 1975, his health had made a miraculous recovery.

A 59-year old pensioner who claimed to have been very close to the monarch until the latter's murder, the eighth witness said that two attempts on the life of the Emperor had failed before the actual deed was committed on the night of Nehase 20, 1967 E.C.

According to him, a certain colonel Daniel Asfaw had three days earlier set on electrical device under the chair where the Emperor had been seated to electrocute him but failed. On the third days, the same person came to the room along with the Grand Palace's head nurse, ordered the witness to stay out and forced the Emperor to take a tablet which the Co. said would be "helpful for his vigour". He said that the Emperor refused to take the tablet and pleaded with them to summon his valet. "At this moment" he recalled "I pushed the door open only to find the Emperors face with sweat and the two people meticulously searching for the tablet that had fallen on the floor." He said that the two people at last found the tablet and took it with them with "utmost care."

The ninth witness, 54, who said he had been working at the palace since he was 15, told the court that he was knocked unconscious with shock when he found the Emperor dead on the morning of Nehase 21, 1967 E.C.

According to him, the king was grotesquely made to lie with his face up and with a piece of bandage around his neck instead of a sheet. He also sniffed in the room something similar to the one he did when the Emperor underwent medical surgery.

Both witnesses said that the night before the murder, their beds were thrown out of the small compound in which the victim was detained and made to spend the night elsewhere.

They told the court that they were later held prisoners in the palace for two months after which they were realised with a severe warning "not to say anything about the Emperor's death."

A tenth witness on his part elaborated on how the burial was conducted secretly. He said that following order by Merid Nigussie, he personally assigned people to dig four burial lots.

According to this former engineer at the palace, the three lots were of normal size while the fourth, the actual burial site of the Emperor, was 3 meters by 3 meters. He said a room was built over it which later served as an office for ex-dictator Mengistu HaileMariam.

The reason behind the digging of four burial lots, the witness said, was to mislead the staff on the whereabouts of the secret spot.

This same person pinpointed the spot when Transitional Government authorities disinterred the remains of the Emperor.

Virtually all the defence attorneys said they had no hard and fast cross- questions to put all witnesses.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


200 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia Food For Thousands Of Affected By Afar Flood


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency June 14, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Addis Ababa - Food, clothing and tents were sent for about 50,000 people forced by floods to flee their homes in Afar Regional State over the weekend, the Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission announced Monday.

Deputy Commissioner Berhane Gizaw said 200 quintals of biscuit, 2,000 blankets, 100 tents and 60 plastic rolls have been sent to Bure-Mudaitu and Gewane areas.

Ato Berhane said similar emergency aid has also been dispatched from Dire Dawa to victims of flood in Mustahil along the banks of Wabe Shebele River in Somali Regional State. 

The Deputy Commissioner said his office has been informed of 50,000 people fleeing homes in Bure-Mudaitu, Gewane and Afambo areas because of the overflooding of the Awash River, while the extent of the damage is pending investigation.

The emergency aid, however, was meant to help children, mothers, the elderly and those injured by the flood, he said.

He said that verifying team of DPPC had visited Gewane and Bure-Mudaitu last Wednesday to see the extent of damage caused by the flood and the same team will go tomorrow for further investigation.

The deputy Commissioner said he had received no information until Monday noon concerning required emergency aid or about the disaster from the Afar Regional State Disaster Prevention and Preparedness bureau.

He said the Commission is, moreover, preparing to dispatch additional food aid to the victims of the flood as the bureau is still in the formative phase and has limitations.

Meanwhile, torrential rain that fell last week in Chero district of West Hararge Zone destroyed standing crops on 738 hectares of land and killed about 346 domestic animals, the wordea council announced.

The council said standing crops damaged by the heavy rain which lasted almost a week included maize and sorghum as well as coffee, banana chat, and horticultural plantations.

The council said that over 200 monkeys, bushbucks, greater kudus and rabbits were also taken away by floods following the rains.

Some of the victims of the heavy rain approached by ENA reporter urged the government and welfare organizations to rehabilitate them as they have lost all their belongings.

However, Ato Benko Taye, head of the East Harerge Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Department, said his office has not yet received reports on the problem, but pledged to dispatch the necessary aid after a through study.

A similar torrential rain has also destroyed a 60-hectare coffee seddling in Godere Woreda of the Gambella Regional State, the woreda council reported.

The council said the rain that fell last Friday for 18 hours non-stop caused an estimated 150,000 birr loss.

Africa News


June, 1996


United States and Africa Assessment of USAID in South Africa Published


BYLINE: Africa Policy Information Center June 13, 1996


LENGTH: 3308 words


 

Washington - The Africa Policy Information Center announces its latest publication, USAID in South Africa: Learning Lessons, Continuing Debates. This 112-page book, written by Douglas Tilton and edited by Jim Cason, is a timely assessment of the strengths and weaknesses of USAID s South Africa program over the past decade. The following excerpts--an Executive Summary and the concluding policy recommendations--provide an introduction to the central themes of the study.

Executive Summary

In a decade when foreign aid is increasingly under attack as inefficient, unsuccessful, and irrelevant to the US national interest, the South Africa aid program has been held up as a model for a new type of aid -- foreign aid that works. Over the last decade the US has spent nearly $1 billion on programs to assist non-governmental organizations and lawyers defending victims of apartheid, to strengthen community organizations, and to help South Africans develop adult education programs to meet the needs of their new society.

Just as the US aid program in South Africa made a contribution in the period leading up to the establishment of a democratic system in that country, so this study suggests that foreign aid to Africa can play an important role in assisting African development initiatives. At the same time, it argues that foreign aid programs, both in South Africa and elsewhere on the continent, need to be fundamentally refocused to support more directly long-term, sustainable, and equitable development. 

Evaluations of the US Agency for International Development (USAID) program in South Africa have praised its innovative character and emphasized its impact. The US was, for example, the largest single donor to voter education efforts during South Africa's first non-racial national election. Since then, American assistance has helped the new government and non- governmental organizations to build houses, to restructure government ministries, to improve the educational system, and to address other legacies of apartheid.

The case study in this book highlights these successes and in particular the program's strength in responding to a changing environment. During the past decade, USAID provided valuable assistance to South Africans working to end apartheid.

At the same time, there is room for improvement. USAID has articulated a commitment to making disadvantaged South Africans the main beneficiaries of its work. But USAID s recent initiatives have not been as successful in addressing the fundamental inequalities in South African society. Generations of segregation and apartheid policies have left most black South Africans with little access to housing, education, health care, and many of the other benefits of modern society. Addressing these legacies is the primary task of Nelson Mandela's government. Yet there is a danger that in the post-apartheid period the small, relatively affluent sector of the urban black population that has found regular employment will enjoy the bulk of the benefits from development planning while a large portion of the black population is left behind.

The report suggests that the USAID mission subordinated the goal of enhancing low-income households' access to housing to a more overtly political objective: maximizing the market-orientation of the post-apartheid South African economy. The US assistance program for housing construction was designed to frame the public debate over housing and to point the new government towards specific policy choices by promoting a relatively narrow range of market-based initiatives.

One historic strength of the US program has been its emphasis on supporting non-governmental and community-based organizations. The reports endorses continued US support for civil society. At the same time, both as a practical matter and as a matter of principle, US foreign aid to South Africa must be structured to support and sustain development strategies designed by South Africans both within the government and in local communities. One key test for foreign assistance should be how well it helps South Africans to create their own independent institutions that can continue to promote long term, sustainable, and equitable development after the last US aid worker has left.

The study concludes that the weaknesses of the South African aid program can be traced largely to policy decisions made in Washington. Consequently, USAID personnel have to deal with a complex and shifting set of priorities that make consistent long-term support based on the needs of the beneficiaries nearly impossible. This contradiction can only be addressed through a reevaluation of Washington s foreign aid priorities. The author has therefore identified several policy recommendations for US aid programs in South Africa.

1) Strengthen local control of the development process: The US must work to strengthen the participation of both the South African government and local community-based organizations in designing the structure, content, and priorities of US assistance programs in South Africa.

2) Reduce economic inequality: The US should structure its programs so that the poorest 50 percent of the population are the primary beneficiaries and so as to strengthen the ability of this segment of the population to organize and to articulate its needs.

3) Strengthen local level, community-based and non-governmental organizations: The US should continue to work in partnership with South African-controlled community and non-governmental organizations, but must strive to channel its aid more effectively in order to strengthen these organizations' capacity to deliver services, to engage in policy advocacy, and to realize their own, internally-defined, development agendas.

There are compelling reasons to continue to provide assistance to the new government in South Africa, both to support that government through this critical transition period and to enable South Africa to become an engine for development and growth in the entire region. But to achieve these objectives the US assistance program in South Africa must be fundamentally refocused in order to support long-term, sustainable, and equitable development.

Policy Recommendations for Future Programs

Two messages emerge from the preceding discussion of USAID programs in South Africa, both of which have clear implications for the continuing debate over US foreign assistance policy:

(1) US aid to South Africa should be continued. The history of USAID's involvement in South Africa, particularly its support for South African organizations working to end apartheid and to establish a more just political and economic order, has demonstrated that US assistance can help to improve conditions for poor communities. Such programs have had the greatest beneficial impact when they have enhanced the capacity of South Africans to act on the basis of their own assessments of the problems confronting them and their own priorities for change.

South Africa's transition to democracy has not resolved the enormous array of social, political, and economic problems generated by apartheid and by the centuries of oppression on which apartheid was founded. Democratic institutions simply give South Africans a mechanism by which they can begin to rebuild their society, but the extent to which they are able to do this will be determined by the resources at their disposal. At a time when many foreign governments are curtailing aid to South Africa, US assistance assumes increasing importance.

(2) The US assistance program in South Africa needs to be refocused. South Africans are working to identify a development path which is simultaneously sustainable and equitable. USAID's growing emphasis on market-oriented approaches is often inconsistent with the commitment to fair and balanced growth articulated by many South African community leaders. This divergence has become more marked in recent years as USAID has devoted increasing attention and resources to its private-sector projects. It is time for a reexamination of the program's direction and a reorientation of its activities.

Both as a practical matter and as a matter of principle, US aid to South Africa must be structured to support and sustain development strategies designed by South Africans, including government officials and community representatives. US assistance should help South Africans to create independent institutions that can sustain equitable development even after the last foreign aid worker has left.

Specifically, US assistance programs in South Africa should be refocused in order to:

* Enhance local control of the development process. US assistance programs must allow South Africans to determine their own development strategies, priorities, and objectives and must respect this emerging agenda. In practice, this means soliciting greater participation by both the South African government and local community-based organizations in designing the structure, content, and goals of US assistance programs.

The new, democratically elected government in South Africa has established several structures to improve the coordination of foreign assistance. These aim to ensure that foreign aid is allocated within the overall priorities of the government's Reconstruction and Development Program and to prevent project duplication or unfunded budgetary obligations. South Africa also has a network of strong and vibrant community organizations, church groups, unions, and non-governmental organizations involved in development projects. Although the US has worked with non-governmental organizations in the past, the responsiveness of the US assistance program to grassroots South African priorities needs to be improved.

* Reduce economic inequality. The US should structure its programs so that the poorest 50 percent of the population are the primary beneficiaries and so as to strengthen the ability of this segment of the population to organize and to articulate its needs. Evaluations of US assistance programs should assess how well they are serving the poorest of the poor, particularly in rural communities. Explicit attention should be devoted to analyzing the extent to which each initiative redresses the economic legacies of apartheid by promoting a more equitable distribution of wealth within the society.

Many of the existing aid projects in South Africa are of most immediate benefit to permanently employed black South Africans working in the formal urban economy. These projects, which are often linked to private-sector business development efforts, can have a tremendous impact on long-term development, but they do not directly address the needs of the poorest sectors of the black majority. Moreover, they can exacerbate existing inequalities within the society. US assistance should be focused on programs which provide sustainable new opportunities to that portion of the black population that was most completely excluded from the apartheid economy.

* Build robust and dynamic organs of civil society. The historic strength of the US program in South Africa has been its work with non-governmental organizations, some of which have strong links to grassroots communities. The US should continue to work with South African-controlled community and non-governmental organizations, but must strive to channel its aid more effectively in order to increase the capacity of these organizations to deliver services, to engage in policy advocacy, and to realize their own, internally-defined, development agendas.

The tensions inherent in this strategy are obvious. The broadly defined "civil society" in South Africa, which includes non-governmental and community-based organizations, unions, religious institutions, and civic groups, is undergoing a period of tremendous turmoil as individuals and institutions seek to redefine their roles in the new society. Many of these organizations were developed primarily to support campaigns against apartheid. A large number will not have useful roles in the post-apartheid era and will be unable to sustain themselves. US aid should not be used to prolong the lives of organizations which have failed to retain popular support.

At the same time, efforts to promote the development of civil society should be complemented by programs which help South Africa's new, democratic government to realize its objectives. Elected officials will ultimately be responsible for defining the broad outlines of social and economic policy and for ensuring the coordinated delivery of services. US assistance programs should facilitate the articulation and implementation of public policies capable of improving the lives of all South Africans.

Community-based organizations in particular can play a pivotal role in ensuring the local level, democratic participation in development projects that is essential if such initiatives are to become truly sustainable. At the same time, they can help to create a government which is both effective and responsive by holding the actions of elected officials up to public scrutiny. In identifying partners in South Africa, the US should assess the degree to which these organizations are accountable to and controlled by the communities which they seek to serve, the effectiveness with which these groups implement their programs, and the degree to which they can ultimately be sustained by funding from within South Africa.

To order, send $8.95 for each copy, plus $2.50 shipping and handling for the first copy and $1.00 for each additional copy, up to 10. (APIC will bill shipping and handling for orders over 10.) Foreign orders -- please add an extra 20% of the subtotal. All orders must be prepaid or accompanied by an institutional purchase order. Please remit payment in US dollars and make checks or money orders payable to APIC. Please allow 4-6 weeks for delivery. Address orders to: Africa Policy Information Center, 110 Maryland Ave., NE, Suite 509, Washington, DC 20002. E-mail: apic@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


202 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Arts Review: Book Portrays Exemplary African Christians


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996 by Abisage Were


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

Nairobi - With the generally strong emphasis put on individual success and acquisition today, many find it difficult to identify even among Christians, one who is truly concerned about 'his brother's welfare'. Through "Changed Lives: Testimonies from Zimbabwe" published by a regional fellowship of Christian communicators, one comes face to face with Christians who are a living example of godliness in Zimbabwe.

In today's world where Christians are "joining the crowd" and succumbing to pressure to compromise their standards, a new book published by the Fellowship of Christian Communicators in Africa and Madagascar (FOCCAM) offers hope that it is, after all, possible to live a godly life as exemplified in the lives of real life characters from Zimbabwe, Southern Africa.

Divided into two sections, the non-fiction "Changed Lives: Testimonies from Zimbabwe," features stories from different writers about people in Zimbabwe who, in the writers' opinions, have consistently displayed godliness especially in the face of difficulty and trials. The 1995 FOCCAM title is edited by Stephen M. Njiro. 

The first section contains stories about people who may be categorized as ordinary Christians while the second is about Christian leaders.

The 183-page volume is dedicated to the memory of Sally Mugabe, late wife of Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, who in spite of her death, continues to be a mighty inspiration toward a better quality of life not only for her country but also for the entire continent of Africa.

For the African Christian, it is said, the true test of faith is seen in times of marriage, sickness and death. It is then that a lot of pressure is put on one to turn for help from African traditional religions and practices that may not be compatible with Christianity which forbids association with diviners and communication with ancestors. This is one major conflict the characters in these stories have to contend with. Forgiveness when deeply wronged, selflessness and perseverance stand out in the lives of these individuals as a hallmark of their godliness.

There is the story of Sally Mugabe, late wife of Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe, described as "one such rare gift given to the children of Zimbabwe for a painfully short time," and one who lives on because "she dedicated her life to the service of others."

Among godly qualities given that set her apart from others is her concern for the plight of children which led her to form Child Survival and Development Foundation, providing patronage to other charitable organisations such as Emerald Hill School for the Deaf, Mathew Rusike Children's Home and Mutamwa Leprosy Colony among others.

Despite her kidney ailment, Sally continued to subject herself to the demanding tasks of helping needy people. She pioneered the formation of the Kidney Fund Association and successfully championed for women's rights, transforming the lives of some prostitutes by encouraging them to form a self-reliant co-operative.

Sally who was also actively involved in the freedom struggle is described as "a wife and a mother at heart" for she took time and effort to ensure her husband's well-being, even preparing some of his favourite dishes personally despite having workers who could do that.

Another example to emulate is that of Stanley, a young man who is mocked by friends and neighbours for not giving in to the advances of beautiful Amanda, a model who other young men would wish to have. Rather than succumb to her advances when she unexpectedly kisses him, a shaken Stanley runs away remembering the biblical story of Joseph and Potiphar's wife. He forgives Amanda who later repents.

When fellow schoolmates pour beer into his open mouth while he is taking a nap under a tree, Stanley, to the chagrin of those who love him, pleads with the headmaster not to expel them. He forgives them and takes the opportunity to tell them of the love of God during their punishment session, resulting in the wild boys repenting and reforming to the surprise of all in the community.

Changed Lives carries a chapter on "Three Brave Widows," - women who undergo the typical experiences African women have been known to face on the demise of their husbands. These three women not only lose their husbands but also at least one child each. However, their responses amidst the anguish is outstanding.

In traditional Africa where it is believed that people do not die natural deaths but rather, that deaths are caused, these widows refuse to give in to in-laws' demands to consult diviners to find out the causes of the deaths of their husbands (including road accidents) and to undergo cleansing. Their Christian faith forbids it. For this, some of them are falsely accused of causing the deaths.

They undergo great anguish as in-laws dispossess them of what property they had acquired with their late husbands. And yet they stand steadfast in their faith in God despite the tragic experiences and forgive those who wrong them.

They are not bitter with God for the misfortunes that have befallen them but give themselves to helping needy people in their communities.

In the story of Mutakura, one sees a role model in a young man who refuses to accept bribes and displays accountability in the handling of funds. He stands firm against pressure from his parents who want to give him a girl of their choice to marry when he has a Christian girl he loves and wishes to marry. He also goes against their wishes to follow the traditional methods of marriage, commonly known as "wife capture," at the cost of his parents disowning him. They later give their lives to Jesus and reconciliation follows.

It is the life of Mr Moyo, a local school teacher and peasant farmer that has stood out as being consistently godly to one writer. He helps the community around him by ploughing for the poor and sponsoring some individuals to carry out their 'O' Level studies, lives by the scriptures and not necessarily by what other Christians do for he believes in biblical backing.

Mr. Moyo refuses to buy much needed and cheap goods some men come around selling because he knows they are stolen property. Unlike many Christians, during prayer sessions in public, he stands out for his short prayers, arguing that in a multitude of words, we increase the incidence of wrong words, repetition and self-centeredness in our requests.

Wild Dominic, the village terror turned missionary, is another godly example in Changed Lives. Before his conversion, the quick tempered Dominic not only terrorised other villagers but also gave policemen a hard time when he would wreak havoc in beer gardens.

On hearing his voice, his wife and children would scatter in all directions for fear of his terror. It was his custom to accuse his wife of some unfaithful act, and then give her a thorough beating with a

python-skin belt. After conversion, Dominic is transformed into a loving husband and father, and becomes a Christian who does not hit back when provoked by others as was his nature before.

There is the story of Tariro who, throughout her student life is an encouragement to others around her. Upon completion of her university education, she gets involved in community work as she looks for a job. Though quite desperate for a job, she turns down many offers on grounds of her faith because she would be required to work during worship day. Her parents are upset and her friends mock her. Finally, after a year's wait she gets a suitable job.

Many of the people in the book are actively involved in improving the well-being of members of the communities in which they live. They help those around them in practical ways and also provide material assistance. Prayer is also a vital part of their lives.

The book, containing 14 chapters, devotes the last three to stories about denominational leaders. These include Andrew Wutawunashe whose story begins with his interesting birth with a blocked windpipe. He is founder of Andrew Wutawunashe World Witness and the Worldwide Family of God Churches.

There is Mrs Gumbanjera who has the gift of praying and barren wombs are opened and demons cast out. She also has the gift of prophecy.

The third is a story about a bishop of African Apostolic Faith Church who died and "resurrected". He too has helped many people as he prays for their conditions such as strange sicknesses.

There is at least something that every African reader can identify with in the book for it carries stories about differently placed individuals whether young, old, male or female in diverse situations.

The circumstances faced by these individuals are not unique, be they bribery, handling of stolen goods, provoking situations, temptations, false accusations or conflict caused by refusal to compromise on matters of faith when it comes to marriage, sickness and death. They are to be found all over our continent and the responses to the situations are those from which readers may want to draw when faced with similar circumstances.

Heavy biblical grounding is evident in most of the stories in Changed Lives.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


203 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Science Group Champions Cancer Awareness In Kenya


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996 by James Macharia


LENGTH: 2107 words


 

Nairobi - The World Health Organization (WHO) annual - No Tobacco Day marked on June 1 this year, coincided with a cancer awareness week observed by the Kenya Cancer Association. Acknowledging cancer as a leading killer disease, the national association hopes to increase public awareness about the various forms of cancer common in women, men and children.

It begins with a small lump or sore in the breast or chest of a man, a feature that one may ignore as just another painless pimple. Or it may be a slight deformity in the nipple making it appear pulled- in or sunken. Is it just an inherited deformity or pimple? Or is it one of the early signs of breast cancer - a disease that has no known cure and affecting men as well as women?

Dr. Yusuf Kodwavwala a consultant surgeon based at the private Nairobi Hospital says men in Kenya are increasingly under the threat of developing breast cancer, predominantly regarded as a disease that affects women. "The disease affects men and women across the racial divides and comprises one per cent of all cancer diseases in the world. The rate in Kenya stands at six per cent, similar to Zambia and Egypt," he says. 

In a recent lecture on cancer, Dr. Yusuf Kodwavwala demonstrated using slides the gruesome swellings, wounds and deformities that arise as a result of breast cancer, which he said is the second most common after cervical cancer. "Most of our patients are diagnosed between the ages of 30 to 40 years according to figures available at the (semi-government owned) Kenyatta National Hospital (KNH)."

The Kenya Cancer Association (KECANSA) held its first ever Cancer Awareness Week from May 27 to June 2, with various events throughout the country to increase public awareness about issues related to cancer and to support the World Health Organization (WHO) worldwide "No Tobacco Day" on June 1.

The theme of the event, Helping To Conquer Cancer, which is now a major killer in the country unlike the past when it was seen as a Western world ailment, was accompanied by free screening, seminars and lectures.

According to available figures from the KNH, out of reported breast cancer cases, a mind-boggling rise has been recorded in just 20 years. In 1972 a paltry 40 cases were treated, rising to 116 in 1986 and the rate now stands at a high 212 in the latest data obtained in 1992, over four years ago.

Dr Kodwavwala lists the general causes of cancer as hereditary, due to increases in fat and protein in the diet of most families as a result of high economic status and benign breast diseases like fibroadenosis. In women, he points out the danger of "a late first pregnancy, lack of breast feeding or use of high hormone contraceptive pills."

Treatment of cancer includes what most women have for long dreaded, and now men too, the scary and often traumatic surgery called "mastectomy", which is the partial or total removal of the breast and all the underlying muscles where the cancer cells may have spread.

But if the cancer lump is not very widespread "lumpectomy" or removal of the lump only is successful if the cancer is detected at an early stage. "Radiation" treatment is also an option where x-ray light is used repeatedly to kill the cancerous cells while "chemotherapy" or use of regular drug injections is an option.

"With the help of modern technology in this field, the fear of losing one's hair during chemotherapy treatment is much reduced now than ever before and anyway the hair usually grows back quickly after the treatment is over, so women need not fear much," says Dr Kodwavwala.

For breast cancer patients, the Nairobi Breast Cancer Support Group, formed in 1988, offers "a safe and trusting atmosphere where they can listen to and observe each other providing new solutions to commonly shared problems and feelings."

The group also aims to assist in the education of women concerning breast self examination and give support for non-medical problems arising from the disease. The group meets every third Thursday evening of the month at the Nairobi Baptist Church.

Dr Michael Hughes, a doctor at the cancer terminal care centre, Nairobi Hospice describes cancer as "a large group of diseases characterised by the uncontrolled growth and spread of abnormal cells. Normally the division of cells takes place in a controlled manner to repair worn-out tissues or injuries. But cancer cells grow for no reason, multiply uncontrollably destroying normal cells and spread to other parts of the body."

During the launching ceremony of the Cancer Awareness Week at the Mayfair Hotel in Nairobi, WHO's Regional Director for Africa Dr Paul Chuke, disclosed that there were 3.5 million cancer related deaths from developing countries in 1993 and predicts that by the year 2000 the deaths will be 4 million, up from 3 million by 1990. At 2 million, the cancer rate in women stands at almost twice that of men, he said.

"Most of them are suffering from cancer of the cervix which is the number one killer in women, followed by breast cancer - which affects men as well, but at lower rates. Cancer is also a Third World problem and approximately 20 million people die from cancer annually while by the year 2015 the deaths will rise to 30 million," said Dr. Chuke.

The WHO Regional Director for Africa says that out of the 20 million, over 20 per cent can be prevented if tobacco smoking is eliminated, noting that lung cancer is caused primarily by tobacco inhalation. "Through the process of downstaging - achieving earlier detection of cancer diseases by enhancing education programmes, the cure rates can be reduced to as high as 80 per cent of sicknesses in their first stages," noted the WHO Director.

At the same function Kenya's Assistant Minister for Health Basil Criticos noted that cancer as a disease struck fear in those it afflicts and those around them. He announced that the government in conjunction with the KECANSA and other cancer research bodies are to produce a national cancer policy "which will form the basis of our planning and activities on cancer for the next decade and beyond. We look forward to receiving this document before the end of this year."

This could lead to the creation of cancer clinics at all major national hospitals, government subsidies on expensive cancer drugs and a programme for concerted public awareness similar to the high profile campaign against the incurable Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).

Christine Ikiara, a mother of two says; "It is a major improvement nowadays, unlike in the past, that during pre-natal visits, the doctor asks a woman whether she regularly checks her breasts for lumps that could lead to cancer."

According to Ikiara, however, most women either ignore any lumps they may feel in their breasts out of fear or ignorance. "Even 'enlightened' women are still shy to visit their doctors for check- ups of their private parts such as pap smears for cancer of the cervix unless one is actually ill," she says.

And as put clearly by Minister Criticos: "The four top killers in Kenya include skin, cervix, glands and liver cancer. The upsurge of cancer in this country is expected from the general increase of tobacco consumption, increase of industries with pollution, exposure to herbicides, pesticides, bleaching creams and lack of awareness of early signs and symptoms."

There are more than 100 forms of cancer which occur in any tissue or organ of the body, including the blood (leukaemia) or the lymphatic system, known as lymphomas. Each cancer has its own name, form of treatment and its own chances of control and cure. The spread of cancer is called metastasis.

It is for the purpose to increase early detection, treatment and prevention of cancer, that KECANSA decided to launch the awareness week which is to be an annual event to compliment the association's work throughout the year. During the week, activity highlights included the launch of a booklet on cancer, conducting of free screening clinics for cancer of the cervix, breast, stomach and lungs in hospitals, publicity of patient support groups like the Breast Cancer Support Group and an open-day at the Nairobi Hospice to give public lectures. The issue of cancer in children was also highlighted.

According to Dr. Leveret DeVebber, the senior medical consultant in the Paediatric and Hematology department at the KNH Ward 45 for children suffering from cancer only, the disease is rare in children compared to adults but is a leading cause of death among the young ones. "Early diagnosis is particularly important as proper treatment can produce cures in most cases. In children it differs from adults in having a higher cure rate, on average 80 per cent."

However, he lamented the high cost of anti-cancer drugs and the long period of treatment, usually two years, which must be strictly followed to achieve the high cure rates. "The cost of anti-cancer drugs is far beyond the means of almost all families (we deal with) except for children under 5 years who are exempted from paying for the drugs."

The cytotoxic cancer drugs at the ward are very expensive with some doses priced at as much as Sh.8,000 (US dollars 138) for one dosage while the treatment thereafter could amount to as much as Sh 250,000 (US dollars 4,310), amounts beyond the reach of most patients' families.

The ward heavily relies on donations from individuals and charity clubs to pay for the treatment period of two years. "The ideal plan for these children is for them to be "adopted" or sponsored for the complete treatment."

The children are mainly affected by cancers which causes swellings of the jaw bone or glands in the neck. It can also cause tumours in the abdomen, chest and brain and spread to the bone marrow, he says. There are usually 32 children on average at the ward at any given time, although the figure may be as high as 45, requiring others to be admitted to other wards.

The solid tumours are treated by surgery which is effective in the early stages, while the advanced tumours are best cured by radiotherapy treatment using x-ray light for a period of months, or the use of chemotherapy which is regular injections using the costly cytotoxic drugs. This treatment is also used to reduce the size of tumours before surgery to enhance the success rate. KECANSA and other charity organizations help in facilitating donor support for the children's cancer ward.

Supported entirely by donations, KECANSA has a long history of struggle against cancer in Kenya since its establishment as the Cancer Council of Kenya in the late 1960s. In 1994 when the founder Chairman Prof. Edward Kasili died, Dr Khama Rogo took over and the council was re-registered as the Kenya Cancer Association.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Kenya Archbishop Says Wrongdoing Fosters Devil Worship


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Nyeri, Kenya - Archbishop Nicodemus Kirima of the Catholic Archdiocese of Nyeri, 120 kilometres north of the capital, Nairobi, has lamented that devil worshipping is taking root in the country "because people have allowed wrongdoing to become a standard way of life."

The Archbishop headed the Devil Worship Probe Committee appointed two years ago by President Daniel arap Moi, following numerous claims by churches in Kenya that devil worship cults were creeping into the country, particularly through schools. However, he declined to be drawn into any discussion about his probe's findings, saying it was a presidential prerogative to release the findings. 

The Archbishop said his involvement had "allowed me to find some answers to my personal questions on this matter." He denied that his hands were effectively tied until the probe report is released if at all.

Said the Archbishop: "We are preaching the doctrine everywhere. It is the antidote to this problem - be kind, be upright, love your neighbour etc. The doctrine is clear and simple."

Citing as an example a recent report in a local daily, wherein a plastic bag containing blood and hair was hung from a roof and people were allowed to enter only in clean clothes, Archbishop Kirima said people in Kenya were degenerating to this level because they had allowed wrongdoing to take control of their daily lives. "It all starts in small ways and grows into a big problem. If people chose to do the right things in the eyes of God, the problem would not exist," observed the prelate.

On June 7 Archbishop Kirima delivered a captivating talk to some 2,000 people who jammed Karatina Catholic, parish some 20 kilometres from here, for night vigil prayers. He told his listeners that much of the world's wars and some diseases like the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) as well as poverty, were deliberately created by shadowy and secret societies in order to serve their evil ends.

Asked if he despaired, Archbishop Kirima told APS that he did not. "Every day, I witness so much goodness in the world - the result of so many people listening to the Word of God and doing the right things."

LANGUAGE: English
