Africa News


June, 1996


Rwanda Rwanda May Institute Truth Commission


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Kigali - Rwanda's Deputy Justice Minister Mr. Gerald Gahima has hinted that his country may establish a truth commission on the lines of the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

Speaking to the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) Africa Service Gahima said this approach may be the most practical way of reducing Rwanda's overwhelming case load involving more than 70,000 prisoners awaiting trial on genocide charges.

He said his ministry had now completed a crash training programme for magistrates who are expected to start work soon. "What is pending is for Parliament to approve the penalties for the various crimes committed." 

More than 500,000 people of Tutsi origin and Hutu moderates were murdered by the Interahamwe and the Rwandese Army during the period between April and August 1994.

But in a decision made to use a truth commission style approach, Gahima said Rwanda's Justice Ministry would send facilitators into the prisons to explain the advantages of making full confessions in exchange for a more lenient sentence.

He also said his ministry was concerned that should normal court proceedings be instituted, "it would take more than five years to clear the case load."

Another way to reduce the case load is to release all children who might have been involved in one way or another in the unprecedented killings that took place in Rwanda in 1994. This approach has consistently been favoured by the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).

The case load would also be substantially curtailed if people charged with damaging property had their charges reduced to civil cases. "They could be allowed to carry out some sort of activity as a means of restitution to the wronged party or parties," suggested Gahima.

Rwanda has been under intense international pressure to do something about the large number of prisoners held in terribly overcrowded prisons throughout the country. T he central African country has in turn charged that she is frustrated by the paltry international assistance to its criminal justice system.

Many Rwandese feel painfully frustrated that the United Nations War Crimes Tribunal on Rwanda, based in Arusha, Tanzania, is proceeding very slowly and is constantly interrupted by postponements.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


206 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Churches Act On Indigenous Concerns About Mining


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 907 words


 

London - As the rush for mineral exploration continues to affect indigenous people all over the world, churches are concerned that some inherent and fundamental rights of these people are systematically trampled on, disregarded and violated by the dominant world neo-liberal economy.

In a meeting organised here by the World Council of Churches (WCC), 45 representatives of indigenous nations and communities around the world raised concern about mining activities characterised by greed and profit making through transnational corporations.

In an interview with APS, the executive secretary of the WCC Programme to Combat Racism, Rev. Bob Scott, said the very first suggestion for such a consultation came during a WCC team visit to Aboriginal Communities in November 1993.

Representatives of an Aboriginal community in Cape York, Australia had earlier on voiced the need for a consultation in which indigenous groups involved in struggles against mining companies should meet to share information and devise strategies, Rev. Scott explained. 

At the consultation last month, delegates were surprised that some transnational corporations make use of international funding institutions such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), World Bank, regional funding institutions and even the United Nations, to impose, coerce and deceive sovereign nations of their policies and programmes.

The London meeting also condemned in the strongest terms "transnational mining companies, armed with international and national organisations, and multi-lateral agreements, with the complicity of the state and their national laws - their denial of our existence, their land-grabbing, their continued destruction of our land and territories and our air and our environment, their exploitation of our resources and the continuing decimation of our people."

Observing that over 2 million people in Africa were engaged in small scale mining, the consultation delegates recommended that African governments should recognise the existence of these community based mining operations and give the necessary assistance to ensure more environmental friendly operations. Namibia and Ghana were represented at the meeting.

The World Bank and affiliate finance bodies who support mining companies and force African governments into this unholy alliance with multi-national companies should act more responsibly. They should also ensure that mining companies comply with the same environmental standards worldwide, the meeting recommended.

Mining codes which give undue power and economic advantage to multinational mining companies would have to be changed, so that they reflect the concerns of mine workers and communities in which mines operate, delegates stressed.

These concerns should include health and safety standards, discriminatory wages between foreign and local workers, environmental degradation and lack of respect for indigenous people's right -- all which can be best achieved through consultation with representatives of the workers and the local communities.

Further recommendations from the London meeting stressed that indigenous people should be consulted with comprehensive information which should be provided in a timely manner when mining activities are being considered for sites located on the people's lands. And that free and informed consent of indigenous people be obtained before any mining development can occur in indigenous people's lands.

The consultation also highlighted the need for recognition of the indigenous people's inalienable rights to their lands and territories and waters, including surface and subsurface resources in accordance with, and respect for, indigenous peoples's traditional forms of collective ownership and control.

Indigenous people single out mining as one of the most destructive forces which they have to contend with.

The International Labour Organization (ILO) describes mining as one of the world's most hazardous sectors, causing more than 15,000 deaths annually. South Africa is among countries with the highest death rates.

Other data report that the world mining industry has become disproportionately dependent on exploiting indigenous people's territory. It is estimated that by 2010, about half of the global copper and gold supply will come from indigenous people's territories.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


207 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Science Gloomy Future For Africa As World Temperatures Rise


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 880 words


 

London - Temperatures worldwide have shot up by about 0.4 degrees Celsius more than the average of the past 30 years, indicating the seriousness of global warming, says a study by the London-based international environment advocate, PANOS.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has also forecast that "despite being partially masked by local pollution and occasional volcanic eruptions, there will be sufficient greenhouse gases in the atmosphere by the end of the next century to cause a worldwide temperature rise between 1.5 and 4 degrees Celsius."

Consequently, scientists are painting a gloomy picture of Africa's future as world global warming that has for long been considered by many as science fiction gradually becomes a reality. Unfortunately, there is little Africa can do to overcome the consequent dangers. 

Among the dangers that the scientists report is the effect of warm weather which they say is already extending the range of infectious tropical diseases such as river blindness, malaria, schistosomiasis, and yellow fever to areas where they are not currently endemic and where the local population has no immunities. African highlands such as Zimbabwe's capital Harare and Kenya's Nairobi, which are currently malaria-free, are set to become vulnerable.

The Nigerian city of Lagos, whose population the United Nations projects to swell to more than 20 million by 2015 would have its environmental hazards aggravated as migrants from the drought-hit Sahel continue to flood to coast. With raw sewage already being discharged into the open, sea level rise, tropical storms and floods would definitely overwhelm an already unhealthy sanitary system.

As these studies come to light, the North-South dispute has been generated with countries in the developing world accusing the rich countries of being the main polluters, thus urging that they reduce their emissions. Developed countries also claim those in the South have no emission targets set for them and thus have an unfair trading advantage.

The overall global production of food and fibres, says IPCC, "may not be greatly altered by a doubling of carbon dioxide levels. Provided, that is, farmers can adapt quickly to changing risks of events such as early frost and droughts, and invasions of new pests."

It says this bodes well for rich farmers and societies with a range of crops to choose from, but not for subsistence farmers for whom crop failure can be a matter of life and death.

"Wheat, rice and some other major crops will be able to make more efficient use of water in an atmosphere richer in carbon dioxide. This could cause bumper crops in some places. But in others such as American Midwest, which currently supplies much of the world grain trade including famine-alleviation stocks, drought and higher temperatures could cause crop failure," says PANOS.

It says other crops such as sugar cane, maize and millet, gain much less from a carbon dioxide rich atmosphere. And the extra carbon dioxide will worsen conditions for grazing on rangelands by increasing the carbon content of grasses at the expense of nitrogen. This will encourage the spread of woody species, and make the grass less nutritious and tasty for many animals.

What is disheartening about the PANOS report is the fact that cotton in Egypt might suffer from reduced water for irrigation if flow in rivers such as the Nile and the Amu Darya diminishes. IPCC warns that "all such projections are very tentative but they show the range and scale of possible responses of farming systems to warming and "millet, most important grain crop of many poorer communities in Africa, is also forecast to decline by about 63 to 79 per cent."

Countries like Ethiopia and Zimbabwe which have suffered some of the major droughts in the past 25 years, are likely to see more and worse calamities and the IPCC warns that "because extremes drive rangeland systems, small changes in the frequency of extreme events may have a disproportionate effect.

"Grasslands will die and there will be an acceleration of desertification which is more likely to become irreversible if the environment becomes drier and soils become further degraded through erosion and compaction," the panel on climate change observes.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


208 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Clergy Meeting Censures Nigeria For Rights Violations


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

NEW YORK - As Nigerian authorities continue to receive worldwide condemnation over the June 4 killing of 44-year-old Kudirat Abiola, wife of the jailed Chief Moshood Abiola, a group of church leaders meeting here a week before the assassination criticized the West African country for its violation of human rights.

The Nigerian regime has stripped away the people's most basic human and civil rights, replacing them with violence, fear and intolerance, said the over 40 prominent church and community leaders in a communique issued at the end of the May 28 Consultation on Africa.

The consultation, where the General Secretary of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), Rev. Jose Chipenda was the key-note speaker, was organised by the Religious Action Network Africa of the American Committee on Africa (ACA).

Many religious, political, trade union and community leaders have been unjustly imprisoned, forced into exile or murdered, the church leaders further said in their statement, adding that "the nation's hospitals and universities, once the pride of Africa, are in runs." 

Describing Nigeria as once a beacon of hope and pride for African people throughout the world, the church leaders lamented that "this African nation has been brought low by the brutality and injustice of a military dictatorship."

The church leaders, drawn mainly from the major African-American founded and led churches, pointed out in their communique that they were committed to the restoration of freedom and democracy in Nigeria.

"We call on all people of good will to mark the 36th anniversary of Nigeria's independence as "Nigerian Freedom Sunday" on October 3, 1996, a day of prayer for the victims of oppression and dictatorship and for the return of freedom and democracy," they said.

Quoting a document released by the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) last year, the church leaders said that "our hopes for amelioration have been dashed to pieces" and that the suffering of the people demands "nothing short of divine intervention."

Multi-national corporations exploit Nigeria's vast human and mineral wealth, extracting billions of dollars in profits, while Nigerian children go hungry, the church leaders stated.

The consultation was held at Canaan Baptist Church of Christ in Harlem and drew delegates mainly from the African Methodist Episcopal Church, African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, the Baptist Church, Church of God in Christ, the Episcopal Church, the Ethiopian Orthodox Disporic Church and the Presbyterian Church (USA). It was coordinated by Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker, the president of ACA, who is also the senior pastor of the Canaan Baptist Church of Christ in Harlem, New York.

In his address, Rev. Chipenda urged church leaders not to be on the side of oppression because, "whenever church leaders collude with the political establishment about the distribution and exchange of power, poor people are marginalised and frustrated, they become like sheep without a shepherd."

In a paper entitled: Africa's Challenge, the AACC head observed that the continental church body, national Christian councils and the African church in general are faced with the problem of how to effectively minister to a divided people.

The haves on one side, and the have-nots on the other; the young on one side and the old on the other; the elite on one side and the "wananchi (common man) on the other side; people living in the cities on the one side and people living in rural areas on the other side and also equally the rulers on one side and the ruled on the other side," Rev. Chipenda explained.

He described as unfortunate the fact that in Africa, those who are rich form less than 4 per cent of the population. "The middle class and their clients form 16 per cent; while the bulk of the population, made up of 80 per cent, are the poor lot."

According to Rev. Chipenda, the top leadership of the church is socially and economically in the lower middle class, but he stressed that "it is strategically well placed because it serves as a link between the elite and the masses."

This continuing temptation toward collusion of disparate interests promises to become a major challenge for the church in Africa in the coming century, said Rev. Chipenda, adding..."As much as this is a collective sin, we all must confess."

Turning to the Seventh AACC General Assembly to be held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, the Angolan clergy said of the occasion's theme - Troubled But Not Destroyed; "We live in a world troubled and fractured, whose problems deserve our attention." We live at a time when the power structure, which held the world together is now disintegrating. A radically different power structure is taking form and this is happening at every single level of human life."

Rev. Chipenda told the church consultation that leaders in the United States need to develop insights into changes affecting post-colonial Africa and that they should not embrace oppressive regimes, whether they are in Nigeria or the Sudan, but support for human rights, democracy and development.

South African Ambassador to the U.S. Mr Franklin Sonn, urged delegates who had "played a vital role in the struggle against apartheid to continue their support for South Africa now because the great work of building a free and just society has just begun."

The consultation recommended that church leaders represented at the gathering should write to their congregational representatives now, asking them to support continued development assistance for Africa, challenge presidential candidates on issues relating to Africa and also support freedom and democracy in Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


209 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Malawi Malawi's Government Coalition Collapses


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Blantyre -The junior partner in the Malawian government coalition, the Alliance for Democracy (AFORD), ended its co-operation with President Bakili Muluzi's ruling United Democratic Front (UDF) party on June 2, raising fears that the pull-out might seriously handicap the government.

AFORD leader Chakufwa Chihana, who stepped down from the post of vice president last month, said the purposes for which the 10-month-old coalition had been set had not been achieved.

The coalition was hammered out last year to consolidate democracy and bind the two parties to a coordinated parliamentary relationship after the country's three decades of autocratic rule by ex-dictator Hastings Kamuzu Banda.

Relations between the two coalition partners started to cool last December when Chihana accused UDF of lacking transparency and governance, as well as engaging in high-level corruption. 

Four AFORD cabinet ministers have refused to resign their government posts and have been expelled from their party. These "rebels" will automatically become independent members of parliament until next general elections in 1999.

A day before the final break, Malawi Law Society chairman James Namphambo declared that "it will be a major handicap for government to the extent that it might not be good for the country," and added that "the UDF government will be short of the required majority to pass bills and motions requiring a simple majority."

Muluzi's UDF has 85 parliamentarians, which with AFORD's 35 makes a working majority which enables the easy passing of bills without much trouble from the opposition Malawi Congress Party (MCP) of Banda.

Gwanda Chakuamba, MCP's vice president said: "I am afraid that Mr Muluzi's powers will be diluted or even end should AFORD pull out. It means the opposition will have the largest say in parliament. I am sorry for Muluzi."

But in his first reaction to the break-up on June 4, Muluzi himself welcomed the collapse of the coalition, saying that "on behalf of the UDF, I accept and I am happy to see the marriage between us and AFORD end."

By law, AFORD was supposed to have given a month's notice to terminate the coalition, but Muluzi hinted it could even end without those formalities.

"No thank you. We will not force them to stay with us. It's the end of the marriage thank you," Muluzi said, adding: "I'll make sure democracy is nurtured. We want peace and nobody will spoil our democracy."

The coalition's collapse leaves Muluzi's governing party four seats short of a parliamentary majority, but he promised to work with opposition parties.

At the same time, Muluzi's government insisted it would continue to function effectively despite the withdrawal of its junior coalition partner.

"The government will continue to work without any problem. "There are many people in AFORD who are prepared to work with us," Information and Broadcasting Minister Brown Mpinganjira said in a statement, an apparent reference to four AFORD ministers who had refused to resign and had been expelled from their party.

But apart from the loss of the working majority, analysts also pointed to fears that the breakup would re-kindle tribal and regional feelings in the tiny impoverished southern African state which is split on regional and ethnic lines.

Chihana had claimed that his party is the main unifier and that "without AFORD, Malawi would slide back into chaos and confusion."

But now that Chihana has resigned his post of second vice-president, it is not known whether Muluzi would still maintain it in the cabinet and appoint somebody else to it.

Opposition forces had called for the abolition of the post created amid controversy to accommodate Chihana.

"The creation of the office was an unpopular political move which can be corrected now. The position never need to have been there," said Hetherwick Ntaba, spokesman of the MCP, who pointed out that he did not expect Muluzi to fill the post in the wake of the country's ailing economy.

Muluzi has never publicly responded to Chihana's accusations, which intensified last month when Chihana bragged that his party was the only main power broker in Malawi, and "without AFORD Malawi would slide back into chaos and confusion."

Chihana attacked both UDF and MCP, saying they had no capacity to govern the country. They do not even have any economic conception on how to plan the future of this country," he added.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


210 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Egypt Egypt Hangs Six As Hard-liners & Moderates Compete


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Cairo - Egyptian authorities have hanged six Muslim militants, the largest number of executions at one time since Islamic unrest erupted in 1992, in the wake of an apparent major struggle between hard-liners and moderates in the country's highest Islamic institute, police sources said on June 2.

The six - Ahmad Abdel Azim Fawaz, 30, Huggag Gomaa Mohammad, 30, Hosni al-Sayed Hussein, 29, Zakariya Mohammad Beshir, 36, Salah Saad Mohammad, 31, and Mustafa Abdel Hamid, 29 - were from a group of 24 members of Jamaa Islamiya arrested between June and October last year for infiltrating Egypt from Sudan with a huge stockpile of weapons "to commit terrorist attacks," the sources said.

President Hosni Mubarak approved the execution order against the six, who were sentenced on January 13, the sources said, adding that the hangings took place in the previous few days, without giving the exact date.

The Jamaa members were arrested in the southern towns of Aswan and Kom Ombo, where prosecutors said they had hidden after slipping across the border from Sudan where they had allegedly been trained. 

Prosecutors said the militants had confessed to being trained in Sudanese camps alongside the same Jamaa members who attempted to kill Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa in June 1995.

They said the Jamaa cell was sent to Egypt by Mustafa Hamza, one of three masterminds of the Mubarak attack who Khartoum is accused of harbouring, "with orders to attack important personalities and leadership figures," but police caught up with them with a massive cache of weapons, including 168 machine-guns, 95 explosives including RPG rockets and 2,500 rounds of ammunition.

Twelve others in the case were given prison sentences, while six were acquitted.

The hangings brought to 54 the number of Muslim militants executed in Egypt over the past three years, during which 76 people have been sentenced to death.

The executions came amid reports that conservative religious scholars who once held sway at the Al-Azhar,

the citadel of Sunni Muslim orthodoxy, were now battling to keep their influence under a new, more moderate head sheikh.

Since Sheikh Mohmmad Sayed Tantawi took the helm of the 1,000-year-old institution in March, conservatives have opened fire on his rulings, led by the Azhar Scholars' Front (ASF) that groups around 1,000 theologians, reports said on May 20.

The ASF has even cast doubt on Tantawi's religious credentials, targeting in particular his refusal to declare militants who carry out anti-Israel suicide bombings as being "martyrs."

The Front insisted Tantawi's statements on the bombers were "his personal opinion which cannot be considered a fatwa," or official religious decree.

Tantawi, who was the mufti of Egypt before becoming sheikh of Al- Zahar, often differed with his more hardline predecessor Gad al-Haq Ali Gad al-Haq over issues such as bank interest and circumcision of girls.

But even while battling Tantawi, conservatives are also being hemmed in by government moves to crack down on radical clerics backing Muslim militants in their anti-state campaign which has claimed more than 1,000 lives since 1992.

They especially protest a draft law from the religious affairs ministry allowing only ministry-appointed imams to preach and a new rule requiring ministry permission to build new private mosques.

"We are shocked by this law which threatens to bar a large number of scholars and imams from conducting their duty of preaching," an ASF statement said, warning that the law could cause "unrest which would go beyond any unrest in the past," referring to the militants' armed campaign.

"The Front's violent reaction shows the high stakes in the game. A preacher without mosque loses all influence since access to the media is restricted," said Nabil Abdel Fattah, a researcher at Al-Ahram Centre or Strategic Studies.

Abdel Fattah said Azhar scholars had become more radical during the 1980s, especially after the secret distribution of a booklet by Sheikh Omar Abdel Rahman, spiritual leader of the militant Jamaa Islamiyaa.

Entitled; God is great, the Sheikh of Al-Azhar must resign, the booklet cast doubt on the institution's legitimacy and found favour among some scholars who felt Al-Azhar had become too much a religious "rubber stamp" for the state.

The head of the Azhar information office, Sayed Askar, was among 54 members of the Muslim Brotherhood sentenced for to up to five years in prison last November for membership in the banned fundamentalist group.

The Religious Affairs Ministry runs 34,000 mosques and plans to take over another 20,000 private ones.

"The conservative movement sees itself threatened by Tantawi's attempts to use the mobilization against Islamic radicals to bring the moderate trend into dominance," Abdel Fattah said.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


211 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Chad Chadian President In Election Re-run Against Opponent


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 867 words


 

N'djamena - Chadian President Idriss Deby took first place in his country's first-ever presidential elections with nearly 48 per cent of the vote, but a second round poll will be held on June 23, during which he will be opposed by veteran southern politician Abdulkader Wadal Kamougue.

Preliminary results from Chad's independent election commission put the incumbent well ahead of Kamougue, a veteran government minister, who polled 11 per cent of the votes cast in the June 2 presidential election.

Two other opposition leaders, Saleh Kebzabo and Jean Bayoweu Alingue, trailed with 8.5 and eight per cent respectively, followed by former national assembly speaker Lol Mahmat Choa with 5.6 per cent.

Ten other candidates shared less than eight per cent of the votes cast, with none of them managing better than two per cent in the poll which opposition parties refused to accept, but which the 100-odd foreign observers expressed satisfaction at the way it was carried out and spoke of only minor problems unlikely to affect the result. 

At a joint press conference here on June 6, the 14 candidates who stood against Deby said the vote "was marked by many irregularities."

"The regime is engaging in a thousand and one manipulations to rig the outcome," they said in a joint statement which complained of "intimidation of militants of other parties, removal of ballot boxes, arrests and fraud."

Kamougue has challenged the validity of the first round result in which Deby was credited with 48 per cent against 11 per cent for himself.

A spokesman for the electoral commission said the results were drawn from all the former French colony in central Africa as well as polling stations for Chadians living abroad.

Provisional for the moment, the figures are to be declared official by the court of appeal in N'Djamena in the coming days.

The turnout rate was 76 per cent, with 2.7 million out of 3.5 million eligible voters taking part.

Because no one candidate got a clear majority, a second round was scheduled for June 23, pitting Deby against Kamougue.

In preparations for the second round presidential run-off against southerner Kamougue, Deby pledged on June 9 that it would be "totally open" and fair.

"Kamougue is a man who knows politics and he is a patriot," Deby said in a statement, adding that he hoped Kamougue would "rise above all other considerations to allow democracy to triumph and make sure Chad does not return to its former deplorable situation."

The remark was apparently an allusion to 20 years of civil war marked by numerous regional rebellions and also to the fact that Kamougue drew most of his support from the mainly Christian south-west, while the Muslims in central and eastern Chad gave their votes to Deby.

The president said he hoped the 13 other candidates would "accept the rules of democracy in which there is a winner and a loser and that they will accept the verdict of the ballot box."

In a statement issued the same day, Kamougue had called the result of the first round "a political hold-up" and vowed to "bring legal action to have the poll invalidated."

Deby had campaigned for support to complete the task of consolidating multi-party democracy in this destitute north African country of six million people, which has been wrecked by civil war since independence from France in 1960.

Multiparty politics were introduced in October 1991, with a national conference in April 1993 promulgating a transitional period towards democracy. But since the national conference brought in a multi-party system, Chad has been stuck in a transitional period that keeps extending, with a transitional council acting as a provisional parliament.

In a referendum late March, Chadians approved their first democratic constitution, which provides for a presidential-style system of government. The presidential elections were intended to establish stable, lasting political institutions. Legislative elections are due later this year.

Deby declared himself president in December 1990, a month after he marched into the capital with his rebel Popular Salvation Movement and ousted Hissene Habre, who fled to Cameroon.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


212 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Liberia Thousands Fleeing Fighting In Western Liberia


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Monrovia - Thousands of civilian population continued to flee western Liberia in the past two weeks to escape renewed clashes between the country's warring armed factions, witnesses arriving here said on June 10.

"There is no law and order. Everything is just chaos," said Morris Kiade, one of hundreds of refugees who arrived by canoe from Grand Cape Mount county, where fighting is continuing between the two wings of the ethnically-divided United Liberation Movement (ULIMO).

Some of the canoes reportedly capsized on the way to the capital. One witness, Boimu Fumnbah, said up to 15 people from one canoe may have drowned. 

"People are suffering from bullet wounds and there is nobody to care for them," Kiade told journalists at Monrovia's Banjor Beach.

Residents in affected areas are "completely out of food and there is no medicine to treat the wounded and sick," said Kiade.

"Our people are dying in the bushes. We have never enjoyed peace since (the African peacekeeping force) ECOMOG withdrew from the country," he said.

The peacekeepers pulled out of Grand Cape Mount county last March after clashes with the ethnic Krahn wing of ULIMO-Krahn in Tubmanburg, in nearby Bomi county, left at least 20 ECOMOG troops dead.

The only road to the western region has since been closed to normal traffic and relief convoys.

Although a ceasefire has held in the capital itself since May 26, after almost two months of factional fighting, banditry and armed robbery are still common in many areas.

Elsewhere, gunmen killed a Protestant pastor during a looting spree in a Monrovia suburb, as fighting between rival militiamen resumed in the Liberian capital, police said on June 6.

Evan Pittman, founder of the Children's Salvation Ministry Church, was killed instantly when he was shot in the head while trying to rescue neighbours from armed looters late on June 5 in the Bardnersville suburb, police said, quoting witnesses.

The killing took place as more than 10 gunmen looted and shot sporadically in the area, which for years has had a reputation for banditry.

Pittman was a well-known figure in Monrovia, but was not politically outspoken and his death was not thought to have been premeditated.

Police say they are investigating the incident, but no arrests had been made by the afternoon of June 6.

Bardnersville residents, who already run neighbourhood watch schemes because of the insecurity, have called on the African peacekeeping force ECOMOG to deploy in the area.

On June 8, a group of unidentified fighters armed with machetes raided the government-run John Kennedy Memorial hospital in the eastern Sinkor district, and threatened health workers.

Although no one was hurt in the incident, it was the third such attack in two months, according to hospital administrator Henry Marvuie, who warned that "a repeat of such behaviour would lead to the closure of the hospital."

On June 9, police announced the arrest of 12 alleged armed robbers on Bushrod island and the seizure of three AK-47 rifles, as well as video decks, a satellite dish and television sets, but said that the ringleader of the armed gang, Junior Sonpon and three others, were still at large.

Meanwhile, Liberian rebels crossed into the Ivory Coast and killed 14 people and wounded four others, Ivorian police in Guiglo, 400 kilometres northwest of Abidjan, said on June 9.

The four wounded in the fighting, which took place on June 7, were in serious condition and taken to a nearby hospital.

The incidents were in the border village of Basobli, near Toulepleu, in Guiglo district, and were carried out by the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) of Charles Taylor, police said.

Police said a column of Liberian rebels had fired on Ivory Coast policemen after they had been called on to stop. The police, who lacked ammunition and resources, fell back without losses.

The 14 casualties were six Ivorian women, six Liberian women, an 18- year-old youth and a baby, they said.

The attackers, who had also set fire to village huts, succeeded in escaping after Ivory Coast police returned with reinforcements.

The incidents came in the wake arrival in the Liberian capital on June 9 of a delegation from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), headed by Captain Kojo Tsikata, security advisor to Ghanaian President and ECOWAS Chairman Jerry Rawlings, which was expected to start meeting faction Liberian leaders from June 10.

Although some differences still needed to be resolved, "the factions have reaffirmed their commitment" to a peace accord signed in Abuja last August by all factions in Liberia's civil war, ECOMOG Commander General John Inienger told the delegation.

One impediment to stability is the refusal, despite the demands of international mediators and the interim council of state, of ethnic Krahn fighters to leave the Barclay Training Centre, a downtown barracks that served as the Krahn's stronghold during the clashes.

The Krahns rejected offers of evacuation to rural areas, claiming those proposed, previously under the Krahns' control, were now occupied by enemy fighters.

However, "all sides have shown their willingness to abide by the ceasefire which ended seven weeks of fighting," Inienger told the ECOWAS team.

June, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Mine Increases Copper Production


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 13, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) has recorded a 3,800 tonne increase in copper production over its projected May output.

According to a ZCCM press statement released in Lusaka yesterday, the increase in production of finished copper has been attributed to the improved performance of the com-pany's two smelters in general and Nkana in particular. 

The company overshot its estimated May target of 24,833 tonnes with a recorded production of 28,730 tonnes.

And a 5 tonne increase in finished cobalt production for May was recorded with the production figures standing at 449 tonnes against the company's estimated 444 tonnes.

"The company is forecasting that the first quarter results in finished copper production (April, May and June) for the 1996/97 financial year will be above target by approximately 4,000 tonnes at about 82,800 as against the company's own official estimate at 78,600," the statement read.

ZCCM has further announced that it has resolved the problem of low grade ore production at the Nchanga Open Pit Mine which had affected the grade of Cobalt concentrate in April 1996.

The increase in metallurgical recoveries in general and at the metallurgical plants at Nchanga Division in particular were also cited as having contributed to the rise in production of both the copper and cobalt.

June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia Digs In For Sudan In World Cup Match


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 12, 1996 by Keegan Mumba


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Lusaka - Embattled national soccer team coach Roald Poulsen is confident that Zambia will beat Sudan in the crucial second leg World Cup qualifer to be played at Lusaka's Indepedence stadium this Sunday.

Zambia are trialing (0-2) having lost the first match played in Khartoum, Sudan last Saturday. 

Poulsen, speaking in an interview said the chances of winning were there especially with the arrival of team captain, Kalusha Bwalya, who features for Club America in Mexico.

'Great Kalu' , as he is fondly known by most adoring Zambians, joined the squad yesterday and begun training with the others in the afternoon.

''We definitely need to win this match at all cost to advance to the next round and the players seem prepared to deliver the goods this Sunday,'' he said.

The coach, relaxing at his Makeni home explained that Zambia played under pressure in the first match because of the hot weather and bumpy playing field.

''You watched the match back home and saw we had problems with the playing field. But that is no an excuse,'' he said.

Since Poulsen took over the re-building of the team in 1993, Zambia has reached the Africa Cup of Nations finals twice except for the time when Briton Ian Porterfield ''temporaly'' took over affairs of the team.

Last January Poulse took the team to South Africa for the Nations tournament and they displayed another a colourful performance and finished a better third to South Africa and Tunisia.

The team is now rated first in Africa on the Federation of International Football Associations FIFA panel.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

June, 1996


Zaire and Zambia Zaire Ignores Appeals For Urgent Meeting


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 13, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The Zairean government has gone mum over requests from Zambia that the two countries hold urgent discussions over matters critical to the welfare of their nationals.

Copperbelt Deputy Minister, Charles Museba, disclosed in the commercial city of Ndola that his administration had in recent weeks sent five urgent reminders to the Governor of the Zairean province of Shaba about the need to hold a meeting between them. 

But so there has been no responce whatsoever either from the provincial capital of Lubumbashi or Kinshasa itself.

Mr Museba explained that what Zambia desires most is for the convening of the 17th session of the Zambia-Zaire Joint Permanent Commission anywhere in Zaire so it can look at outstanding issues.

Zambia is particularly concerned with the increased incidents of harrassment of its nationals travelling from Mansa in Luapula to Mufulira or vice-versa, using the pedicle road which is a stretch of gravel road linking both towns through Zaire.

In addition Zambia is unhappy with the prevalence of banditry and petty thieving in such border towns as Ndola, Mufulira and Chililabombwe by armed men from Zaire who are suspected to be renegade soldiers of that country.

Also the Zambian government would have raised the issue of a heavy influx of Zairean illegal immigrants who in recent months have made the work of Immigration officers on the Copperbelt a little bit more complicated.

Mr Museba says according to an agreement reached at the last meeting of the Joint Permanent Commission which was held in Ndola, this session should have been hosted by Zaire and that was why Zambia was anxious to see it take off the ground.

But so far Zambia has met negative responces from the other side of the border, he added.

June, 1996


Zambia University Student Leaders Missing


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 13, 1996 by A Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - University of Zambia Students Union (UNZASU) vice-president, Joseph Munsanje has gone missing, friends, family and union colleagues disclosed in interviews yesterday.

And armed plain clothes police officers are said to have been hunting for him in connection with the interviews he gave to foreign journalists.

UNZASU president, Emmanuel Tembo, on Thursday said Munsanje was last seen at the campus on Sunday before three armed police officers in plain clothes stealthily, without notifying the security officers at the university, went to his room but did not find him for he was out studying. 

Tembo said the three, who included a lady, then went to his girlfriend's room with a view of finding him there.

When contacted yesterday Munsanje's girlfriend, a third year psychology student who asked not to be named, said the three officers went to her room around midnight on Sunday.

Munsanje's girlfriend said she had noticed that the three had been following her that night on her way from her studies and she only opened for them when the lady called her by her name, they then demanded to know where Munsanje was.

"On my way from studies I noticed that three people were following me, later I heard a knock on the door and I only opened for them when the lady called out my name," she said. "They then identified themselves as detectives and wanted to know where Munsanje was but I did not tell them because I had no idea."

She identified one of them, who was brandishing a pistol, as detective Banda.

Security personnel at the campus said the three had not passed through their office as was the procedure.

Munsanje's family are wondering what could have happened to him.

"We don't know where he is and what is worrying us is why the police have been following him especially at awkward hours," said Dr Moono Munsanje, a brother to Joseph who travelled from Luanshya on Tuesday when he got the news that the brother was missing.

Police spokesman, Francis Musonda, yesterday said as far as he was concerned no student was facing any arrest and wondered what the detectives could have been looking for.

By yesterday Munsanje's whereabouts had not been known despite exams having commenced.

LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's opponents in this Sunday's World Cup qualifier Sudan were on Tuesday held to a 0-0 draw by Taifa Stars in an international friendly played in Tanzania.

According to the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) radio's Fast Track sports programme, the two sides, both preparing for the World Cup, failed to score in the match . 

But it is believed that the Sudanese might have played a dull game to mislead the Zambians who they are meeting this Sunday. Sudan hold a 2-0 lead over Zambia from the first leg played two weeks ago.

And officials at the Ministry of Sport have announced that a 30-man Sudanese national soccer delegation arrives in Lusaka this afternoon for the crucial match.

"They have confirmed that they are flying in tomorrow (today) aboard an Aero Zambia plane at 17:15 hours and we will today get in touch with FAZ to see which hotel we can book them in," an official said.

Business and Finance Italy Ready To Build Zambian Roads


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 12, 1996 by Mervin Syafunko


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - Italian ambassador to Zambia, Dr Magherita Costa, yesterday requested Works and Supply minister Patrick Kafumukache to give road construction projects to her government because it knows the job better.

Speaking at a handover ceremony of three tractors, two vacuum tankers, two tractor trailers and Fiat tractor spares to Kafumukache in Lusaka yesterday, Dr Costa said Zambian should take advantage of the Italian government's expertise in road building. 

"We must not forget that Italians are the heirs of the ancient Romans and Via Appia, Via Aureria and Via Cassia were the first ways of communication realised in the world," Dr Costa said. "Those roads still exist and, I assure you they can compete with the modern highways."

Dr Costa was hopeful that Italy would soon be called upon to build new roads and upgrade the old ones.

"We could even start today," she said. "Machinery is already here."

Kafumukache, without committing himself on road construction contracts with the ambassador, said he hoped Italy would continue helping Zambia.

June, 1996


Zambia Opposition Charges Zambia Cheated Donors


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 12, 1996 by Mukalya Nampito


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - Donors do not need the opposition to influence them into making any aid cuts to Zambia because their decisions are caused by the failure of the MMD government to honour its commitment to them on good governance, claimed UNIP publicity secretary Bweendo Mulengela yesterday.

Mulengela told a press conference at UNIP's Freedom House head quarters in Lusaka yesterday that it was childish for the MMD to imagine UNIP can influence the independent stand of the donors who are ably represented here and can assess things on the ground.

Mulengela said in 1994 finance minister Ronald Penza, the then National Commission for Development Planning deputy minister Dean Mung'omba and former health minister Boniface Kawimbe, upon return from a donor meeting told the nation of the set conditions for the aid they had agreed to. 

"Why should they turn around and say that us in UNIP are so intelligent and persuasive as to turn the donor community against them?" Mulengela asked.

"It is the fault of the MMD that the donors have turned against them since they have failed to comply with the set donor aid conditions."

Britain, the United States, Japan, France and Norway have so far indicated an inclination to freeze any new aid to Zambia "until good governance is restored".

"We feel the assurances given to us by the Zambian delegation at the last consultative meeting in London about this government's commitment to have a consensus based constitution have not been met," Norwegian Charge de Affairs, Thorbjorn Gaustadsaether, said in an earlier interview.

Last week, Foreign Affairs minister, Christon Tembo, had told reporters that "donors felt the amendment to the Constitution was intended to eliminate UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda from the presidential race".

Mulengela said in the past, MMD had alleged that president Kaunda's return to power would scare away investors but circumstances are such that the investors are now running away from them.

"Indicators are that as long as MMD leads no-one will be interested in investing in Zambia," Mulengela charged.

He further warned MMD not to fight donors unless they had the right cause.

"We reiterate further our call to the Commonwealth and Frontline States to shun this unfortunate government for the Zambians," Mulengela appealed.

June, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Manufacturers Say Economy Should Be No 1


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 13, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - The government should think of the state of the economy when it makes decisions, advised Zambia Association of Manufacturers (ZAM) chairman Mark O'Donnell in an interview yesterday.

"The economy must be number one on the agenda," O'Donnell said." Surely what matters is that people have a healthy diet, are driving on good roads and are getting better education instead of always concentrating on politics. Government should address relevant issues."

O'Donnell pointed out that Zambia, with a gross domestic product (GDP) of under US$3 billion, was operating under capacity.

"It means the economy is continually sliding and we are not producing anything. The economy of Zambia is very sick," he said. " If the downward slide is not halted there will be further loss of jobs."

O'Donnel was, however, happy that the government was taking some positive steps in the right direction on import duty.

"The government has reduced import duty on some materials such as label paper from 15 to five per cent," O'Donnel said. "As a country, we import ready-made packaging materials from Zimbabwe instead of creating our own packaging for Zambian products simply because of the high duty."

He said the only way to get the economy to boom was to get duty off materials. Pointing to the label paper, he said this improvement in the sub-sector would benefit a lot of other sectors.

"Industries in the export sector which needs attractive packaging would benefit if we had our own packaging industry," O'Donnell said."This is what should be happening,"

Commerce ministry permanent secretary, Kabeta Muleya, assured the government was doing everything possible to resuscitate the economy.

"The government is working with the manufacturers to improve the economy," Muleya said in an interview yesterday.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Behind the Scenes: Stop Sudan -- And Redeem Africa


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 13, 1996 by Bright Mwape (Column)


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia national soccer team has been a surprise team full of contradictions. They win when everyone doubts them and lose when everyone expects a win.

I have come to realise fame and immense self confidence have not been the cup of tea of most of our players. It over runs them. 

The team's defeat at the hands of Tunisia in the last Africa cup of nations tournament was to many as much a shock as the 4 goal blitz past the tough Egyptians.

That the Egyptians, by far a superior side to the then rebuilt youthful and untested Zambian squad, would fall that easily to Zambia, did not only shock us but excite our hopes about an easier run over Tunisia. In both cases the unexpected happened.

Zambia unexpectedly again lost to Sudan but will still do what some may not expect - maul the Sudanese.

Zambia may historically have had a tough time against Sudan but few Zambians (I am sure not even the team itself) expected that these men from cartoon or is it Khartoum, with their ancient football, played in the air with the speed of an aboriginal hunter, would overcome the mighty skill of our tested men.

I however, appreciate the frustration of playing amateurs running about in all directions and cheered in their confusion by a religiously partisan crowd.

What skill is appreciable in the Sudanese team apart from heavy running around and wild kicking? These are men who have never known modern competition and football and who must not be allowed to ruin Africa's world cup chances by moving a step ahead at the expense of quality.

There is no reason to look at this game from the Zambian point, Africa must raise a team to make a difference in world football.

I could have been of any other nationality but would never have said Sudan in its form is a team for Africa's soccer leadership. Much as I would have a lot to say about the level of our own preparations, I still feel the Zambian camp has a better deal to offer Africa.

Sudan must for this reason be mutilated this Sunday and be helped to appreciate a few lessons that will polish their no-style football before Africa suffers more humiliation in France.

Soccer, dear Sudan, is not just running like a windmill or it would have long ceased to be entertainment. Cool down and learn a few things about coordination, building a system, passes and launching an attack that will make you leave the pitch this Sunday with substantial energy but quite a basket full of goals against you.

Victory in Sunday's game is expected but that is not the issue. What is the issue is how many goals are fair for Sudan and safe to forestall Africa's reputation.

It is a good thing that all key players like Kalusha and Johnson Bwalya have returned home.

In Zambia two goals is not a margin. We have no difficulty raking in four goals in less than 50 minutes so Sudan may well be lucky getting away with the unexpected of just about three goals.

Sorry I ought to have been more courteous and recognised your presence here - Welcome home Sudan!


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Sports - General Zambia: Athletes' Trip To Cameroon Flops


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 12, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has failed to send a team of athletes to the All Africa Athletics Championships starting this Thursday in Cameroon.

"We are unable to send our team to the All Africa Championships because we have failed to raise money. We needed about K50 million and we were assured by a certain sponsor who has sadly pulled out at the eleventh hour," said Zambia Amateur Athletics Association (ZAAA) general secretary, Phil Kubombela in a telephone interview from Kitwe yesterday.

Kubombela disclosed that top runners, Fackson Nkandu and German-based Issac Mukongo, were among the twenty athletes picked to represent Zambia in Cameroon.

"We need to compete in such events and the fact that we are unable to send our team means that we may have to lag behind those that will compete at that competition. We need assistance if we have to improve," said the ZAAA secretary of the event that will see all countries in Africa competing.

Angola CORRECTION: As a matter of fact


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 147 words


 

A mistake occurred in a report in last week's edition about a convoy from Pretoria to Angola, headlined "Wagons roll". The report said the convoy was transporting 60 tons of aid to the rebel Unita movement. It should have read the aid was a gift from South Africa to the United Nations for quartering areas housing Unita soldiers.

A second convoy of South African aid is now on its way to Angola, also destined for the UN to assist with the process of housing Unita troops in assembly points. President Nelson Mandela gave R29-million of aid to assist the ongoing peace process in Angola and it is being used by the UN in Unita assembly points.

224 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia South Africa Ducks Kaunda's Election Dilemma


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Judith Matlofft


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Johannesburg - Western donors have deplored moves by the Zambian government of Frederick Chiluba to prevent his rivals from taking part in October's elections. But South Africa is pursuing a foreign policy of quiet, if not silent, diplomacy.

Even the debt the ANC feels towards Zambia's former president Kenneth Kaunda for sheltering the movement during apartheid is apparently not enough to condemn efforts to disqualify him from running.

Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo says that Pretoria does not want to take the lead, preferring instead to leave it to Botswana President Quett Masire, who is also the head of the Southern African Development Community (SADC). 

But Masire is doing very little and the regional body is appearing spineless as one of its members nakedly flouts the regional trend towards democratisation.

After telling foreign correspondents at a lunch on June 7 that South Africa's foreign policy priorities include promoting human rights and keeping the peace in the region, Nzo lamented the "tragedy" occurring in Zambia which he said could lead to conflict there.

But he insisted: "It is up to the chairman of SADC to respond ... South Africa is not a global power nor does it seek to be a dominating force in the region. We have made it clear we see ourselves as a nation among equals in the sub-region."

Pressed further, Nzo said masire was considering convening a meeting of regional officials to discuss Zambia, but that no other action was being considered for the time being.

Kaunda said in a telephone interview that a recent visit to Lusaka by Masire was a "disaster" in terms of persuading Chiluba to reverse his non-democratic path. Kaunda said he would have liked a telephone call from his old friend, Nzo. But he expressed some sympathy for South Africa's reluctance to get too involved, saying: "I can well understand their position. The government here thinks they (the South African government) are too close to me. So that's why they left it to President Masire and SADC."

The SADC's passivity is in sharp contrast to 1994, when member states including South Africa threatened to intervene in Lesotho after the palace coup and in Mozambique after former rebel leader Afonso Dhlakama initially rejected his electoral defeat.

The Zambian silence follows South Africa's withdrawing its tough stance on Nigeria after failing to muster regional support last year.

Foreign donors, including Britain, the United States, the Netherlands and several Scandinavian countries, have threatened an aid freeze over the constitutional amendments passed by the Zambian Parliament last month which disqualify as presidential candidates, traditional chiefs, people who lived abroad for the past 20 years, or anyone who is not at least a second-generation Zambian.

This not only rules out Kaunda, whose parents were immigrants from Malawi, but also his United National Independence Party deputy chief Inyambo Yeta, and Zambian Democratic Congress leader Dean Mungomba.

Further concern has been raised over a charge of treason against nine political opponents, including Yeta and other senior Kaunda aides, for allegedly forming part of a shadowy group called "Black Mamba" which the government blames for recent bomb attacks. Kaunda denies any link.

Kaunda will not quietly accept the role of sidelined senior statesman and has threatened civil disobedience, such as staging unauthorised rallies.

The Chiluba government was clearly worried that a deteriorating economic situation could facilitate a comeback for Kaunda.

Kaunda left office after being overwhelmingly defeated by Chiluba in the country's first democratic elections in 1991, chastened by a popular rejection of his economic mismanagement.

Chiluba's adoption of donor-dictated austerity measures have worsened life for many Zambians who now look back nostalgically on the days of free education, food subsidies and state-protected jobs.

Western diplomats say that, ironically, Chiluba would probably have won the elections without thwarting his rivals. Now, however, he has eroded his credibility and elevated in popular esteem Kaunda, who was certainly no democrat during his 27-year reign as Zambia's first post-independence president.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Southern Africa SA Minister Seeks End to Trade Row With Harare


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Iden Wetherell


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Harare - South African Minister of Trade and Industry Alec Erwin is pressing for an early resolution of the trade dispute that has soured relations with Zimbabwe -- South Africa's most important regional market.

Erwin brought a 25-strong delegation that included industrialists and trade unionists to one-day talks hosted by his Zimbabwean counterpart, Nathan Shamuyarira, at Victoria Falls on Monday

The talks were aimed at defusing an increasingly acrimonious row over terms of trade which have recently threatened to get out of hand. Zimbabwean industrialists called for a "trade war" if South Africa refused to remove obstructive tariffs on Zimbabwean goods. President Robert Mugabe recently adopted similar fighting talk at an economic forum in Cape Town. 

Erwin is determined to find solutions, sources in the South African delegation said. "He agreed there was a lack of balance in the present situation and communicated a willingness to resolve differences," said one delegate, who was impressed by the new minister's command of detail.

But significant obstacles remain. Zimbabwe is hoping to revive preferential access to the South African market as provided for in the 1964 trade agreement between the two countries which lapsed in 1992.

The South Africans, however, conscious of World Trade Organisation rules that bar bilateral pacts, are anxious to focus on a wider range of issues that will free trade in the region as a whole.

"We don't want negotiations with Zimbabwe to be out of step with what we might achieve later at the regional level," said South African high commissioner Kingsley Mamabolo.

Present at the Victoria Falls talks were leading members of the steel and engineering industries' federation, textiles manufacturers and
representatives of the Food and Allied Workers' Union, the National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa, the National Union of Mineworkers and the South African Textile Workers' Union. They met their Zimbabwean counterparts in bilateral talks.

As a result, three working groups have been formed to look at the three main problem areas: textiles and clothing, agricultural produce and other sectors such as minerals and leather products and the motor industry. They are due to report back at a meeting in South Africa at the end of June.

The formation of the working groups "demonstrated seriousness on the part of the South African and Zimbabwean governments," said Mamabolo who spoke of a new sense of urgency.

Zimbabwe's textiles industry is on the verge of collapse since South Africa, partly at the insistence of trade unions, made access to its market prohibitive. Beef and poultry producers have also been hard hit while local manufacturers complain that Pretoria's export incentives encourage South African companies to flood the Zimbabwean market with cut-price goods.

Progress in talks will depend on local-content monitoring. The South Africans complain that Zimbabwe includes items imported from the Far East in its manufactured goods. While South African manufacturers want goods entering South Africa to contain no less than 75% local content to qualify for tariff reductions, Zimbabwe would prefer the figure to be closer to 25%.

The meeting saw a South African proposal for a local-content sliding scale that would increase annually. But such a scheme would be difficult to monitor, observers say.

While there is a clear willingness to make progress, several hurdles remain.

Economists point to the influence of trade unions in South African policy making. The Congress of South African Trade Unions believes neighbouring countries exploit cheap labour. This explains in part their inflexibility regarding textiles imports.

But their presence has had at least one positive result. Zimbabwean trade unionists, mostly marginalised by their government in the past, are delighted to be sitting at the top table in the current negotiations, unthinkable a year ago.

"Zimbabwe is having to learn the politics of inclusivity," one delegate said.

Observers have said Erwin got on well with Shamuyarira despite the Zimbabwean minister's adherence over many years to the Pan Africanist Congress. "It is irrelevant," said one diplomat attending the talks. "The politicians got on well. Everything now depends on the other players."


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
