Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Soweto '76: SABC Rode With Police


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Johannesburg - Soweto 1976 was the first big news story that dropped into the laps of the South African Broadcasting Corporation's fledgling television service. But the corporation's efforts at covering the uprising are lost to history.

The SABC never kept recordings of its early TV news bulletins, and all that survives in the archives is a random selection of unedited footage. Most of it is a catalogue of burnt-out buildings and cars with smashed windows, indicating that reporters had missed out on some of the action. 

But there are clues to how the SABC tried to get close to the story -- they hitched rides with the police.

In one telling piece of footage, a camera looks over the shoulder of a policeman who crouches in the back of a speeding van, his bayonet silhouetted against the light as he fires at an unseen target. Such records speak of an SABC which had not yet lost its innocence -- a few years later, the camera crews knew very well where they weren't supposed to look.

And with innocence comes fun, as can be seen in one delightful shot of a policeman dozing on the grass, and then jumping up in embarrassment as he realises the camera is on him.

Radio news bulletins from the period have also disappeared, though the recorded inserts survive and give an indication of the corporation's priorities.

Always keen to give an ear to black voices, the SABC recorded the views of homeland leaders Lucas Mangope of Boputhatswana, Gatsha (as he was then known) Buthelezi of KwaZulu and Cedric Pathudi of Lebowa, none of whom thought the riots were a good idea.

Neither did "well-known black writer and inhabitant of Soweto" Credo Mutwa, who said "this thing has been started on the flimsiest of excuses".

And the then-prime minister, BJ Vorster, was there telling us the events in Soweto were "a deliberate attempt to bring about polarisation between whites and blacks". He reassured listeners that "instructions have been given to maintain law and order at all costs".


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


227 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Soweto '76: Story Of The Decade


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Johannesburg - Gabu Tugwana (he was known as Jan at the time,) was working on retainer for the Rand Daily Mail at the time of the June 1976 uprising. It was he and his colleague Nat Sechake who brought first-hand accounts of events to Mail readers, and he was detained by the police for his efforts.

His application form for a permanent post at the Mail was delivered to him while he sat in the cells. That launched him on a journalistic career which continues 20 years later as editor of the New Nation. 

At a time when some white journalists stayed out of the townships fearing attacks, or were barred by the police, black journalists were at a unique advantage. They could slip past the police lines looking like ordinary commuters.

Newspapers which had attached little value to black journalists were hard-pressed to find enough of them to cover the events unfolding in the townships.

The Mail called in and promoted its freelancers. The Star relied on staff from its black sister paper The World. Beeld's front page on June 17 1976 includes a testimony by one David Sithole, who is identified simply as a "werknemer" (employee) of Beeld.

Raymond Louw, who was then editor of the Rand Daily Mail, describes 1976 as "the coming of age of black journalism. Their reports dominated."

Not all of the black journalists concerned speak about the era with such warmth. Tugwana recalls the disbelief with which editors greeted the testimony of black reporters fresh from the action.

"One night I knew about an impending attack. I hid in a coal box. I heard a military vehicle and someone speaking through a loudhailer, saying: 'Don't destroy these houses, destroy everyone inside the houses.'

"The next day I went through such a grilling at the office. They asked me: 'Are you sure you heard those exact words?'"

Tugwana was arrested at Orlando High School after the police allowed him to drive into the school. "They said, 'This is a big fish', and I was detained for three and a half months under the Internal Security Act."

Peter Magubane, the Mail photographer whose records of the period have become legendary, remembers: "I had my nose broken by a police captain in Alexandra. But what was most hurtful was when they ordered me to take out my film and expose it to the light. I lost historic images."

While some journalists were injured or threatened by students, Magubane says he had no difficulty in persuading demonstrating students that his photographs would help to publicise their struggle.

Magubane scoffs at the received wisdom among white journalists that it was dangerous for them to go into the townships: "Whites were frightened because of apartheid. They didn't want to go into the townships."

Carol Lazar, then a junior reporter on the Mail, agrees the threat to white journalists was exaggerated: "We felt safer among the people than among the police."

Whatever the reasons, the situation called for creative ways of reporting. Harvey Tyson, then editor of The Star, speaks of the difficulty of having no single credible source of information, with official reports toning down the violence and the students making no effort to communicate their version of events.

The Rand Daily Mail team, in particular, came up with some ingenious ways of getting the story out.

"We totally disregarded police restrictions, or found ways around them," says Lazar.

She recalls how she and her colleagues donned hospital overalls and hid for days in Baragwanath Hospital, counting the dead and injured to provide an alternative to the sanitised official reports. Friendly doctors provided cover for them and even donated their vouchers for the canteen -- had the hospital authorities known of their presence, the journalists would have been expelled or arrested.

Mervyn Rees, the Mail's crime reporter at the time, spent June 16 and the two following days hiding out in the house of a priest opposite Orlando police station, counting the bodies brought in in the police vans.

Another Mail innovation -- a home-made riot-proof vehicle -- was less successful, usually ending up with punctured tyres in the middle of the battle zone.

For all the ingenuity, both Louw and Tyson speak of the difficulty of providing anything beyond an episodic view of the events.

"There is no other way of covering a breaking story," Tyson says. "We turned out six or seven editions in seven hours. In a perfect world it wouldn't get much better than that."

"It took two or three days before the significance started to percolate into our minds," Louw says. "And there was no sense of the historical importance the events would assume."


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Soweto '76: Looking Back At A Defining Moment


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

'Soweto riot" read The Star's banner headline on the afternoon of June 16 1976. It was followed by a mere four paragraphs -- all the paper could scrape together before deadline.

"At least one child was shot as about 300 police fired hundreds of shots into the air as they tried to quell a riot involving more than 10 000 Soweto high school pupils today," the story began.

Underneath, a late flash informed readers of the first two deaths. 

The story pushed aside the first edition's lead, which was about tensions brewing between Rhodesia and Botswana over the shooting of a Motswana cattle- herder who had wandered over the Rhodesian border.

And the story which ran over the following days eclipsed the story which had been big earlier in the week: one concerning the impending meeting between the then-prime minister, BJ Vorster, and Henry Kissinger, the then-US secretary of state, in Bonn.

That first interpretation of the events -- the police were just doing their job -- was quickly discredited. But the "Soweto riot" headline became a label for one of the defining moments in South African history.

By the time The Star brought out its first city late edition, the headline was "Six die in riots". The story was sourced to hospital and ambulance officials, and a confused South African Police Brigadier R le Roux, who was quoted as saying "everything is in such an upheaval here, I really don't know what is going on".

Later came the first eyewitness reports, and a photograph which was to become an icon of apartheid repression: two pupils carrying the lifeless body of a third pupil -- only the next day was he identified as Hector Petersen.

By the end of the day the headlines were running scared. "Mobs take over" was splashed across the top of the page, with individual stories headed "25 dead and count may rise", "Rioters storm hospital", and "Drunken Tsotsis on prowl".

But readers who bothered to turn past the horrors of the front page found a report that pieced together the sequence of events which had sparked the riots -- and found the police to be at fault. Pupils only began throwing stones after a police officer had thrown a teargas cannister into the crowd.

Next morning, the Rand Daily Mail had its share of horror news in the lead ("bands of maurauding blacks rampaged through Soweto last night"), balanced by a front-page editorial lambasting the government for its failure to forsee the inevitable. Eyewitness reports with the bylines of Jan Tugwana and Nat Serache were pushed onto page five.

The World, aimed at black readers but owned by the Argus company, was no less guarded than the white newspapers. It was a World journalist, Sophie Thema, who provided the first eyewitness account of the start of the riots accusing the police of provoking the violence by throwing a teargas cannister into the crowd.

Yet Thema's report came with the proviso "according to Miss Thema's eyewitness account", suggesting a lack of editorial trust in what Thema saw.

Editor Percy Qoboza resorted to innuendo when he suggested a way out of the crisis. His editorial dismissed as irrelevant the talks between the West Rand Administration Board and the Urban Bantu Council, suggesting "what one needs to do is to talk to people who the students have confidence in." The tantalising implication was that the people the students had confidence in could neither be named nor quoted.

Beeld was the most blunt of all: "Hell in Soweto" read the headline, with a photo of the dead body of Dr Mellville Edelstein -- a government employee killed in the riots -- across the width of the page. Die Transvaler ran with "Shock violence -- whites chopped to death".

Beeld had tracked down Andries Treurnicht, then deputy minister of bantu administration, in Windhoek, and ran an interview. "In the white part of South Africa," Treurnicht proclaimed (meaning anything that wasn't a homeland) "where the government erects buildings, gives subsidies and pays the teachers, it is surely our right to determine the language arrangements."

Yet Beeld defied stereotypes about the Afrikaans press with the damning editorial comment: "Has our government really no more effective weapon than bullets against children who are running amok?"

Beeld also came up with the only photograph of Winnie Mandela on June 16, explaining in the caption that she had been trying to persuade the children not to demonstrate.

From the start, stories in the English press emphasised the riots had been sparked by the policy of giving Afrikaans equal status to English as a medium of instruction in black schools.

The Afrikaans papers placed the language issue low down in their stories, but squared up to it in their editorials. Beeld said the language issue ought to be a matter for negotiation, but "the bullets in Soweto have placed it outside the realm of argument".

A front-page editorial in Die Transvaler ventured to suggest the real problem was there were not enough Afrikaans-speaking teachers in black schools, but insisted "after order is restored as a first priority, more negotiations over language rules are essential".

On Sunday, Rapport was more forthright: "Scrap the language provisions in Bantu education. What Afrikaner would want to fight with blacks because they don't want to use his language?"

The comment echoed remarks by prominent Afrikaans intellectuals quoted in English and Afrikaans papers, who compared the government attempts to force Afrikaans on black pupils to Lord Milner's imposition of English on Afrikaners.

It took the Rand Daily Mail to question the importance of Afrikaans in the whole affair. "It was a protest against subservience," read the Mail's front-page editorial on June 17. "The manifest enemy may have been Afrikaans, but the real target was white domination and racial injustice."


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Mandela Gets Tough On Campus Unrest


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Philippa Garson


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Johannesburg - The destablisation of higher education campuses has triggered the personal intervention of President Nelson Mandela, who is known to be extremely concerned about the ongoing crisis and the negative impact on international fundraising efforts for the sector.

Mandela met the ANC Youth League and the Committee of Technikon and University Principals this week, and intends meeting other student groups.

At the meeting with technikon and university principals, the university leaders expressed concern that foreign donors -- put off by the conflict on campuses -- were starting to withdraw their funds. They expect further conflict later this year and have requested R400-million from the government to tide them over and stall possible strife over financial exclusions. 

In turn, Mandela has requested a co-operative stance from the institutional managements in allowing police onto campuses to quell conflict.
Traditionally universities have closely guarded their autonomy by trying to keep police off their campuses unless their presence is requested.

Mandela has also asked the ANC Youth League to come out against the trashing of campuses.

Meanwhile, the heat is on to find lasting ways of addressing ongoing problems in the tertiary sector. After weeks of consultation, criticism and outright rejection in some quarters, the National Commission on Higher Education shuffled back to the drawing board this week to rework its document before handing the final draft to Minister of Education Sibusiso Bengu at the end of July. For the commission, it's a case of God is in the principles and the devil's in the detail, as one Chinese philosopher put it.

The commission has been plagued from the outset by the contradictory imperatives of coming up with new policy as quickly as possible on the one hand, and making sure everyone -- particularly those at the centre of the crisis -- are happy with the results on the other.

In this second goal, the commission has failed. While most groups appear to endorse the commission's fundamental principle of "co-operative governance" for the higher education sector, student organisations and other groups -- including the college sector and a significant group of black intellectuals speaking for many historically black universities -- are unhappy with many of the proposals.

Student organisations, particularly the South African Students' Congress, accuse the commission of paying lip service to the notion of consultation. They also reject the idea of a governing higher education council staffed by experts and believe the commission failed to come up with solutions to redress the imbalances in the system.

Last week they passed a "motion of no confidence in the commission" and called on all stakeholders to reject it as a "dismal failure".

However they have mistakenly looked to the commission to come up with miraculous solutions and reflect all their concerns. They have misunderstood the commission's primary role in coming up with a discussion document compiled by experts rather than a report reflecting stakeholder concerns, says executive director Teboho Moja.

"At the end of the day the report is our report and not an aggregation of what everyone has said. We come together to consult once we have something to consult over," said Moja. Intense government-led consultation is expected to take place in the next few months leading up to the drafting of a White Paper at the end of the year.

Major concerns have been expressed over the governance system proposed by the commission, particularly the Higher Education Council.

There is agreement on the need for a co-ordinated governing body separate from the Education Department: however whether it should be made up of stakeholders (including student and staff bodies) or experts and how much power it should have is being hotly contested.

The issue of redress is also the subject of heated debate. The commission punted the notion of "earmarked" funding, so that institutions be rewarded with funding for producing the necessary graduates for the country's human resource development. However the historically black universities and student groups believe this does not go far enough in restoring the current imbalances.

While the commission is adamant that redress money cannot be taken from existing budgets if the sector is to expand and fulfil students' demands for greater access to higher education, there is now an acknowledgement among commissioners that some kind of redress fund -- or overt way of levelling the playing fields -- will have to be worked into new policy.

Another hotly contested issue is that of divisions between institutions. Increasingly, technikons and universities are taking on each other's functions but some in the sector believe the boundaries should be put back in place. The commission favours flexibility in this instance, allowing institutions to define their own role, but many of the technikons, historically black universities and technical colleges favour keeping the functions distinct. The technical colleges fear losing their identity by falling under the umbrella of higher education.

The ANC has yet to formulate its policy position and will do so after a workshop next month. Blade Nzimande, head of the parliamentary portfolio committee on education, said the commission was faced with the dilemma of coming up with long-term solutions as a matter of urgency. Piecemeal changes would only bring short-term rewards, he said.

"The report was neither an exclusively expert report nor one that simply reflected the views of the stakeholders," said Nzimande, adding that it was not inconceivable that a Green Paper could differ significantly from the commission's report.

Nzimande said students were at the cutting edge of educational transformation and their concerns must be looked at.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa ANC Woos IFP in Parliament


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Johannesburg - Home Affairs Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi's budget vote in Parliament last week could have been the cue for a tongue-lashing from ANC MPs. Instead, they kept quiet.

ANC members say the restraint was deliberate. "We don't want Buthelezi leaving the Cabinet," explained a senior ANC MP. 

Yet such an explanation raises more questions than answers. Firstly, should parliamentary scrutiny of government departments be sacrificed for the sake of better relations between political parties?

And secondly, why are the ANC and Inkatha warming to each other on the eve of the KwaZulu-Natal municipal elections?

Everybody in Parliament has noticed the thawing of relations between the two parties: the way the ANC MPs have been clapping appreciatively after Buthelezi's speeches and laughing at his little jokes, and the way Buthelezi himself has been smiling in public. ANC MPs deny they have received "be nice to Buthelezi" instructions from top leadership, but they admit grudgingly attitudes have changed.

One reason suggested for this warming is that the peace process is taking off in KwaZulu-Natal and this new-found sense of brotherhood is trickling through to Parliament.

But no one will comment publicly on the nature of the new IFP-ANC relationship, not even MPs from other parties. Neither can anybody explain why the two parties, after being at each other's throats for such a long time, are suddenly seeing eye to eye.

However, speculation abounds. According to one theory coming from the ANC, the impending National Party withdrawal from cabinet has left Buthelezi a much happier man, because he feels he is now on an equal footing with Mandela in Cabinet, and does not have to share the limelight with FW de Klerk.

But sources in the NP say that the ANC is warming to the IFP because it is scared of an opposition alliance which could combine the NP resources with the IFP black vote. The fear of a powerful opposition, particularly in KwaZulu-Natal and the Western Cape, has driven them into amiability.

IFP members are sceptical about the ANC's "niceness". "It's just a ploy, a pre-election strategy and they are probably going to hit us hard just before the elections," commented one IFP MP.

The ANC's failure to meet its commitment to international mediation on the Constitution still rankles IFP members. Yet the party political debates in Parliament have, for the time being, lost their edge.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


231 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa KwaZulu-Natal Township One Big No-Go Area


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Ann Eveleth


LENGTH: 1107 words


 
Durban - Nobody remembers exactly when Wembezi took the first step down the road to ruin, but today endless rows of gutted houses are witness to the decline of this township in KwaZulu-Natal's Midlands.

Separate taxi ranks for political opponents in nearby Estcourt are a bitter remnant of the days when Wembezi's war threatened to engulf the city centre. The nicknames of sub-sections, like "Ulundi" and "Shell House", testify to the continued polarisation of the township's landscape. An effective curfew operates after dark, residents being terrified of getting caught in the crossfire of the men with guns. 

Wembezi is a microcosm of the ever-shifting patchwork of African National Congress and Inkatha Freedom Party "no-go" areas which make up much of KwaZulu-Natal -- and which pose a major threat to the province's hopes of holding free and fair local government elections on June 26.

The Human Rights Committee (HRC) lists 52 areas where one of the parties is unable to move and campaign freely. HRC Durban researcher Makhubetsi Sekhunyane says the list does not cover all such areas in the province, which remains "essentially one big no-go area".

In Wembezi, one of the province's most insatiable war-zones, three of the township's six sections are no-go areas -- C section (IFP), "5-room Depot" (ANC) and "Longhomes" (ANC). The other three -- Mahashini, Nkwezela and VQ section -- are fiercely contested terrain, claimed by both parties as strongholds.

The two party leaders in Wembezi, ANC chair "Teaspoon" Mhkize and the IFP deputy mayor in Escort, "Spitfire" Dlamini, say they welcome the recent peace efforts announced by their provincial leaders, but warn it will take more than high-level agreements to end the bloodshed.

Meeting briefly this week at the local police station, the two school principals shook hands, laughed together like old friends and exchanged invitations to put up election posters in their respective strongholds. "We can talk about any problem we have and find a solution together, we have no quarrel between us," said Mkhize and Dlamini in near unison. "The problem is there are some people who don't want peace."

Mkhize and Dlamini have made at least five peace bids over the past three years; all have failed to end the nightly staccato of gunfire which the HRC says has claimed at least 137 lives since 1992, and which keeps the township shrouded in fear.

Captain Obrie Nzimande of the Public Order Policing Unit joined the two men in a renewed peace effort when he arrived at the station in March. "Since then there have been nights when not a single shot has been fired," he boasts.

While the confidence Nzimande appears to have won from both sides marks a significant departure from earlier claims of police complicity in the conflict, the death of at least 25 people in the township since March -- including five already this month -- along with a host of attempted murders indicate peace is still little more than a dream.

Although Dlamini and Mkhize both blamed "intruders" for fanning the violence, they were talking about different people. Mkhize pointed to the intervention of IFP provincial MP David Ntombela and IFP Senator Phillip Powell whose visits to the area, he said, "are always followed by violence".

Citing "internal IFP problems" as a reason for the ANC's recent growth in the township, Mhkize said: "The IFP accuses its own people of being ANC, and then they get attacked and come to join the ANC."

ANC election candidate Petros Mtshali agreed. An IFP leader in the township until last December, Mtshali said he came under attack after the IFP accused his daughter of dating an amaqabane (comrade).

"I didn't know who this person was, but at one meeting a youth pulled a gun and said he was going to shoot me. After that, my cousin was killed and a gunshot came through my front door and a group of youths came to my house looking for the ANC. Then I joined the ANC," he said.

The IFP's Dlamini -- a relative of Mtshali -- claimed a liaison between Mtshali's daughter and an ANC activist had led to the mother, and later Mthsali himself, being converted to the ANC.

While Dlamini admitted "there have been some cases" of IFP supporters being labelled ANC, he argued that the same was true of his opponents: "The real problem in Wembezi is the people who are profiting from the violence -- the criminals."

Dlamini blamed the constant turf battles on youths who deserted their IFP-supporting parents in Nkwezela and other sections, and fled to the ANC's Depot-section stronghold: "From there they have been terrorising people in other sections. When the victims flee their houses, these criminals take them over; they take the furniture, the stereos, everything, to make some money because they have no parents and no jobs. What is needed here are jobs, so nobody would be around to cause trouble."

The ANC also cites socio-economic factors as contributing to the violence. Deeply rutted dirt roads, sparse phone and electric lines, and a wrecked school and community centre are evidence of the township's dire under-development.

ANC supporter Phikeleli Zuma -- a refugee from Nkwezela -- blamed the housing shortage and urban influx from outlying rural areas for stalling peace in the area. "We can both sign a piece of paper with some agreements. But after the agreement, I will want to go back to my house. When somebody else is living in my house, I will have to fight to get it back. Then what happens to the peace?" he asked.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


232 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Holomisa Sparks ANC Truth Row With Tutu


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Johannesburg - The David and Goliath battle between Deputy Minister of Environmental Affairs and Tourism Bantu Holomisa and the African National Congress has thrown tensions within the party into sharp relief and highlighted apparent confusion over its approach to dealing with the Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

The stand-off between Holomisa and the ANC over its bid to discipline him for remarks he made while testifying before the commission now threatens to be eclipsed by a broader political row sparked by Deputy President Thabo Mbeki's assertion that ANC members should consult party leaders before making their submissions before the commission.

In a swift and vehement reaction, commission chair Archbishop Desmond Tutu gave notice he would be seeking clarity from the ANC on a position which could discourage members from coming forward, saying: "We find it impossible to believe that a political party would seek to muzzle its rank-and- file members by vetting their statements before they approach the commission."

On Thursday, Holomisa formally objected to being disciplined for saying Public Enterprises Minister Stella Sigcau, when prime minister of Transkei, took a R50 000 cut of a ER2-million bribe allegedly paid by hotel magnate Sol Kerzner to sew up gambling rights in the bantustan. 

ANC disciplinary committee chair, Water Affairs Minister Kader Asmal, informed Holomisa of his rights by fax on Wednesday, but did not specify a hearing date or the charges, Holomisa told the Mail & Guardian.

"I will refuse to appear before any disciplinary hearing," he said. He did not intend to undermine the hearing, but objected to it. "I don't see how they can say I was acting outside my rights. The ANC has no policy barring members from going to the truth commission."

There was "no rule" saying ANC members should first have their statements before the commission vetted by the leadership and there had been no discussion of this in the ANC's national executive committee, he said. If such a rule existed it should have been communicated.

"We have discussed the ANC leadership making a presentation on behalf of the organisation, but as a strategic input. I went before the commission, which is constituted by an act of Parliament, as a former head of government and a concerned citizen."

The issue has divided ANC members: the party's Women's League, led by Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, rallied behind him this week, saying: "We suspect that Holomisa is guilty of telling too much truth." By contrast, the ANC Youth League, which backed Mbeki for the position of ANC deputy president in 1994, said it had "full confidence" in the disciplinary committee and would not comment until it had tabled its recommendations before the NEC.

Thabo Masebe, youth league secretary for information and publicity, said he did not believe the suggestion that members first clear truth commission submissions with party leadership would lead to information being suppressed. "It is more a question of the party being informed if submissions were to have implications for other party members."

While he did not believe the row between Holomisa and the ANC would divide the organisation, "if it is handled very badly it will have the potential of causing problems".

Holomisa, a maverick whose outspokenness has proved a source of irritation to the ANC hierarchy on several occasions in the past, commands wide support among rank and file members. Elections for the ANC's national executive committee in 1994 saw him come in with the most votes, with Madikizela-Mandela fifth.

He was rebuked by Mandela last year after criticising the way the ANC handled its sacking of Madikizela-Mandela as arts and culture deputy minister and suggesting a campaign was underway within the organisation to "vilify and isolate" certain members.

He was in trouble again later for accusing an elitist ANC clique of trying to sideline members seen as "populist", and subsequently apologised. The spectacle of the ANC seeking to discipline one of its deputy ministers and Holomisa's defiant stance has obliterated the thrust of what he told the commission -- a detailed account of the National Party government's attempts, both covert and overt, to destabilise the Transkei after Holomisa came to power in a 1987 coup which toppled President George Matanzima and ousted Sigcau.

"My statements at the truth commission were not intended to call for the commission to investigate Sigcau or for her to be fired from government. I was overviewing the circumstances of Transkei's destabilisation by South Africa."

Sigcau has never denied receiving the money. She was cleared of corruption in 1988 by the Alexander Commission, which could make no adverse finding against her on available evidence and did not recommend any further investigation, while noting the source of the money was illicit.

But the battle has thrown into sharp relief tensions between Holomisa and Sigcau, who spent years operating as a politician within the bantustan under the corrupt regime of the Matanzimas, yet was appointed to Cabinet in 1994 by President Mandela. Holomisa, who during his rule provided the ANC space to operate in his territory and suffered several Pretoria-driven coup attempts and budget squeezes for his pains, was given a relatively junior position.

The ANC now has to contend with public perceptions of its action, coming in the wake of Health Minister Nkosazana Zuma being judged by the party to have emerged "without a blemish" from the Sarafina II debacle. Rank and file members, thrown into confusion by lack of clarity on whether they should first clear submissions to the truth commission with party leaders, are also asking why Holomisa should be disciplined "for telling the truth" when the public protector had found that Zuma misled Parliament over the Aids play.

Sigcau refused to deny or confirm that she -- reportedly along with Sports Minister Steve Tshwete -- laid the complaint against Holomisa.

Holomisa said it appeared the decision to discipline him had been taken by ANC officials. "One would have expected a matter of national importance like this would at least have been discussed by the NEC or the national working committee," he said.

He had asked ANC secretary general, Cyril Ramaphosa, to refer the matter to the NEC "because of its sensitivity" but had received no response.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Police 'Knee-jerk denials' to End


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Johannesburg - Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi is determined to bury the culture in which government gave the police carte blanche to waste taxpayers' money fighting their "knee jerk denials" of human rights abuses.

In an interview with the Mail & Guardian, Secretary for Safety and Security Azhar Cachalia spelled out how Mufamadi, he and National Police Commissioner George Fivaz were trying to inject an accountable, human rights culture into the police. "I want to send a clear message that we are pushing for a clean break from the past."

Instead of the police pumping hundreds of thousands of rands into "knee jerk denials" in cases lodged against them, under the new era the department will investigate cases, settle if the police are liable, and take appropriate action against the police responsible. 

Cachalia also announced that Mufamadi had decided to withdraw an appeal being fought by the police in his name against a R180 000 damages award to former MK soldier Japie Maphalala who was tortured and imprisoned unlawfully in 1992.

Despite the move to have a more thorough investigation into the merits of fighting cases, it would take a lot of time and effort to "turn the ship around". He said there were dubious cases, such as Maphalala, which started under the old regime before he and Fivaz were appointed, and which were being fought in Mufamadi's name.

The case, a prime example of wasteful and unaccountable litigation, had been brought to his attention when the Mail & Guardian contacted Mufamadi for comment. He said it had been difficult to find out who in the department had authorised lawyers acting in the department's name to appeal the damages award.

Cachalia said the written argument from lawyers acting in Mufamadi's name was morally and legally indefensible. The lawyers argued that as a soldier, Japie Maphalala should have been trained for such abuses. "It is shocking that the minister should be associated with such argument. This is certainly not the view of the minister. From now on it must be clear that government is accountable for its actions."

Not only would the minister withdraw the appeal, but he would also contact Maphalala's lawyers to ask them to bring criminal charges against his torturers. "Under the old era the police would not have thought it strange to defend this kind of case to the bitter end and then settle 15 minutes before a hearing after running up huge legal costs."

Cachalia said what was even more offensive about the way the old system ran was the "absolute abdication of responsibility by the state attorney". He said part of the problem was that the state attorney's office was understaffed and underskilled. "There is no tradition of doing anything other than hold counsel's bag." He said he was also troubled by the choice of counsel recruited to fight these cases, where in many instances the legal bills outstripped the damages claim.

Under the reformed system, the department would obviously have a say in what kinds of argument were put forward. "The department and officials must be responsible for investigating the merits of these cases."

"We are initiating a process of legal reform which will change the relationship between the department and state attorneys. The department will now have a direct say in what criteria state attorneys use to brief counsel and what arguments they use."

Cachalia stressed it was impossible to monitor all cases being fought by the police. But he said rules were being laid down so important cases of principle were brought to the attention of a senior official in Mufamadi's department. Fivaz was setting up an information system which would give department officials access to key information on what was happening in the police department.

Cachalia said it was not really a question of old guard officials undermining the ministry, but more that they and state attorneys were used to acting in an environment in which the minister abdicated responsibility. "That is how you get this kind of case (Maphalala)."


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Police Lawyers Cash In On Abuse Claims


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Johannesburg - Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi is battling to control old guard civil servants who are wasting hundreds of thousands of rands of taxpayers' money by fighting cases on behalf of the police which appear to be against the public interest.

In several instances the cases, fought in Mufamadi's name, are against ANC victims of police abuse in the early 1990s, putting the minister in the embarrassing position of fighting his old comrades. Instead of reaching an out-of-court settlement, the state has on several occasions fought these cases at great expense all the way to the appellate division in Bloemfontein. Two attorneys specialising in human rights cases told the Mail & Guardian Mufamadi had at times personally intervened but then appeared unable to bring the bureaucrats in the state attorney's office to heel. 

"Government officials are fighting to avoid settling these cases with the same vigour they used to keep people in detention in the old days," one said.

The civil servants' and state attorneys' zeal appears to have enriched a select group of advocates who have specialised in acting for security force personnel. They include Barry Roux, "Cor" Grobelaar, and "Flip" Hattingh. Roux, whose curriculum vitae includes representing the police during the Goldstone commission, has fought many of the claims for damages against the police. Hattingh has earned more than R2-million defending Vlakplaas commander Colonel Eugene de Kock.

During the apartheid era, a batch of advocates earned huge fees fighting for the state in political cases. A hint of the gravy train emerged during the Harms Commission of Inquiry into the Civil Cooperation Bureau, when two advocates were reprimanded by the Pretoria Bar Council for charging excessive fees.

Last week the M&G reported Mufamadi was fighting a R180 000 damages award against a former MK soldier, Japie Maphalala, who was locked up unlawfully for 144 days in 1992. Judge John Coetzee awarded the damages in the Rand Supreme Court in February 1995 after cataloguing the torture inflicted upon Maphalala. Coetzee hit out at former Law and Order Minister Hernus Kriel for abusing the "emergency" legislation of the apartheid state. He said Maphalala had been electrocuted on his penis and ear, had his testicles squeezed, and had been shown a room full of bodies from the Boipatong massacre.

Although Coeztee denied lawyers acting on Mufamadi's behalf leave to appeal the damages award -- which was a record sum -- the lawyers went on to appeal directly to Bloemfontein and succeeded in getting leave to appeal. Mufamadi has since withdrawn the appeal (see story alongside).

Senior officials in Mufamadi's department only learned of the case when the M&G approached them for comment. They were struck by the absurdity that their legal team, headed by Bruce Burman, SC, was arguing for a R60 000 reduction which was likely to be less than their bill.

In another case, lawyers acting in Mufamadi's name fought damages claims from four ANC members who were tortured by police trying to get confessions out of them in 1993. The men were arrested by the police and locked up in Sebokeng. During a criminal trial which saw one of them convicted of murder, there was a "trial within a trial" to discover whether the police had tortured a confession out of the accused.

Judge Roos found the evidence of assaults had been so overwhelming that the prosecution did not argue that the confessions could be admitted. In fact, the prosecution had expressed shock at the damning evidence heard against the police. Lawyers acting for the ANC men sued for damages in 1993 and have pleaded with Mufamadi's office to settle the matter.

By March of this year, Mufamadi's office had still not settled despite assuring the lawyers in a letter that "taxpayers' money is not wasted in unnecessary litigation where the facts and evidence clearly show liability on the part of the state".

But it is not only Mufamadi's department which has puzzled and infuriated legal commentators with its approach to litigation in the new era. Last month, the Home Affairs Department opted for the apparently untenable position of defending in the
Constitutional Court a lynchpin of apartheid censorship legislation, the 1974 Publications Act. "It is astonishing that the government is defending apartheid legislation and not the Constitution," said one advocate.

A few weeks later in the same court, the commissioner for inland revenue, represented by three advocates, conceded he had unlawfully raided Glynn Rudolph's office on the eve of the April 1994 elections.

Despite fighting Rudolph all the way to the appellate division, the commissioner capitulated in written argument days before the Constitutional Court heard the matter.

It conceded Rudolph had been in the right all along.

Rudolph's lawyer, Gilbert Marcus, SC, said this was an unfortunate case of where unnecessary litigation could have been stopped in its tracks in April 1994.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Deputy Says Buthelezi Knew About SADF Training


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Ann Eveleth


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Durban- The trial of former defence minister Magnus Malan took a dramatic turn this week when Inkatha Freedom Party deputy secretary general Melchizedec "MZ" Khumalo suddenly turned on his political master.

Testifying in his own defence in the Durban Supreme Court murder trial he faces together with Malan and 15 others, a surprisingly relaxed Khumalo implicated the man he has served with infinite loyalty for more than 20 years.

Giving credence to State Security Council documents presented to court earlier by the prosecution, Khumalo said the documents made it "obvious" that IFP leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi and former KwaZulu Police (KZP) deputy commissioner Brigadier Sipho Mathe were aware of South African Defence Force (SADF) involvement in the 1986 paramilitary training of 200 IFP supporters in the Caprivi Strip.

Testifying that he had recruited the 200 on Mathe's request, in the belief that a private security company -- Swart Security Services -- would train them for incorporation into the KZP, Khumalo said: "The documents indicate that (the SADF involvement) was not something (Buthelezi and Mathe) wished should be known, because I was not personally even told of this ... What becomes clear to me is that their withholding the fact that the military was involved indicated that they did not give me the whole true version of what was really happening here," he said. 

Khumalo said he realised "by the end of 1987" that the SADF was involved in the project.

Khumalo's testimony marks a dramatic departure from his erstwhile loyal protection of Buthelezi. When the Mail & Guardian exposed the Inkathagate scandal in 1991, Khumalo -- then Buthelezi's personal assistant -- took the blame.

Last December, sources close to Khumalo's family told the M&G that his relationship with the IFP leader spanned 20 years, beginning when Khumalo worked as a propaganda officer for Eschel Roodie's notorious Department of Information.

At the time of the 1987 KwaMakhutha massacre, Khumalo disappeared from the political scene after Inkathagate, later re-emerging in connection with subsequent party paramilitary projects. Believed to have fallen out with the IFP after the intervention of the party's white militarists, including senator Phillip Powell, Khumalo later reappeared in 1994 when he was elected to his current leadership post.

Denying any knowledge of the massacre of 13 friends and relatives of United Democratic Front activist Victor Ntuli, Khumalo told the court he had received many reports on violence between supporters of the UDF and IFP at the time, but he did not remember reading about the massacre.

Khumalo testified that his involvement with the trainees on their return from the Caprivi had been plagued by problems as most had not been incorporated into the KZP. He said he discussed the problems with Buthelezi and Mathe, and Buthelezi eventually suggested he should meet with Malan.

Khumalo said he had raised problems during an August 1988 meeting with Malan in parliament, during which Malan "said to me that I must remain with this project and report to him any problems".

Khumalo testified that he had met state witness JP Opperman "about five times" at the Durban Malibu hotel and the Ulundi Holiday Inn, but denied having been present during "mock attacks" which the state alleged were conducted prior to the KwaMakhutha massacre.

Khumalo said Opperman had issued him with two bullet-proof vests, one for himself and one for Buthelezi: "He said he wanted to test the groin part of the vest."

Khumalo said he took Opperman to a donga five kilometres outside Ulundi where shots were fired at the vest. He could not confirm whether state witness Andre Cloete had been present, but denied that anyone else was present. Opperman and Cloete earlier testified that Khumalo had been present when they took 10 offensive unit members through "dry runs".

Khumalo is the seventh accused to the testify since the seven defence teams opened their case this week. Earlier, six Caprivi trained accused denied knowledge of the massacre or any conspiracy to kill members of the ANC,UDF and related organisations.

The six said they believed they had been trained as members of the KZP.

Khumalo's cross-examination is expected to continue Friday, after which the 10 former security officials will begin their defence.

Malan's attorney, Sam Maritz, SC, confirmed that Malan would take the stand in his own defence. He said he intended calling former SADF chief Tienie Groenewald -- against who charges were dismissed -- to testify, along with "military experts".


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance G7 Summit To Establish Debt Landmark


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Alex Brummer


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Johannesburg - Leaders of the G7 leading industrial countries will use their summit in France on June 27 to launch the "Lyons terms", a debt initiative that could reduce the debt of the world's poorest countries by up to 90% by the year 2005.

In a confidential paper presented to the executive board of the World Bank this week, president James Wolfensohn will promise the bank's unconditional support for its share of the debt plan, which will cost at least $5,6-billion.

The bank cautions, however, that if export growth in the recipient countries fails to meet expectations, the cost could rise rapidly to $7,7-billion or more, with the larger part of the burden falling on the bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). 

President Jacques Chirac, who will host the G7 meeting, has made clear he wants Lyons to become a landmark in the history of international finance, symbolised by efforts made by industrial countries to resolve the problems of their poorer
counterparts. Several former French colonies, such as Cote d'Ivoire, would stand to benefit.

The Lyons terms would offer a significant advance on the Trinidad and Naples terms, which only covered 67% of debt and never addressed the far more substantial problem of funds owed to the multi- lateral organisations.

Although the World Bank under Wolfensohn has thrown itself wholeheartedly behind the plan, it has partly been hampered by the IMF. The IMF has insisted the initiative be directly linked to the refinancing of its own fund to help poor countries -- the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility. This would require a gold sale by the IMF to fund its contribution.

Under the revised World Bank plan (dated June 4) the commitment by the bank, through a special trust fund, "to reduce the present value of a country's debt would be unconditional". The bank plans to make allocations "of available net income or surplus" to such a trust fund and believes the IMF should do likewise, rather than waiting for gold sales.

The revised plan also proposes to cut the waiting time for countries qualifying for multilateral debt relief. Instead of waiting up to six years, poor countries -- such as Uganda, Bolivia and Niger -- - could see benefits after three years.

Of 41 highly indebted countries examined by the World Bank, some 19 are classified as "possibly stressed or unsustainable" and therefore considered eligible for the 90% debt reductions.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


237 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Facelift Or Whitewash For Johannesburg Stock Exchange?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Aspasia Karras


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

Johannesburg - Amid all the fanfare surrounding the restructuring of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, two important issues -- equity and liquidity -- have still to be addressed. Do the adjustments deal adequately with access to the market by disadvantaged communities, and has the liquidity problem really been tackled?

JSE executive president Roy Andersen responds: "We undertook the restructuring with two perspectives in mind. First, to ensure we are relevant in the new South Africa, and second, to interest and secure the foreign investor." 

Commentators have for years argued that the exchange was merely a paper-chasing-paper exercise, without playing the role of an enabling environment where entrepreneurs could form companies in order to raise capital.

Andersen feels the restructuring should transform this perception. In the first instance, he explains, the JSE education programme is going a long way towards providing access and incentives to new investors from disadvantaged communities.

More than 1 000 students have graduated from the JSE night school and two educational officers visit factories, trade unions, and chambers of commerce. It has also launched investment competitions in the radio and print media, and flighted audio-visual material on the SABC.

"In this way we are demystifying the entire concept. Furthermore, the new black-controlled listed companies on the exchange have brought 20 000 new investors to the market. We have lowered the entrance requirements for venture capital to R500 000 to make the market more accessible."

Andersen also argues that the new listing category for development capital has been added to satisfy the requirements of the Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) and companies listing must be involved in social service ventures.

Interestingly, capital requirements for the Development Capital Market double the requirements for the Venture Capital Markets.

"All information concerning new investment by black investors is purely anecdotal, but black investment through pension funds is enormous," concedes Andersen. "Two out of the 47 brokers' firms are black controlled. We also introduced an affirmative action policy three years ago."

But Dr Patrick Bond, senior economist at the National institute for Economic policy (NIEP), argues that "the JSE is still an overpriced casino, sucking in ordinary citizens' insurance premiums and pension contributions via a small number of enormous, unaccountable institutions. The old argument ... that such funds should rather be used for development, not driving share prices ever higher ... still applies."

Andersen, however, is indifferent to this kind of critique. He points out that the JSE has made great strides -- an investigatory team is in London assessing international practices such as tax incentives for investors so more progress can be made.

But it is the systemic and structural changes that are more interesting. Apart from the move to automation with the Johannesburg Equities Trading (JET) system, the exchange has introduced dual capacity trading and new listing requirements.

Andersen is clear about the impact on investors. The listing requirements allow for more disclosure. Second, brokers separate their own funds from client funds, providing the client with more protection from insolvency.

Third, the fact that limited liability companies, and non-stockbrokers, can own part of a full member, allows banks to become members and provides more accessibility as more outlets to buy stock become available.

While the system may be costly in the immediate term, Andersen is categorical that in the medium term it will make the entire process cheaper.

Fair enough, but have these reforms addressed the major issues, for example, the results of the World Competitiveness Report showing South Africa ranking lowest in the world in terms of insider trading?

Andersen claims the JSE has raised its concerns with Parliament. He sits on an Advisory Committee on Company Law that is addressing the issue through a special committee on insider trading.

Committee chairman Mervyn King of Frame textiles says the committee "is positive that the government is aware of the problem".

However, the government adopted the RDP as its policy frame of reference and seems to register a lot more than simply awareness, argues Bond.

The RDP clearly states in the section on reform of the financial sector that: "The apartheid system severely distorted the South African financial system. A handful of large financial institutions, all linked closely to the dominant conglomerate, centralise most of the country's financial assets, but prove unable to serve most of the black community, especially women."

Although King would not comment on the committee process, he did state that he believed insider trading was "not worse because of concentration".

What then would ensure that the market becomes liquid? For Andersen the solution is clear. "Government has halved the transaction tax, but investors still think twice before turning over; the other half must go. Secondly, exchange controls must be lifted, we must be able to trade freely offshore."

Bond responds: "Andersen brags that last year more than half of JSE trading was sourced overseas. But beginning in February, within just 10 days a huge amount of hot money that had entered South Africa in 1995 fled, leaving the country 25% poorer in US dollar terms and contributing enormously to financial instability and economic uncertainty.

"When this happened in Mexico, even the International Monetary Fund agreed that capital controls on incoming hot money should have been applied. South Africa's big financial institutions obviously want to attract more hot money, arrange asset swops to take as much of their own asset base out as they can, and force government to fully liberalise exchange controls. But with the volatility now apparent in financial markets, this could very likely result in a Mexico-style meltdown."

The worst-case scenario for the JSE, according to Andersen, is if the 51% of foreign investors in the JSE all withdraw; the best case is a liquid market with the JSE becoming the regional market for Southern Africa, a process that is already under way.

"The approach we have taken will be an effective way of facilitating privatisation and a vehicle for creating a middle class in South Africa."

Bond concludes: "The kind of reforms the NIEP advocates are increased share transaction taxes and capital gains taxes, as well as tighter controls on international financial capital flight. These are also reforms promised in the RDP. It is a reflection of the financiers' back-room political power that the RDP implementation is taking so long."

Lifting exchange controls should not result in capital flight, Andersen argues. "It depends on when and how it is done, at the right time it could enhance confidence, at the wrong time it would be clearly dangerous."


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Rights to Mozambican Gas Fields In Doubt


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Johannesburg - United States exploration giant Enron is in danger of losing its exclusive rights to develop Mozambique's Pande gas fields as it has only two weeks to come up with a major client for the gas.

A senior South African government official said this week it was very unlikely Enron would sign up with the Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) by the end of June when its "exclusive agreement" expired. 

The IDC, touted as Enron's only hope, is investigating building a R2,5-billion steel plant at Phalaborwa in the Northern Province, but the project is only at pre-feasibility stage. "Enron have been chasing after lots of possible clients but they have come up with very little," the source said.

He said Mozambique's government was likely to put the job of tapping the gas up for tender shortly after its deal with Enron ran out. A successful exploitation of the gas would provide a crucial shot in the arm for Mozambique's war-ravaged economy.

Last month, Enron said it was close to signing an agreement with the IDC. The government source said the IDC project would probably use the gas in at least five years -- but the gas would be tapped by whichever company won the tender.

Neither Enron nor Mozambican Energy Minister John Kachimila could be reached for comment.

South Africa's trade and Industry department is understood to be keen for Sasol to bag the gas, and then market it in South Africa. However, Sasol and Enron fell out over the development of the fields.

The Financial Mail reported this week that Enron, which was brought into the project by Sasol, went behind Sasol's back to secure exclusive rights to the field.

Sasol managing director Pieter Cox said recently Sasol was still interested in the fields.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Plans Uncertain For South African Oil Firm


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Johannesburg - At the time of going to press, Engen, which has recently had its profits savaged by hefty restructuring costs, had not yet announced details of the deal which is believed to involve a foreign oil player.

On Tuesday it suspended its share price ahead of the announcement. Market speculation pegged Elf and Mobil as its most likely suitors. Sasol, which has been eyeing a tie-up with Engen, was eliminated from the list as no cautionary announcement was slapped on its shares. 

But whichever company it is, a much stronger Engen will probably thwart plans for a national oil company. Senior officials in the trade and industry and finance departments are keen to set up such a company, which has become known as Sanoco, to counter the influence of the international oil majors in the South African fuel retail market.

At the heart of the proposed oil giant lies a merger between Sasol and Engen. It recently appeared that Total SA was also part of the equation. Both Engen, South Africa's only listed fuel retailer, and Sasol are understood to be wary of Sanoco.

Now, a merger between Sasol and Engen appears out of the question. Sasol loses out badly as a marriage with Engen would have given it a stake in the lucrative retail market from which it is barred in terms of an agreement with the crude oil companies that buy Sasol's subsidised synthetic fuel.

Commentators say that assuming Sanoco plans stay afloat without a Sasol and Engen merger, the backing of either the United States's Mobil or France's Elf should enable Engen to resist pressure from government to become part of Sanoco.

A senior official in a South African fuel company, who was betting on Mobil, said: "Sanoco is dead if Engen teams up with Mobil. With American money behind it, it will be easier to resist efforts to get it into Sanoco. No foreign player like Mobil or Elf would want to get into something like that."

Analysts say that apart from helping Engen dodge Sanoco, an international tie-up would also arm it to bag a large slice of the retail market when it is eventually deregulated.

Sanoco's backers are understood to be convinced of the need for what they call a "big maverick player", which could undercut the price of the other oil companies in a deregulated market.

So, although playing along with Sanoco would win Engen and Sasol favour with the government, they face the prospect of being part of a company designed to keep prices down.

Outgoing Minerals and Energy Affairs Minister Pik Botha never discussed Sanoco in detail, leaving the plan to be thrashed out by colleagues in the trade and industry and finance departments.

Botha's long-serving aide Roland Darroll said this week he was keen to work under Botha's African National Congress replacement, Penuell Maduna. "It would be good to work under an ANC minister," he said.

Botha gave one of his last public speeches before ending an extraordinary political career launched under John Vorster.

He told the Sub-Saharan Oil and Minerals Conference in Johannesburg: "I, in the meantime, have no intention of becoming a recluse. I may still be useful to drive a truck or two on certain roads which I know well ... There may still be a distance to be travelled."


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


240 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance South Africa's Great Expectations


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Madeleine Waskernagel


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Johannesburg - On the eve of a top-level government and private-sector roadshow targeting international investors in Cannes, all eyes are on the government's long- awaited growth plan.

The task of selling South Africa abroad is becoming more and more a priority on everyone's agenda, says acting director general of finance, Maria Ramos. But it won't be easy: "South Africa is being looked at in a more realistic light; the post-election glow has given way to hard analysis on the part of international investors. 

"Global competition means we have to offer more than most -- even those countries with less positive fundamentals," she says.

Providing that may prove more difficult. The original growth scenario mooted by Deputy President Thabo Mbeki in February envisaged 6% growth by the year 2000 based on a 10% boost to exports and investment. But with the upswing in worldwide demand for commodities fading fast, that projection looks unsustainable.

Certainly our manufacturing industry is not strong enough to take up the slack. Investment goals, with the associated Keynesian kick-start, are also proving unrealistic.

"The government has been very good on intentions, setting up yet more committees and commissions and concentrating on consensus-seeking, but its record has been dire in terms of making difficult choices," says an analyst.

This time is not expected to be any different. "It (the growth plan presented by Finance Minister Trevor Manuel) will be yet another whitewash, with the government telling us what they think we want to hear.

"What they haven't realised is that 6% growth is not attainable without sacrifices. As it is we're going to have a tough time getting to 3% growth for the foreseeable future."

Mbeki heads the list of dignitaries attending the three day conference in Cannes; with virtually every government department represented, the pressure will be on ministers to impress the Europeans with hard proof of policy direction. Last year's conference in Switzerland resulted in positive feedback, but this year's key speakers -- Manuel, Reserve Bank governor Chris Stals, Public Enterprises Minister Stella Sigcau and Trade Minister Alec Erwin -- can no longer rely on goodwill alone.

Ken Andrew, the Democratic Party's economics representative, says attainable, short-terms goals are more important than long-term plans.

"We've been let down so many times that expectations are running very high. We need to address the problems of fiscal discipline and economic growth by setting short, medium and long-term targets. Then we can quickly ascertain if they are being met and change course accordingly.

"With so much to do at once, the government has to prioritise and compromise. It must set the parameters and stick to them, enforcing them rigidly within all the different departments. It won't be easy; the Cabinet faces tough decisions, but we could end up sinking the whole country if we try to do everything at once."

The biggest sense of expectancy was felt in the financial markets -- the rand was firmer and bonds weakened on rumours of concrete proposals on privatisation and the lifting of exchange controls. The concomitant cost of disappointment will be high.

"Any fudge will not go down well," says Dennis Dykes, chief economist of Nedcor. "It is vital that we have more than just rhetoric and grand ideals to take to France on Monday. We can't go empty-handed," says Ian Robinson, executive director of the Building Industries Federation of South Africa, and one of the participants.
-0


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


241 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Some Pearls Of Wisdom From Pele


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Paul Wilson


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Johannesburg - Pele is a lousy tipster -- his prediction for big success before the start of USA 94 was ill-starred Colombia -- so the Croatians can start worrying now.

In England for the start of Euro 96, the great Brazilian was asked the inevitable question, and confessed he was struggling for an answer. "It's very hard to pick the eventual champions of a tournament like this, because it seems all the leading teams are very even," he said. "The difference between the sides is not too big, but I did see Croatia not long ago and I like the way they play. They have some good players, they play very nice football. If there is going to be a surprise winner I would go for them. Portugal, too, have impressed me." 

If this sounds vaguely insulting to the established powers of Europe, it is not meant to be. "The best teams in the world are over here," Pele admitted. "If you took Europe out of the World Cup, it would be quite a different tournament. Normally, you look to England, Germany and Holland to be strong, and I don't think it will be any different this time. England have got to have a chance as they are the hosts, and this is definitely the time for them to wake up and come good.

"Holland, France, even Germany play openly at the moment, but England still look to me to be playing defensively," he said. "Their line-up looks defensive, anyway. Playing with one forward is not going out for a win, is it? I think Alan Shearer is a good player, but he must get lonely up there on his own."

Okay, teams must defend when they lose the ball, but when England have the ball they seem afraid to go forward.

Pele has been disappointed by England in the 30 years since he was kicked out of the World Cup here in 1966.

'Everybody supported England in 1966, but in all the years afterwards we didn't see them do any good,' he said. The limited glory that was 1970 and 1990 fails to register on the Pele scale, and the Brazilian minister of sport was particularly disappointed at England's absence from America two years ago. 'I spent a lot of time trying to get the World Cup to come to the USA, and I kept telling people that England would be one of the attractions, then they didn't come,' he complained. 'I think England need to wake up and realise that the defensive way they play is a handicap.'

Defensive is not a word that many coaches prefer to use, but Pele is not a coach, and presumably never could be, since his preference for attacking football makes Kevin Keegan look conservative. He tends to fall out with coaches who argue in favour of safety-first tactics or over-technical approaches, and had words with Carlos Parreira, the Brazilian coach, over the way the simple purity of the traditional Brazil style was compromised in the last World Cup.

There is a simple purity, too, about the way Pele sees international football. 'I was totally against the way we played in America, and I told Parreira so,' he said simply. 'Parreira said "Pele, we came here to win, we had to play like that." I can respect that, but I don't necessarily agree with it. If you ask the Brazilian fans, they don't like the way we play, either. But sometimes we are the best team in the competition, as we were in Spain in 1984, and we don't win, so it is difficult. But if you always play positively, you win more matches than you lose, and you give the supporters what they want.'

Parreira, not to mention Terry Venables, one of his most ardent admirers, would view this as over- simplistic, not to say over-romantic. The game has moved on, Venables argues, from the time when talent and sheer ability was enough to win tournaments. The England coach is fond of quoting his Brazilian counterpart's dictum that the star of the team must be the whole team, and undoubtedly draws inspiration from Parreira's successful attempt to introduce discipline and organisation into his side in the face of overwhelming public opposition.

'I would like to see England play more for a win. But I am not a coach, except at home in my house. And in my house I think everybody should play positively and play for a win.'


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - General Rugby: Cover Is The Key For Selectors


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Jon Swift


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Johannesburg - By Sunday morning, the 26-strong Springbok squad will be history and the debate on selections will already be in full swing.

All the agreement and criticism of the squad's make- up for the one-off Test against Fiji at Loftus Versfeld on July 2 and the Sanzar series internationals against Australia and New Zealand, which follow immediately, are all part of the healthy climate of debate which is so much part of the magic of man's sporting endeavours.

For Andre Markgraaff and his selection panel, perhaps the greatest problem will be in creating cover in key positions without having the facility to choose two full sides. In some positions, this presents few problems, in others the headaches could reach the proportions of an unmanageable migraine. 

There is also the question of Francois Pienaar's nagging shoulder injury. It is unthinkable that Markgraaff and company can leave as fine a player and as gifted a captain out if he is fit. Pienaar simply means too much to the side and to the game as a whole for this to be a consideration.

He will surely be first choice alongside Ruben Kruger at the side of the scrum, which leads to the question of covering these two. In this regard, Markgraaff has a number of options and one that readily presents itself is to name players who are versatile enough to take over this role given the fact that Kruger operates as well on the blind side as he does as an open side flank.

Here, the thinking could be governed by choosing the on-form Steve Atherton, playing some of the best rugby of his life at lock, and Schutte Bekker to back up Gary Teichmann at No 8.

Teichmann has been almost without peer in this specialist role this season, but moving him to the side of the scrum in an emergency is another option which opens up if he is selected and giving Mark Andrews -- an automatic choice in the second row -- the job he did at the back of the scrum for the Amabokoboko in the World Cup final and semi-final.

Adriaan Richter will doubtless come strongly into the frame. But Bekker is probably a better long-term bet than his veteran Northern Transvaal teammate and fills the gap left by the injury which has ruled Fritz van Heerden out of contention.

Admittedly, this is not an ideal solution, but with three Tests coming up against a trio of nations where the big hit tackle is de rigueur, it will certainly open some avenues in a worst-case injury scenario.

If selecting the Natal pairing of Andrews and Atherton at lock -- and they are the form pair this season -- is the route the selectors follow, the back-up could well come in the form of Hannes Strydom and Johan Ackermann.

Strydom is a known and dependable quantity and Ackermann is a really exciting prospect for the future. The big Northern Transvaler deserves to get the nod ahead of the arguably better line-out skills of his provincial teammate, Krynauw Otto, because of his physical presence, something that has looked to be lacking in Otto on the evidence of Super 12 performances.

Similarly, the thinking on prop forwards revolves around the ability to pack at either side of the scrum. Os du Randt is surely an automatic choice at loose head now he is back in full cry for Free State and exhibiting the form which makes him a standout from a position not renowned for creating players as able to dominate in open play as in the nether regions of the machine room in the set-pieces.

But, with Balie Swart still to make an impact after coming back from surgery, it would be risky in the extreme to pick the World Cup tight-head until he has come back sufficiently strongly at provincial level.

Here, Markgraaff could well go for Garry Pagel, switching the Western Province iron man from the loosehead role he currently fills for his Currie Cup side and backing this pairing up with Toks van der Linde and Marius Hurter.

The hooking berth presents some dilemmas too. John Allan is the form man this season and his understanding in the vital area of the throw-in with Andrews and Atherton has been peerless.

The ability to cover is also a strong consideration in the make-up of the backline players who will make the squad. Andre Joubert is an automatic choice, but Markgraaff will surely look to the exciting emergent talent of Dawie du Toit as back-up with James Small, who started his provincial career in the No 15 jersey as insurance.

Small is back to the form which brought him international recognition in the first place and, with Pieter Hendriks and Justin Swart, should make up the wings.

Swart has been in superb scoring form this season and has provided many of the flashes in an otherwise dull season for the Newlands faithful, reeling from defeat to defeat with almost metronomic consistency.

Hennie le Roux, Japie Mulder and Dawie Snyman make up the centre trio, giving the young Northern Transvaler the break he so richly deserves alongside the World Cup pairing.

Selecting Le Roux at centre and Henry Honiball as back-up to Joel Stransky at flyhalf also opens the doors for positional switches if needed. Le Roux is equally at home in the pivot position and Honiball is no stranger to playing in the centre.

Stransky surely must keep his position despite some lacklustre form for Western Province and some wayward kicking. He has two vital things going for him ... he is the man in the saddle and has always been a big-game player.

At scrumhalf, there can be no doubt that Joost van der Westhuizen is without a significant challenger. He has the ability to change the face of a match with one of those searing breaks which leaves opposition stranded in his wake.

And while not suggesting that playing Van der Westhuizen out of position is a viable option, it cannot be ignored that he has substituted both on the wing and at flank in Test matches. To back Van der Westhuizen up, the selectors will surely go for the known quantity and call up Transvaal's Johan Roux, a seasoned veteran in the green and gold and a fine tactical kicker on his day.

In the analysis though, armchair selection is a dangerous business and there will be almost as many variations on paper as there will be players in the final line-up the selectors decide on.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
