Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer South Africa: Another Step To Paradise


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Andrew Muchineripi


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Johannesburg - South Africa takes the second of what they hope will be eight steps to paradise when they host Malawi on Saturday in the return match of a World Cup preliminary tie.

Overall victory against the Central Africans, and there are strong grounds for optimism following a 1- 0 first-leg success in Blantyre two weeks ago, would take Bafana Bafana into the mini-league second phase.

A separate draw on a date to be announced will divide the 16 preliminary winners plus the four countries who received byes (Cameroon, Nigeria, Egypt, Morocco) into five groups of four.

Each team plays its three opponents at home and away with three points for a win and one for a draw and the group winners qualify for the 32-nation finals in France. 

But the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de Triomphe are probably a million kilometres from the mind of national coach Clive Barker today as he prepares to complete a mission that began promisingly in Malawi.

Amid all the criticism of the missed chances from Philemon Masinga and Shaun Bartlett, the media and the football public appear to have forgotten what a good result it actually was for Bafana Bafana.

Compare the 1-0 triumph at the Chichiri Stadium with the results of Zambia, Algeria, Guinea, Ivory Coast, Mozambique, and national coach Clive Barker has every right to demand the erection of a monument in his honour.

It is not that those misses should be brushed aside, but that they should be seen in the overall context of a match which South Africa controlled for long periods.

The sweeping one-touch move which led to Bartlett having his shot pushed on to the upright by Malawian goalkeeper Bothwell Kuwanda came straight from a best-selling Brazilian manual.

Masinga was the biggest culprit with his second-half blunder almost unbelievable as he failed to steer the ball into the net from a couple of metres with Kuwanda helpless on the ground.

Barker has wisely and rightly defended his forward from some sections of the media with questionable motives and the "hate mail" some newspapers seem far too eager to publish. Masinga happens to be the joint leading scorer in the national team with Doctor Khumalo and has the benefit of being a full- time professional operating in a top-class environment at Leeds United.

He also went into the Malawi match with several large and extremely dark clouds hanging over his head, specifically the "traffic affair" and his future with the English Premiership club.

Whatever did happen in Braamfontein that Wednesday afternoon when the slick wheels of Bra Phil pulled up so that teammate Innocent Buthelezi could buy some burgers, is irrelevant. But the publicity and the court appearance could only have distracted "Chippa" from the task at hand and may well have affected his performance in front of 60 000 superbly behaved Malawians.

Masinga has also been hit by British regulations which stipulate that foreign footballers must play in 75% of matches each season to continue at the club.

Masinga fell well short of that target and when Leeds applied for his work permit to be renewed, the British authorities turned it down. As things stand, Masinga must seek a new club, or a new country.

Letters from so-called football fans telling Masinga that he is in line for the "Makalakalane" treatment can only add to the torment ahead of the match at FNB Stadium.

Barker now faces a difficult choice. Does he give in to public opinion (as he was forced to do with white-shoed Augustine Makalakalane) or does he give Masinga another chance?

Sean Dundee apart (and that is another issue for another day), South Africa is not exactly blessed with free-scoring forwards and the likely replacement for Masinga is Brendan Augustine.

The Austrian-based former Bush Bucks star has been capped 10 times, scored three goals and never let his country down. But is he a vastly superior player to Masinga?

Finishing apart, South Africa impressed in Blantyre, restricting a home team which had boasted of winning by two goals to a single clearcut chance (a header from Albert Mpinganjira which Andre Arendse tipped over).

Malawi were incredibly inept with little imagination in attack against quick-tackling, physically stronger South African defenders and Chancey Gondwe and Ernest Chirwali never stamped their authority in midfield.

But at least the pressure is off the "Flames" on Saturday. No one really gives them a chance while expectations are high for the holders of the African Nations' Cup.

In many respects the World Cup match will resemble a cup tie between a First Division club and an amateur side. An early goal for the favourties and they can cruise to victory.

But the longer the match remains scoreless, the more confident the underdogs become and the more frustrated the favourites get. South Africa may be in the driving seat, but if Malawi score first they will share the steering wheel.

If the countries finish level on aggregate after 90 minutes, the Golden Goal will apply for the first time at senior level in Africa with the first goal scored in extra time determining the winners.

However, if there are no goals after 30 minutes of extra time, the normal penalty shootout will apply with each team taking a mandatory five followed by sudden-death kicks if needed.

All this should not be necessary, though, because if football fans turn up in large numbers and support their country (which means the coach and his players), South Africa should move within six steps of the ultimate dream.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


244 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - General South Africa: First Time Could Be The Right Time


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996 by Julian Drew


LENGTH: 1707 words


 

Johannesburg - There haven't been too many column centimetres devoted to the name of Simon Malindi as the experts debate the favourites to lift the Comrades Marathon crown on Monday. It is after all the first time the 33-year-old Scaw Harriers athlete has attempted the mother of all races and it is seldom won by a novice. But while Malindi may be short on experience he is not lacking in pedigree and those with serious aspirations to victory will write him off at their peril.

A relative apprentice in the ranks of ultra runners, Malindi first ventured beyond the standard marathon distance after a string of disappointing results over 42.2km. His coach Francisco Andre observed that Malindi was still strong after a poor run in the Lisbon Marathon at the end of 1993 which saw him repeat his 2:19 personal best from Paris and the Hyper to Hyper Marathon in Pretoria.

"After Lisbon Francisco told me he thought I would do better at ultra marathons. He suggested I start with the City to City because it is only 8km longer than a marathon. He changed my programme and increased my mileage. To me it was much easier and I won the race," recalls Malindi. 

It was a fine induction into life beyond the marathon which claimed the scalps of such seasoned ultra runners as Nixon Nkodima, Phineas Mokaba and Lucas Matlala. "I could see he was cruising when he finished in Lisbon and I told him that on a good day he could probably run a 2:13 marathon but that still wasn't good enough to do well internationally," says Andre.

"In South Africa people respect ultra marathon runners more than anything. You just have to look at the money put into a race like Comrades compared with the Olympic marathon trials. That's the way it is in South Africa and I decided if you can't beat them, join them!" he says. Malindi's next target was last year's Two Oceans Marathon.

"It was the same story as for City to City. Francisco said it's just another 6km and altered my programme. He said, 'Don't worry, just train,' and then I went and ran a good time and won the race," says Malindi. Malindi's 3:10:53 Two Oceans victory was the fastest in five years and the sixth-fastest ever. "I suppose you could say Simon found his niche. Now he's a personality in South Africa," declares Andre.

Malindi's athletic progress owes much to the astute guidance of Andre whose own path towards coaching excellence has also been remarkable. Ironically it was a dose of old fashioned, apartheid-style racism that set him on his course. Andre was a "fairly average" middle distance runner in Portugal and emigrated to South Africa in 1981. As an employee at Scaw Metals he competed in the early Eighties versions of company relays which were more akin to social bonding outings -- for white executives -- - than athletics contests before the mining houses started entering their best black athletes.

Scaw followed suit and opened its team to everyone in 1985. "There were good quality athletes in our team but then I never saw them again until the next relay the following year. In 1986 I spoke to them and asked why they didn't run more often. They said they'd love to but they had no transport and didn't know where and when to compete. I ended up taking them to road races and a couple of them turned out to be quite good," remembers Andre.

He decided to enrol one of them at his own club, Alberton AC, and took Nelson Buthulezi round to the chairman's house. Andre was stunned by what he heard. The chairman told them he couldn't prevent black runners from joining the club but he would never allow them into the club house or invite them to prize givings even though he acknowledged they could become the best athletes at the club.

Andre told him to take a long run and keep going. He went back to his employers and asked them if they would set up a club, and Scaw Harriers was born. "The athletes had so much faith in me after that that they started asking me for advice about their running and I couldn't answer them," says Andre. So he wrote to Bernado Manuel in Portugal whom he used to train with in Lisbon.

Manuel, an Angolan, was then understudy to the great Moniz Pereira, the Portuguese national coach who put the likes of Carlos Lopes (1984 Olympic marathon champion) and Fernando Mamede (former 10 000m world record-holder) onto the map. Manuel, who has now taken over from Pereira, started assisting Andre and recommended two books to him, one of which was Pereira's story of how he coached Lopes. "One of the things I took from Pereira's book was his favourite saying which, roughly translated, says, 'A good meal is not made from rice or meat only. It is a careful blend of the right ingredients.'

"I looked at my situation in South Africa and I also blended various running philosophies and coaching methods to suit my own athletes just as Pereira had done for the Portuguese runners," says Andre.

That he has been successful there can be no doubt. He took Abel Mokibe to the South African marathon title and the Barcelona Olympics and made Meshack Dandane into one of the country's top 5 000m runners before injuries took their toll. Scaw Harriers are now also the top company relay side in the world after winning last year's World Corporate Challenge in New York.

Malindi is the latest success story. "I was very lucky to meet somebody like Francisco. He's a very good coach and I have complete trust in him," says Malindi.

Malindi's debut in Comrades has actually come a year earlier than Andre had planned. "For a long time I had the goal to build Simon up for Comrades and I was really aiming for next year but that will be a down run. Simon is strong on hills and he's not getting any younger so we decided to give it a go this year. Even if he doesn't win he will gain experience for the future and I believe he has what it takes for a race like Comrades," says Andre.

One of the biggest adaptations for Malindi was the type of training he had to do for Comrades. "Simon likes his track work and time trials. He's always been used to a lot of quality work and for a long time he's had to concentrate on quantity and strength work in the gym," reveals Andre.

As a full time employee at Scaw who does work study analyses in the steel rolling mills he didn't have the time to do very high mileage as well as gym work. His peak training never exceeded 160km a week. Andre did condition him for the loneliness of Comrades though.

"I used to deliberately start his training sessions later than the rest of the group. He used to go home with them on the train to Tembisa and he didn't like it when they left and he still had to do some more track work. Comrades is a lonely race and I wanted to build up his discipline and self reliance. He needed to be alone with his thoughts and realise why he was doing what he was doing," says Andre.

Four weeks ago Andre took Malindi to Durban for a weekend to train on the course and he finally realised what all the hard work was for. "It's a very tough course but it's up to the individual how they approach the race. You must be clever and use your head in Comrades," says Malindi, who is meticulous in his preparations and has spent hours watching videos of the race and talking to experienced Comrades runners.

One thing in Malindi's favour that hasn't been available to many black runners before is that he will have a full back-up team from Scaw on race day. "I know the market goes with who can best sell a product but in the past there was never an attempt to give support to people like Hoseah Tjale. I believe he could have won Comrades if he was given the support people like Bruce Fordyce received," says Andre.

" That's one of the reasons Fordyce could do so well. Not only was he one of the best prepared athletes physically but also logistically. We all know that without a back up team in Comrades you're on your own and it's difficult to do well. We realised this and approached Scaw and they said we could have whatever we needed."

Andre is realistic about Malindi's chances on Monday and is not making any brash predictions. "We know there's a big question mark over Simon in the Comrades because he's never raced the last 30km, but he's very confident in a nice kind of way and he's in good shape. He's also a very intelligent runner and knows exactly what he wants to do and where he must do it," Andre says.

Speaking to Malindi that much is evident. "I don't want to be faster than 2:48 or slower than 2:52 at halfway. The race will really begin after 60km and at that stage its all in the mind. If your mind is weak you will never make it. You must believe in yourself and never give up. I believe I can finish in the top 10 but if there is a chance for me to win I won't let it pass me by," says Malindi. And one thing Malindi certainly has in abundance is self belief.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


245 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Arts Soweto '76: Documentary Examines The Flagbearers and Beyond


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

TELEVISION: Andrew Worsdale

Film-maker Khalo Matabane was only two years old on June 16 1976. Twenty years later he has been commissioned by SABC3 to research and produce a documentary on the legacy of that day. The result is an intriguing hour-long film, "Two Decades Still," that expressly looks for the story behind the three or four fallen icons the media have held up as flagbearers of an uprising which, says Matabane, contributed more than any other to the shaping of South Africa today. 

During the course of his research, Matabane began to realise that "it was not just that a generation unafraid to face the gun injected the struggle with a new freshness, it was also how the entire community was affected behind the scenes -- from those kids to their parents to the hostel-dwellers and the workers ..."

In the documentary, writer and activist Duma Ndlovu describes how his decidedly apolitical, domestic- worker mother was transformed into an activist when she heard accounts of children being shot at. It is this communal legacy that the film-maker wants to preserve for posterity. "When I saw Schindler's List I realised we can't just move on without understanding our own histories ... During my research I realised that the full hypocrisy of the new South Africa can only be understood when we see how many of these people haven't been given due homage."

It is, however, a legacy with its own confounding realities. During the shoot the crew was held up by armed robbers while filming in the Morris Isaacson School (where the fuse of the uprising was lit) and their equipment, tapes, cellphones, wallets and minibus were stolen.

Another point of interest is the film-maker's attempt to interview a leading organiser of the protests, Zweli Sizane. When the film-makers arrived to interview him they discovered the full effects of police brutality and detention. Suffering from post-traumatic stress syndrome, Sizane was unable to give a comprehensible interview. There can be no doubt that June 16 1976 lives on.

"Two Decades Still" will be screened on SABC3 at 6pm on June 16


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


246 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Arts Soweto '76: Pictures From An Uprising


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 14, 1996


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Johannesburg - "I have waited 20 years for this," says Peter Magubane, whose exhibition "Never Never Again" commemorates June 16 1976 and celebrates the re-release of his book, The Fruit of Fear, removed from the shelves three hours after its first launch in 1986. "Yet at the time I would never have believed I would commemorate it in a free, democratic South Africa."

Magubane is one of several artists -- some of whom could barely count to 16 at the time -- commemorating the student revolt that inexorably changed the course of South African history. "Without 1976, without the courage of those schoolchildren, we wouldn't be where we are today," insists Magubane, who spent June 16 as cameraman, ambulance driver and -- after suffering a broken nose courtesy of a police baton -- casualty. "They showed the adults the way." 

Step inside the Morris Isaacson School in Rockville, Soweto, or the Phefeni Senior School in Orlando West, and you'll meet a type of schoolchild very different from the generation of 1976. The "we will never forget" crowd competes with coiffed young women whose political consciousness extends no further than a first-hand knowledge of mating manoeuvres, and with teenage boys emulating the slouch of their Hollywood heroes.

Mention the name of Dan Motsitsi, a student leader in 1976, and some faces light up. Others register blankness. "That's the date I met my boyfriend," says a student when asked what significance June 16 holds for her. "We celebrate our second anniversary this weekend." She is 16.

No wonder Magubane titled his exhibition Never Never Again.

"Not only should the events of June 16 never be repeated, but the memory must never be erased," says Kevin Brand, who, together with several other Cape Town-based artists, is participating in Faultlines, a series of projects organised by the Mayibuye Centre around the events of June 16. Situated at the Castle in Cape Town, Brand's work includes a giant mural -- three images transposed on to the outer and inner walls of the castle.

For the outside wall he has chosen that enduring photograph of Hector Petersen, for which photographer Sam Nzima received a R200 "bonus". "I have examined Nzima's contact sheet," says Brand, "and it is obvious why that shot was chosen above all the others. It resembles a pietC." Brand has selected photographs with similar themes of tragedy and sacrifice for the inside walls. "Petersen was the most recognised icon of 1976, yet although (the uprising) revolved around specific issues, its message and meaning are universal."

In the foyer of MuseumAfrica in Newtown stands a series of framed newspaper headlines, images and articles spanning the period June 16 1976 to August 1976. An integral part of Magubane's exhibition, the display serves a strangely schizoid role: as conventional truth-teller -- document of and testimony to the revolt -- and hyperreal tour of the past, assuming a greater truth than the event itself. Some might regard 1976 as a historical snuff movie, a theme-park tragedy or a curious period piece told through a racially punctuated narrative and headlines like "I saw a child shot and I couldn't look".

Magubane and Nzima witnessed 1976. Kendell Geers didn't. He was nine years old at the time, the progeny of a "white trash" right-wing working-class family in the suburb of Leondale, Germiston, a stone's throw from Katlehong and Natalspruit townships -- two of the hotspots of 1976. His enduring memory of the day is hearing his police relatives talking about their covert missions into the townships. Later, he tracked down the death register of 1976, with Petersen's name scrawled on it. As a student he reproduced the image of Petersen and titled it Blood Sport. He also produced a photograph of himself taken on his ninth birthday, at the circus, and called it June 1976.

"History takes place on a physical level," he explains. "Yet it gets coded into a number and text. It becomes an object of appropriation, saying little about the truth of the event but much about our perceptions of it." Now, Geers has teamed up with mixed-media artist Willie Bester at the Goodman Gallery in Johannesburg, producing two June 16 installations.

"On a formal level our work is different, but its underlying concerns with history and images of violence are similar," explains Bester, "as was our experience of 1976, although we saw it from opposite sides."

At the time Bester was a police reservist in Cape Town. A year later, he witnessed the deployment of a special task force to monitor the situation in the Cape. "They were given pick-axes to deal with the childen and received permission to use live ammunition on them." He adds: "I saw 18 kids lying on top of one another. I still can't come to terms with it."

Bester's work for the show comprises a sculpture made from an old motorcycle, titled The Oxwagon. It confronts issues of insularity and identity, but mostly it is about the need for reconciliation. "In order to achieve this, our history must be revealed in its entirety. We are all damaged, but with remembrance comes healing, in the same way that a lamp lights up the dark."

Magubane's exhibition is on view at MuseumAfrica until July 28; Bester and Geers's show opens at the Goodman Gallery on June 15, and Faultlines opens at the Castle on June 16


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


247 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Ivory Coast CPJ Protests Jail Terms for Ivorian Reporters


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) June 14, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director of the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) to President Henri Konan Bedie of Cote d'Ivoire (Ivory Coast), June 13, 1996:

Your Excellency,

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to protest in the strongest terms the confirmation of the two-year sentences of journalists Abou Drahamane Sangar , Emmanuel Kor and Freedom Neruda of the Nouvel Horizon media group.

An appeals court in Cote d'Ivoire confirmed, on Wednesday, 12 June, the two-year jail sentences imposed on the three journalists for insulting the head of state in the opposition daily newspaper, "La Voie."

The three "La Voie" journalists-director of publications Sangar , reporter Kor and deputy editor Neruda-will now appeal to the supreme court. 

On 18 December 1995 the newspaper had published a satirical article suggesting that Your Excellency's presence brought bad luck to the Ivoirian soccer team ASEC by attending the African Champions Cup final, which ASEC lost to South Africa's Orlando Pirates. Sangar and Kor were arrested on 21 December 1995 and sentenced to two years in prison on 28 December 1995 for "offenses against the head of state." "La Voie" was also fined three million CFA francs (US$6,000) and banned for three months. Neruda was arrested on 2 January 1996 and sentenced to two years on 11 January 1996.

As a nonpartisan group of journalists dedicated to the protection of its colleagues worldwide, CPJ contends that the sentences handed down against Sangar , Kor and Neruda are excessive and unjustified. Having written to Your Excellency on two previous occasions regarding this matter, we strengthen our call for the reversal of their convictions, and their immediate and unconditional release.

We welcome your comments.

For information, contact Kakuna Kerina, program coordinator for Africa (212)465-1004; f:(212) 465-9568; e-mail: africa@cpj.org.


LOAD-DATE: June 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Lagos Reported Calm As Anti-riot Police Move In


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 12, 1996 by Paul Ejime , PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 916 words


 

Lagos - Anti-riot police stood guard at strategic locations and patrolled Lagos streets under heavy rain Wednesday as residents ignored calls by anti-government groups to stay at home on the third anniversary of Nigeria's annulled 1993 presidential election.

The security measures came in the wake of threats of demonstrations by pro-domocracy groups in the build-up to the anniversary. 

The detained millionaire-politician, Moshood Abiola, claimed he won the election.

He is awaiting trial for treasonable felony after proclaiming himself president of Nigeria in June 1994. The military administration of Gen. Sani Abacha has refused to heed calls for Abiola's release and says the trial will go ahead.

Pro-democracy groups warned Tuesday they would protest as hundreds of sympathizers offered the eighth day Islamic prayers for Abiola's wife, Kudirat. She was shot dead June 4 in Lagos by unidentified men.

The Campaign For Democracy, one of the anti-government groups, Tuesday cancelled its rallies planned for Wednesday.

The group's acting national president, Olugbenga Awosode, told journalists that the association had decided against the national rallies because of developments in the country, especially the death of Kudirat.

Reports from western Nigeria, Abiola's home area and the bastion of opposition to the military administration, also spoke of tight security to forestall protests.

The police in the area had earlier banned rallies and political meetings, warning that trouble makers would be arrested.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Ghana Forum Examines The Military and Democracy in Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 12, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Accra - A forum on the military and democracy in Africa on Wednesday in Accra urged a transformation of the African military's "colonial character".

The forum of some 15 intellectuals, politicians and military officers, organized by the United States embassy and the Institute for Economic Affairs, said this would help end the spate of coups in Africa and enhance democracy. 

The forum discussed "Civil and Military Relations in Democratic Societies: the American Experience."

Colonel Dan Henk of the United States Army, who led the discussions, said maintaining a healthy balance between liberty and security in a democracy is a "complex and delicate" issue.

"Democracy is an unfinished business and efforts to maintain a balance between liberty and security will always meet new challenges," he said.

Col. Henk, Director of African Studies at the U.S. Army War College, said Africa should borrow selectively in its efforts to find solutions to its problems.

He stressed the importance of training, saying the U.S military places emphasis on "military subordination to civil authority", adding "this is a very fundamental part of our ethics."

He said no single group of persons in the U.S. has power or control of the military, adding that the military cannot be "used to stage a coup without shattering the constitution which the military owes allegiance to."

Lt. Col P.K.D. Anku-Tsede, chairman of Ghana's parliamentary committee on defence and the interior, called for the removal of the "aura of secrecy" surrounding the Ghana armed forces.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Sudan Surgeons Restore Sight In Sudan


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 12, 1996 by Yahya el Hassan , PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Khartoum - A group of Pakistani eye surgeons has been touring various parts of Sudan, operating up to 400 patients a day, free of charge.

The Pakistani Eye Hospital, as it is called by the common man in Sudan, operates patients in tents installed in any empty space, anywhere. 

The head of the group, Amir Yousif told PANA that none of the operations had failed.

"We have operated thousands of patients. We have performed major and minor eye operations in Khartoum, Rufa'a, El Obied Kamlinnn, Damazin, Medani, Dongola, Merowe and Halfa...We have established six camps in one year.

The mobile hospital, an affiliate of the "Eyesight Charity Society", a Saudi-Pakistani charity organization, does not charge its patients any medication fees. "In fact we pay for their medicine and eyeglasses," said Yousif.

According to a member of the team, Dr Khaleeg el Rahman, most of the patients suffered from cataract or glucoma, mainly due to excessive heat and dust, although the disease can also occur because of old age.

"Diabetes also causes cataract..Diabetes is reminiscent of sugar. You in Sudan consume huge quantities of sugar. People do not know the destructive effect of sugar on the eyes..If sugar does not harm you body, it is sure to harm the bodies of you children," he said.

The eye specialist said his organization was preparing to establish the first eye bank in Sudan. "Everything is ready, he said, adding that some doctors who had been training abroad have returned and were ready to assume work.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Niger Military Ruler And Four Others To Run in Niger


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 12, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Niamey - The Supreme Court in Niger has endorsed the candidature of military ruler Gen. Ibrahim Mainassara Bare and four others, to run for president in polls slated for July this year.

A decision issued by the court in Niamey on Tuesday, said the other candidates are, Tandja Mamadou of the National Movement for Development Society (MNSD), former President Mahamane Ousmane of the Democratic and Social Convention (CDS), Mahamadou Issoufou of the Niger Party for Democracy and Socialism (PNDS), and Moumouni Djermakoye Adamou of the Niger Alliance for Democracy and Progress (ANDP). 

Mainassara will run as an independent candidate.

The court decision was released five days after the expiry of the deadline given to aspirants to file their papers.

Meanwhile, the timetable for the polls says campaigns would officialy commence on June 14, while first-round voting will be held on July 7.

Run-off voting would be held for the two runner-ups on July 28, if no contestant emerged clear winner in the first round.

The election is being organized under a program to return the country to democratic rule, prepared by the military government which seized power in January.

Africa News


June, 1996


Liberia Ghana Rejects Appeals To Accept Refugee Ship


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 12, 1996


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Accra- Ghana turned down Tuesday appeals from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to accept Zolotitsa, the Russian vessel carrying some 400 refugees from Liberia.

Speaking to the Ghana News Agency in Accra after a meeting with government officials, UNHCR representative in Ghana, Chrysantus Ache, said Ghanaian authorities stuck to their decision not to accept the ship.

The meeting, which was at the instance of the UNHCR, followed concerns about the fate of the passengers who have been at sea for about two weeks. 

The minister of foreign affairs, Obed Asamoah, who led the government side at the talks, said that acceptance of the ship will trigger social and economic consequences that the country cannot bear.

He said in as much as Ghana appreciates the plight of the refugees, she would be doing more harm than good to herself, if she accepted the boat.

Asamoah said he would not want to believe that there are Ghanaians on board, adding that some people might be claiming citizenship just to win sympathy.

According to Ache, the authorities agreed to a request to assist aid workers, especially medical experts, to have access to the boat, which is believed to be in international waters off the Ghanaian coast.

In his appeal, Ache reaffirmed UNHCR's preparedness to "take full responsibility" for the refugees if the ship was allowed to dock.

He said there were enough resources for as many as 5,000, and appealed that the ship be allowed to dock.

Meanwhile, the UNHCR headquarters in Geneva has issued another appeal to West African nations to permit the ship to dock for humanitarian purposes.

On Monday, navy tugboats for the second time in 48 hours, towed the ship back to sea after it apparently returned to Ghanaian waters off Takoradi harbour.

Togolese authorities refused to allow it to discharge its passengers last Wednesday, after they provided food and water to the fugitives.

The United States has also appealed to West African countries to allow the ship to dock for humanitarian reasons, and promised to help cater for the refugees in collaboration with U.N. agencies and international relief organizations.

Last month, Ghana bowed to intense diplomatic pressure and took in about 2,000 refugees from Liberia on board an old Nigerian freighter, Bulk Challenge.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


253 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Crime Cost South Africa $7 Billion in 1995


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 12, 1996 by Lionel Williams PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Johannesburg - South Africa was on Wednesday reeling from the shock disclosure that crime cost the country seven billion dollars last year.

The disclosure emerged from a a survey conducted by the Nedcor Project on Crime, Violence and Investment, funded by the national banking group, Nedcor Limited.

The survey points out that the seven billion dollars spent on crime last year was equal to 5.6 percent of South Africa's Projected Gross Domestic Product for this year, and 18 percent of the government's national budget. 

The leader of the survey team, Prof. C. Lee of Witwatersand University, told reporters on Tuesday that steadily increasing crime and diminishing public confidence in the government's ability to combat it were leading to an unstable economy.

"It is badly hurting business, reducing confidence and diminishing local investment," he added, "and we cannot afford it".

The survey covered 300 businesses, 47 shopping centres, 59 business experts and 2,163 individuals. It took more than a year to complete at a cost of 700,000 U.S. dollars.

Eighty-two percent of the small businesses and 59 percent of the large companies admitted that crime was a deterrent to further investment in the local economy.

Lee pointed out that the annual cost of crime in South Africa was equal to 19 months of net capital inflow into South Africa following the historic 1994 general elections which ushered democratic rule in the former apartheid enclave.

It also exceeded the projected benefits over ten years in South Africa of the 2004 Olympic Games, should Cape Town win the rights to host the global games.

Ineffective crime prevention is also highlighted by the report, which says that for every 1,000 crimes committed only 77 criminals are convicted, and only eight are sentenced to more than two years' imprisonment.

"Crime is costing almost double the amount of money being spent on trying to catch criminals," Lee said.

The deputy safety and security minister, Joe Mathews, told the news briefing that the government acknowledged that the survey was as stark confirmation of the seriousness of the crisis. "The government has no illusions about the scale of the problem we are facing," he said.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: We'll Qualify, Assures Goalie


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 7, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - National team goalkeeper James Phiri has predicted that Zambia will pull through the Sudan hurdle and qualify to the next stage of the Africa qualifying series for the 1998 World Cup.

"Sudan is a very tough team and the game will be tough, but we shall still qualify. We cannot afford to lose to them twice especially that we lost in the away game," said Phiri in an interview at the Hotel Intercontinental in Lusaka yesterday shortly after the team arrived from Sudan.

Phiri, who acted as the team's skipper in the Sudan match, observed that no excuses could be made over Zambia's 2-0 defeat in Sudan.

"Sudan just outplayed us, they are actually a better team than we expected," said Phiri.

But national team trainer, Roald Poulsen refused to give any comments on the match nor his plans for the return match.

"I do not want to talk on the game because we need time to rest before we start talking. But what I can say is that we shall resume training on Sunday and all players that played in Sudan will not play for their clubs this weekend," said Poulsen.

And John Fashanu, Zambia's soccer agent for management, arrived with the national team yesterday.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Shelter-Afrique Unveils $100 Million Plans


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 11, 1996 by Stephen Kazeze


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Istanbul - Shelter-Afrique, the housing company owned by 37 African countries which include Zambia, launched a continental housing investment programme here on Monday.

In this scheme the company plans to spend US$100 million over the next five years in various projects centred mostly in urban areas.

Shelter-Afrique, which is also owned by the African Development Bank, African Reinsurance Corporation and the Commonwealth Development Corporation said in a statement after the launching that the new initiative was designed to lure additional private sectore and international resources to achieve a significant impact on post-Istanbul efforts. 

Istanbul efforts refers to the UN second conference on Human Settlements (Habitat two) being held here where it has been agreed that housing is a right to everyone in the world and that every effort should be made to ensure everybody in the world is adequately housed.

The Nairobi headquartered firm oversees the design and implementation of some 60 projects in member states the statement said.

It further said in the last 10 years, Shelter-Afrique co- financed shelter and related projects in several countries including Zambia.

These projects which were financed through loans were targetted at low income and middle income households and had helped thousands of families in African cities, it said.

And a group of donor countries and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) plan to launch a US$10 million project development sector in the urban services infrastructure in developing countries.

The UNDP said that the project development facility to be launched on Wednesday would be used to identify, design and implement 50 projects in cities worldwide over a five-period.

It said the initiative was a response to the call by the habit conference here for member states and organisations to make concrete committments to be implemented in the framework of the global plan of action.

Source: ZAMTODAY-MIBS

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia University Students Praised


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Lucy Sichone (Column)


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Lusaka - Congratulations to UNZASU and the student body for preserving the integrity of the history of the University of Zambia as the depository of the last resort of ideals and principles of equality, liberty and fraternity.

It was with a sense of total despair that I received the news of a planned solidarity march to State House by students for the purpose of celebrating the enactment of the MMD constitution.

The immoral procession was a betrayal of student ideals and sacrifice for the common good across the world. The Chinese students massacred in cold blood in Tianamen Square for demanding rights such as those taken away from Zambians by the MMD, Steve Biko, civil rights movements of the sixties at universities in America. 

Nearer home Ronald Penza, Super SAP Capitalist, sacrificed his government scholarship and worked his way through university by demanding of the UNIP government that they close the French Embassy for selling arms to apartheid South Africa.Betrayal of the ideals of Justice and Fair Play came with his job as an MMD politician.

Derick Chitala's ideals as a student made him an architect of the Garden House Meeting - his vision only became clouded when he became a Minister in the MMD government.

Azwell Banda sacrificed ten years of his life working as an unqualified school teacher and only completed his degree as an old man rather than apologise to KK as was required of him which would have destroyed the standing of UNZA as a custodian of community ideals.

Caine Mweemba is living in a servants quarter in order to uphold the history of the student movement in the world as the vanguard in the never ending struggle for justice.

There are many others whose names are not known but who have sacrificed the hope of a lustrous career because as students they chose to stand for justice.

The duty of the University as the custodian of community ideals cannot be sold for 30 pieces of silver in the manner that the 16 or so Judas Iscariots who marched to State House did. Those students are intelligent enough to appreciate the fact that the Republican Constitution is not an MMD issue. And the best they could have done in their exercise of their constitutional right to free association would have been to join Chawinga and company in the dance at State House on May 28.

In a country such as ours, in which Parliament has been corrupted, we can survive; the judiciary has been emasculated and we stagger on; Francis Ndlovhu is a political stooge who is doing everything possible to destroy the police service but sooner rather than later he will answer for it and the Police Service will continue.

But a nation cannot survive the corruption of its University as clearly evidenced by the Rwandan experience where the privileged Tutsi university students rioted against the democratically elected Hutu President in that country's first free and fair elections.

It was that unjust action by the students that ignited the tragedy that is Rwanda today, the genocide of 2 million people which included almost the entire student body and effectively sounded the death knell of a nation.

It was with Rwanda in mind that on Saturday morning, I went to my favourite newspaper vendor. I returned home to view my certificate at it's usual pride of place, a proud Zambian and UNZA graduate. My children are looking after their today and tomorrow against those politicians that would seek to cheapen the proud history of UNZA, by enlisting students to support injustice and division that can only point to the death of a nation.

But I notice that UNZA and Zambia is safe.

I salute you all.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambian University Students Attack Officers


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Kunda Mwila


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka - Paramilitary officers were on Sunday morning clobbered by University of Zambia (UNZA) students.

A mob of irate UNZA students stoned several paramilitary officers and detained four others in the wake of confusion which has rocked the Great East Road campus since June 7 when 22 pro-MMD students marched to State House in support of the constitutional amendments.

The paramilitary officers were deployed at the rooms of students who had gone to State House, a move which students perceived as "intimidation by government". 

President Chiluba was reported as having assured the students who went to State House protection.

But the paramilitary officers officers were forced out of the residential area and in the confusion a woman officer was severely beaten and disarmed.

Several paramilitary officers were severely injured and had to run for their lives.

And even after burning the belongings of 9 of the 22 MMD activists, students have vowed that they will not allow those students who went to State House to enter campus again.

"We are not going to allow any of them to enter the campus again," declared a group of students. "If anyone attempts to come, he or she will be burnt to death."

President Emmanuel Tembo said in an interview yesterday the MMD cadres had offended all the other students whose good name they had attempted to tarnish.

"The offence of binding the whole student body to the statement that it was in favour of the constitution has been committed on all students," Tembo said, "and it is only them who will decide whatever punishment to impose on all those who marched to State House."

Tembo also claimed that most of the people who marched to State House were street vendors mobilised by MMD.

Top in the group of the students who marched to State House are UNZA MMD Henry Malikyama who is also a relative of President Chiluba's private secretary Fabian Mumba, Bruno Lungu, George Chilengwe, Daudeni Phiri, Faith Kolala, Victor Tembo, chairperson for UNZA MMD ladies Martha Mwansa, Sandra Sisya (Zelu). Several MMD documents and campaign materials were found in their rooms.

And UNZASU vice president Joseph Munsanje dismissed the allegations by the pro-MMD group leader Henry Malikyama that students who were against their solidarity march are being used by the opposition and said students were are not divided on the constitution as it has been potrayed in the governmnet owned and controlled media.

"What MMD should know is that UNZASU has been operating even before the opposition parties came into being and it has its own way of reacting to issues," Musanje said in an interview yesterday. "The student populace is not in support of the constitution as can be seen by their reaction."

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Zambia Bans Scrap Metal Export


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 7, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - A thirty day ban on all exports of scrap metal was announced by mines deputy minister Ackim Nkole in Lusaka yesterday.

Speaking at a press briefing yesterday Nkole said that the ban was effective from yesterday and was aimed at facilitating the "cleaning up" of the scrap metal dealers association's operations.

"No scrap metal inspection certificates will be issued with effect from today," Nkole said, "there will be no exports of scrap metal for a period of thirty days." 

Nkole said that during the ban period, scrap metal licenses would not be processed and there will be a review of all licenses issued out and scrutiny of applications before issuing.

Nkole revealed in an interview that despite several successful arrests in cases of copper thefts there had been no prosecutions which he attributed to an incompetent police force.

"The law provides for stiff penalties. The offender is liable to 15 years imprisonment but no one has been prosecuted despite the many arrests," Nkole carped. "It is incompetence to send a starving prosecutor to an offender because he will just be given whisky and the case is no more."

He further called for the re-classification of the copper thefts charge as a capital offence so as to scrap bail which enabled the offenders to manipulate all evidence against them allowing them to go scot free.

The Scrap Metal Dealers' association was however divided over the ban with some members calling for a grace period.

"There is need for the ministry to allow us about two weeks to clear off our stock and meet some conditions of some contracts we've gone into with our partners abroad," scrap dealer Kambwili Chishimbwe suggested.

But Scrap Metal Dealers Association welcomed the move.

Speaking in an interview yesterday the association vice chairman, Chris Kelari, thanked the government.

"The government has been lenient to us, a 30 day ban is better than forever and we are happy that now the government is working towards formally recognising us," Kelari said

June, 1996


Zambia Sports - General Council To Resolve Darts Wrangle


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - The National Sports Council of Zambia (NSCZ) plans to stage a meeting to resolve the wrangle between the Zambia Darts Association and its affilate, the Lusaka District Darts League.

NSCZ chairman Patrick Chamunda, indicated that though his office is yet to be briefed on the problems between the two darts groupings, he will call for a meeting. 

"I haven't as yet got any information of any problems in darts, but if there are any problems, we will surely have to sit down to resolve the issue," said Chamunda said in an interview in Lusaka yesterday.

The Darts Association of Zambia dissolved the whole Lusaka darts executive after the disappearance of a staggering K3 million and alleged misconduct among some members.

But Lusaka district darts league fixtures secretary, Teddy Sambaka, insisted that the darts mother body had personalised the issue.

"We have nothing against the mother body but the problem is that some people within DAZ want to personalise the issue. We are ready to resolve the matter but we may be faced to ask the Sports Council to help us resolve the issue if anything is done on the part of DAZ," Sambaka said in an interview yesterday.

Business and Finance Corporations Win Zambian Mining Rights


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 7, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Lusaka - Eleven international companies have been awarded rights to carry out various mining activities in Zambia. 

According to a statement released in Lusaka yesterday by mines minister Keli Walubita, the MMD government recognises the importance of the mining industry to the Zambian economy.

"The government has taken specific measures to address the needs of investors who wish to participate in the country's resource development. The measures are contained in the Mines and Minerals Act," read the statement.

Among the major companies are Gencor of South Africa, Western Mining of Australia, RTZ, Anglovaal, and Phelps Dodge.

The companies have invested over US$2 million in exploration, prospecting, and mining in the northern and northwestern parts of Zambia.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Parties Clash Over Aid Cuts


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Elias Kamanga


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - Tempers flared at the interparty meeting in Kitwe last Friday, as opposition parties and the ruling MMD clashed over recent threats of donor aid cuts, sending the meeting into disarray.

The highly charged meeting attended by the MMD, UNIP, ZDC, National Party and Movement for Democratic Process (MDP) failed to come up with resolutions after 12 hours of heated arguments over recent calls by some opposition parties for a donor aid squeeze against the government.

The opposition parties, led by the National Party, refused to budge when MMD proposed that a communique be jointly signed by all opposition parties condemning recent threats by the donor community of aid cuts. 

"We are not going to be hoodwinked into legitimising a hostile and dictatorial government by appending our signatures to this trickery," National Party provincial chairman Simon Kunda charged immediately after MMD delegation leader Kaunda Lembalemba made the proposal.

The MMD maintained that unless the communique was signed, they would not accept all the other resolutions.

"It is either you take this resolution by the MMD who in this case are in majority, or we forget about this inter party meeting all altogether," Lembalemba argued.

Lembalemba further accused the opposition of not adhering to the principles of democracy, among which was tolerance.

But the opposition was not deterred by Lembalemba's threats and maintained that unless the MMD reasoned with them on the matter, they would not mind forgetting about the meeting as well.

"The MMD should learn to reason and not suppress other parties' views, otherwise there is no need for sitting in conference rooms talking to an adamant and disrespectful party like the MMD," ZDC Copperbelt Provincial senator, James Chilemu, said.

Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) president, Alfred Zulu, was left with no alternative but to postpone the meeting.

MMD and opposition party cadres kept on jeering and chanting slogans in support of their own stances with the ruling party members accusing their colleagues from the opposition of being unpatriotic.

After the meeting was adjourned MMD members shouted abuse at the opposition leaders and continued singing and denouncing the donor community for threatening aid cuts.

Angry MMD cadres later started singing that since the talks had failed the solution was to fight it out so that the winners would be left to rule.

MDP president Chama Chakomboka said he was disappointed with the conduct of the MMD, saying the country was quickly drifting into a one party monopoly state.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


262 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Amnesty Says Chiluba Playing Games


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Mervin Syafunko


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba's government has been accused by Amnesty International, a human rights organisation, of "playing political games" by detaining UNIP leaders on charges of treason which is punishable by death.

Amnesty International, in a facsimile message to The Post on Friday and distributed to various political leaders on Saturday, said the arrest and detention of the eight UNIP leaders, who include vice-president senior chief Inyambo Yeta, might have been politically motivated and for that reason the international community would keep an eye.

"The international community will be closely watching to see what evidence has been collected in support of making these arrests on suspicion of treason," Amnesty International said. 

Amnesty International demanded that if the UNIP leaders are being detained simply because of political differences they should be released immediately.

"If these men are, indeed, being held because of opposing the President politically, Amnesty International would consider them prisoners of conscience and would demand their immediate and unconditional release," the statement read.

Amnesty International wondered how the eight could be linked to the clandestine Black Mamba which was responsible for a spate of bomb blasts and threats because when their homes were searched by police who were apparently looking for bomb-making materials, guns or incriminating documents, no evidence was reportedly found.

"Amnesty international's concerns are heightened by lack of concrete evidence to justify these arrests which lends weight to the organisation's fear the real reason for these men's detention is to prevent them from carrying out non-violent political activity in line with their beliefs.

"Is there enough evidence to hold them without chance of bail at Lusaka Central Prison which has notoriously poor conditions?" wondered the human rights organisation, whose secretariat is in London.

When contacted, police spokesman, Francis Musonda, declined to talk about the detention saying "it is already in court".

Amnesty International, however, called for the detainees to receive a fair and prompt trial in accordance with international standards.

It said it was also aware that police were seeking to make further arrests and was concerned that there might also be political motives as what happened in 1993 when several UNIP members were wrongfully detained in connection with The Zero Option.

And the Barotse cultural Association at a mass rally by opposition parties on Saturday condemned the detentions.

"Chiluba can't respect any traditional leadership because he does not know where he comes from,"charged BCA publicity secretary, Mutungulu Wangu. "Kaunda never hid his background that is why he respected traditional rulers."


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


263 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Donors Hailed For 'Withdrawing' Aid


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Mervin Syafunko and Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition parties have praised the donor community for withholding aid to Zambia and are now calling for frontline states to close their borders to government traffic and bar delegations from attending regional conferences until good governance is upheld.

This agreement was announced at a mammoth rally attended by eight political parties near Kafue round-about on Saturday. The rally, which had police mounting the largest security operation in the political history of the country, saw 700 paramilitary police officers, a hundred of whom were armed, 14 on horseback and two supporting helicopters monitoring the proceedings on the ground. 

"We mounted this operation to protect them and to show anyone with ill intentions that they cannot do so," Wynter Kabwiku, officer commanding Lusaka Division said, adding: "We have been liaising with the organisers of this rally."

Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) did not attend but its Eastern Province Senator, Andrew Banda, who attended in his individual capacity apologised for the party.

Banda wished he had traveled to Lusaka earlier to convince other leaders about the importance of unity.

In a joint opposition statement read by Liberal Progressive Front chairman, Rodger Chongwe, said: "We salute the donor community for finally heeding the calls of the oppressed people of Zambia, that they prefer to live in abject poverty as is the case now than under a donor funded dictatorial oligarchy.

"We call upon the front line states to close their borders to Zambian government traffic and ostracise its delegations to regional conferences until the government is seen to be upholding the principles of good governance that brought them into power."

The opposition also said they would not honour the newly amended constitution until it was adopted by a constituent assembly and a National Referendum or else the 1996 elections be held under the 1991 constitution.

They also demanded for the immediate re-registration of voters and that the one done by Nikuv Computers Limited of Israel be ignored.

They also demanded for an independent electoral commission whose composition should be accepted by all parties.

"We challenge the constitutionality of the Public Order (Amendment) Act, 1996 and demand its immediate repeal," resolved the parties.

They also expressed displeasure at the provocative adverts made by government leaders in the public media.

It was also decided that police should not superintend the elections and that no MMD cadre should be recruited in the police service.

At the beginning of the rally police officers, mostly youthful recruits who were commanded to surround the assemblage met with overpowering resistance prompting their commanders to withdraw them to Kafue Road side.

UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda, disturbed by the police, took it upon himself to talk to the commanding officers.

Addressing the crowd former president Kaunda demanded to know who was selling copper and cobalt for ZCCM since the closure of MEMACO and why President Chiluba was clinging to the Gabon and the Mukwela Rail Disaster reports.

"What does he want to do with those reports? See now another rail disaster has occured in Kapiri Mposhi, we must know what is causing these accidents," Kaunda demanded.

He said under any circumstance he would face and defeat President Chiluba in the elections and that would be when the President would account for the "sins" of his government.

All the leaders present at the rally condemned the detention of the UNIP leaders.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Donor Aid Withdrawal Not Affecting Privatisation Agency


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Operations of the Zambia Privatisation Agency (ZPA) will not be affected by the withdrawal of donor aid, assured its chief executive, Valentine Chitalu, in an interview on Friday.

Chitalu said the agency, which has been supported by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), would be able to sustain its operations from the present funds collected from the sale of companies. 

"The programme is sufficiently advanced to be able to sustain the privatisation of state enterprises if the donors were to withdraw their aid now ," said Chitalu. "But donor aid has been of great help to us."

Chitalu also disclosed that the agency was expecting two more trading groups , along the lines of the Shoprite chain, to open up shops in the country. But he could not disclose which country they were coming from. It is, however, believed that the two are South African chains.

Chitalu announced that Choma Milling had been sold to A B Georgitsis and R.L Musenge of Nshima Milling at a price of K1 billion. An initial deposit of K450 million, being 45 per cent of the purchase price, has been paid to the Privatisation Revenue Account.

The balance of K550 million, or 55 per cent, will be paid over a period of six months.

ZPA has also sold Kabwe Industrial Fabrics, a 100 per cent state owned enterprise manufacturing a variety of industrial packaging materials, to Tate and Lyle, a UK based multinational corporation.

Mulungushi Sawmilling and Joinery of Kitwe has been bought by Lusaka's former mayor Fisho Mwale and Siteke Mwale at K300 million. A 20 per cent deposit has been paid while the balance will be paid in a period of three months


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Constitution Aimed At Kaunda


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Fred M'membe (Column)


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - And President Chiluba has told many lies to many people about his constitution.

The President lied to the country's cooperating partners that he was not going to assent the Constitution (Amendment) Bill. 

And the more MMD leaders tried to justify the clause requiring one's parents to have been born in Zambia to qualify for presidency the more their deceit that the clause was not aimed at UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda was laid bare.

MMD members of parliament and cadres celebrated when the Bill was passed that former president Kaunda has been blocked. "Kaunda alala, Kaunda alala...," was the MMD slogan in, and outside Parliament.

President Chiluba has, in many ways, argued that Kaunda has had his fair chance of ruling Zambia and should be stopped, clearly indicating that the presidential clause, although affecting many other citizens, was primarily targeted at Kaunda.

But the presidential clause is not the only unacceptable thing about President Chiluba's constitution. There are many other clauses, including the mode of adoption, that still require consensus.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Channel Africa Faces Closure


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 7, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - South African journalists have launched a national and international campaign to forestall the impending closure of South Africa's state funded external shortwave broadcasting station, Channel Africa.

A member of the committee set up to spear head the campaign, Promise Lekalake, said in a telephone interview from Johannesburg yesterday that the overwhelming majority of journalists in South Africa favour the continuation of the station as it is viewed as a national asset.

"It is regretful that an organisation like Channel Africa which was so active in promoting and developing understanding of South Africa's position in Africa has to be the subject of closure," Lekalake carped. 

According to Lekalake, Channel Africa "reigned supreme during the apartheid era" and wondered why it should be closed now.

"It is sending wrong messages," Lekalake said. "It boils down to politics."

And, in a press statement sent to The Post , SABC radio chief executive, Govin Reddy, observed that Channel Africa is a comprehensive and authentic African communications forum which serves Africa from Africa.

"It is totally objective and credible and reliable. It is dedicated to the promotion of positive development in Africa and is committed to the enhancement of dialogue and co-operation between all African people as their channel of goodwill," Reddy said.

South African foreign affairs minister, Alfred Nzo, announced last month that the station would be closed as no provisions for funds had been made in his ministry's budget for 1996/97.

Channel Africa was first established in 1966 as Radio RSA but repositioned itself as Channel Africa in 1992.

At present, the station has an estimated 15 million regular listeners and broadcasts in three Southern African languages (Chinyanja, Silozi and Xitsonga), one East African language (Kiswahili) , as well as in English, French and Portuguese.

And, according to Lekalake, the station employs several foreign journalists, among them Zambians.

Cabinet is meeting next week to put a seal to the decision.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


267 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Liberia Fighters Withdraw from Monrovia Training Centre


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996 by Terence Saysay, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

MONROVIA, Liberia - A total of 402 Krahn fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson's Ulimo faction and George Boley's Liberia Peace Council on Tuesday withdrew from the Barclay (military) Training Centre in Monrovia amidst cheers from hundreds of onlookers.

The Krahn militia, who were resisting an attempt by Liberia's Council of State to arrest Johnson on murder charges, had been holed up in the barracks for the past two and half months.

The fighters refused to board the 13 trucks provided by Ecomog, the West African peacekeeping force, for transportion to their various destinations. They walked out of the centre in high spirits, singing and clapping. 

Prior to the withdrawal, witnessed by United States embassy staff, and the United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL), Ulimo-J spokesman Madison Wion turned over an assortment of over 50 assault rifles to Ecomog.

Wion said the weapons had been captured from the rival National Patriotic Front of Liberia and Ulimo-J during the recent fighting in Monrovia.

He said the handing over of the weapons was in compliance with a request from Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) that Ulimo-J hand over all arms in its possession to Ecomog by Tuesday and also withdraw from the training centre by the same day.

Wion said, however, that although it had been agreed that all the warring factions withdraw from the safe haven of Monrovioa, Ulimo-J fighters would comply only if Charles Taylor's NPFL withdraws his forces from Kakata, Todee and Bong mines.

He said these areas had been seized from Ulimo-J in contravention of the Abuja (Nigeria) accord which states that all factions must remain in the positions they occupied at its signing.

Wion said Ulimo-J would return all weapons seized from Ecomog during the fighting in Tubmanburg in December last year as soon as the highway to the town is reopened to enable them return to their headquarters.

The withdrawal of Krahn fighters from the Barclay Training Centre coincides with the launching of an operation by Ecomog to make Monrovia a gun-free society.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Hedgehog Breeding In Gabon Gains Popularity


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996 by Jean Kennedy Ewoumou, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - For almost a year now in Gabon hedgehog breeding has been growing in popularity, mainly in the region of Libreville.

The effort has been spearheaded by the French non-governmental organization, Veterinarians Without Borders.

If the practice continues, hedgehog breeding will mean protected wildlife in Gabon will have a greater chance of survival, having escaped the snares, spears and guns of hunters. 

This is because Gabonese have traditionally hunted primates such as monkeys and other bush meat for their source of protein, which is higher in content than chicken, beef or mutton.

Therefore, the captive breeding of hedgehogs provides an opportunity to assure protein to the population and save some wildlife.

In the markets of the capital alone, four tonnes of bush meat is sold each month. Among the wildlife slaughtered, the World Wildlife Fund says, are protected species.

Farmers and the unemployed in peri-urban areas are also cashing in on the business. But the longterm aim of the veterinarians'programme is to get hunter-gatherer communities adopt this sedentary practice for the protein source.

An advantage of hedeghog breeding is that start-up money is small. Feeds cost little or nothing as the animal lives off weeds and the by-products of maize, cassava, yam or sugar-cane. However, if uncontrolled they tend to devastate crops. All the family are omnivorous but generally prefer animal food.

The hedgehog is among Africa's largest rodents. It is the general name for the 14 species of these ancient mammals whose family is Erinaceidae, the order Insectivora.

There are two kinds of hedgehogs: the Gymnure or hairy variety and the spiny one, whose sub-family is Erinaceinae. The latter exists in Africa.

Spiny hedgehogs weigh between four to five kilogrammes. They have round bodies, a small head, pointed face, short legs, sharp claws and little or no tail. They live in savannahs and ravage all sorts of crops.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


269 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Gabon Hedgehog Breeding In Gabon Gains Popularity


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996 by Jean Kennedy Ewoumou, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - For almost a year now in Gabon hedgehog breeding has been growing in popularity, mainly in the region of Libreville.

The effort has been spearheaded by the French non-governmental organization, Veterinarians Without Borders.

If the practice continues, hedgehog breeding will mean protected wildlife in Gabon will have a greater chance of survival, having escaped the snares, spears and guns of hunters. 

This is because Gabonese have traditionally hunted primates such as monkeys and other bush meat for their source of protein, which is higher in content than chicken, beef or mutton.

Therefore, the captive breeding of hedgehogs provides an opportunity to assure protein to the population and save some wildlife.

In the markets of the capital alone, four tonnes of bush meat is sold each month. Among the wildlife slaughtered, the World Wildlife Fund says, are protected species.

Farmers and the unemployed in peri-urban areas are also cashing in on the business. But the longterm aim of the veterinarians'programme is to get hunter-gatherer communities adopt this sedentary practice for the protein source.

An advantage of hedeghog breeding is that start-up money is small. Feeds cost little or nothing as the animal lives off weeds and the by-products of maize, cassava, yam or sugar-cane. However, if uncontrolled they tend to devastate crops. All the family are omnivorous but generally prefer animal food.

Spiny hedgehogs weigh between four to five kilogrammes. They have round bodies, a small head, pointed face, short legs, sharp claws and little or no tail. They live in savannahs and ravage all sorts of crops.
