270 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Missing Chief's Fly Whisk Causes Uproar


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 10, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 814 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - A lost fly whisk belonging to detained Senior Chief Inyambo Yeta of the Lozi ethnic group, in western Zambia, has caused uproar among traditionalists.

The fly whisk, a symbol of traditional authority among Lozi chiefs, is feared to have been misplaced or lost in the wake of Yeta's detention last week for alleged treason.

The independent weekly newspaper, The Sun, reported Monday that the counselors of traditional chiefs, who constitute the Barotse Kuta, the Royal Court, met last week in the regional headquarters of Mongu to discuss, among others, the fate of the namaya, or fly whisk.

By tradition, all Lozi chiefs carry the namaya as the symbol of their power. 

According to the counsellors at the meeting, quoted by the newspaper, it is taboo for the fly whisk to be handled by a commoner. It is one of the most respected symbols of chieftainship in the Lozi tradition. A chief without the namaya in hand is not respected.

Yeta, who is the senior chief of Sesheke District in western Zambia, is the son of the Litunga, the paramount chief, Ilute Yeta of Western Province. He and his father once served in the former government of Kenneth Kaunda.

Inyambo Yeta appeared in court for mention for treason, last week, without his namaya. He wore jeans-like attire. This was in contrast to his usual immaculate two piece suits, a hat complete with the namaya in hand.

"Now police must explain where Inyambo Yeta's fly whisk is, otherwise we Lozis will sue Chiluba's government for disgracing our tradition," said Sepiso Muliokela, a Lozi who hawks his wares in one of the city's markets.

Under the new constitution, Chiluba has legislated against chiefs' participation in politics unless they resign their posts. He has said that it is not in order for chiefs to be "insulted and humiliated" in the "dirty game of politics."

Most chiefs, including Yeta, have however challenged the law. They say they should decide whether or not to involve themselves in politics.

Yeta is deputy leader of the United National Independence Party (UNIP) of former President Kenneth Kaunda. He is being detained with seven other party leaders and supporters.

Last week, he emerged from the court smiling and flashing the two-finger UNIP "victory" sign. It did not appear that he was in the least worried about the "missing" fly whisk.

Many other Zambian traditional chiefs also carry fly whisks. They are made mainly from the hairy end of a cow's or ox tail.

The whisk is occassionally handled by chiefs' retainers to ward off flies or other undesireable insects from a relaxing chief.

Chief Yeta is locked up in Chimbokaila prison in the capital, Lusaka, while his Lozi traditional counsellors fret and frisk over the "sacred" chiefs fly whisk.

The best-known fly whisk belonged to Kenya's first president, Jomo Kenyatta and another to Malawian President Hastings Kamuzu Banda.

Kenya's current president, Daniel Arap Moi, carries a small knobkerry. Kaunda, on his part, does not part with a white handkerchief which he keeps clutched between two fingers of his left hand.

Unlike Banda and Moi, Kaunda says the cloth has nothing to do with show of "power." The handkerchief is a symbol of "love and goodwill among the human race."

Several years before he lost power, Kaunda almost caused a rumpus at his official state house residence in Lusaka when he briefly "lost" the handkerchief. Reporters at the state luncheon and other guests saw an impatient Kaunda pace up and down angrily shouting at his securitymen: "Where is my handkerchief, where is my handkerchief?"

He had accidentally placed it under an empty plate while he served lunch to his guests, including journalists. He smiled broadly after it was retrieved.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


271 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambian Royalists Demand Release Of Chief


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 10, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 694 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian traditionalists are demanding the release of a their chief detained by the government for alleged treasonable offences.

The Barotse Cultural Association, which maintains close links with the Lozi Royal Establishment in Zambia's western province, demanded Monday the immediate and unconditional release of Senior Chief Inyambo Yeta.

Yeta, vice-president of the opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP), has been detained with seven others for alleged involvement in a terror campaign by the clandestine "Black Mamba" group. 

In an open to President Frederick Chiluba, the association said the detention was malicious and designed to ruin the chief's standing, particularly among his people.

"The Barotse Cultural Association, having considered the circumstances leading to the unlawful detentions of Senior Chief Inyambo Yeta and seven others, do hereby demand their immediate and unconditional release," said the association in the letter to Chiluba.

Yeta and the seven others from UNIP, which is led by former President Kenneth Kaunda, were arrested and charged with treason last week.

They are alleged to have participated in a spate of bombings by the Black Mamba. The group launched its campaign of terror after government's adoption of a controversial constitution that bars Kaunda from contetsing Zambia's 1996 presidential elections, on the grounds that he had foreign parents.

The constitution also bars traditional chiefs from participating in active party politics, unless they abdicate their psotions.

The association also told Chiluba that it considered the chief a prisoner of conscience whose detention had been politically motivated. It pledged to continue supporting both his political position and chieftainship.

"A Lozi chief remains one for life as long as that chief does not violate the Lozi customary law. The Barotse Cultural Association and many other concerned ma-Lozi (Lozis), who have closely followed Senior Chief Inyambo's political career and philosophy, shall continue to rally behind him and ensure his success, regardless of what government may do," the association said.

The London-based human rights group, Amnesty International, said Saturday it would launch a campaign for the release of the detainees whom it said it considered as prisoners of conscience.

In a message to Kaunda Saturday, which the UNIP leader read at an opposition political parties meeting in the capital, Amnesty accused Chiluba's government of "playing political games" by arresting opponents and said that it would watch developments in the matter "carefully."

The leaders of eight opposition parties represented at Saturday's meeting reiterated, in a joint declaration, their opposition to the new constitution and demanded its immediate repeal.

They also repeated the call for a constituent assembly and referendum to adopt the country's supreme law and that this year's general elections be held under the 1991 constitution.

The parties commended the donor community for heeding appeals to deny aid to the Chiluba government and appealed to the Southern African Frontline States to close their borders to government traffic. They also urged neighboring states to bar Zambian government officials from regional meetings and conferences until the government agrees to respect human rights.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

June, 1996


Nigeria Nigerian Ministers Banned From Politics For Five Years


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 227 words


 

AMAIGBO, Nigeria - Nigeria's serving ministers are banned from partisan politics for at least the next five years, Information and Culture Minister Walter Ofonagoro said Monday.

"Any minister now is ruled out of politics, for at least up to the year 2003, from present calculations, to avoid partisanship," the News Agency of Nigeria quoted him as saying in his Amaigbo country-home, in eastern Nigeria. 

The administration of Gen. Sani Abacha is implementing a 36- month transition programme to democracy. It is due to be completed October 1998.

Government had given ministers wishing to join politics to resign by October 1995.

Therefore, Ofonagoro said, it would be "futile" for any minister now to nurse political ambitions. He said the measure was designed to ensure an unbiased and credible transition.

"You cannot be an umpire and at same time participate in the celebration of victory," he said. "We have to commit ourselves to ensure a smooth process of handing over, and this should be seen as call to national service."

Africa News


June, 1996


Libya and United States Tripoli Celebrates the Departure of American Troops


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - Libya on Tuesday celebrates the 26th anniversary of the closure of United States military bases on its territory.

The Libyan leader, Col. Moammar Kadhafi, ordered the closure of the bases and departure of American troops shortly after a successful military coup he led on June 11, 1970. 

"Our independence remains incomplete if a single foreign soldier remains on our national territory," Kadhafi said at the time.

There were five American bases in Libya, including Houills, the biggest American air base outside the United States. It was later renamed Maitiga after a seven-year-old Lybian girl killed by the debris of an American plane that exploded while flying near the site.

Relations between the United States and Libya, which it accuses of backing international terrorism, have remained tense.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Ghana Ghana Warns Captains of Refugee Ships


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana has repeated earlier warnings that she will no longer tolerate any ship carrying refugees into her waters, saying any captain who violates the warning will face prosecution.

Speaking Sunday to the Ghana News Agency in Accra, deputy minister of foreign affairs, Mohamed Ibn Chambas, said "our position has not changed. We will not accept any refugee ship any more, we have had enough." 

He said Ghanaian port officials have been made aware of this position and will not allow any such ship to dock.

Chambas was reacting to press reports that negotiations were going on between Ghana and the United Nations on the plight and possible acceptance of refugees on a Russian vessel, Zolotitsa, which has been at sea for the past 12 days.

Chambas said Ghana had not been approached to take the vessel carrying about 400 refugees and warned that the captain will face prosecution if he docked at a Ghanaian port without authorisation.

The vessel, which arrived at the Takoradi anchorage on Friday, was towed out of Ghanaian territorial waters the following day under Navy escort.

The United States has urged countries along the west African coast, especially Togo, Benin and Nigeria, to accept the ship which relief officials said was in poor condition and had run short of food, water and medicine, "for humanitaian reasons".

Zolotitsa was sent back to sea on Wednesady by Togolese authorities, after they had given it some assistance.

Thousands of Liberians have been making desperate efforts to flee renewed fighting in their country, but West African countries are reluctant to take them, saying it will trigger a mass exodus.

Last month, Ghana bowed to intense diplomatic pressure and accepted about 2,000 refugees brought in by a rusty Nigerian freighter, Bulk Challenge, after a 10-day drama at sea.

Meanwhile, a special delegation from Ghana, chairman of the 16- nation Economic Community of West African States, is in Liberia for a new round of negotiations to speed up moves to stop the fighting.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

June, 1996


Business and Finance Currency Update


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The Ghanaian cedi continues to drift in spite of claims that the liberalized Ghanaian economy is performing well.

Reports from Accra said Monday tht the currency exchange rate averaged 1,630 to the dollar from 1,606 about two weeks ago. 

Some 353 cedis exchanged for one dollar in 1991, mid-way through the country's structural adjustment program, hailed by multilateral finance institutions.

Elsewhere the CFA franc, used in 13 French-speaking African countries, began a quiet week opening at the nominal rate of 519 to the dollar from 517 to the dollar on the same day last week.

In Dakar the currency exchanged at 504 buying and 534 selling. Last week it exchanged at 502 buying and 532 selling to the dollar on the same day last week.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


276 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Transforming The African Development Bank


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996 by Abel Basutu, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote d'ivoire - The African Development Bank has embarked on a long and tortuous road to local and international respectability, in the process laying the groundwork for longer term changes.

Much of this is due to austere measures adopted by the bank's new president, Morrocan Omar Kabbaj and his advisers in this first year of his tenure.

The bank's corporate governance, nature and style of executive management and credit policies, have all come under intense scrutiny and alterations, with the most visible being the removal of 250 staff early this year.

There have been four strands to the reform programme: measures to improve bank lending, tighter controls over loan arrears and administrative costs, new organisational structure and efforts to improve institutional governance of the bank. 

As Kabbaj surveys results of the re-organisation, he promises "the worst is behind us", and the bank needs to surge forward.

"This restructuring was not my own idea. But morale is improving and I think staff are emerging from the trauma of re-organisation," said Kabbaj.

So far, administrative costs, which however still lag behind World Bank standards, have been lowered by 15 percent from a percentage of loan portfolio of 1.3 percent in 1992 to 0.99 percent in 1993 compared with the World Bank's record of 0.6 percent in 1992-93.

The depths to which the bank had sunk and the radical changes being implemented initially depressed staff morale but observers say it has dissipated fears about the survival of the institution.

ADB donors from western industrialised countries scrambled, at the bank's annual meeting at the end of May, to put together a 2.6 billion-dollar package to replenish the exhausted coffers of the bank's soft-loan arm -- the African Development Fund.

Another psychological boost also came from the newest member -- South Africa -- which promised to become the first African country to contribute to the Fund and expressed "a historic obligation to debunk the all too-pervasive Afro-pessimism".

A much relieved Kabbaj then declared the bank would open for business now that donors have pledged to replenish the ADF.

The donors will meet again in the Japanese town of Osaka this month, stretching the long-search for funds for the poorest members of the group comprising 53 African and 24 non-African states.

David Lipton, who represents the United States at the ADB, pledged to push Congress to approve its 200-million-dollar contribution to replenish fund.

Although Lipton had earlier said the ADB was dysfunctional, he changed his heart, saying "under Kabbaj it had turned the corner. In a incredibly short period of time, he has made sweeping changes and brought a fresh start."

Kabbaj also plans to impose severe sanctions on bad debtors though he admits it may take a major political initiative to resolve the problem which has been described as "ticklish".

Arrears will for the first time be considered on the same basis as those of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

The number of delinquents who have fallen into long-term arrears totalling more than 800 million dollars has risen to five from three during the past two years.

Angola and Cameroon are newcomers to the list which also includes Liberia, Sudan and Zaire.

"The five cases are in chronic state which may require political intervention at the highest level," says Kabbaj.

The cases are now scheduled to be discussed when African Heads of State meet early in July in Libreville, Gabon, to debate the ADB'S future prior to the annual Organization of African Unity summit, in neighboring Cameroon.

The ADB has also approved a revised arrears policy with tighter sanctions and a more rigorous application of directives on cancellation.

It also moved from specific to general provisioning and moves are underway to clean up non-performing loans. Other measures of financial management such as new currency and interest rate policies are scheduled to be discussed by the ADB board later in June.

In the wake of re-organization, the bank has started wide-ranging new training programs aimed first at 70 percent of managers who have risen through the ranks.

Korn Ferry, a UK-based consultancy, will assist the bank with specialised new recruitment to fill all available professional positions by the end of June.

"There is a problem of culture in the bank that will not be corrected overnight. We have to work, in my view, for another 18 months to two years to change that," Kabbaj said.

To tighten accountability and transparency, three more accountants are being attached to the ADB president's office to ensure all financial outflows are made in conformity with bank regulations and procedures.

"Some have said Africa is a lost hope. Others have said Africa cannot make it. I say, Africa cannot afford not to make it," said Aleke Banda, Malawi's governor to the ADB.

But perhaps the litmus test in the bank's revival is the sticking issue of institutional governance.

Most African countries are opposed to industrialized states increasing their shareholding, warning "the bank will lose its African identity".

This issue comes in the wake of a radical report prepared by a three-man panel comprising retired Asian Development Bank vice president, Gunther Schulz, former Africa director of IMF, Mamadou Toure and ex-senior Kenyan treasurer, Harris Mule.

The report presents four options for restructuring the bank's capital base, the first of which includes allowing non-African shareholders equal shares with the African owners of the bank.

Bank officials say implementation of the report's recommendations will be a key factor in determining the size of the forthcoming general capital increase and a key condition in the release of resources for the replenishment of the ADF.

African shareholders of the bank led by Nigeria, Egypt, Libya and Cote d'Ivoire control two-thirds of its African share capital. The so-called non-regionals own one-third of the capital of the ADB and 50 percent of the capital of the ADF.

There is substantial African opposition to any attempt by non- regional shareholders to increase either managerial control or equity in the bank.

Nigeria's finance minister, Anthony Ani, warns against "attempts to steal the bank".

Africa News


June, 1996


Busines and Finance More Nigerian Banks Run Into Trouble


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Thirty-six more Nigerian banks have run into trouble, bringing the number of distressed banks in the country to 60, according to a recent corporate finance report.

Bankers in Lagos said currently some 52 percent of the commercial and merchant banks in the country were insolvent.

The report on "Financial Indices on Distressed Banks as at December 1995", said the 60 troubled banks, included 33 merchant banks. 

The Central Bank of Nigeria has been involved in some rescue operation, and recently acquired six commercial banks. Last year, the apex bank took over 17 banks and handed them over to new managements as part of the rescue mission.

The report said the troubled banks held deposits amounting to 93.5 billion naira (82.5 naira=1 USD). Only 52.6 billion naira or 56 percent of the amount was covered by the Nigeria Deposit Insurance Corporation.

According to bankers, claimants of uninsured deposits may not be able to receive compensation if the failed banks go into liquidation.

At least, seven executives of failed Nigerian banks have been sent to prison under a government decree, aimed at sanitizing the financial system. Some 200 other bank executives are in detention.

The report said as at December 1995, the troubled banks had loaned some 57 billion naira, mainly to insiders, notably directors.

Only about 3.08 billion naira or 5.4 percent of the loans had been recovered, while another 35.8 billion naira is listed as "non-performing" funds.

Two weeks ago, bankers claimed that another major problem facing the financial houses in Nigeria was the rising crime wave and incessant bank raids.

Only between 10 and 15 percent of the total money in circulation was in the banking system, because citizens no longer considered banks safe enough to keep money, the bankers say.

The military government, however. says its has stepped up anti-crime meassures to arrest the situation.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

June, 1996


Business and Finance Foreign Companies Prospect For Minerals in Zambia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - About a dozen foreign companies have been awarded rights by the Zambian government to prospect and extract various minerals in the country.

Mines minister, Kelly Walubita, in a recent statement said that the companies had so far invested some two million dollars in exploration, prospecting and mining, mainly in the mineral-rich northern and northwestern parts of the country. 

The companies include, Gencor of South Africa, Western Mining of Australia and Phelps Dodge.

Caledonia Mining Corporation of Canada said in May that it had discovered some traces of gold in Chilabombwe, northern Zambia, in addition to copper ore deposits.

Its mining director, Stefan Hayden, said that indications were that his company would be able to strike substantial amounts of the mineral after necessary tests.

The company has already started to mine cobalt, also in the northern region. Cobalt and copper are among Zambia's major export minerals.

The government in this year's budget, allowed tax rebates on imports of mining and agricultural machinery, to attract foreign investors in the country's two major industrial sectors.

Africa News


June, 1996


Science Very Few Zambian Babies Are Breast-Fed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 494 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - A United Nations official has said that there is need to conduct a study to find out why pregnant African mothers weigh less compared to others in Europe and America.

Speaking at the official opening of the workshop on "trainer of trainers in lactation management" Tuesday, the acting U.N. Childrens Fund representative to Zambia, Marashetty Seenappa, said it was critical for pregnant mothers to gain weight.

He said that a study found that in America pregnant mothers put on 35.6 pounds, in the United Kingdom 24.2 while in Tanzania it was 19.8 and Uganda 17.6 pounds. 

"Why the wide viriation? May be it is economical or lack of care but lets not speculate, it is important to find out the reasons behind this," Seenappa said.

Weight gain, he said, was fundamental to pregnant mothers since breast-feeding guaranteed 300 calories per day for a baby.

Meanwhile, a senior socio-anthropologist in Zambia has said that 13 percent of the country's babies are exclusively breast-fed between zero to two months.

Funny Kondolo told PANA Tuesday in Lusaka that although about 98 percent of Zambian mothers breast-feed, the infant feeding method is not practiced exclusively for six months, as advised by scientists.

Kondolo said that a consultancy team was working on a breast-feeding policy to be submitted July to the Ministry of Health. The policy suggests that employees provide creches at worksites so that mothers could breast-feed their babies during tea and lunch breaks.

She said that if adopted, the policy would compel employers to extend maternity leave from three to four months.

Officially opening the workshop, the ministry of community development and social welfares' assistant secretary, Meselina Hampango, said one of the causes of child death was poor nutrition. she said that this condition was due to poor child feeding practices coupled with general poverty.

She said the high child mortality rates and infant and under five years mortality rates were 123 and 202 per 1,000 in 1992.

The three-week workshop, which opened Tuesday, is aimed at adopting breast-feeding practices which will increase knowledge in advantages off breast-feeding in relation to child survival and safe motherhood.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

280 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Burundi Burundi's Donors Meeting Set For Geneva


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996 by Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 880 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - A meeting of donors assisting strife-torn Burundi is scheduled for Monday and Tuesday in Geneva.

The United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs said in a dispatch to PANA Tuesday that the meeting would be hosted by the Canadian minister of international cooperation.

The U.N. department said the meeting will discuss the situation in Burundi, "in a bid to secure a common approach amongst donors and U.N. agencies in support of peace negotiations and aid issues."

The Great Lakes region consists of the troubled central African states of Burundi and Rwanda, as well as their neighbors -- Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire. 

It is estimated that due to ethnic violence between the majority Hutu and minority Tutsi in Burundi and Rwanda, at least 1.7 million refugees have fled into exile in the three neighboring countries.

Violence started in Rwanda on Oct.1, 1990, when the sons of Tutsi exiles living in Uganda fought their way into Rwanda, in a bid to topple the government of the late President Gen. Juvenal Habyarimana.

The violence turned into genocide when Habyarimana, a Hutu, was killed in a mysterious plane crash before landing in Kigali. In the revenge killing which followed, Hutus massacred up to a million of people from the Tutsi minority.

The genocide ended when the Rwandan exiles from Uganda, known as the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF), defeated the government army in Kigali. At least two million Hutu were forced to flee into exile, to escape the RPF's advance.

In Burundi, violence was sparked off by the assassination of the first Hutu to be democratically elected, Melchior Ndadaye, allegedly by rogue Tutis soldiers, on Oct.21, 1993.

The death toll since Ndadaye died is estimated at 100,000 people, both Tutsi's and Hutus.

According to the U.N. humanitarian affairs department, the meeting in Geneva will bring together donors, U.N. Agencies and the Organization of African Unity (OAU).

The discussions will focus on a possible program of development support for Burundi, the review of contingency planning and consideration of initiatives which might support Burundian leaders in their dialogue by "broadening the constituency for peace in the country." the U.N. dispatch added.

The donors meeting will be held amid signs of aggravating tension between the majority Hutu and minority Tutsi, who control the armed forces.

This tension, including rumors of a coup d'etat, results from the failure by Burundi's leaders to reach a consensus on ways to end the violence, which has lasted for more than two years and a half since Ndadaye' death.

The meeting in Geneva will come barely two weeks after the collapse of the second round of peace negotiations in Mwanza, involving the Hutu-dominated ruling Burundi Democratic Front (FRODEBU) and the country's former Tutsi-dominated sole party, the Union for National Progress (UPRONA).

FRODEBU favours the inclusion of Hutu rebels, grouped under the National Committee for the Defence of Democracy or CNDD of former Interior Minister Leonard Nyangoma, in the peace negotiations, moderated by former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere.

However, UPRONA, whose Tutsi soldiers reportedly assassinated Ndadaye, categorically rejects that position, saying this would abrogate the "government convention" the two parties signed in July 1994.

It was under that "power-sharing" convention that the current president, Sylivestyre Ntibantunganya, a Hutu, was allowed to step into the shoes of the late Ndadaye.

That convention calls for the exclusion, from the reigns of power, of all Burundians who have been implicated in acts of violence. Among these is Nyangoma and his CNDD.

However, Nyerere has warned the Burundians to seriously negotiate their differences, if they want to prevent a Rwanda-like blood-bath. At one time, he even said Nyangoma could take over power, in the same way Uganda's Yoweri Museveni stormed to power in January 1986.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


281 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Uganda Over 600 Zairean Tutsi Flee Into Uganda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 11, 1996 by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 427 words


 

KISORO, Uganda - Over 600 Zaireans of Tutsi ethnic group have reportedly crossed into Uganda's south-western Kisoro district, for fear of being attacked by exiled soldiers of the the defeated Rwanda government and the "Interahamwe", a Hutu militia.

The Kisoro district chief administrative officer, Abdallah Kiganda, said Monday that the refugees started arriving last Thursday. 

The refugees were reportedly coming from eastern Zaire's Jomba area in Rucru zone, along with hundreds of heads of cattle and other property.

Kiganda said the refugees crossed through the Busanza border post and were camped at Nyakabande, four kilometres from Kisoro town on Ugandan territory.

On Monday alone, Kiganda said, over 100 refugees with about 174 heads of cattle, crossed through Busanza, about 24 kilometres from the common border.

"The refugees, mainly people of the Tutsi ethnic group, say the Interahamwe have gone on the rampage since Thursday and have murdered a big number of their relatives," Kiganda told the PANA correspondent in Kampala.

The Interahamwe is accused of being behind the killings during the 1994 massacres in Rwanda.

Kiganda said the refugees reported that the attackers, armed with spears and pangas, had on Monday morning, murdered the Rucru zone assistant district officer.

His head was found hanging on a tree near Chengerere, about 10 kilometres from the Uganda side of the border, the official added.

"We have already contacted the ministry of local government and the UNHCR (UN High Commissioner for Refugees) which have sent a team to assess the situation and we are expecting relief items tomorrow (Tuesday)" Kiganda said.

He said the Kisoro district commissioner, Asudu Lutale, had contacted his counterpart in the neighboring North Kivu province and discussed with him the possibility of allowing the refugees back to their areas of origin under protection.


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


282 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Igbo Debate: Whose King?


BYLINE: TheWeek (Lagos) June 12, 1996 by Louis Onyia


LENGTH: 2134 words


 

Lagos - Emeka Ojukwu, erstwhile leader of the defunct Republic of Biafra, stirs the hornet's nest by declaring himself King of the Igbo.

The man had done it before or something similar. That was in 1983, around the time of the gubernatorial and presidential elections. Emeka Ojukwu, erstwhile leader of the short-lived rebel Republic of Biafra, was deeply involved in the political maneuvers of the time as a member of the ruling National Party of Nigeria. Apparently to feather his political nest, Ojkwu, who had his eyes firmly fixed on the senate, took the title of Dike Di Ora Nma of Igboland. The title, which roughly translates into the beloved warrior of Igboland, was conferred on Ojukwu, who returned from over 10 years' self exile in Cote d'Ivoire in 1981, by a group of Igbo traditional rulers.

The title immediately touched off a controversy. Nnamdi Azikiwe, then chairman and presidential candidate of the Nigerian Peoples Party, took on Ojukwu, denouncing his new title for being out of line with the Igbo standard of awarding chieftaincy titles. Zik was readily supported by his political disciples of Igbo origin such as Sam Mbakwe and Jim Nwobodo. 

In the event, Ojukwu stuck to his guns and kept using the title until the novelty wore off. These days he hardly answers Dike Di Ora Nna of Igboland. Nor does he need to, for he has acquired a more treasured title - the Eze Igbo or King of the Igbo.

But since he took the title, -- reportedly his 90th -- Ojukwu has not known peace, nor has Igboland. The title and the circumstances surrounding its conferment have snowballed into something close to a scandal since May 19, when it was denounced by Oha-na-Eze, arguably the highest power welding body in Igboland.

That day separate meetings of the council of elders and General Assembly of Oha-na-Eze, had been called to discuss the death and burial Azikiwe, Nigeria's first president, who died May 11.

Sources close to the meetings, held at 7, Park Avenue, Enugu told Theweek that "Ojukwu's leadership maneuvering" dominated discussions. The Eze Igbo chieftancy title conferred on Ojukwu May 4 by Shedrack Mbanefo, an embattled Nri red cap chief, who lays claim to the Adama status of Nri, was hotly debated. Nri community in Njikoka Local Government Area of Anambra State is generally believed to be the origin and head of Igbo culture and tradition.

Critics of Ojukwu's new title contend that under Igbo custom, no traditional ruler of any of the autonomous communities has the right to confer an all-encompassing chieftancy title on anybody no matter how highly placed. Another argument is that the people who conferred the title on Ojukwu have no authority to do so since "they are merely the palace traditional servants of the traditional ruler of Nri, Eze Obidiegwu Onyesoh."

Onyesoh believes that "Ojukwu and Shedrach Mbanefo, Adama of Nri, committed an abomination against the gods of Nri." To prevent the abomination, Onyesoh had made spirited efforts to prevent Mbanefo from giving the title, and Ojukwu from taking it. His warning to all those invited to the conferment ceremony to stay away and avoid trouble worked, but only temporarily. On that day, May 4, over 100 anti-riot policemen led by a senior officer from Awka, the state capital, prevented the ceremony from holding at Akamkpisi Village Square, Nri. Determined to have the title, Ojukwu simply invited Mbanefo to his Is Uzor Street residence at Independence Layout, Enugu, where the title was eventually conferred on him.

The Oha-na-Eze meeting of May 19 which discussed the unusual development attracted the cream of Igbo society. In attendance were Alex Ekweueme, former Nigerian vice-president; C.C. Onoh, one time governor of Old Anambra State; Emmanuel Iwuanyanwu, Champion publisher; Pius Okigbo, renowned economist; Jerome Udoji, an Industrialist, Nnia Nwodo, a second republic minister; and Ben Nwabueze, a professor of law and ex-secretary for education during the defunct Interim National Government. Others included Godwin Odenigwe, political adviser to Shehu Shagari, the Second Republic President; Bernard Onuegwunwoke, chairman, Imo State council of traditional rulers, who presided over the meeting; Chris Nwankwo, a former presidential aspirant; and one Aghanya, a colonel in the defunct Biafran army.

Theweek learnt that when Onoh, father of Biancah, Ojukwu's wife, raised the Eze Igbo title issue, members unanimously condemned Ojukwu for demanding and taking the title. The consensus was that the title does not exist in Igboland. According to sources, the Oha-na-Eze was told during the meeting that what Mbanefo had wanted to confer on Ojukwu was the title of Ofor Na Afor, but that Ojukwu convinced him to change the title to Eze Igbo.

To buttress this allegation, the one who made it was said to have refered the gathering to Ojuwku's letter dated April 16, inviting his friends to grace the chieftancy installation ceremony on May 4 at Nri. After a heated debate on the issue, Onuegwunwoke called for suggestions on how to amicably settle the problem.

Aghanya reportedly advised that the matter be forgotten since the title merely exists in the minds of the Ojukwu and the man who conferred it on him. Aghanya's counsel did not however, make sense to people like Nwodo, Onoh, Ekwueme, Nwabueze and Iwuanyanwu, all of whom recommended that Ojukwu should be sanctioned. They suggested rather sarcastically that since Ojukwu wanted a title at all cost, he should be conferred with the title of Eze Ogbunigwe, meaning "king of mass destruction," a veiled reference to his activities as a civil war rebel head of state.

At the meeting, those who spoke in favour of Ojuwku argued that Eze Igbo has no territory or authority over anybody in Igboland. But they were defeated by those who maintained that in the eyes of outsiders, especially non-Igbo speaking people, Eze Igbo implies King of the Igbo, and that Ojukwu, who nurses presidential ambition, may be tempted to use it for political gains in future. Based on a suggestion by an unidentified person at the meeting, it was agreed that a newspaper advertisement be placed to disown the title.

Nwabueze was asked to place the advert immediately. A suggestion that Ojukwu be stripped of other chieftancy titles earlier conferred on him by Igoba was dropped on popular demand. Those who recommended this sanction referred to Ojukwu's unguarded utterances on both local and national issues to justify their stand. They claimed that Ojukwu was refered to as Eze igbo at the Sultan's palace in Sokoto, during Ojukwu's recent visit to Muhammdadu Maccido, newly appointed sultan of Sokoto.

In a full page advert in the Daily Champion on May 23, which Ojukwu's supporters claimed was donated by Iwuanyanwu, Oha-na-Eze stated that the title of Eze Igbo does not exist and that no one is recognised as such by the Igbos. The organisation, "noting that a member of the council of elders, Chief Chukwuemeka Odumegwu- Ojukwu, Ikemba of Nnewi, at some ceremony in his Enugu residence has had conferred on himself the title of Eze Igbo, which title is already being used in certain public announcements and publications, hereby state for the information of Nigeria authorities and the general public that the title of Eze Igbo does not exist," Ojukwu replied Oha-na-Eze four days later, at the third general assembly of his political association, the Nigerian Peoples Movement. At that meeting, held in Enugu, the Ikemba used more than one-and-a-half hours to dress down his opponents. Ojukwu: "Oha-na-Eze has no leadership. Oha-na-Eze has no membership. The person who signed as the secretary-general of Oha-na-Eze in Champion newspaper, who elected him? Who did he defeat to emerge as the secretary-general and how many votes did he get?" Ojukwu, who was visibly angry, told the gathering that Nwabueze failed to win election to represent his people in the constitutional conference and so could not lead them (his listeners) to Abuja. "Together, I and you shall match to Aso Rock." Ojukwu enthused.

Referring to Iwuanyanwu, Ojuwi said that he was not bothered by unfriendly remarks on his person by those who donate newspaper space to run him down. He claimed that Iwuanyanwu had failed to execute all the road contracts awarded him by both the past and present governments in the country. Said Ojukwu: "I will go to Abuja and I will recommend to the authorities to constitute a failed contracts tribunal quickly to try those who have failed to execute contracts given to them when the money had been fully paid."

Ekwueme was not spared by Ikemba Nnewi, who asked: "What of the one who could not speak at the constitutional conference until I came to stand behind him to say whatever he wants?" Ojukwu was obviously making reference to the constitutional conference days when the confusion generated by one of Ekwueme's speeches on the floor of the conference, Ojukwu came and stood behind him as a sign of solidarity.

Although he has an array of prominent Igbo sons to contend with, Ojukwu, it is believed, sees the contest for Igbo leadership as a straight fight between him and Ekwueme. In fact, Ojukwu's actions in recent times are seen by some people as part of his attempt to wrestle the leadership position from Ekwueme.

Sources close to the Ikemba told Theweek that the former Biafran leader is not comfortable with Ekwueme's domineering presence in Igbo affairs. The sources recalled that during the constitutional conference, Ekwueme was nominated to lead Igbo delegates, including Ojukwu. At the conference, Ekwueme, as Igbo leader, presented the Igbo position on all issues. During the burial, late last year, of Akanu Ibiam, former governor of defunct Eastern Region, despite Ojukwu's closeness with Sani Abacha, the head of state, Ekwueme was once more asked to lead the Igbo dignitaries.

Even in matters between the Igbos and other tribes in the country Ekwueme has always been placed first before Ojukwu. At the all-politicians' summit held last year in Lagos, Ojukwu was said to have been miffed that some of his followers did not oppose Ekwueme's position as chairman of the summit.

As if to reiterate Ekwueme's supremacy, the Oha-na-Eze meeting of May 19, appointed Ekwueme chairman of Zik's burial committee, with Ojukwu as one of the members of the committee. Sources close to the Ikembas, however, told Theweek that "Ojukwu will attend Zik's burial as Eze Igbo whether they like it or not and not as member of the Oha-na-Eze,"

Ekwueme on his part, has been reluctant to join issues with Ojukwu. Approached by Theweek, Ekwueme insisted that the matter was between Ojukwu and Oha-na-Eze and that he would not want to make personal comments on Ojukwu's utterances about him. "Oha-na- Eze has said that the title does not exist and nobody holds such title in Igboland," said Ekwueme, "What else do you want me to say?'

Issue Cover Date: June 17


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


283 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


West Africa For Nigerian Drug Dealers, There's No Place Like Ghana


BYLINE: TheWeek (Lagos) June 12, 1996 by Theo Nicol


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Lagos - Run out of town by the National Drug Law Enforcement Agency, an increasing number of Nigerian drug merchants find a new haven in Ghana.

Musa Bamaiyi, chairman of the National Drug Law Enforcement Agency, must hear this: Hundreds of Nigerian drug traffickers driven out of the country by him and his boys have relocated to neighboring Ghana, from where they sneak in and out of town with the illegal stuff.

TheWeek's investigations in Ghana showed that unable to use the airports anymore, an increasing number of Nigerian drug dealers now export cocaine and heroine to Ghana by road because of the porous nature of the boarders. With a few crisp naira and CFA notes doles out to security operatives and anti-narcotics officials at the borders, each of the drug dealers are allowed to enter Ghana with as much as a kilogram of cocaine or heroine. 

On arriving in Accra, the Ghanaian capital, the drug merchants supply their Ghanaian and Nigerian retailers, who then take the drugs to the various joints at Tudu, Keneshie, Legon, Abeka-Lapaz and Nkrumah Circle in Accra, where they see a pinch for an equivalent of N250.

Those who sell outside Accra, in big towns like Kumasi, Tokoradi, Tamale, and Cape Coast, usually travel with the buses of either the State Transport Corporation or the Ghana Private Transport Union. They make the trips at night, when there are no policemen at the checkpoints to disturb them.

One of the Nigerian drug dealers in Ghana told Theweek that "the business is more lucrative here than in Nigeria because there are less people to settle." According to him, "here, the policemen are more liberal and they don't ask for much to protect us. Most of them don't even know the true value of our trade. When you give them 50,000 cedis (about 2,500) they get so happy that they can protect you conveniently for a week. Whenever there is going to be a raid in Tudu, for instance, which is like the retail headquarters, we are quickly informed by our contact in the force, so we can avoid the area. It is not like Nigeria. Here we hardly get burst."

Ayo, another Nigerian drug dealer who lives a life of affluence in Accra, owning the latest car models, told Theweek that he was a trainee dealer in Lagos before his friend told him to try Accra about two years ago.

He said that at first, things were fairly hard for him, until he met a big buyer who owns a hotel in Accra. "That man recruited me and sent me to Lagos twice a week to bring in market," revealed Ayo. "In a year I made enough money to buy a BMW and a Honda Civic. I only had problem once at Seme border when a stubborn woman detective refuse to take kola. She insisted I must be searched. Eventually, I settled her with two thousand dollars and she chilled."

Ayo, who is now on his own, disclosed that his customers include military officers, wealthy businessmen, government officials and expatriates living in Ghana.

"That is why it is easy for me to make it big, because big guys pay bigger bucks for coke, because they need protection, which I give," said Ayo. "I sometimes hawk the stuff from office to office and from one big hotel to the other. When they desperately need it they call me on my mobitel, (mobile phone) and I deliver. Everything is cool."

According to Emeka, another Nigerian drug dealer, there are now over 300 Nigerians involved in the drug trade in Ghana. A few are wholesalers, while others, usually brothers, friends or recruits of the wholesalers, retail the illegal drugs.

"We Nigerians now prefer this end," Emeka explained. "We don't make a hundred percent profit, sometimes less, but here there is no Bamaiyi to disturb us, so we can change our money to dollars, smuggle it to Nigeria and do something good with it."

At the police headquarters along Kojo Thompson Road in Accra, a senior officer confirmed that Nigerians are involved in the dragon trade in Ghana, but quickly added that it is not only Nigerians who are engaged in the unlawful business.

"We have caught Indians, Britons, Ghanaians and some other nationals here dealing in drugs, so we cannot single them (Nigerians) out even though people complain about them." said the officer.

Issue Cover Date: June 17


LOAD-DATE: June 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


284 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Kudirat Abiola - Her Murder and the Aftermath


BYLINE: TheWeek (Lagos) June 12, 1996 by Taye Ige


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4200 words


 

Lagos - A burst of gunfire stills Kudirat Abiola forever and shatters Nigeria's peace.

"If my own child stand between the actualization of June 12, I will kill that boy because I believe so much in it. I will fight to the last pint of my blood. The almighty Allah is my hope for this struggle."

Those words uttered on the eve of the second anniversary of the voided presidential election of 1993 were to resonate with a brutal finality on Tuesday, June 4, a few days to the third anniversary. That morning, a burst of gunfire from yet-to-be identified assassins drained the last pint of blood, not from her son, but from Kudirat Abiola, 44, mother of seven and wife to the detained politician, Moshood Abiola. 

Kudirat's last earthly sojourn began on a fast motion and with unusual occurrences. First, she woke up rather early. Babrinsa Jolaosho, her cook of four years was surprised to find her already seated in her living room so early, going through the dailies, her first chore of the day. Minutes later, she made for the bathroom for a wash during which Mercy Ette, an assistant editor with Newswatch, intent on booking an interview appointment with her came and left, without accomplishing her objective.

Next was her meal. Jolaosho who had dashed to the kitchen soon emerged with a steaming plate of yam and stew, his madam's favourite breakfast. He was mistaken. Kudirat would have none of it. Instead she asked to be given just tea and then not in a cup as Jolaosho knew her to prefer, but in a jug. In between taking her bath and emptying the jug of what turned out to be her last meal on earth, one or two visitors called which prompted Mark Adesina, her personal assistant who had also arrived the Abiola home to remind her boss of the 9 o'clock appointment she had to keep that morning. She quickly dismissed the visitors and dashed outside, Adesina in tow. Dauda Atanda Salami, her senior driver who had prepared the car and was already behind the wheels, threw the white Mercedes Benz 380 S class with registration number AA 73-ZAR into gear and sped off with Abiola's wife of 23 years to her fatal encounter.

As the party set out to keep the appointment, reportedly with Walter Carrington, the American ambassador to Nigeria, the car was flagged down by Celestine Okafor, a journalist on the political desk of the Punch newspapers who had unsuccessfully sought to gain entrance into the compound. Kudirat, her usual urbane and pleasant self, expressed regrets and asked the unrelenting newshound to call back by six o'clock that evening. She then offered Okafor who seemed to be going her way a lift in the car. He agreed and had almost opened the door to sit beside Kudirat when he hesitated. He suddenly remembered an appointment with Tony Momoh, former information minister. He declined the ride. Fate had intervened to save his life. With that interruption over, Dauda screeched into the main road of Toyin Street and passing through Allen Avenue joined the Obafemi Awolowo Way to the Lagos State secretariat. he was urged on by both Kudirat and Adesina who were conscious of the fact that they were already minutes late for the appointment with the diplomat. It was shortly after negotiating the 7-up bend and about to join the Lagos-Ibadan express road that tragedy struck.

One account has it that the assailants used two cars, one a white BMW and the other a Peugeot 504 car which overtook Kudriat's car while the BMW provided a rear cover, perhaps to ensure that if the front car missed the target, the occupants of those in the rear would complete the dastardly act. As it happened, the occupants of the Peugeot car were dead on target. A source at the Alausa police station to which the Mercedes Benz was later towed said that a bullet went through the driver's side via the front light, indicating that Kudirat's car might have been shot from the front. Having thus stopped the driver, they then shot Kudirat at close range. In the confusion, another account says that the Peugeot car first leveled up with Kudirat's limousine before the assailants shot the driver, and then released a volley of shots at Kudirat's temple. With their fiendish mission accomplished in a matter of seconds, the attackers sped in the direction of Lagos before the police and soldiers at the nearby former toll gate about 150 meters away, raced to the scene.

There, the soldiers and policemen met an almost lifeless Kudirat, a deeply wounded Dauda, and an incoherent Adesian, beckoning on passers-by and motorists to come to the aid of the party. The police reportedly commandeered a Toyota Hiace bus to convey the wounded to the Eko Hospital, less than two kilometers away.

In no time, the news of the attack spread like bushfire in harmattan, ricocheting through Lagos. Some witnesses of the bloody event telephoned media houses. One of those so informed was Bayo Onanuga, founding editor-in-chief of TheNews. he rushed to the Abiola household and in fact the first to inform the security men at the gate.

Whether Kudirat, the fourth amongst her parent's seven children, would survive the attack became the subject of intense prayers and fervent wishes until later in the evening when Mubasiru, Abiola's younger brother and Kola, his eldest son confirmed the worst: in a space of four years, Abiola has lost his second wife, the first being Simbiat who died in 1992.

Kudirat's condition when she was wheeled into Theatre Two of the Eko Hospital at about 9:50 a.m. was hopeless. That she stayed alive for about three more hours after she had been shot in the head at such a close range was a minor miracle. A team of surgeons suddenly arrived from around Lagos and other consultants, including some of the hospital's medical directors who were attending a seminar within the hospital's premises battled gallantly to save Kudirat to no avail. At about 1.30 p.m. she breathed her last.

Dauda, the driver, who was said to have been "seriously wounded" and Adesina, the personal assistant, were luckier. They were said to be responding to treatment by press time. Sources say the driver's case worsened considerably by Wednesday afternoon, but by Friday, the driver who received gunshot wounds in the arm seemed to have passed through the critical stage. Adesina was apparently not wounded by the gun men although he is believed to have received a waist injury when he hurtled from the car into a ditch.

The importance of the life and death of Kudirat came starkly home the following day when her remains were interred at about 5.07 p.m. in the well-manicured lawn overlooking her own duplex in the Abiola compound.

In what was powerfully evocative of a martyred freedom fighter, virtually every metre of the sprawling compound was cramped by the sea of humanity, ranging from ordinary Nigerians and celebrities to members of the diplomatic corps. The burial rites commenced shortly after two o'clock when students of the Moricass Arabic and Islamic School, Agege, encircled the grave side chanting Islamic songs. Their recitations were almost disrupted by the emotional outburst which greeted the arrival of Mumuni and Mohammadu Hadi, two of the deceased's children in Nigeria. The pair were said to have been spirited out of the Abiola's household to an aunt's place as soon as their mother's death was confirmed. They were informed of the incident only an hour before they were brought into the compound - for the burial ceremony. The wailing had hardly subsided when the first of four groups of students showed up at the burial. First to arrive were those of the Lagos State University and the Yaba College of Technology. Each group chanted songs casting aspersions on those who cut their heroine down in her prime. Each of the four groups were calmed by Musedik Alogba, president of the United Muslim Council. His mediation efforts paid off until one of the students recognised Abdulwahab Folawiyo, the Baba Adinni of Nigeria, in the section reserved for the Islamic leaders gracing the occasion. The students who perceived Folawiyo as an opponent of the struggle to actualize Abiola's mandate insisted that the millionaire had no business attending Kudirat's burial. He had to be spirited out of the house through the family mosque unto the pedestrian gate by the largely disused upper gate of the compound. His white flowing gown had become stained by the grass and sand hauled at one of the foremost Islamic leaders in Nigeria.

Lateef Adegbite, secretary-general of the Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs almost had a similar treatment. The students had mistaken him apparently for Tele Olukoya, Alogba's predecessor and member of the last constitutional conference. He was spared however when his identity became clearer. Bolstered by their seeming victory, the students soon made for the diplomats' seat where they not only sang but also addressed them, asking for the intervention of the ambassadors' home governments in the unending Nigerian political and economic crises which they said had engendered hunger, insecurity and deprivation.

When the situation nearly got out of hand, leaders of the National Democratic Coalition led by Bola Ige, Abraham Adesanya, Ayo Adebanjo and Wahab Dosunmu who had arrived about 2.00 p.m. sent Ademola Adeniji-Adele, former chairman of the Lagos Island local government to appeal to the students. The situation thereafter became calm but not before Bala Aiyelabola, one of the student leaders addressed the gathering.

By 4.25 p.m. when the Eko Hospital ambulance bearing the white and gold casket arrived the compound, crowd control had become virtually impossible. With further movement by the hearse absolutely impossible, the coffin was lifted off it and taken to the lawn tennis court where the last prayers were said. If the situation inside the court was rowdy, it was even more so at the graveside to which hundreds of people had laid ambush hours before Kudirat's body arrived. At the praying ground, the casket was not opened contrary to normal Islamic practices, apparently for fear of the body being mangled by the ever surging crowd.

And at the graveside, the officiating ministers had to be extra swift removing the corpse from the casket in conformity with Islamic injunctions which prescribe austere, solemn burial for the faithful. Only the body wrapped in immaculate shroud white material was interred. The empty casket was promptly snatched by the students and other urchins who, carrying it shoulder high, rained abusive songs on the government of Sani Abacha, whom they suspected of masterminding Kudirat's death. They soon emptied into Toyin Street and from there to other major streets of Lagos.

The mob's accusation conforms with one of the views prevalent in the NADECO and other pro-democracy camps since last Tuesday. One of such views linked Kudirat's death with that of Alfred Rewane who was shot in his bedroom, October 6, last year. In retrospect, they now praise the foresight of Anthony Enahor, the septuagenarian politician now in exile in the United States. They claim the elder statesman would have been given the "Rewane treatment" if he had not escaped. This view believes that the federal government is bent on totally annihilating the opposition.

Yet there are those willing to absolve the government. They ascribe the murder of the woman activist to forces opposed to the Abacha regime. According to this speculation, the killers are out to destabilise the polity, by creating unrest among the populace at home and complicating the government's problems with the foreign powers most of whom had never really forgiven the administration for hanging Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others last November. Perhaps, it is an attempt to proclaim its innocence to the world that the government sent a high-powered delegation led by Isaya Bamaiyi, chief of army staff to the burial. Abacha's condolence message which was delivered to the Abiola family by the delegation was broadcast for two days by the NTA last week, just as Zubair Kazaure appeared on the American cable network to deny government involvement in the death of Abiola's wife.

The police, too, added their own bit. They have so far, left no one in doubt as to their ostensible readiness to fish out Kudirat's killers. In addition to a well broadcast statement asking Nigerians to forward information on the killing to telephone numbers which were repeatedly advertised on network television, a panel headed by Archibong Nkana, deputy inspector- general of police, Federal investigation and Intelligence Bureau, was also put in the works. Lately, it announced a N1 million price tag on any useful information that leads to the arrest of the hoodlums. Nkana personally assured the Abiola family of his panel's resolve to fish out the miscreants.

Another possibility in NADECO's thinking is that the Kudirat assassination and others before it may have been organized by individuals or groups loyal to the government who chose to act on their own in what they consider to be in the interest of the government. A simple logic is believed to account for this possibility: Security reports have reportedly claimed that there would be no end to the Nigerian crisis if hard-liners like Kudirat were not eliminated. Such self-proclaimed friends of government might not have to be ordered specifically before carrying out their plans.

In sheer timing, the killers of Kudirat might just be exploiting the current feud within the Abiola family to throw suspicion all around. To the public, the open disagreements within the family, with Kola on one side and Kudirat on the other, over the legal strategies to adopt to free Abiola might have exposed Kudirat's flanks to the assassins. Already, the Nigerian in the United States is reported to have pointed accusing fingers at some sections of the family as being responsible for Kudirat's death. Such thinking was not lost on Kola himself. A source close to the Abiola's first son said he felt "terribly sad" at the death of his stepmother last week. he reportedly lamented that it was precisely to avoid this kind of calamity befalling his father's house especially now that he is in detention, that he has been advocating a less confrontational approach in the struggle to free his father from the clutches of the ruling military government. He was said to have told relations that his opposition to Kudirat was purely on strategies and that their goals were the same. Lola Edewor, Kola's elder half-sister echoed similar sentiments in an interview with Theweek shortly after Kudirat's interment. She urged people to stop looking for cracks in the family where none had existed and affirmed that the family remained one in the struggle to secure freedom for their detained father.

As the Abiolas grieve over their loss, NADECO leaders seem to have another source of worry: the whereabouts of Adesina. Early reports had it that he was in police custody, ostensibly helping in the investigation of the murder. The group had given the impression that it was desperately in search for the personal assistant to the slain Kudirat as he could be the repository of information and documents vital to the continuation of the struggle.

Surprisingly, the police came out to say they were not holding Adesina and proceeded to question the Abiola family on his whereabouts. The following day, THISDAY reported that Adesina had been arrested in a two-story building opposite the Abiola household thus giving the impression that he had gone into hiding. According to the newspaper, the police took him to Eko Hospital to confirm his story that he had been on admission there. Adesina reportedly denied claims of the pro-democracy activists that none of them had seen him since the fateful Tuesday. The hospital staff seemed to have corroborated Adesina's claim that he had been on admission at Eko Hospital.

If anything, the Kudirat killing has further polarised the nation and is capable of escalating the burgeoning political crisis in the nation. A pointer to the divisive chagrin of Nigerians was the manner the various mourning delegations were received at the Abiola compound. When the federal government delegation headed by Bamaiyi the chief of army arrived, it was received with jeers and boos and stony faces. The ten minutes the delegation spent was tension soaked. "What do you want here?" A group chorus to Bamaiyi's entourage. "Just release Abiola to come and mourn his wife. We are no more interested in the presidency." The anxiety heightened to a point that the army chief had to request from his host if the party could depart through an exit different from the one which it came into the tastefully furnished reception room. Efforts were then made to open an alternative exit, the one used exclusively by Abiola himself. The door would not open apparently because of long period of disuse. The delegation had to brave the odd to out the way they came in.

When Musa Bamaiyi, brother to leader of the government delegation and boss of the National Law Enforcement Agency came in about two hours later, the federal delegation had departed and the crowd more daring. "What is he writing, one woman asked in Yoruba as Mamaiyi started filling the condolence register. Another wondered aloud why the youth couldn't break through the security cordon around the two-star general to snatch the biro with which he was writing. Unruffled Mamaiyi managed to find his way into Kudirat's living room where he was received by Kudirat Aka- Basorun, wife of one of Abiola's counsel.

A different sort of reception awaited leaders of pro-democracy group considered friendly to Abiola cause. Delegations of such groups as the Campaign for Democracy, and the Civil Liberties Organisation were given triumphed welcome. For the CD, Kudirat's death was a clarion call for "the June 12 struggle to be pursued to its logical conclusion at whatever cost." Ayo Obe the CLO president said of Kudirat that the "torch of hope which you boldly grasped and which is now so cruelly extinguished will soon be rekindled."

Despite the acrimony, nearly all Nigerians were agreed in their effusions of the evil nature of the assassination. Bamaiyi, the NDLEA boss called it "a most disturbing incident and too callous." To Doyin Okupe, a politician, Kudirat was one of the most steadfast women he had ever met in his 44 years and believes her death will affect the struggle in a great way, "unless we want to kid ourselves."

Laila Dogonyaro, a woman activist who was reportedly devastated by the news of Kudirat's death described it as a "very sad development." Her one wish was that government would release Abiola to take control of his family.

Given the pro-democracy struggle to which Kudirat dedicated her last moments on earth, it was hardly surprising, that the international community felt outraged. The International Roundtable on Nigeria based in the United States situated the assassination within the context of other attacks on prominent Nigerians in recent times, and condemned them as politically inspired.

Tow days after the killing, the group offered its "deep sympathies" to Abiola and noted that Kudirat's murder is an unwarranted addition "to the already too-heavy burden of the family." For the Nigerian Democratic Awareness Committee, headed by Edward Oparaoji a US based Nigerian professor, the Nigerian embassy officials in Washington should stop pointing to the Abiola family as being responsible for the death of their matriarch. More than 40 clergymen and community leaders also met under the aegis of the Religion Action Network at Canaan Baptist Church of Christ, Harlem, New York and noted that the Nigerian regime has stripped the people of their "most basic human and civil rights, replacing them with violence, fear and intolerance." The conference recalled that many opposition leaders in Nigeria have been unjustly imprisoned, forced into exile or murdered. The clerics called "on all people of goodwill to mark the first Sunday of October this year as the "Nigerian Freedom Sunday, a day of prayer for all victims of oppression and dictatorship" such as Kudirat.

At a broader level, the United States government called for a thorough investigation of what it regarded as the "apparent assassination" of Kudirat, according to Gly Davies, acting spokesman of the US State department. Noting that the incident occurred shortly after her car had passed a police checkpoint, he called on the Nigerian government to "diligently pursue these killers and ensure that they are brought to book."

The British foreign office also reacted, calling for "full investigation" in the murder of Kudirat.

In her wildest dreams, Kudirat Olayinka Adeyemi, the pretty one-time head girl of Muslim Girls Secondary School, Ijebu-ode could not have imagined that she would command world attention of this magnitude in death at only 44 years. The big transformation came for her in 1993 when Moshood Abiola whom she married in 1973 declared his interest in that year's presidential election. The widely condemned annulment of that election believed to have been won by her husband roused the latent activist streak in her. And from then on, there was no looking back. She acquired the register of her new found love in the process. Much against the advice of friends, relations and some of her in-laws, Kudirat picked the gauntlet and continued with the struggle when her husband was arrested.

And she would not relent even when danger loomed large, Kudirat Alao Aka-Basorun, her bosom friend testifies to her strength of character: "She was a strong woman. Once she was convinced on an issue, almost always, you can't get her to renege."

Such was the driving force that propelled the woman who was born on Tuesday, August 29, 1951 detained overnight for the first and last time in her life on Tuesday may 7, 1996 on account of sedition charges and finally died unbowed on Tuesday June 4, 1996.

With Yusuph Olaniyonu, Emmanuel Ado, Jaiyeola Ajasa, Akaninyene Esiere, Austin Avwode, Mfon Uyen, Felix Ojogwum Chigbo Anichebe and Kalu Ukpong Mba.

Issue Cover Date: June 17
