Zambia Sports - General Council To Resolve Darts Wrangle The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - The National Sports Council of Zambia (NSCZ) plans to stage a meeting to resolve the wrangle between the Zambia Darts Association and its affilate, the Lusaka District Darts League.

NSCZ chairman Patrick Chamunda, indicated that though his office is yet to be briefed on the problems between the two darts groupings, he will call for a meeting. 

"I haven't as yet got any information of any problems in darts, but if there are any problems, we will surely have to sit down to resolve the issue," said Chamunda said in an interview in Lusaka yesterday.

The Darts Association of Zambia dissolved the whole Lusaka darts executive after the disappearance of a staggering K3 million and alleged misconduct among some members.

But Lusaka district darts league fixtures secretary, Teddy Sambaka, insisted that the darts mother body had personalised the issue.

"We have nothing against the mother body but the problem is that some people within DAZ want to personalise the issue. We are ready to resolve the matter but we may be faced to ask the Sports Council to help us resolve the issue if anything is done on the part of DAZ," Sambaka said in an interview yesterday.

Business and Finance Corporations Win Zambian Mining Rights The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 07, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Lusaka - Eleven international companies have been awarded rights to carry out various mining activities in Zambia. 

According to a statement released in Lusaka yesterday by mines minister Keli Walubita, the MMD government recognises the importance of the mining industry to the Zambian economy.

"The government has taken specific measures to address the needs of investors who wish to participate in the country's resource development. The measures are contained in the Mines and Minerals Act," read the statement.

Among the major companies are Gencor of South Africa, Western Mining of Australia, RTZ, Anglovaal, and Phelps Dodge.

The companies have invested over US$2 million in exploration, prospecting, and mining in the northern and northwestern parts of Zambia.

June, 1996


Zambia Parties Clash Over Aid Cuts The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Elias Kamanga


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - Tempers flared at the interparty meeting in Kitwe last Friday, as opposition parties and the ruling MMD clashed over recent threats of donor aid cuts, sending the meeting into disarray.

The highly charged meeting attended by the MMD, UNIP, ZDC, National Party and Movement for Democratic Process (MDP) failed to come up with resolutions after 12 hours of heated arguments over recent calls by some opposition parties for a donor aid squeeze against the government.

The opposition parties, led by the National Party, refused to budge when MMD proposed that a communique be jointly signed by all opposition parties condemning recent threats by the donor community of aid cuts. 

"We are not going to be hoodwinked into legitimising a hostile and dictatorial government by appending our signatures to this trickery," National Party provincial chairman Simon Kunda charged immediately after MMD delegation leader Kaunda Lembalemba made the proposal.

The MMD maintained that unless the communique was signed, they would not accept all the other resolutions.

"It is either you take this resolution by the MMD who in this case are in majority, or we forget about this inter party meeting all altogether," Lembalemba argued.

Lembalemba further accused the opposition of not adhering to the principles of democracy, among which was tolerance.

But the opposition was not deterred by Lembalemba's threats and maintained that unless the MMD reasoned with them on the matter, they would not mind forgetting about the meeting as well.

"The MMD should learn to reason and not suppress other parties' views, otherwise there is no need for sitting in conference rooms talking to an adamant and disrespectful party like the MMD," ZDC Copperbelt Provincial senator, James Chilemu, said.

Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) president, Alfred Zulu, was left with no alternative but to postpone the meeting.

MMD and opposition party cadres kept on jeering and chanting slogans in support of their own stances with the ruling party members accusing their colleagues from the opposition of being unpatriotic.

After the meeting was adjourned MMD members shouted abuse at the opposition leaders and continued singing and denouncing the donor community for threatening aid cuts.

Angry MMD cadres later started singing that since the talks had failed the solution was to fight it out so that the winners would be left to rule.

MDP president Chama Chakomboka said he was disappointed with the conduct of the MMD, saying the country was quickly drifting into a one party monopoly state.

LANGUAGE: English

308 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Amnesty Says Chiluba Playing Games The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Mervin Syafunko


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba's government has been accused by Amnesty International, a human rights organisation, of "playing political games" by detaining UNIP leaders on charges of treason which is punishable by death.

Amnesty International, in a facsimile message to The Post on Friday and distributed to various political leaders on Saturday, said the arrest and detention of the eight UNIP leaders, who include vice-president senior chief Inyambo Yeta, might have been politically motivated and for that reason the international community would keep an eye.

"The international community will be closely watching to see what evidence has been collected in support of making these arrests on suspicion of treason," Amnesty International said. 

Amnesty International demanded that if the UNIP leaders are being detained simply because of political differences they should be released immediately.

"If these men are, indeed, being held because of opposing the President politically, Amnesty International would consider them prisoners of conscience and would demand their immediate and unconditional release," the statement read.

Amnesty International wondered how the eight could be linked to the clandestine Black Mamba which was responsible for a spate of bomb blasts and threats because when their homes were searched by police who were apparently looking for bomb-making materials, guns or incriminating documents, no evidence was reportedly found.

"Amnesty international's concerns are heightened by lack of concrete evidence to justify these arrests which lends weight to the organisation's fear the real reason for these men's detention is to prevent them from carrying out non-violent political activity in line with their beliefs.

"Is there enough evidence to hold them without chance of bail at Lusaka Central Prison which has notoriously poor conditions?" wondered the human rights organisation, whose secretariat is in London.

When contacted, police spokesman, Francis Musonda, declined to talk about the detention saying "it is already in court".

Amnesty International, however, called for the detainees to receive a fair and prompt trial in accordance with international standards.

It said it was also aware that police were seeking to make further arrests and was concerned that there might also be political motives as what happened in 1993 when several UNIP members were wrongfully detained in connection with The Zero Option.

And the Barotse cultural Association at a mass rally by opposition parties on Saturday condemned the detentions.

"Chiluba can't respect any traditional leadership because he does not know where he comes from," charged BCA publicity secretary, Mutungulu Wangu. "Kaunda never hid his background that is why he respected traditional rulers."


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Donors Hailed For 'Withdrawing' Aid The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Mervin Syafunko and Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition parties have praised the donor community for withholding aid to Zambia and are now calling for frontline states to close their borders to government traffic and bar delegations from attending regional conferences until good governance is upheld.

This agreement was announced at a mammoth rally attended by eight political parties near Kafue round-about on Saturday. The rally, which had police mounting the largest security operation in the political history of the country, saw 700 paramilitary police officers, a hundred of whom were armed, 14 on horseback and two supporting helicopters monitoring the proceedings on the ground. 

"We mounted this operation to protect them and to show anyone with ill intentions that they cannot do so," Wynter Kabwiku, officer commanding Lusaka Division said, adding: "We have been liaising with the organisers of this rally."

Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) did not attend but its Eastern Province Senator, Andrew Banda, who attended in his individual capacity apologised for the party.

Banda wished he had traveled to Lusaka earlier to convince other leaders about the importance of unity.

In a joint opposition statement read by Liberal Progressive Front chairman, Rodger Chongwe, said: "We salute the donor community for finally heeding the calls of the oppressed people of Zambia, that they prefer to live in abject poverty as is the case now than under a donor funded dictatorial oligarchy.

"We call upon the front line states to close their borders to Zambian government traffic and ostracise its delegations to regional conferences until the government is seen to be upholding the principles of good governance that brought them into power."

The opposition also said they would not honour the newly amended constitution until it was adopted by a constituent assembly and a National Referendum or else the 1996 elections be held under the 1991 constitution.

They also demanded for the immediate re-registration of voters and that the one done by Nikuv Computers Limited of Israel be ignored.

They also demanded for an independent electoral commission whose composition should be accepted by all parties.

"We challenge the constitutionality of the Public Order (Amendment) Act, 1996 and demand its immediate repeal," resolved the parties.

They also expressed displeasure at the provocative adverts made by government leaders in the public media.

It was also decided that police should not superintend the elections and that no MMD cadre should be recruited in the police service.

At the beginning of the rally police officers, mostly youthful recruits who were commanded to surround the assemblage met with overpowering resistance prompting their commanders to withdraw them to Kafue Road side.

UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda, disturbed by the police, took it upon himself to talk to the commanding officers.

Addressing the crowd former president Kaunda demanded to know who was selling copper and cobalt for ZCCM since the closure of MEMACO and why President Chiluba was clinging to the Gabon and the Mukwela Rail Disaster reports.

"What does he want to do with those reports? See now another rail disaster has occurred in Kapiri Mposhi, we must know what is causing these accidents," Kaunda demanded.

He said under any circumstance he would face and defeat President Chiluba in the elections and that would be when the President would account for the "sins" of his government.

All the leaders present at the rally condemned the detention of the UNIP leaders.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Donor Aid Withdrawal Not Affecting Privatisation Agency The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Operations of the Zambia Privatisation Agency (ZPA) will not be affected by the withdrawal of donor aid, assured its chief executive, Valentine Chitalu, in an interview on Friday.

Chitalu said the agency, which has been supported by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), would be able to sustain its operations from the present funds collected from the sale of companies. 

"The programme is sufficiently advanced to be able to sustain the privatisation of state enterprises if the donors were to withdraw their aid now ," said Chitalu. "But donor aid has been of great help to us."

Chitalu also disclosed that the agency was expecting two more trading groups , along the lines of the Shoprite chain, to open up shops in the country. But he could not disclose which country they were coming from. It is, however, believed that the two are South African chains.

Chitalu announced that Choma Milling had been sold to A B Georgitsis and R.L Musenge of Nshima Milling at a price of K1 billion. An initial deposit of K450 million, being 45 per cent of the purchase price, has been paid to the Privatisation Revenue Account.

The balance of K550 million, or 55 per cent, will be paid over a period of six months.

ZPA has also sold Kabwe Industrial Fabrics, a 100 per cent state owned enterprise manufacturing a variety of industrial packaging materials, to Tate and Lyle, a UK based multinational corporation.

Mulungushi Sawmilling and Joinery of Kitwe has been bought by Lusaka's former mayor Fisho Mwale and Siteke Mwale at K300 million. A 20 per cent deposit has been paid while the balance will be paid in a period of three months

Zambia Constitution Aimed At Kaunda The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Fred M'membe (Column)


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - And President Chiluba has told many lies to many people about his constitution.

The President lied to the country's cooperating partners that he was not going to assent the Constitution (Amendment) Bill. 

And the more MMD leaders tried to justify the clause requiring one's parents to have been born in Zambia to qualify for presidency the more their deceit that the clause was not aimed at UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda was laid bare.

MMD members of parliament and cadres celebrated when the Bill was passed that former president Kaunda has been blocked. "Kaunda alala, Kaunda alala...," was the MMD slogan in, and outside Parliament.

President Chiluba has, in many ways, argued that Kaunda has had his fair chance of ruling Zambia and should be stopped, clearly indicating that the presidential clause, although affecting many other citizens, was primarily targeted at Kaunda.

But the presidential clause is not the only unacceptable thing about President Chiluba's constitution. There are many other clauses, including the mode of adoption, that still require consensus.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Channel Africa Faces Closure The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 7, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - South African journalists have launched a national and international campaign to forestall the impending closure of South Africa's state funded external shortwave broadcasting station, Channel Africa.

A member of the committee set up to spear head the campaign, Promise Lekalake, said in a telephone interview from Johannesburg yesterday that the overwhelming majority of journalists in South Africa favour the continuation of the station as it is viewed as a national asset.

"It is regretful that an organisation like Channel Africa which was so active in promoting and developing understanding of South Africa's position in Africa has to be the subject of closure," Lekalake carped. 

According to Lekalake, Channel Africa "reigned supreme during the apartheid era" and wondered why it should be closed now. "It is sending wrong messages," Lekalake said. "It boils down to politics."

And, in a press statement sent to The Post , SABC radio chief executive, Govin Reddy, observed that Channel Africa is a comprehensive and authentic African communications forum which serves Africa from Africa.

"It is totally objective and credible and reliable. It is dedicated to the promotion of positive development in Africa and is committed to the enhancement of dialogue and co-operation between all African people as their channel of goodwill," Reddy said.

South African foreign affairs minister, Alfred Nzo, announced last month that the station would be closed as no provisions for funds had been made in his ministry's budget for 1996/97.

Channel Africa was first established in 1966 as Radio RSA but repositioned itself as Channel Africa in 1992.

At present, the station has an estimated 15 million regular listeners and broadcasts in three Southern African languages (Chinyanja, Silozi and Xitsonga), one East African language (Kiswahili) , as well as in English, French and Portuguese.

And, according to Lekalake, the station employs several foreign journalists, among them Zambians.

Cabinet is meeting next week to put a seal to the decision.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Airport Security Tightened


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - Security at the Lusaka International Airport has been tightened following last Thursday's bomb blast in which a policeman was killed.

Plain clothes policemen, some wearing National Airports Corporation identity tags were seen milling around the airport premises especially the main terminal building in which the explosion occurred. 

By Friday afternoon the debris had not yet been cleared and the toilet in which the explosion occurred was still barricaded and guarded.

Superintendent Ordon Banda, a police bomb disposal expert died in the explosion last Thursday after tampering with the device.

Banda was one of the officers who had been sent to Angola to participate in the peace-keeping mission following a cease fire in that country.

"He had just returned from a peace-keeping operation in Angola where he was for about one year," said his father, Makalipeni Banda, in an interview yesterday.

Banda, 45 , joined the police force in 1970 and is survived by a wife Florence, and five children. Burial takes place tomorrow.

And the condition of the other officer, Paul Ngoma, who was injured in the blast is said to be improving.

University Teaching Hospital(UTH) public relations manager, Don Mwape, was quoted on Saturday as having said "Ngoma was out of danger".

Police Inspector General Francis Ndhlovu has since disclosed that police have acquired highly sophisticated bomb disposal equipment.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Historical Meeting of African Chiefs of Staff


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa) June 7, 1996 by A Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Chiefs of Staff of state members of the OAU central organ, met in early June at Africa Hall in what Secretary General Salim described as an 'eloquent illustration' of their commitment to fight 'the scourge of conflicts and instability in Africa and to promote peace and understanding on the continent.' Noting that it was the first of such gatherings, Dr. Salim reflected that since its inception in 1963, the founding fathers of the OAU, regarded peace as a 'sine que non for development and human progress.' 

It was the coming to an end of the Cold War that induced Africa to 're-think' as Dr. Salim put it, its place in the new world order. In July 1990, African heads of state met at their twenty- sixth session in Addis Ababa and adopted a new declaration. The 'fundamental changes taking place in the world and Africa's response' declaration, saw African leaders committing themselves to close cooperation to bring about peace and resolution of conflicts within Africa. In doing so Dr. Salim said, African leaders reconciled themselves to the reality that Africa would only be credible in the eyes of the African people and of the International Community when it took the lead in resolving its own problem.

Brigadier-General Hashim Mbita of Tanzania and Major General Opaleye of Nigeria, first and second commander of the OAU force in Rwanda, were present during the meeting. Also present was the commander of the military component of the OAU mission in Burundi.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Business and Finance European Community Increases Resources To Ethiopia


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa) June 7, 1996 by A Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Delegation of the European Commission has announced that over the next five years resources consisting entirely of grants will be 294 MECU, or US $370 million dollars. This marks an increase from the period 1990 - 95 which was 214 MECU. A press release said the increase bears witness to the European Commission's desire to "maintain the privileged relationship with Ethiopia and contrasts with the general contraction of both bilateral and multilateral aid."

The release added that a programming mission is anticipated to visit Ethiopia to discuss the use of the funds. The charge d'affaires of the Delegation announced this agreement in a meeting with Prime Minister Meles Zenawi on May 22.

Business and Finance Ethiopia Signs Cooperation Pact with Austria


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa) June 7, 1996 by A Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Addis Ababa - In a visit to Austria, meeting with the president and deputy chancellor, Ethiopian Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin signed an economic cooperation agreement with Austria. Ato Seyoum told reporters that the agreement was meant to enhance cooperation in economy, trade, education, tourism and science.

The foreign minister also met with the Austrian foreign and economic cooperation ministers. Ato Seyoum said that the Austrian business community has shown interest in investing in Ethiopia.

He also visited Algeria where he met the president, prime minister and foreign minister. Ato Seyoum said delegations from both Austria and Algeria have plans to visit Ethiopia by the middle of next year.

June, 1996


Ethiopia Teachers Group Protests Detentions


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa) June 7, 1996 by A Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Addis Ababa - On returning from a working tour in Europe, Dr. Taye Woldesemiate, President of the Ethiopian Teachers Association (ETA) was arrested on arrival at Bole International Airport last Thursday. Dr. Taye had, during his tour, talked about human rights conditions in Ethiopia. He is at present being detained at the Central Investigation Bureau's prison according to the ETA. 

On June 4, the association drafted a letter to Prime Minister Meles Zenawi. The letter appealed for 'urgent action against violation of ETA's Constitutional rights'. ETA noted that to date, it has written a total of 1098 letters to various government offices, including to the TGE's president and prime minister. None of these have received a response.

ETA's appeal to the prime minister centered on the 'repeated detention of teachers' elected representatives by government officials', 'illegal take over of ETA offices and facilities...', 'violation of the right to assemble' and 'the freezing of the bank account of teachers' welfare fund.'

The letter referred to other grievances such as the search of Dr. Taye's home and office as well as his father's home, last March.

The Association put forward four demands, to the prime minister. Included was the unconditional release of its president, Dr. Taye.

Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia The Rights of the Child


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa) June 7, 1996 by Tamrat Bekele (Editorial)


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - Reliable estimates indicate that one in every 5 children under the age of fifteen in Ethiopia lives under extremely difficult circumstances. Such children are victims of a variety of factors including abject poverty, rapid urbanization, drought and famine, and armed conflicts. These children are constantly exposed to physical danger, exploitation, and all forms of abuse.

The Convention on the Rights of the Child, which the Ethiopian Government has ratified, defines children's rights and services to which they are entitled as survival, protection, development and participation in social activities. It provides a set of universally accepted standards for their well-being and provides a legal framework which society can use to measure their progress in the protection, survival and development of the children. The Convention pays special attention to children in especially difficult circumstances and calls for concerted action by governments and inter-governmental agencies to address the problems facing these highly vulnerable groups.

Ethiopia is yet to formulate legislation to protect the rights of the child. We hope our legislators have the rights of the child legislation in their high priority list.

In the meantime the police, and the kebele representatives should be educated on the rights of the child. Here in Addis, we have seen street children given harsh treatment by the police. We raise our voice against this abuse. We appeal to all concerned, especially to Region 14 and the Police Commissioner, to address this issue as soon as possible.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia Country First In Jailed Journalists


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa) June 7, 1996 by A Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Addis Ababa - Figures given by the Reporters Sans Frontiers Newsletter for May 1996, have indicated that Ethiopia now ranks first, equal with China, in the number of journalists in prison. The newsletter reads that on April 1996, one hundred and three journalists were imprisoned around the world; Ethiopia and China hold 17 each. 

These statistics are said to be based on infringements of the right to inform and be informed. The newsletter states that " In 1995, fifty-one journalists were killed in the course of their work or because of their opinion (compared to 103 in 1994 and 59 in 1993). Three-quarters died on the African continent, mostly in Algeria. At least 386 journalists were imprisoned for at least 48 hours in 1995 because of their profession or their opinions, mainly in Asia (China, Burma, Vietnam), Africa (Ethiopia, Nigeria, Cote d'Ivoire) and North Africa and the Middle East (Syria, Algeria, Tunisia).

The Reporters Sans Frontiers Newsletter is a monthly publication produced with the support of the European Commission.

June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: We'll Qualify, Assures Goalie The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 7, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - National team goalkeeper James Phiri has predicted that Zambia will pull through the Sudan hurdle and qualify to the next stage of the Africa qualifying series for the 1998 World Cup.

"Sudan is a very tough team and the game will be tough, but we shall still qualify. We cannot afford to lose to them twice especially that we lost in the away game," said Phiri in an interview at the Hotel Intercontinental in Lusaka yesterday shortly after the team arrived from Sudan.

Phiri, who acted as the team's skipper in the Sudan match, observed that no excuses could be made over Zambia's 2-0 defeat in Sudan.

"Sudan just outplayed us, they are actually a better team than we expected," said Phiri.

But national team trainer, Roald Poulsen refused to give any comments on the match nor his plans for the return match.

"I do not want to talk on the game because we need time to rest before we start talking. But what I can say is that we shall resume training on Sunday and all players that played in Sudan will not play for their clubs this weekend," said Poulsen.

And John Fashanu, Zambia's soccer agent for management, arrived with the national team yesterday.

Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Shelter-Afrique Unveils $100 Million Plans Zambian News Agency June 11, 1996 by Stephen Kazeze


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Istanbul - Shelter-Afrique, the housing company owned by 37 African countries which include Zambia, launched a continental housing investment programme here on Monday.

In this scheme the company plans to spend US$100 million over the next five years in various projects centred mostly in urban areas.

Shelter-Afrique, which is also owned by the African Development Bank, African Reinsurance Corporation and the Commonwealth Development Corporation said in a statement after the launching that the new initiative was designed to lure additional private sectore and international resources to achieve a significant impact on post-Istanbul efforts. 

Istanbul efforts refers to the UN second conference on Human Settlements (Habitat two) being held here where it has been agreed that housing is a right to everyone in the world and that every effort should be made to ensure everybody in the world is adequately housed.

The Nairobi headquartered firm oversees the design and implementation of some 60 projects in member states the statement said.

It further said in the last 10 years, Shelter-Afrique co- financed shelter and related projects in several countries including Zambia.

These projects which were financed through loans were targetted at low income and middle income households and had helped thousands of families in African cities, it said.

And a group of donor countries and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) plan to launch a US$10 million project development sector in the urban services infrastructure in developing countries.

The UNDP said that the project development facility to be launched on Wednesday would be used to identify, design and implement 50 projects in cities worldwide over a five-period.

It said the initiative was a response to the call by the habit conference here for member states and organisations to make concrete commitments to be implemented in the framework of the global plan of action.

Source: ZAMTODAY-MIBS

322 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambian University Students Praised The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Lucy Sichone (Column)


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Lusaka - Congratulations to UNZASU and the student body for preserving the integrity of the history of the University of Zambia as the depository of the last resort of ideals and principles of equality, liberty and fraternity.

It was with a sense of total despair that I received the news of a planned solidarity march to State House by students for the purpose of celebrating the enactment of the MMD constitution.

The immoral procession was a betrayal of student ideals and sacrifice for the common good across the world. The Chinese students massacred in cold blood in Tianamen Square for demanding rights such as those taken away from Zambians by the MMD, Steve Biko, civil rights movements of the sixties at universities in America. 

Nearer home Ronald Penza, Super SAP Capitalist, sacrificed his government scholarship and worked his way through university by demanding of the UNIP government that they close the French Embassy for selling arms to apartheid South Africa.Betrayal of the ideals of Justice and Fair Play came with his job as an MMD politician.

Derick Chitala's ideals as a student made him an architect of the Garden House Meeting - his vision only became clouded when he became a Minister in the MMD government.

Azwell Banda sacrificed ten years of his life working as an unqualified school teacher and only completed his degree as an old man rather than apologise to KK as was required of him which would have destroyed the standing of UNZA as a custodian of community ideals.

Caine Mweemba is living in a servants quarter in order to uphold the history of the student movement in the world as the vanguard in the never ending struggle for justice.

There are many others whose names are not known but who have sacrificed the hope of a lustrous career because as students they chose to stand for justice.

The duty of the University as the custodian of community ideals cannot be sold for 30 pieces of silver in the manner that the 16 or so Judas Iscariots who marched to State House did. Those students are intelligent enough to appreciate the fact that the Republican Constitution is not an MMD issue. And the best they could have done in their exercise of their constitutional right to free association would have been to join Chawinga and company in the dance at State House on May 28.

In a country such as ours, in which Parliament has been corrupted, we can survive; the judiciary has been emasculated and we stagger on; Francis Ndlovhu is a political stooge who is doing everything possible to destroy the police service but sooner rather than later he will answer for it and the Police Service will continue.

But a nation cannot survive the corruption of its University as clearly evidenced by the Rwandan experience where the privileged Tutsi university students rioted against the democratically elected Hutu President in that country's first free and fair elections.

It was that unjust action by the students that ignited the tragedy that is Rwanda today, the genocide of 2 million people which included almost the entire student body and effectively sounded the death knell of a nation.

It was with Rwanda in mind that on Saturday morning, I went to my favourite newspaper vendor. I returned home to view my certificate at it's usual pride of place, a proud Zambian and UNZA graduate. My children are looking after their today and tomorrow against those politicians that would seek to cheapen the proud history of UNZA, by enlisting students to support injustice and division that can only point to the death of a nation.

But I notice that UNZA and Zambia is safe.

I salute you all.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


323 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Zambian University Students Attack Officers The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 10, 1996 by Kunda Mwila


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lusaka - Paramilitary officers were on Sunday morning clobbered by University of Zambia (UNZA) students.

A mob of irate UNZA students stoned several paramilitary officers and detained four others in the wake of confusion which has rocked the Great East Road campus since June 7 when 22 pro-MMD students marched to State House in support of the constitutional amendments.

The paramilitary officers were deployed at the rooms of students who had gone to State House, a move which students perceived as "intimidation by government". 

President Chiluba was reported as having assured the students who went to State House protection.

But the paramilitary officers officers were forced out of the residential area and in the confusion a woman officer was severely beaten and disarmed.

Several paramilitary officers were severely injured and had to run for their lives.

And even after burning the belongings of 9 of the 22 MMD activists, students have vowed that they will not allow those students who went to State House to enter campus again.

"We are not going to allow any of them to enter the campus again," declared a group of students. "If anyone attempts to come, he or she will be burnt to death." president Emmanuel Tembo said in an interview yesterday the MMD cadres had offended all the other students whose good name they had attempted to tarnish.

"The offence of binding the whole student body to the statement that it was in favour of the constitution has been committed on all students," Tembo said, "and it is only them who will decide whatever punishment to impose on all those who marched to State House."

Tembo also claimed that most of the people who marched to State House were street vendors mobilised by MMD.

Top in the group of the students who marched to State House are UNZA MMD Henry Malikyama who is also a relative of President Chiluba's private secretary Fabian Mumba, Bruno Lungu, George Chilengwe, Daudeni Phiri, Faith Kolala, Victor Tembo, chairperson for UNZA MMD ladies Martha Mwansa, Sandra Sisya (Zelu). Several MMD documents and campaign materials were found in their rooms.

And UNZASU vice president Joseph Munsanje dismissed the allegations by the pro-MMD group leader Henry Malikyama that students who were against their solidarity march are being used by the opposition and said students were are not divided on the constitution as it has been portrayed in the government owned and controlled media.

"What MMD should know is that UNZASU has been operating even before the opposition parties came into being and it has its own way of reacting to issues," Musanje said in an interview yesterday. "The student populace is not in support of the constitution as can be seen by their reaction."


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


324 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Arts Review: South Africa's Piano Men


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Gwen Ansell


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Johannesburg - The waiter at the Time Square Cafe in Yeoville is a little startled when Sean Fourie and Paul Hanmer suddenly lean across the jumble of crumbs and crockery on the table and hug one another.

Both pianists have recently completed their first major jazz recording projects. In Hanmer's case, it was the album Unofficial Language, with Peter Sklair and Ian Herman; in Fourie's, a leaderless collaboration, Jaci Dazz, with Valencia Ferlito and a whole bunch of others -- probably South Africa's first homegrown acid jazz album.

We're about half-way through the interview, in an intense patch of discussion, and the two players are emphasising how, despite growing up separately, their lives in jazz have brought them inexorably to more or less the same place. 

Which is two thirtysomethings sitting over coffee cups, contemplating an uncertain musical future.

Fourie is big, blonde and cherubic, with the kind of easy looks that belong on the rugby- field, not crouched over a piano. Hanmer is slim, dark and ascetic, with the intensity of a tight-coiled spring. Yet the two have a lot in common -- starting with around two decades each in music.

Hanmer, in Crawford in the Cape, followed his three sisters to piano lessons: "I'd heard the youngest playing Bach, and I really got into that music, alongside the jazz, classical and big-band records that my parents loved to play. But when I started lessons, it wasn't so easy. The guys I went to school with would be hanging around on the corner as I sneaked past, whistling and jeering: 'Ya! Mozart!'"

The boys on the corner weren't the only obstacle. Hanmer gigged in amateur and later professional bands -- with The Sapphires, Taliep Peterson and others -- and began studying for a BMus degree. He quit as an escape from family pressures. "My dad wanted me to switch to teaching, so that I'd have something to fall back on. But by then, I was so committed to music that I didn't want a fall- back."

Fourie breaks in: "Whereas my dad wouldn't let me have anything to fall back on. If I was going to go for music, I had to make it." Dad, of course, is highly respected guitarist Johnny Fourie. "So," says Fourie, "I never really had a choice. Dad would come in late and play John Coltrane till 5am when I was just waking up to go to school. I lived and breathed music."

School for Fourie stopped in standard six, after an incident involving an apoplectic, cricket-bat wielding, Afrikaans teacher. "I wasn't going to take that kind of treatment, and my dad backed me up. So I stayed home and practised, with the sons of his friends. But we weren't serious yet: sometimes we'd break off practice just to rush out and play cowboys and indians."

A series of teen and 20s bands -- Fragile Express, Adverse Edition -- ended for Fourie with chart success for a song called The Scheme of Things, which went to number one on Radio 5. He confesses that his stage name at that point was Sean Fury, and we all commiserate.

Both pianists want to kick against the musical barriers which South African history has set up. When Hanmer landed in Johannesburg in 1987, "I initially saw it as a relaxed and open place. Then I found out about how segregated jazz music was -- not just in the obvious way, but segregated from resources and from exposure." Fourie agrees: "We've been kept down, and we've been kept apart." Hanmer: "The system divides you even from yourself." Cue for hug.

Both albums represent a rejection of the lowest-common-denominator approach of the South African music industry. Unofficial Language, says Hanmer, is "a gesture to the unacknowledged many, to the culture that's been buried". Is it political music? "No. In an unassuming way, we're just making music that could only have been born here. But at the same time, it's modern music. The record companies still have an anthropologist's view of the place, which only leaves room in jazz for the historic or the quaint."

And Fourie adds: "People here are doing really hip, world-class things with three-chord structures, but they're not getting the support to take those ideas in new directions. On Jaci Dazz we took a listenable, commercial, new feel, but over that everybody improvised to express their own individual voices. Each song had an organic growth into its own completeness, without a record executive telling us what to do."

And a dream for the future? For both, it's writing a movie soundtrack. For Hanmer, the appeal lies in "the discipline of writing to an image on deadline". Fourie breaks in impishly: "And you get to put the most far-out sounds in, and the audience has to listen."


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


325 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large UN Warns Of Worsening Global Urban Crisis


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by John Vidal


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Istanbul - They are calling it the "brown agenda" -- the search for ways through the murky soup of poverty, homelessness, pollution and deprivation afflicting the world's ever- expanding cities. It is a priority for the United Nations city summit, Habitat II, which opened in Istanbul on June 3.

The scale and depth of the global urban crisis, says the official conference report, is far greater than previously thought. And it is steadily worsening as huge urbanisation takes place throughout Africa, Asia and Latin America. 

Wally N'Dow, head of the conference, said: "A low-grade civil war is being fought every day in the world's urban centres. Big numbers are risking their lives every day. Many cities are collapsing. We must wake up to the fact that it is no longer business as usual.

"Urbanisation is bringing about one of the most significant transformations in history. The problems are staggering." There are now more than 600-million people officially homeless or living in life-threatening urban conditions. More than a billion lack sanitation and a further 250-million have no easy access to safe water.

He said: "The overwhelming speed at which the world is urbanising leaves little time to adapt. We are witnessing daily urban catastrophes. Youth is going to seed. Drugs are rampant in cities. Crime and terrorism are increasing. We risk a complete breakdown in cities. People feel alienated everywhere."

Governments, local authorities and citizen groups were told in Istanbul that declining resources, growing competition, food scarcity and environmental problems will set the agenda for cities in the next 50 years.

Most urban centres in the developing world will face extreme water shortages within 15 years, threatening life and health, N'Dow warned. "More than one billion people cannot get clean drinking water. Dirty water causes 80% of diseases in the developing world."

The UN report says one of the main reasons for the rapid deterioration in world cities in the past decade is structural adjustment programmes imposed by the International Monetary Fund. These, it is said, have increased poverty, homelessness and unemployment in more than 50 countries, including some of the poorest in the world.

Structural adjustment programmes were devised in the 1980s after the international debt crisis. They have demanded that developing countries privatise and deregulate industries, cut public spending and reduce or eliminate health and education subsidies.

The report says: "In most countries undergoing structural adjustment, large numbers of people have lost what had been relatively stable jobs.

"One of the effects in the south has been to cut public spending and to reduce budgetary deficits. The cuts are usually in sectors not considered as priority or core productive sectors, which in many cases included human settlements."

But the blame is put on the rich for much of what N'Dow calls "the emerging anarchy" in the world's cities. He criticised the United States and other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries for not accepting that people have a right to adequate housing and blamed liberalisation of trade and the activities of multinational corporations for accelerating urbanisation.

"The world's aid agencies and development banks mostly give low priority to what is being called the brown agenda of sanitation, housing, air pollution and waste, which adversely affect the poor most," he said.

The report paints an alarming picture of growing crime accompanying urbanisation. "The process of urbanisation goes hand in hand with a rise in urban violence that outstrips the growth of cities," said a UN adviser on urban poverty in a parallel report presented to the conference.

'Violence is the product of a society characterised by inequality and social exclusion. The offender has often been stimulated by a social environment dominated by consumerism, competition and by the mass media, which propagate and legitimise violence," said Franz Vanderschuren.

According to studies in the US, watching violence encourages aggressive behaviour, increases violence and desensitises viewers. Research suggests that by the time a child leaves a US school, she or he will have seen 100 000 violent acts and 16 000 murders on TV. The annual cost of urban decay due to violence in the US is estimated at $50-billion.

Highlighting the fact that urban decay has been accelerating while the numbers of young people in cities has been growing rapidly, the report says that about two-thirds of the rapidly growing urban population in Africa is now made up of the nought to 25 age group.

It warns of the social and political risks in having very large numbers of "unoccupied and very frustrated" young people. One of the contributors to the report says that cities are increasingly prone to politicised urban violence, fundamentalist or mafiosi activities.

The UN was told that at least once every five years 60% of people living in cities with more than 100 000 people are victims of crime. Most urban crime is committed by the young against property.

The report says that between 30% and 60% of all housing in most developing country cities is now illegal, with more than 75% of homes in cities such as the Kenyan capital Nairobi, and the Bangladeshi capital Dhaka, built without permission.

The UN's city summit was not recommending giving more power to governments or new money to alleviate the problems of urbanisation, but a shift in decision-making to citizen groups and local authorities.

"It's a call for partnerships," said N'Dow. But not many heads of state attended the conference.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


326 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance A New Helping Hand For South Africa's Poor


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Peter Roussos


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Johannesburg - Scepticism about lending to the poor is not confined to the corridors of banking. Few people believe that the poor, with virtually no jobs or income, no banking history or collateral, and no track record of repayment, could develop successful enterprises, pay back loans, and generate enough loan volume to be able to build successful institutions.

But the Ecumenical Development Co-operative Society (EDCS) has succeeded where many others have failed: it boasts a 90% recovery rate after 21 years of operation and loan loss provision of 20% of outstanding balances.

Arguably one of the world's most successful lending organisations that targets the poor, and one of the only institutions in the sector with an average loan size of US$250 000, EDCS is soon to open its doors in South Africa, with Zanele Mbeki, former head of the Women's Development Bank in South Africa and wife of Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, on its international board. 

On a fact-finding trip, Gert van Maanen, EDCS general manager, met South African players, including Cas Coovadia of the Community Bank, Zanele Mbeki and the Reverend Peter Story. They agreed a reference group should be set up. The next step will be to recruit the EDCS branch manager in South Africa.

Over the past 15 years, numerous organisations such as the EDCS, the Grameen Bank, Accion International, BankoSol and Bank Rakyat have revolutionised the concept of lending to the poor. Loan sizes vary from a few dollars in the case of Grameen (average loan size of $75) to $250 000 in the case of EDCS.

The common thread is that the loans are repaid; the institutions are viable, and the sector is growing.

How can these institutions lend profitably to the poor, despite the absence of almost all the four "C's" traditionally required by the commercial banking sector: collateral, capital, character and capacity?

The EDCS was founded in 1975 to mobilise financial credit and resources from the First World to aid development of the third world. It is not an aid agency -- it mobilises the institutional savings of the churches and the individual savings of church members and invests them in selected business ventures that have the potential to repay these loans with interest.

The majority of the bank's clients are groups, mostly co-operatives, rather than individuals. The bank finances productive investments that lead to sustainable income-generating activities (a viable business plan is a pre- requisite).

The success of the bank (90% repayment rate over the past 20 years) is related to its policy of financing activities defined by its members (the urban and rural poor) and not schemes drawn up by overseas consultants or international donor agencies.

The activities must be within the reach of the borrowers and in line with their skills and experiences. Although collateral is seldom required, the borrowers are expected to raise a percentage of the loan amount (up to 20%) as proof of their commitment. The bank insists on ownership of the business venture by the borrowers.

EDCS emphasises the participation of women up to management level, believing that the commitment of marginalised women to the success of a business venture goes far deeper than that of their men.

The interest rate charged by EDCS is related to its cost of capital and operations. The bank charges a flat rate of 9%, comprising 2% cost of capital; 3% operating costs; and 4% loan-loss provision. The loan period is generally between five and seven years (up to a maximum of 10 years) with either one or two years' grace period for the enterprise to gain economic strength. The flexible repayment period enables the bank to allow for cases of drought or loss of harvest.

Today EDCS works with more than 250 project partners in 65 countries worldwide. The minimum loan is $50 000 and the maximum is $1- million.

Some 50% of EDCS loans have gone to agriculture or agri-related business and a growing percentage to financial intermediaries (similar to, although not including, the Community Bank of South Africa), which then on-lend the EDCS loan to their own members in smaller amounts. Since the bank opened its doors in 1975, it has disbursed nearly 120- million guilders ($62-million).


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

June, 1996


Business and Finance South African Business Barometer


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Johannesburg - Confidence index drops. The 0,4% drop in last month's business confidence index compiled by the South African Chamber of Business (Sacob), came as no surprise, given the economic slowdown and negative implications of the interest-rate hike.

Sacob said the worsening business sentiment was being reinforced by a "perceived inability of government to show sufficient leadership in respect of key policy issues". Sacob has cut its economic forecast for the year by a half percentage point to 3,1%, but does not expect the weaker rand to impact too severely on inflation. Its forecast for the year is little changed from the original 8% year's average. 

* Johnnies Industrial Corporation is teaming up with United States-based Conrad International Hotels Corporation to pursue a casino licence application for a R1,5-billion mega-gaming complex planned on 19 hectares of land adjacent to Gallagher Estate's conference centre.

Russel Jackson, general manager of Johnnic's commercial property division, said the company had negotiated an option to acquire 51% of Riccia Property Holdings, owner of Gallagher Estate, conditional on obtaining a licence. "In partnership with black business interests and Conrad International, we plan to establish an international hotel, entertainment and exhibition complex on the enlarged site," he said.

*ABSA gets cold feet - AMALGAMATED Banks of South Africa has put on ice plans to tap the London capital market, crucial to its offshore expansion plans. Spokesman Alec Hogg said the decision stemmed from the rand's plunge and the negative perception of South Africa, which had been spurred by "certain immature and ignorant statements on the SA economy".

*BB rating for SA - London-based credit rating agency IBCA has left South Africa's long-term foreign currency rating as BB, a non- investment rating. The IBCA said the rating applied to senior and unsecured long-term government debt securities, and acted as a ceiling to IBCA ratings for other South African issuers.

The foreign currency rating compared with that of Mexico's and was better than the rating for Romania, IBCA said.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Final Lap For Mossgas Sale


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Johannesburg - The privatisation of Mossgas will enter the final lap this month when the deadline for interested buyers passes on June 14.

Government and the merchant banks handling the sale hope to find a buyer by October. While they sift through the offers, they will pin an order of priority to sale price, jobs, foreign exchange savings and other sale "criteria".

But despite the expense of hiring merchant banks and advisers to steer the sale there remain some government officials close to the process who are not keen for Mossgas to be sold.

They want Mossgas to become part of a national oil company, Sanoco, which would also include Engen, Sasol Oil and Mossgas's sister company, state exploration group Soekor.

Although the Sanoco backers, who reside in the finance and trade and industry departments, have touched on the plans with the companies involved, there has so far been no open debate about the merits of a national oil company. It was never stated as policy by Minerals and Energy Affairs Minister Pik Botha.

Sasol said last month it had "had dialogue" with government about Sanoco.

329 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Judgment Day For Restructuring


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Madeleine Waskernagel


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Johannesburg - Government is finally realising that actions speak louder than words. Within two weeks South Africa should not only have a growth plan in place but also firm proposals for the restructuring of state assets -- three years after the African National Congress made privatisation official policy.

On Wednesday, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki is due to present his long-awaited growth plan, as foreshadowed at the intergovernmental conference in February. Three days later, ministers will meet labour representatives to thrash out a detailed policy for state sell-offs. With the basic guidelines in place, they will consider each industry and how best to go about transforming individual companies. At the same time, the government will announce its team of advisers. 

The going may not be easy, however. Cosatu is sticking to its guns, says representative Nowetu Mpati. "We are completely against privatisation, and remain so until we see the data to convince us that it can be done without significant job losses."

But other union representatives believe a softening of Cosatu's stance is possible. "We can no longer afford to put ideology before the good of the country. Even Cosatu must understand that," said one official.

Increased openness has contributed to this view. "The new approach of consultation and transparency has gone a long way to clearing the air. It is no longer a question of them and us."

Despite the new pragmatism, the issue of job losses still looms large. Says Colin Smith, privatisation co-ordinator and bi-lateral task-team negotiator for Fedsal: "We fully support a case-by-case approach to privatisation; we cannot take a blanket decision to sell off every state asset. But we have to use partnerships, joint ventures and retraining to minimise, if not totally avoid, any job cuts."

This view is echoed by Professor Ben Turok, an ANC MP. "Just because we believe in free- market principles does not mean we should privatise willy-nilly. The British experience is a perfect example of the dangers involved.

"Many state institutions are grossly inefficient and misdirecting resources. We have to make sure the taxpayer is not subsidising inefficient use of resources and some form of privatisation could help to get them back on track.

"But worries about possible job losses are valid and all the more reason for taking a case-by-case approach and acting on sound economic principles."

Professor Louise Tager, head of Transnet, is not convinced privatisation is the answer. "Where does it say that the state cannot run a business successfully? We are trying to sort things out internally, improving efficiencies and productivity.

"Certainly, some parts could be sold off, but wholesale privatisation is not a good idea. The country cannot afford it. For every job lost, up to six people lose their support system; we have to be careful not to exacerbate the already serious unemployment problem."

With most of the companies earmarked for restructuring in growth industries such as telecommunications, tourism and airlines, fears of job losses may be overplayed, says an analyst. So far, government has taken an ad hoc approach, forging ahead with little consultation and even less focus. But getting the unions on side will take more than just rhetoric and reassurances. It's up to the government to set out its objectives and make them work.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

June, 1996


United States and Africa TransAfrica Forum Announces Annual Weekend Activities


BYLINE: Transafrica Forum (Washington) June 3, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Washington, DC - On Thursday, June 6th, TransAfrica Forum will hold its Annual Fundraising Dinner at the Washington Hilton and Towers in Washington, DC. The theme for this year's dinner is "Celebrating the Cultural Traditions of Africans in the Americas".

TransAfrica Forum will present awards to the following individuals at this year's event: Dr. Camille Cosby, Global Public Service Award; Danny Glover, Arthur R. Ashe, Jr. Humanitarian Award; Bob Herbert, International Journalism Award, and The Honorable A. Leon Higginbotham, Jr., Lifetime Achievement Award. 

TransAfrica Forum and TransAfrica, Inc., have played a pivotal role in shaping U.S. foreign policy toward African and Caribbean nations. TransAfrica Forum's primary purpose has been to work for the advancement of human rights and democracy and to educate the public on U.S. policies that affect these regions of the world. Funds from the dinner are used to ensure continuation of the vital work that TransAfrica Forum performs.

Tickets are $250 per person or $2,500 per table of ten. For further information please contact TransAfrica Forum at (202) 797-2301 or fax (202) 797-2382. Tickets are also available for purchase the night of the dinner at the Washington Hilton and Towers, 1919 Connecticut Avenue, NW. The dinner will begin at 7:00pm.

The Annual Weekend will conclude with its second annual African World Day on June 8. The Saturday activities will feature the Peoples of Senegal and The Gambia, and is sponsored by the Forum's Arthur R. Ashe, Jr. Foreign Policy Library, the TransAfrica Metro DC Chapter and Black Adults of Action Section of the National Council of Negro Women. This program focusing on African history and culture will be held at the TransAfrica Forum Building, 1744 R Street, NW from 12 noon to 5:00pm. The activities will include discussions on cultural and social issues, Senegambian storytelling, musical interpretations, art and vendor exhibits, and samples of the region's cuisine. For more information contact Mwiza Munthali or Monique White at (202) 797-2301.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer South Africa: Bafana Crosses First World Cup Hurdle


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 3, 1996 by Linda Rulashe


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Bafana Bafana came out tops in their 1998 World Cup qualifier against Malawi yesterday, though the team squandered several goal opportunities.

The African Cup of Nations title holders managed only one goal during the game played in front of 60,000 soccer fans at Blantyre's Chichiri stadium. 

Captain Neil Tovey, who earned a record 37th cap yesterday, headed a strong defence with the local team holding the ball for 55 per cent of the match.

The South Africans, ranked 20th in the world, were expected to win the game against the 113th-ranked Malawians.

But they will face pressure to perform when they play Malawi during the second leg of the preliminary round at Johannesburg's FNB stadium on June 15.

If Bafana Bafana qualify for the preliminary round of the World Cup, they will have to play eight matches in Africa against the likes of Ghana and Nigeria. The World Cup takes place in France in two years' time.

SY LERMAN reports from Blantyre that South African coach Clive Barker said after the match: "We should have buried them. We should have had at least four goals and made the second leg a formality."

The game's solitary goal was scored in the 21st minute by midfielder Eric Tinkler after man-of-the-match John "Shoes" Moshoeu had mesmerised the Malawian defence with a deft dummy.

Africa has been allocated five of the 32 places for the 1998 finals in France.

Source - The Sunday Times, Johannesburg

June, 1996


Zambia Opposition Plans Fight Over Black Mamba


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 4, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - UNIP chairman Malimba Masheke yesterday said his party was planning a combination of mass demonstrations, rallies and court action to fight government attempts to link UNIP to the shadowy Black Mamba organisation.

"We want to organise the people because no one can rule if the people don't want him to rule," Masheke said at a press briefing at Freedom House yesterday. 

Masheke reiterated that the Black Mamba scare was an MMD creation designed to facilitate the declaration of a state of emergency in the country.

"The Black Mamba is being linked to UNIP because Chiluba wants to use it to declare a state of emergency," Masheke said. "We are top UNIP members and it can't be UNIP if we don't know about it."

Masheke said UNIP had information that 31 of its members including all central committee members were due to be picked up in the continued police swoop.

Masheke also announced that opposition parties including the Zambia Democratic Congress, Liberal Progressive Front, National Party, National Democratic Alliance and others are due to share the platform this Saturday at which there will be major pronouncements on last month's inter party talks which were boycotted by MMD.

National Party chairman Edward Shamwana in a separate interview regretted the arrests of the UNIP leaders and said it was sad that the opposition could not be allowed to operate freely.

"This seems like a ploy to frighten the opposition so that it can be less vigorous in campaigning for issues," Shamwana said.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia More Opposition Leaders Arrested


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 4, 1996 by Reuben Phiri and Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Lusaka - Police, in a move seen as an attempt to paralyse the country's leading opposition party, yesterday continued to arrest senior leaders of UNIP - linking them to the 'Black Mamba'.

Amongst those arrested by yesterday is the party's vice-president, senior chief Inyambo Yeta, central committee member, former finance minister Rabson Chongo, and former president Kenneth Kaunda's special assistant, Muhabi Lungu, former Zambia Air Force officer, Capt Phangula Banda and former diplomat in Japan, George Zulu.

"We know that this is a deliberate plan by the MMD government to link all criminal activities like the Black Mamba to UNIP and especially to its president. We believe firmly that these criminal activities are contrived by the same accusers," said Muhabi Lungu on Sunday night, adding: "The intention is to create so much distrust in the nation so as to find a pretext for declaring a state of emergency." 

But the Barotse Cutural Association has condemned the detention of senior chief Inyambo and described the action as "a dastardly and cowardly act calculated to bring Lozi Cultural heritage into ridicule and contempt."

"This move is unprecedented since colonial days because a Lozi chief has never been detained. The BCA believes that the only reason why the senior chief has been detained is because he is a Lozi. The government should realise that senior chief Inyambo is not only the UNIP vice-president but also a very highly respected Lozi senior chief," the statement signed by BCA national chairman Batuke Imenda and his secretary Mutete Kashimani reads.

Police Inspector General Francis Ndhlovu announced at a press briefing in Lusaka on Sunday that police had targeted about twenty people suspected to be responsible for the recent bombings and bomb threats by the Black Mamba over the constitution amendment.

"We know them. We have some more names of people we want to arrest and it is better for them to surrender to the police," Ndhlovu warned at a press briefing on Sunday.

General Nicholas Zulu's wife Catherine, said the search at their home did not yield anything though they had charged her husband with treason.

"What treason are they talking about? They are just behaving like the Gestapo because there was nothing they found to implicate my husband," a visibly shocked Catherine, whose husband was arrested on Sunday, cried in an interview.

Chief Inyambo's wife, Moonde, also said that the search did not yield anything though the police locked up her husband.

"They came home around 04:00 hours and had a warrant which said they were looking for illegal firearms and seditious material. After they failed to find anything they drove him to his office at Freedom House where they also searched but did not find anything," narrated Moonde in an interview yesterday. "They later said they have charged him with a conspiracy to commit a felony. We don't even know what this felony is."

Zambia Civic Education Association chairperson, Lucy Sichone, charged that the arrests were an act of provocation by the government on UNIP.

"The arrests are completely unjustified and may lead into violence. All they are trying to do is to push UNIP into a situation where they will have no option but to erupt," Sichone charged.

The five arrested yesterday bring the number to nine UNIP members who have so far been arrested.

Others arrested include retired Brigadier General Joseph Chintomfwa, who also worked as director of Military Intelligence Services (MIS), ex-intelligence officer and UNIP secretary for defence, Patrick Goma, retired senior police officer and now Kenneth Kaunda's aide in charge of physical security, Morris Kaulung'ombe and another retired army officer Brigadier General Nicholas Zulu, who also worked as general manager for Mulungushi textiles in Kabwe.

The list of detainees is expected to soar with amongst those targeted for arrest being UNIP Malambo Member of Parliament and son to Kenneth Kaunda, retired Major Wezi Kaunda.

And yesterday afternoon most of those arrested were not at the places of their detention as officers indicated the detainees had been taken to force headquarters.

At Chilenje officers said Kaulung'ombe who had been detained there was taken to force headquarters just before 14hrs. At Emmasdale officers claimed gen Zulu had also been moved to the police headquarters while at Matero police officer G. Milupi referred all queries to Forece head quarters.

"I cannot help you at my level and rank. Ask the inspector general or force public relations officer Francis Musonda," Milupi said. He could not indicate whether gen Chimtomfwa was in the cells or not.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


334 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Trees Now Zambia's Endangered Species


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 4, 1996 by Staff Reporters


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - The forestry department in Petauke has within the last three weeks confiscated 15 cubic metres of illegal timber worth approximately K4.5 million.

The timber is all Mukwa, an expensive indigenous hardwood used in furniture production. 

"Due to illegal commercial cutting, Mukwa is a threatened species in Zambia," district forest officer Deuteronomy Kasaro disclosed in an interview last Friday. "With the present cutting there will be no Mukwa left in Petauke District for commercial use within five years."

But the forestry department's capacity to combat illegal mukwa cutting is highly impaired by lack of resources.

"We don't even have a vehicle but for three weeks we borrowed a truck from MS-Zambia (the Danish Association for International Cooperation), and we gained a lot from that," Kasaro said.

According to Kasaro, most of the illegal cutting is done by groups of individuals coming from other parts of Zambia.

"They camp in the bush where they find the Mukwa trees and cut them. The timber is usually transported to Lusaka by truck and from there sent out of the country, mainly to South Africa we are told," Kasaro said. "The pit-sawers themselves do not earn much but the businessmen behind get a high profit."

Mukwa is one of the most expensive types of timber in the country and a licence to cut a Mukwa tree costs around K10,000.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Sichone: US Review Overdue


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 4, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Intentions by the USA government to review its bilateral and multilateral relationship, including assistance programmes, with Zambia are long overdue, charged Lucy Sichone in Lusaka yesterday.

Sichone, chairperson of the Zambia Civic Education Association (ZCEA), claimed in an interview yesterday that the USA and other donors released funding for the Mwanakatwe Constitution Review Commission on condition that submissions would be taken back to the people for consensus. 

"The action has been long overdue in view of the blatant breach of the arrangements agreed in the contract. The Americans should set a stage for other donors," Sichone said. "They should not only stop the balance of payments support but all other form of aid to bring this government back to dialogue."

And Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace(CCJP) chairman Fr Joe Komakoma observed that "donor aid was always tied to good governance".

"If they feel that their conditions are not being fulfilled they are right to withhold the aid," Komakoma said in an interview yesterday.

Foundation for Democratic Process (FODEP) president Bishop John Mambo appealed to the donors to assist in resolving the constitutional impasse before things get out of hand.

"Donors have the capacity to do that without waiting for a situation where they are going to be bringing aid in form of bandages and ambulances when there is confusion," Mambo advised in an interview yesterday, adding: "They can use all the available means possible to bring the government back to the negotiating table on the constitution."
