336 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Post Correspondents Linked To Black Mamba


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 4, 1996 by Staff Reporters


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba's security men last Friday accused two Post Copperbelt correspondents of being members of the Black Mamba.

The two correspondents, covering the Copperbelt Agricultural Show in Kitwe, were removed from where a group of journalists from the government owned and controlled Times of Zambia and Daily Mail were gathered, claiming they were a security risk.

One security officer identified as Paggy Kalawela charged at Elias Kamanga and Brian Malama grabbing a camera and accused them of being part of the Black Mamba. 

"You guys from The Post have launched a serious campaign against President Chiluba. My instructions are that you should not get any closer to the President," Kalawela said in the presence of several other reporters from Times of Zambia and Daily Mail.

The two journalists were then pushed out of the stand President Chiluba was touring and Kalawela placed police to guard the entrance.

"We have instructions to obey and we will do just that. We have been instructed to scrutinise all reporters covering this function and as far as we are concerned you are a security risk," Kalawela charged.

But when asked why Post journalists were being discriminated, home affairs minister Chitalu Sampa, who witnessed the scene, denied there were any such instructions.

"I have no idea whatsoever of such orders, though security men have the right to block those they deem as security risks from nearing the President," Sampa said.

The scene was described as "unfortunate" by former information minister Stan Kristafor.

"I don't think members of the press can be a security risk," Kristafor said. " I hope they don't link The Post to the Black Mamba."

The government yesterday claimed they had information of a campaign to be launched by The Post and some opposition parties to discredit President Chiluba and make the country ungovernable.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


337 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Germany To Freeze Aid?


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 3, 1996


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Lusaka - The Federal Republic of Germany embassy in Lusaka is waiting for 'an appropriate' responce from Bonn on measures to take against Zambia over the wish of the people that a clause be inserted in the Constitution which will restrict the Presidency to citizens of the country.

Charge de Affairs at the Embassy, Axel Zeidler, disclosed in Lusaka today that the embassy had sent a report to Bonn recommendation that some measures be taken against the Zambian people following the enactment of a law restricting the Presidency to Zambian citizens.

"It is unfortunate that government did not listen to the concerns raised by donors over this matter," he said. 

Information and Broadcasting Minister, Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, said Government was aware of the German position and that they were still studying the statement and would issue a comprehensive statement at an appropriate time.

On Saturday the United States said it is reviewing its bilateral and multilateral relationship with Zambia, which will include development aid cuts.

US State department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, says the move has been prompted by the passing into law the Constitutional Amendments which restrict the presidency to Zambians whose ancestry was also Zambian.

"These amendments seriously threaten the intergrity and credibility of the electoral process and significantly undermine Zambia's action.

"In light of the Government of Zambia's action, the United States is reviewing its bilateral and multilateral relationship, including assistance programmes in Zambia," Mr Burns warned.

He explained tht the warm relations between his country and Zambia, and the partnership in Zambia's development, were based on the shared commitment to democracy and economic reforms.

"We have repeatedly made known to the Government of Zambia our deep concerns over these amendments and other recent actions that threaten Zambia's new democractic system.

"The United States urges the Government of Zambia to reverse its decision on the Constitutional amendments, to renew its commitment to democracy, and to take immediate steps to ensure that this year's elections are free and fair," Mr Burns said.

But reacting to the statement, Finance Minister Ronald Penza regretted the stand adopted by the US government explaining that even before President Frederick Chiluba signed the Constitutional Amendment bill he had held wide consultations with representatives of donor countries, including that of the US.

Mr Penza observed that the amendments introduced in the constitution had originated from the people and it was, therefore, regrettable that the US government was unable to respect genuine wishes of the Zambian people.

Mr Penza expressed hope that the radical stand of the US government will not be copied by other western governments now helping Zambia with funding for development programmes.

Opposition United National Independence Party president, Kenneth Kaunda, reacted with glee at the news that the US government was about to cut aid to Zambia.

Dr Kaunda, who has been among those calling for sanctions against the Zambian government, said in Lusaka that he hoped other donor countries will follow the example set by the US government and introduce similar measures too.

Others calling for cuts have been Zambia Democratic Congress President Dean Mung'omba and Liberal Progressive Front leaders.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


338 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia US State Department Threatens Aid Cuts


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 2, 1996


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - The United States is reviewing its bilateral and multilateral relationship with Zambia, which will include development aid cuts.

US State department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, says the move has been prompted by the passing into law the Constitutional Amendments which restrict the presidency to Zambians whose ancestry was also Zambian.

"These amendments seriously threaten the intergrity and credibility of the electoral process and significantly undermine Zambia's action. 

"In light of the Government of Zambia's action, the United States is reviewing its bilateral and multilateral relationship, including assistance programmes in Zambia," Mr Burns warned.

He explained tht the warm relations between his country and Zambia, and the partnership in Zambia's development, were based on the shared commitment to democracy and economic reforms.

"We have repeatedly made known to the Government of Zambia our deep concerns over these amendments and other recent actions that threaten Zambia's new democractic system.

"The United States urges the Government of Zambia to reverse its decision on the Constitutional amendments, to renew its commitment to democracy, and to take immediate steps to ensure that this year's elections are free and fair," Mr Burns said.

But reacting to the statement, Finance Minister Ronald Penza regretted the stand adopted by the US government explaining that even before President Frederick Chiluba signed the Constitutional Amendment bill he had held wide consultations with representatives of donor countries, including that of the US.

Mr Penza observed that the amendments introduced in the constitution had originated from the people and it was, therefore, regrettable that the US government was unable to respect genuine wishes of the Zambian people.

Mr Penza expressed hope that the radical stand of the US government will not be copied by other western governments now helping Zambia with funding for development programmes.

Opposition United National Independence Party president, Kenneth Kaunda, reacted with glee at the news that the US government was about to cut aid to Zambia.

Dr Kaunda, who has been among those calling for sanctions against the Zambian government, said in Lusaka that he hoped other donor countries will follow the example set by the US government and introduce similar measures too.

Others calling for cuts have been Zambia Democratic Congress President Dean Mung'omba and Liberal Progressive Front leaders.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

339 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Government To React to US Action Over Constitution


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 4, 1996


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Lusaka - Government will only react to the threatened US State Department sanctions after it is formally informed of the decision, President Frederick Chiluba said on Monday.

But Mr Chiluba hoped that the United States of America, a leading country in the world, will use its enormous clout constructively especially with regard to the Washington based Bretton Woods Institutions which are the biggest source of financial support for Zambia.

He maintained, quite firmly however, that the Zambian government is there through a popular mandate from the people of Zambia. 

"It has an unquestionable mandate. And parliament in accordance with the Constitution of Zambia has the exclusive preserve to legislate for Zambia. There has been no impropriety in the enactment of the Constitution Amendment Bill which was a matter of putting into law the legitimate wishes of the Zambian people," he said.

Adding that those Zambians who hold contrary views have all the opportunity later in the year to put their case sto the electorate.

"This is the only acceptable way in any democracy to proceed if the law of the jungle is to be avoided," He added.

The President pointed out that Zambia has since 1991 struggled to repair a severely shattered economy and Zambians have made enormous sacrifices and thanks to the very substantial support from the international donor community we have made some progress which, if sustained, will provide a sound base for sustainable economic growth.

Mr Chiluba noted that Zambians are at a critical turning point and that help from the donor community is definitely crucial if the achievements of the last four years are not to be eroded.

But he stressed that the responsibility of developing Zambia is of Zambians and other countries in the international community can only help supplement these efforts.

"Zambia will for some foreseeable future continue to have substantial resource gaps which will be difficult to bridge from the low and slow internal accumulations.

"The most appropriate reaction for Zambians to threats of curtailment of foreign aid is for us to increase our resolve to work harder. The farming community has set the tone and the performance should improve in the next crop season. There should also be more extensive use of irrigation to reduce dependence on rainfed agriculture," Mr Chiluba observed.

He declared that Zambia's committment to democracy and good governance is irrevocable. It is the only way to safeguard Zambia's future and is not a gimmick for obtaining aid.

He added that Zambians are peace loving people and we can boast of a proud record of harmony in diversity.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


340 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Women Register For Elections


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency June 1, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Two hundred Zambian women have registered with the National Women's Lobby Group so that it can help them contest the coming presidential, parliamentary and local government elections.

Former Non-Governmental Organisations Cordinating Committee Chairperson, Susan Jere, disclosed this in Lusaka last night when she appeared at the forum organised by the recently revived Zambia Media Women's Association (ZAMWA) at Pamodzi Hotel. 

Mrs Jere explained that it was important for organisations like Women's Lobby to throw their weight behind women candidates because at the moment Zambian women are at a great disadvantage.

Speaking on the theme 'Women in Politics,' Mrs Jere lamented that women politicians were greatly handicapped by a lack of resources and proper education noting that in some cases women activists failed to advance in their chosen careers because the electoral process required them to be adept at speaking English, which is the official language in Zambia.

Women politicians, she added, had no resources with which to match those of men opponents adding that Zambian politicks have been marred by corruption as candidates have to give gifts to voters if they hoped to be elected.

Mrs Jere also moaned over the party structures which stiffled women adding that in these organisations most officials were 'gender insensitive'.

She urged women to start organising for the coming elections so that at the end of the day they too can have their representatives who can fight for their own rights.

Mrs Jere, who resigned from the organisation so that she could go full time into politics, has joined the Zambia Democratic Congress and she is hoping to contest the Chawama parliamentary constitutency seat in Lusaka which is presently held by Foreign Affairs Minister, Lt-General Christon Tembo, on a Movement for Multi-Party Democracy ticket.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia 'Asians' Snub Vice President


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 3, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - Members of the Asian business community in Chipata on Friday refused to attend a meeting addressed by Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda.

A disappointed Vice-President Miyanda later pleaded with the businessmen to cooperate and support the MMD government. 

"I wish to appeal to the Asian community in the Eastern Province to support the ruling MMD and the government and co-exist with the locals here," Vice-President Miyanda pleaded.

Vice-President Miyanda said he was disappointed to note that Asian businessmen were not represented at the meeting he addressed on Friday to explain the new constitutional changes that had taken place in the country.

Last week Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) treasurer Dante Saunders challenged members of the Asian community to get up and fight for their rights and against the MMD's constitution which had down graded their citizenship to second class.

"I urge them to take an active part in the politics of this country just like their friends in Kenya, Tanzania and other parts of the world," Saunders said

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Olympics Zambia: Track Stars Shine


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 5, 1996 by Maidstone Mulenga


LENGTH: 400 words


 

New York - Three of Zambia's biggest hopes for track and field medals at this year's Olympic Games in Atlanta blazed to impressive performances in four different countries in the last few days.

Samuel Matete, Godfrey Siamusiye and Ngozi Mwanamwambwa raced to some awesome times in various competitions in the United States, Canada, Slovakia and France. 

Leading the charge was Matete who skipped past opponents to win the 400 meters hurdles in France on Monday with a time of 48.42 seconds. Matete beat Bryan Bronson, United States, 48.44; Winthrop Graham, Jamaica, 49.43; Eronildo De Araujo, Brazil, 49.56; Ken Harnden, Zimbabwe, 49.72; and Dusan Kovacs, Hungary, 49.89.

Matete's victory in France's St. Denis International Meet was 060 faster than the time he ran on Wednesday in Slovakia when he won the IAAF Slovnaft International Meet in Bratislava, Slovakia.

Back in the United States, long-distance specialist Godfrey Siamusiye led University of Arkansas to its fifth consecutive men's team win during the NCAA Track and Field Championships on Saturday and Sunday in Eugene, Oregon.

Siamusiye won the 10,000 meters race and finished second in the 5,000 meters. In one of the most impressive races on the NCAA circuit, Siamusiye edged teammate Jason Bunston at the finish to win the men's 10,000 in a thrilling race that featured three lead changes on the final lap.

A day later on Sunday, Siamusiye and Bunston finished second and third in the 5000, behind Colorado's Alan Culpepper.

Across North America in Canada, another Zambian star was working hard on the track. Mwanamwambwa was participating in the Jerome International track classic in Abbortsford, British Columbia. Mwanamwambwa, a graduate student in the United States, came third in the 400 meters race with a time of 54.21 behind Cathy Rattery-Williams of Jamaica, 52.04 and Elena Rusina of Russia, 53.45.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Stock Exchange Records Low Turnover


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 3, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - The Lusaka Stock Exchange (LuSE) has recorded a low turnover for the months of April and May.

But it is, however, showing increased participation from small investors. 

Chilanga Cement Stock Price has dropped further and the company's shares are now trading at K50, as compared to K65 last year in April.

But the LuSE May report says this drop in share price is not reflective of the general performance of the company.

The report insists that the downward pressure on the Chilanga share price is more of the result of cash trapped by first time shareholders trying to off load their shares.

"These tend to be small volume investors. To assist these investors, the LuSE has written to all Chilanga share holders individually, providing them with information on how to manage their investments and use the stock exchange," read the report.

The report also reveals that up to 540 million shares may be offered for sale by the Zambia Privatisation Trust Fund on behalf of the government through a public floatation around September.

The price earnings (PE) ratio would be 7.17 with a dividend yield of 7.75 per cent.

The Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) share price has moved up in the last few weeks to K1,900 per share. The market capitalisation of ZCCM is now the highest on LuSE at K169,663 million followed by Zambia Sugar at K108,539 million.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


344 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Politics Of Mealie Meal In Zambia


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 3, 1996 by Elais Kamanga


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - President Chiluba's assurance last Friday on the Copperbelt that the price of mealie meal will soon drop by half has been dismissed as mere politicking without any rational basis.

Addressing the Copperbelt Agricultural Show President Chiluba assured that the price of mealie meal will be reduced by almost 50 per cent to K7,000 for a 25 kg bag. The President pointed to the forecast bumper harvest as the basis for the mealie meal price reduction.

But millers and farmers see things differently.

"On what grounds can the price of mealie-meal come down so much?" asked National Milling Company managing director, Mwansa Mutanuka, in an interview in Kitwe on Friday. "This assertion is not backed by any positive factors in the economy."

Mutanuka advised the government against interfering with mealie meal prices.

" I would love the government to let prices control themselves so that we don't run away from our commitment to a free market," Mutanuka advised. "You don't expect a miller to sell for less than he spends. That is not good economics."

The government was also advised to assess the ramifications of low mealie meal prices on farmers.

"If millers have to reduce their prices, farmers will moan. This is not a one way thing," Mutanuka said, asking: "How does the government expect us to bring the price of mealie-meal down when it has not leveled the playing field regarding outside competitors who bring their mealie meal into the country at very cheap prices?"

And Zambia National Farmers Union president, Ben Kapita, warned that tampering with mealie meal prices, for any political expediencies, will reduce maize production.

"The nation can then expect low maize production for the next season because farmers will not be able to recover their costs," Kapita warned.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


345 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Party Cadres Besiege Courts


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 5, 1996 by Sundie Sinkala


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Lusaka - Hundreds of chanting UNIP cadres and sympathisers yesterday besieged the Supreme and Magistrates Courts grounds to wait for their eight leaders facing treason charges.

There was euphoria as the cadres adorned in white head bands on which the message "No Kaunda No election", was inscribed, ran all over the place, singing anti-Chiluba songs.

Big banners carrying different messages were hang out for motorists and passers-by on Independence Avenue to read. Some of the messages read, "ZCTU- Do you still trust this traitor Chiluba? Chiluba has sold Zambia to Nikuv, Chiluba can never be more Zambian than KK, UNIP- Kubwela Mukuteka ( UNIP is coming back to rule again) 

Workers from the Supreme and High Courts and the nearby offices abandoned their offices to witness the myriad of activities taking place outside.

As women cadres danced in jubilation and in praise of UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda, who was present at the scene, while the youths poured scorn on Chiluba, police recruits were brought in blue Land Rovers to contain the situation.

But the cadres put up their 'V' sign chanting "We Want Peace".

When the situation became tense and more cadres poured in from different parts of Lusaka, a bus load of policemen appeared and the police were this time deployed at critical points mainly surrounding the court of the senior principal magistrate where the accused were to appear.

But the over 100 police recruits all with shot batons did not have it easy from the UNIP cadres, who constantly taunted them for "being used by the Chiluba government instead of serving the nation".

"Ba buju lelo muzaciwona. Ni ndewo naimwe chifukwa mwanyanya (Today you the police and us will fight. We are tired of your partisanship)," cadres shouted.

It was also not a pleasant day for journalists from the government-owned media who were harassed and told to leave the premises.

"Your masters will not allow you to report objectively," shouts came from the crowd.

A ZNBC cameraman was dragged and pushed around as he tried to cover the jubilating cadres.

Reporter Della Phiri stood her ground and explained to UNIP Information and publicity secretary Bweendo Mulengela that she was simply doing her job. Her resistance paid off and she managed to get her story but without her cameraman who ran off and took refuge in the High Court building.

More ululations deafened the atmosphere when the suspects who included UNIP vice-president, senior chief Inyambo Yeta and two retired generals, Joseph Chitomfwa and Nicholas Zulu appeared.

And expelled Mongu National Party member of parliament Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika (Aka) 'proudly' walked with the eight accused persons through the police cordon right into the court room.

"If this is treason," Aka said, "then the only exception to treason in Zambia is cowardice."

Police, including Lusaka police boss Wynter Kabwiku, who tried to bar supporters from entering the court were pushed aside by the surging crowd.

Even as the court proceedings started, there was deafening noise both inside and outside the courts, forcing principal resident magistrate Francis Nsokolo to plead for silence from the jeering public.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: Gender Issue Addressed


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 5, 1996 by Brian Malama


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - Linesmen will now be referred to as assistant referees.

The general secretart of FAZ, The Zambian Footaball Association, Hermann Mpashi said the new moves are in line with the quest for gender equality as today even women are match officials. 

"This change has been made to keep up with the times as women are now also admitted to panels of referees and linesmen, so this terminology of assistant referee is neutral," he said at a press briefing yesterday.

Meanwhile Power Dynamos striker Melvin Mwila, has finally left for South Africa to finalise his professional contract with Spur Amazulu.

"I am happy that everything has been arranged for me to travel with Power Dynamos officials to finalise the deal," Mwila said yesterday in Kitwe shortly before departure.

And Power Dynamos secretary, Edgar Mvula, who is accompanying the player to South Africa, said all was set for the player to start his professional career.

"I am going to South Africa with Melvin to see what is on offer. We want to make sure we get the best for the player. But we will not by any way block the player," Mvula said.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: Defender's Injury Fake


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 5, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - The Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) has officially lodged a protest to FIFA over the Saudi Arabian club's failure to release defender Elijah Litana on pretext that he was injured.

"We have written to FIFA to protest at the conduct of the Saudi Arabian club because we feel they cheated that Litana was injured. We are now awaiting the response from FIFA but we are confident that Litana will be released to play in the return match against Sudan," FAZ secretary general Hermann Mpashi said yesterday at a press conference at his Anchor House office yesterday.

Mpashi charged that he had spoken to Litana before Zambia's departure to Sudan and was stunned when he was told later that the player was injured.

"I had spoken to him (Litana) and he assured me that he was coming but I was surprised that his club officials phoned later to inform us that he was injured.

"But the rumours we got were that his club was engaged in a Cup Final and hence they could not afford to release him," said Mpashi moaning: "It is actually dishonesty on our Arab partners that we have to face such problems in getting our players for international duties."

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - General Table Tennis: International Player Confident


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 4, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - International table tennis player Kennedy Katungu, is confident of scooping the Africa Zone Six Championship from South African Steven Browns, who dethroned him last year.

The 21-year-old Katungu, who was speaking shortly after defending the Alliance Francaise National Table Tennis Open Championship last weekend at the Zamsure sports complex in Lusaka, said his mission is now to grab the Africa Zone Six Championship. 

"I feel great that I have managed to defend the championship. Competition was tough but because of the training I had, I managed to beat Friday N'gandu," said Katungu who scored an impressive 21-19, 21-16, 21-16 in the men's singles' finals.

And teenager, Gladys Nyendwa, also defended the ladies' championship after stopping her Nkana team mate, Hariet Manda via a 3-0 bashing in the best of five series.

"It feels good to defend such a big championship," said Nyendwa, who lost out in the Rothmans Sportswoman of the Year Award for 1995 to swimmer, Ellen Hight by less ten votes.

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer FIFA Blocks English Agent


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 4, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The world soccer governing body, FIFA, has ordered the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) to stop using Englishman John Fashanu as an agent for the transfer of local players to the outside leagues.

According to sources within FAZ, the association received the order from FIFA last week to stop using John Fashanu who last year signed a contract with FAZ to become Zambia's sole soccer agent. 

"We actually got the order last week from FIFA, asking us to stop any dealings with John Fashanu concerning the transfer of players. And we are yet to send FIFA a feedback on the issue," said a FAZ insider.

But FAZ general secretary, Hermann Mpashi, when approached could neither confirm nor deny the allegations.

"I cannot as at now say if we have got the information or not, but the best I can say is that come tomorrow (today) for a press conference," said Mpashi who is expected to release the contents of the FIFA fax message this afternoon at his Anchor House offices.

But FAZ treasurer Musa Kasonka, who insisted only Mpashi could give full details, explained that FAZ had no deal with the Nigerian-born Fashanu on the transfer of players.

"The only person who can talk on that is Mpashi but what you must understand is that Fashanu is only our agent as far as arranging international friendly matches and also looking for sponsors of our national team, he has never been our soccer agent," insisted Kasonka in an interview.

The FIFA move to stop Fashanu selling Zambian players comes only two weeks after the Dennis Lota Commission of Inquiry, headed by Tom Mtine recommended that Fashanu must not be involved in the transfer of players.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


350 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Aid worries Chiluba


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 5, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - Presideint Frederick Chiluba yesterday complained that the national sovereignty of African states will always be compromised due to dependence on donor aid.

Addressing the official opening of the Rotary 9 th District Conference at Lusaka's Mulungushi international Conference Centre yesterday, President Chiluba said Africa as a Continent cannot continue to rely on charity and indeed aid because however benevolent the donors may be, conditions will always compromise the recipients. 

"National sovereignty and independence of action will always be compromised if we are seen as perpetual beggars and recipients of foreign aid. We should not be objects of charity but masters of our own destiny," President Chiluba said. " We in the Third World are poor because we have allowed ourselves to be objects of charity."

President Chiluba's remarks come in the wake of the United States government's intentions to review the bilateral and multilateral relationship with Zambia, following the impasse that President Chiluba's controversial constitution has created.

President Chiluba further called for closer co-operation amongst Rotarians to alleviate poverty.

"Enough time has been wasted in ideological experiments," President Chiluba carped. "We must break out of this vicious cycle if we, as a people, are to make an impact on the global economic scene."

And representative for president of Rotary International, Dr Edward Spiff from Nigeria, said Rotary was an idea deeply rooted in humanity and responding to personal needs immediately.

"Rotary is no longer just a fellowship," Spiff said. "World peace will only be achieved if the members of Rotary worldwide come together."


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


351 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: Professional Help Coming


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) June 3, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - The Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) has promised to provide national team trainer Roald Poulsen with all the professional players he may require in the return battle against Sudan.

"After the defeat in Sudan, we have to make sure that we win the return match and hence as FAZ, we will provide Poulsen with the professional players he may ask for," said Musa Kasonka. 

Speaking in an interview at his Roma residence yesterday, Kasonka insisted that all was not lost in the battle for a berth in the group stages of the Africa World Cup matches.

"We lost to Sudan but I think even the coach and the players know we can also win here. As FAZ, we will see what we can do to provide Poulsen with a full house," said Kasonka, adding that medical facilities will be provided to Jonson Bwalya and if possible Elijah Litana, both said to be injured.

Zambia, playing without Kalusha Bwalya, Jonson Bwalya, and Elijah Litana, key professional players, last Saturday lost 2-0 to a strong Sudanese side in a very hot desert conditions.

Kalusha, who skipped the Sudan tie as he was on holiday, will arrive in the country this week.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


352 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Africans Change Strategy In Wildlife Conservation


BYLINE: Africa Resources Trust June 5, 1996


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Washington - After decades of decline in wildlife populations, Africans are trying a different approach to conservation. The strategy -- involving community management and commercial use of wildlife -- is controversial, but Africans are making it work. This is the message that a delegation of Africans will deliver during a tour to Washington, DC, New York City, and Ottawa, June 18-27, 1996. 
 The Africans -- experts in conservation and community development from Botswana, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe -- will explain how rural communities are reviving traditional techniques involving local management and comunity benefit from wild animals. The proceeds from tourism and animal products create incentives that help sustain both threatened animal species and impoverished human communities, by providing funds to construct schools or clinics, for example.

The seminar tour coincides with a march on Capitol Hill by animal rights activists who oppose this African strategy. Many Americans who care about animals do not realize how much African communities sacrifice in terms of lost crops, water sources, and human lives in order to share their land with wildlife. The Africans are seeking opportunities to provide balance to the debate about African wildlife by explaining their indigenous approach to resolving human/animal conflicts.

In addition, the Africans will explain the need for U.S. policy regulating foreign species to be developed in consultation with the countries in which the species exist. Many species listed under the U.S. Endangered Species Act, for example, occur in Africa.

The long-term success of the African strategy for sustaining wildlife depends on access to international markets for wildlife products such as ivory. Sustaining a demand for products within Africa requires a global understanding of how regulated trade benefits both the conservation of wildlife and the development of human communities.

The African strategies will be discussed at seminars June 18 and June 21 in Washington, June 25 in New York City, and June 27 in Ottawa. Seminar hosts include the World Resources Institute, the World Bank, the World Wildlife Fund, the Forum of African Voluntary Development Organizations, The UN Development Programme, the International Conservation Union, and the Canadian Wildlife Federation.

Africa Resources Trust, a private voluntary organization based in Zimbabwe, is sponsoring the tour.

For more information, contact Africa Resources Trust, 1400 16th Street, NW, Suite 502, Washington, DC 20036. Phone: 202 939-4321. Fax: 202 797-5461. Email: artindc@aol.com


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


353 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Judgement Day For the Rich Kaduna State Board of Internal Revenue declares war on tax evaders


BYLINE: TheWeek (Lagos) June 7, 1996 by Emmanuel Ado


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Lagos - When last month, Habib Yakubu, executive chairman, Kaduna State Board of Internal Revenue, vowed to surpass the target of N1,205,709,330, set for the board by the government this year, not many people took him serious. Not even the fact that in 1995, he was able to increase internally generated revenue from a mere N200 million in 1994 to N793,266.699.38 could impress cynics, who insist that the target of one billion is rather over-ambitious.

Even before he outlined his strategy, traders of the Kaduna central market and other interest groups, notably the rich in Kaduna, were up in arms against the board. Their major argument was that government could not justify the collection of taxes in view of its failure to provide social social services. The government has, however, deflated the argument with a swift rehabilitation of roads in Kaduna and the provisions of potable water. 

Reportedly leading the opposition against the state government is Sunday Danladi Okogwu, brother-in-law of former president Ibrahim Babangida. He is alleged to have described Kaduna State tax policies as colonial and oppressive. Okogwu's position has expectedly pitched him against the state government. Sources told Theweek that Lawal Jaafaru Isa, Kaduna State administrator, was furious when he was briefed about Okogwu's indebtedness to the state government, through alleged false declaration of his income in the last six years.

Between Isa and Okogwu there is no love lost. Late last year Okogwu reportedly slighted Isa by presenting him with a gold watch in public. Though Isa returned the watch, he has not forgotten the public embarrassment. But Government House sources insist that Okogwu's travails in the hands of the revenue board has nothing to do with the watch episode. Theweek reliably gathered that government picked on him as a scapegoat, a reward for his being the most outspoken critic of the internal revenue board's activities. The thinking is that he might be part of a concerted effort by tax evaders to instigate the people against the government. For the government, panic set in when traders at the central market threatened to close shops unless the government reduced taxes. In reality, the state government has not increased taxes, it has only blocked leakages and become more aggressive towards revenue collection.

Unknown to the Okogwu is the fact that the government had since last year resolved to drag suspected tax dodgers before the Miscellaneous Offenses Tribunal. Shehu Idris, the emir of Zaria, strengthened governments resolve by paying N1 million as personal income tax. An elated Isa in a letter to Idris commended him for being "the only one to pay N1 million as personal income tax despite the existence of more wealthy individuals in the state."

With the emir's gesture, the government's response to the stiff opposition of Kaduna's rich men was swift. First, it caused a list of tax evaders to be published. The list could pass for a who-is-who in Nigeria. Second, the government contracted an accounting firm to produce a register of all taxable entities in the state. The government hopes to increase its monthly revenue from N30 million to N70 million by the end of the exercise.

The case between Okogwu and the Board of Internal Revenue will to a large extent determine whether the Kaduna State government would be able to recover the over N600 million being owed it by its wealthy subjects. Already the board has written Okogwu, asking him to voluntarily provide details of his business activities in Nigeria and abroad, including certified final accounts of his businesses. He was further advised to appoint a "competent tax consultant who will liaise between you and the tax authorities at the federal, state and local government levels including appeals against assessment." Okogwu's case might be a bad one, going by Yakubu's statement that Okogwu made false declaration to the board.

According to Yakubu, the war against the rich can be justified on two grounds: the rich complain most about lack of social services; while only a fraction of them pay tax, meaning that it is public servants that bear the tax burden. It was learnt that between January and November, last year, the government realised N102 million through pay-as-you earn while it realised a paltry N3.9 million through direct assessment of self employed people. Worse, companies hardly pay to the state government deductions from staff salaries. One company is said to be owing the government N32 million, being deductions for six years. Can the government prove its case against the rich men of Kaduna? The answer is a resounding yes, going by the report of a special tax audit committee.

Issue cover date: June 10, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
