Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria To Pay Or Not To Pay?


BYLINE: TheWeek (Lagos) June 7, 1996 by Wisdom Dike


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Lagos - A Port Harcourt-based contracting firm tackles Shell Petroleum Company for allegedly failing to abide by the terms of a contract over a boat detained by the Nigerian Navy.

These are not the best of times for Shell Petroleum Development Company of Nigeria. Worried by a seeming refusal to pay agreed damages for a detained barge hired from Samesokey Company Nigeria Limited by Willbros (WA) Incorporated for Shell Petroleum, a N48 million suit has been slammed on the multi-national oil company by Manfred Sappy, chief executive of Samesokey Company. Only last two weeks, a Port Harcourt High Court presided over by T.K. Osu had ordered the general manager (East), Shell Petroleum and the Rivers State Commissioner of Police to produce H.S. Al-Lamki, an expatriate staff of Shell or risk being jailed for contempt of court. 

The sledge-hammer is also hanging over Adams Okoene and C. Henderson, engineering and human resources managers respectively of the oil giant. The duo were joined in the suit as co-defendants for their role in negotiating for an out-of-court settlement which failed. Al-Lamki had promised to prevail on Shell to pay the contractors for the period of detention of the barge.

Theweek investigation revealed that N48 million is being demanded by Samesokey as total loss, damages and inconveniences incurred during the period of seizure of "African Oil Barge," a self-propelled boat belonging to the company on lease to Will bros (WA) Incorporated, contractor to Shell Petroleum. The contract history dates back to January 25, 1994, when a major oil leakage occurred at Nembe Creek IV Manifold. Willbros was mobilised by Shell to carry out repair works on the site and the Samesokey barge was used to evacuate sludge (mixture of crude oil and mud) to Nember Creek I flow station. The sludge could not be evacuated into the Nembe Creek. It was subsequently diverted to the Bonny Terminal Sludge Pit C.

Business went awry for Willbros when the self-propelled boat was arrested by Owems, a sub-lieutenant with the Nigerian Navy, NNS Okemini, on February 18, 1994. The company was accused of carrying petroleum products along the sensitive Bonny Terminal without proper documentation and authorisation. All attempts to release the boat failed as the Nigerian Customs Service subsequently impounded the boat for "a suspected case of illegal dealing in petroleum product." This was contained in a letter addressed to Shell Petroleum dated August 15, 1994 and signed by J.O Alobo, an assistant legal adviser for the Nigerian Customs Service, Area I, Port Harcourt.

In another letter dated June 20, 1994, J.A. Kalu-Igboa, a commander in the Nigerian Navy, NNS Okemini, Port Harcourt, warned Shell Petroleum and its contractors that "no petroleum products, no matter how little or how degraded, can be moved between points without prior approval from this Base which is the sole representative of the Task Force in this locality." After many weeks of seizure, the barge was release having attracted penalties from he two regulating bodies.

Acknowledging the seizure and recommending full compensation to the contractor for losses and inconveniences, I.O Ahize of the legal department of Shell Petroleum in an internal memo to Shell management (ECPE Department) dated October 20, 1994, noted: "The absence of relevant documents coupled with Bonny being a major crude oil terminal/ocean port would have raised the suspicions of the authorities, thus leading to arrest and detention of the barge.."

Ahize recommended full payment to the contractor, Willbros, who, in turn, would settle Samesokey. But this did not go down well with Shell management. For many months the oil company refused to pay the contractor. Snappy told Theweek in an interview that "after several weeks of negotiations, the managing director of Willbros met with Shell management and they agreed to pay me my money covering the period of detention of my boat." Manfred was disillusioned when the promise to pay was not honoured. He went to court and sued Shell for N48 million in damages in 1995.

After several weeks of protracted court hearings, Sappy was advised by some top management staff of Shell to withdraw the case for an out-of-court settlement negotiated by Adams Okoene, Sappy went into a closed-door meeting with Okoene, Al-Lamki, and Henderson. The two parties (representing their companies) agreed that Shell would pay on the condition that the suit be withdrawn from the court by the plaintiff.

True to the terms of the mutual agreement, Sappy proceeded to the court with his lawyers and formally withdrew the case on September13, 1995. But Shell allegedly refused to pay. The lawyers of Shell refused to comment on the matter when Theweek visited the legal department. One of the lawyers who pleaded anonymity, told Theweek that "facts are sacred and the courts will determine the case." The battle-line seems to have been drawn.

Issue cover date: June 10, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


355 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Sierra Leone The War: No End In Sight


BYLINE: TheWeek (Lagos) June 7, 1996 by Theo Nicol, Special Correspondent


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Alimany Sankoh, erstwhile spokesman of Sierra Leone's Rebel United Front, who abandoned the rebellion last January, tells Theweek why the war in the West African country may not end soon.

Theweek: What motivated you to join the RUF? Sankoh: At first we were opposed to the war completely since its inception, we of the People's Democratic league even called for cessation of hostilities and negotiations to return the country to normalcy even when the military took over. But it came to a time when we received reports that foreign troops and mercenaries were being recruited to fight on behalf of the Freetown government and they were using banned weapons against the people of Sierra Leone, so we in PDL, entered on the side of the RUF in defence of our land and our civil population in the country. The rebels are Sierra Leoneans and every Sierra Leone'an life is equal to us. We cannot afford to sit down and watch mercenaries being deployed to destroy our people. We have to rise and fight to defend them.

What was it like working with Foday Sanko? 

It was like working with former Nazi leader, Adolf Hitler. Foday Sankoh believes that power lies in the barrel of the gun, so the only way he can become president of Sierra Leone is through the gun. He has vowed since the inception of the war not to talk peace or respect peace until his mission is accomplished. outrightly, he is a dictator. he doesn't allow others' opinion. Whosoever challenges his views faces death. He is a demi-god to his supporters. Working with him was always a master-servant relationship. he believes that everybody should bow down before him?

Why and How did you escape to Ivory Coast?

I was the political and foreign relations official for the RUF. So I was in Abidjan trying to inform the world about the situation in Sierra Leone. There, I met a friend of NPFL's Charles Taylor, Addae Sebo, a Ghanaian exile in London, who is also a freelance journalist, writing for NPFL. He came to me and requested that he wanted to go into RUF territory to cover stories for publication in newspapers and magazines. At the time, some expatriates were captured and were in the RUF camp. We needed publicity to tell the world our side of the story. So I sent Sebo to the camp to cover the story against the wishes of most of the other RUF officials. Sebo's claim to represent International Alert (NGO) embarrassed Sankoh and even the white captives that were there, because the only NGO Foday Sankoh approved then was the Red Cross.

Before Sebo went in, we had already handed over seven nuns captured by us, to the Roman Catholic Bishop in Mukeni, western Sierra Leone. We had also made it clear that the remaining ten foreign captives would be handed over to the Red Cross.

I then sent another communication to Foday Sankoh that the captives were to start making the journey from Foday Sankoh's headquarters to the Guinean border, on foot. When they reached the border towns, the RUF secretary for agriculture, who was Fajiah Musa, now deputy PRO, aligned with Addae Sebo. On the day of the handing over, Foday Sankoh radioed me that I should announce that the foreign nationals had been handed over to the Red Cross. So I called the BBC and announced that we had handed them over on humanitarian grounds without collecting ransom.

On hearing my interview with the BBC, Addae Sebo radioed Foday Sankoh saying I was trying to overthrow Foday. That was the beginning of the problem. When I learnt of a plot by Foday Sankoh and his boys to kill me, I decided to return, and not to go into the RUF camp anymore. So I called a meeting and about 319 of my boys in the RUF escaped to Guinea from the camp. On 31st of January 1996, we parted ways with the RUF.

Who are the main Supporters of the RUF?

When I was there, there was no country supporting RUF. But before my PDL aligned with them it was Charles Taylor who was providing arms and ammunition.

How do they get their supply of arms, ammunition and food?

Through ambushes, and sale of diamond to the business people in Guinea, they are able to get ammunition. For food, they have farms and they capture some from anywhere. There is a lot of yam, banana, plantain etc. in the bush.

Now in Ghana, what are you up to?

We have now organised ourselves into the PDL to champion the course of peace and true democratic movement in Sierra Leone. It was the PDL that had stated the need for peace since 1991. We are still capable of bringing all the warring parties to accept peace. We don't want the Somalian or Liberian experience to be a replica in our country. We encourage only genuine peace brokers to be involved, not those who are out to just make money.

The present parliament in Sierra Leone is not democratic. It does not represent the entire Sierra Leone. Constitutionally, it should have 112 members but now it has only 68. So what happens to the other constituencies? Are they not part of Sierra Leone?

Do you see this war coming to an end soon?

No! The involvement of the mercenaries show that the war will last for more years to come. Because South African mercenaries are receiving half a million dollars every month from the government salaries. And they have been given the whole of Komo district to mine diamond free. Only to kill Sierra Leoneans in their own land. Indirectly, our sovereignty has been handed over to them by the Freetown government. So these people will prolong the war for its economic ends.

As for the Nigerian and Guinean soldiers they will like the war to continue so that they can loot and take booties to their countries, such as cars, diamonds, electronics. International Alert is also there working to prolong the war. They are a Mafia group who are being used against African people. They were party to the Rwanda genocide, Burundi and Liberia. They are now in Sierra Leone to continue their exploits.

Even the minister of foreign affairs in Kabbe's government is an anti-peace element. While he was working as adviser to Samuel Doe in Liberia, he advised Doe not to talk peace, but to continue to fight these foreign mercenaries in the country.

The UN also is not doing enough for the peace process in Sierra Leone. It is a shame that the UN is afraid to condemn the presence of the foreign mercenaries and troops in Sierra Leone. Last November, the UN organised a donor conference in New York to solicit for funds for the election in Sierra Leone, but up till now no conference on peace in Sierra Leone has been held by the UN. And it has failed to give protection to Sierra Leone.

The policy of silence pursued by the British government towards the conflict in sierra Leone is disappointing and frustrating. They have done nothing to help the peace process.

What do you prescribe for peace in Sierra Leone?

The only way peace can come is that all foreign troops and mercenaries must leave and be replaced by the UN monitoring group or peace keeping force. And the international community should help all the genuine Sierra Leonean groups fighting for peace in Sierra Leone. That International Alert and other foreign peace brokers who are just out to make money must leave. South African mercenaries have planted about five million mines in the soil of four million people and no country has ever come out to challenge or question their activities in the country.

How do you fund your PDL?

Through voluntary contributions. Presently, the Canadian government has allocated 3 million-dollars to help the democratic process in Sierra Leone, Nigeria and Gambia. Since the PDL believes in democracy, and we intend to get power through the democratic process, we have applied to the Commonwealth to give us our own share of the allocation, since it is for all democratic groups in these countries. It is not for the government alone. We, the PDL, has a clear manifesto. No other political group, not even the SLPP has. And the last election in Sierra Leone was greatly supported by the PDL. We hope that justice will prevail in the allocation of the funds so that all of us will get our share.

Issue cover date: June 10, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


356 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Friends Die First


BYLINE: TheWeek (Lagos) June 7, 1996 by Godwin Agbroko


LENGTH: 4507 words


 

Lagos - The Abacha war on corruption turns full circle to focus the searchlight on the cabinet. Those in the first line of fire are the presidents own cronies.

For Jeremiah Useni, minister of the Federal Capital Territory, Abuja, it was relationship as usual as he sought to table the request of his cabinet colleagues before Sani Abacha, the head of state. Earlier at an informal discussion among some of the ministers, Useni had been unanimously chosen, apparently because of his cozy association with the boss, as the right man to go and lobby the head of state to release the capital grants for the second quarter of the year early enough so that the ministries could execute their projects on schedule. 

Now before Abacha, Useni got far less than he was accustomed to. Instead of the head of state attending to his request personally as was the case in the past, he told the FCT minister to direct his inquiry to Anthony Ani, Useni's colleague in the finance ministry, as he was the appropriate officer to handle such matters. Useni hobbled over to the finance ministry where a greater shock awaited him. As soon as he got into the finance minister's office, Ani greeted him with, "Ah! thank God you're here, I have been meaning to get across to you." He told Useni that he was under a presidential instruction to write a memo to him to account for all the monies released to the FCT for capital projects in the last quarter, as well as, for the transfer of some ministries from Lagos to Abuja. Could he please oblige? Useni was aghast, particularly at the bit about the transfer money which Theweek learnt was just a mere N1.5 million. He scuttled back to Abacha where his confusion was to be compounded further. When he inquired of the head of state whether it was indeed true that he had ordered Ani to write to him to render the accounts of the FCT, Abacha was generally vague. He said he could not now recollect whether he had given such an instruction, but then he added rather ominously, "what is wrong in asking you to account for the monies you have received?"

It dawned on Useni that this was more or less a confirmation of what he had heard earlier. Before the fateful encounter between him and the head of state, Theweek learnt that certain directors in the ministry had petitioned Abacha, alleging, among other things, that the FCT minister was diverting funds meant for the federal capital to the development of Langtang, his home base. Somehow, the minister got hold of the petition and decided on a course of reprisals against the petitioners. The outcome was a retrenchment of all those connected with the petition.

All of this was said to have filtered through to Abacha was greatly displeased by the action of his crony and subordinate. Following this development, sources say, the head of state held a meeting with close confidants in the government on how to deal with the FCT minister and some of his colleagues who may have infringed the financial guidelines in this year's budget for executing capital projects. It is believed that it was part of the decisions at that meeting that led to the presidential instruction to the finance minister to ensure that the ministers account for the capital projects funds they had received.

In their second encounter, the head of state was in turn jolted by the FCT minister. Useni was said to have told him that he believed that Abacha gave specific instructions to Ani to query him based on what he had heard before now. He related in detail the high-level meeting at which the decision might have been taken. His information was so accurate that the head of state became convinced that someone who was privy to the discussions must have squealed. As soon as Useni departed, Abacha ordered a discrete inquiry to know the source of the leak. Sources say he was utterly amazed to learn that all indications pointed to M. Jubrin, a lieutenant-colonel and his aide-de-camp, as the mole. Abacha was furious. His immediate reaction, according to sources, was to retire Jubrin from the army. But after series of appeals to reconsider the issue based on the ADC's past services, he relented. As a source put it, Jubrin was not only removed as ADC to the head of state, he was "banished" to Pakistan as defense attachi to the Nigerian embassy there, to be replaced by one Aminu, a major.

The former ADC was apparently caught in the web of dual loyalty. Sources say that if indeed he was the mole, he would have found it pretty difficult to keep what he overhead about Useni to himself. Useni is said not only to have helped Jubin to own a house in the federal capital territory, he has all along acted as his godfather in the military, rendering every kind of assistance to him. On the other hand, the former ADC was so enamoured of Abacha that he is believed to have been penciled down as the next military administrator of Kano State by the head of state. As it turned out, he unwittingly became the first casualty of Abacha's desire to turn the searchlight of accountability inward.

Information available to Theweek suggests that the administration's anti-corruption crusade was the brainchild of the presidential Economic Intelligence Monitoring United headed by Sam Aluko, a retired professor of economics and social critic. Quite early in the life of the administration, the unit was said to have suggested the rather novel idea of using special tribunals to fight corruption to achieve multiple goals - both political and economic. The unit is reputed to have recommended for special tribunals on failed banks, failed contracts, and failed parastatals.

The group's argument was that a crackdown on corruption at this point was such a popular measure that would appeal instantly to the broad masses of Nigerians and thus help to garner immeasurable political support for the administration. At another level, the unit argued that if the crusade was prosecuted to the letter, it would yield a bounteous harvest for individuals and the treasury to such an extent that such unexpected funds could help kick-start the prostrate economy. As a sop to all this, the unit said that whatever the government did to stir the economy would be in vain until there was a return to some form of probity and financial sanity.

It is believed that it is these powerful arguments that swayed Abacha from previously chosen course not to exhume the past. Still, the head of state decided to play it cautiously. While the economic intelligence unit recommended that the war should begin with a band and simultaneously on all fronts, Abacha preferred to make a probing foray with the special tribunal on failed banks. The success of it, both at the political and economic level, was said to have astonished the head of state himself. Ordinary Nigerians did not only embrace the war, they seem to love the discomfiture of the high and mighty who are generally seen as those who have pillaged the economy. For the first time, the administration seemed to have hit on a weapon not only to guarantee it public support in the face of domestic and international opposition, but one that was re-directing the public's attention from the lingering political crisis to economic issues of financial sanity, and accountability. It is this success that has presumably encouraged the administration to venture afield into trying to set up tribunals on failed contracts and parastatals.

All the same, the economic intelligence unit has long before now pointed to an area capable of undermining public support for the crusade - accountability in the government itself. In the unit's reasoning, if the war of probity was not extended to the cabinet, it would erode the confidence, and by extension the support, of the public. It was the unit that was said to have drawn up the guidelines on capital projects on expenditure that were incorporated in the 1996 budget. Theweek learnt that at the high-level meeting on Useni and his colleagues, a member of the unit who was present argued for the strict enforcement of the guidelines.

It was confirmed by last week that the ministries of national planning and finance have swung into action. Some ministers who went to solicit the release of the capital votes for their ministries this quarter were turned back. They were told that the votes would not be released until they had obtained from the military of National Planning certificates of compliance with the financial guidelines for their previous expenditures. To make the message sink, those ministries that have obtained clearance certificates have been rewarded with allocations to the tune of some N25 billion, while withholding abut N23 billion naira due to the defaulting ministries.

Theweek learnt that some ministries might find it difficult to scale the clearance hurdle. To issue a clearance certificate, officials of the national planning ministry are expected to conduct a physical inspection of projects and to certify that they had been undertaken according to specifications. Sources at the ministry said last week that such a tour conducted recently by its officials revealed that some of the defaulting ministries and agencies acted clearly in breach of the financial procedures. Their default ranged from outright misappropriation through improper use of funds to what former vice president Augustus Aikhomu would call misapplication of funds. It is suspected that Useni's ministry of the federal capital territory and the Ministry of Works and Housing under Abdul Kareem Adisa may be among the distressed ministries caught in the clearance web.

Abacha seems to have picked on Useni deliberately to start the war for inner cleansing; to send a powerful signal to his cabinet that the searchlight would not discriminate in those it beams upon. Says a source close to Aso Rock: "The head of state is sending a signal to his ministers and Nigerians that this thing has nothing to do with friendship or cronyism. It is a way of bolstering public confidence in what he's doing. No good general will go to war with his flanks wide open.

It is believed that the inner cleansing would be counter-productive in the long run. Sources say that the strategy of the administration is to drop erring ministers who after a deadline fail to pass the test of financial prudence being administered by the national planning ministry. it is even said that the administration is planning that ministers with serious cases of misappropriation of funds may have to stand trial. By press time, it was unclear whether such cases would have to go to the now famous special tribunals for failed chief executives of government departments. In official circles in Abuja, insinuation was that Useni's recent inspection of projects in federal capital territory was a kind of valedictory tour.

Giving the closeness of the head of state and the FCT minister, his exit from the cabinet is by no means certain. What seems clear, however, is that the Abacha administration may soon undertake the long speculated cabinet change. Insiders say the change will be wide-ranging and may not necessarily have to do with probity alone.

One of those likely to be dropped is Uba Ahmed, the controversial labour and productivity minister. In Abacha's court, Ahmed's cup appears not only to be full, but overflowing. Despite the gale of controversy that had dogged his every action, Ahmed seems to have reached the last post only lately. The immediate cause of his worry was the conference "labour and transition" organised by the Nigeria Labour Congress, NLC, in Kaduna, May 3.

In an attempt to abort the conference, the minister sent a report to the presidency claiming that the labour leaders were going to use the seminar to discredit the administration's transition programme. What irked the presidency most was that Ja'afaru Isa, the military administrator, was part of the conference. He was queried. At any rate, when the conference held, the communiqui was a fulsome endorsement of the political programme. The presidency was, therefore, as perplexed as Isa was angry at what he was as Ahmed's perfidy.

Even so, the minister was not through yet. A day after the conference, he reportedly instigated security agents to arrest Adams Oshionmole, a labour leader and one of the principal architects of the pro-government seminar. Isa became even angrier when upon inquiry, he was informed that the order for Oshionmole's arrest did not come "from above" but was masterminded by the labour minister. Isa's was not the only sensitive corn that Ahmed stepped upon. He equally got Mohammed Wase, the administrator of Kano, who is a close friend of Oshionmole, very angry. According to sources, Wase's effort to get the labour leader released displeased Ahmed who decided to act. he was said to have mobilised eminent persons to go and complain to the administrator's father who is the emir of Wase. Ahmed's charge was the action of the emir's son was capable of jeopardising his ministerial job. Ahmed who is believed to be in the same age bracket with the administrator's father has lived almost all his life in Jos, and has been quite close to the emir. The administrator who saw Ahmed as exploiting his relationship with the emir was livid. As he saw it, the minister had gone too far.

Between them, the two administrators are said to have been making numerous contacts to get the presidency to drop Ahmed from the cabinet. The pair need not to have worried themselves over Ahmed's continued tenure as minister. Even before the Oshinmole episode, Aso Rock had become suspicious about the agenda of the labour minister.

Matters came to a head in April when the minister unilaterally fired Usman Jalingo as the sole administrator of the National Union of Petroleum Energy and Gas, NUPENG, workers. When he wrote a letter sometime last year asking for approval from the government to sack Jalingo, he was turned down. When he persisted in arguing for the need to remove the NUPENG administrator, the government resorted to dilatory tactics in the hope that the matter would die naturally. He was asked to discuss it with Ahmed Gusau, the sole administrator of the NLC, and report back.

That was all Ahmed needed. Although it was far from clear whether he discussed the matter with Gusau and the outcome of that discussion, the minister proceeded with Jalingo's sack apparently without reference again to the government. Jalingo's reaction became an embarrassment to all sides. He refused to quit for Ali Ciroma, the minister's nominee for the NUPENG job. When Jalingo adamantly refused to hand over to his successor, the minister had to order his arrest, a situation that heightened the embarrassment for the government. The presidency was said to have been displeased with what it regarded as the shabby treatment of Jalingo. In its view, Jalingo should have been treated more decently if only for the fact that he came to NUPENG at a critical time and managed to restore normalcy to the restive oil workers union.

At about the same time, Ahmed was engaged in series of battles on other fronts. One of his war sectors was the union members themselves with whom he had been waging a running battle over the merger of their unions. A typical case, illustrative of the minister's alleged penchant for manipulation, was the merger of four unions to form the Steel and Engineering Workers Union of Nigeria, SEWUN. The federating unions were those of Iron and Steel Worker; and Dockyard Workers.

Because of Ahmed's alleged meddling to ensure that Bilyaminu Rimi, supposedly a close associate of the labour minister, got elected as president of the new union, the close aaociate of the labour minister, got elected as president of the new union, the merger exercise had to be postponed three times - on March 8 and 18, and again on April 11. The first postponement resulted from the purported inability of the minister to attend the merger conference. On the second occasion, Gusau, the NLC administrator said he was not given money to host it. The third time, no reason was given. After the first two postponements, some of the union members were compelled to petition the minister, march 22, alleging government's attempt to impose Rimi on them. Said the petitioners: "It is clear that the government is very much interested in seeing Comrade Rimi, the president of the former Iron and Steel Workers Union of Nigeria ISWUN, becoming the president of SEWUN, thereby intimidating the other presidents and other financial members that are more qualified from contesting. "Pleading to be left alone to elect leaders of their choice, the unionist raised an alarm that "instructions have been given to the security agents to arrest and detain every member/officer opposed to his (Rimi's) candidature."

That was the very charge that Salihu Mohammed laid at Ahmed's door when he resigned in a huff. The personal assistant to the minister accused his former boss of planning "mass arrests of unionists and to pitch the government against labour." What seems to rile the presidency was that in kicking off these controversies, starting with the sacking of Ason Bur as NLC's sole administrator last year, the minister is not acting to implement government's agenda. The suspicion in Aso Rock is that he is merely creating an enabling environment for his own candidate from Kano State to emerge as NLC's president in furtherance of his own future political activities.

Those who see the issue in that light easily point to the manner he apparently tried to demonize Oshiomole, and thereafter getting him arrested after failing in that subterfuge. For one thing, Oshiomole because of his pro-Abacha activities, has virtually been the government-anointed candidate for the NLC's presidency even before the dissolution of Paschal Bafyau's executive in 1994. For another, his showing at the Kaduna labour conference where he played a visible role in ensuring that the communiqui adopted a pro-government position should have been enough proof of his establishment credentials.

When the minister was summoned to Aso Rock in April amid the swirling problems in the labour sector, the speculation was that he was about to be fired. Theweek obtained different accounts of what transpired. One account says that Ahmed, convinced that he would be sacked, offered to resign. His request to be allowed to go was rejected by the head of state who saw such a resignation as an indirect vote of no confidence on the administration. Another has it that Abacha was in fact dissuaded from sacking him, along with Gusau,, by lobbyists. Those who advised against the sack were said to have pressured the head of state to exercise patience until he was ready to change his cabinet. As for Gusau, the NLC sole administrator, the restraining hand was that he should be allowed to complete the merger of the industrial unions.

Sources told Theweek that Abacha was exasperated with Ahmed for tow main reasons. He and Gusau are said to have been unable to account for the votes given to the labour ministry and the NLC, just like some of their colleagues in other government departments. Again, the pair were equally unable to refute the widespread allegations of causing disaffection in the ranks of labour without promoting government interest.

Ahmed is not alone in his predicament. The long-awaited cabinet shake-up is said to be taking the head of state such an unusually long time because of the need to change many of its members who are now believed to have turned into liabilities rather than assets. One of those that might be dropped is Wole Oyelese, a special duties minister. he came into garrulous visibility last year when he noisily fired Mohammed Saleh, the acting Director-General of the Centre for Democratic Studies, Abuja, on January 17 and set up a panel headed by Catherine Okon to probe the institution. In quick response, Gidado Idris, the secretary to the federal government, countermanded the minister. He quashed Saleh's suspension, disbanded the probe panel and withdrew its members back to the presidency where Oyelese had apparently pinched them without proper authorisation. As if to empahsise the disdain with which he held the minister's action, Idris left the signing of the letter to a subordinate, S.K. Okpara, a director-general in the presidency.

In the meantime, the minister, huffing and puffing, bristled: "I do not take orders from the SFG because I am responsible to him. I am only responsible to the head of state and accountable to the people of this country." Saying that "my ministry is not under the SFG," Oyelese boasted that, "Saleh remains suspended until the terms of reference of the probe panel are resolved and its recommendations passed to the federal government for final resolution." It was almost comical. As the minister was blowing this hot air, the panel members were already back to the presidency where the secretary wanted them. The presidency had to come to the rescue of the combatants with the face-saving policy of no victor, no vanquished by dissolving the CDS.

Nigerians were to hear from Oyelese again during the local government elections in March. Working ostensibly to prevent opponents of the administration from participating in the elections, the special duties minister was everywhere in Oyo, his home state, meddling with the screening of candidates. In no time, he ran into a brickwall in the form of Omololu. Because of Oyelese's unabashed interest in sponsoring a candidate for the chairmanship of his own Egbeda local government council, both government officials literally came to fistcuffs. Nothing could have undermined the transition programme - already the subject of intense suspicion both at home and abroad - more than this trading in insults and accusations. As David Attah, chief press secretary to the head of state described the feud, it was an "embarrassment to the government."

Oyelese's unabashed pursuit of his political self-interest was only symptomatic. His two other colleagues in the special duties train followed in his beaten path. In Imo State, Laz Unaogu strove to protect the interest of his political godfather, Emmanuel Iwuanyanwu, publisher of the Champion group of newspapers.

Under the guise of stopping opponents of the government from coming to power many ministers allegedly used their paraphernalia of office to pursue their own political interest in varying degrees. Among those widely believed to have played politics with their office and thus casting a shroud of credibility over the entire transition programme included Muhammadu Gambo-Jimeta in Adamawa State and Tom Ikimi in Edo State. After the elections, the head of state was so unhappy with the politician-ministers that he swore to clear them from office before the next round of elections.

Still it is not clear which of the criteria would weigh most in Abacha's decision on who stays and who goes. Said to be on top of the hierarchy of influencing factors is probity and accountability, to be followed by competence and the ability to stay out of controversies. If Abacha follows his score-card to the letter, ministers like Ikimi of external affairs; Walter Ofonagoro of information; Jim Nwobodo of Sports; and of course Oyelese, Unaogu and M.T. Liman of education as well as a host of others. would be swept away by the tidal change.

For now those seats seem impregnably safe are Ani, Abacha's collaborator on his many economic wars, and Dan Etete of petroleum resources - and perhaps, a few others. But for a mercurial leader like Sani Abacha, Nigeria's seventh military head of state, nothing can be truly safe - just as nothing can be ruled out. Proof? His war on corruption, the rave of the moment. With Yusuph Olaniyonu, Amos Esele and Sani Yaro

Issue cover date: June 10, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


357 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Parable of the Lunaria


BYLINE: TheWeek (Lagos) June 7, 1996 by Louis Onyia


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Lagos - In his usual frank manner, Anthony Aniagolu, former Supreme Court justice and chairman of the defunct Constituent Assembly, uses a public function to berate the corrupt Nigerian leadership and to call for a change of values.

Only the organisers know why they invited him. For ever since the annulment of the June 12,1993 presidential election and the subsequent discarding of the 1989 constitution which he toiled to write with his colleagues in the Constituent Assembly, Anthony Aniagolu, retired justice of the Supreme Court and chairman of the defunct Constituent Assembly, has never hidden his loss of faith in the Nigerian leadership and its brand of politics. Whenever he gets an opportunity to speak on the socio-economic and political problems of the country, he does not fail to rebuke both the military and the political class for the mess into which they have thrown the country. 

For Aniaglolu, one such opportunity came May 23 during the third general assembly of Nigerian People's Movement, held sat the Cinema Hall of the Hotel Presidential, Enugu. In his address as chairman of the occasion, the renowned jurist rained abuses and innuendo on the leaders of the country, leaving everyone in attendance with much food for thought.

In his opening remarks, Aniagolu made it clear that he had "no belief in the Nigerian brand of politics in which deceit and dishonesty appear to prevail." He said that he accepted to attend the event because "I am committed to honesty, fair play and immutable justice."

Aniagolu regaled his audience with the story of "Lunaria," a plant fondly called honesty because of its round, translucent pods. The former Supreme Court justice said that Nigerian leaders are supposed to be like the translucent pods of Lunaria by being as exactly as they look outwardly. He stated that honesty is an essential ingredient of friendship and that for friendship to subsist among people, individuals or couples, there must be honesty. Honesty is equally necessary, according to him, between countries, between towns and villages, between ethnic groups and between God and man. He noted that honesty breeds peace and happiness as against dishonesty, which begets deceit, suspicion and confusion.

Aniagolu lamented that even though the Almighty God, by endowing the country with wealth and riches, has made it the number one nation in Africa, prolonged period of military rule has made the country to sink from the exalted position of giant of Africa to the pitiable level of one of the 22 poorest countries in the world. He regretted that under military, the economy of Nigeria has touched the rock bottom of degradation, its reputation as a nation has sunk to the lowest ebb ever while its currency cannot be quoted anywhere in the world. He submitted that under military rule, Nigeria cannot achieve much in terms of its economy, political prestige, the happiness of its people, spiritual emancipation, education advancement, international cooperation and a high level of gross national product. The country's saviour, he pointed out, lies in democracy, justice, equity and the rule of law.

Aniagolu stressed that Nigeria must turn its back on the soldiers and face the legal draftsman for solace. He advised the military to lay down their "political guns" and take up their "constitutional guns" in defence of the territorial integrity of the nation and the people.

Turning to the politicians, the retired justice accused them of shortsightedness since they do not seem to see that their only trade is in jeopardy. He asked rhetorically whether they do not see that they are fast losing all credibility both with the military and with the rest of the people of Nigeria. "Do they think that the people of Nigeria are so gullible that they can deceive them all the time?" he asked.

The ex-constituent Assembly chairman enjoined the politicians to leave the path of deceit, unjust enrichment, greed and avarice, lies, double dealings and double talk, chicanery, and stealing from the public treasury. He advocated that they return to the road of honesty and to Almighty God. He offered the same suggestion to the military, whom he accused of "having stolen the people's monies and vandalised their treasury."

For Aniagolu, unless both the military and the civilian leaders change their attitude and values for the better, Nigeria can never be saved by what he called the corrupt dealings and criminal conglomerates that have afflicted her to this day. He wandered what it profits a politician who has made all the money and wealth for himself by looting the public treasury, only to end up as an object of ridicule before the world.

Aniagolu is consoled by the fact that such politicians after making the money, are searched to the bones, "quarantined" and subjected to all sorts of indignities whenever they get to the international airports of many countries outside Nigeria, while ordinary folks from other countries are welcome without any fuses. In a fit of rage, the retired justice warned all the dubious and corrupt leaders in Nigeria to realise the folly of their evil ways or suffer, not only disgrace before man but also eternal damnation by God. He insisted that whether Nigerians were talking of solidarity of one ethnic group or the inter-relationship of different ethnic groups in the country, honesty should be allowed to link all the people together in peace and honesty. Aniagolu's conclusion: The time has come in the context of Nigerian affairs, when the people must take stock and ask themselves whether they shall continue to be weighed down by military dictatorship and civilian misrule.

Issue cover date: June 10, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Sports - Olympics Nigeria: 1,200 Athletes Set For Pre-Olympic Trial


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 5, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lagos, Nigeria - Some 1,200 Nigerian athletes, including 20 based in the United States are expected for a June 20-22 national pre-olympic trial in Lagos.

Those invited from the U.S. include African track queen Mary Onyali, Christy Opara-Thompson, Olapade Adeniken and the Ezinwa brothers. 

The Athletic Federation of Nigeria (AFN) chairman Abdulkareem Amu, said Wednesday the Lagos trial, supported by oil firm, Mobil will be used to pick Nigerian representatives at the summer games in Atlanta, United States.

He warned the athletes to stay away from drugs as the federation would be conducting random tests to detect offenders.

A spokesman, Pius Akinyelure said Mobil was committed to Nigeria's dream of winning its first Olympic gold in Atlanta. Nigeria's best showing is a silver medal.

Meanwhile, the country's under-23 soccer team, composed of mainly Europe-based players, is training in the eastern city of Enugu.

The team plays a friendly match against a Togolese side June 9.

June 10, 1996 Issue

Africa News


June, 1996


United States and Africa Religous Leaders Call for Nigeria Actions


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 6, 1996


LENGTH: 854 words


 

New York - Some thirty religious leaders gathered in New York in late May to pledge themselves to the task of restoring freedom and democracy in Nigiera. These leaders have appealed to their community to proclaim a "Nigeria Freedom Sunday" on October 3, 1996 to focus attention on the situation in Nigeria. Below Africa News Online has reprinted the full text of their declaration.

Declaration of Conscience on Nigeria

We Ministers of Faith gathered at the Canaan Baptist Church of Christ in Harlem, New York, on May 28, 1996 today declare our commitment to the restoration of freedom and democracy in Nigeria. Once a beacon of hope and pride for African peoples throughout the world, this African nation has been brought low by the brutality and injustice of a military dictatorship. 

The Nigerian regime has stripped away the peoples' most basic human and civil rights, replacing them with violence, fear and intolerance. Many religious, political, trade union and community leaders have been unjustly imprisoned, forced into exile or murdered. The nation's hospitals and universities, once the pride of Africa, are in ruins.

A democratic election was annulled in 1993 and the winner, Moshood Abiola, has been jailed for nearly two years. Multi- national corporations exploit Nigeria's vast human and mineral wealth, extracting billions of dollars in profits while Nigerian children go hungry. The Christian Association of Nigeria lamented last year that, "Our hopes for amelioration have been dashed to pieces," and that the suffering of the people demands "nothing short of divine intervention."

We call on all people of good will to mark the 36th anniversary of Nigerian independence as "Nigerian Freedom Sunday," on October 3, 1996, a day of prayer for the victims of oppression and dictatorship and for the return of freedom and democracy.

Reverend Wyatt Tee Walker President, American Committee On Africa and Senior Pastor, Canaan Baptist Church; Canon Frederick Williams Rector, Church of the Intercession and Treasurer, American Committee On Africa; The Very Rev. Petero A.N. Sabune, Trinity and St. Phillip s Cathedral; Rev. Johnnie Johnson, M.D., Ethiopian Diaspora Orthodox Church; Reverend Michael Battle Executive Secretary, Hampton University Ministers Conference and Vice President, American Committee on Africa; Reverend Jose Chipenda, Secretary General, All Africa Conference of Churches; Reverend Michael DuPlessis, Rector, Trinity Episcopal Church; The Rev. Dr. Errol Harvey, St. Augustine s Episcopal Church; Bishop James I. Clark, Jr. Greater Refuge Temple; Reverend Dr. B. W. Smith, Jr. President, Progressive National Baptist Convention and Senior Pastor, St. John s Baptist Church; Reverend Dr. Glen C. Missick, Church of the Master; Reverend Al Sharpton, National Action Network; Dr. Calvin B. Marshall, III, Varick Memorial A.M.E. Zion Church; Reverend Monica H. Marshall, Varick Memorial A.M.E. Zion Church; Dr. Diane Porter, The Episcopal Church.

Also, Reverend Joseph R. Jordan Corinthian Baptist Church; Rev. Edward-Earl Johnson, Mount Moriah Baptist Church; Reverend Abraham Oyedeji, Christ Apostolic Church, Inc.; Rev. Father Emeka C. Nwigwe, All Souls Episcopal Church; Jumoke Ogunkeyede, United Committee to Save Nigeria; Benjamin Norris Scott, Ephesus S.D.A.; Reverend George Houser, Director Emeritus, American Committee on Africa; Reverend Bruce Southworth, The Community Church of New York; Minister Toon, Liberty Baptist Church; Renato L. McCray, National Action Network; Rev. Dr. Suzan Johnson Cook, Mariner s Temple; Eugene G. Meerdink, Reformed Church in America; Doreen Tilghman, Board of Global Ministries, United Methodist Church; Reverend Ioma Mills-Murray, Bethel A.M.E.; Rev. Ronald Sullivan, Abundant Joy Baptist Church; Reverend Dr. Emmanuel Osei-Acheampong and Mrs. Adwoa Osei-Acheampong, Universal Calvary Church; Rose Ella Ferguson, United Church Board for World Ministries-Refugee Branch; Sister Marsha Allen, Universal Calvary Church; Barbara Elam, Memorial Presbyterian Church; Bishop James I. Clark, Jr., Greater Refuge Temple.

For more information contact: Religous Action Network, American Committee on Africa, 17 John Street, New York, NY 10038. Phone: (212) 962-1210. E-mail: acoa@igc.apc.org

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Nigeria Roundtable Condemns Assassination


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Washington, DC - The following statement is from the International Roundtable on Nigeria.

The International Roundtable on Nigeria (IRTON) condemns the assassination of Mrs. Kudirat Abiola. Mrs. Abiola was shot along with her driver in an ambush in Lagos yesterday. She was rushed to the Eko Hospital but efforts to save her were unsuccessful.

IRTON would like to offer its deepest sympathies to Chief M. K. O. Abiola and the Abiola family. Mrs. Abiola's murder adds to the already too-heavy burdens of the family. Chief Abiola, the presidential candidate of the Social Democratic Party, saw his victory in free and fair elections in June 1993 annulled, and he has been incarcerated since June of 1994 for trying to claim his mandate. Mrs. Abiola's tireless efforts to have her husband released brought constant harassment from officials of the Abacha regime. In May, she was arrested and was to appear in court in June. 

The increasing violence in Nigeria is the result of the breakdown of the rule of law in Nigeria. Responsibility for this breakdown and the crisis lies directly with the regime of General Sani Abacha. The recent spate of political attacks, which include the shooting of Alex Ibru, publisher of the Guardian, and the murder of Alfred Rewane, a key financial supporter of the Social Democratic Party, are alarming indicators of Nigeria's continuing slide into violence. Even as the Provisional Ruling Council claims to be presiding over a transition to democracy, the country's leading voices remain stifled in jail, leaders of the independent press have been detained or forced underground for trying to publicize the truth, and the judicial system remains handcuffed by decrees granting immunity to members of the military.

The Abacha regime must ensure that those responsible for this crime are brought to justice, and that justice must be open and meet international standards of due process. At the same time the persons responsible for the attacks on Alex Ibru, Alfred Rewane and all other human rights abuses must also be brought to account. This is the only way the rule of law will be re-established.

IRTON calls upon the international community to put its rhetoric to practice and increase diplomatic and political pressure on the Nigerian government. Unless action is taken soon, Nigeria's descent into political violence will no longer be a question of if, but of when. The Clinton administration has referred to freezing the assets of members of the military junta, targeted sanctions on the oil industry, a cultural boycott and a boycott of Nigerian oil. We call upon the Clinton administration to implement an activist, preventative policy now, before the body count increases.

Africa Faith and Justice Network * Amnesty International USA * Africa Project, Institute for Policy Studies * Chicago Coalition for a Democratic Nigeria * National Democratic Coalition (NADECO) * Nigerian Democratic Awareness Committee, Nigerian Democratic Alliance, Boston * United Committee to Save Nigeria * United Nigerian Organization * Service Employees International Union * Fellowship of Reconciliation * The Africa Fund * Missionaries of Africa * PEN Center USA West * Center for Economic & Social Rights * Washington Office on Africa

The International Roundtable on Nigeria is an informal association of human rights, environmental, labor and US-based Nigerian pro-democracy groups working to help Nigerians restore a rights-respecting accountable government.

For more information call: Adotei Akwei, Amnesty International USA. (202) 544-0200, ext. 234.

This material is being reposted for wider distribution by the Washington Office on Africa (WOA), a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation. WOA's educational affiliate is the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC).

Note: For additional information on the content of material cited from another source, please contact directly the source mentioned in the posting rather than WOA. Documents previously distributed are available on the Web at: http://www.igc.apc.org/apic/index.shtml. To receive a description of the list, send an e-mail message to africapolicy-info@igc.apc.org. To receive information about WOA, with a list of publications, send an e-mail message to woa-info@igc.apc.org. Messages requiring more than an automatic response must instead be sent to woa@igc.apc.org.

For additional information: Washington Office on Africa, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E-mail: woa@igc.apc.org.

361 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Association of Nigerians Abroad Speak Out On Assassination


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is a press release from the Association of Nigerians Abroad (ANA) on June 5, 1996.

The Association of Nigerians Abroad (ANA) has learnt of the assassination of Mrs. Kudirat Abiola, the wife of the jailed winner of Nigeria's last presidential elections. Unless it is irrefutably ascertained otherwise, we in ANA are of the opinion that the military regime of General Sani Abacha bears complicity in this assassination a week away from June 12, the third anniversary of the annulled presidential elections which Kudirat's husband won. Indeed the dividing line between the so-called "hoodlums" and the Nigerian military has become increasingly thin by the day. 

Several atrocities have been committed, and continue to be committed by the regime. Her assassination follows the pattern of the cold-blood assassinations of Chief Riwanu a 73 year old veteran politician in his residence and attempted assassination of Mr Alex Ibru an ex-Minister of Information and a newspaper publisher in February, still in hospital in London. Indeed this week's murder of Mrs Kudirat Abiola was preceded a week ago by the murder of two naval officers in Lagos, and the armed storming of Bauchi prison on the 31st of May, where Gani Fawehinmi the lawyer that defended Mr Ken Saro-Wiwa is held without trial.

ANA has said on numerous occasions that the current Nigerian military regime is a lawless and brutal regime used to pathological lying to buy credibility from gullible international and local organisations. That the regime has absolutely no regard for local and international laws has been repeatedly demonstrated before the world. The regime will go to any length to maintain it's reign of terror on the law abiding and resilient citizens of Nigeria, including the use of hired assassins to maim and kill it's citizens.

The murder of author and environmentalist Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other Nigerian political activists of the minority Ogoni ethnic group is still very fresh in our minds. At present, hundreds of Nigerians have been imprisoned by the regime, several without any charges or prosecutions. Within the last two weeks more labour unions, the Academic Staff Union of Universities (ASUU) and the National Association of Nigerian Students (NANS) were proscribed, adding to the unending list of labour unions being proscribed and intimidated. Is it coincidental that these wanton and barbaric killings are taking place one week after the release of the report of the UN Fact-Finding Mission to Nigeria, it appears the junta has seen the report as a UN endorsement of its modus operandi - the oppression of the people, the denial of human rights, neglect for the rule of law and sanctity of life.

We again take this opportunity to call on the international community to take actions, including sanctions, that will help bring a rapid end to this brutal and tyrannical regime in Nigeria. We specifically request the following:

* Imposition of mandatory oil embargo on Nigeria.

* An immediate visa ban on all sporting contacts.

* Visa restrictions on members of the Nigerian regime and families.

* Withdrawal of military attaches.

* Cessation of military training.

* Embargo on the export of arms to Nigeria.

* Denial of educational facilities to members of the regime and families.

* A downgrading of cultural links.

* Downgrading of diplomatic missions.

* Ban on airlinks with Nigeria.

* Freezing of the financial assets and bank accounts of military and government ministers in foreign countries.

* Unconditional release of all political prisoners.

* Initiation of dialogue with Mr Abiola the winner of the June 1993 presidential elections to form a government of national unity that will handle the transition program.

We also request the international community not to give any semblance of credibility whatsoever to the regime or any of it's activities. We refer here to the recent United Nations Human Rights probe reports which gave some credibility to the military junta's plans to restore democracy to Nigeria at the junta's pace. The international community must be consistent in its criticism and opposition of non-mandated Nigeria's military regime.

The Nigerian people will like to see an immediate end to the jailing, maiming, and killing of fellow Nigerians by it's government. Most Nigerians fully support the individuals and pro-democracy organisations attempting to correct the injustices in Nigeria. The support of the international community will go a long way in hastening the demise of this brutal regime.

May the soul of Mrs. Kudirat Abiola rest in peace.

Signed: Johnson I Agbinya, Ph.D, President, The ANA (Australia); Mr Ikhide Ikheloa, General Secretary, The ANA (USA); Usman G. Akano, Ph.D, Vice-President, Canada; Akinola Ogungbadero, Assistant Secretary General (USA); Alwell Nwankwoala Ph.D, Legal Adviser, Australia; Michael Olusade Sekoni, Financial Secretary, USA; Adeniyi Akanni, Treasurer, Canada; Patrick Nta, Listserve Administrator, USA; Rev. H. Olufemi Awoniyi,Ph.D, Regional Representative, Europe; Anthony J. Afolayan, Regional Representative for Africa; Innocent E. Davidson, Regional Representative for Africa; Uzoma Onyemachi, U.S. Regional Representative (USA); Muktar A Dan'Iyan, Regional Representative (USA); Basie Etukudo, Information/Archivist; Francis Ogbonnaya, Regional Representative (Australia); Philip O. Ogunbona, Ph.D, Regional Representative (Australia); Christian Ukachukwu, Assistant Public Relations Secretary (USA); Akin Kumoluyi, Ph.D, Regional Representative, Europe; Fatai Oyejobi, Public Relations Secretary; Michael O. Sekoni, Finance Secretary; Deji Odetoyinbo, Ph.D, Regional Representative, Canada; Omoshile O. Clement, Ph.D, Regional Representative, Canada


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


362 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Release on Chief Kudirat Abiola's Death


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Washington, DC - The Nigerian Democratic Movement (NDM) issued the following information release on June 4, 1996.

We bring to your attention the extremely tragic news of Chief Kudirat Abiola's assassination today. It is a dastardly crime against a woman merely seeking the release of her dearly beloved husband from illegal detention. It represents a continuing Stalinization of Nigeria by a brutal military regime.

We hope that it has now become clear to all Nigeria watchers and apologists that the barbaric junta of Abacha must not be allowed to continue to run Nigeria and its people down for ONE MORE DAY.

Saro-Wiwa - Rewane - Ibru: who next? Is this any environment for "a political transition programme" when the lives of ordinary and not-so-ordinary Nigerians are lost every day due to government-orchestrated violence ? We now ask the United Nations and Butros-Ghali: is this an environment demonstrating Abacha's "commitment, statesmanship and sincerity", when the lives of Nigerians cannot be protected ?

NDM vows the removal of the Abacha regime by all means necessary, and calls upon all lovers of Nigeria to pledge same. We ask for all in the international community to match their words with action.

Released by the Executive Council of the Nigerian Democratic Movement (NDM), JUNE 4, 1996. P.O. Box 91291, Washington, DC 20090. Phone: 202/806-6617; 202/597-7052; 301/808-0800. Fax: 202/806-4632

See the NDM Web Site (http://www.cldc.howard.edu/ ndmorg/) for this and other statements and updates.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


363 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria The Assassination Of Alhaja Kudirat Abiola: The Very Depth Of Depravity


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the text of a press release from the National Democratic Coalition of Nigeria (NADECO).

We received with great shock the news of the assassination of Alhaja Kudirat Abiola, wife of the detained winner of the 1993 Nigerian presidential election, Chief MKO Abiola. The world has become used to bad news from Nigeria but no one, in his or her wildest imagination, would have thought that the Nigerian regime would descend so low as to engineer the calculated cold blooded murder of an innocent and courageous wife whose husband they are holding in unjust detention. 

We are aware of the many direct and indirect approaches, including threats, to try to get Kudirat Abiola to betray her husband by modifying her support of Chief Abiola's mandate. But Kudirat stood firm. Now, like the many fallen and yet unsung heroes of the Nigerian struggle, Kudirat has paid for principle and courage with her most precious possession - her life ! And with her death, the Abacha regime has finally sunk to the lowest depths of depravity.

Our appeal is to the international community. Ken Saro-Wiwa was murdered by this same regime. The world convulsed momentarily. Mrs. Kudirat Abiola must not be allowed to die in vain. Her death like many before hers was not the work of any hoodlums but the result of organized state terrorism. For long we have tried to convince the world that the Abacha regime is not interested in democracy but is carefully stringing the world along in the hope that, given the ponderous rate at which the world responds to crisis, he just might get away with his antics. Whilst the world is busy looking for evidence that the Abacha transition is genuine we have been trying to make them see that, transition or no transition, Nigeria is gradually sinking into anarchy and possible disintegration. The murder of Mrs Abiola can only further complicate and speed the process.

Nadeco does not want anarchy; Nadeco does not want violence; Nadeco does not want Nigeria to disintegrate. The consequences of violence and ethnic hatred are all too clear in recent history, vide Bosnia and Rwanda to mention only two. But time is getting dangerously short. Unless the United States, the European Union and key African countries act soon, the world will be faced with the spectre of a nation of 100 million people in the process of bitter disintegration. This will result in refugee and humanitarian problems of horrendous proportions for which the long-suffering taxpayers of the western world have to foot the bill. Preventive action now can still avoid unnecessary human suffering and huge outlay by the western world on humanitarian aid and possible peace keeping.

The Nigerian opposition has pursued the struggle in a responsible, non-violent manner. The world would be sending the wrong signals to the more radical Nigerian elements if effective action is not taken now. We have already pointed out that only oil sanctions, freezing of assets, and a ban on air and sporting links can bring the regime to its senses speedily. The world should help Nigeria effect peaceful change. Time is fast running out.

Prof. A. Bolaji Akinyemi/ Gov. John EK Oyegun/ Air Cdre Dan Suleiman (Rtd) Foreign Affairs/ Executive Secretary/Chairman, Spokesman. June 5, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Nalicon Statement On The Murder of Kudirat Abiola


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Washington, DC - The following is a statement from the National Liberation Council of Nigeria on June 5, 1996:

Yet another patriotic Nigerian has been killed for voicing an opinion that the illegal Nigerian regime did not want to hear.

The junta will no doubt try to pin the murder of Kudirat Abiola on armed robbers, it is clear however that this planned assassination was the culmination of months of harrassment. The junta recently brought charges of 'false publication' against Kudirat. She was brought before the court, released and arrested again. She remained unrelenting in her vociferous campaign to obtain her husbands release and recognition of the June 12th mandate. 

Now Kudirat Abiola has been murdered, and Sani Abacha's fingerprints are all over her corpse. She joins Chief Alfred Rewane, Ken Saro-Wiwa and a host of others on Nigeria's ever lengthening roll-call of martyrs that indict the very existence of this regime.

Nalicon has no doubt that the junta are responsible for the murder of this brave woman, and calls on Nigerians to act with restraint, but with undiminished resolve. The junta is itching to create a situation that will justify the imposition of a state of emergency under which other crimes against humanity will become even more routine. Let the nation remain vigilant but uncowed.

The international community must acknowledge the evidence before their eyes. This regime has neither the ability nor the intention to return the country to civilian rule. Those who speak out against the military junta risk their lives.

The Military dictators have been emboldened by the repeated failure of the international community to back their words with decisive action. This inaction has merely served to show the despots that they can kill their critics with impunity.

The time has come to stop trying to appease this criminal regime. Again we call on the free nations of this world to unite in bringing pressure to bear on this regime by imposing economic sanctions including an oil embargo, and freezing all known assets of the members of this regime.

We call on the international community to be specific in their demands which must include the immediate release of all political prisoners including Moshood Abiola and an agreement to hand over the task of ushering in democracy to a civilian body immediately.

A failure to act decisively now is likely to result in a spiralling violence and bloodshed within the country, with consequent destabilisation of the West African subregion.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


365 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


United States and Africa Shattuck Outlines U.S. Support for Rwandan Tribunal


BYLINE: Africa News Service June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 1707 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is a statement by John Shattuck, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for democracy, during a briefing on Rwanda co-sponsored by the Congressional Human Rights Caucus and the Congressional Black Caucus June 6.

Mr. Chairmen, thank you for inviting me to meet with you today to discuss the International War Crimes Tribunal for Rwanda.

I am particularly pleased to be able to brief you at this time, particularly in light of significant, breaking developments regarding the Tribunal, and coming, as it does so soon after my recent trip to (the) region with Rwanda/Burundi Coordinator Ambassador Richard Bogosian, which focused in large part on the Tribunal and on justice issues in Rwanda. This trip was part of the Administration's broad effort to bring peace and stability to the region.

WHY WE SUPPORT THE TRIBUNAL

The United States strongly supports the work of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda in bringing to justice those individuals responsible for the genocide in Rwanda in which hundred of thousands of people were killed in 1994. We believe the Tribunal has a key role to play in promoting peaceful settlement of conflicts and long-term respect for human rights. 

RECENT DEVELOPMENTS: RESULT OF INTENSIVE EFFORT AND COOPERATION

The Tribunal at Arusha, Tanzania, last week took important steps toward beginning the trials of those persons accused of the 1994 genocide.

Three persons, Georges Anderson Rutaganda, Jean Paul Akayesu, and Clement Kayishema appeared in court on May 30 and 31, had the charges read against them, and entered their pleas.

These first appearances were the result of months of careful work by the Tribunal and growing cooperation by other countries, particularly by other African countries who have come to realize the Tribunal's value to the region.

The Government of Zambia, after appeals from the Tribunal and the Government of Rwanda, arrested a number of suspects; they were subsequently indicted by the Tribunal and held in Zambia at the request of the Tribunal until being transferred to Arusha on May 26. A third, Clement Kayishema was arrested last month at the request of the Tribunal, and also held by Zambia until his transfer to Arusha.

Ten other suspects have been detained in Cameroon; four of these have been provisionally charged. These include Col. Theoneste Bagosora, suspected of being one of the chief architects of the genocide, and Ferdinand Nahimana, who directed Radio Mille Collines, the hate radio which exhorted the population to commit the killings. We hope to see these four transferred to Arusha in the near future.

In addition, there are three suspects now being held in Belgium and another in Switzerland, all of whom will hopefully be transferred in coming weeks. Eight others have been indicted but not yet arrested, and are believed to be living in Zaire.

The United States has actively encouraged the Tribunal to move forward expeditiously on indictments and transfers. When other countries have arrested suspects, we have stepped in to encourage their cooperation with the Tribunal and have at times served to pass messages in countries where communications are difficult. We have urged other countries, including Kenya and Zaire, where suspected war criminals are believed to reside, to be responsive to requests from the Tribunal to make arrests. Finally, we have successfully urged countries with competing claims to extradition, especially Rwanda, hundreds of thousands of whose citizens were murdered, and Belgium, ten of whose peacekeepers were brutally killed, to recognize the primacy of the Tribunal's jurisdiction in trying these war criminals.

COOPERATION WITH THE GOVERNMENT OF RWANDA:

On our recent trip, Ambassador Bogosian and I were particularly pleased to see the stepped-up cooperation between the Tribunal and the Government of Rwanda. Rwandan Government leaders acknowledged the benefit to Rwanda of having key figures in the genocide tried by the International Tribunal and we have urged them to continue their cooperation with the Tribunal. We believe this kind of cooperation can assist Rwanda in moving forward in its own efforts to bring to justice those accused of participating in the genocide.

THE SITUATION IN RWANDA:

The work of the Tribunal is closely tied to the justice situation in Rwanda. In the year since my last visit, the Rwandan justice system, which was decimated by the civil war and genocide, has progressed significantly. The physical infrastructure is being rebuilt; judicial personnel are being trained; and the laws necessary to go forward with the prosecutions are now with the Parliament for consideration.

The U.S. has contributed substantially to these programs, with $4.5 million in FY 95 and an anticipated $2.5 million in FY 96 for our Administration of Justice program which has contributed to training new magistrates, rebuilding of courtrooms, and advice on reform, and $1.2 million for our ICITAP program to assist in training the police. This, coupled with sustained diplomatic engagement demonstrates the positive results to be gotten through our assistance. The process is on track. In addition, we visited three prisons and emphasized to Rwandan authorities our concern about horrendous and continuing overcrowding. The Deputy Justice Minister described efforts under way to use U.S.-donated tents to expand prison space.

U.S. SUPPORT FOR THE TRIBUNAL:

U.S. support for the Tribunal remains a key element of our Rwanda policy. Since the establishment of the International War Crimes Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR), we have been one of the Tribunal's most active supporters, not only politically, but financially and logistically as well. Beyond the regular 1994-95 U.N. budget assessment of $1,683,000, we have made voluntary contributions in the form of cash, personnel, goods, database development, and sharing of information at an estimated cost of $3,900,000. We hope to contribute an additional $500,000 this year for personnel. The U.N. budget for the Tribunal for this year is $40.1 million.

A substantial portion of our voluntary contributions are personnel, sub-contracted under the Department of Justice's ICITAP mechanism. Thus far, the U.S. has ten individuals sub-contracted to work for the Tribunal: three investigators, one interpreter, and six case managers. The U.S. has also sponsored the temporary assignment of two computer specialists to the Tribunal.

In addition, the U.S. was responsible for the establishment of a Rwanda Tribunal Documentation Center. Essentially, the Documentation Center, housing thousands of unclassified documents on war crimes suspects, will help provide the information necessary to ensure full and effective investigations and trials. This U.S.-sponsored project has gone toward the development of a database and provided for the hiring of six case-managers responsible for handling Tribunal investigators' requests for document information.

A lack of equipment and supplies has hampered Rwanda Tribunal investigations from the start. The Clinton Administration has attempted to fix these deficiencies with the purchase and delivery of thousands of dollars worth of equipment, most notably secure-communications equipment, microfilm printer-readers, photocopy machines, computers, and Polaroid cameras. Most recently, we sponsored a humanitarian airlift of excess Department of Defense equipment, including vehicles, forensic equipment, computers, and office furniture. Judge Goldstone has expressed deep appreciation for the timely delivery of these urgently needed items.

MORE TO BE DONE:

Needless to say, and despite our contributions and those of other governments, there is still a tremendous amount of work to be done. The genocide in Rwanda was unique in the scale of involvement of ordinary citizens at the behest of their government, yet little was committed to paper, making it difficult to put together dossiers on individual suspects. In his recent visit, Justice Goldstone reiterated a plea he had made earlier in Geneva for additional investigators and prosecutors. The U.S. will attempt to be responsive to his request.

Despite these difficulties, the important first steps have now been taken at Arusha. As trials begin and the spotlight is shown on the Tribunal and the contribution it can make to accountability for this terrible genocide, the people of Rwanda can begin to move forward toward reconciliation and justice.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
