Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria and South Africa The Altar Of Solidarity


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Johannesburg - Alfred Nzo, it has to be said, is not a man favoured by Lady Luck. On the day our foreign minister makes a grand gesture towards the ideal of consultation -- in the process conceding that our government has done a U-turn on Nigeria -- the wife of that country's imprisoned president-elect, Chief Abiola, is shot dead in Lagos. But, as many a gambler would be happy to advise Nzo, luck has to be earned. With that in mind we feel less than sympathetic towards the minister. 

Nzo's gesture towards consultation this week came in the form of a so-called "Green Paper," offering his ministry's views on foreign policy as a basis for a national debate. While the initiative is to be welcomed, the
discussion document is not.

It suggests that South Africa should adopt a "leadership role ... without politically antagonising the country's African partners". In apparent justification of this Nzo cites the difficulties he ran into with the Nigerian saga, when South Africa found itself the only African country breaking diplomatic ties over the Saro-Wiwa hangings and the only country on the continent calling for sanctions against the Abacha regime. As a result, according to the minister, we found ourselves breaching what he characterises as "the norms of
solidarity".

The betrayal of principle inherent in this pusillanimous approach is self-evident. And the price to be paid for such betrayal was illustrated by the murder of Kudiratu Abiola. If we had stayed on course with our original approach to Nigeria we would be proud of our stand this week. As it is, we are once again wiping egg off our collective face.

The word "pride" points to the difficulty under which Nzo may be labouring a
misunderstanding of what foreign policy is about. It needs to be appreciated by the government that it is not expected to reform the world, or Africa, or, even Nigeria.

Nelson Mandela did us proud when he took the stand on principle which cost him much of his life in prison, but which finally broke the back of apartheid. The ANC's negotiators did us proud when they faced down the National Party on issues of principle and secured democratic rule. Now we want to make a
contribution to the cause of humanity, to discharge our duties as members of the
international community. And we want to take pride in that as well.

To be fair to Nzo there are some aspects of our foreign policy in which we can take pride. Our support of Cuba comes to mind. But the reverse side of the coin is Libya. Can we really take pride in support of an
authoritarian dictatorship which is probably busy developing a chemical weapons industry and which is certainly making a sizeable contribution to the politics of violence in various parts of the world, including Africa ?

The choices we face on the diplomatic front can be difficult. They will be that much more difficult if we sacrifice principle on the altar of solidarity.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


367 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Kenya Corruption Scandal Hits


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Charles Wachira


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Nairobi - Corruption in state firms alone has been costing Kenya an average of $104,5-million annually, according a parliamentary probe, but chances are not much will be done with the investigators' findings.

In a 672-page draft report, Kenya's Parliamentary Accounts Committee (PAC) reveals that in six years the heads of the country's 56 state firms misappropriated 36,8-billion shillings.

In hard currency terms, that's $627-million - -- more than the $508-million, which, according to the World Bank, Kenya received in official development assistance in 1994. 

The officials who committed the frauds were members of the ruling Kenya National African Union (Kanu), according to the draft. Thus, when the 11-member PAC issued it, state officials refused to release additional documents the committee needed to complete its investigations.

According to PAC Chairman Kijana Wamalwa, leader of the opposition Forum for the
Restoration of Democracy, the officials have refused to provide critical information on audit queries and have stonewalled investigations by denying the PAC access to crucial sites.

Opposition members of the PAC also say the committee's work has been hampered by the abusive application by the speaker of parliament of the sub judice rule. He argued that the issues were under judicial consideration and therefore were prohibited from public discussion.

"The very unco-operative attitude adopted by government officers shows that the state is afraid of an independent inquiry," Wamalwa said.

Those fingered by the report include Moi's private lawyer, Simeon Mauncho, whose two firms Yamco Limited and Nchoke Limited are accused of fraudulently obtaining the
equivalent of $55 172 from the National Cereals and Produce Board.

Another ally of the president, Kipng'eno arap Ng'eny, former chief executive of the Kenya Posts and Telecommunications Corporation, is accused of charging the utility $1 431 003 in consultancy fees for an abandoned project.

Time is running out for the PAC. Its deadline is June 11, by which date parliament expects the final report to be tabled. In desperation, the committee's five opposition members have written to President Daniel Arap Moi, seeking his intervention to force the release of the outstanding documents.

According to Wamalwa, attorney general Amos Wako, parliamentary speaker Francis ole Kaparo, Fares Kuindwa -- who heads the public service -- Joseph Sang, permanent secretary in the Ministry of Lands, and financial secretary Joseph Kinyua should be forced to provide the information the
committee needed.

"We have taken the unusual step of seeking your excellency's intervention in view of the grave constitutional crisis that has been precipitated by your officers' and the speaker's conduct," the five PAC members explained in their letter at the end of May.

However, Moi dismissed the request as a "political gimmick".

"Our appeal to the president was in realisation that the presidency is the confluence of the three arms of government ... and that as the head of the executive, he could order officers to give the vital information required by the committee," Wamalwa said.

On the other hand, Kanu members of the PAC team criticised their colleagues' action.

"We condemn strongly this move which amounts to contempt of the laid down standing orders of parliament," said Kanu legislator George Ndotto. "According to order number 161, no evidence received by and no documents presented to a select committee shall be published or otherwise disclosed to any person other than a member of the house."


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


368 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zimbabwe and South Africa Trade Policies Attacked


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Brian Latham


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Harare - Relations between South Africa and the rest of the region are at their worst since the end of apartheid.

When South African trade minister Alec Erwin visits Zimbabwe this week, he will be astonished at the level of anger which meets him over South African tariffs and subsidies which have left the region devastated by unfair trade practices.

South Africa's economy is 20 times bigger than Zimbabwe's, but prior to South Africa's inclusion in the Southern African Development Community (SADC), Zimbabwe accounted for more than 50 percent of gross domestic product in the region.

Many businesspeople in the region feel South Africa should decide whether it belongs to the SADC or the South African Customs Union (Sacu), saying that membership of both allows South Africa to move the goalposts. 

John Robertson, a leading economist in Zimbabwe, claims that South Africa is a victim of its own history. "Sacu is very expensive for South Africa," he said. "Customs duty payments are shared within Sacu, but these could never be extended to a country like Zimbabwe. It was a sort of political buying off of Botswana, Swaziland and Lesotho during the apartheid years, the need for which has gone." He added that disbanding Sacu requires the assent of all members, making South Africa's position difficult.

South Africa has imposed import tariffs of between 60 and 90% on many countries in the region -- and a deposit tariff of 125% on goods in transit. The World Trade Organisation (WTO), which recommends tariffs of no more than 35%, has given South Africa a moratorium on bringing import duties down which lasts well into the next century. But elsewhere in the region, manufacturers argue South Africa's high import duties were deviously imposed just before South Africa joined the WTO. "They may have done this so that they could negotiate down," said Robertson.

The dispute is further complicated by South African subsidies for manufactured exports, a measure brought in by the previousm administration in its fight against sanctions. The subsidy allows, for instance, South Africa to sell car batteries in Zimbabwe and Zambia at a price well below their production price in those countries.

As a part of their economic reforms, most countries in the region have removed all producer subsidies. This is despite levels of productivity in South Africa being well below Zimbabwe and, in certain sectors, below even Tanzania and Kenya.

Elsewhere within the SADC, governments and business alike accuse South Africa of pandering to both its trade organisations and its militant trade unions who fear competition and job losses. South Africa counters that its fight is not against imported goods from the SADC alone, but also from the Far East. South African officials allege that Zimbabwe has been used as a conduit for cheap textiles from China, dressed up as Zimbabwean clothing.

Accusing South Africa of economic imperialism, manufacturers in the SADC say that it is unfair to penalise the region simply because South Africa is unable to police its civil servants.

Mark O'Donnell, chairman of the Zambian Association of Manufacturers, says that South Africa has again gone into the laager. "They would like to control the region," he claims, adding that his country's 13-to-one trade imbalance is worsening by the month.

Appearances appear to back him up. At the Shoprite supermarket on Lusaka's Cairo Road, even the milk is from South Africa -- and the Spur restaurant flies in meat from Johannesburg. On the street, hundreds of hungry vendors sell cheap products as diverse as toys and perfume -- often labelled in Afrikaans.

The region remains divided on how to tackle South Africa's devastating push into Africa, with many countries seemingly willing to let South Africa and Zimbabwe battle it out.

Zambia would prefer its own dispensation with the southern giant. "We cannot sustain the imbalance," said O'Donnell, "but our position is not the same as Zimbabwe's. Our impact on the South African economy would be negligible even if the tariffs were removed, whereas Zimbabwe could have a significant impact."

But there is another issue and it is charged with emotion. The countries worst affected by South African protectionism are all former "frontline states", countries which suffered, to a greater or lesser degree, the ravages of destabilisation and the torment brought about by helping and providing shelter to those who now rule South Africa.

O'Donnell says Zambians are hurt by their exclusion -- and Zimbabweans say Mandela is doing more harm to their economy than
apartheid ever did.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


369 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria and South Africa Abiola's Death Won't Change Pretoria's Policy


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Stefaans Brummer and Sapa-AFP


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Johannesburg - The apparent assassination of Kudiratu Abiola, activist wife of imprisoned Nigerian leader Chief Moshood Abiola, is unlikely to prompt South Africa to formulate a stronger policy against Nigeria's military government.

Abiola (44) died from a gunshot wound to the head in Lagos on Tuesday, the same day Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo publicly acknowledged South Africa had toned down its hardline stance on Nigeria in response to accusations by South Africa's partners on the continent that it was acting against African solidarity.

Nzo told Parliament's foreign affairs committee it was "important to go along with other countries", while "we have not retracted from our call for Nigeria to embark on democracy". This confirmed the view that President Nelson Mandela's call for sanctions against Nigeria, first made after the execution last year of Nigerian minority rights activist Ken Saro-Wiwa, had been dropped in favour of a softer common African position. 

This week the African National Congress's labour partner, the Congress of South African Trade Unions, made a new call for sanctions -- and South African high commissioner to Nigeria, George Nene, joined mourners at Abiola's funeral on Wednesday afternoon -- but it seems unlikely Nzo's ministry will plot a new policy course for now.

A Foreign Affairs representative said: "We decided at a summit that we would work through the SADC (the Southern African Development Community)... I don't think that will change."

South Africa's deputy high commissioner to Nigeria, Jan van Jaarsveld, said members of the diplomatic corps doubted Nigerian dictator General Sani Abacha's statement that the attack on Kudiratu Abiola, her driver and her personal assistant, had been a robbery attempt.

He said: "Her car was forced from the road at a T-junction. People are talking about several shots from an automatic gun. But what raises suspicion is that she died of a single shot to the head."

Van Jaarsveld said the driver had died of several wounds, but the personal assistant, who was unscathed, had been arrested by the Nigerian police "to help with the investigation" . He said this came across as a possible attempt to keep him away from publicly giving his version of events.

Van Jaarsveld said in spite of suspicions about the attack, it would not have immediate bearing on South Africa's policy: the police investigation would have to be evaluated first.

Millionaire newspaper tycoon Moshood Abiola has been in virtual solitary confinement, awaiting trial on charges of treason, since he declared himself president in 1994 -- the year after the military government run by Sani Abacha annulled elections he appeared to have won.

Kudiratu Abiola, who married him in 1973 and was one of a number of wives -- and was said to be his favourite -- was also one of the main figures in Nigeria's opposition.

Last month she appeared in court on charges of conspiracy and making false statements. She and two co-accused pleaded not guilty and her trial was to have started on July 17. The charges apparently arose from interviews she gave to Nigerian and foreign media in which she called for her husband's release from prison.

Nigerian police said in a statement they had "directed a full-scale investigation" and pledged that "no stone will be left unturned in unravelling the perpetrators of this heinous crime".

On Wednesday police made several arrests when they broke up a protest against the assassination by thousands of students in the city of Ibadan.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


370 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Angola Wagons Roll


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Antonio Mateus/Lusa


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Johannesburg - Portugal and South Africa last month found themselves partners in a peace mission to Angola, where more than two-thirds of the people have known only war in their lifetimes.

This kilometre-long convoy (above), seen here passing through Huila province in south-western Angola, is one of the longest ever launched by the United Nations in Africa. It was also the first road convoy from South Africa to Angola in decades. It took 11 grinding days to travel from Pretoria to Luanda via Lobito, to deliver 60 tons of aid to the rebel Unita movement.

After crossing the Namibian border into Angola, the average speed of the convoy was about 30 km/h. A second United Nations convoy of trucks will leave from Waterkloof, Pretoria, for Luanda, sponsored by South Africa and driven by United Nations and Portuguese logistics personnel.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


371 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Angola New Army To Usher In Peace?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Victoria Brittain


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Luanda - The Angolan military leadership has started to form a unified national army to bring an end to the United Nations' peacekeeping process.

The move comes as the political leadership tries to shape a new government following the dismissal of the prime minister, the government and the central bank governor by President Jose Eduardo dos Santos.

Fernando Franca van Dunem, the national assembly president appointed as prime minister to replace Marcolino Moco, is under pressure to pick a cabinet quickly. 

As the political crisis was erupting in the first week of June, the first 15 officers from Jonas Savimbi's Unita guerrilla army were being incorporated into the Angolan Armed Forces (FAA) and the process of selecting 26 000 Unita soldiers for the army was beginning under a two-month deadline set by the FAA chief of staff, General Joao de Matos.

General Matos said the new army would be complete by July 30.

"At that point the state administration will be restored over the whole country. We are tired of this peace process, it's been going on too long.

'The country is in a morass, the people are exhausted, the international community has had enough. So much money is being wasted by the UN," he said.

Within the UN there is growing concern about the credibility of its largest peacekeeping operation, costing more than $1-million a day.

At least half of the 35 000 Unita men registered in the 11 UN quartering areas are not soldiers, according to UN and aid officials. One-third of them came without weapons, according to General Matos.

In addition, no heavy weapons of any sort have been handed in, the munitions relinquished are derisory, and new arms supplies are regularly being flown in by Unita from Zaire, he said.

A UN official said: "Unita has not even begun a serious effort towards disarming and demobilising, 18 months after the Lusaka accords, and there is no sign of any change in their attitudes."

The mood among both UN and aid agency personnel is pessimistic, despite the robust optimism of the UN secretary general's special representative, Aliyoun Blondin Beye. He believes the problem of non-surrendered weapons will be rectified by Unita, and does not accept that there is any problem with the identities of the people already quartered.

General Philip Sibanda, the Zimbabwean military commander of the UN force, said, however: "It is clear we do not have the best troops in the quartering areas, we do not have the best weapons, we do not have ammunition or other war stores, explosives, communications equipment."

Last year's ceasefire left Unita in control of over half the country, though some areas are barely populated.

General Matos said the UN could not monitor what was going on in Unita areas, or where the soldiers outside the quartering areas were being kept.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


372 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Changes Considered At Broadcast Company


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Jacquie Golding-Duffy


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Johannesburg - Most of the SABC's current affairs programmes may be scrapped to accommodate African-language viewers.

SABC television analyst Don Seokane said the decision to reduce the corporation's eight current affairs programmes was not yet finalised, but the management of Television News had attended a bosberaad last month where proposals on repositioning the corporation's news department were garnered.

Television News management, he said, was only at this stage "considering increasing the time allocated for news bulletins and reducing the number of Focus programmes". 

This means news bulletins could be accompanied by packaged current affairs programmes of between 15 and 30 minutes long, in the language used during the news bulletin.

"Current affairs programmes are predominantly in English and management, in reassessing the situation, felt African-language groups should be accommodated. It was proposed that extra time be latched on to African-language bulletins, allowing for a current affairs programme to occur in any of the indigenous languages," Seokane said.

The bosberaad involved all the regional news heads, heads of the various sections, including current affairs, and Television News editor-in-chief Joe Thloloe.

Seokane said it was believed that the various news sections could be more "effective", and the proposal arose from concerns that current affairs programmes in particular may not be complying with the language requirements stipulated by the Independent Broadcasting Authority.

A meeting between Television News management and channel heads was planned this week to gather more proposals and discuss the feasibility of attaching packaged current affairs programmes to news slots, he added.

"The length of the current affairs programmes depend on the air time allocated on each channel, but nothing in this regard has been finalised. It is still in the process of discussion and is a mere proposal."

Although the SABC is adamant that the proposal is based around accommodating South Africa's 11 languages, some sources within the corporation argue that this is a cost-cutting exercise, an effort to increase audience ratings and a bid to attract more advertising revenue around its flagship programmes.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


373 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa The Royal House Of Scandals


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Ann Eveleth


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

Johannesburg - The Zulu royal house faces a House of Windsor-style controversy as its political enemies make sordid allegations of familial sex, royal rivalry, abduction and bribery.

Claims by the powerful Prince Clement Zulu that King Goodwill Zwelithini's spokesman Prince Sifiso Zulu had admitted to sexually abusing a young princess is the first salvo in an impending propaganda war of the princes.

Sifiso Zulu's attorney hit back with claims that Clement had tried to convince Sifiso to vacate his post and settle in the United States. The attorney, Samuel Nkosi, said the sexual abuse allegations appeared to be part of a smear campaign waged by Clement Zulu after Sifiso Zulu refused to leave the country voluntarily. 

The claims -- first published by the Zulu-language newspaper UmAfrika -- were the subject of serious concern among African National Congress and Inkatha Freedom Party MPs in the provincial corridors of power this week. Clement Zulu's allegations were the latest in a series of scandals which have plagued Sifiso Zulu since he lurched into controversy in late 1994 as Zwelithini severed ties with IFP leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi.

The IFP-owned Zulu-language newspaper Ilanga claimed last year that Sifiso Zulu had had an affair with Zwelithini's youngest wife, Nompumelelo.

While Sifiso Zulu argued that the latest allegations should be seen in this context, senior ANC KwaZulu-Natal leaders -- including provincial chairman Jacob Zuma -- are said to have intervened in the latest crisis.

The ANC leaders are believed to have taken the allegations -- this time lodged by a royal council heavyweight credited with prising Zwelithini away from Buthelezi -- seriously.

Nkosi -- who also represents the alleged victims and their mother, Sifiso Zulu's sister-in-law, Gladys Zulu -- blamed the saga on two VIP bodyguards previously assigned to protect Sifiso Zulu. The two princesses reside with him in Durban, while their mother lives along the KwaZulu-Natal North Coast.

Clement Zulu alleged that Sifiso Zulu had admitted sexually abusing 21-year-old Princess Nana Zulu when Constable Mfanafuthi Mhlungu confronted him about the matter in his presence. Clement Zulu subsequently reported the matter to Zwelithini, and Gladys Zulu had intended to do the same, he said.

Nkosi countered that "no charges to that effect have been filed", and said affidavits from Gladys Zulu and the princesses told a different story. Excerpts from Gladys Zulu's affidavit in the possession of the Mail & Guardian portray an elaborate plot to discredit Sifiso Zulu: "On about April 9, constables Mhlungu and (Khanyisani) Mazibuko ... asked me to assist them and Prince Clement Zulu to remove Prince Sifiso Zulu from his position.

"They suggested that we could use my children as if they were sexually abused or ill-treated in whatever manner, and report that to the king so that the king could remove him as his spokesperson. They told me Prince Clement had already prepared the king, therefore our effort would be an easy one."

Rejecting the allegation, Clement Zulu said: "Gladys is lying because she wants to protect somebody and smear me." He added that he was "very happy" with Sifiso Zulu 's performance as the monarch's spokesman and had "no reason" to try to discredit him.

Clement Zulu admitted he had suggested that Sifiso Zulu should "try to get a scholarship to go overseas", but said this was intended to avoid a scandal.

Gladys Zulu further alleged that the two VIP guards had offered to bribe her to report the allegations to Zwelithini, and on April 12 had "produced their police appointment cards and ... took me by force, very much against my will and very much against our tradition, to Nongoma (in northern Natal)."

Gladys Zulu said a car accident prevented the group from seeing the monarch. Nkosi filed a complaint with National Protection Services' Senior Superintendent, Hendrick Olivier, alleging the VIP members had threatened her.

Olivier said possible charges related to the car accident were under investigation, but "the complainant refused to file charges" relating to the harassment allegations.

In a further twist, the car in which Gladys Zulu and the VIP members crashed is alleged to belong to an Elias Khumalo -- a man whose name has cropped up as a possible replacement for Sifiso Zulu.

Now the allegations are in the hands of KwaZulu-Natal Attorney General Tim McNally, according to South African Police Service Director Bala Naidoo. He stressed that they currently rested on a "third party report -- there is no statement of complaint as yet."

Given the lapse of time, it appears no complaint will be lodged. However, the war of the princes has added fuel to recent public controversy over the Zulu royal family. Debate over the monarch's R17-million budget and a new luxury mansion he is alleged to be eyeing in Durban's La Lucia suburb -- denied by the royal council -- and political controversy over his relationship with IFP Premier Frank Mdlalose have put the monarch and his family in the public spotlight as never before.

Newspaper reports involving the intimate details of royal family squabbles were unheard of in the days when Zwelithini was ensconced in the former KwaZulu homeland. Constitutional monarchy is changing all that, as the family is quickly learning.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


374 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa The Man Behind SA's Proposed News Agency


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Justin Pearce


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Johannesburg - If everyone is entitled to 15 minutes of fame, Sol Kotane's quarter-hour struck when his photograph was splashed across a full page in RDP News, in the illustrious company of Nelson Mandela, Thabo Mbeki, and FW de Klerk.

Together they made up a pull-out centrefold, with such captions as "The leader of the nation and the architect of the RDP" for Mandela; "Leading the Sacs in communicating the RDP" for Kotane; and "Close to the heartthrob of the RDP" for De Klerk.

Sol Kotane, head of the South African Communications Service (Sacs), has become a figure of major controversy after championing plans to establish a government-funded news agency.

Last weekend, Sunday Independent columnist Zakes Mda described the idea as "the mother of all hare-brained schemes", concluding: "The government needs to communicate, but a government-controlled news agency is neither viable nor desirable in South Africa." 

For a man who is often dismissed as a wannabe propagandist, Kotane appears engagingly frank as he replies to the battering he has received in the media. He seems embarrassed that the RDP News -- published by Sacs -- had, with the photos, stepped into what one seasoned hack described as the "Ho Chi Minh school of journalism" rather than sticking to its brief of reporting on the development of the government.

"From a journalistic point of view I don't think it was in good taste to do that, especially to include my photograph," Kotane admits, adding that RDP News is produced by a team and it was not his decision to run the large photos.

Kotane's background can only add to fears that his news agency plans are a way of using taxpayers' money to trumpet the glories of the government. Most of Kotane's media education took place under the auspices of the Department of Information and Publicity (DIP) of the ANC in exile, where former colleagues say he did not hold a particularly senior position.

His active experience in the print media consists of a spell as a junior on the Bulawayo Chronicle, a faithful follower of the Mugabe regime, and at the Pan-African News Agency (Pana) which is funded by the Organisation of African Unity and which operates spasmodically. Pana's failure has been blamed on its inability to offer a voice independent from the outpourings of state- controlled agencies across the continent.

Suspicions about Kotane's intentions deepened when, while explaining his proposals to Parliament's Select Committee on Communications, he praised the partisan Zimbabwean government news agency, Ziana.

Kotane insists he was quoted out of context on Ziana -- it was only one example among several that he cited, he says. And his long association with the ANC translates not into a conviction that the regime will always do right, but into a blind faith that the government's commitment to freedom of expression will never falter.

"Looking at the position of the government, what I see is support for freedom of
expression -- not the muzzling of opinions."

Not only will government continue to allow other media a free rein, he believes, but government can succeed where the commercial press failed in mirroring South Africa to itself.

He pre-empts suspicions of a hidden agenda by taking an old-school liberal view of the media. News, in Kotane's view, is not a means of control -- it is a service.

"The government has an obligation to establish something to help deliver information to its constituency," he says. "I appreciate the role played by the newspapers and Sapa (the South African Press Association, an independent national agency). But is that enough?"

Unlike many who bang the empowerment drum, he sounds almost apologetic about raising the question of race, and his criticisms of the shortcomings of existing media could not be more diplomatic: "In the 60 years of Sapa's existence, the majority voice never had a platform. I am not lumping the blame on Sapa -- the regime of the day did not want to encourage a diversity of opinion."

Kotane's vision is of a news agency which can reach into the remotest village and the most miserable squatter camp in the country, and come back with the stories. And if no one else is going to do this, then the government can and the government will.

Kotane declares the agency will enjoy editorial autonomy and will even carry articles critical of the government -- a notion which has been greeted with scepticism by observers of the history of any number of other well-intentioned schemes in Africa.

Kotane is bullish about the agency's chances of success in an environment very different from countries like Zimbabwe where state-owned newspapers are a captive market for a state- owned news agency. He would like to see the large papers subscribe to a government service, but if they don't, then he is confident that mostly rural community papers will jump at the chance of news that is not filtered through the big city press.

Some have accused Kotane of being an empire- builder, citing the pin-up portrait in RDP News, and Kotane's brief but amply rewarded spell as head of Bophuthatswana Broadcasting which began with no prior broadcasting experience, and ended after little more than a year with a retrenchment package of around R100 000. This incident is one which Kotane explains away without embarrassment: he says he was entitled to R500 000, but thought it would not be appropriate.

He unblinkingly refutes the idea that the proposed news agency will continue to swallow taxpayers' money until the end of time: if it has served its purpose after a decade, then let it be disbanded, he says.

Victor Moche, who worked with Kotane in the DIP, describes him as "not ambitious, but tenacious -- sometimes to a frustrating level. When he bites into something he has to be prised off."

Talking to Kotane, it is clear that it will take a lot to prise him away from his plans for a government news agency. He acknowledges that the future of government communications policy is still a matter for discussion, but the enthusiasm with which he talks about the agency plan makes it quite clear where his intentions lie -- never mind the costs to the taxpayer, and the fears that a state news agency will inevitably become a propaganda tool.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


375 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Angola and South Africa Crisis Leads To Visit Cancellation


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) June 7, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Johannesburg - President Nelson Mandela has called off his visit to Angola in the wake of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos's sacking of his Cabinet and the governor of the central bank.

Mandela was to have left South Africa on Tuesday for a largely symbolic visit, during which he would have addressed the Angolan Parliament. It was intended as a gesture of goodwill to send a signal that the United Nations-brokered peace process was working and to boost confidence in the region. 

"The president sent a note to President Dos Santos this morning asking that the visit be rescheduled due to prevailing circumstances," said presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana.

"The president feels it would be inconsiderate to impose a state visit of this magnitude on the Angolan government while they were undergoing a period of transition."

In the letter Mandela assured Dos Santos of his full support in addressing the problems which had led to the dissolution of the government and said he was committed to ensuring the success of the peace process.

Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo will travel to Angola on Monday to convey a personal message to President Dos Santos from Mandela.

On Monday, Dos Santos axed prime minister Marcolino Moco and all his ministers and suspended the country's foreign exchange trade.

"He is getting rid of the people blamed for the economic crisis in the country," said Institute for International Affairs researcher Glenn Oosthuysen. "He could be making them scapegoats, however. Angola is run by the military -- the generals have their finger in every economic pie. Civil society doesn't really exist."

By presidential decree, Dos Santos named Fernando Franca van Dunem as the new prime minister. Van Dunem now has five days to form a new government, which is expected to make better headway in pushing through economic reforms.

Oosthuysen said he expected Unita would "make a meal of it" should the new government comprise only members of the ruling party, the MPLA, but said this would only be of rhetorical value. "It is too early to expect Unita to come into the government."

A government of national unity, with key ministries for Unita, is due to be formed at some stage this year.

Unita leader Jonas Savimbi's troops were not yet demobilised and each side was accusing the other of rearming. It was unclear what progress had been made on the integration of the two forces, due to have begun on June 1.

June, 1996


Ethiopia Eye Diseases Afflict 2.5 Million Ethiopians


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 5, 1996


LENGTH: 240 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - About 2.5 million Ethiopians are afflicted by curable blindness, including 500,000 suffering from cataract, according to a leading ophthalmologist, Dr. Tebebe Yemane-Berhan.

He disclosed this during a press conference last week at which he announced that 581 patients had their eye sight restored in the north-western town of Bahr Dar on Lake Tana. 

The operation was jointly undertaken by the Addis Ababa Lions Club and the Mombasa Pwani Club, Kenya, in cooperation with the Ethiopian Opthalomlogists Association.

Tebebe stated that the May 16-24 Bahr Dar operations had been successful not only in terms of the number of patients treated, but also "because it had enabled to revive the visions of people who had been needlessly blinded by cataract."

The Lions Club of Addis Ababa had earlier this year cooperated Awith a sister club in Mombasa, Kenya, in conducting a medical eye camp at Merhabete, in north Shoa province, about 200 kilometers north of of the Ethiopian capital.

June, 1996


Swaziland Swaziland Sets Up Anti-Corruption Unit


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 5, 1996 by Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 467 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland - Swaziland said Wednesday it had established the country's first anti-corruption unit in an effort to curb massive graft in the public and private sectors.

In its official gazette published Wednesday, the government said a bill providing for a budget allocation for the operations of the new unit was passed by parliament earlier in 1996. A motion instructed Justice Minister Maweni Simelane to set up the unit as soon as possible. 

A followup bill, explaining full details of the powers of the unit and it operations, is to be tabled in parliament within the next two weeks. It is expected to pass without delay and be given royal assent for it to become law.

Simelane said, in the gazette, that the unit would be manned by 25 officers. The posts are to be advertised to get the right people.

The unit's officers will be empowered to arrest, without warrant, any person suspected of an offence bordering on corruption. These officers will be empowered to use force "as is reasonable" in the circumstances to effect arrests.

In what is seen as intended to be a no-nonsense unit, the agency will also be empowered to over-ride the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) in deciding whether to proceed with prosecutions of suspects.

These clauses reflect frequently expressed public dissatisfaction at the soaring rate of serious crime and the blatent large-scale corruption of the police and the office of the DPP.

A number of senior police officers have been transferred over the past few months following alleged police involvement with criminals including drug traffickers and smugglers of stolen vehicles between Swaziland and neighboring Mozambique and South Africa.

Public confidence in the country's judicial system has been shaken, recently, by allegations of fraud against the director of public prosecutions, Adinkrah Donkoh. The police have completed their investigations into allegations that he tried to defraud the Swaziland Royal Insurance Corporation, in connection with his car damaged in an accident.

The police docket has been handed to the DPP office but there is confusion as to who will decide whether Donkoh should be charged and prosecuted.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


378 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Swaziland Tuberculosis Reaches Epidemic Proportions In Swaziland


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 5, 1996 by Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 614 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland - A total of 161 people died of tuberculosis in Swaziland since January this year, according to figures issued by the kingdom's T.B. Control Offices in Manzini.

The figures, given during Swaziland's T.B awareness week, indicated that 60 of the deaths occured during the past three months.

According to Dr Casphina Mabuza, the medical officer incharge of the Swazi T.B control program, some 480 new T.B cases were diagnosed between January and March this year. 

Mabuza said the death rate for 1995 was 215 from a total of 2050 cases.

Tuberculosis cases have been rising since 1993 when 1400 new cases were diagnosed, causing 95 deaths. The next year, 1897 cases were recorded with 147 deaths.

In an interview with the PANA Correpondent in Mbabane Tuesday, Mabuza said what was even more frightening was that the patients who died had reported their illness to the country's hospitals and clinics.

The medical officer said that even the officially reported cases and deaths were no doubt the tip of the iceberg.

According to her, the sharp increase in T.B cases in the country was in proportion to the rapid increase in HIV and AIDS. Similar increases in T.B infections have been noted in other countries with high HIV prevalence in the African region and elsewhere.

The latest HIV figures from the Swazi health ministry show that over 20 percent of the kingdom's sexually-active population lived with the virus that causes the incurable human immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Other factors that fanned the disease include poor sanitation, unbalanced diet resulting from mass movements of populations, refugees from war-torn countries in Africa, and neglect by T.B authorities, Dr Mabuza said.

The doctor said that T.B had become one of the worst and most infectious environmental killer disease in the Swaziland's crowded cities and townships.

"T.B germs are in the air just waiting to be inhaled unknowingly by people. We are all at risk. There is nowhere to hide,' she said.

Asked how people could protect themselves from inhaling unseen T.B. germs, Dr. Mabuza advised against spending hours in crowded closed places such as bars where coughs and sneezes spread the diseases.

Tuberculosis is spread by several species of mycobacterium, collectively called the tubercle bacillus from which the abreviation "T.B" originated.

In man, T.B is caused by the human and bovine varieties of the bacillus, mycobacterium tuberculosis and mycobacterium bovis, respectively.

Dr Mabuza said the best protection from the bacillus was the natural body resistance to disease. This does not work in already weakened bodies, including those of people who live with HIV.

Dr. Mabuza said that the recipe against the disease is a balanced diet, fresh air and exercise.

But she warned that without protected sex to avoid HIV infection, all other protective measures amount to nought.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


379 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Uganda Full Military Honours For Former Ugandan President


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 5, 1996 by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 374 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda - Former Ugandan head of state, Tito Okello Lutwa, who died Tuesday in a Kampala hospital, will be accorded full military honours at his burial.

According to a programme released by the office of the president, Lutwa, 82, will be burried Thursday at the family ancestral ground in the border district of Kitgum, north of the country. 

Doctors at Nsambya hospital, where the former army general had been hospitalised since May 14, declined to disclose the cause of death. However, family friends said he died of liver and heart ailments.

Okello was first admitted in critical condition in March at Nsambya hospital. Then, when his condition worsened, he was flown to a university hospital in Frankfurt, Germany.

After a month of intensive care he seemed to have recovered and left Germany for London to meet members of his family. He flew back May 14 and was immediately readmitted at Nsambya.

In his condolence message, President Yoweri Museveni described Lutwa as "a great man" who was dedicated to the service of his country.

Lutwa assumed the chairmanship of Uganda's Military Council, which overthrew the second government of Milton Obote in 1985. Six months later, on January 25, 1986, the National Resistance Army of Yoweri Museveni ousted his regime.

He fled into exile in Sudan for a year before he was granted political asylum in Tanzania. In 1994, he briefly stayed in Kenya before he returned to Uganda.

Lutwa thus becomes the first former head of state to return and die at home. Two former heads of state, Edward Mutesa, the first post-independence president, and Yusuf Kironde Lule, died in London in 1969 and 1984.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Donors Express Reservations Over Zambia's Constitution


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 5, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, Pana Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia said Wednesday that three donor countries had indicated they would withhold aid to the country, and two others expressed reservations over the new constitution, which bars Zambians with foreign parents standing for president.

Britain, Norway and the United States had indicated their withdrawal of bilateral aid to Zambia after President Frederick Chiluba assented to the bill, Foreign Minister Christon Tembo said. 

He added that Denmark and the Netherlands had expressed reservations on the constitution.

Speaking at a press briefing, Tembo said that the donors were in particular concerned with the timing of the amendment of the constitution which they felt was intended to eliminate former President Kenneth Kaunda from contesting this year's presidential elections. Kaunda had Malawi parents.

The minister said that the government had already held meetings with donors and only a few of them were sceptical over the matter.

Countries belonging to the Southern African Development Community had been briefed on the matter and they indicated that the problem of the constitution bill was an internal matter.

However, two countries, which Tembo did not name, have disputed the constitution.

Meanwhile, Chiluba has appealed to the donor countries to cooperate with his government to develop the country.

He said punishment by donors to withhold aid to Zambia was targetted at ordinary citizens who made the decision to enact the new constitution. He was speaking during the swearing-in ceremony of the newly appointed ministers and other government officials at state house.

The president condemned Zambians who attack his government while visiting other countries, saying their action was unfortunate.

"Where is your pride? Even in poverty there must be a bit of order to preserve our country and promote democracy," Chiluba said.

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Police Chief Orders Probe Into Killing of Abiola's Wife


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 5, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 600 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's inspector-general of police, Ibrahim Coomassie, has ordered a full-scale investigation into Tuesday's slaying of Kudirat Abiola, the outspoken wife of detained millioniare-politician Moshood Abiola.

"No stone will be left unturned in unravelling the perpetrators of this heinous crime," Coomassie said in an appeal for public cooperation in tracing the killers.

Describing the killing by yet-unidentified gunmen as "a serious development," he said a crack team from the police anti-robbery squad, headed by a commissioner, had been charged with the probe. 

Kudirat Abiola, 44, and her driver were shot and killed in the attack, which has aroused national outrage.

Ore Falomo, the personal physician to Moshood Abiola, said he was with the politician's wife during the three hours of surgery before she died at the Lagos Eko Hospital.

Falomo described her death as "a blow to the Abiola family." A former civilian state governor and leader of the opposition National Democratic Coalition, Adekunle Ajasin, expressed shock.

"Although I don't know who is responsible, I don't see why the young lady had to be killed," he said.

Another politician, Joe Nwodo, was undergoing a medical check-up at hospital when Kudirat Abiola died. "It's a sad story," he said.

An official of the Campaign For Democracy, Moshood Erunbami, said the "death of Kudirat is a shame on those who can kill the body but not the soul."

Sympathisers were Wednesday streaming to the Abiola family house in Ikeja, a northern suburb of Lagos. Kudirat Abiola is expected to be buried today, in accordance with Muslim rites.

Swift reactions to the killing have also come from Britain, the United States and South Africa. These countries, which have strained diplomatic relations with Nigeria, have nonetheless urged the government in Abuja to investigate the killing with utmost care and ensure that the culprits are brought to book.

It was unclear Wednesday if the shooting was an assassination or pure violent crime, which has been on the increase especially in Lagos, the nation's economic hub.

The upsurge in urban crime prompted the military government to launch, in May, a 4,000-strong joint police and military task-force code named "Operation Sweep."

Kudirat Abiola had been locked in a family feud with Abiola's eldest son, Kola, over the millionaire's legal representation in his treason trial. She was also on bail from another case for alleged conspiracy and false publication before her death.

Abiola is in detention awaiting trial for declaring himself President of Nigeria after the annulled June 1993 presidential elections.

June, 1996


South Africa and Nigeria Mandela's Shocked At Killing Of Nigeria's Mrs. Abiola


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 5, 1996 by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - President Nelson Mandela of South Africa has expressed shock at what he described as the "heinous act" of the shooting of Kudirat Abiola, wife of the imprisoned Nigerian political leader Moshood Abiola.

Kudirat Abiola and her driver were shot dead by gunmen Tuesday near her Lagos home. 

Asked whether South Africa's policy toward Nigeria would be affected by this development, presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana said the government was keeping a close watch on the situation.

The South African foreign minister, Alfred Nzo, described the attack as "horrifying" and urged the Nigerian military government to free Moshood Abiola.

Meanwhile, Nzo said South Africa has eased off on its hard-line stance against Nigeria. He told the South African national assembly's Foreign Affairs Committee in Cape Town Tuesday that this action had resulted from allies of the Organization of African Unity accusing South Africa of acting against African norms of solidarity.

South Africa was the only African country to demand penalties against the Abacha administration and which withdrew its high commissioner from Lagos, following the execution of human rights activist and writer, Ken Saro-Wiwa, and several of his colleagues in November 1995.

But, Nzo added, South Africa had been pressured into a rethink on its Nigerian policy and he had been compelled to make a statement in the OAU confirming South Africa's commitment to African solidarity.

He said African solidarity was important to South Africa but the country had not retreated from its demand that Nigeria embark on a democratic transformation.

The government in Abuja has already started what it says is just such a program.

Africa News


June, 1996


Swaziland Swaziland Public Accounts Committee Refuses Press Ban


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 6, 1996 by Tom Holloway, Pana Correspondent


LENGTH: 294 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland - The media will be allowed to cover hearings of Swaziland's Public Accounts Committee whose first sitting, this year, will be held Wednesday, its chairman said.

Roy Fanourakis said Thursday that since the press served as the eyes of public it should be present when principal secretaries of ministries were grilled by the committee, concerning failure to control funds. 

Fanourakis' decision came despite strong opposition from ministers and top civil servants, embarrassed by disclosures of overspending and misuse of governments funds.

One of the worst offenders is the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. It was criticized, strongly, in the auditor general's report in parliament in 1995 for massive overspending and irregular use of governments funds by its missions abroad.

The committee was set up by parliament two years ago after budget surpluses changed to massive deficits reaching a record high of some 300 million rand (about 1.5 million U.S. dollars).

In an effort to reduce government expenditure this year, Finance Minister Derek Von Wissel trimmed budget allocations to ministries.

In his budget speech, he said that this was "a pre-emptive measure to avoid the need for a tougher structural adjustment program being imposed on Swaziland by the International Monetary Fund."

Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa Crime Halts South African Tourism Boom


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 6, 1996 by Lionel Williams, Pana Correspondent


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANESBURG, South Africa - South Africa's tourism boom has slumped dramatically in the face of ongoing crime and rising costs.

The number of foreign visitors to the country "which rose almost 60 percent in the first quarter of 1995" managed a meagre 3.4 percent increase between January and March 1996. 

Latest figures from the Central Statistical Services show that some 324,000 foreign visitors entered South Africa in the first quarter of this year, an unimpressive increase over the estimated 313,000 during the corresponding period of 1995.

The total increase for 1995 was 51 percent -- more than one million foreign tourists.

The president of the Association of South African Travel Agents, Roger Mackie, claims that South Africa has the biggest crime problem in the world outside war zones.

He has also criticized the government's role in tourism, expressing the need for consistency with a long-serving minister drawn from the private sector.

"It is time that the government acted positively on expectations that tourism is set to overtake mining as the country's top revenue source," he said.

The South African Tourist Corporation, or SATOUR, does not share Makie's pessimistic view.

Spokesman Martin Van Heerden says crime is not such a telling factor, although costs in South Africa are becoming high. He predicts a 20-percent increase in tourism for the country during 1996.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


385 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Burundi Bodies Of Slain Red Cross Workers Repatriated


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 6, 1996


LENGTH: 547 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The remains of three delegates of the International Committee of the Red Cross, slain in an ambush Tuesday in north-western Burundi, were repatriated from Bujumbura Thursday.

The bodies were those of two Swiss Red Cross workers who were shot dead Tuesday in an ambush in the guerilla-war troubled Cibitoke province in north-western Zaire. The third was an Italian. 

As the bodies left the Burundi capital, all non-governmental organizations operating in this war-torn country decided to suspend their activities for one week.

Meanwhile, the Burundi Prime Minister, Antoine Nduwayo, Thursday called for the creation of a common front against "organized crime."

Speaking during separate audiences with representatives of communal dvelopment associations and trade unions, Nduwayo said he was deeply surprised "to see that Burundians were increasingly becoming used to war and organized crime."

As long as we accommodate the plague, we cannot combat it, Nduwayo told a meeting of communal development associations here Thursday morning.

"The Burundi society is heading towards its own destruction if we accept crime as a day to day event," warned the prime minister.

Addressing trade union leaders, Nduwayo called for "responsible behavior from people who know they are really in a war and who cannot afford disorder."

He called for discipline among civil servants, whom he asked to contibute a monthly wage each towards the war effort to enable the government double the size of the army.

"The people of Burundi are responsible enough to know that if we do not develop an appropriate defense, the entire salary can even disappear, " he told the trade unionists.

Nduwayo condemned what he termed as the passiveness of people, who, due to ethnic affinities or fear of reprisals, say nothing, even when crimes are committed in broad daylight.

In a few years or months, "the assassins will turn against us if we do not expose these criminals," the prime minister warned.

Nduwayo recently launched a self-defense plan under which civilians from all ethnic groups would run to an army protected safe area in case of an attack by guerillas.

Burundi has drifted into virtual civil war since the assassination of that country's Hutu elected President Melchior Ndadaye in Oct. 1993.

Since then, more than 100,000 civilians have been killed in revenge killings between the majority Hutu ethnic group and the minority Tutsi, who are dominant in the army.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


386 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Burkina Faso and Western Sahara Burkina Faso Withdraws Recognition Of Sahrawi Republic


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 6, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - Burkina Faso has withdrawn its recognition of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR), whose admission into the Organization of African Unity (OAU) in 1984 caused Morocco's departure from the continental body.

A statement issued by the cabinet in Ougadougou Wednesday said the decision was motivated by "the concern to strengthen the principle of self-determination." 

Nonetheless, the cabinet pledged to support the efforts of the United Nations and the OAU to resolve the problem of Western Sahara's decolonization.

The ownership of the phosphate-rich former Spanish colony has been under dispute since Spain pulled out in 1975.

The same year after Spain's unilateral withdrawal, Morocco occupied the desert territory claiming that it historically belonged to the kingdom.

King Hassan II led a well-publicized "green" march into Western Sahara to proclaim himself as the country's legitimate ruler.

This view was strongly opposed by the POLISARIO front, which fought against the Moroccan troops posted there, with support from Algeria.

POLISARIO proclaimed the territory as a soverign state known as the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR).

Since then, SADR has been recognized by at least 60 countries throughout the world, including members of the OAU to which it became a full member in 1984.

Recently, Nelson Mandela's South Africa became the latest African state to recognise SADR.

The United Nations is currently trying to arrange a referendum to enable the Sahrawi people choose whether they want to be considered as Moroccans or as independent SADR citizens.

However, the exercise has been hampered by problems of knowing who were the territory's real indigenous people.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


387 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Kaunda Calls For Help In Fight Against Zambian Laws


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 6, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's fomer President Kenneth Kaunda Thursday urged Southern African states, the Organization of African Unity (OAU) and the international community to help the campaign against recent constitutional amendments and other bad laws in his country.

Talking to journalists in Lusaka Thursday, Kaunda claimed there were plans by the government to ban his opposition United National Indepence Party (UNIP) and arrest another 17 of its leaders. 

Eight of UNIP's leaders, including the party's Vice-President, Senior Chief Inyambo Yeta, have alreday been arrested and have appeared in court, charged with trying to overthrow President Frederick Chiluba's government.

Kaunda in particular appealed to the international donor community not to relent in the pursuit for good governance and respect for equal rights to citizens in the country.

He urged Southern African states, OAU and donor countries to take effective measures that will bring about good governance and genuine democracy in Zambia.

"When a government enacts laws that offend the basic notions of justice, uses the arms of justice against its own citizens for personal self-preservation, through lies, turns one citizen against another, the only remedy open to the public is non-cooperation with such an evil government," he said.

Kaunda demanded immediate and unconditional release of all UNIP political detainees, saying the treason charges prefered against them were tramped up.

Arresting UNIP leaders is dangerous because troops left without a leader have often become dangerous, he warned.

Kaunda declared that although the government has passed the law baring him and his vice-president from contesting this year's presidential and parliamentary elections, they would both contest the elections.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Donors To Review Relations With Zambia In London


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 6, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Britain and other Western donors plan to meet in London next week to review their relations with Zambia, in the wake of Lusaka's adoption of constitutional amendments that bar some citizens from standing for president.

The proposed meeting was announced Thursday in a statement issued by the British High Commission in Lusaka.

The news release quoted the British Overseas Development minister, Baroness Lynda Chalker, as saying donors would find it increasingly difficult to continue providing government-to-government aid if Zambia continued "down its current path." 

Chalker, who was speaking in Harare, Zimbabwe, is quoted by the release as saying "we shall be meeting in London next week when we shall see what the news is, what the prognosis is and review the situation." She described the situation in Zambia as "very sad."

"We have strongly supported the political and economic reform programme the MMD included in their manifesto. Free and fair elections are fundamentally important for all countries, especially Zambia," Chalker was quoted as saying in Thursday's statement.

The British government said it was particularly concerned about the restrictions which the constitution imposed on certain candidates wishing to stand for presidency.

The statement said these measures risked damaging the democratic system that the MMD itself had fought for so hard before it was elected in 1991.

"We urge all parties to cooperate in seeking a peaceful solution to the disagreements...we hope sincerely that they can do so soon," said Chalker.

Last Saturday, the United States said it would review its cooperation with Lusaka unless the Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government of President Frederick Chiluba immediately reversed the constitution.

Chiluba appealed Wednesday to the donors not to slap sanctions on his government saying these would hurt the ordinary Zambians who, he said, had chosen the new constitution.

"It would be unfair to punish the innocent Zambian people because we responded to the aspirations of the Zambian people. We need friendship but it should be founded on mutual respect," Chiluba said.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996

Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Moshood Abiola's Wife Laid To Rest


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 6, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 347 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Thousands of Nigerians, mainly youths and schoolchildren, attended the burial in Lagos Wednesday of Kuridat Abiola, wife of detained politician Moshood Abiola.

Kudirat, 44, were laid to rest according Muslim rites in the family compound, at Ikeja, north of Lagos. 

The funeral was also attended by foreign diplomats, politicians and representatives of pro-democracy groups.

Police are investating her killing by yet-unidentified gunmen in Lagos.

Kudirat is survived by seven children.

In his sympathy message, Nigeria's military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha described Kudirat's death as "a national loss."

"This tragedy is not only a loss to the Abiola family, but to the people of the Federal Republic of Nigeria," Abacha said in the message delivered by a government delegation to the family.

Nigeria's Chief of Army Staff, Maj. Gen. Ishaya Bamaiyi, led the government delegation, which included eight ministers.

The government team was received by Bashiru Abiola, younger brother to Moshood Abiola, the undeclared winner of the June 1993 presidential election, annulled by the last military regime.

Abiola is in detention awaiting trial for treasonable felony, after he declared himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

Meanwhile, the military administrator of Nigeria's western state of Oyo has ordered the indefinite closure of the university of Ibadan following students' protest Tuesday against the killing of Kudirat.

Police reportedly broke off the demonstration without incident.

June, 1996


Nigeria Reward For Information On Killers Of Kudirat Abiola


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 6, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Nigeria Police Thursday, announced an offer of one million naira (about 12,000 U.S. dollars) as reward to anyone with information that could lead to the arrest of the killers of Kudirat Abiola, wife of detained politician Moshood Abiola.

Announcing the offer, the highest ever promised to track any criminal in the country, police spokesman, Tunji Alapini, said the police inspector-general, Ibrahim Coomassie, "is still appealing to members of the public for information on this distardly act." 

He said Archibong Nkana, a deputy inspector-general of Police Federal Intelligence Bureau, has been put in charge of the investigation.

Five toll-free telephone lines operating round the clock, were set up Wednesday for anyone who wished to provide information on the murder.

Nigerian military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, in a condolence message to the Abiola family, described the woman's death as "a national loss."

Her slaying provoked national outrage and condemnation from a number of countries, including the United States, Britain and South Africa. These countries urged Nigeria to bring the killers to book.

Kudirat, 44, was murdered by gunmen in Lagos Tuesday. She was buried Wednesday.

She was senior wife of Moshood Abiola, the undeclared winner of the June 1993 presidential election, annulled by the last military regime.

Abiola is facing trial for treasonable felony after he declared himsef president of Nigeria in June 1994.

Kudirat's campaign for the actualisation of Abiola's mandate had sparked a feud in the husband's family.

One of Abiola's children wanted the leading defence lawyer changed, but Kudirat insisted that the first attorney should continue to handle the case.

Meanwhile, hospital sources said Kudirat's driver, who was also shot during the attack, was alive contrary to previous reports that he also died in hospital.

June, 1996


South Africa-Nigeria Trade Unions Call For Action Against Nigeria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency June 6, 1996 by Lionel Williams, Pana Correspondent


LENGTH: 214 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - The South African Congress of Trade Unions (COSATU) has called on the United States and other western countries to impose sanctions against the military regime of Gen. Sani Abacha in Nigeria.

This is the latest reaction here to the news that Kidirat Abiola, wife of jailed Nigerian opposition leader Moshood Abiola, was shot dead in Lagos Tuesday by unidentified gunmen. 

COSATU has also appealed to the United Nations to launch an international investigation into the circumstances surrounding the death of Abiola's wife.

The powerful trade union movement further demanded that Nigerians pressurize the Abacha regime to release all political prisoners.

President Nelson Mandela Wednesday expressed his shock at what he described as the "heinous act" of killing Mrs. Abiola.

His foreign minister, Alfred Nzo, described the attack as "horrifying", and urged the Nigerian military regime to free Abiola.

Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia European Community Makes $370m Grant to Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency June 6, 1996


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Delegation of the European Commission has announced that over the next five years the indicative volume of resources on which programming can be based will be 370 million dollars (294 million ECU) consisting entirely of grants. This was announced by the Charge d' Affairs, Mr. Henry Prankered, during his meeting with Prime Minister Meles Zenawi on May 22.

According to a press release obtained from the European Union Delegation of the European Commission to Ethiopia, another miles tone in relations between Ethiopia and the European commission is reached with the announcement of the signing of the agreement revising the IV LOME Convention in Mauritius in November 1995. This convention will govern the use of the grant funds of 370 million dollars for Ethiopia up to the year 2,000. 

The increase in resources, from 214 MECU for the period 1990-1995, bears concerted witness to the European Commission's desire to maintain the privileged relationship with Ethiopia and contrasts with the general contraction of both bilateral and multilateral aid.

It is anticipated that there will be a programming mission to visit Ethiopia to discuss the use of these funds which will be made available in two branches of 70% and 30%. In addition to the above grant funds there are also funds available to Ethiopia through the Regional Indicative Program as well as through additional financing instruments such as food Aid, Social Rehabilitation Program, STABEX and to support institutional and administrative reforms. Furthermore loan funds are available through the European Investment Bank.

A few days after celebrating Europe Day (May 9), the 20th anniversary of the establishment of the Delegation in Ethiopia, the Charge d'Affaires handed over a note from Prof. Pinheiro, Commissioner for External Relations to ACP states, to the Prime Minister indicating the volume of resources which can be expected in the framework of the Lome Convention.

The foundation of the Lome Convention, which links 70 countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific to the European Union, was laid in the Treaty of Rome. In 1975 the European Community signed the first Lome Convention: During the past twenty years, the Lome convention has provided African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) states with a partnership characterised by security and reliability.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June, 1996


Business and Finance Ethiopia Discusses Amended Investment Code


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency June 6, 1996 by Seifu Mahifere


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Addis Ababa - Officials from the Investment Office of Ethiopia yesterday discussed with representatives of the business community and members of the House of People's Representatives standing committee for economic affairs the amended investment proclamation of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia.

This new Investment Proclamation is a completely revised and expanded form of the original investment decree 15/84 which was considered as vague, not explicit.

Explaining the rational behind introducing the new proclamation, the head of the Investment Office of Ethiopia, Ato Tadesse Haile, said that the previous version was prepared hastily and thus had many weaknesses which created problems in its implementation. The new Investment Proclamation No . . ./96, he said, was a revised and expanded version and is intended to better serve the interests of the society and encourage investors in particular. 

According to Ato Tadesse, the drafting of this proclamation involved serious and extensive research and study and valuable lessons had been drawn from problems encountered in the implementation process of the previous proclamation 15/84 as well as the fruitful experiences of foreign countries, especially those of South East Asia and Africa as well.

Nothing that the new Investment Proclamation will help in the successful execution of the government's five-year plan of peace democracy and development, Ato Tadesse said that it has a great deal of incentive to offer and guarantees aspiring investors, both foreign and domestic, firm security. He said such details have been clearly and distinctly included, adding this is a marked departure from the Proclamation 15/84 which was "not transparent."

This new proclamation includes various basic sectors in the production and social areas like education and health, which were not included in the previous Proclamation 15/84 that focused on "limited sectors."

On the occasion, representatives of the business community posed several questions and reservations on the new proclamation, including on such sectors as minimum capital requirement for foreign investors, which they said should be lowered to 200,000 dollars from 300,000 dollars stipulated by the new proclamation. Ato Tadesse said that this was not a worrying matter as most applications from foreign investors up to now have not complained, adding that the minimum capitals presented were even many times bigger than expected.

They also demanded that such general expressions as "other relevant information" found in several articles of the new proclamation be avoided as they are "highly subjective" and create favourable conditions for bureaucratic redtape. They also requested that such activities dealing with those incentives to be given to investors and on ways of land allocation be listed clearly and in detail. They also recommended that at least one, representative from the private sector be given membership of the investment board.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia Oromiya Deforestation Is Ethiopia's Highest


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Nazareth, Ethiopia - Deforestation in Oromiya accounts for over 50 percent of the over all forest depletion in the country which leaves each year 150-200,000 hectares of land barren, devoid of its natural floura head of land use and environmental protection department in the agricultural bureau said.

In a remark he made at the three day workshop devoted to environmental problems in the region Ato Kasso Morka said the country is left with only three of the 40 percent woodlands it had 40 years ago.

The depletion of forests in the region has resulted in unprecedented soil erosion to aggravate desertification which greatly affected agricultural production. 

Depletion of natural resources in West and East Hararghe and East Shoa zones has been aggravated for lack of natural vegetation, he added.

The region has given due attention to water and soil conservation as well as terracing activities in a bid to ward off environmental degradation.

According to the official, the public and domestic animals who live on the polluted waters of the Akaki, Awash, Mojo and Kitabi rivers, serving as outlets for factory by products, are suffering from various water-borne diseases.

The professionals draws from the zonal agricultural departments in the region, the bureau of the Environmental Protection Authority and the Ministry of Planning and Economic Development would discuss some six research papers during their stay at the workshop.

Meanwhile , the North Shoa Zone agricultural department said the zone loses close to 150 tonnes of soil each year due to deforestation.

In a statement the department gave in connection with the world Environment Day observed last Wednesday soil erosion in the area has resulted in climatic disorder to add up to its adverse effect on agricultural production.

Nursing Woodlands and curbing deforestation should be the preoccupation of the public as well as pertinent bodies so as to enhance a sustainable co- system, it noted.

LANGUAGE: English
