395 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia Census Gives Picture Of Addis Demographics


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency June 7, 1996 by Kisut G/Egziabher


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Addis Ababa - Nineteen months after the second Population and Housing Census was conducted, the office of the commission in charge yesterday released results which covered Addis Ababa proper and three Regional states.

According to the findings, Addis Ababa has 2,254,862 (2.3 million) residents of whom 48.4% are male and 51.6% female. About two third of the population fall under the age group 15-64 years, of which 67% are economically active. Out of the total 863,051 economically active citizens, 563,147 are employed, while 299,904 are jobless. 

According to the result, 2,084,588 are urban dwellers while the remaining 28,149 live in rural areas in the suburbs.

Compared to the results of the First Population and Housing Census which was conducted a decade ago, the present figure exceeds by about 800,000 which puts the last ten-year annual growth rate at 3.8 percent.

The census indicated that the metropolis has 978,880 living rooms in 380, 307 residential quarters which means an average of 2.1 persons per room.

The findings of the Census show that 82.0% of Addis Ababa's are followers of the Ethiopian Orthodox Christian Church, 12% Muslims, 3.9% Protestants, 0.8% Catholics while 0.6% follow various other religious denominations.

The major ethnic group in the city comprise of the Amhara which covers 48.3% of the total. Oromo, Ghuraghe and Tigray represent 19.2, 17.5 and 7.6 percent, respectively.

The population of Tigray regional state was found out to be 3,274,740, of whom 49.2% are male and 50.8% are female. About 51.2% of the population fall under the 15-64 age group of whom about 78% (131,425) are economically active. Among these, 1,226,970 are employed while 20,103 are jobless.

The urban residents of the regional state constitute 468,478 while 2,667, 789 reside in rural areas, according to the census.

The census disclosed that there are 686,876 residential housing units in Tigray of which 115,421 are found in urban areas and 571,455 are rural based.

According to the findings, the religious composition of the people of Tigray is 95.5% Orthodox Christians, 4.1% Muslims and 0.4% Catholics.

The ethnic composition is 94.8% Tigray, 2.6% Amhara, 0.9% Eritrean, 0.7% Saho, and 0.7% Agew/Kamyr, the census revealed.

The Amhara Regional State has population of 14,417,807, of whom 50.2% are male and 49.8% female. About 7,188,468 of the total fall under the 15-64 age group of whom 86% are economically active. Out of the total 6,170,671 who are considered to be economically active 6,100,674 are employed while 69,997 jobless.

The regional state has 1,265,315 urban residents and 12,568,982 rural dwellers.

According to the census, there are 2,985,268 residential housing units in the state, of which 285,203 are found in urban areas while the rest 2,700,065 are located in rural areas.

The result indicated that 81.5% of the Amhara people are Orthodox Christians while Muslims and Protestants constitute 18.1 and 0.1 percent, respectively.

Ethnic wise, 92.2% are Amharas, 3.0% Oromos, 2.7% Agew, 1.2% Kimant, and 1.0% Kamyr.

Harari Regional State, the result stated, has a total population of 138,864 with about the same sex ratio.

Those who fall under the 15-64 age group number 76,874 of whom 48,800 or about 64% are economically active, 41,476 among these are employed while 7,324 have no jobs.

Some 76,378 of the Hararis live in urban areas while 54,761 are rural residents.

According to the report, the state has 29,264 residential quarters.

About 60.3 percent of the Hararis are Muslims, 38.2% Orthodox Christians, 0.9% Protestants, 0.5% Catholics, and 0.1% percent followers of other sects.

The Oromo, who constitute 52.3 % of the population, are the major ethnic group in the state. The Amharas, Hararis and Ghuraghes comprise 32.6, 7.1 and 3.2 percent respectively.

The Secretary General of the Population and Housing Census commission, Dr. Abdulahi Hassen, told reporters that the results of the census for the other states are being computer processed and will be released soon.

Dr. Abdulahi, who is also the general manager of the Central Statistical Authority, said: "Some are at data processing stage and others have been sent to the printing press."

The Secretary General said the delay in announcing the results should not be exaggerated, adding: "But recent restructuring of woredas across the nation stymied our word and we had to thus restructure our findings accordingly."

According to the official, the government allocated 100 million birr while UNFPA, UNDP, USAID, SIDA and other donor agencies helped with material, technical and financial assistances valued at over 3.5 million dollars.

Africa News


June, 1996


Ethiopia Houses Debates Credit Licensing Law


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency June 7, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Addis Ababa - The House of Peoples representatives yesterday discussed a bill on the licensing and monitoring of small scale business credit organisations catering to credit needs of farmers, and microenterprises in urban areas.

The law stipulates that the credit institutions would be share companies to be set up only by Ethiopians and could provide loans either in cash or kind. 

The licensing and monitoring credit institutions law was necessitated out of the need to incorporate small credit service into the country's fiscal and financial policy.

A study carried out by the National Bank of Ethiopia and submitted to the house indicated that state and private banks at present serve mostly the business community in major towns and as a result people in the low income groups are suffering at the hands of usurers.

An expert from the National Bank said small scale business credit agencies differ from big banks in that their credit amount is decided by the bank and mostly they operate while making losses.

The house has also looked into a bill amending the code establishing the federal courts.

Meanwhile, a three-day legal workshop organised for members of parliament was opened by House Speaker Dawit Yohannes.

The house, he said, has the responsibility of legislating and following up the proper interpretation of laws as of gathering public opinion and seeking ways for a joint development endeavours. In this regard, the workshop would greatly help MPs to discharge their duties properly.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


397 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Ghana Media Deny Negating Investment Programme


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996 by Samuel Sarpong


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Nairobi - The Ghanaian authorities are getting increasingly worried over what they deem to be the local media's destructive agenda to derail the gains being made in this West African nation's investment drive.

Their concern stems from what they deem as an orchestrated attempt by the media, particularly the independent press, to stifle investment initiatives taken by the government.

"This is because the image being projected does not reflect the truth and only goes to reinforce a perception, which we are constantly bemoaning," says Kwesi Ahwoi, Chief Executive of the Ghana Investment Promotion Centre, a government body charged with investment promotion.

"Otherwise why should a section of our media scream 'coup d'etat' in banner headlines when they know very well that they do not want one to occur - you know investors do not put their monies in coup prone areas," stresses Ahwoi. 

He adds; "To them (journalists) if there is no bad news about the government and key leading political figures, then there is nothing to write about."

Kwesi Ahwoi is not alone in such condemnation. Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings has often complained bitterly about the supposed anti-government stance of the media, particularly the independent press.

The plain truth is, the government feels the media have not been an ally in the authorities' desire to bring investment to the country.

"They have played out to the propaganda of the West," retorts Kwesi Ahwoi.

Since Ghana embarked on an Economic Recovery Programme (ERP) in 1983, the nation's major ambition has been to encourage foreign direct investment in the country. But this has not materialized to any appreciable level. The investors are not coming as expected, concedes Ahwoi.

What Ghana succeeded in attracting were only trickies of inflows averaging US$ 35 million of direct foreign investment from 1990 to 1994.

In view of this, the country embarked on an aggressive and clearly focused image building campaign as a prelude to the investment generation and aggressive investment promotion activities. Between 1994 and March 1996, Ghana featured consistently in the International Herald Tribune, the Euromony Financial Times, Paris Match, Afrique Golfe, USA Today, Business Direction (Singapore) as well as other international journals. Even the Cable News Network (CNN) carried out an effective expose on Ghana as an emerging investment location.

President Rawlings' personal and direct involvement in the investment drive had also been very beneficial to the country, in that, some investors called in to find out more about the opportunities available after the President's visit to the United States, Singapore and Malaysia last year. After the intensive image building campaign, Ghana reaped benefits of US$ 150 million from direct foreign investment in 1995 compared to only US$ 35 million average per annum for the preceding years.

Ahwoi says with this seemingly breakthrough, Ghana has succeeded in emerging as a politically and socially stable country with a steady and predictable macroeconomic regime characterized by consistent and emerging transparent and predictable business regulations and procedures. "What is left now is to sustain this position and image, and the local media acting as feeders to the international media have a far greater responsibility and role to secure this," he stresses.

The promotion centre head together with other government officials think the Ghanaian media have a different agenda which appears not to be in line with the country's collective interest.

But the President of the Ghana Journalists Association, Mr. Kabral Blay-Amihere thinks otherwise. "If anything, the government should be proud of our performance in calling to attention certain abnormalities in the running of the country."

He reckons that if the government thinks that media practitioners should close their eyes to all the happenings around them and offer the government unalloyed support, then journalists would be doing a
disservice to the nation. After all, the media are expected to play a vanguard role which is being fulfilled accordingly, he adds.

Kwesi Essuman, a veteran journalist, concedes that there may be certain excesses by some journalists, but on the whole, he thinks that his colleagues have really put the Ghanaian authorities on their toes, hence the concern being expressed by government officials. "In the absence of any credible opposition in Parliament, the lot fell on journalists and we have done very well," he observes.

Indeed, following a boycott of the Parliamentary elections by the opposition in 1992, the need for a credible opposition seems to have eluded Ghanaians and the media seemingly took it upon themselves to play that role through occasional scrutiny of government policies Most Ghanaians however agree that but for the media, the country could have been run as a one-party state. They agree there have been certain excesses, but these they contend, had come about because of the government's inflexibility and insensitivity to a number of issues.
a role that has driven the two institutions apart.

Indeed, Ghana is at crossroads, where every opportunity that avails itself should be used to stimulate critical discussions, appraisals and decisive action in the drive forward into sustainable nationhood. And this can only be done in a give and take atmosphere, where the government would not subject itself to its line of thoughts alone, but also be guided by constructive criticism which is a basic ingredient for any democracy.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


398 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Science Northern Women Generate Income From Wild Nut


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Nairobi - The shea butter tree grows wild in much of the savannah woodlands of the Sudan-Sahelian region of Africa. In West Africa, the shea butter tree is well established as a cash crop. In East Africa, by contrast, the British colonizers ignored it entirely.

Now a Ugandan non-governmental organisation (NGO) is teaching local women in the northern part of the country how to process food and cosmetic oil from this neglected wilderness resource. The intention is to generate household incomes and save the environment at the same time. 

Women in Otuke county of Lira district, northern Uganda, are the main beneficiaries of an oil crop project that should boost household incomes considerably in this otherwise neglected area. Otuke in the north-eastern corner of Lira district is a marginal area even in the context of northern Uganda. Households here are among the poorest in the country, having few opportunities to improve their standard of living and often facing real difficulties in meeting basic daily needs.

At the same time as the project boosts household incomes the local environment in Otuke will be conserved because the people see the need to do so. The source of the oil is a wild tree called Butyrospernum paradoxum more commonly called the shea butter tree.

Under the aegis of the shea project of the Cooperative Office for Voluntary Organisations of Uganda (COVOL-Uganda), the shea nut is harvested from the wild where it grows in great abundance in the whole of Otuke county and indeed, the vast savannah region beyond. This area, measuring up to millions of hectares of savannah woodland, extends into southern Sudan.

Shea butter is well known in West Africa where it is a long established oil crop. By contrast in East Africa, it is hardly known, perhaps because the British colonial administrators saw no need to encourage its cultivation when there were other oil crops like sesame, groundnut, coconut, and cotton -- the traditional vegetable sources of oil for the manufacture of soaps and cooking oils.

Later the British encouraged the importation of huge amounts of palm oil from plantations in the Far East. Today, Kenya alone annually imports $200 million worth of vegetable oils, much of which the country could produce itself if the authorities cared to set up the right environment for oil production locally.

The main oil crop for the women of northern Uganda is sesame (simsim) which is both a source of protein for domestic consumption with only a little amount ending up as oil for the market.

For domestic consumption in Otuke county, the sesame is ground to afine paste and mixed into soups. It is excellent food for children and adults alike.

In addition to its potential as domestic cooking oil, shea butter is also in high demand as a cosmetic product. Much of the production of shea butter from Ghana goes to Bodyshop, the main retailer of natural beauty products in Great Britain.

Mr. Eliot T. Masters, coordinator of the shea butter project in Lira district is very keen on its environment protection component. "It is an integrated long term effort to reinforce a local economy based upon conservation of savannah woodland, in collaboration with the people and the many community based NGOs.

"We see the primary goal of the project as prevention of environmental degradation before it occurs." The emphasis is on sustaining the ecological balance in the marginal Lango countryside,adds Masters.

He says this is possible because the need for sustainability of the project is inculcated in the women and other participants at the outset. And this is backed by a series of incentive factors. "It takes 15 years for the shea butter tree to reach productivity stage.

Those who wish to grow it are free to do so. However, most women have chosen to harvest the nut from the wilderness while at the same time conserving the woodlands."

A highly motivated rural development worker, Masters says the project will remain "fundamentally linked to female incomes and household food security."

He believes it is important to reduce the demands on female time and labour since rural women have other numerous time consuming or labour demanding chores in their daily routine.

Simple mechanical oil presses developed at the University of Technology in Kumasi, Ghana have been introduced in Otuke to help boost productivity. Two West African experts are helping the women of Otuke to familiarize themselves with the oil extruder presses from Ghana.

Masters is confident that the COVOL project will meet its target of producing 30 tonnes of oil within 18 months. At least 20 tonnes of this will be sent to Ghana for onward export to England. COVOL has a working arrangement with a company in Ghana that sells shea butte

to Bodyshop and they are keen to encourage further shea butter output from Eastern Africa.

The Shea Butter Project will initially run for three years. Several thousand dollars have been secured as funding for the project, with most of the money coming from the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), through the Kampala based Grants Management Unit, Action Programme for the Environment.

Masters is constantly looking for new outlets for COVOL's products.

He is in contact with refugee agencies in northern Uganda with a view to selling them a substantial amount of their output for the nutritional uses of refugees in Uganda and Kenya.

There is also the likelihood that the large number of Sudanese refugees in camps in Uganda will spontaneously set out to produce shea butter oil themselves since the required raw materials are vastly available all over northern Uganda and southern Sudan.

Local conservation and development of shea butter will be reinforced by; technical improvement of shea processing to maximize efficiency of women's labour; extension services addressing the needs of local farmers; environmental education through extension services and local micro-enterprise development with a small loans scheme.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


399 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Uganda Northern Women Generate Income From Wild Nut


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Nairobi - The shea butter tree grows wild in much of the savannah woodlands of the Sudan-Sahelian region of Africa. In West Africa, the shea butter tree is well established as a cash crop. In East Africa, by contrast, the British colonizers ignored it entirely.

Now a Ugandan non-governmental organisation (NGO) is teaching local women in the northern part of the country how to process food and cosmetic oil from this neglected wilderness resource. The intention is to generate household incomes and save the environment at the same time. 

Women in Otuke county of Lira district, northern Uganda, are the main beneficiaries of an oil crop project that should boost household incomes considerably in this otherwise neglected area. Otuke in the north-eastern corner of Lira district is a marginal area even in the context of northern Uganda. Households here are among the poorest in the country, having few opportunities to improve their standard of living and often facing real difficulties in meeting basic daily needs.

At the same time as the project boosts household incomes the local environment in Otuke will be conserved because the people see the need to do so. The source of the oil is a wild tree called Butyrospernum paradoxum more commonly called the shea butter tree.

Under the aegis of the shea project of the Cooperative Office for Voluntary Organisations of Uganda (COVOL-Uganda), the shea nut is harvested from the wild where it grows in great abundance in the whole of Otuke county and indeed, the vast savannah region beyond. This area, measuring up to millions of hectares of savannah woodland, extends into southern Sudan.

Shea butter is well known in West Africa where it is a long established oil crop. By contrast in East Africa, it is hardly known, perhaps because the British colonial administrators saw no need to encourage its cultivation when there were other oil crops like sesame, groundnut, coconut, and cotton -- the traditional vegetable sources of oil for the manufacture of soaps and cooking oils.

Later the British encouraged the importation of huge amounts of palm oil from plantations in the Far East. Today, Kenya alone annually imports $200 million worth of vegetable oils, much of which the country could produce itself if the authorities cared to set up the right environment for oil production locally.

The main oil crop for the women of northern Uganda is sesame (simsim) which is both a source of protein for domestic consumption with only a little amount ending up as oil for the market.

For domestic consumption in Otuke county, the sesame is ground to afine paste and mixed into soups. It is excellent food for children and adults alike.

In addition to its potential as domestic cooking oil, shea butter is also in high demand as a cosmetic product. Much of the production of shea butter from Ghana goes to Bodyshop, the main retailer of natural beauty products in Great Britain.

Mr. Eliot T. Masters, coordinator of the shea butter project in Lira district is very keen on its environment protection component. "It is an integrated long term effort to reinforce a local economy based upon conservation of savannah woodland, in collaboration with the people and the many community based NGOs.

"We see the primary goal of the project as prevention of environmental degradation before it occurs." The emphasis is on sustaining the ecological balance in the marginal Lango countryside,adds Masters.

He says this is possible because the need for sustainability of the project is inculcated in the women and other participants at the outset. And this is backed by a series of incentive factors. "It takes 15 years for the shea butter tree to reach productivity stage.

Those who wish to grow it are free to do so. However, most women have chosen to harvest the nut from the wilderness while at the same time conserving the woodlands."

A highly motivated rural development worker, Masters says the project will remain "fundamentally linked to female incomes and household food security."

He believes it is important to reduce the demands on female time and labour since rural women have other numerous time consuming or labour demanding chores in their daily routine.

Simple mechanical oil presses developed at the University of Technology in Kumasi, Ghana have been introduced in Otuke to help boost productivity. Two West African experts are helping the women of Otuke to familiarize themselves with the oil extruder presses from Ghana.

Masters is confident that the COVOL project will meet its target of producing 30 tonnes of oil within 18 months. At least 20 tonnes of this will be sent to Ghana for onward export to England. COVOL has a working arrangement with a company in Ghana that sells shea butte

to Bodyshop and they are keen to encourage further shea butter output from Eastern Africa.

The Shea Butter Project will initially run for three years. Several thousand dollars have been secured as funding for the project, with most of the money coming from the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), through the Kampala based Grants Management Unit, Action Programme for the Environment.

Masters is constantly looking for new outlets for COVOL's products.

He is in contact with refugee agencies in northern Uganda with a view to selling them a substantial amount of their output for the nutritional uses of refugees in Uganda and Kenya.

There is also the likelihood that the large number of Sudanese refugees in camps in Uganda will spontaneously set out to produce shea butter oil themselves since the required raw materials are vastly available all over northern Uganda and southern Sudan.

Local conservation and development of shea butter will be reinforced by; technical improvement of shea processing to maximize efficiency of women's labour; extension services addressing the needs of local farmers; environmental education through extension services and local micro-enterprise development with a small loans scheme.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


400 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Habitat II: Sub-Saharan Africa's State Of Shelter


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996 by Wafula John and Makur Kot


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Istanbul - As 25,000 delegates from government, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), religious groups, women, youth groups and private sector converge in Istanbul, Turkey from June 3 to 14 to discuss human settlement, poverty, population and the environment, sub-Saharan Africa still disturbingly bears the brunt of these amongst many other woes.

Despite advances made in human welfare and technology, there is today a growing polarization between rich and poor and a failure of political will to address the silent but nevertheless threatening emergence of those who cannot make ends meet, millions of whom are concentrated is sub-Saharan Africa.

In this region, poverty is said to be on the increase. On the UN list of the 52 poorest countries in the world, 32 are in sub-Saharan Africa, while 75 per cent of the zone's population of over 500 million people earn less than one US dollar a day. 

The human settlements scenario is said to be appalling, more so in fast growing urban centres. Some sub-Saharan African urban populations are growing at an alarming rate. Zimbabwe's urban population was expected to grow from 1.2 million in 1975 to 4.5 million by the year 2000 and to peak to 20.2 million by 2025.

The United Nations Centre for Human Settlement (UNCHS), Habitat, Global Report on Human Settlements, Statistical Annex, (Draft) 1995 further shows that Nigeria which had an urban population of 14.6 million people in 1975 is expected to be home to some 146.9 million by 2025. Sudan which had an urban population of 3 million people will have to house, feed, transport and employ 27 million people.

The population of most sub-Saharan African towns is growing at an average of over 5 per cent per annum. Ethiopia's population, for instance, is said to be growing at 5.53 per cent and Malawi's at 5.88 per cent. The continent's urban population, estimated at 104 million in 1975 is expected to swell up to 804.2 million by 2025.

Often, immigrants in search of better living standards or in flight from conflicts swell up African towns and cities whose infrastructures are static. This leads to acute overcrowding, the straining of such facilities as water, electricity, means of transport and housing.

It also leads to environmental degradation which HABITAT II, also referred to as The City Summit is poised to discuss.

The task ahead of HABITAT II is ardous and unenviable. What makes the work of the UN body even more difficult is lack of a positive track record of the hosts which could help salvage its image and imbue in sub-Saharan African people trust that this time round, the international forum will come up with viable and sustainable resolutions for their region's development.

HABITAT II, whose two themes are Adequate shelter for all and Sustainable human settlements development in an urbanizing world was preceded by HABITAT I in 1976, in Vancouver, Canada. But it appears the meeting came out with resolutions which seem to have been swept under the carpet.

Since the Vancouver summit, the problem of human shelter has deteriorated even further. A United Nations report ahead of the Istanbul conference said that about 100 million people worldwide, mostly women, are today homeless and up to 600 million are poorly and unhealthly housed.

Matters have become worse for sub-Saharan Africa. A 1992 World Bank study reports that 220 million people south of the Sahara live in absolute poverty. It adds that 18 of the world's 20 poorest countries are in this region and that due to war, drought, famine and desertification, food production has dropped to a level 20 per cent below the 1970 level while the population has trebled.

Skeptics wonder whether this time the HABITAT II meeting will reverse this woeful trend. Many issues are poised to be points of discussion at the Istanbul summit. In fact the Istanbul agenda is said to be so expansive that the summit appears to be attempting to solve all of humanity's problems in one sitting.

According to the HABITAT Agenda, the Istanbul summit will discuss and make recommendations in relation to "the right to adequate housing, which includes access to safe and healthy shelter and basic services," which the UN publication cites as essential to a person's physical, psychological, social and economic well being.

The meeting will also discuss "sustainable development of human settlements which combines economic development, social development and environmental protection, with the full respect for all human rights and fundamental freedoms; including the right to development, and offers means of achieving a world of greater stability and peace, built on ethical and spiritual vision." How and whether this can be achieved in the near future remains to be seen.

Running up to the Istanbul meeting have been a chain of other international conferences which, among other issues, aimed to alleviate the suffering of the poor. From The Global Strategy for Shelter to the Year 2000, adopted in 1988 through the 1989 World Conference on Education for All to the World Summit for Social Development held in Copenhagen in 1995, little has been said of the gains made by the poor of sub-Saharan Africa. In fact, the situation has continued to worsen instead of improving.

During the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development duped the Earth Summit, which was held in Rio de Janeiro in June 1992 and where Agenda 21 was produced, "the international communities agreed on a framework for the sustainable development of human settlements" according to the HABITAT Agenda. How much sub-Saharan African has benefited is still not clear.

During this conference, the United States of America reportedly pledged to donate US dollars 125 million towards environmental protection. The Third World, on the other hand, was asked to raise a further 500 million dollars towards the same project. Today, little is known of these noble proposals.

Observers say that all these conferences "have begun to deliver a more holistic, informed and humane message about our global problems and about the cooperative and creative solutions they require."

So be it. However, the Istanbul meeting should aim to translate "the messages about our global problems" into action to solve these real problems, more so in regard to the world's most impoverished region -- the sub-Saharan region.

As the Secretary-General of Habitat II, Dr. Wally N'Dow put it, "Habitat II is more than a conference. It is a recognition...an awakening...that time is running out; that if we want to save the future we have no choice other than to find answers today..."

Quoting Juma Assiago, of youth for HABITAT II (Kenya), one may ask; "Will the coming conference be a real step forward in building a different and better sub-Saharan Africa?"


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


401 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Uganda Country Loses Peacemake, Gen. Okello


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Kampala - Former Ugandan Head of State General Tito Okello Lutwa died at Nsambya Hospital here on June 5. He was 85.

He was first admitted to Nsambya in sub-urban Kampala last February, complaining of heart problems. He was flown to West Germany for specialised treatment in late March. Upon his recovery he stayed with his sons in London only to relapse again when he returned to Kampala in May. 

Tito Okello became Uganda's Head of State in 1985 after staging a coup against former President Milton Obote whose constant preoccupation with intrigues, General Okello simply detested.

He was passed over for promotion as Commander of the Uganda Army in the mid-sixties because Obote was aware that General Okello was against the violent uprooting of the kingdoms ordered by Obote in 1966. Obote appointed Colonel Idi Amin to be his commander, bypassing Okello who was senior to Amin.

After the overthrow of Milton Obote in 1985, General Tito Okello's short lived military junta attempted to negotiate peace with Yoweri Museveni's National Resistance Army (NRA), whose guerrillas had reached the outskirts of Kampala.

President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya agreed to broker peace between the Ugandan combatants in Nairobi, but Museveni changed his mind after the Nairobi accord. His victorious forces entered Kampala in January 1986.

Okello went into exile in Dar es Salaam until 1992 when he took advantage of a general amnesty extended to him and others by President Museveni.

The Government built him a mansion and offered the general generous retirement benefits.

Until his death, he was advisor to Museveni on the North, particularly on Acholi issues. It is General Okello who advised Museveni not to launch an all out offensive against the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) of Joseph Kony but instead to use the carrot- approach simultaneously, so as to gradually win over the North including Lango district, former President Milton Obote's home.

President Museveni was the first to send messages of condolence to the family and relatives of General Okello who would be accorded full military honours during his burial scheduled for June 7 in his Kitgum district in the North.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


402 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Angola Kennedy Family Wants To Start Catholic University


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 574 words


 

LISBON - Members of the family of the late United States President John Kennedy are expected to travel to Luanda soon to discuss the setting up of a Catholic University in Angola, as well as other aid projects, the Portuguese daily Journal de Noticias reported here on May 24.

Quoting the US Consul in Luanda Daniel Chase, the daily said the Citizen Energy Corporation, headed by Michael Kennedy, son of Robert Kennedy and nephew of the assassinated president, was in contact with the Angolan government and the Catholic church.

A 17-member mission was expected in Luanda on May 30 to hold talks with Angola's ministers for Oil, Agriculture and Communications and Transport, as well as with the country's Roman Catholic Archbishop Alexandre do Nascimento, the report said. 

The establishment of the university would be one of the few major projects the Catholic church intends to establish in the war-torn former Portuguese colony once the ongoing peace process is realised.

Last December, the Catholic bishop of Lubango, Monsignor Manuel Franklin da Costa, announced here during a visit to Portugal that the Catholic church in Angola was preparing to relaunch a radio station, and possibly a newspaper, 20 years after Angola's independence from Portuguese rule.

Monsignor Da Costa said then that Radio Ecclesia would resume broadcasts from January, starting around the capital city, Luanda, with coverage to extend across the war-ravaged nation from March.

"It is very important that Radio Ecclesia go on air and provide news with total impartiality ... to help Angolans draw their own conclusions on what is happening in the country," the bishop stressed.

Before 1975, when Angola was still a Portuguese colony, the radio used to operate 24 hours a day.

The bishop also announced then that another fixture of colonial times, the Apostolado newspaper, may also reappear in March, but it would be a monthly, and not a daily as before.

"We are now rebuilding everything that was destroyed in the war," the bishop said, referring to the civil war between the People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) and the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA).

"We hope to be able to do this because it is important for the Angolan people," Monsignor Da Costa stressed.

The bishop's revelations came amidst mounting fears in Angola that the ceasefire between the warring factions was collapsing as a result of suspicious and conflicting reports on the situation in the country, which would have called the UN-brokered peace into question.

However, it is not clear whether both the church radio station and newspaper are operational.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


403 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Africa-at-Large Ecumenical Council To Raise $8 Million For African Refugees


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Geneva - The World Council of Churches (WCC) intends to raise US dollars 8 million for emergency and other related refugee activities in Africa this year, the organisation's Executive Secretary for Migration, Patrick Taran, has disclosed.

In an interview with APS onJune 6, the WCC official said the amount will be "outside the normal WCC budget for its refugee activities on the continent, which runs at US$ 2 million, annually."

"We also intend to raise another US$ 3 million for the WCC sponsored refugee activities in the Sudan," Taran further said. 

The WCC Secretary for Migration was briefing APS on the organisation's contribution at the May 30 to 31 international conference here, on the problems of refugees and other displaced persons in the former Soviet Union countries, referred to as Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) since 1989.

"This was the first time that (the Geneva-based) WCC joined other church-related bodies to make its stand on a vital issue such as the problem of refugees and other displaced persons," said Taran.

Other bodies that joined the WCC in making the statement for the conference included the Lutheran World Federation (LWF), International Catholic Migration Commission, Hungarian Interchurch Aid, Caritas Internationalis, the World Young Women's Christian Association and the Conference of European Churches.

"We strongly support the emphasis given to prevention of involuntary human displacement...We urge that particular attention be given to the special needs of uprooted women and children in the implementation of the programme of action," said the WCC statement, signed by Taran.

The international conference, which brought together more than 60 countries represented by governmental, non-governmental organisations and church-related delegates such as the WCC, was organised jointly by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), International Organizations for Migration and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

>From Africa, participants represented Kenya, Zambia, Angola,
Morocco, Algeria, South Africa and Madagascar.

According to the WCC statement, some 9 million people have been displaced in the CIS countries since 1989.

And the Geneva conference was the first full-scale effort by international organisations, the CIS countries and other states to formulate a concerted plan of action for dealing with movements of people described by UN High Commissioner for Refugees Sadako Ogata as "of astounding scale and complexity," said the WCC statement.

Noting that humanitarian, pastoral and legal action taken by Christians and church-related organisations to attend to refugees, displaced, migrants and uprooted people has often preceded action by governments and inter-governmental agencies, the statement noted that the dissolution of the former Soviet Union, saw church-related organizations become increasingly concerned with the population movements within and to the republics of CIS and neighbouring countries.

The Geneva meeting also highlighted the commitment by international Christian organisations to continue supporting uprooted people in the CIS region through programmes for training social workers, personnel exchanges, provision of material assistance and other activities.

The WCC and its related church bodies welcomed the CIS conference and "the efforts to elaborate common principles, policy and operational framework for the entire region."

The migration phenomenon must be identified as distinct from such issues as drugs, crime and terrorism; these exist and must be combated irrespective of migration, the WCC statement added.

Africa is home to an estimated 6 million refugees out of the world total of 16 million.

Out of the estimated 30 million internally displaced persons worldwide, 50 per cent are said to be in African countries.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


404 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Nigeria Thousands Protest Killing of Abiola's Wife


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Lagos - Thousands of Nigerians took to the streets of the south-western city of Ibadan on June 5 to protest the assassination of Kudiratu Abiola, the senior wife of jailed Nigerian opposition leader Moshood Abiola, witnesses said.

Mrs. Abiola, 44, died on June 4 in Eko Hospital, a private clinic in Ikeja in the north of Lagos near where she lived, shortly after unknown gunmen opened fire on her car.

According to witnesses, five people in a car opened fire on her Mercedes as she was on her way to a meeting with a senior Western diplomat in Victoria, a residential area of the capital, sources said.

The protestors, mostly students, chanted slogans critical of the military regime and demanded the release of Moshood Abiola and acceptance of the June 1993 presidential election results. 

Abiola has been in detention on treason charges since June 1994 for declaring himself president on the first anniversary of the election which he claimed to have won, but which was annulled by the military.

The protest march started from Ibadan University and headed towards the headquarters of the Oyo state military governor, Colonel Ike Nwosu but although there were no signs of trouble, police intervened and broke up the march, making several arrests.

Ibadan, a major city in south-western Nigeria is only a few kilometres from the town of Abeokuta where the late Kudiratu was born.

All was said to be calm also in Lagos where Kudiratu Abiola was to be buried later in the day, with many representatives of the diplomatic corps in Nigeria attending the burial ceremony, diplomatic sources said.

Mrs Abiola's violent death sent shock waves across the country, sparking a wave of condemnations at home and abroad.

The senior wife of the Muslim opposition leader and millionaire newspaper tycoon was also one of the main figures of the Nigerian opposition group.

Married to Chief Abiola in 1973, she was said to be his favourite wife among the 15 or so he is reputed to have.

Since her husband's imprisonment, Abiola's wife and sons had been looking after his business interests, including the national daily newspaper Concord headed by another wife, Doyin Abiola.

One of her husband's most ardent defenders during the past few years, Kudiratu Abiola fought for his cause, publicly calling for recognition that he won the presidential election.

Last month Kudiratu Abiola and two printers had appeared in court charged with conspiracy and making false statements. They pleaded not guilty and her trial was due to start on July 17.

Her family said in a statement signed by eldest son Kola Abiola that "the way and manner of her death is to say the least bizarre and shocking. The family implores the authorities to do everything within their powers to bring the culprits to justice."

The opposition umbrella Campaign for Democracy group said in a communique that "we do not have to look too far for her assassins."

It said her struggle to get her husband released had set her on a collision course with the military government, and called for an independent commission to investigate the attack and "bring her killers to justice."

"This is the only way we can resist the temptation to conclude that she was assassinated by the military junta which has illegally held her husband captive for two years now," it added.

The charges apparently arose from interviews she gave to Nigerian and foreign media in which she called for her husband's release from prison.

Nigerian police chief said in a statement they had "directed a full-scale investigation" into Abiola's assassination and pledged that"no stone will be left unturned in unravelling the perpetrators of this heinous crime."

One of the first reactions from outside Nigeria was that of South African President Nelson Mandela, who expressed shock and disbelief at what had happened in Nigeria.

Similar reactions were registered from Washington, London and Paris, with the respective authorities calling on the Nigerian government to ensure that the killers of Kudiratu Abiola were brought to book.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


405 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Liberia Death, Disease Increase As Agencies Reduce Operations


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Monrovia - Reports from Liberia say at least 15 people a day are dying from food shortages and disease in and around the north-estern town of Tubmanburg.

Tubmanburg has been cut off by nearly two months of bloody factional fighting in the Liberian capital, Monrovia.

At the same time, the Lutheran World Federation (LWF), heading a group of relief organisations including the Catholic Relief Service,has scaled down operations in Liberia following increasing insecurity in the country. 

LWF said armed men are preventing the few remaining relief workers from carrying out their duties. Most aid agencies and their staff were evacuated from Monrovia when factional fighting erupted there early April, while a United States naval task force of 2000 marines has been stationed off Liberia ever since.

According to a press release issued from the Ecumenical Centre in Geneva, Switzerland, following a meeting of 12 non-governmental organisations (NGOs) on May 28, more than 400 vehicles belonging to aid agencies including the United Nations, were looted during the recent fighting. The statement put the value of the vehicles, other equipment and resources at US$ 35 million since early April.

The statement issued by the LWF said the NGOs' action is due to the repeated abuse of humanitarian principles and materials. The statement quoted the NGOs as saying it is time to break a cycle of broken promises and stop contributing to the profits of the warring factions and fueling the war.

The agencies, drawn from both church and secular organisations, said they would provide only "targeted minimal life-saving interventions" in order not to unwillingly prolong the fighting.

They said their decision to limit emergency response, taken late May, would be communicated to the people of Liberia, the warlords, and to the wider international community including the US government, the European Union, the UN and its agencies, the West African peacekeeping force, ECOMOG and the governments of the Economic community of West African states (ECOWAS).

Meanwhile, a senior US official has accused troops from the West African peacekeeping force, ECOMOG, of being involved in the looting. The official said recently the troops "are heavily involved, and have been involved since the day they arrived, in ripping off Liberians."

"West African governments ought to police ECOMOG better," he is quoted as saying adding that Nigerian members of the peacekeeping force were particularly at fault.

The official's statement came after State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said recently that Liberian looting "has reached outrageous heights."

Burns said the United States was asking West African countries to cooperate in the inspection of ships in their ports which they have reason to believe are transporting stolen goods and to facilitate the return of looted property.

"Monrovia has been emptied," Burns told reporters, adding that the rival factions vying for control of the country were not the only culprits.

The State Department spokesman went on to say that three recent ships were responsible for looting "large quantities of goods" in Monrovia from the United Nations, NGOs and private businesses.

Burns further alleged that the Bulk Challenge, after receiving permission to disembark more than 1000 passengers in Ghana, departed for Nigeria with looted property still in its hold. The ship had spent 10 days at sea with the refugees.

On the Tubmanburg situation, witnesses are quoted saying the only hospital near the town, Guthrie Hospital, has been looted and forced to close down. Tubmanburg was also the scene of heavy fighting between ECOMOG troops and Ulimo-J fighters last December.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


406 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Uganda Judge Cautions Men Against Abuse of Wives' Rights


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Kampala - A supreme court judge has cautioned Ugandan men against interfering with the democratic rights of their wives or in any way discriminating against them for exercising their right to vote for candidates of individual choices.

"Husbands keep off your hands from your wives and let them enjoy and exercise their newly recognised freedoms," Supreme Court judge Justice Benjamin Odoki said.

Reacting to reports that a number of women had been battered throughout the country in the aftermath of the recently concluded presidential polls, the judge said it was a criminal offence for husbands to beat their wives for voting candidates of their choice.

Justice Odoki who was officiating at the launching of Guidebook on Domestic Violence early June said that wife battering, assault or any other form of discrimination against women was prohibited by Uganda's new Constitution. 

According to press and other reports, a number of women were beaten and invariably intimidated for supporting, actually voting for or celebrating the victory of a candidate their husbands did not favour.

In one incident, Jesca Kasiri of Nawandyo in Iganga district, Eastern Uganda, was allegedly beaten into a coma by her husband, Peter Kolwa, after she revealed to him she had voted for Museveni.

In Mukono district, a middle-aged Karim Lubega of Kikuba Nkima village, is suspected to have beaten his wife, Rose Namubiru, 40, to death.

In a different but related case, a bicycle mechanic in Arua town staked his wife against another man's Uganda Shillings 100,000 (US$1000) over the outcome of the presidential elections.

These developments prompted the Alert Group for the Uganda Women's Network (UWN) to petition President Museveni and the Chairman of the Interim Electoral Commission (IEC) to intervene and put a stop to the "intimidation and harassment of wives by their husbands" and to treat any such violence as "serious crime" and not "domestic dispute."

The group further asked the government and the IEC to tell all Ugandans that women's rights are human rights and to re-emphasize the fact that women have rights as citizens of Uganda.

The women also demanded reassurance that the Government will protect them and their property during and after elections. The group said that police should always be called in where there is intimidation, harassment and violence against women.

Said Justice Odoki: "Such acts are criminal, unconstitutional, degrading and unacceptable in a free and democratic society like ours. Women have equal democratic rights with men and do not have to consult their husbands on whom to vote for in a public election."

The Constitution also prohibits cultures or traditions which are against the dignity, welfare or interest of women or which undermine their status, Justice Odoki said, adding, "the battered women's syndrome could lead to despair and hopelessness."

He suggested that though emphasis has been traditionally placed on physical abuse, there was a need to pay more attention to the psychological consequences of domestic violence as one way of averting such despair and hopelessness.

The guidebook was written by the National Association of Women Judges (NAWJ) as a follow-up to a meeting of the International Association of Women Judges (JAWJ). Held in 1992 in San Diego, United States, the meeting among other highlights resolved to treat domestic violence as a major issue that requires investigation and public awareness in each individual member country.

The NAWJ was formed in 1994 and has since provided counselling services to spouses, both men and women, and helped in sensitising the general public on gender issues. Next August, the NAWJ will host a regional conference for Africa on domestic violence, marriage and property rights, Justice Mukasa Kikonyogo, a spokesperson of the association said.

It now remains to be seen whether men will heed Justice Odoki's caution during the forthcoming parliamentary elections for the 214 "normal constituency seats" scheduled for June 27. These will be followed by local authorities elections at a date yet to be announced.

In one of many attempts to address one aspect of gender imbalance, the new constitution provides for 39 additional elective district seats specifically for women - one for each of the country's 39 districts. These will be elected on June 20, six days ahead of the normal constituency polls.

There are 86 women candidates for the 39 district seats while a total of 26 women will contest in 24 of the 214 normal constituencies in straight fights with male contestants.

In her address, Justice Mukasa Kikonyogo thanked the Government for its continued policy to correct the gender imbalance in the Ugandan society, which she said was largely responsible for domestic violence.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June, 1996


Zambia Opposition Leaders Charged With Treason


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Lusaka - Eight members of former Zambian president Kenneth Kaunda's United National Independence Party (UNIP), including its vice president, were charged with treason on June 4 over a string of bombings, a charge which is punishable by death in Zambia.

They have been accused of forming a group calling itself Black Mamba, which has claimed responsibility for recent bomb attacks in the country.

The previously unknown group surfaced in response to a new constitutional amendment which effectively barred Kaunda from running for re-election later this year because his parents were not born in Zambia. 

UNIP vice president Inyambo Yeta, former Finance Minister Rabson Chongo and Kaunda aide Muhabi Lungu appeared with five others -- including three former army officers -- in the Lusaka magistrates court in connection with four counts of treason.

Kaunda defied a heavy police presence to address a crowd of about 700 UNIP supporters outside the court, accusing President Frederick Chiluba's Movement for Multi-Party Democracy (MMD) government of trying to create a state of emergency.

"We are dealing with little frightened criminals," the former president said, claiming that the government was trying to block an opposition rally scheduled for the weekend.

The eight men have been accused of involvement in a bomb blast which damaged a wall at State House two weeks ago, planting a bomb at the Intercontinental Hotel in Lusaka and the bombing of the government-owned Times of Zambia newspaper offices in the town of Ndola the previous week.

They were all arrested on June 2 and 3 and UNIP officials said they expected more of their members to be picked up in the next few days.

The eight UNIP members were not asked to plead and were remanded in custody until a High Court hearing, expected later this week.

Apart from threatening to plunge the country into an unprecedented political uncertainty, the controversial new constitutional amendment already signed into law by the Zambian parliament, has also been attracting unfavourable international attention.

On June 2, the United States also threatened to review its Zambian aid programmes following the controversial constitutional amendment, a US State Department communique released by the US embassy in the Zambian capital said.

"In the light of the government of Zambia's action, the United States is reviewing its bilateral relationship, including assistance programmes in Zambia," they said.

US aid includes some 20 million dollars for health matters and legislative reform.

President Frederick Chiluba recently signed into law the amendment which stipulates that presidential candidates' parents must have been born in Zambia, and effectively barred Kaunda from running in the elections later this year because his parents came from Malawi.

Kaunda, who heads the opposition UNIP, has vowed to break the law if he is not allowed to stand.

The US statement said that the United States deplored the constitutional amendment, which it said limits Zambians' right to choose their president freely.

It added that the amendment was a serious threat to the integrity and credibility of the electoral process and significantly undermined Zambia's democratic development.

The United States said it had repeatedly expressed concern over the amendments to the Zambian constitution, and called on Zambia to reverse the changes and take steps to ensure the elections were free and fair.

Finance Minister Ronald Penza, quoted by the state-owned Sunday Times of Zambia, criticised the US action, saying it would influence decisions by other donor nations, although he said US aid was insignificant.

It was unfair of the United States to dictate the pace of democratisation in Zambia, he added.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


408 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Angola President Sacks Cabinet to Rescue Ailing Economy


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Luanda - Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos sacked the government on June 3 in an effort to rescue the country's collapsing economy, and named the respected parliamentary speaker Fernando Van Dunem as the new prime minister.

Central Bank governor Antonio Gomes Furtado was also dismissed and Dos Santos suspended the currency exchange market, saying that all "strategic" banking operations now had to be authorised by the president alone.

"The system of production is paralysed and the social situation has worsened," Dos Santos said in a message to the nation that clearly blamed sacked Prime Minister Marcolino Moco.

"The health and education services have collapsed. It is time to change things and those who have made mistakes must assume the responsibility," Dos Santos said. 

Saying that formerly Marxist Angola must advance step by step to a market economy, the president set as targets the revival of production reduced to nothing -- apart from the oil industry -- by 20 years of civil war, the repair of basic infrastructure and reform of the banking system.

He also said there must be a single rate of exchange for the national currency, the kwanza, which is officially worth 55,000 to the US dollar but on the black market fetches 240,000.

In fact, the aims are hardly different from those set out in the Economic and Social Plan drawn up in April last year, which the Moco government had totally failed to implement.

Dos Santos pledged to introduce a realistic wage policy -- the minimum wage is about six US dollars a month -- as well as fight corruption, embezzlement and illegal immigration.

He also made a small but important gesture to Jonas Savimbi, leader of the formerly rebel Union for the Independence of Angola (UNITA) movement, by promising to put into effect an amnesty law approved last month.

Savimbi had demanded a solemn proclamation of the amnesty, pardoning those who had taken up arms again over the past five years following a peace accord which failed to hold.

The end of the civil war with the Lusaka accords of November 1994 has failed to improve the standard of living of Angola's citizens.

Luanda, with its three million inhabitants, is overpopulated and dilapidated, with open sewers, crumbling streets and virtually no electric power.

Crime is rife, often involving the police and the army, poverty absolute, and tension high in the shanty suburbs, where police pounce on any sign of revolt.

A German Catholic priest, Konrad Liebscher, was arrested last month for alleged offences against state security after calling on the government to raise wages, before being freed on June 3.

The secretary-general of the ruling People's Liberation Movement (MPLA), Lopo do Nascimento, warned in an interview with the Portuguese weekly Visao last week of a military coup if things did not improve.

The new premier, Van Dunem, 61, is a lawyer by training, becoming a career diplomat in 1973 with the Organization of African Unity (OAU), which he represented at the United Nations in Geneva from 1978-79.

Between 1979 and 1982 he was Angola's ambassador to Belgium, the Netherlands and the European Community before becoming ambassador to Portugal, the former colonial power.

In 1985 he was named Deputy Foreign minister, then Justice minister and Planning minister before becoming Speaker of Parliament.

Van Dunem has been given up to five days to form a new government.

Meanwhile, the UN Security Council on May 8 renewed the mandate of the UN force in Angola for two months, but warned that the lack of cooperation by UNITA rebels could bring about the "collapse" of the peace process.

In resolution 1055 adopted unanimously, the Security Council renewed the mandate of the UN Angola Verification Mission III (UNAVEM III) until July 11, but expressed "profound regret" at the slow pace of the peace process.

Since the disarmament operation began at the end of November under the peace accord, only 32,800 of the 63,000 UNITA troops have gone to the UN-supervised camps.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


409 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Arts Pan-African Children's Book Fair Closes in Nairobi


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Nairobi - The fifth pan-African Children's Book Fair (PACBF) which opened its doors to the public on May 28 at the Kenyatta International Conference Centre (KICC) here, ended on May 31, with most participants describing it as successful.

Addressing participants during PACBF's closing ceremony, Mrs Elizabeth Masiga, the Chief Inspector of (Kenyan) Schools, commended both local and external publishers for "the efforts you put in this exercise to make it a success."

Mrs Masiga went on to say that the event "is a significant development for our children as it will enhance and nurture the development of a reading habit among children at an early age." 

The four-day fair which attracted more than 1,000 participants, was organised by the Nairobi-based Council for the Promotion of Children's Science Publications in Africa (CHISCI), with assistance from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

A total of 19 countries, 12 of which came from Africa were represented at this year's fair. These among others include Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Malawi and Zimbabwe. Others were France, Germany, and Philippines.

The pan-African Children's Book Fair is said to be "the only full fledged regular book fair of international stature in the East and Central African region."

Various activities took place at the children's fair. One such event was UNESCO's launching of the Science for Africa Project (SAP). The launching of SAP, an activity of the Cultural Division of UNESCO, took the form of a one-and-a-half day seminar addressed by a number of experts from Japan, the Philippines, India and Colombia. The project is meant to encourage science writing of children's books by African authors.

Another highlight was a unique seminar duped "Libraries Alive", meant mainly for teachers, parents and librarians. Its purpose was to "develop strategies of making libraries attractive to children."

A number of papers and case studies were presented by experts who work in this field.

Also featured was a children's reading tent. The children's reading tent gave children an opportunity to see all the books exhibited from Africa and the rest of the world as well as a chance to read as many as they could. The reading tent was visibly a favourite among children's activities, especially because of the dramatized story telling which went on in the tent.

Addressing participants during the closing ceremony, Mrs Masiga noted that the most important African resource is the human resource of which children make about a half. She noted that "children are a rich reservoir of skills and talents which we must start tapping now by giving children the ability to understand the environment around them."

Other activities which took place during the fair include a read-to- the-children-competition, a children's environment debate and a fun-with-science workshop which ran throughout the fair to exemplify its theme: Learning Science at an Early Age.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


410 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1996


Rwanda First Two War Crime Suspects Charged


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Arusha, Tanzania - The first two Rwandans to appear before the UN tribunal trying suspects alleged to have carried out the 1994 ethnic genocide in Rwanda were formally charged here on May 30 and immediately pleaded not guilty to a total of 20 charges.

Former militia leader George Rutaganda, 37, and former municipal leader Jean-Paul Akayesu, 43, appeared before the court in this northern Tanzanian town before their trials were adjourned until September.

During the May 30 hearings, which lasted less than 45 minutes each, an assistant to the court clerk read out eight charges against Rutaganda and 12 against Akayesu.

Charges, read in French, included genocide, crimes against humanity and murder. 

Rutaganda, who arrived amid tight security and was escorted by two police officers at the preliminary court set up in a room in the International Conference Centre in Arusha, from time to time smiled tensely, but showed little emotion as the charges were read to him, only shaking his head as he was accused of ordering Hutu militia to "throw the Tutsis in the river."

A former businessman, Rutaganda was second vice-president of the national committee of the Interahamwe -- literally "youth section" - which later became the feared Hutu militia.

He is accused of distributing arms to Hutu militiamen who allegedly used them to massacre men, women and children sheltered in a school near the Rwandan capital, Kigali. Rutaganda is further accused of ordering them to kill Tutsis and of himself taking part in the killings in various places.

The Interahamwe, who were often armed with machetes, lances or cudgels, are accused of the worst atrocities during the 1994 genocide which left at least 500,000 dead among the Tutsis and moderate Hutus.

Court clerk Andronico Adede suggested the proper trial should begin in mid-August, but defence lawyer Luc de Temmerman told the court that would not give him sufficient time to prepare his defence, and asked for a visa for Rwanda, so that he can collect witness reports and "examine the scene."

Akayesu, who was mayor of Taba in the Gitarama district of central Rwanda, also appeared calm during the hearing and sat straight in his chair and took notes as he listened to the charges against him.

He is accused of having incited genocide and of participating in murders and interrogation sessions that ended in torture.

A third suspect Clement Kayishema, the former local government chief in Kibuye south-western Rwanda where the massacre of minority Tutsis and Hutu moderates was particularly ferocious and systematic,

also appeared before the tribunal on May 31.

The prosecution at the UN war crimes tribunal here said Clement Kayishema, a doctor by profession, had led a systematic campaign of genocide by allowing the massacre of people who had taken refuge in a church and sports stadium.

Kayishema, 42, was the government's top representative in the Kibuye region of south-west Rwanda. It had one of the highest percentages of minority Tutsis of any region in the country.

Kayishema did not appear troubled as the damning charges were read out to him, and grinned when the court clerk spoke of him firing the shot at the stadium.

Asked by Judge Laity Kama after each charge whether he pleaded guilty or not guilty, he repeated 25 times in a confident voice: "I plead not guilty, your honour."

There were 252,000 Tutsis in Kibuye before the 1994 civil war, but less than 8,000 afterwards, according to the human rights group, Africa Rights.

Another key Rwandan suspect, Colonel Theoneste Bagosara, who is accused of being one of the leading figures in the country's campaign of ethnic slaughter is expected to be moved soon from his Cameroon prison to await trial before the UN war crimes tribunal.

Colonel Bagosara would be transferred within two weeks to the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha, where the tribunal is being held, his Belgian lawyer Luc de Temmerman said.

At least another three Rwandans imprisoned in Cameroon, including Ferdinand Nahimana, one of the founders of the infamous Thousand Hills Radio, - Radio Milles Collines, would also be transferred with Colonel Bagosara to Arusha.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
