Africa News


June, 1996


South Africa New Anglican Archbishop To Succeed Retiring Desmond Tutu


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service June 10, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Cape Town - Rev. Njongonkulu Winston Ndungane, the Bishop of Kimberly and Kuruman in the Northern Cape, was elected late on June 4 as the new Archbishop of Cape Town to succeed retiring Archbishop Desmond Tutu.

Archbishop Tutu, 64, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984, retires as head of the Anglican Church in Southern Africa next September, although he plans to take his sabbatical leave from church duties from the end of June, only three months away from his 65th birthday.

He will continue to serve as chairman of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, the panel created to probe human rights abuses of South Africa's apartheid era. He is also President of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC). 

Tutu was one of the most vocal critics of the former National Party regime's policies of racial separation and was the first black man to head the church, before winning the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984.

Ndungane, 55 is the son of an Anglican priest who studied at King's College, London and served as assistant priest in several London parishes before returning to South Africa.

He became Bishop of Kimberley and Kuruman four-and-a-half years ago.

Before last week's elective assembly in Bishop's School in Rondebosch, Rev. Njongonkulu Ndungane and Bishop Duncan Buchanan had been proposed as the two candidates for the position of Archbishop of Cape Town and Head of the Province of Southern Africa. Bishop Buchanan is serving in Johannesburg, where Tutu also served as bishop before.

The church's elective assembly is made up of the three houses of bishops, clergy and laity.

Besides South Africa, the church province includes Lesotho, Namibia,and St. Helena, Niassa and Lebombo in Mozambique.

Earlier in the week on June 2, Archbishop Desmond Tutu gave a farewell communion service in a huge undercover sports arena here. Packed into the Good Hope Centre to say goodbye to the archbishop were 10,000 congregants, many of whom had been brought in with fleets of buses.

Two thousand choristers led the singing of hymns and psalms in English, Afrikaans and Xhosa, along with an organ, a group of instrumentalists and a marimba band, playing drums and the African xylophone.

When the centre reached its capacity, officials closed the doors, leaving several hundred would-be communicants pressing angrily against the glass outside. A number of unChristian remarks were passed, but eventually everyone was accommodated.

A group of dancers performed a "liturgical dance" to the tune "Africa is the place of the beating drum," and a lone ballerina in gypsy costume also danced "God Bless Africa."

Archbishop Tutu praised God for His sense of humour in making a small man with a flat nose archbishop, and giving him a name which lent itself to graffiti. He cited one example: "I was a Christian, until I put two and two together." And then mentioned a pop song, one line of which ran: "Don't mess with my tutu."

The archbishop also praised what he called God's sense of timing in allowing him to say farewell soon after South Africa became a fully democratic country.

"We were those who were against apartheid. We were in the 'against mode'. Now we have to show much more clearly what we are for. We must change from the 'against mode' into the 'for mode'," he said. "So clearly we need a fresh, a vigorous and certainly a much younger leadership. A leader with a new vision for our church, which has sometimes appeared to be directionless," the archbishop said.

What better time, he asked, to say: "Bye-bye Tutu"?

Tributes were paid to the archbishop and to his wife, Leah, by representatives of the province, by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Cape Town, Lawrence Henry, and presents were given by dioceses from around the province, including the sees of Namibia, Lesotho and Niassa and Lebombo in Mozambique.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


412 of 412 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 27, 1996


South Africa;
Report does anything but exonerate Cuban anaesthetist


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

PIETERSBURG - The recent exoneration of a Cuban anaesthetist in the death of four patients at Pieterburg Hospital by Northern Province health MEC Joe Phaahla flies in the face of an expert report he commissioned from the SA Society of Anaesthealologists (Sasa).

Extracts of the confidential report, leaked to Mail & Guardian this week expressed "alarm" at Dr L de la Parte's attitude to the deaths and found that his degree of competence was far below the level where he could work without constant expert supervision.

Phaahla claimed during television and press interviews that the Sasa report exonerated De La Parte and accused the media of "picking on the deaths and sensationalising them to discredit the whole Cuban volunteer programme".

He did, however, concede that the report was "critical of some aspects of the management in the cases" but refused to release the report for public debate. 

The department insisted this week that the report was being kept confidential to protect the families of the deceased - so confidential that relatives have not been told the report finds that any civil action by them would "probably be successful".

Provincial health department director general, Dr Nicholas Crisp, was even more blunt, saying that "we don't make a practice of telling people they can sue us. We definitely don't see that as our obligation at all".

Stressing that the portions of the report leaked to M&G dealing with the medical background of the patients were "severely paraphrased", Crisp confirmed that the section dealing with Sasa's peer review committee findings were accurate.

He also confirmed that the report slated De La Parte for both his treatment of the patients and subsequent insistence that the patients had died "because that were sick".

"We were alarmed at his attitude. We found him to be arrogant, especially while making comments such as 'I am not worried, (about the deaths) as they were sick enough' and 'the surgeons were not well qualified'," the report reads.

Pointing out that all alternative treatment suggestions were "fobbed off as being our British training whereas in Cuba things are done differently" the report advised that evidence indicated a Medical and Dental Council disciplinary hearing would probably find De La Parte guilty of misconduct in all four cases.

The report's four core recommendations expressly state that De La Parte cannot be permitted to continue practicing in South Africa without re-training and "complete supervision" at all times.

Acting on the recommendations, Dr Crisp declined to renew De La Parte's contract with the department and told the anaesthetist not to bother returning to South Africa from a holiday in Cuba.

Phaahla told the media that De La Parte had returned to Cuba because of the stress created by sensationalistic press coverage and a subsequent nervous breakdown.

The review panel also voiced their support for Wits University Medical School professor, Dave Morell's original recommendations to the Medical Council that all foreign anaethetists be attached to large training hospitals for initial "re-orientation" before being placed in rural areas.

Paatha's spokesman, Tshepo Moshima, consistently refused to give M&G access to the MEC on Wednesday to explain the discrepancies between his public comments and the report's findings but insisted that Phaatha stood by his previous public statements.

"Why would his views have changed? If you look carefully, there are actually no discrepancies between the statements and the report. The MEC is not available on this issue and I speak for him," said Moshima.

He did, however, concede that there were "things that we need to still clarify on some points".

Stressing that the department had commissioned the report to ascertain whether "the department is really taking care of lives", Moshima said that it had never been intended for public debate or for the families of the deceased.

"That is just not the nature of the report - it is not meant for the families. It is true that we haven't advised them that the report says any civil action would probably be successful but the document is confidential," he added.

"And in any case, we don't know whose duty it would have been to tell the families. Must administration or the MEC do this?"

Sasa president, Dr Leon du Preez, agreed that the report had been confidential to protect the families' identities but stressed on Wednesday that they had to be informed that they had grounds for civil action.

"The whole case is now being investigated by the police to determine whether there are grounds for an inquest, as recommended in our report, but is essential for the families to at least know that they could sue for damages," he said.

Both Du Preez and Crisp repeatedly stressed that the issue that De La Parte was Cuban had focused undue attention on the incident and that it was "unfortunately discrediting the very good work being done here by brilliant Cuban surgeons and doctors".

Confirming that there had been at least 12 anaesthestic deaths at Pietersburg Hospital during the same period as the four cases involving De La Parte, Crisp said that the department had instituted new strict monitoring procedures to review all future deaths immediately.

"If you saw the number of patients who are classified as dying 'anaesthetic deaths' in South Africa, you'd be surprised. It's masses of people but there are often other factors involved. We all recognise that this is not a well managed service but the new measures we have instituted and a new national study to determine exact figures and causes will give us a better handle on the situation," he explained.

The new protocol for anaesthetic deaths developed by MEDUNSA's department of forensic death and a proposed national pilot study by Sasa will, Crisp, insists improve the situation.

Police investigating the deaths of those at Pieterburg Hospital are still collecting affidavits for the Attorney General but feel that there is sufficient evidence to justify a full Inquest.

According to Crisp, a government to government agreement between Cuba and South Africa ensures that De La Parte will be brought back should he be required to "answer questions". It is unclear whether this would also apply for a civil case by the relatives of his alleged victims.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
